title: Fantastic
content: A cultural highlight of Shanghai, don’t miss this - a fabulous garden of many rooms with various pavilions and pools. Believe it was built in the 17th century so a great survivor of old Shanghai. There is also a temple behind and a good shopping district around in a traditional and vibrant setting of small shops.

title: Crowded but peaceful
content: Despite the crowds it was a really interesting place to visit and the history of the place can't help but shine through. There are plenty of little knocks where you can sit and escape the crowds.

title: Great garden
content: This is a 2000 year old garden that is kind of a maze. It is worth the small entrance fee charged. It is located in the middle of old Shanghai and you really don’t need a guide.

title: Tourist Magnet
content: This area was really busy at the weekend, but quieter early on a weekday. We made a return visit in order to look properly at the buildings. They are very authentic and you would think they were really old rather than relatively recent constructions.

user_loc: 英国泰晤士河畔金斯敦
title: Afternoon excursion.
content: This exquisite garden is a window on the past. The buildings are exquisite and there are various nooks and crannies throughout. It is a restful, peaceful place well worth a visit.

title: Crowded
content: We visited during Golden Week, and got to enjoy the crush of every time being on vacation along with the local tourists. Went for very pricy tea in a teashop above the garden. It was a nice break for all the hustle and bustle down below.

title: Breath taking and enchanting
content: This is one of the highlights of a two week tour of "important" sites we visited over a period of two weeks.

title: Nice but crowded
content: Interesting place to visit but very crowded. Nice to see but didn't spend a long time in the garden.

title: Fantastic at night with lights
content: Wonderfully lit up and beautiful place to visit and roam. It is crowded but I didn't mind the crowds since it was so visually stimulating.

title: Intresting Complex
content: The area is very interesting and there is a nice, short walk on the bridge across the small lake. BUT go early as it gets very crowded as the day goes on.

title: Very very busy
content: The area around the Yu Garden is beautiful and so full of people. There are so many shops especially for Shanghai local cuisines. Candy shops and Chinese handicrafts shop. I really liked the marker area around the Yu Garden more. The ticketed entrance was 40 yuan each and was not worth it.

title: Tourist
content: Nice to have a walk around. A respite from busy Shanghai. Great for photos. Spent about 30-40 minutes

title: A must see and experience while in Shanghai
content: Do not miss this Garden and Bazaar !!! So much fun. First the gardens and all the koi are amazing. There are views from every direction. Just wander about and you will be thrilled. Eveyone is taking photos of everyone. Then there is the Bazaar which surrounds the gardens. Everything you could ever want in items is here for you. Even explore the upper levels and there is even more for you to buy, buy, buy !!! Everything from Nike to ancient jade. Just keep exploring. Leave plenty of time for you to explore and have lunch or dinner.

title: Must see
content: Beautiful gardens and temple well worth visiting, amazingly crowded. We were with a tour guide who explained many details we would otherwise have missed.

title: An Unusual Attraction
content: A visit to the Yuyuan garden is a different experience. One has to meander through a few lanes with typical Chinese architecture buildings of a bygone era that is a busy and colourful market today, selling souvenirs, food, fashion. boutiques etc. until you come to a bridge that has a few left and right turns that take you to the entrance of this garden. The bridge itself is a fun place with lots of things in the water below: small isles with pretty plants, fish, ducks etc and people throng here to take pictures/selfies etc.

title: Delightfully Unexpected !
content: If you've got a couple of hours to spare in Shanghai, then a visit to this spectacular formal 16th century garden is a must. Yes, it's busy, but try to find a 'quiet' time (early morning) and enjoy the architectural styles which will take you back a couple of hundred years .... A real flavour of Old China.

title: Shanghai Yu Garden (Yuyuan) Is Very Beautiful But Crowded
content: The Yu Garden in Shanghai is simply beautiful with so much history to take in. I would recommend to go first thing in the morning as I would say this is when you would see it at its best (without the crowds - we found a lot of them are very pushy). It would be amazing to be able to take in the serenity of the gardens, pagodas etc and really enjoy the ambience - and get great photos without too many people in them! It is worth visiting, but go early to make the most of it.

title: The Gardens are great
content: Enjoyed the gardens very much and they themselves are worth a trip there. The rest of the area apparently was all recreated in an old town chinese style and is loaded with shops and restaurants. Very interesting to walk through and experience.

title: Nice but be prepared for the crowd!
content: Its an impressive « familly » house. Lovely gardens in the very middle of the City! Most living space similar to my none specialized eyes... but the crowds are taking away from the peace of mind one should enjoy in this place..

title: Not worth going
content: Supposedly a historical site with an ancient temple (closed at the early hour of 4.30 pm). In actual fact there’s nothing there except shops.

title: Crowded
content: Beautiful garden with antique items from Ming Dynasty. There are food stalls and souvenir shops outside. Overall, place is picture-worthy but overcrowded

title: Beautiful Chinese garden
content: It is actually 3 major attractions here: garden temple and market.

title: Beautiful, but crowded
content: I visited this garden thirty years ago when it was a much more impressive and pleasant experience. Now the garden is buried and hidden in a huge crowded bazaar / shopping area. There are no clear signs to the garden entrance, I had to ask several tourists. The approach to the garden has this lovely bridge, but it was black with noisy people. I enjoyed the stylish beautiful old garden, the buildings, rocks, carvings, views. Go, enjoy.

title: Only surviving Ming Dynasty Garden in Shanghai
content: Exquisite garden, decorated bridges, colorful pagodas and intimate enclaves separated by "dragon walls" — partitions with dragon decorations on top and the Jade Rock, said to have been one of Song Emperor Huizong's private collection. Crowded but well worth a visit.

title: Amazing history.
content: Yuyuan Gardens are amazing. The old culture and history is gives the garden a unique apparel. It's a peaceful escape from the crazy busy sights and sounds of the city. I read about it in a travel book and I listed it at the top of my list of things to do in Shanghai and it did not disappoint me.

title: Classic garden
content: But very crowded. Too many tourist shops inside. But some really good buildings and sights. Probably worthwhile going with a guide

title: Good place to visit
content: it's my favourite place for visiting. You can enjoy to see many things like clothes, toy, food, souvenir, etc. You can visit temple nearby. Don't miss to visit this place if you come to Shanghai.

title: Get clear directions before you set off
content: Had huge trouble finding this - met half a dozen people in the same situation (including a Chinese tourist). When we got to the entrance, I wasn’t sure why it was so difficult. I think we got caught up in the alleyways around beforehand. We went on a Sunday and it was very busy. Not sure it would be different on another day. It is beautiful and worth visiting. If you don’t get to Suzhou, I think this is an excellent alternative.

title: Beautiful a must to see
content: Very beautiful area. Very old traditional styled houses and tea house (tea house very expensive). Gets very busy around this area and to walk across the pathways that bridge over the water. Spend time feeding the koi carp, they are huge! Lovely shopping, maybe a little more expensive as its very touristy but lovely to spend some time. Try some bubble tea.

title: Too commercial
content: We were here about 12 years ago and now it is very commercial. So many vendors selling the same things. It was such a pretty place before.

title: To discover
content: Please do not limit yourself by staying on the first Street. Go further in the market as you will be able to see some of the greatest Chinese architecture.

title: Oasis in the city
content: Ver6 pleasant garden in the city where the sounds of the city don’t seem to penetrate. Lovely old gardens and buildings interspersed with ancient walls and moon gates.

title: Tasteless food
content: The food in foodcourt near gate 7 is tasteless and expensive. Floor is dirty and oily. Souvenirs has to be bargained carefully. It is a lot more higher that outside.

title: Yu Gardens A Calm Oasis
content: WE did this tour as part of a 14 day tour organised by Top China Travel.. Our guide in Shanghai was Leo. He took us to Yu Gardens and adjoining market as part of our Shanghai Tour. This area is really worth visiting and is close and convenient to other major tourism sites. He is energetic, passionate and we all quickly became friends. Our driver was Mr Wong who beyond expectations to ensure our travels were safe and enjoyable, including making sure we got to the airport in plenty of time for our flight

title: Another place Must see
content: Pleasant place in the middle of a modern and vibrant city. In gardens with breathtaking atmosphere to relax, gather new energy. The tour is about 1 hour if you do not hurry anywhere. Admission approximately 5 €.

title: Yu garden visit
content: Been there with my friends in winters in February.Nice place to have a look around with various food shops and shopping street around....Yu gardern is beautiful.

title: Must visit place in Shanghai
content: Classic Chinese garden with beautiful architecture. Unique zigzag bridge with lots of fish in the pond. Many craft shops and local restaurants. The famous soup dumpling was originally from one of the restaurants there. There is a very cute Chinese tea house located in the middle of the pond looks like a big gazebo. All rosewood Chinese style furniture, they have different types of tea selections; and even visited by Queen Elizabeth II in the 1980’s. This is a must visit in Shanghai.

title: An unending maze
content: This place is fun. Getting there can be tricky and rather crowded (there is a single doglegged bridge you need to cross), but once you are inside the crowds (relatively) thin out. The place is massive, beautiful and interesting. Without a lot of direction or signage, you basically stroll along, finding forks in the roads, taking them and trying to imagine what the other road would be like. There are bridges, tunnels, rooms, buildings, gardens, ponds (with Koi), deadends, rock sculptures, bonsai's and water jade. Basically an explosion of sights all strung together in a surprisingly cosy yet extensive location.

title: Lovely grounds
content: Wonderful visit.

title: Yu Garden is Stunning!
content: This is the major stop when in Hop in Hop off bus tour. It does not disappoint you in any manner. It is beautiful. Though its very crowdy but its really stunning. You will feel awesome here. Also, you can have a lot of shopping in old town area.

title: A must visit at night!
content: A must visit at night! It's a bit crowded but let's do it for the 'gram.

title: A nice oasis in the middle of Shanghai
content: We accidentally came across the gardens in a shopping area and rather that spend time in shops we spent the time in the gardens and thorough enjoyed the peace and serenity. It was a very nice break from the commercialism.

title: Stunning
content: Busy but peaceful if you know what I mean. Very old trees well laid out and historical. Go early. Access via old town so you can shop afterwards

title: Very nice garden - but can be a bit crowded
content: I visited here on a weekday afternoon and enjoyed the garden. It is quite large and the leaves were just beginning to turn when I was there. The garden is also near a large market, making it easy to do some shopping after you have seen the garden. The various ponds and buildings are all well-maintained. I would have preferred a visit when there were fewer people, but it is a major attraction, so perhaps arriving at the start of the day would be better.

title: Chinese Garden
content: Another must do when visiting Shanghai. Located in the mainland side of the Bund area. EASILY a few hours of good free excursion. Traditional Chinese culture and garden. Busy in afternoons. Food in area.

title: Magic
content: With the crowds outside and the queues, I anticipated a chaotic scene inside this favourite garden. But no, the garden just seems to absorb the crowds into its many tranquil rooms. A beautiful, contemplative place. Don’t be put off by the hustle and bustle outside.

title: Picturesque but crowded
content: Set in middle of shopping streets, provides a bit of an oasis. But it is crowded. Small lakes are stuffed with large fish. Some interesting plants

title: Beautiful garden and home
content: This is a great example of the home gardens . There are dragons in the architecture . This a fun way to spend an hour or 2. There is a fee to enter the gardens . I would recommend a tour guide to explain what you are looking at . There are coy ponds throughout the gardens . The terrain is a little rocky and can be slippery when wet . The contrast with the old and new was also visible here. There are examples of weapons and coins .

title: The Lantern Festival at Chinese New Year is a must!
content: If you're lucky enough to visit Shanghai during Chinese New Year, you must visit Yu Garden to see the Lantern Festival. it is a spectacular display, not just of lanterns, but giant lit dioramas laid out in succession as you follow a path through the ponds. It can get crazy crowded and you need to buy a ticket, but it's worth it. And while you're there, there's lots of shopping and food nearby. The soup dumplings that are served with a straw and the amazing Shanghai dumplings that are fried on the bottom and steamed on the top are a must! So delicious.

title: So beautiful!
content: In the heart of Shanghai, something you must see! Near to the bund, totally worth it. Great garden, and history.

title: Locelu
content: The area of Yuyuan gardens is easy to get to as it’s a stop on the metro. Actually getting in to the gardens was hard. When you walk out of the metro and get to the Main Street, you need to walk in to the centre of the shopping area. Once in there, follow the signposts. You’ll walk across some bridges over the water and past the famous tea house. Keep walking around the path and you’ll finally come to the ticket office. Then you can enter the actual gardens.

title: Great shopping entertainment and culture
content: Takes 3 visits to see it. The day visit for the narrow market streets and the zigzag bridge. The Visit to the actual ancient gardens - for peace and tranquility in the middle of downtown Shanghai. And finally the night visit - to see it lit up - spectacular!

title: Old vintage garden beautiful to see
content: Beautiful garden

title: Beautiful gardens dating from 1559
content: This is a classic tourist stop in the Shanghai Old Town, and we highly recommend to you. We’d suggest hire a guide to get the best overall experience and to learn the meanings of each feature - building, inscription, floor surface, etc.

title: Very crowded.
content: I came here a couple times and every time I visited the crowds never go away! I like to come here for the famous xiao long bao. There is an old tea house located right in the middle of the garden. It’s quite nice with the small olden tables and chairs.

title: Crowded tourist & historical building
content: Walking distance to & fro Metro. Crowded full of tourists, Old man / Lady chasing you to buy their fake merchandise such as handbag and watches...Freelance Tour guide (Maybe) question mark for me?? approaching & asking to try on their freelance tour services. Just don't bother, overall they wont harm you. DO take note, bring more cash with you, no money changer. You might need to search for bank and will need to pay an extra charge of RMB50 per transaction (This only applicable for certain bank (have no ideal why they have such rules). Overall i enjoyed the scenery, shopping for local products and can try to asked for bargaining good deal and The historical buildings are beautiful & Charm.

title: Nice visit
content: It's very beautiful with it's historical buildings.  Quite crowded with tourists though.  Still worth a visit.

title: Excellent place, must see
content: Enjoyed both the garden. Friends and family enjoyed the shopping (and bargaining too), we came back to shopping next day

title: Oh my God ! This district is a piece of art
content: This is a must see.

title: Very nice parc
content: Very nice location to spend some time and relax after the crowded inner city of shanghai. after 30 minutes there is not really something new to discover but the place is worth a visit

title: A must See in Shanghai
content: Wow! this place is really cool for an authentic slice of old Shanghai. We went on a Sunday and it is crazy busy, but well worth it. The gardens and buildings are spectacular. There is a small fee to enter - but just do it, you won't regret it.

title: Very interesting wholesale market and sightseeing spot!!!!
content: Yu Garden was built in the 15th century and is now a tourist sightseeing spot in Shanghai. There is an old garden as well as surrounding area with local craft works, jade/jewelries, souvenir shops, wholesale markets, local food and restaurants, etc.

title: Go with a tour guide
content: The garden is tucked behind Yuyuan bazaar. We went with a tour guide so didn’t have any trouble to find it. I suggest it’s better to go with a tour guide so that you can have insightful knowledge of its history rather than going there to take pictures only. Yu garden is very beautiful although the size is not very big compared to Lingering garden in Suzhou.

title: Nice for photo taking
content: Went there with two friends, a bit crowed inside quite a lot of tourists, nice for taking pictures of traditional chinese style buildings

title: Amazing gardens but very busy
content: The gardens here in Shanghai are lovely. They are huge and very well taken care of. This is why there is a small entrance free of around £4. The downside is it's very busy here so it is not a garden where you can sit and relax. As soon as you leave the garden their are a million tourist stalls all trying to sell you things which also annoying.

title: Busy Busy Busy
content: Go early or late - this place gets busy fast. But it was worth going it gives you an appreciation of Chiese art of garden scaping. It is extremely popular on the weekends

title: There are much better parks in China
content: We went here as part of a tour,and we was dissapointed ,the gardens are extremely busy with huge crowds of people.

title: Too Touristy
content: Decent garden and it is a nice slice of tranquility in an otherwise busy city. But the garden is a total tourist trap. Go instead to the former French Concession for free gardens with better food and smaller crowds.

title: Slice of tranquility
content: Beautiful gardens with historic buildings and picturesque ponds. A wonderful afternoon had wandering around these pretty gardens. Wonderful opportunity to take some nice photos of my children. They loved watching the giant koi.

title: We went during a Golden Week- DON'T go during a Golden Week
content: This place is probably very cool to experience, but not on a GOLDEN WEEK-- with a literal million other people. It's beautiful but just getting to the point of entry was crazy. Like a crush of humanity, no organization at the ticket counter- just push and prod your way to the counter.

title: Ancient garden
content: The garden has been around for a long time, over a few hundred years. Very splendid. The garden style is that of a private garden, meaning the garden owned by a family has this kind of style in the olden days. We were attracted to the many koi fishes and some terrapins in the pond, which surrounds the garden. If one observes closely there are many fine details in the architecture in the garden. Each window has a different design. The whole garden is

title: Night visit to yu garden and markets
content: We went to the yu garden and markets as part of our tourist experience. Lovely relaxed market but be prepared to bargain hard for any purchases. Treat this as a bit of fun and don't take any offence with some bargaining attitude. Lots to choose from for all your touristy purchases. The tea House is a lovely traditional building with surrounding pond full of large koi and ducks. Overall its a nice way to spend a few hours some evening, definitely recommend it. Excuse the poor pics...

title: Nice
content: Really good place , culture , nature , food and shopping near by , not expensive 40 yuans to go in !!!

title: Old China in new Shanghai
content: This felt like a hidden gem in the middle of the bustle of Shanghai. Although there is usually quite the queue to get into the gardens, this moves quickly and I was distracted by the beautiful surrounds as we approached the entrance. We spent a couple of hours exploring the gardens and the buildings that hold much history.

user_loc: 佛罗里达博尼塔斯普林斯
title: Brave The Crowds
content: A bit crowded, but an efficient way to see to see and experience life in a by-gone era--plenty of shops in the adjoining bazaar

title: Relax
content: Take the time to enjoy this space in the middle of Shanghai. Great place to just sit down and forget you are in such a bustling city.

title: Must see!
content: Yuyuan Gardens is a must-see spot in Shanghai. The garden itself can be quite crowded, so if you can do a week day excursion, you won’t be sorry. When it’s not crowded, it is a serene gem in the heart of the city. The surrounding buildings & markets are bustling- and although they are only replicas of ancient buildings, the atmosphere is undeniably charming. Be brave- the vendors can be quite assertive & personal space is non-existent- but you can find countless treasures & popular street food, if you are game to elbow in among the locals. If you are so fortunate to visit during Chinese New Year, the Lantern Festival is stunning!

title: Old School China
content: This is the old town of Shanghai. The structures are exactly what you would expect old structures in China to look like. There are some nice walkways, ticky tack shops, and tourist restaurants. It is worth a short visit, but be prepared for the crowds!

title: A beautiful must visit in Shanghai
content: Yuyuan (Yu Gardens) date back to the Ming Dynasty (16th Century). They city of Shanghai has grown up around it, but the 5 acre gardens are an oasis unto themselves, quite hidden away from the city right outside its walls. I visited during a national Chinese holiday week and while the garden was crowded with visitors, it still maintained a sense of serenity. Strolling the paths from buliding to building evoked a different time and place. I would definitely return.

title: Very nice garden
content: This garden is worth a visit when you are in Shanghai. The buildings are well preserved with nice furniture and the atmosphere is quiet and peaceful. Not as nice as the Suzhou gardens though.

title: A must see
content: Great architecture and history. Beautiful gardens and fish pools complete with very large koi carp. Despite being quite crowded, very relaxing place to visit. Also, it's free!!

title: Nosiy, Confusing
content: Location : Best to access by Metro. Green line station East Nanjing road (Line No 02). Get down here and catch Line no 10. Yu Garden is the next station. Take exit 3 and follow the crowd.

title: Magnificent Garden
content: This was our favourite sight on our trip to Shanghai partly as we didn't know what to expect. Nestled in Old Shanghai you have little clue from the outside just how fabulous each part of this garden is. Highly recommended!

title: Peaceful Garden
content: This is a lovely garden which is nice and peaceful. It is a joy to walk around and admire the gardens or just sit and enjoy the atmosphere.

title: Very Peaceful
content: This garden is well protected from the hurley burley around it by large walls. It is well laid out and very ornate. The crowds make it a bit of a challenge, but well worth a visit

title: Crowded
content: These gardens are in the old quarter of the city so just getting to them is a fun experience passing all the shops stalks and fast food outlets. The gardens are inexpensive and even cheaper if you are over 60 like me. The big problem is their popularity. There are loads of tour groups but also the tour group leaders will send their party in and wait for them to emerge. So the best time to see the gardens is either very early or late in the afternoon when all the tour groups have gone. As for the garden it is a maze of paths through buildings and rocks over bridges that span waterways. Its a Chinese garden so not many flowers and not a blade of grass. There are koi carp to feed and an exhibition of Chinese art. There is also a shop selling paintings but as soon as you enter you will be followed by a rep eager to sell you a painting.

title: Wonderful place
content: End of 2016 I stayed in Shangai and also visited Yu Garden. There was very historical buildings and good athmosfere. You can buy lots of things for a gift.

title: Busy
content: So busy...

title: Most beautiful garden
content: Wonderful garden in Shanghai; Very extensive with different areas; grottos, dragon sculptures, fish ponds, like a massive maze - go with a guide who knows the way !

title: Beautiful recitation of old China
content: While it’s obviously a recreation and a “tourist trap” with overpriced souvenirs it is also absolutely beautiful and a must see, you can see recreations of ancient architecture and taste local snacks. Don’t forget to finish the tour with a visit of the temple at the end of the street.

title: Nice old buildings
content: The buildings around are very antique and good place to take photos. There are several eateries and place to buy souvenirs.

title: Worth your time to visit
content: On a recent business trip to Shanghai we took a day to tour the city since it was the first time for most of us. We asked our concierge to pick an English tour operator and Cindy was great. They are a small private tour guide in a mini van and not sure the name of company but we stayed at the Hyatt on the Bund. Cindy only does private small groups. We let her tell us what we were seeing and we’re very happy with the tour. We felt Yu Gardens was the highlight because you were in the city but felt like you were transported to another time. The Gardens are over 450 years old and we’re made to look like they are 1000 years old. They did a great job. They added to it in recent years to look like the aged gardens were always there. The buildings and pagodas and landscaping were beautiful. I highly recommend this area for a visit and stop to visit the kiosks along the way to buy unique musical instruments or in the gardens they have some made of china and sell vases and other unique pottery and Jewlery. Don’t miss the tea house near by.

title: Very nice
content: The place is nice and quit, with some good relaxing corners. Recommended for relaxing and enjoying a nice garden.

title: Beautiful Garden
content: We visited as a family and found the self-guided tour delightful! Entrance was a bit frantic, perhaps because we visited during Golden Week and didn’t realize we still had to wait in the ticket line even though we had purchased tickets online. While we didn’t find it peaceful, we loved the architecture, water gardens and plants! Overall, a delightful way to spend the morning!

title: Peaceful and Restful
content: Our ladies loved the small garden because it was so peaceful in the middle of the Yuyuan Market. Old house and gardens serve a restful stop.

title: Beautiful place to visit
content: These gardens are not really gardens in the real sence of the word but are well worth a visit. The zig zag bridge is fantasic with all the carp in the ponds below. The buildings are in really old chinese stile and the history is very interesting especially the dragon wall.

title: Very nice place to visit
content: Definitely enjoyed these gardens. Very peaceful and relaxing. Wasn't very crowded when we got there Loved the busy shopping area around it.

title: beautiful
content: Very calm place with all the symbolism of china: rock and water, zig zag pathways. Not big but easy to lose yourself in its placidity. Watch out for dragons on top of the walls!

title: A bit meh if you ask me
content: I've heard great things about the garden, but unfortunately, I left feeling underwhelmed. One of the reasons was probably because it was rather crowded when I visited. There are touristy stores outside of the garden if you're looking to buy souvenirs.

title: A Hidden Surprise in modern Shanghai
content: A must visit to this few hundred years old building when in Shanghai. It is so well preserved and have so many beautiful gardens. Visitors are treated to the various unique collection of rocks and a fabulous dragon sculpture on top of the wall. Some of the old furnitures are still there (not sure if they're restored ones) but they give us a good glimpse of what's life like in those days. Outside, there are abundant old building structures (mostly tea houses) that represent olden times and they are so elegant. Shopping here is fantastic but you need to bargain hard.

title: Overrated, overcrowded tourist trap
content: Maybe we were spoilt after two weeks of exploring historic sights in this stunning country, but we couldn't wait to get away from this place. Crowded full of tourists, sellers chasing you and harassing you to buy their fake merchandise and overpriced tacky rubbish... Not for me! The buildings are beautiful and the central square with the fountains and zig zag bridge is well worth a look but other than that steer well clear. Not worth paying to get into the garden either, really overcrowded even on a weekday and pretty underwhelming compared to many other gardens in China. Once you've seen the first courtyard with fish ponds you've seen it all, just more and more of the same.

title: Worth visiting atleast once
content: Arrive there in the morning when the garden opens. Price is 40 yuan for one adult. I went at 9am to avoid the rush and even then there was quite a few tour groups. Not a problem if you want to get isolated shots since many of these tour groups move slowly and you can easily just start from the middle. The park covers a small area but because it can be complex, it is tight and can be confusing to navigate. However, it will take possibly more than 2 hours to see everything. I spent an hour and a half and I was going through the garden at a fast pace. Definitely worth a visit.

title: Lovely Gardens
content: If you are in Shanghai, you definitely want to allow time to visit Yu Garden. We went during school holidays so it was very busy, but if you can, try for a quieter time. It takes a few hours to go through the whole complex as there quite a few little trails off the main track and it is worthwhile exploring them. Make sure you have your walking shoes on. There are many beautiful places to stop for rest if you want to. Do take a bottle of water with you, but if not there is a tea house in the middle of the gardens. Once you exit the main gardens but still inside the main complex there are quite a few gift shops that are also worthwhile exploring. I purchased 2 paintings by a very gifted artist, painted entirely using the hand (no brush). After exiting into the street, there are many shops offering clothing and souvenirs but we elected to go into one of the first shops on our right and upstairs into the most quaint and peaceful little tea house, where the lady working there educated us on all things tea and made us the most delightful iced tea, using dragon tea and osmanthus tea. Very restful after a crowded place and refreshing in the hot weather. Definitely a worthwhile visit!

title: Nice architecture and relaxed environment.
content: A pleasant way to spend an hour or two. Pick your time to go as it was busy when we were there. lots of secret pathways through rock formations.

title: Hard to find
content: We took ages looking for the gardens and the queues to get in once we found it were so long. Nice gardens though but not botanical. Little areas of pretty ponds and serene spots, worth a visit though.

title: Peace in metropolis city
content: The Yu garden provides tranquility in a busy city.  The architecture was interesting with plenty of examples of feng-shui incorporated.

title: Very business
content: A nice place but madly busy, worth a visit though. A little tip if you want to have tea is ignore the famous tea room on the bridge as you can go into one through a shop just outside the paid entry bit and sit on the balcony there and take tea whilst watching the world go by and it’s surprisingly quiet after the crowds. Look for a neon sign saying beer and tea at the back of a shop with a balcony.

title: Great shopping and historical landmark
content: I come to Yu Garden every time I visit Shanghai. This is my 6th visit. There are beautiful gardens. Seniors get half price. The surrounding streets are teeming with great shopping, everything from fine jewelry, to contemporary Chinese dresses, and traditional Chinese attire. Lots of great restaurants. We enjoyed Starbucks and dumplings for lunch!

title: Really enjoyable garden
content: Went first thing in the morning before it got too crowded. Really gorgeous architecture, beautiful ponds, great to learn about all the different nooks and crannies. Surrounding market sweet to explore as well (although all recreated).

title: Gain an understanding of Chines Landscape Gardens
content: Somehat disappointing in comparison the Japanese and some European gardens. Had an unkempt appearance. Useful to learn that Chinese gardens are made up of water;stone;plants and pagodas. It would have been wonderful for the original owner, in times gone by, to sit is his study admiring the peaceful view

title: Delightful Garden
content: It must be said, that this is much more than just 'a garden'. Yes, there are trees and flowers but the buildings and water features etc. add an awful lot more to the experience of your visit.

title: Best picture opportunity in town
content: It's a small garden but it is truly wonderful especially for photo Ops and then you have some really meet shopping close cry not the typical trinkits but actually more artistic stuff is also available in dusk had crowded in the afternoon so an early on morning visit or late evening would be best.

title: Go Early
content: This is a lovely place to visit just off The Bund thoroughly recommend a visit but enjoy it before the crowds get to big. Then explore the shopping area that offers everything you can imagine and more. Very much old and new China.

title: Go first thing in the morning
content: I went several times on a recent visit and it is a much more pleasant experience early in the morning, prior to the arrival of the tour groups. Try to get there right when it opens.

title: A Nice Little Garden
content: My advice is to engage a guide to show you around all the little areas and rooms in the garden. A good collection of food stalls and food courts surrounding the garden. Try the steamed Shanghai buns.

title: CROWDED but well worth exploring...once you can find it!
content: We had some trouble finding the gardens as we walked in from an unusual direction. Eventually a local businessman took pity on us & escorted us there and, once at the tourist entrance, we joined the queues and snaked our way in.

title: Great walk
content: It is a must visit if you are in Shanghai for the first time. The only setback is the over rated dumplings, long queue but the taste is just so so

title: Go early
content: Beautiful and worth it, but after 10 am it is very busy. Lots of places to sit and admire the gardens and buildings.

title: Really pretty, if you go to Shanghai you have to go
content: Beautiful temple, I went with a tour guide that gave us a tour around the city, but would recommend pay for a guide there or go with one. The tour guide told us a lot of interesting things.

title: The perfect place to shoot marvellous pictures.
content: Visiting the gorgeous YU Garden not only brings you to the Chines past but also gives you the opportunity to live like Chines people used to live centuries ago.

title: Beautiful garden in the city center
content: After crossing the zigzag bridge over a pond with countless koi you reach the entrance to the garden. Here you pay the entrance fee and then can wander through the many paths and check out the different houses. Very peaceful.

title: Unexpectedly serene despite crowds
content: This place gets super crowded but oddly you can find pockets of emptiness and solitude to relax in. Beautiful garden with lots of spots for great photos. Overall I’d say a must when in Shanghai. The shops around are also quite fun to explore.

title: Tourist Trap!
content: This place is a tourist trap. Do not eat in the food hall because you will get ill. The food has been prepared earlier and just left out on the counter. Prices are different for western travellers and Asian travellers. It’s is one part of Shanghai that had kept the old buildings so lovely to walk through but the prices are so expensive and it is the same quality you would get in the non-tourist markets.

title: Well worth the visit beautiful gardens
content: Really enjoyed walking around this beautiful garden and old building which was once owned by the Pan family. Very relaxing with a waterway throughout the grounds. very peaceful area. Highly recomended.

user_loc: 斯洛文尼亚卢布尔雅那
title: Cute contrast to the surrounding city
content: quite a big park with lakes, traditional houses, trees... perfect escape on a hot day like in our case. relaxing, refreshing, beautiful.

title: lovely garden for a wander
content: it was really nice to get away from the heat for a bit and find some shade. the gardens are small but very pretty

title: ENJOY BEING A BIT LOST
content: A little bit tricky to find but the effort is worth it. Its a maze of everything, temples, gardens, lakes, bridges, very large what appeared liked giant goldfish, shops, shops and more shops, laneways, food. You can spend many hours strolling around and around and then find a side street which will lead you off somewhere else. We went there about four times, a good shopping area for those gifts to take home, but don't forget to hassle/bargain even when they have signs saying no bargaining you still might win.

title: A must see
content: On the 3rd attempt I was able to enter the garden! Yeehaw:) Expect a crowd of mostly Chinese and some foreign tourists. 1st attempt during Spring festival when I stayed in Shanghai and, I faced very long waiting lines to enter the garden so I turned around. 2nd attempt lantern festival on the last day of Spring festival, at this time, the garden was closed at 5pm, I ended up wandering around in the alleys and shops. Lantern festival is also a must see, AMAZING!

title: Beautiful, authentic and FREE
content: A must when visiting Shanghai. It’s nice to leave the modern city (though beautiful itself) and go to this hidden gem.

title: Amazing garden
content: By all means visit this garden. Is just breathtaking. You can walk around and enjoy it with your own pace. Definitely a must in your visit in Shanghai. The tickets are sold at the entrance and they accept only cash like almost everywhere in china.

title: Crowded but an amazing introduction to Shanghai
content: My first day in China and my hosts took me here. I was caught up in the scale of the city, the gardens, the juxtaposition between the old and the new, the smells, food and of course the sheer overwhelming amount of people squashed into the Gardens and the surrounding markets and temples. It's a great experience. Leave your claustrophobia and discomfort of crowds at home, and just enjoy the experience.

title: Worth a trip for sure
content: This is a really nice part of town. Wonderful buildings, lots to see (and eat!) and plenty of places trying to sell you things. A great atmosphere to soak up and take in the sights.

title: Must Visit
content: Yu garden is one of the must-visits when in Shanghai. You can easily spend half a day here exploring the garden, soaking the atmosphere over tea at one of the tea houses as well as enjoy the knick-knack shopping at the bazaar. The garden is extremely packed with both tourists and locals with loads of tour groups covering this in their itineraries. Probably better to visit on a weekday although I would still expect some crowd given its popularity.

title: Go early
content: We turned up at 8:30am on Saturday and had a lovely walk around with two small children before the crowds began to build. And they do build! Worth a visit.

title: Beautiful layout and traditional buildings.
content: This is a very crowded and popular venue surrounded by a lively market that has a lot of food and shopping options, however it was a bit commercial (the surrounding areas). The gardein itself is extremely interesting and fun to walk around. Great people watching opportunity.

title: Classic Chinese garden
content: If you need to fit in one classic Chinese garden or your tour of China this should be it. Beautifully built. Having a guide this you will help you appreciate it more.

title: Visit this famous Chinese garden
content: My very first Chinese garden did not disappoint! I did not have nearly enough time on my tour (2 hours) to wander through this ancient garden, with its numerous large temples, pathways and waterways. I tried many times to savour the moment of being at the Yu Garden, eg sitting in one of the little pagodas and closing my eyes to focus on the sounds of the cicadas and feel the extremely happy family orientated location. There was a real sense of joy at this garden. Lots of tourist buses, but also lots of locals enjoying these famous gardens. I plan to revisit one day and spend a whole day here!

title: Take you camera with you :-)
content: Whilst it’s very very busy I don’t think you can afford to miss this if you visit Shanghai. It’s full of old Chinese building some in need of TLC but nevertheless picturesque. We really enjoyed a few hours there even though the commercial side seemed to be taking over the culture side. Way too many shops selling low quality tourist ‘stuff’.... I hope they try the get back to a good balance in the future.

title: Suprisingly nice place
content: Unfortunately, we went there during the National holiday so it was a little crowded but we went in among the first so that was good. So, be sure to check Chinese holiday calendar before planning a trip.

title: Beautiful Chinese Garden and adjacent Bazaar
content: We went to visit this garden with a tour group. We went through the Bazaar first but did the shopping after the garden visit. The garden dates from Ming-dynasty. There are rockeries, ponds, Dragon wall, and several scenic areas, but full of tourists. The garden has one of the largest rockeries resembling peaks, caves, gorges of other parts of China. The shopping and corresponding haggling over prices in the adjacent market is always challenging but interesting. I tried crab soup dumpling off the street and enjoyed the coffee at the Starbucks!

title: Super Fun, if you dig Pagodas.
content: This is a delightful way to spend an afternoon. The architecture is beautiful. And if you don't mind dodging a million goofballs and their selfie sticks, you can feel right at home.

title: Is a Maze...
content: While it is not cheap, it is worth a visit. The place is well kept. If it has has good signboards which can guide you through the garden will be even better.

title: Too commercialized
content: The garden itself is nice but the area was too commercialized. Have many restaurants and shops. Abit too touristy but the building of the shops are really pretty.

title: Nice walk
content: Yu garden is a nice place to visit. It is pretty much packed with tourist but it does offers a nice old chinese architect. At night the building light up. There a lot of vendors selling different products. There also a lot of food vendors. It's a nice place to go for a walk.

title: beautiful and peaceful
content: good place to go

title: Beautiful Garden
content: The Yu Garden is an incredible experience in Shanghai. Is a MUST visit if you think to come to Shanghai.

title: A tranquil place in a busy bazaar
content: These gardens can be found at one end of the Yuyuan bazaar. Although the bazaar is extremely busy with locals and overseas tourists this is a small tranquil (but still busy) area. A nice place to wander through and enjoy the trees, flowers, ponds, sculptures and rockeries. Just inside the gate is a large rock called the Great Rockery where you can go to the top and see the entire gardens from there. Admire the old traditional buildings as you wander through the gardens. When you're finished in the gardens spend some time wandering around the bazaar.

title: Pretty Garden
content: This is a 400 year old garden built by a wealthy gentleman for his elderly parents to enjoy. It is peaceful and pretty. It is extensive with a great rockery, coy pond, bridges and the Exquisite Jade Rock.”

title: You need a guide
content: Lovely gardens and buildings. Very busy but still plenty of opportunity for photos. The whole experience was greatly enhanced by having a guide with us who pointed out various symbols and details we would otherwise have missed. Well worth a visit.

title: The gardens are nice and well kept but boring after some time
content: The gardens are nice and well kept but get a little boring after as while. Would be better to take a professional guide with you during the visit so that he can explain the history behind the gardens and culturural significance of the various designs and the dragons etc to you. Dont try the gift shops as i think these are hugely overpriced.

title: Very Good
content: Visiting Shanghai, Yu Garden is a must go. Nice to see some old buildings in new Shanghai and sense a little more of Chinese tradition.

title: Odyssey Tour
content: Preserved gardens in center of Shanghai. Features pavilions ponds with fish bridges and rock structures with pine trees

title: Business
content: Not worth the trip there

title: A very tranquil and worthwhile experience
content: A must go too place if you taking in Shanghai on a tourist trip.

title: Relaxing
content: Beautifully reconstructed traditional Chinese garden. Nice way to escape the hassle of the city. Also great place for good quality souvenirs.

title: Tough to find but lovely garden
content: We had a hard time finding the garden. However, once we got there and battled the crowds, we had a fun time. It’s really beautiful and we got some great pictures.

title: Beautiful Yu Garden
content: The Yu Gardens are a must see in Shanghai. They seem to go on forever and are an oasis of calm in a busy city. Go first thing in the morning to avoid crowds and then spend time after visiting Old Shanghai and enjoying some dumplings. There is a great souvenir shop in the gardens with an artist making beautiful finger paintings. We bought 2!!

title: Very nice to visit and stroll through the old town afterwards
content: Yu garden is worth your while. See authentic buildings with todays’ food places. The gardens are beautiful and well preserved. I believe a must see when in Shanghai. I suggest after finishing to take a walking tour through the old town before it will be demolished. We had a great time just wandering the small streets going from Yu garden to the insect market.

title: Amazing garden
content: This garden is spectacular. Worth a visit even if your not a gardener. Beauty & history combine to create something unique

title: Crowded but brautiful
content: One of another must see places in Shanghai - from the outside and also inside, lots of stores and little streets hided in the temple area. Can be that there are other beautiful and less touristy spots like this one..

title: Very pretty to walk around
content: The surrounding streets have lots of shops and restaurants, all Chinese style buildings and great for pictures.

title: Make sure you visit the Emperors garden
content: This place is fanastic, and somewhat overcrowded. But once you get used to that, and then find the serene Emperors garden you can just take a step back and enjoy the traditional Chinese culture and architecture.

title: Beautiful garden ...worth surviving the crowds
content: Exceptional Chinese gardens in the heart of the old Chinese city, with a reconstructed  quite scenic city market all around. Well worth a visit. Go early for avoiding massive crowds!.

title: Visit to Yu Garden
content: An interesting area with old Chinese architecture, shops and street market with a variety of stalls and food.

user_loc: 新西兰奥克兰中心地区
title: Beautiful Retreat
content: Winding our way through these gorgeous gardens was tranquil and energising. The beautiful buildings and gardens were cool on a hot day. The history and stories on each of the buildings was fascinating. This would be a place I would return to.

user_loc: 新西兰奥克兰中心地区
title: Great Place to Eat Wander and Shop
content: The garden takes you back to the Old Shanghai. With good array of food, shops and stalls you'll have you hand full with activities and maybe bags of goods.

title: Where History and Tourism collide
content: Amazing place. Shops and shops and people. And in the middle of it all a amazing historical hidden garden and temple. Should be a stop if you have some time.

title: A Taste of History Close to The Bund
content: This is a cute area, full of shops, restaurants, cafes, plus there is a lovely Temple, Gardens and Historic Teahouse within the area. The shops were not particularly cheap but there did seem to be some good quality items for sale. It was busy, even on a weekday but it is also very close to the downtown area and close to the subway station of the same name.

title: Very pretty
content: As a national living treasure this is a must see in Shanghai. It was really beautiful. It needed more information/signs on how old the trees and buildings were and more information on the buildings.

title: Beautiful
content: We walked here through the alleyways which is awesome , worth going to for sure . Great shopping around here too for gifts

title: Love the sheer brilliance of it
content: So so beautiful. Despite the inflow of tourists, it is worth to go inside and just be lost in the beauty of ancient trees, jade stones, and its design

title: Beautiful
content: Lovely gardens in the Old City right across from the Huxinting Tea House. Lots to explore inside the gardens and it is in a nice location to wander around after. Very picturesque if a bit on the crowded side.

title: Crowded, but worth one visit
content: Fully packed of local tourists, you can see many international travellers here. The garden is beautiful, fully of culture and history, and worth a visit. Be patient and all will be fine. Local eateries and teahouses around. And Starbucks too...

title: Aesthetically Pleasing
content: The garden is from recent Chinese history and reflects the taste and the sentiments of the last era of the last dynasty of China. Other than the typical features of Chinese architecture, the figures on rooftops were impressive. Getting into the garden was a challenge because of the people who like to walk on the bridge to look at the pond.

title: very beautiful
content: very beautiful if u into chinese culture you can get lost o e you jn there it is like a maze and getting out is difficult

title: Wives and concubines
content: The Yu Garden is one of the (rare) wonders of Shanghai. There is a mandarin house from the imperial era with its small courtyards for the bride, the children, the master and guests, theaters for the afternoons and its nature domesticated to the architecture of the place. Even though there are often many people, you have to see this place for a fascinating dive into ancient China

title: Must see garden
content: It's a must visit garden don't miss it, simply nice beautiful and magical, I have visited this garden twice during my trip to Shanghai although it was short trip but couldn't resist to see this garden again,

title: Busy but nice
content:
Came on a Thursday and accidents got sandwiches between 2 your groups. Still a nice visit but crowded, just like everywhere else.

When you get off the metro, walk down the major street until you get to the market. The garden is located inside.

title: Shanghai mustsee
content:
Beautiful and crowded place.  Worth to spend 30 minutes,  max one hour. 
Extremely commercial neighbourhood.

title: View of old China
content: These are simply beautiful gardens and buildings. I recommend a tour guide to help you appreciate what you view. The surrounding area is perfect for souvenir shopping but beware aggressive “helpers” who might try to get you to follow them. One of our favorite stops in Shanghai. Highly recommended.

title: Worth the visit
content: This place is worth a visit if you really want to feel the ancient Chinese architecture work in gardens. A bit busy on weekends so its best to get there in the morning which we did, so you can take picture all you want and avoid unwanted photo-bombers. This place gets too crowded before lunch and afterwards. i enjoy souvenir shopping and walking around..but be ready with your MAP and skills in directions when you get lost its hard to ask around because not all people speaks in english .

title: Yu garden great but not in weekends
content: Yu Garden is beatiful, quiet spot in the busy enviroment of Shanghai but in weekends very crowded. The beautiful trees and ponds is quite an atmosphere in the buzzing city of Shanghai

title: Pretty bit busy
content: The gardens are worth visiting but difficult to find. On the day we visited, it was very busy and quite crowded. We took lots of pictures but I know that it is not as picturesque as the Summer Palace in Beijing. If I had not visited the Summer Palace, I think I would have enjoyed it more.

title: Well worth a visit
content: During our city tour of Shanghai we were taken to the Yu Garden. It was very enjoyable, took lots a photographs.

title: Wow
content: Very nice area for shopping, lots of nice things, no real antiques though. Very busy in evenings and weekends.

title: Awesome.  Brave the crowds and go for it.  30 yuan each.
content:
Yes it was busy - but less busy than outside. Staff friendly; other visitors friendly. Go for it!!  Mind your head if going through low ceilinged passages
.

title: Beautiful gardens
content: This is a must stop if you are in Shanghai. The gardens are on 3 acres with several rock formations.

title: Simply amazing travel activity
content: We love the garden, we noted the historical values. Has to paid rmb 40 tp enter the garden, but it is worthed. Got discount for senior by presenting identity card or passport. During rainy season, it is advisable to bring umbrella, the place is not really near to metro station and taxi ia not that easy to get in China for traveller. The garden is very clean and well maintained despite of its age, it has been there for thousands year

title: Lovely spot in central Shanghai
content: Having located the entrance through the winding lanes of the surrounding market, we visited the Gardens on a hot August day in the summer holidays. There were quite a few people around but it still didn’t feel overcrowded, so we were really able to appreciate the beautiful layout and tranquil moments this space offers in the middle of a bustling city. Would definitely recommend it as a little taste of history and contrast to the more recent history of Shanghai offered at the nearby Bund.

title: Tranquil
content: Although quite busy this garden is very tranquil and worth the visit. The day was hot but as long as you had a bottle of water with you it was fine. Can take some lovely photos there.

title: Yu garden walk
content: Pretty man made garden in the old town area. Great to walk around. You can take kids but keep and eye out as there are slippery areas near the water. Nice atmosphere but gets busy.

title: Beautiful Garden
content: Somewhat of an Oasis amongst the hustle and bustle of the City. Some interesting history and worth a visit to take a breath.

title: A diamond surrounded by coal
content: The gardens are very nice. I would say a must see. An oasis of silence and calm in the caotic city. Walking distance from the Bund. However not very easy to find. The area is a tourist trap not worth to visit. A lot of shops of souvenirs. And a lot of people trying to get you into fake bags and fake garment shops.

title: shopping market - don'[t bother
content: Wouldn't go back, it was getting renovated, the crowds and heat were horrid, it is just a market with shops which are over priced. grotty place .

title: An Oasis in Shanghai
content: When you start to be really missing nature and calm, please go visit the Yu Garden.

title: Early Morning Visit
content: Visited early on a Sunday morning before the crowds formed, was really hard to find in the old town though as it is a maze of old buildings and alley ways. Cheap entrance and good to get an idea of classical China architecture. Very nice gardens and waterfalls some big fountains and pools was nice to take a few photos. Looked to be getting very busy as I came out of the garden so would recommend going early.

title: Yu garden
content: We visited the yu garden with a traditional Chinese student. She told us the yu garden would be nice, but touristic. And she was all right. It is a good place to visit, there are a lot of shops to buy souvenirs. But there are so many tourists. The garden was beautiful as well. If you do not like touristic and crowded places I recommend to not visit this place.

title: Nice but very crowded
content: Very touristic and busy but still very beautiful garden with nice small wooden/stone buildings. Entrance was only 30rmb. I walked around for 45min to see the complete garden. It was a bit difficult to find the entrance at first.

title: Gorgeous Garden
content: The Yu garden is located near the Bund and if you have spare time, you must go visit this place. It is quite beautiful and historic and a nice place to relax and spend a nice morning/evening.

title: A Must-do in Shanghai
content: Though certainly a crowded and popular destination, the gardens of Yu Yuan are a feast for the eyes. It’s a terrific initial exposure for those unfamiliar with a Chinese garden, with its elegant structures, hidden bat and dragon features, and huge rockery. There is less emphasis placed on flora with, rather, more emphasis placed on flow, water, and the harmony of elements. This site is reminiscent of the spectacular gardens of Suzhou. You will be amazed by how much is squeezed into such a small area (as seen from a map of the bazaar district). The paths enable the visitor to walk through a maze of elegant pleasures. Eye candy abounds.

title: nice garden, quite crowded though
content: The central pool with the tea house is really very nice. Be aware of the crowds of tourists. There are many souvenir shops. The good part is that you find nearly everything around, the other part is that the place is crowded with tourists and shoppers. Entry to the garden requieres a ticket, large queues if you want one. the rest is free.

title: Night Scene
content: Interesting shops in this giant shopping compound with a few familiar brands such as Starbucks and Dairy Queen. Very commercialized for tourists. The place gets busier later in the day so plan to visit early if you want to avoid crowds. A number of food and beverage places serving traditional food is always packed with long lines of hungry tourist waiting for their share of soup dumplings. Visited at night to get a different view and it was worth the second trip. I find the night view much more interesting with the buildings lighted up. The place closes at 10pm and it’s advisable to leave before they close. Taxis prawling the area will want a high premium for a ride.

title: Peaceful
content: If you go in summer go very early to beat the crowds. Very peaceful place in the middle of a bustling city. Amazing when you think how old it is and that it was one man’s private garden.

title: Peaceful, Pleasant Garden with a lot of History and beautiful architecture.
content: Very Peaceful and Pleasant and quite a bit bigger that I expected. Cool breezes, amazing architecture, and well worth the visit!

title: Get the experience
content: Great place to see a bit of China and the way the Chinese people live. Super crowded but worth the shot. Lots of food, shops, stores and street vender. Sure you'll find what you're looking for.

title: Typical Shanghai!
content: Only here you can see how Shanghai was. Houses, canals and the best tea you can taste. Crowdy, but worth seeing!

user_loc: 菲律宾马尼拉大都会区
title: Must See in Shanghai
content: You Garden is a very big garden with old China architecture. There are nice shops and street food. The place is very clean and worth the visit.

title: Nice garden in the center of Shanghai
content: It is in a central location and 5-10 minutes from the subway station. We like the garden, especially architecture. After visiting the garden, we spent a few hours on nearby streets (popular for tourists).

title: Really crowded! But, worth a couple of hours, if you can choose a quiet time to go!
content: We were really unlucky with this beautiful place! It is really magical, and I should perhaps have rated it higher, BUT.... we went on a public holiday and it was awfully crowded. I feel it was the only time I felt frightened of the crowds in China. Frightened that I would get separated from my group, and frightened that I might get trampled if I slipped and fell. The crowds were unbelievable. Which is a pity, because this is a really nice place (occasionally I did get a chance to look around, and what I saw was really good!). Dangerous to go here on a crowded day with a stroller, and very dangerous to come here with little kids, they could very easily get lost. Check before coming what the crowds are likely to be!

title: A must-see in Shanghai
content: Go with a tour guide - there are so many stories they will tell you about this place and it's rich history.

title: Mystical & historic
content: Yu Garden was believed to be built 400 years ago during the Ming Dynasty but it was destroyed by wars and restored in the 1960s and was opened to the public. Some called it the “Garden of Happiness” . There were several koi ponds and rock formations. There are several openings ( like doors ) in interesting shapes. There are several preserved old structures too from the past dynasties. The place is quite not safe for elders and very young because of the rocky pathways that can be slippery when wet and dangerous. When we went there , the place was full of people and very hot because it was summertime. Outside , we are glad to see starbucks & Dairy Queen and you can also buy souvenirs from the small shops just outside the Yu Garden.

title: Nice
content: Nice to be here in old town. Very crouded outside but once in you feel in an oasis of peacefullness.

title: Nice garden, over rated
content: What was once probably a quiet and peaceful garden is now a sad tourist trap. There are blocks of cheap shops completely surrounding the actual garden.

title: Crowded and unpleasant.
content: Crowded and overrated garden. In fact it's the house of a rich man with varoius parlours, corridors and lakes. Should be quiet and pleasant and it's not beacause there are too much local people. The ticket costs 30  RMB.

title: Yuyuan is a must-see!
content: I love going to Yuyuan Garden! Living in Shanghai, I recommend going early in the morning--first thing when it opens because once the crowds set in, it's hard to get around.

title: awesome to see
content: this was one of the 10 things we had on our list to see in shanghai on our trip to china. definitely a good place to get a feel for what the city was like in ancient times. The buildings were super cool, the only complaint was how crowded it was when we were there.

title: MUST visit place
content: Definetly a MUST visit when coming first time to Shanghai.

user_loc: 加利福尼亚纽波特海滩
title: Step into old history of Shanghai
content: Go early as Yu Gardens is extremely popular with Chinese visitors and can feel claustrophobic with all the pushing of people. Charming historic buildings and and a must-do zig-zag bridge across a small lake. Close walking distance from the Bund.

title: it used to be a residence
content: This is a complex of small buildings, ponds, bridges and gardens within Shanghai's Chinatown. There is a ticket to visit and is worthy in my opinion. It has many little corners where you can stand and rest and take pictures. This used to be the property of a high ranking official. Just image him having the luxury to meditate in this serene environment while outside the bustling commercial activity of the old Chinatown was taking place. I say 45 to 60 min can be spent in there.

title: too crowd
content: My 2nd time to visit Yu Garden since year 2004. I don't like this place because it was too crowd. The building design for this garden is almost the same with Zhu Jia Jiao old town. I rather go to Zhu Jia Jiao old town for less visitors.

title: Yu won't be sorry!
content: Without a doubt this was my favorite sightseeing spot in Shanghai. Built by a son for his aging parents (completed in 1577) the 2 hectares of rambling pathways, striking pavilions and ancient flora will keep your trigger finger busy snapping pics. I especially liked the ancient oriental architecture and curved roofs.

title: Realy nice
content: Was there with my sister. Realy nice garden! And not only the garden but the shopping area around it was realy nice.

title: Really beautiful
content: We loved this area, so much local food! The shopping was such a good mix too.There are street vendors, pearl dealers, and real clothing stores. Nearly all the clothes had English saying and a great many merchants spoke English or were happy to use google translate. We got great deals and toured the actual garden. The garden had many beautiful rooms. It was well designed and we fun.

title: Charming building
content: Was very crowded when I got there in June.

title: Beautiful
content: Stunning gardens right in the heart of the city. The architecture of the buildings and details on them was amazing. A must see for sure.

title: Pretty buildings but too crowded
content: The crowds of Asians in the area made it impossible to walk around freely. The shops and restaurants like McDonald's and Starbucks ruined the beauty of the area. Would recommend going early in the morning to enjoy it better.

title: Necessary but not so impressive
content: Other of most famous attractions in Shanghai. I felt a bit dissapointed with this gardens because my expectations were bigger than i saw

title: Love the place but too crowded
content: Lovely garden in a big place like old town. All the shop are selling very expensive items whether they are good or not. I found one shop sells big bun with watering inside the taste was too bad. Anyway it was just something we want to tell to anyone.

title: Lovely garden complex in the heart of Shanghai
content: The Yu Garden is a delightful oasis tucked away from the hustle and bustle of Shanghai. Filled with traditional Chinese art and architecture, a walk through the Garden complex takes visitors over walkways and bridges, through archways and buildings, amid lovely trees, waterways and rock formations. This is a gem, a delight for photographers and lovers of traditional Chinese culture, and a must-see for visitors to Shanghai.

title: Busy, but rewarding...
content: We visited here as part of a tour and found it an interesting garden to wander and view. A little busy at times (perhaps a one-way system could be considered?), but certainly well worth the effort.

title: Crowded oasis of calm
content: Visited after reading all the reviews and still enjoyed. Despite the huge number of people there are still snatched moments of calm to be had here amongst the pools, walls and statues of this intriguingly complicated garden. I particularly liked the dark, cool buildings dotted around the gardens and imagined the peace and quiet to be had here in a previous era.

title: Traditional garden where you can find the truly chinese culture
content: This place is one of my favorite place in Shanghai! where you can runaway for extremely busy city. If you get the chance to go on a weekday, go for it as it gets very crowded during weekends. However its very crowded during weekends,

title: Beautiful place!
content: Yu Garden is a beautiful place to visit in Shanghai! You will find many stores to buy Chinese stuff. It’s good to go at the end of the day because you will be able to see it during the night with the light on. It is BEAUTIFUL!!!

title: Calm and serene in the middle of a bazaar
content: When I planned to visit, I was looking for some quiet time in Shanghai. When I got here, there is a very busy market in the periphery of the gardens which makes it a bit difficult to reach the entrance (no signs). Ask your way around and don't get ushered into tea ceremonies along the way. When you enter, the fountains and the old architecture immediately hushes the outside noise and there are many paths to walk along and little lakes to sit by and relax. Definitely recommend a weekday visit to avoid the long ques for tickets and arrive early to make the most of it.

title: Gorgeous gardens in the middle of the busy city
content: Yu Yuan is one of my favourite spots in Shanghai. It’s a traditional garden in the midst of the extremely busy city. If you get the chance to go on a weekday, go for it as it gets very crowded during weekends.

title: Highlight of my Shanghai trip
content: Gorgeous and serene garden in the middle of the city. Yu Garden was the highlight of my time in Shanghai. It was crowded when I went, but somehow because of how big the garden is and how narrow a lot of the paths are, I still had lots of moments where it felt like I had the place to myself. Definitely do not miss. Recommend going right when it opens to avoid crowds and (in summer) the heat.

title: Very nice and cultural place
content: Nice garden with a lots of Chinese culture to see. From the Feng Shui to the decoration, architect.. It's nice to see all the shop next to it.

title: Good for Cheap shopping , Beautiful Ancient China Architecture
content: Pros:

title: An Oasis in the middle of old town tourist area...
content: This is very worthy of a visit before you hit the old town. There is lots to see and classic chinese garden architecture.. if you like English/French gardens (Tuileries, Luxembourg)...this is for you. Do it before you do the touristy old town (also worthy) while you still have energy. We noticed some people had guides, probably organized at their hotels and it would be good to have someone explain all the subtleties - like square to round doors symbolizing earth and heaven.

title: A bustling spot
content: We visited here a few times while in Shanghai. Lots of shops, restaurants, and food vendors. The entire complex appears to have been restored to match the original, but modernized to handle the crowds. It is always busy here and safe with plenty of police patrols keeping peddlars and thieves away (which is not a problem in Shanghai or most large cities in China). A visit here is a 'must', just because it is so interesting.

title: Relaxing place in Shanghai
content: Very nice park, quite silent after crowded Shanghai street. You will enjoy water, fish, old style Chinese buildings and sculptures. Better to visit at morning hours.

title: So beutiful and serene, hard to believe it's in the middle of Shanghai
content: The Yu Gardens which was first built in 1559 during the Ming Dynasty by Pan Yunduan as a comfort for his father, the minister Pan En, in his old age. Pan Yunduan began the project after failing one of the imperial exams, but his appointment as governor of Sichuan postponed construction for nearly twenty years until 1577. The garden was the largest and most prestigious of its era in Shanghai, but eventually its expense helped ruin the Pans. Inside the gardens contains the Huxinting Teahouse, which was originally built in 1784 but only became a teahouse in the 19th century. Also there was The City God Temple. It also had very pretty gardens, ponds, a rockery dating from the Ming Period and a dragon wall. It was very pretty and would of course been serene if not for the vast number of tourists. But that’s China! On leaving Yu Gardens there was a huge Bazaar called the Yuyuan Tourist Mart that covers many streets. While many sold the same type of touristy merchandise there actually was a lot of variety. In addition there were many different types of restaurants as well.

title: Very very busy
content: Very very busy but worth a look as the gardens are beautiful. Its a shame that the gardens allow people in selling goods as this took away the charm of it. Heaps of shops surround the gardens. Beware of creepy market lady that waited for us to finish looking at the gardens then wanted to take us to the basement of her shop....I think not.

title: Busy, busy, busy
content: Busy, busy, busy market with a Dairy Queen. The center of the area is the home built by a filial son for his father. The upstairs living quarters are under construction and not opened for touring.

title: Garden in the Center of the City
content: I was disappointed that there were very few flowers. The garden is mostly oddly shaped rocks. There is a nice koi pond. The garden is adjacent to the market which is huge.

title: Wonderful garden
content: Beautiful garden, and one of the best in China obviously. Definitely worth a visit, but a bit hard to find in between all the buildings. Take the tube to Yuyuan garden station and walk about 800 meters.

title: Lovely Gardens
content: Can get pensions pass half price with ID. lovely gardens but can get busy. Most people do pass through quickly. Lots of Photo spots. Area to sit around pagodas.  Huge Fish pond.Lovely chinese carvings on tops of walls.

title: A pleasant afternoon
content: Yu Garden and the nearby shopping facilities provided us with a very pleasant afternoon outing. I had visited the area 25 years earlier and found this visit equally charming. Lots to see but of course very popular and at times rather crowded. My blonde wife was amused to find so many Chinese keen to take photographs with her. Plenty of amusement if little common language between us. Well worth a visit.

title: Must see in Shanghai
content: Of course it is very crowdy and also the conditions for the fish and turtles are far from optimal, but it is still worth a visit. Despite the high amount of tourists you can get a feeling of the ancient china spirit (which is rare in Shanghai).

title: Wonderful Gardens
content: We spent about an hour walking through these gardens which were very unusual.  The buildings are interspersed with gardens of rocks, water and plants and the architecture is wonderful.

title: Nice but touristic
content: Nice place to be. The whole area with its gardens and shops and temple give you a good feel for the old chinese buildings

title: Nice scenic place for souvenirs and photos,
content: This area is beautiful and full of your essential souvenirs and phototaking.

title: Must see
content: I have been here three times and it is a great place to wander and explore. The gardens are beautiful, but I love the stalls of handcrafted items that are in the surrounding area. If you are looking for unique gifts and personalized gifts, this is the place to go. The gardens are easy to get around and kids will enjoy the large koi fish, secret passages and many dragon carvings.

title: Lovely but very busy
content: Visited on Saturday while on private tour. Was lovely but very very busy area on the Saturday which i believe is normal. Lots to see. Lovely architecture

title: Beautiful garden! ❤️
content: One of the great places to visit when you’re in Shanghai. The garden is big and beautiful. Highly recommend this place.

title: Afternoon walk
content: This is an amazing garden. We spent over five hours here and could’ve stayed longer. They are so well presented and maintained. A true chinese tea house is a great visit and time to absorb the tranquility of such a beautiful place. Thoroughly recommend it.

title: Interesting
content: Mountain style garden creation that took 19 years to complete. Includes Gardens,water features, carp,rocketies and the like. Nice relaxing environment for a couple of hours. Next to traditional housing and bazar area.

title: Nice Garden in Old Shanghai
content: Went here on a Sunday, and it was busy, but not packed. The garden is a small-to-medium-sized area that can easily be toured in an hour or two. Its a nice space in a busy city to take a stroll and take in all the plants and ponds.

title: Such a good place
content: If u are going there, find a day for it. In such place need to enjoy, not to be in hurry. Price of the ticket for students- 15 yuan only, but don’t forget ur student’s id

title: Stunning and Beautiful
content: Yu Garden is a beautiful and historic garden that has a special place in the hearts of the Shanghai community. It is packed with trees, flowers, lakes, and ancient buildings. It’s peaceful atmosphere is special. Everyone should go here.

title: Beautiful garden, interesting
content: 30 yuan entry fee. I am an aimless wanderer and a people watcher, and this whimsical garden that models an old dynasty style garden and regal estate layout is beautiful way to spend part of a day. When you enter main entrance explore the temple and area surrounding it, but don’t miss out on going through the little grotto to the best part of the park. I wandered for several hours. Saw magnificent botanical specimens and interesting pond creatures such as carp and painted turtles. There is shade to be found and some small shops and exhibits with air conditioning if you are wilting. The shops are expensive and if you are on a budget, save your money for its nearby cousin- old town aka Nanshi. Unlike nanshi- There was very little solicitation and very little haggling. I did manage a 20% holiday discount on a lapis lazuli piece I really wanted for my sister’s birthday. Go early if going on the weekend. Not as large as map makes it look and all of the sections are connected in a round about way.

title: Gorgeous but Rushed
