content: Visited Yu Garden with friends. Small entrance fee, you buy the ticket next to the entrance. Fairly crowded but you could find areas that were less crowded and has the calm feel of a garden. The lucky bridge was packed. Overall worth a visit.

title: Go early!
content: Once the masses arrive, there is no enjoying of this gem. The garden is beautiful and intricate, but if you go past noon a complete zoo. If possible, go early in the morning and enjoy the different little hideouts and the koi ponds. A must in this crazy city.

title: Stunning Chinese pagoda gardens
content: We visited these gardens whilst in Shanghai and they were one of my favourite things in China. A high ranking government official man built them for his parents to enjoy in their twilight years but unfortunately they passed away before he finished. They include pagoda buildings, bridges, ponds, giant koi, and lovely sculpted plants and trees. It is a major spectacle not to be missed. There is also a very good market bazaar next to it.

title: Great Chinese history mixed with tourism
content: Yu Gardens Mar 18

title: Old city and gardens
content: Charming beautiful old buildings it gave the real taste of the great old culture we liked the small shops with nice silk goods but one has to negotiate the price it was joyful to walk there

title: The hustle and bustle of a marketplace!
content: Very busy, tot as lly crowded, but eorth a visit! Loads of shops and restaurants all with a local flavour. The food was authentic and the prices midrange. Great photo opportunities!

title: Peaceful Garden In The Middle Of The City
content: Great place to get away for some down time or peace and quiet.

title: Lucky to visit this serene place after the Chinese New Year
content: We went through the various floats to get to this Garden as we visited Shanghai a week after the Chinese New Year. If you go through the floats, you are likely to miss the entrance.

title: Tourists wherever you look
content: The garden itself is very beautiful, a piece of Chinese garden architecture of the past. But there are thousands of tourists and they are climbing on each stone or garden bench, they are feeding the Coi carps so that the water is dirty. It's really horrible. Outside the garden was rebuilt a Chinese town with "ancient" houses, in which you find souvenir shops, street food, clothing, jewelry and so on. And the tourists push and shove.I don't like this place.

title: Ya Garden Still A Winner!
content: For a nominal entry fee (10 or 15 RMB IIRC) you get to experience the beautiful You Garden. I’ve visited a dozen times at least over the last 15 years and will continue to do so. Very beautiful.

title: Must visit
content: A ex rich man residence with historical background. Outside of this compound is a big old style modelled area with shops and restaurants catering to tourists. Also nearby is the city temple which is also exceptional.

title: Frantic busy busy
content:
Busy market, bound to find what
You’re looking for but it is like a maze.  We went on a Saturday so I guess it would be busier than normal.  Again would recommend because the buildings are beautiful!

title: Nice but better parks in Shanghai
content: After visiting the sculpture park, Yu Garden was a not living up the expectations. Nice and clinical and a bit of fun with people jiving in the street, but aim in early spring to the sculpture park

title: Very busy
content: We were not blown away by this place. Very busy (shortly after Chinese New Year so the lanterns were will in place) and while the inner gardens were nice and a wonderful piece of history, I would probably not recommend it to others as a must see if you are only in Shanghai for a short time.

title: Oasis in a crowded place.
content: We thoroughly enjoyed the gardens. We were there at a very busy time. Lantern festival. The access to the gardens through the narrow streets lined with small shops was a little confusing but ver bright and cheerful. When we finally enter ed the gardens it was such a pleasant surprised. Very well maintained with some lovely architecture and displays. Loved the trees. So very old. Interesting to see the backdrop of high rise modern buildings in the background.

title: Very busy during Chinese New Year.
content: A great place to experience a typical Chinese Shopping area. Best avoided during Chinese New Year when it is very busy and everyone wants to stand where you are standing. Very interesting and a great experience both visually and aromatic. The aromas of the various vendors selling a great variety of food, but we did not sample the Bull Frog! Tourists should be aware with regard to personal belongings but safe if you take care. Well worth a visit.

title: Beautiful garden
content: It is a beautiful house and garden to visit..

title: the crowd
content: I've been to the Yu Garden many times with my wife. After all it's not very far away from our place in Shanghai. However this time we decided to take our children there during Spring Festival. It was probably the worst crowd I've ever seen in my life. I'm trying to push the stroller with a small child and people are literally stepping over the first two wheeled and tripping and then getting pissed off at me because of it. If you want to go with children then definitely don't go during any holidays.

title: A must see
content: Truly loved this visit, a small piece of history tucked inside the mega city of Shanghai.   A must visit spot.

title: Peace
content: Incredibly beautiful and not too crowded. Would love to spend an afternoon here. Great for quiet reflection and photos.

title: Souvenirs of all types
content: Firstly this place is crowded so if your not wanting to get too close for comfort with strangers stay away or go very early. The food here is quite mediocre with lots of souvenir shops.

title: Short trip and bad time of year
content: Was there for 3 nights stayed at Renesassance hotel near Yu Gardens. Great location and hotel, loved Bob the robot.

title: Old Chinese garden in the city of shanghai.
content: Visited during winter , January, it is the Old Chinese garden in the city of shanghai. Very beautiful place to visit however it’s a touristic place as it is. Worth the visit.

title: Beautiful architecture!
content: My favorite place so far. Super beautiful and feels like a palace that you can run around and get lost. It’s just amazing how you can feel like you were in hundreds years ago while being here.

title: A must visit
content: Enjoy a morning wandering through the maze of pagodas and gardens. Entrance fee is 30 C/Y and is at the end of a stunning walk across the bridge surrounded by colorful floats featuring Chinese childrens stories.

title: History in the Middle of Modern China
content: The gardens were really impressive. To see the historical rooms and stories behind them let you imagine what it was like. The buildings and the functions that they served were really amazing. A must see if you are in the Shanghai area.

title: Nice but crowded
content: It is typical chinese garden with many places for taking photo. Pools and temples are nice but they are not very amazing espicially for who has travelled other asian cities.

title: Crowded but yeah
content: A must visit garden in Shanghai

user_loc: 埃塞俄比亚亚的斯亚贝巴
title: A must visit
content: It’s a garden along Taoist thinking, i.e. people are not at the center of the universe. t’s a rock garden, with porous stones. Kind of lava, with holes in it. My uneducated guess. The layout and formation was new to me. It was once private property. During the Ming period. We had tea in a 200 year old tea house. It was overcast the day we visited. So not crowded, although plenty of people around. As we are senior citizens, we got discount on entrance ticket. No queue.

title: Small but a Must!
content: The garden itself is rather way smaller than what I have expected. Nontheless, It is nice and has shops all around it! (Note that is crowded)

title: An overcrowded shopping area with a quiet garden
content: Before you enter the Yu Garden, you will go through an overcrowded shopping area. You will find tons of good deals and food places and you will Not be able to resist.

title: Experience the old Shanghai first hand
content: Beautiful site to visit while in Shanghai. Although crowded, it is worthwhile. Lots of shops and displays of old Chinese crafts, silk, tea, music instruments and more. The pool with great fish of different size and colors. Highly recommended!

title: Day trip
content: Many interesting shops - local artists/craftsman there the day we went. The crab soup dumpling is worth the line!! The gardens are beautiful!!

title: March....PLUM and MAGNOLIA Blossoms!!!!!
content: Stunning, peaceful Gardens. I have been here several times. This time (mid-March) the Plum Blossoms and Magnolias were in full bloom. Lovely. The wisteria will kick in in April...draped over an arbor. My son loved the fish when he was younger. This year I was with a good friend and she loved the old stone mosaics. Look up for the Dragon. It's impressive.

title: Concrete garden with a touch of colour
content: I stumbled upon a beauty and stepped back in time. The old architecture coexisting with the new buildings in the background. A street lined with Chinese New Year (CNY) lanterns with all kinds of small shops - from galleries, metal doors, clothes, jade stones, jewellery, souvenirs and food. I loved it.

title: Calm oasis in a hectic city
content: At first we were quite terrified by the massive amount of people outside the gardens when we visited during the Chinese spring festival. But then we realized that only a few people actually went into the garden, so we did. And it was a great choice.

title: Umm. Where is it?
content: We tried for ages to find this place even with the aid of 5 other people and their sat nav all to no avail! Never did figure out where it was. Rating therefore based on us not locating it.

title: Beautiful gardens and an oasis within busy Shangai
content: Beautiful gardens and pavilions in the middle of the city so perfect to get away from the hustle and bustle and see some greenery.

title: A must see in Shanghai!
content: Yu Garden is great. A hidden gem in the middle of Shanghai. You are taken back 400 years, to the time of the Ming Dynasty, and get to experience a small portion of the great Chinese history.

title: To many people
content: I visited the yuyuan gardens on a normal Tuesday around noon, and the place was packed with people. Even though it was a rather large area, you still felt like walking in a line the whole time. There was some pretty buildings, but the excessive amount of people and decorations made them difficult to view and enjoy...

title: Overrated and super touristy.
content:
It doesn’t matter when you come, it’s always crowded and the stores sell over-priced rubbish. 
The Yu Yuan is ok, but certainly not special. This tourist destination is definitely skippable and never go more than once.

title: Full of tourists !
content: Every organized tour either from China or from the rest of the world brings its busload of tourists to this location , so do not be surprise if you feel crowded or are having a problem taking a picture (selfie being even worse ) . But IT IS WORTH the visit . It is simply beautiful and typical of landscaping in China . Very commercial but still cultural ! Naturally our two excellent Shanghai Greeters included it in our visit !

title: Heavily commercialized, ok for first timers!
content: I ventured out at night for a stroll through the bazaar and narrow alleys leading to the garden, it felt very unique with Chinese lightning themed after the year of dog!

title: Interesting
content: Chinese Architecture typical, lot of people! Temple is amazing and the little walk in the garden with the tea room and the bridge

title: Great Place to Visit
content: Yu Garden and the surrounding shops are a great place to visit for 3-4 hours. The garden provides a glimpse into a residence from the past. The shopping area gives you a nice cultural experience. All of your souvenir shopping can be accomplished here, but be sure to compare prices of identical items between shops. The clerks will also barter so feel free to make your best offer. This area is also home to "the oldest tea house" in Shanghai.

title: Attractive
content: Notice to opening hour 8:45 to 16:15 very nice place around it lots shops take subway line 10 at station yuyuan garden

title: Simply amazing
content: The day we visited was during the Chinese New Year so the place was insane! They had everyone going in one direction to make it easier. It really is a beautiful and amazing place though even with the crowds. In fact the crowds added to the appeal. There were a lot of giant colourful structures of mythical gods and animals in the open squares. This is a must do for Shanghai.

title: Weakness of crowd control and frightened by visitors fighting at Underground station
content: Uncontrol of visitors pushing each others for trying to buy train tickets.

title: Historic garden in the middle of the city
content: My family and I walked to the Yu Garden after visiting the Bund in the morning. It's probably a walk of a mile or two, but it was picturesque and very safe. The grounds and architecture are beautiful, which resulted in plenty of photographs. I also learned a great deal of Chinese history thanks to a myriad of English signage throughout the garden.

title: Oasis in the middle of the skyscraper
content: This was one of our favourite things we did in Shanghai. The garden was like a peaceful oasis in the middle of Shanghai. There were several gardens to wander through, all traditional Chinese style with rockeries, lakes and bridges. Could easily spend a couple of hours here.

title: Pretty garden
content: Lovely place, inexpensive excursion. Was cold wet and slippery but if you walked carefully was not an issue. Located just near some great shops so a good afternoon outing.

title: Best and busiest Garden in Asia
content: Certainly the busiest Garden with shopping areas in the biggest city of the world. Rule of thumb? Any goods in small shops cut the price to 1/3 or 1/2.  Must visit in Shanghai.

title: Beautiful settings, serene...give it some time!
content: We managed to get in like 3 minutes before clowning was like 5pm...felt a little early. This is one interesting attraction going on forever. Easily can spend 3 hours. Quite a lot of history attached...So take your time...you won't be disappointed!

title: Nice but "cramped"
content: Inside this garden which is about 500 years old (according to the sign right outside the entrance) are: a number of small ancient-styled buildings (mostly with displays of furniture, but there's one with beautiful paintings & calligraphy displays), narrow passageways, some ponds or waterways (with colorful fish in them), some dragon sculptures on the walls (like "full-length" dragons with long tails) and some warrior sculptures on the roofs of those ancient-styled buildings. It's just that despite all those great things, the garden grounds are "cramped" (this is for sure not a wide-open garden and to add to that, the place is also "crowded" due to its popularity), and also here you'll see "as much rocks" as you'll see plants (not sure if that's just the "typical style" of an ancient Chinese garden since I recall the imperial garden in Beijing's Forbidden City is like that too with plenty of rocks alongside the paths of the garden), so overall I wasn't too impressed by it although the "best part" of my visit was just before leaving which is when I saw the stage performance of a musical show for about half an hour by five or six musicians with "mainly chinaware" as musical instruments (but the music was "quite good" which probably is how the Ming emperors were entertained back in the day!).

title: busy place but worth seeing
content: Yuyuan Garden is a nice place to have a stroll. Close to subway. I was lucky to catch the end of new year celebration with the lantern festival. Very busy, but just lovely to look, get lost among the people and soak the atmoshphere. Not to be missed.

title: Real China
content: I was lucky to visit Yu Garden during the annual New Year Folklore Art Lantern Festival. Amazing experience and beautiful exhibition.

title: Feel Chinese-like thing in Short time
content: This used to be mansion of the load of manor. THere are a lot of suvenir shops then it is good for shopping. SHanhai is now very modern city so

title: Really good afternoon out
content: We came here one afternoon after a recommendation. We had a good afternoon and the garden is very nice. Well kept and some interesting things to see. Very peaceful and not that busy when we visited.

title: Yu Garden
content: I can’t imagine if you to Shanghai and not visit this beautiful place, such nice architecture of old time and really Chinese way

title: Don't visit during national holidays or weekends
content: Yuyuyan Garden is a beautiful attraction and everybody wants to see it. There will be people trying to sell you stuff at high prices so I recommend you fight the urge. The pond area is very busy but the garden is peaceful.

title: Peace and tranquility
content: Built for his parents this garden took so long they never actually saw it finished.A beautiful place with so much to see it was amazing.

title: Ok to take a look.
content: Nice to take a quick look, but the shopping area is not the best. recommend to go somewhere else for shopping.

user_loc: 德克萨斯州圣安东尼奥市
title: Beautiful Place
content: I have been to this garden twice, so that should tell you how much I enjoyed the place.  It is a haven for taking photos and you will see people from all over the world visiting this remarkable place.

title: Beautiful garden
content: Unfortunately we bumped up with school trip so was too busy, too noisy but the garden is so beautiful.

title: Lanterne festival
content: With my wife and friend, we been there for the lantern festival... incredible to see all this color. I highly recommend to go there after the original lantern festival otherwise that’s will be pack of people!

title: Very good sightseeing spot
content: This is the tradional garden in the heart of Shanghai. There are many shop near by the garden. You can enjoy sightseeing and shopping in the same place.

title: Must See Especially During Chinese New Year
content: This beautiful garden area was decorated for the Chinese New Year, and is a must see if you’re visiting during this time.

title: Chinese tranquillity
content: Yu Gardens in Shanghai is a beautiful place of peace and tranquillity in the heart of Old China town in Shanghai. Typical Chinese buildings, feeding koi (large gold fish), dragon emblems along with beautifully maintained gardens offers the quintessential Chinese experience.

title: Lovely, classical Chinese garden
content: Definitely worth a visit. This is a classical Chinese garden in a completely different style from traditional European gardens. Yes, it was crowded, but the harmonious plan and the emphasis on natural forms were evident. Our guide's explanation of the stone sculptures was truly enlightening. If we hadn't been with a group, I could easily lingered for hours enjoying this place.

title: Perfect for an easy stroll
content: The garden offered nice views and was affordable it was great to be able to take your time walking through the area and exploring different sections of the Garden depending on your pace it can take a little while to walk through.

title: Special place, but be prepared for crowds
content: From the photos I had seen, in particular of one of the tea houses on site, I had expected a tranquil experience of classic Chinese landscaping. Though the beauty was there, the crowds were as well and the experience was very different from expected. Definitely worth a visit but be prepared for crowds, even in the off season in bad weather, which is when we went. (We were also there on a Sunday, which would be a contributing factor; try a weekday if you can.) The garden is surrounded (inundated?) by souvenir shops, street food stalls, etc., but that appears par for the course.

title: Go, go there for the crowd in fact
content: The actual garden is lovely and for sure worth a visit. If you prefer peace and quiet, be sure to get there early, like by 7:30am. It will not be open yet. But something better is waiting for you: The 200+ years old HuXinTing tea house in the middle of the manmade lake. I will stay to the ground floor with the locals. It is also cheaper. Opposite the tea house, is the famous NanXiang dumplings. So here is the drill: get to Yu Yuan around 7:30am, have some dumplings, then have some tea, go to the Yu Garden. By the time you get out, you will see the crowds and start shopping. All kinds of Chinese souvenirs can be found there. People linger there for a day easily.

title: Beautiful spot in the middle of the city
content: Beware the Tea House scam in this area. We were approached by two young Chinese women who wanted to practice English. They enticed us to a special tea ceremony in a seedy area near the garden and we were ripped off for Yuan 1000 by the time we left.

title: nice garden nestled in the city
content: Nice garden to walk around and see the historic elements of chinese culture. its great to stop by from the hustle and bustle of the city

user_loc: 加利福尼亚拉古纳尼格
title: Worth the Small Fee For the Actual Garden
content: We walked around the touristy area for a while before realizing there is an actual 'Yu Garden' area that requires a fee- we almost opted out of going to the actual Yu Garden, but I'm so glad we didn't! It is much larger than you would expect and we found ourselves walking around in circles to make sure we didn't miss anything. There are some really beautiful spots in the garden and the history is very interesting - take the time to read some of the signs! As far as the touristy part of the Yu Garden, there's tons of souvenirs to purchase - we did have some trouble with finding food because we don't speak Chinese, no one spoke English, and none of the menus were in English. Would've loved to get a food recommendation before going (maybe ask your hotel!).

title: Nice scenery
content: Nice place to go for spending some time to admires Chinese architecture. Went on winter most of the trees are in winter state. I bet it is splendid on spring. To be honest i gave a star less due to the ticket personal and security guard was not friendly and rather rude. Other than that. Its an awesome place

title: If you want to see a Chinese garden...
content: If you don’t particularly enjoy gardens but would like to see one while in China, this is a great one. Semi compact garden with many beautiful flowers and trees. Nice any time a year but particularly in spring with the fresh blossom. They smell very good! There are fun books and crannies to explore with younger children and photo ops with fine examples of architecture within the garden walls. The surrounding area streets are also a draw and fun to roam.

title: Beautiful bonzais
content:
Beautiful plants and bonzais and koi fish and pond and architecture
They hve small shops that sells souvenirs as well as gifts that u can purchase

title: Beauty beyond belief
content: Gardenia from shangaidriver.net took my husband, my sister and her husband to beautiful garden. It is full of history, culture and beauty.

title: Has to visit
content: Nice place for shopping and a walk for a day love to go there buy some silk and Chinese souvenirs place number 1 to visit in shanghai

title: A taste of Old Shanghai
content: Nice find among all the modern buildings! The market nearby is also a fun place to visit for food and souvenirs.

title: nice new experiance
content: I recommend it for a new experience

title: Yu garden
content: Nice garden. Well worth a visit. NOTE: The entrance is hard to find. We wouldn't of found it some nice Chinese man didn't help. The entrance is in the middle of the markets, find the windy bridge path in the middle  :)

title: Well done
content: The original gardens were built in the late 16th century (Ming Dynasty) and have needed to be rebuilt several times over due to various wars. While taking up a relative small overall footprint you wind and weave along paths, over ponds and by ornate Chinese buildings so that it feels much larger. The garden is part of the larger Yu Yuan Bazaar

title: Too much people
content: Maybe the season i went this amazing place is to bad for visit china. Exactly the golden week too longs queues in mtr, cant stop to take some picture there. . so sad

title: Spring festival time of year in the garden
content: We are in Shanghai, China on business and we’re told to spend some time on our own. We decided to head into the city center and did the obvious Bund stop. This definitely the next stop if you are wondering. You will have a hard time reading the route directions once you get there but follow the flow of the crowd and signs for Yu Garden. They aren’t as consistent and you might expect back home, but as I said, stay with the flow. You will want to cut through from one block to the next, but guards wont let you. It’s ok, because they are funneling you along. If you stay with the crowd you will get to the garden. You will know you are at the entrance because it’s the only ticket booth and currently it’s about $5 per person (30RMB).

title: Excellent
content: Fabulous place. Well worth the cheap entry fee. Plan to spend at least 2-3 hours to look around properly

title: tranquil garden of happiness
content: Built in 1559 during the Ming Dynasty, Yuyuan Garden confuses me. Firstly, I can’t really decide if it’s Yuyuan Garden, Yu Garden or just Yuyuan. Cause in English signs at the metro, it’s Yuyuan Garden. Some guidebooks called it Yu Garden. In Chinese words, it’s just 豫园 (Yu Yuan), with Yuan actually meaning garden. Because the gardens contains so many ponds with beautiful koi fish, my initially thought was Yu actually meant Fish, hence a “fish garden”. Pardon my bad mandarin.

title: Nice Tea Garden
content: This area is tourist central, but the gardens are a nice escape from the bustle of the city. I recommend going on a weekday to avoid the crazy mad rush of tourists.

title: Nice area to walk in evening
content: Many kiosk shops and restaurants. All shop decorations in old traditional Chinese style. Recommend to try food kiosk , tofu or Chinese snacks

title: brilliant great value and deffo worth a look round
content: had a great tie here even in the one days rain we had, cheap to get in and the place is hidden as its huge, you can easily spend a good few hours here or more, very pretty, places to sit and chill and i really enjoyed it , even my 8 year old loved it, like a hidden place as looks small from outside, you buy the tickets outside by the water gardens and not by the entrance where you go in if that helps anyone. closes at 5pm and lasts time in was 4.15pm in jan 2018

title: Love this place
content: The old time view of china. It is tourist are, don't forget to bargain as they markup all the stuff alot.

title: very quiet place in the center of the city
content: This ancient "politician" house and gardens turned into museum nowadays, provide peace and tranquility in the busy city.

title: as a historcall garden it was actually good
content: on a rainy day this was ok, but the walking surfaces were dangerously slippery in those circumstances, but as a place of interest is worth a visit

title: Amazing place
content: This is something you'd see in films. It's so old and has lots of history. I don't know how much it costs to get in as I was with a tour who paid for it all, but it's a must see.

title: Shameless Tourist Trap - But a Must See
content: Shameless tourist trap without exception. But it's a must see. Lots of little shops and street food options here.

title: Beautiful tourist attraction
content: These gardens are situated in the heart of shanghai and are absolutely breath taking. I would probably recommend heading earlier in the morning or later in the afternoon as it gets very busy. With so many photo opportunities you wouldn’t want to miss. I would recommend doing this attraction in your own as I did it part of tour and felt like it was rushed. This is definitely a place beauty meets culture.

title: Great place
content: The place is really nice and many things to buy for gifts to take home , we where there at day time , it’s lovely and many food to eat you can choose everything you want

title: nice place
content: Beautiful garden in the center of chaotic Shanghai, unfortunately overrun by tourists so maybe you should visit it midweek

title: Garden in the city
content: The Yu Garden is just near our hotel. it is just a walking distance from the hotel. This place has lot of souvenir and food shops.

title: Beautiful...definitely go
content: The crowds in the Old Market can be overwhelming, and the shops and restaurants are very touristy. But, once you finally make your way across the winding bridge to enter the gate to The Yu Garden, the experience on the other side of the wall is more conducive to contemplating the gorgeous view in front of you. The maze of structures, ponds, walkways and trees that make up The Yu Garden were really beautiful, even in January. Very charming. Terrific photo op. A must in Shanghai for sure.

title: A need to go in Shanghai
content: Very beautiful area, inside and outside the garden. If possible go there during the week, avoid weekends and public holidays. It's ver crowded then. Nice DimSum restaurant nearby.

title: beautiful and very interesting
content: These gardens are in the middle of old town. The gardens and the buidling were wonderful then stepping out of the walled gardens yopu are in old town which is the first china town

title: Charming and Enchanting Garden !!
content: The Garden was built in 1577 and hence the architecture and the feel of the place brings a mixture of the new and old.

title: Must visit
content: This is a place I think its a must visit when you are first time in Shanghai. It’s winter when I visit so the crowd wasn’t disturbing. There are so many food to try it out. And so many shops and stalls to visit. A small Chinese garden to walk through. Basically, you can find cheap street food and souvenirs. I bought an embroidery painting 450yen. A good buy to me! I miss the fresh strawberries coated with sugar. There is a famous Xiao Long Bao restaurant with a Long queue. We went upstairs to dine in. Heard that it’s very famous there. But I think Ding Tai Feng taste better. I did not visit the temple which is just beside it.

title: Exceeding average for 30RMB
content: If you've been around China, you probably at one point or another have stumbled across a garden with a few ponds, koi fish and really nice architecture. Whilst Yu Gardens delivers all this, it does charge you a fair bit for it. We found that it wasn't as peaceful as it was intended to be due to the huge tourist numbers even in low season - the line to get in took about 15 minutes. Once you're in, you'll find that although its really pretty and calm, it'll only be half an hour before you've seen and appreciated it all. If you're travelling around China, definitely try to find a garden or park that doesn't charge and isn't overflowing with tourists like this one. If you're only stopping in Shanghai and need things to do, pay these gardens a visit.

title: Classic Chinese architecture, a must see location
content: Spent several hours in the gardens enjoying Chinese architecture and in the museum. While i went there in the winter, it was snowing--a rare sight. There are several buildings, walking trails, and ponds to enjoy.

title: Contrasts
content: The location itself (although crowded) is really suggestive and relaxing. You can smell the meditational atmosphere, all the sacred icons. The small corner dedicated to the cherry blossoms is really enchanting.

title: Authentic experience in the middle of Shanghai
content: Old world garden and historical site in the heart of Shanghai.  Perfect spot to capture photos in many different scenes.

title: Nice gardens
content: Visited in January on a rainy day. Was a very pretty garden costs 30 rmb to get in. We finished it in about 30 minuted but you could spend a lot more time in there, was just very cold and wet when I went. The area outside is awesome too with lots of cool food and stalls

title: Brilliant place
content: Had a good two hours with Partner and 8 year old son who also loved this place. Cheap entry and lovely place very pretty

title: Serene and peaceful
content: Such a beautiful garden in the middle of the city . The best part is that when you go to Yuyuan area, its just not the garden but there are so many things around to do. The garden in itself takes about 1-2 hours to explore. There is a beuatiful water body with beautiful gold fish in it . Its a pleasing experience to walk and explore the garden.

title: Pleasant
content: Although our visit was in winter we still enjoyed taking a stroll around the gardens. Not overly crowded but still plenty of people around. Would like to see in Spring.

title: Great place
content: Beautiful place to visit and enjoy an evening there with the shops around. I would not go too late as lost of shops close early.

title: Cheap and cheerful
content: Great to walk around, very cheap to enter and a nice way to spend an hour in Shanghai. Well worth a look

title: If you love crowds you will love Yuan Gardens
content: This is an interesting place for tourists, but it is crowded and you will be approached by sellers of watches, wallets, bags etc upon arrival. I think the best way to get there is Subway. While the garden is 100s of years old the surroundings are recently built with starbucks, KFC, Mcdonalds etc. Entry into the garden itself is about 45 yuan. Yuan garden is like a small town, you could walk around it and through it without actually finding the actual garden and you can do that for free. If you aren't in Shanghai for long, you should see the actual garden, not just the surroundings, but if you want a less commercial more authentic and less crowded experience. Visit the Confucion temple in Wenmian road, however if you like crowds, being hassled by hawkers, can't stray too far from a Mcdonalds or Starbucks, than Yuan Gardens is perfect for you.

title: Beautiful Chinese garden even in winter!
content: Very pretty place to visit wasn't too crowded either (I'm sure it would be in season) but was a beautiful garden yo to walk around even in the winter definitely recommend if you want to see a Chinese garden :)

title: Amazing Old China
content: It’s a living park in a very old Chinese style - lots of cool shops, temples, cafes. The old gardens are simply amazing, with very unusual architecture, statuary, even the doorways are unique! It’s a 100% Must for Shanghai!

title: Great place to explore.
content: Great place to explore. Nice little shops and tea houses. Had the most amazing buns here.

title: Lovely gardens
content: Really nice gardens with many old traditional Chinese buildings, good place to take pictures, rmb30 entrance fee, well worth it!

title: A must see
content: Enjoyed my visit here, had a lovely time meandering about in this garden looking around. Lots of time to take photos, it wasn't very busy so ideal. Guide book recommended it and I would say it is a 'must see' whilst in Shanghai. Have a look around the old town too whilst in the area and the city Temple nearby too.

title: Local culture
content: great spot to walk through to see local elderly chinese playing games, dancing, and practicing martial arts

title: A fun place to visit but very touristic
content: This place is always z hit when i take people visiting shanghai

title: an exceptional garden - a real must for every visitor!
content: Garden and tea house - looks peaceful and absolutely beautiful - must be lovely when the white Wisteria comes out in the Spring.

title: China Culture Feature Spot
content: The Building of YU GARDEN is China Culture Feature Spot, The garden is really big, and it a lot shop selling a lot of ancient things, the yu garden is memorize China ancient history, I suggest all of you must go there.

title: A must see!
content: Follow the bridge with 9 curves and be amazed by the architecture from the Ming Dynasty. View men on classic old boats clean the ponds which are filled with large numbers of fish and beautiful water lillies

title: Beautiful gardens in a busy metropolis.
content: This is a welcome escape from the hustle and bustle of the city but beware the scams in the area. I also found this very crowded and selfies galore at every corner. I appreciate that this is the case with all touristy areas but at one point I couldn't even stop for a second without butting into someone's picture which was irritating. Not quite the relaxing vibe I was looking for!

title: nothing special
content: there are many tourist (especially Chinese) in Yuyuan Garden but you can eat many authentic food outside

title: The Yuyuan Garden
content: This is where I fell in love with Shanghai... for me - was the best part of my trip! Here you can shop, eat, and revel in Chinese culture. It’s a very busy place but worth the hustle and bustle!

user_loc: 菲律宾苏比克湾自由贸易区
title: Culture in the middle of a concrete jungle...
content: If you every go to Shanghai, don't forget to go to this area. I think this is the only area where part of the Chinese culture, and architecture is preserved. coz if you go around, you will be surprised that everything you see around Shanghai are tall, modern, buildings. this area would be a nice breather. make sure to allocated more time when you plan to visit. theres a lot of people traffic and a lot of walking...love the experience

title: Tourist trap
content: We went to the Yu garden for their famous Siu Lung Bao. We were disappointed, with the wait to the quality of the product. Other people we talked to, said that they are milking it through their reputation and there are better places to eat them.

title: Well Worth a visit
content: These gardens are well worth the visit. Although can be rather crowded. Set among ancient buildings and temples. Very historic

title: Beautiful garden
content: Went here in the early morning everyday I was in the city. It's beauty and peaceful helps you centre yourself for a busy day ahead

title: Crowded and touristy but has to be done
content: Nestled in the middle of modern Shanghai is Old Street and the Yuyuan Gardens. Avoid the tourist shops and purchase a pass, allowing you some reprieve from the crowds. Yuyuan Gardens is constructed as a maze, allowing it to feel larger than it is. There are lots of old-style pagodas and covered bridges, carp ponds and sculpted trees. It was bitterly cold and drizzling when I went, which may have impacted my mood. It was good to see it and I'm glad I went but maybe I was expecting more. I liked Qibao much more.

title: Very nice but...
content: ... not the best garden in China. If you're visiting Shanghai that's a must, if you've already seen other gardens in China (e.g. the concubine garden in the forbidden city in Beijing) you've probably seen a better place.

title: difficult to find in the bazaar
content: the garden itself is beautiful and serene, but to get there you need to pass a very busy bazaar with highly agressive marketing. it may be frightening at times. better not to go there alone and hold your belongings close to you.

title: China adventure
content: This is a unique garden with beautiful trees and bonsais, i highly recommend it  if u visit china, this is a must see place

user_loc: 佛罗里达科勒尔盖布尔斯
title: Magnificent!
content: This is a lovely place to visit and spend a while admiring Chinese landscape design, We visited in the rain and that curtailed our experience somewhat as several of the surfaces were slippery. But very worthwhile nevertheless.

title: A Garden in mist of modernisation
content: Yu Garden or Yuyuan (in chinese, misnomer to called it yuyuan garden which literally mean Yu garden garden), is a place of a traditional/classical chinese design/architecture build garden. Simply amazing and a sight to behold. It is make more heartfelt knowing that the garden was build 500 years ago by one Pan Yunduan for his parents to rest and enjoy a beautiful scenery. (Yu literally mean soothing/happiness). The visit will be more meaningful if one visit with a local guide, as there is almost no direction/guide for visitor.

title: Eating at the Palace
content: Can you imagine that you were enjoying the food at the Chinese Palace? Here is the place you can look for a wide variety of Chinese local cuisine. The building's architecture is really amazing. It is suitable for you to come during day or night.

title: Gorgeous
content: Restful, beautiful, imaginative—this garden is a must-see in Shanghai. Beautiful structures surrounded by trees, rock formations, and ponds. I can easily spend two hours here and walk out feeling more peaceful than I have in years.

title: touristic but to be visited
content: Clearly recreated but in a very good taste. The atmosphere is nice and at least it reminds of China. Better to close all those junk-food kiosks!!

title: if you go, go with a tour guide
content: I went alone, around the Yu Garden is very nice, especially at nights the stores are cool and the style is unique, next day I went to the Yu Garden but was very crowded and also confusing, better to go with a tour guide, there are many outside..

title: Nice way to spend a couple of hours
content: It is hard to believe that the garden is in the middle of the city. I did not like that it was surrounded by street hawkers and markets, but I guess most tourists like the convenience. You do need to pay to get in but it is only 30RMB.Once you are inside the paid area, there are a lot less people and you could actually walk around and enjoy the beauty of the garden. Look for the dragon head on the wall. It's kind of fun.

title: A glimpse in the Chinese living in the past!
content: A must see place if visiting Shanghai. Garden built about 400 years ago by rich Chinese family for their retired parents to enjoy, went through many royalties and has interesting Chinese architecture, flora and fauna, ponds and an interesting rock collection!

title: Packed with tourist, unable to enjoy the view!
content: We went during the off peak season (according to the locals) and it was still packed with people! The sceneries would have been great without swarms of people blocking it. Not their fault, just too many people in a space too small. But there were lots of dining options available that sells authentic local foods (soup dumplings, xiaolongbao, etc) recommended by locals.

title: Lovely
content: Absolutely place to visit. Beautiful and amazing place. Peaceful eventhoug there we lots of tourist. In january no queues. Ticket price is reasonable

title: Fantastic!
content: Great feeling of history to this place. Unfortunately, a number of areas in disrepair but the architecture is superb and well worth the visit.

title: An exemplar garden, get a tour guide for your visit!
content: Is it worth a visit? Definitely yes, because it is an exemplar Chinese garden, situated in the Chenghuangmiao area, which is by itself an eye porn already.

title: All we know about "Chinese big family"...
content:
It shows the history of Chinese family lifestyle.  Really elegant.  Highly recommand!
The must see place!

title: Travelling
content: This garden is absolutely gorgeous. I would definitely say it is worth a visit. It doesn't cost much to go in either. It is also in a great location to do other things like visit the temple and go try some street food and nose around in the shops.

title: Well worth a visit
content: Nice gardens, relaxing, so attractive they were visited by many student artists who were trying to capture the tranquil atmosphere of this attraction. Worth a visit just to see the reflections of the temples in the many garden ponds.

title: A place with tranquility in busy Shanghai
content: A very pleasant area in the center of this busy city. You can experience a little bit peace even if there are a lot of other visitors. Nice place indeed!

title: A must see in the Center of Shanghai!
content: This garden has a lot of very cool sculpture like the dragon wall so make sure you look up it outlines the very top of the wall in several places. A nice change after the hustle and bustle of the city in November! It was crowed but cannot even imagine what it is like in spring and summer....

title: So relaxing. You can hardly believe this exists in the middle of Shanghai.
content: This garden, and home, are just amazing. There are properly preserved history and you can really get a sense of the living arrangements of the ruling and aristocratic families.

title: Incredible Ancient Garden
content: Well worth the visit. Substantial infrastructure - bridges, rock formations, pond, trees, numerous buildings, and walk paths.

title: Well worth a visit even if busy
content: The last time we were here was in the middle of Typhoon Wipha in September 2007 and what a difference! Then it was practically deserted and quite magical with the biggest rain drops in the world dripping off the beautiful roofs. This time it was glorious sunshine but heaving with people. We still managed to find the odd nook and cranny where the tour groups didn’t visit so you could pretend you had it to yourself. Despite the crowds it was still worth visiting as there’s lots to see. My favourites were the big dragon on top of the wall and the pond teaming with koi carp. A must see when in Shanghai.

title: A beautiful - some times crowded - oasis in Shanghai
content: The Yu Garden is a beautiful oasis in Shanghai. You need to spend entrance fee, but it is worthwhile. Being a nice place in China, this means, LOTS of tourists are coming, that transform the experience of a quiet garden to sometimes that of a football stadium. This is sad, and makes the place less romantic than it could be. Still: very much worth the visit

title: Relaxing on a Monday morning
content: Almost skipped this because of warnings that was crowded and uncomfortable to visit. Went to on Monday morning which ended up being good time to visit because it wasn't very crowded at all. A bit of peace in the middle of a bustling city.

title: Good place to visit
content: The garden leads us from market to inside and that's interesting to do window shopping and mostly to be bargained.

title: Simply stunning
content: Set along side the market sector the gardens offer a tranquil escape from the crowded narrow streets. We went during autumn so the yellow leaves of the gingko tree has started to fall. Such an brilliant and memorable sight to see along side the buildings and other fauna. The ponds with coy carp are also a sight to see.

title: paradise among 26 Million
content: Phenomenal...Serene, historical and awestruck If you have the time, visit this site from 1559 AD. Opens at 0845. Ig on the weekend get there early as the line builds quickly. Leisurely stroll through the gardens and enjoy the beauty

title: Inner-city oasis
content: This park was so quite and relaxed, even with hundreds of tourists walking around. It made for a nice break from the busy city. We went with a guide who explained to us about the history and buildings. It was nice to have the context.

title: Beautiful but touristy
content: Beautiful place. Swarms of tourists. You have to pass numerous junk dealer stalls to see the gardens. Recommend a visit, but you need to go early in the morning!

title: Fun
content: This is a very touristy place and I bet you can buy most of the stuff sold there from Taobao - however, the buildings are interesting to see, and you do feel that you are back in the Qing Dynasty with the buildings and the layout. Love the dumplings at 南翔小籠包 and the sweet dumpling 寧波湯糰 in the 湯糰restaurant there.

title: A bit Too fake!
content: Well, if you are in Shanghai looks like being in the oldest place of the city, it's a pitty the place is mostly fake, nothing really old inside and be carefull if u wanna get a tea in the tea shop in front to the entrance....high class price..:(

title: Authentic
content: Authentic is the word that comes to mind when trying to describe Yu Garden, felt like traditional China. Plenty of place to grab a coffee and walk around and get some very nice photos. When i t gets darker the buildings light up and it gets even more beautiful.

title: My favorite place in Shanghai
content: You Gardens offer a shelter of quiety in the cosmopolitan metropolis of Shanghai. Absolute worth visiting.

title: One of the few old "antique" area in Shanghai
content: One of the few old "antique" area in Shanghai. Most "old" places in Shanghai dates around the 1920's, Yu Garden area is from several centuries back. A must see touristic area of Shanghai. Full of old buildings, small shops, tea houses, snack places and restaurants. Full of character and well worth a visit.

title: Different kind of garden
content: Our guide, Harris Gu, took us here on our first day in Shanghai.

title: Not my place of interest
content: My wife wanted to see the garden. The garden is well kept but is just not my taste of interest. It would be fruitful if you go in with a guide to explain to you the history of this garden. Without knowing the story of this garden is a-bit boring to walk through the pavilions, pond, man-made rookeries and cloisters. Visiting during autumn would give you another perspective as the leaves turn golden yellowish which is beautiful.

title: Must visit Yu Garden if you are in Shanghai
content: Interesting place with lots of interesting tasty snacks and foods. Beautiful Garden. Don't go too late. Too crowded and it got dark early (~4:30pm) there when we went in 11/2017. Then, it's not easy to catch a cab late at night and no more hop on hop off bus. We walked like 30 minutes back to our hotel.

title: Beautiful formal gardens
content: This is a definite must-see in Shanghai. The gardens are very beautiful, laid out with many paths and alcoves, like a maze. There were carp ponds with wooden walkways, cloistered passageways and many rock features. Very few carved statues featured in the Chinese formal gardens we saw. Instead large rocks were displayed, naturally twisted into strange shapes or grouped with the aid of some discrete cement.

title: Beautiful old Chinese mansion
content: Visiting Yu Garden to be best without guild, otherwise will be too rush to see the place. Very well maintain and clean. 2 to 3 hours is recommended for this place, you will never regret and amaze with how the rich in ancient Chine live they life.

title: Relax and enjoy
content: Peaceful gardens with lots of unusual features, but by all means go on a weekday when its not so crowded. I was there on a Sunday when many of the locals and tourists were there. Wedding photos being made and just the number of people made it difficult to enjoy, but well worth seeing. I saw it as part of a guided tour of the city, so uncertain about the pricing.

title: Relaxing and Quiet
content: We walked the Gardens during the day and they are very well kept. Very peaceful with lots of locals exercising.

title: OK Garden
content: This is in slightly off the centre of Shanghai. Full of shops around the Yu garden but selling same items!! Yu garden itself was just OK. Nothing spectacular because it looks old but not very very old and the garden was not kept in good condition. You can see that this place hasn't been well kept. If you haven't seen much China then this place may give you certain wow factor but not after 10-15 minutes. I was a bit bored after 15 minutes or so.

title: Nice old garden
content: We maybe didn’t see it at its best in the winter months would have liked to have seen it when it was in full colour but was very nice to walk around, the fish were amazing

title: Peace in the city centre
content: This beautiful garden is a tranquil haven of peace in the centre of the busy city, but go early in the morning if you want to experience the tranquility and peace as it fills up fast.

title: Highlight of old  Shanghai
content: Go early in Morning as gets very crowded.allow atlas 2 hours to walk through the Gardens and visit the Halls

title: An oasis in the city
content: To find the garden you need to enter the old town shopping area, find the old tea house, cross the zig zag bridge and there’s the garden entrance! It’s an incredibly beautiful garden with tons of nooks and crannies to explore. So lovely and pretty peaceful even full of tourists.

title: Spectacular
content: Beautiful gardens, bringing you back in time. it's a must visit while in Shanghai. Walk around and take your time...do not be in a hurry. Absorb the beauty.

title: Crowded, shoppers and foodies paradise
content: Interesting mix of stores from Dairy Queen to dumpling. Plenty of items for tourists and shoppers. On a Sunday, a bit crowded on walkways. People are used to that. There are always some hawkers selling items directly to people, likely USA tourists. Old architecture too.

title: Beautiful Chinese halls, chambers and garden!
content: This is a beautiful garden and highly recommend for couples and families. You can get to the garden by taking the Subway Line 10 and get off at Yuyuan Station and exit from Exit 1.

title: Old China
content: Great place to see old face of China with the history and culture behind. A different face from skyscrapers and technology that is overwhelming at the center of Shanghai. A must go to see the culture of old China.

title: Admire this place !
content: Yu Garden (Yuyuan) is one to be admired. It is beautiful garden . It was crowded when we visited but still we could enjoy walking and get the special atmosphere.

title: Nice architecture.. hard to find.
content: This spot is very rich in architecture and beauty. We rode the subway to Yu Yuan station and got off. There is a huge maze of markets surrounding the garden making it very difficult to find the entrance to the Yu Garden. Once we found it, our visit was wonderful.

title: Avoid! You see no garden but humans cramping each other!
content: Just don’t go if you don’t like to be cramping around with crowds! I was there during the supposed to be low season but still the crowd was unbearable! You get nothing out of visiting this place. There were nicer garden at Shanghai just don’t pick this one, it just too much to handle and it just not worth it. If you may just go around the vicinity of this place for souvenir shopping.

title: Beautiful But Busy Setting in Old Town Area of Shanghai
content: After walking around the old town streets we ended up in the tranquil setting of the Yu Garden. If there werent hoards of people it would be very peaceful place to be. It is very cool to see some of the very tall buildings outside this very ancient place. It was probably the most beautiful of the gardens I visited in China. Take your time and enjoy

title: Gorgeous
content: The Yu Garden was beautiful!! We loved seeing the history and architecture. We went on a day and time that seemed to be very busy so wished I had time to go back and have less of a crowd. You definitely want to see this on your visit to Shanghai. The area around the garden is also filled with fun shops and the zig zag bridge that are fun stops too !

title: Watch out for "Tea ceremony" scam
content: I found the Yu Garden and surrounding area to be the dirtiest tourist area in Shanghai and was not impressed by it at all. Big shopping area with a little garden.

title: Great place to visit
content: We got the MRT to Yu Garden which was pretty easy to negotiate. We were told it is best to arrive early which was a good tip. Great place to get a sense of the old Shanghai. The gardens are very serene with lots of areas to look at. The area outside of the gardens is surrounded by tourist shops and restaurants.

title: Limited fun
content: It is very nice to see the garden, but not as big as you would expect. Therefore its quite expensive (40 UN)

title: Restful
content: You could quite happily sit here for any number of hours. Always people around but there are little niches to hide away in for a while.

title: Very peaceful
content: We had a spare afternoon and went to enjoy the peace and solitude its was a great afternoon loved the place a typical Chinese garden and so cheap!!!

title: A peaceful oasis in a bustling mega city
content: Carefully planted and maintained these gardens provide a rare but tranquil oasis  in this bust bustlig city

title: What a delight
content: Despite the crowd, we could feel how relaxing this garden would have been when it was in private hands and appreciate the efforts that must have been made to restore the garden after the ravages of the second world war.

title: Brilliant at night
content: Everyday one sees many tour groups visiting Yu Yuan garden from morning until night. Yu Yuan garden is brilliant at night. Enjoy the architecture, the lights, shopping, eating, people watching,  walking across the bridge.

title: Beautiful Piece of Chinese Architecture and Fung Shui
content: The place itself is very well preserved and has a lot of history and stories

title: Yu Garden- Shanghai
content: If going to Shanghai a visit to Yu Garden is a must see site. The architecture of the site is stunning.

title: Nice place to visit
content: Yu garden and its surroundings was a pleasant suprise. We toured the city using the hop on hop off and decided to stop here. There are many traditonal streets around the area worth venturing. The grounds before you enter have many stores and reataurants. The steam pork buns and crab soup dumplings stores each had very long line ups but we had to try it and as expected very tasty considering its massly produced. Can easily spend 3-4 hours in the whole area.

title: One of the beautiful and interesting places we visited in China
content: A beautiful example of structural art. One can spends hours looking at the intricate detail. Our visit ended in a marketplace that added to the positive experience we had.

title: Beautiful gardes
content: This is a place where you feel at peace.  So beautiful worthwhile spending time to go an see if in Shanghai

title: Lovely Gardens
content:
Worth spending some time walking around these beautiful garden which is full of history.
The gardens are within the market area where there are lots of shops and eateries

title: A very nice, typical Chinese garden
content: This very nice garden is more than 500 years old and it offers a nice visit! Many typical statues and the vegetation is really nice. One warning - be ware of pickpockets when you walk through the market!

title: Cool afternoon activity
content: Moderately priced tourist attraction. The gardens are vast and fun to explore. The surrounding bazaar is fun to walk through, but mostly just sell the same stuff in every shop.

title: Must visit
content:
Beautiful garden setting to meander around. 
Check out all the different “rooms” and different doorways which lead to different views and gardens.

title: Serentiy within a huge tourist area
content: Yu gardens is on the must do sites for Shanghai and it didnt disappoint. Located within an area of Yuyuan market - huge walking streets full of various shopping and food outlets which is bustling with tourists so finding the entrance to the gardens was difficult until a gorgeous volunteer lady speaking perfect English gave us directions. We pleaded over 65 (we are) and got a discount on the entry fee.

title: Great historic garden to visit and relax
content: A very nice and relaxing place to go if you need a break from the busy city. Good for travellers who interested in history and architecture. This place is recommended.

title: Classic gardens in the very center.
content: This zone is famous for the impressive gardens, but since it would be impossible to see all them, you shouldn't miss this one in the very heart of the old town. It has all the classic elements which made the Ling gardens so popular, plus it is a great place where to detox for a while from the else bustling atmosphere of Shanghai.

title: More fun outside than inside the garden
content: Outside you can walk, eat, see a small lake, a beatiful construction so you may think that paying to see inside the garden it's a good idea, but it's worthless

title: Tradition in the middle of modernity
content: Shanghai is a great city, very modern and caotic. This is very traditional area where can find relax in a very nice spot. Of course is very touristic.

title: Wonderful secret place in the heart of a busy city
content: This is a lovely place to visit and shows Chinese history in a beautiful setting. It is well described although a tour guide is a bonus. It gives a taste of ‘hidden Shanghai’ and is highly recommended.

title: Very quaint and touristy
content: If you have one place to shop and eat - this is the place.  One could easily spend four or five hours here...eating authentic Chinese food, taking in the shops and buying gifts, taking a break at Starbucks.

title: Great place!
content: The gardens were beautiful and very traditional Chinese in the middle of a built up city. Get there early to enjoy the peace before the crowds.

title: Too Crowded but must to see in Shanghai.
content: Too Crowded but must to see in Shanghai. But careful with pickpocket mainly during the weekends that is usually crowded. But nice to see and have so local food just to try some street foods in China

title: Well worth a vist and gives a real feel of old time China.
content: We first went here with our guide, but enjoyed it so much we went back on our own later in the week. Even though it's not huge, it is laid out in a clever zig zag path, so it feels much larger and you see different views. We were there in early winter and there was still some lovely late Autumn colour on the trees, especially the Ginkgo trees. I took lots of photographs, it's one of those places that you can catch lots of good angles etc.

title: Nice garden!
content: I highly recommend visiting this place with a tour guide.

title: Terrific Fun for a First Shanghai Experience
content: I love Yuyuan Gardens and all the surrounding marketplaces, although I can see how for some this is not a real Chinese experience. If you just go with the flow (and crush) it can be great fun. The gardens are very nice, and while there are much better Chinese Gardens to see (try The Humble Ambassadors Garden in Suzhou) these are lovely for a first time visitor. The surrounding market places are visually fabulous, if no longer fully authentic. The Tea House in the centre of the market area (in the middle of the pond) is a must-do for people gazing and just immersing in the environment. The tea is expensive, but the experience is terrific – I took my elderly parents there and they loved the atmosphere and respite from buzzing crowds. The markets expand for ages all around so if you’re not into the hard core tourist stuff, just keep wandering in the direction of the Old Street Market and things start to get more authentic. This is a tourist attraction, so expect as much but enjoy the madness as well.

title: Beautiful Garden with Chinese Feels
content: Love the Yu Garden. With the tall buildings surrounding Shanghai, this one made me feel the real China was. I also love the food stalls outside. The garden has small lake and it's nice to take pictures.

title: Too busy and too much rock to be a good garde.
content: Were taken here as part of a tour.

title: Interesting gem
content: A delightful garden and with the benefit of a guide we learnt a great deal about the history of Chinese gardens and this lovely place. It is tranquil despite crowds and has lovely water features and huge rocks that must have been a trial to transport. The Chinese seems to have a fixation for rocks! Fish not a lot of planting and formal buildings to meet your visitors or to see others and so forth all reflected the time and social organisation of society then and the changes to now

title: Piece of local history and place to learn
content: Highly recommend to take time for a guided tour through that historic parc. Learn amazing background information about Chinese culture, signs and believes.

title: The last chinese buildings in a modern city
content: I think yu garden is a must!!! Shanghai is a very moder city but it has nothing to do with old China... this area is the only place where you can get the feeling you are in china of many years ago! Building are great but it is very crowded

title: Not a must visit
content: Too crowded, dirty streets. The local food center was so-so and overpriced, don't waste your time there. The only spot to recommend is the Lu Bo Lang restaurant, delicious food & dim sum with good service. Vegetarian food available too.

title: Did not see the point of this.
content: Went twice, thinking I must have missed something... really nothing here to see though. A bit sad as was hoping!

title: It's ok
content: If you have extra time, sure check it out. It would not be on the top of my list for Chinese gardens. I guess coming from California we are spoiled with gardens in SF Golden Gate park or LA's Huntington Library, best one I've seen is in Portland, Oregon. It's not that well maintained and no, not because it's "really old". Most areas need some repair or a fresh coat of paint, the grounds and plants also looked like they need some attention. The garden also lacks information or historical background for key spots in the garden. When I visit Chinese/Japanese gardens, I enjoy reading about what's so special about this funny rock sitting here, why it's positioned this way, what's note worthy about this arch way, etc. Yu garden is major lacking in this area. If you just want to wonder around and take pictures, sure this will do.

title: Historic and Must See stop in Shanghai
content: Our visit to Yu Garden was very enjoyable. Despite the crowds and “touristic” feel, the history and architecture is truly stunning.

title: Nice place and lots of nice food!
content: Its a nice place to take lots of photo with family and friends, especially with the architecture that shows the ancient culture of China's building.

title: A fairly average garden
content: I last visited this garden in 1987 and had fond memories of what it was like then. Unfortunately now it is surrounded by a theme park area of fairly new buildings built in the old style. What a shame area has been changed so much. Once inside garden very crowded and not really as well cared for as I remember in the past.

title: Loved strolling around the garden
content: The visit to the Yu Garden was certainly a memorable one! It was like walking back into history! Worth the visit!

title: Very Good Gardens
content: Worth while to visit, reasonable access fee and close to "old China's shopping." The gardens, ponds, pagoda are well kept and very clean. Weekends are very busy in fall

title: Astonishingly Beautiful!
content:
Visited the gardens on a sunny afternoon with my girlfriend. The scenery was wonderful! Lovely architecture and history throughout the gardens.
So peaceful and quiet, very relaxing.
Bring a picnic and enjoy the surroundings!

Make sure to get a student discount!

title: Peaceful taste of old Shanghai
content: One of the few spots in the city where you can get the old Shanghai experience. The garden is a decent size and peaceful compared to the chaos on the outside.

title: Tradition preserved
content: Beautiful garden crisscrossed with water in between made it a refreshing place to visit. The handicraft shops were plush and unique though little expensive.

title: A wonderfully bizarre experience of the new and old...
content: 1. Unless you're fascinated by crowds ;-), never go on a weekend.

title: Old China in the middle of modern Shanghai
content: Classic, historic, go early to avoid crowds, a lovely morning if not too crowded. Also, worth getting a tour guide if you can.

title: Definitely should be on the things to do list...
content: ...for shanghai. But be warned - go on a Monday or through the week (which is busy but not mobbed). Don't expect to get a photo next to something on your own at the weekend - rammed with Chinese and foreign tourists. The streets surrounding the Yu are interesting too - bustling shops and market traders looking to haggle with you for business. The Yu is an oasis of calm in a manic city with lots of tradition chinese architecture, gardens and a performance stage too with singing or demonstrations. Some nice shops too and I picked up a lovely necklace with my wifes name hand engraved in English and Chinese for a bargain £18! If you've been to Japan and experienced their ornate gardens the Yu is not as good but still a spectacle worth seeing when in the city.

user_loc: 印度尼西亚班贾尔马辛
title: Family trip
content: Nice place. Many shops. So many trees in the garden, love it. The road signs are very clear. Yu garden @line 10

title: Could have spent a day here
content: The gardens were great and our tour guide Ocean provided a great tour. There is quite a bit of history here and repetition of symbols (mirrors, vases, bats, and other animals). A very beautiful garden (although crowded) in the middle of the city.

title: Beautiful peaceful park.
content: Very busy but well worth the visit. Gardens are beautiful and would be gorgeous in spring with many blossoms. Architecture interesting and sculpture and art awesome

title: Lovely, but very crowded.
content: This is a lovely garden and the buildings are quite amazing, but the crowds were oppressive at times.

title: Touristy
content: Lots of pedlars and vendors selling souvenirs and fake stuff.

title: An oasis of calm
content: Right in the middle of a bustling street but once in the garden everything changes. Peaceful and calm. Well worth a walk around to see interesting buildings and bridges.

title: Hidden gem
content: If you want a fast set of great photos, this is the place to come! Not as busy as the surrounding streets as you have to pay a small entry fee, which is well worth it!

title: Must visit when in Shanghai.
content: The temple area is packed with tourists from all over the world and is crazy busy most of the time but well worth the time and bustle.

user_loc: 新罕布什尔州贝德福德
title: Beautiful
content: This is a uniquely beautiful restored garden. Thanks to the modern government, the destruction from the Cultural Revolution here was minimized and much has been nicely restored. Go to see if you want to understand about how gardens where put together in that time period.

title: Gorgeous gardens but very crowded
content: This is one of the nicest gardens in Chine from what I have been told , and I can't disagree . Maybe because when we paid our visit or the time of the year but it was very crowded , specially to get through the market to get in to the gardens which was a shame not to be able to admire everything in peace . A blessing was that we had a very good guide Judy Zhu who explained all the very important spots , buildings and artifacts .

title: Really worth to go there
content: Seriously no words can describe this place's beauty. It is a must-seen destination in Shanghai, especially if it is a rainy day. Very easy to go there just take metro line No.10 and exit at Yuyuan garden station then take exit 1 and walk a little bit then you will find souvenirs market. The garden in located inside this market ( follow the signs you will not get lost ). Ticket cost is 40 RMB. Once you enter the garden you will feel like the garden is taking you back in time and history.

title: Great place to relax!
content: Very nice place to relax in midst of extremely busy Shanghai! Nice small food stores (try crab dumplings for 20 CNY), local shops (try locally produced hand creme), and beautiful garden!

title: An interesting step back in time
content: From the modern to the old. Well preserved with so many interesting buidings and rooms. The chance for a presentation tea tasting where the variety of flavours and ways to prepare will astonish. Another plus if the Silk Museum and chance to but the betterquality items you may not find in the underground markets.

title: Good place to visit
content: Part of my China Trip- we spend 3 hours. it was a good experience and the family liked it very much.

title: A garden inside Shanghai
content: Not soo old as it seems to be. Beautiful place. Beautiful garden.Very touristic and crowd. You have to negociate the prices if you want to by somethings.

title: Lovely piece of nature in town
content:
More than worth a visit when you are in town.
Easy to find from the Bund. Walking distance.
40Rmb entrance fee.
A visit takes about an hour

title: Love the energy
content: The place is an absolute gem with a peek into Chinese culture and lifestyle. This is not for those who like quiet and peace. The lanes leading to the gardens are an attraction unto themselves and you can see scores of people eating , drinking having fun. If you are new to China, this is a good enough place to begin, although you may not visit a second time. The shops are also fun even if you do not buy anything. The gardens are crowded but lovely and could imagine the Chinese emperors enjoying a quiet cup of tea and the peace. The peace is gone , but the tea is very much available in the 200 year old tea shop. The quaint bridge leading to the gardens was crammed with people and there was also a photographer with a printer who has set up shop selling photos for just 10 yuan. Strongly recommend to go, but do so with an open mind.

title: Beautiful Gardens
content: Well worth seeing. The history is always interesting in these gardens as they were once the compound of the rich dynasty. They have been taken are of and are a beautiful place to visit as a tourist or resident.

title: Visit to Yu Gardens
content: A great place to visit. Probably allow about an hour and half to walk around and take photos.

title: Yu Yuan gardens .......
content: This is a nice example of a classical garden in old China style and is well worth a visit to enjoy the ambience that these places give. The garden has many buildings overlooking lakes full of brightly coloured koi carp , duly fed by tourists, and very large pieces of limestone rocks and boulders , some portrayed as sculptured art. Amazing place to spend a few hours , but very busy.

title: Breathtaking
content: What a sight, amazing views. Visited with a big group, didn’t have to q, perfect opportunities for scenic pictures

title: Tour
content: Our tour took us here and it was breathe taking was one of my top 10 visiting China. Another must in my opinion when visiting Shanghi.

title: Gorgeous chinese garden! Felt like chinese alice in wonderland!
content: Tricky to find initially, had to ask around using my translator app. But once you find the garden hidden among the ancient Yuynan market ...its just wow! Gives you a great perspective on chinese garden style, unique jade stone caves and you feel like lost in a maze at times, which is fun when you let yourself flow in the garden, connecting with the vibe of the several water streams, lakes and ancient chinese huts! must visit attraction when in shanghai!

title: Yu Garden
content: Spent a lovely afternoon here. You definitely get more of an experience with a guide. Less crowded in the afternoon.

title: The garden in the middle of a market .
content: Go early to avoid the crowds if possible , interesting place to visit.

title: Superb example of traditional Chinese garden
content: The garden is a truly amazing experience albeit for the hoards of tour groups that can make it tough to reflect on its composure and beauty (and we were there on a week day). The problem is that its located in a major tourist precinct and getting to the entrance involves navigation through the contemporary version of a market bazaar with the associated pedestrian congestion. Never the less, to find some moments of quiet in this garden is enthralling. We can learn from such ideas around 'separation' and 'borrowing' in application to contemporary landscape design and architecture. A must for any visitor to Shanghai.

title: Too crowded
content: There was alot of people when I went there. I wasnt able to take a good photo but the place is good for sightseeing. I ate steamed bun from Nanxiang Restaurant and I liked it.

title: Not what we expected.
content: From the name, we expected typical Chinese gardens (and spent trying to find such a thing!) The Yu gardens are nice to visit but we didn’t spend too long. A quick picture is enough

title: Stunning place but crowded
content: I loved the place, but really crowded when we went in the afternoon maybe better in the morning ? But it was also a weekend day. Entrance fee is 40 or 50 rm . If you are in the neighbourhood definitely go there !

title: Beautiful but busy
content: The gardens are beautiful and totally worth seeing.....but try avoid the weekends because, like everywhere in China, it was MOBBED

title: Yu Garden
content: We caught a taxi to the garden and were impressed with the architecture and design of the garden and pavillions. The markets were fun for a bit of shopping too.

title: Must see in Shanghai
content: This is the quintessential Chinese garden, full of pounds, fish, traditional Chinese houses and more. It's a great place to go wether with friends and family or on a romantic date.

title: Beautiful Rock Gardens
content: This is a quiet get away among the old shopping district.  Nice to go after warding off the hackers trying to sell you stuff.  The garden is lush and mostly rocks. Be careful since it is easy to get lost.

title: Beautiful Place to Walk
content: We had a guided tour of YuYuan Garden.  Very beautiful walkways, gardens, small streams, very old trees.

title: Awsome
content: Beautiful a must do when in Shanghai! A magical place with awesome views.  Saw it as s part of a tour.

title: Good place for soup dumplings
content: Went on Sunday night and got good soup dumplings. Also nice area and in walking distance to the bund

title: Yuyan Garden
content: Established in the Ming Dynasty over 18yrs and surviving 2 wars they are a popular tourist attraction in Shanghai.I made the mistake of going on a weekend and it was very crowded.Admission is 40 yuan.Metro Yuan Garden Exit 1 turn right walk to the end of the street and then right again.You actually weave your way through hundreds of shops.Very few signs at all in English.Fortunately a few of the shops owners spoke a little English and I eventually found the way.

title: Fascinating history and flora
content: Very typical Chinese garden, much different from a lot of Western design and layout. Having a guide helps with history and context

title: Very nice part of town
content: I love this part of Shanghai. Ok it's touristy but it's well done none the less. Whether it's by day or night it is normally very busy and of course there are endless amounts of touts trying to see you watches etc but that is part of the charm.

title: easy to spend hours here
content: The gardens are beautiful and unlike a lot of Japanese gardens I have visited there were actually lots of places to sit and rest and enjoy the sights. It was teeming with tourists and everyone was quite well behaved with no jostling but simply finding their own place of peace to relax.

title: Beautiful rockwork and gardens
