title: Perhaps the oldest attraction in Shanghai
content: This garden is beautiful at any time of the year but it gets very crowded, especially on holidays and weekends

title: Great garden in heart of the city
content: You need to get past the crowds outside and pay to get into the garden (about 20 or 30 yuan). Most people go to the buildings outside so massive crowds can gather there. It is worth paying to go into the actual garden itself.

title: Gotta See It But....
content: If you like crowds, come. If you like quiet and restful? Naw, and it's never quiet and restful. If you have to see a garden on your quick tour, well, then, OK, but if you have any time a spare, check out others in the area.

title: Peace and harmony
content: Take a few time and go to see this place! It's calm and beautiful! Its a nice spot to visit! We can take good pics but like many others places there are a lot of tourist...lol

title: Fun shopping in a traditional styled complex
content: This is always a good place to unwind and do some people watching and shopping.  Plenty of local stores in a architecturally beautiful complex.

title: Worth a visit when the crowds are low
content: Spent a morning roaming the food markets and enjoyed a fabulous tea experience at the tea house near the Old Temple. Crowds always impact the overall experience though, so I'd recommend timing your visit when crowds are low.

title: Nice landscape but beware of the shops
content: I would only recommend you to visit the garden for taking photos and enjoying the Xiao Long Bao restaurant and some well known shops or restaurants. Please do not engage in any sales or bargain with the locals. And do not believe any luck draw or free gifts shop.

user_loc: 阿根廷布宜诺斯艾利斯
title: A peaceful place to visit
content: This is an excellent place to enjoy, with many pavilions, ponds, bridges and some gardens.

title: Old Chinese tempel in middle of city
content: Easy to access since it is in the city. Closest metro station is less than 1 km away and there is a lot to see during the walk.

title: Beautiful rocks and ponds, quiet escape from the crowds
content: The bazaar was an absolute zoo, you could barely move and we were about to leave when we saw the ticket booth for the garden itself. It was much less crowded and the scenery was really interesting, with huge goldfish in the ponds and oddly shaped arranged rocks.

title: Popular Place
content: I visited on a weekday when it was a little less crowded. Initially, I had a little trouble finding the entrance, but once I found it was really cool inside.

title: Lovely gardens
content: I took my parents here as a bit of quiet time, at their request, although I did think it wouldn't be particularly quiet. Despite the crowds, it was easy to walk around and find quieter areas. Some traditional Chinese style buildings, although not a lot of information about them. We managed to catch on the back of a few tours going around the garden which sounded interesting, and meant we learnt bits and pieces. However, it's more than doable on your own with no guide.

title: Lovely place to visit
content: This was more than I expected.  Beautiful gardens with lovely decks with lots of sitting benches to soak in the beautiful setting.  Nice relaxing place to visit.

title: Go early to avoid the crowds
content: We did a tour and we were picked up at out hotel 08.00 on Friday morning, and taken on tour around Shanghai that included Yu garden, we got to the garden at about 09.00-9.15 and walked around the outer area and then went into the garden, there were very few people around that early. We returned the next day mid morning before lunch and it was extremely crowded

title: Great place to visit in Shanghai
content: A very beautiful garden. You can see old buildings, chinese architecture, flowers (spring), some old artefacts.

title: Missed it :( was closed
content: We headed down late afternoon, really looking forward to this but the information on the internet was inaccurate and it was closed . SO poor rate due to information but it does look an excellent place to visit. We did find it a bit tricky to find the entrance too

title: Beautiful - get here when it opens.
content: I went to these gardens on my first day in Shanghai and was not disappointed. Beautiful combination of trees, rocks, water and buildings. I read other reviews and got here when it openned at 800 (Saturday), and had no issues with crowds. However other travel buddies of mine went a couple of days later around noon and had a much different experience. I think the crowds can ruin the experience. Do yourself a favour and it make it the first item of your day.

title: Lots of crowds
content: Visited the Gardens as part of a Wendy Wu tour. When we visited, it was a Chinese Family festival time, so it was very busy. You felt you just followed the queues around. Beautiful buildings and some interesting statues of dragons on the roofs. Not very nice toilets..very smelly. Located in the middle of shops/markets and you can easily get lost trying to find your way out.

title: Must see.  One of the last remnants of old Shanghai.
content: I went with a guide which really helped as the peddles left us alone.  The beauty and history of the garden was amazing.

title: Shanghai high light
content: This location was part of our tour, very impressed with the architect and the beautiful lay out, peaceful place.

title: Crouds!
content: Its full of people, this is crazy. Somehow destroyed my impression. Its rather bazar than garden, but maybe we saw just part of it. Go, see and run from there!

title: Calm in the midst of chaos
content: The Yuyuan Garden is such a serene spot yet surrounded by the mad bustle of city life. Beautiful landscaping and calm ponds with colourful Koi.

title: Lovely traditional gardens set in the old part of Shanghai
content: It is a lovely garden, and I've been to it several times. I think it's a must-see for first time visitors to Shanghai. Personally I now go for the peace and quiet, to get away from the chaos of the Old Shanghai shopping complex around it.

title: One of the highlights of our trip to China!
content: These gardens are spectacularly beautiful. Even on the grey day that we visited it was so gorgeous. It's like a maze and you could spend an entire day there but it's definitely worth a visit when you're in Shanghai.

title: Overrated
content: It's a good place to go to pick up souvenirs and trinkets. Nothing special. Too touristy for my liking. I would not recommend you on any of the streets food.

title: Harmony and Tranquility
content: We loved our visit to Yu Garden. I was in awe of the attention to detail in design, and decorative features on the buildings and the beautiful gardens. Visit in spring when the cherry blossom and peonies are flowering.

title: Great place to visit.
content: If you have a couple of hours spare this place is worth a visit. The gardens are interesting with lots of period nooks and crannies to while a way time finding.

title: YuYuan Garden and Bazaar
content: YuYaun is good for a short visit. It's a pity this place has been "destroyed" in the name of development. The architecture is beautiful, otherwise, it has become far too commercialized.

title: Tourist Trap
content: Tons of people not that interesting. Garden looked to be recreates throughout. Nothing special to see. I've seen much better Chinese Gardens in the states and Canada.

title: Loved It
content: This place I loved, Nothing more tranquil to walk around a beautiful garden in a bustling city and this one was a beauty.

title: Amazing place
content: The best place in shanghai. Take your student card to get a discount at the entrance. is crowded. (is china).

title: Tranquil location, great food nearby
content: The Yu Garden is a very beautiful and tranquil location, filled with interesting walk ways. Right outside of the gardens you'll find some of the best xaio long bao in the city.

title: Must-see, but full of tourist hordes
content: This is a lovely garden, but in the middle of a touristy district and alway packed with crowds. Try to go during an off time of day to have a more pleasant experience.

title: Beautiful gardens
content: Beautiful gardens to walk around and take pictures.  The shopping area is also right there.  Lots of low end knock offs.  Shop keepers were pushy.  There are lots of typical places to eat lunch.

title: beautiful, but you have to choose the right time
content: I went there on chinese new year's day, and i thought all the chinese people were here- it's super crazily crowded.

title: Old Shanghai
content: After passing the colonial Bund with its neoclassical and other foreign buildings built before 1949, and its vibrant waterfront, it was an adventure to go by foot into the old winding alleys of Chinatown. There is the usual tourist shops, but the silk shop located in the basement had offerings of duvets, and scarves. At the end of the old town is Yu Yuan Garden. The Garden, part of an estate in the Ming Dynasty, shows off the traditional red walls and upturned tile roofs of that era. It is less of a "garden" in what we expect of a garden.

title: Yu Garden
content: This is an area of 2 parts.  The gardens themselves which were beautiful, and the shopping are which was very busy and amazing.  Well worth a visit.

title: BEAUTIFUL
content: We were lucky to visit in spring time, so the weather was cool and foggy but many of the plum and cherry trees were just starting to blossom. The beautiful combination of buildings, plants and ponds make this one of Shanghai's best sights.

title: It is a town made into a sudden, but I feel the emotion.
content: Yu Yuan Garden (garden) is a city made as a tourist destination. To me who knows the old Shanghai, it was not enough. However, huge buildings and brooks can make us imagine the old Shanghai.

title: Shanghai show
content: My favourite place to visit have lunch in dim sung reasteraunt , tea in a tea house where president clinton went , whole area is old china the gardens are worth visiting but area full of 000s of little shops but prices negotiaable whilst the art booths allow a present with a difference

title: Beautiful. Amazing. Add to your List!
content: What a beautiful walking journey. Our teenage children enjoyed this as much as we did. This is a great spot for those of just about any age, except small children as there are some rocks, and areas where they will really need extra supervision.

title: Too crowded but...
content: It is beatifull.you can walk and sit and take relax.you can come early to have a peacefull time.stones,trees,water.

title: Not overrated
content: Only overrated if someone tells you this is a must see. The garden is next to Old "Chinatown" and the combo of the two is really nice. We really liked our tour and explanation through the garden and I think that it's important to have a guide. Makes it much more interesting.

title: Overrated
content: I would not bother going here.  It is way too touristy.  Just go to one of the many beautiful parks in Shanghai and enjoy the peace and quiet.

title: Wonderful Gardens!
content: Thoroughly enjoyed these wonderful gardens. Tucked away in bustling Shanghai, they offer a peaceful and beautiful spot to visit.

title: You Gardens
content: A beautiful garden, possibly one of the oldest places in central Shanghai that you can visit. Although most of the building were restored in the 1870's, this does not detract from the tranquility of the gardens, it is also the only place in Shanghai that I heard bird song.

title: Very nice
content: I recommend this location to see.you can see traditional and old China here.  A painter man is here who paint with his finger without any brush or pencil !

title: Lots of interest in busy environment
content: Had a very different day shopping sightseeing and people watching.

title: Tourist spot
content: Fun place to get cheap souvenirs and soup dumplings. It is one of "the" big tourist spots, but you still can't count on finding English speakers. Beware of 'tea ceremony' scammers. Most vendors are very nice.

title: Scenic garden
content: A must visit place in Shanghai. History merging with old architecture. This place takes you into history just stones throw away from skyscrapers of the modern world .

title: Really interesting part of Shanghai
content: Wonderful architecture with lots of shops and eateries. Is one of the stops on the hop on hop off bus. Even a Starbucks. Lots of tourist souvenir type stalls.

title: just beautifull
content: hangzhou west lake is more beautiful than yu garden but th area and shopping around is very good and price are very good

title: garden in shanghai
content:
I visited this place , many people but not so much good,
i seen old stones and any build in wood ,nothing too much interesting.

title: Impressive solace.
content: Despite the crowds outside the gardens, once inside -- I still found spaces of solace and quiet beauty.

title: Crowded
content: The entrance to the garden is found inside....a shopping street. We were busy searching for the garden when we realised we had already reached it...its interesting even if its not something "not to be missed"

title: A little paradise in a hectic city
content: The Yu gardens are a delightful place to visit in Shanghai. Amid the hustle and bustle of this large city is a bit of peace and tranquility. Even the way to walk to the gardens is full of surprises and provides an opportunity to see how many live and work in Shanghai - it isn't all cosmopolitan and glamorous but extremely interesting.

title: Great Architecture and Street Views
content: Well worth the visit but very crowded. Lots of hawking by vendors which was really annoying.  Water is not very attractive, very brown.

title: Reminiscing the Centuries old garden
content: An ancient and old garden previously owned by prominent figure at that era. Garden is segmented into few sections of gardens, fish ponds, homes and communal hall for the family. Visitors can view closely sculptures of woods, stones and floorings. Majestic trees, flowers and scrubs trees are planted all around the garden. There are souvenirs shops inside the garden selling antics, jades and other souvenirs of many kinds. The place can be crowded with visitors and beware of pickpocket.

title: Nice garden in the center of Shanghai
content: The Pagode type buildings with nice tea houses are building an excellent character and are really a place to visit when in Shanghai. Most of the time it is a really busy location as it is a place to visit for Chinese and foreigners alike.

title: Old World-Looking Charm
content: Visited one evening while on a business trip to Shanghai as this site was rated quite highly by Trip Advisor reviewers. The garden was closed but there was plenty of area to walk around in. Lots of shopping but as a westerner, I was accosted by several watch sellers on the street. The buildings were beautiful even though they were replicas. It was quite crowded and lots to stimulate the senses. Worth a visist when in town.

title: Beautiful oasis in a megacity
content: The ponds, tress, flowers and attractive buildings in this garden are a beautiful respite from the bustling city that surrounds the gardens. A real gem.

title: Beautiful, but too crowded
content: This garden is nice and well-located, but small compared to the huge crowd that visits it on weekends.

title: Cultural trip
content:
This is a complete travel in time. The China that you know from the movies.
Tip - go early! around lunch and DO NOT FORGET YOU CAMARA.

title: Lantern Festival
content: Lantern Festival is great, but there are way too many people, you must be prepared to spend 3 hours on it.

title: Complete lack of signage
content: i rate this experience as poor, but not the attraction itself. Once you find how to actually get inside the garden walls, the attraction (what i saw) was pretty special.

title: As gardens go, highly over rated.
content: Not sure what other people were rating this place on. If you look at my profile, my main attraction is nature and natural places. This fits neither. I guess the attraction is that it is old and historic, which is nice but a fantastic beautiful garden it is not. Crowded, not peaceful and it is really really hard to find!!! Why? Because you have to go through a gauntlet of thousands of souvenir stands, winding paths to find it. Actually, this was the best part of the day-- great places to eat and some nice artisan and craft places on display plus the other "tourist" trap stuff. Again, as with most of the Shanghai, it really is a "Chinese" tourist site, little western help or signs. Even most of the tourist stuff is directed at the Chinese-- which is great-- they seemed to be having a good time, so was I. But, would i go out of my way to go here? No, it costs a little bit of money, which i don't mind paying, but there is a very nice "free" garden 1 block down that is peaceful, beautiful and truly a garden. If you spend a half hour here you are doing good. Old rocks and hundred year old wood structures, not even that nice compared to the rest of Shanghai is what you are looking at. I guess, from a preservation concept, a historic saved garden for the people to experience their history-- that is a good thing. But to say this is an excellent example of Chinese gardens or architecture is very misleading. Sorry for the negative review, but after all the reviews definitely expecting more. It is very small; i like a peaceful place but with the crowds taking selfies it is not from a western perspective. So, if you are in town, need something to do ok-- but definitely do not take a tour here or go out of your way except to shop. it closes at 5 so be careful of timing.

title: Family trip.
content: Good for exploring this old Traditional and nice cultural heritage, with many shops selling souvenirs of old Shanghai and Silks & Shawls aplenty for bargain buys. Nearby restaurant Serves Good Olde Dumplings wrapped in Meat & Crabmeat & roe and the Soup in it is good but careful not to get burn on your lip and tongue. Local name for this Dumpling is Xiao Long Bao.

title: One of the mist amazing places ever
content:
It will take you at least 1,5-2 hours.
Amazing garden, created during 5 centuries! Beautiful spots, interesting historical facts, amazing way to spend your time in Shanghai!

title: A must do site in Shanghai
content: Don't be misled but the name. This is a large area of Shanghai that provides an well maintained architectural snapshot of the early 20th century. Its very tourist oriented but still worth a visit. Inside the garden is the Ming Dynasty era garden which is amazing given it was created in the 15th century.

title: Wonderful garden have to visit
content: Yuyuan garden is very big area, there is a garden, palace, village, store, restaurant and cafe. We can buy everything here...!

title: New tourist area
content: A beautiful garden surrounded by lots of tourist shops and stores.  The gardens themselves are beautiful with many interesting parts.  Very unique "dragon-like" wall...with unique story behind it's modification.

title: Nice Garden, better without crowds
content: A nice example of the courtyard garden style made famous by the nearby city of Suzhou. If you are only visiting shanghai, the "Yu Garden" area is a must see place for tourists, reminiscent of old shanghai. The area is full of old architecture, old shops, street foods and chinese souvenir shopping. The garden itself is actually often overlooked, many people do not actually go inside. The garden is a very nice place to visit if the crowds are not too bad; try and visit during weekdays rather than weekends. If you have a deeper interest (and available time), a day trip out to the masterpieces of landscape architecture in Suzhou will be even more impressive.

title: Wow!
content: I was most delighted to see a little bit of something entirely Chinese in a high-rise city like Shanghai. Loved strolling here and finding little bits 'n' pieces of -probably- future garbage to spend bargain-sums of Yuan on!

title: Beautiful 500+ year gardens
content: This was beautiful and we really enjoyed shopping for souvenirs after visiting the garden. There were many things to choose from. There is even a Dairy Queen there! Beware of the pan handlers and their quality. It's best to buy from one of the store owners.

title: Wonderful gardens
content: An oasis of peace and quit. The garden is situated in a crowded area where tourists from all over China visit the various tourist attractions. To enter the gardens you must pay a small entrance fee and as soon as you are in, everything is very peaceful and serene. The landscaping is beautiful and there are many antique buildings (some as old as the16th century). We wanted to stroll around in 10 minutes or so but we stayed for almost two hours to enjoy the gardens.

title: Beautiful old garden
content: it's a must see garden if you are in shanghai.It's old architecture but unique.It shows Chinese lived wealth in the past.

title: a quick summary of China's former architecture
content: Impressive chinese garden architecture. Provided a quick glimpse to how rich Chinese lived hundred of years ago.

title: Avoid unless you want your pocket picked or be ripped off
content: This place preys on tourists, stallholders have dollar signs in their eyes every time a tourist walks past. It's full of tat, overpriced rubbish and pickpockets. Avoid - there are plenty of other places to go.

title: Do Not buy souvenirs there!!!
content: It is a nice place however DO NOT buy any tea sets or souvenirs there! They are not good quality and you can find the same in the area 5 times cheaper!

title: A must of Shanghai
content: A very crowded Tourist and shopping area with little restaurants in rebuild houses There is a fee to get in the bamboo garden. The other is free.

title: Saturday walk
content: Very impressive ambience of Chinese gardens including buildings. It's a shame such beautiful place deserves better care by local administration.

title: Time Well Spent in Shanghai
content: We went on a morning tour that included the Yu Gardens.  Even though it was busy, I enjoyed it a lot.  I still remember the ancient chairs made out of tree roots...amazing!

title: Yu Garden with Jenny's shanghai Tours
content: This is a beautiful garden and is a must see experience while in shanghai. Contact Jenny at Jenny's Shanghai Tours for a day-long personalized tour of the gardens and other must-see locations in Shanghai. Jenny or her colleagues will meet you at your hotel and give you an unforgettable day-long experience. There are many parts of this garden that most people never see and a guided experience helps immensely.

title: Very pretty
content: Sounded by recreated Chinese traditional buildings housing a myriad of tacky tourist stores and 'street' food the garden was an unexpected delight. A beautiful space that offers some insight into the lives of the weather but not royal families of ancient China. Worth a visit.

title: Beautiful even on a rainy day
content: Simply lovely garden with a rich history. Even though you can enjoy all the sights on your own, I had a much better appreciation of the experience with a guide. There is a lot of walking (some covered areas). The trees, shrubs, and structures are lovely. There is also the famous Huxinting/Tom's Tea House in the middle of the pond.

title: A haven in the busy city
content: So nice to experience some peace and gentle beauty within the modern city of Shanghai. We missed the spring flowerings, but it was still a lovely place to see.

title: Poorly-maintained garden
content: The garden itself is not so clean, and not as pretty as the gardens you can visit in the towns outside Shanghai. But the stores outside the garden make for some interesting browsing.

title: Deserves Its Reputation
content: Located in Old Shanghai, this oasis in the middle of the busy, cosmopolitan city is a joy to visit.

title: Wonderful Get-A-Way in the Heart of Shanghai
content: This tranquil garden area is a great place for individuals and groups. You will need to meander through MANY market stalls and vendors to get to the main gates. If you have one, make sure to bring your student card for a discount. Oh, and don't forget your camera, comfortable walking shoes and umbrella or rain jacket. It will most likely be very crowded, but it is worth a trip. NOTE: ground is very uneven cobblestone - take care. I noticed people even had difficulty pushing strollers. Also remember your water bottle and snack. If you forget, there are plenty of vendors who will gladly charge you double what you would expect to pay. Expect to stay at l3ast 3 hours, unless traffic is light and you are quick on your feet.

title: Wonderful visit
content:
We really enjoyed the Yuyuan garden in shanghai, 
amazing architecture and a  very beautiful planning.
Lovely trees and ponds and beautiful golden fish

title: Light decoration wonderful
content: Easy access by subway. Beautiful light and art decorations. Good experience to see CN traditional stuff and culture

title: Lovely place
content: It's incredibly crowded, if you expect to take a photo and not have anyone in the background photobombing, let go of that expectation. You can get amazing things in the market and it's a very fun experience.

title: Yu Garden
content: It would have been better if it was Spring or Fall.  I will visit this place again if I return in Springtime or Fall! However, it gave me a picture of how the rich people in China live.

title: Garden of pagodas, ponds and dragons.
content: Tardis like garden containing many, many pagodas and pavilions, ponds with huge Koi, bonsai trees, be careful not to miss the main part of the site which is accessed by a small entrance through the rocks to the right of the entrance - it would be easy to miss this part of the gardens. This is a real photo opportunity, the many zig-zag bridges, pavilions, koi filled ponds, dragons and stone door ways give unlimited chances to take some perfect holiday photos! The gardens seem slightly uncared for but I feel this actually adds to their charm. The entrance to the gardens is quite difficult to find - in the middle of the market - but do persevere as they are well worth a visit - quite unique. The koi are something to behold!

title: Yuyuan garden
content: Beautiful traditional garden dated back about 300yrs, around the area there are hundreds of shops selling items from silk scarves to all sorts of souvenirs and antiques. Plenty of eating places to try, recommend the tea room on the bridge and the xiaolongbao place just opposite the tea room.

title: A must visit while in Shanghai
content: To be honest this is the only place in Shanghai where we experienced old China and we loved it. We visited Yu Yuan Garden in the mid-week and it was raining, this was a good excuse to avoid the crowd :).

title: Oasis in the City
content: A lovely tranquil garden - such a surprise in this bustling city - highly recommended. The rock formations are fascinating and there's plenty of flora and fauna to enjoy.

title: Worth the visit to gardens
content: If you go to Yu Gardens spend the money to go to inner garden and get one of the students to give you a guided tour.  It's free and it helps them with their language skills.   Very nice gardens with many unique rock features.

title: Lovely relaxing scenery
content: A beautiful garden kept so well,if you go out of season you can wlkround at your own pace. The Golden Fish are huge as visitors often feed them.

title: Amazing
content: Don't miss out -- in busy and westernised Shanghai the Yuyuan is just one of the last preserved traditional places left to see in the area. Don't miss out!

title: Don't bother unless you like to be squashed by tourists
content: This is a place best visited in the morning before tens of thousands other tourist poured in. The Old Temple area outside the garden is jam packed with tourists with all walks of life from all over the world. Many small shops selling gifts and souvenir, traditional jewel and gold, and local snacks. If you have not been there before, one visit is more than enough. Try avoid weekends or public holidays, or you will feel like a sardine in a tin.

title: Beautiful example
content: Enjoyed walking in this area and could imagine it when it was not a tourist attraction. Serene and peaceful.

title: Nice garden
content: Very nice garden right in the center of the city. However it can get quite busy during the day, therefore, it's best to visit early in order to appreciate the peaceful atmosphere.

title: Beautiful garden
content: Amazing traditional Chinese garden in the middle of the city with an interesting story of a historical events.

title: Suprisingly bigger than anticipated.
content: This garden was amazing, even in the beginning of Spring. Only a few of the blossom trees were showing any colour. In another couple of weeks, the garden would have been in all its Spring glory.

user_loc: 南卡罗来纳美特尔海滩
title: Great historical site in heart of Shanghai
content: Yu Gardens are a historical gem in the heart of Shanghai . Unfortunately you will have to fight large crowds through a shopping area to get to the entrance . The cost of entrance is $ 30 yuan and there are great historical buildings , rock gardens , bridges and koi ponds . It would have received 5 stars but the crowds and what I believe better maintenance could help but with that said I am glad I went .

title: Beautiful garden, lots of interesting nooks and crannies!
content: This was a wonderful little quiet place in the middle of a huge city! Yes, it was crowded but so well worth the stroll through! Make sure to read the signs and learn all you can about the garden unless you are on a tour! Loved the dragon wall and all of the quaint buildings. Must see!

title: Its a peaceful spot in otherwise crowded Shanghai.
content: Its a peaceful spot in otherwise crowded Shanghai. Just don't go on the weekend when its overrun by millions.

title: Nice place but crowded
content: Excellent place to visit but expect huge crowds! Place is beautiful but packed with people, at least on the day we went. A lot of craft and food stalls all around so interesting place to sightsee.

title: must visit place in Shanghai
content: this is one of the many must visit place in Shanghai. It does get extremely busy during the weekend so I suggest to avoid it then unless you like very crowded place. There is plenty of shopping to do if you want to. Souvenir shops,....

title: City Retreat
content: This is a nice garden to relax during the week, do not go during the weekend as too many people and the crowds are a dampener for relaxation. Dong's dumplings are absolutely fantastic with the local green tea from Zhejiang province. lovely old buildings from yesteryear.

title: Scenic tour of Yu Garden and attached market
content: This beautiful garden was much lovelier in reality than photographs can capture. We spent more time here than I originally thought we might, because it was so enchanting. A private guide doubles the artistic appreciation of this site. Former residents of Shanghai all recommended the Bund, Yu gardens and Shanghai Museum as must see sites.

title: Can't be missed if only for a couple of hours.
content: This place is very popular among Chinese tourist. If you go during any of the China holiday periods it will be jampacked with people from outside of Shanghai. On one of the streets are about 10 stalls that have some hand made unique items. Honestly speaking those of the only things actually worth buying, unless you're looking for trinkets to bring back home, and there are many shops with the same stuff.

title: A garden within a metropolis
content: What a surprise and pleasure to "discover" this garden inside the city in contrast to the vibration outside the garden confines.

title: Spirit of China
content: If you wanna feel chineese spirit you have to visit this place. In the early morning hours you can feel completely different atmosphere beeing simultaneously in and out the big city.

title: Oasis in the middle of shanghai
content: Nestled inside the heart of Shanghai is this small oasis that will transport you into another world... the old world of the king dynasty. Don't get worried by the over crowded streets just outside... just get in. You can spend hours but about 60-90 mins is good enough. Peace within urban chaos! Must visit

title: Peace amid the noise and pollution.
content: Tea was over $10, but it arrived with a big thermos of kai shui (boiled water) to add as I wished to the already steaming cup full of leaves; three small eggs (quail?) hard boiled in soy sauce; three pieces of plain, warm tofu (the firm kind), and two pre-packaged sweets--one like a Japanese mochi, and a tart, candied fruit no bigger than my thumb with a rather large seed inside. It was an interesting snack. Along with the treats was a sealed packet containing a fresh-smelling moist towelette, with which I gratefully scrubbed my hands and sweaty face. (I visited Yuyuan Gardens in 2013.)

title: Amazing little Gem in this huge busy city. Make sure not to miss the world famous Xialongbao.
content: Amazing little Gem in this huge busy city. Make sure not to miss the world famous Xialongbao the lines can be crazy long but if you are lucky it will be only 30 minutes. The place is great in the day time but it really is amazing at night, the illumination make it look magical. The Xialongbao is an amazing little Gem absolutely the best if you love dumplings if not skip the long lines.

title: Nice, but very crowded
content: This place is no secret and especially in the area in front of the entrance are many many people. You can also find a lot of shops in this area and people trying to sell as much as possible. The garden itself (30 rmb entrance in the off season) was not that crowded and you could find some quite places. The place is beautiful and a "can do" for Shanghai if you want to see something else than crowded buildings.

title: Beautiful
content: Awesome place to visit very busy with lots of tourists but still great to see. Lots of photo opportunities. We didn't get to spend time at the market shops which annoyed us. Recommend going here.

title: Lovely garden in early morning: beat the crowds by 9 am!
content: The gardens, towers, and pavilions are really beautiful and peaceful. But in order to enjoy this site the fullest, come right at opening time, 8:30 am, so that you are not hindered yet by crowds and loads of tour buses!!!!!

title: something unique
content: We went to this place and found it interesting and preserved despite the developing places in the city. It is a nice place to just relax, enjoy cool air ...

title: Beautiful haven of calm in busy Shanghai
content: The Yu gardens are a haven of beautiful tranquility. Busy in the late afternoon, the gardens are a collection of pavilions, walkways, ponds and garden that give you an idea of the grandeur of old Shanghai.

title: Average place: Do not have high hopes
content: We went to Yu Gardens after 10 months of living in Shanghai. The Garden is a "must see" when you search Shanghai tourism map but i believe it is more due to the fact that Shanghai has very few places with Historic links, unlike Beijing. It is a nice little garden with old pattern buildings, Ponds, bridges, corridors and archways and impressive rockeries... there are tiny carvings and sculptures. But the whole point is that it all finishes in at most 30-45 mins... it's at best just a glimpse into ancient china art. If you are hoping to be taken back into time and be amazed... do nit get your hopes too high... if you have an evening with an hour of walk through ancient chinese structures, nice pools (with lots of fishes) and if lucky some old fashioned music show, and take some pics for your memories then it is a nice place.

title: Worthwhile to visit
content: Many shops and snacks stalls.  $30 admission fee to get into the actual Yu Garden.  15 mins walk from Yu Garden MTR station.  Also close to ChengWang Temple.

title: Nice garden but too commercial
content: Garden is very nice and typical Chinese. However, the traditional Chinese ambiance it is a little bit destroyed by all the commercial stands, mostly streetfood.

title: Very nice
content: This was what we imagined China would be like.  Very nice but also very crowded.  Don't let the that keep you from a visiting.  It's well worth dealing with the crowds.

title: More Than Just A Garden
content: The touristy, but fun crowded shopping area is worthy of a good look around. Lots to see+lots available to buy+sellers are willing to deal, do not accept first price.

title: Worth the visit
content: The gardens are a great place to visit with many little areas of buildings and ponds. It was raining the day we went, which in some ways was good as it meant not too crowded! The shopping outside the garden is always very busy but there are lots of interesting buildings and perhaps a few bargains at the shops.

title: Must do in Shanghai
content:
cannot go to Shanghai and miss the Yu Garden !
I lived in Shanghai for 5 years and even after so many years I keep going to Yu Gardens during the weekends! 
It can be -very crowded, but .... that's China!

title: Underwhelming at best
content: Visited here and stayed only for 20 minutes - too many people and underwhelming, poorly cared for garden.

title: interesting area
content: We arrived here at nightfall very jetlagged so didnt get to enjoy the garden as much as we would in daylight. There was still lots of activity, and pretty things to see. There are nice restaurants, as well as walk up stalls. Same with shopping - nice shops, as well as street vendors of junk.

title: A "Must See!" for any visit to Shanghai
content: Designed for the Tourist experience, but an excellent introduction to what is available to buy and what food and buildings are like in the area. Lots of police in the area, which made us feel safe - much appreciated - but we never felt we would need them. All people friendly, just beware of people inviting you into a small shop where there are no other people.

title: Nice and peaceful place close to the Bund
content: Very nice place to spend a few hours walking around, old buildings next to modern Shanghai. Would be beautiful once trees start flowering.

title: Very relaxing
content:
This is a 16th century traditional Chinese garden in the middle of Shanghai near the "Old City". 
Worthwhile. Enjoyed the garden and surrounding area

title: Flowering Plum Blossom
content: These lovely gardens are situated in the busy China Town. We visited as the Plum blossom had begun to flower. Many ponds filled with huge Koi,lovely architecture,very peaceful.away from the hustle and bustle of China Town.

title: Classical Chinese Garden
content: Pales in comparison to the famed classical gardens in Suzhou. Nevertheless,  it is a good enough garden to visit when you do not have enough time to travel to the nearby city of Suzhou.

title: A fascinating maze
content: Lots of little buildings with rock arrangements, ponds or streams full of brilliantly colored fish, and picturesque little squares. Bring a good camera.

user_loc: 佛罗里达费尔南迪纳岛
title: Cool but crowded
content:
Tons of people so if you go early you will beat the crowd and you will enjoy it much more.   Take a camera as it was beautiful 

Beware of pickpockets outside the garden

title: Beautiful green spot in the middle of the city
content: A stroll through this garden is a good break from the bustling city. The settings are nicely done and you also get some info about the history.

title: Beautifull place, but very crowded during my visit
content: A lot to see and a very interesting view of chinese garden architecture. You can spend a long time walking around the garden and have a nice tea in the old tea-house nearby.

title: Beautiful but Beware of Crowd!
content: Yu Garden is beautiful, but rather crowded on weekends and holidays! If you want to go to the real garden, the admission is RMB40/person. The shopping area around the garden is worth visiting, particularly the Classic Street, which despite being very crowded has certain charm.

title: Serene & Peaceful Garden
content: Escape the urban madness of Shanghai to this wonderful garden.  Relax and unwind as you walk through the manicured paths.

title: Worth to go there for 1-2hours
content: I am living in SH since two years and lived close to the Yu Garden before. - It is a very hot spot for tourists and the area is super crowded.

title: Disappointing
content: Not expensive entry fee and rightly so. This is an ok way of spending 30 minutes but after that you've pretty much seen all there is to see. A maze of paths around some fish and turtle filled ponds, some (relatively few) trees and some nice architecture (nothing special) and that's it. There is virtually no information given to what any of it is. Go if you have time to kill but I wouldn't be making specific plans to see it.

title: Go!
content: Quite a large garden given its location. A few hundred years old with old trees, ponds and stone sculptures, shrines. It has numerous courtyards fenced by stone walls. A bit like a maze. Completely different feeling from busy streets of old quarter. Though many tourists. Nice for a walk or for sitting around and enjoying the views. Recommended.

title: Nice place, not too crowded
content: Walking in this garden is really nice. I really suggest to visit this place, even if some more information in the different areas wouldn't be that bad...

title: Must Visit for Shanghai Visit
content: this place is very very big & have so many stalls. you can find any thing which is available in shanghai at this big market. If you visit during chinese new year festival you can see all the festival activities. Very nice for shopping lovers

title: Lovely Enclave
content: Definitely worth a visit, and astonishingly peaceful given it is in the center of Shanghai. Try to go when it's not raining.

title: Oasis of calm in the middle of the city
content: It is right in the middle of a bustling city. And yet, once you enter, it is serene & peaceful. Lots of photo ops.

title: One of the most beautiful gardens
content: Yu Garden is one of the most beautiful gardens i have seen so far. It is very well maintained and has super photo opportunities. A must visit when in Shanghai.

title: stop over
content: Well worth seeing we had a one on one tour guide and that made it very personal. Be aware there will be lots of people in the gardens so it does get very crowded. It felt very safe though as the people were mainly Chinese families and tourists.

title: Beautiful !!!
content: This is an absolute must-to-visit place. Beautiful buildings and sculptures. Fantastic lakes with plenty of fish and turtles. But very crowded all over (but it`s Shanghai)

title: Pretty but too touristy
content: It was very pretty but the overcrowding from tourists ruins it. So loud and just impossible to walk even because of the crowding!

title: So crowded:(
content: Yu Garden is supposed to be peaceful with fish pond and beautiful trees, but with too many visitors it is hard to walk or even look around. So was a disappointment.

title: A peaceful haven in a bustling city
content: An insight into times gone by and very quiet whilst being so close to the hustle and bustle of the outside world and relentless traffic. Very tranquil and you can get an insight into traditional Chinese crafts. The artist painting Pictures by hand palm and nail was incredible, worth purchasing finished products.

title: A historical place for you to visit
content: A historical place for you to visit. The scenery is like the ones shown in Mandarin movies. There are many weird stones here too.

title: Beautiful!
content: Definitely worth the entrance fee. Went later in the afternoon in an overcast day. Still crowded but less than it probably would be on a sunny day or at midday.

title: Not as good as I thought
content: I did like the visit... But, it is definitely a tourist scene. You should do it, but; do not expect a wow experience. Nothing negative, just your classic tourist visit. I enjoyed the surrounding neighborhood (old town and back streets much more) Check it out, it deserves that.

title: Really pretty
content: Nice walk through from Bund, very near Old Street, nice to stop and see some green, well kept and very clean.

title: Was ok
content:
I guess it wasn't really my thing, garden was nice but was nothing spectacular.
Over rated in my opinion but I can understand some people may like it

title: A nice garden with a side of shopping
content: Its a beautiful garden, but I would say having a guide is essential. You can tour the fantastic gardens and afterwards, you can go for some shopping afterwards. Plus there is tons of food on offer :)

title: A jewel of a garden in the middle of the city
content: To get to this garden, you have to vault through an amazing array of shops and stalls after the taxi drops you off. But once you fight your way through, you'll find acres of green and water and pathways. All with a backdrop of Shanghai skyline. It's a wonderful outing both for city lovers and nature lovers. you get both!

title: Would have been nice to have a guide.
content: Beautiful garden to walk around. I just didn't plan enough to hire a guide so I will do that next time. Could have been more interesting.

title: Beautiful period gardens well preserved, unfortunately in the middle of a commercial mess
content: The general Yuyuan garden area is basically a fake construction made to look like some preserved set of buildings from the Ming dynasty. There might be some authentic element like the Chinese temple there, but most of it looks like it was removed from a movie set in the last decade. But ,,, the gardens are spectacular and a true representation of what would have been a family's or a scholar's private garden for reflection, discussion and contemplation. Like all Chinese gardens of this quality, much use is made of stone and seasonal trees. Paths wander through lovely arcades of plants and arching trees and, dependent on the season, a blaze of colour from variegated flower bearing trees. This really is lovely, but head for the park as soon as you can. You can experience the retail dross on your exit. There is a nice tea house at the end of the zig zag bridge, which does at least contemplate for the loss of authenticity. The temple is also worth a (paid) visit. Metro stop is Yuyuan Gardens Exit 1, follow the crowd.

title: Peaceful, but a bit of a tourist trap
content: It is "nice" with lower case "n". For the cost (40 RMB), you would expect more. The area is small, the bazaar around it is definitely a tourist trap, and the gardens themselves do not feel much different. Yes, it is worth going, but don't expect much.

title: A beautiful landmark in Shanghai
content: If you have not been to Hangzhou, probably this garden should not be missed. Seniors enjoy a 50% discount. Need to spend 1.5 hrs exploring the entire landscape. Do not go during the weekends as it is overcrowded.

title: A compact gem
content: This was by far the prettiest garden we visited in all the places we visited.  It is compact but spectacular.  Worth the time to visit, then combine it with shopping along the local streets.

title: Nice time for the weekend visits
content: I spend my one of the weekendin shanghai to visit to Yu Garden. The smallshops around the place are good tourist attraction.

title: Beautiful
content: This is a beautiful garden area in the middle of a bustling city.  Besides the gardens there are stores, restaurants and ponds.  I recommend a tea presentation while there.

title: Best preserved garden
content: This place is beautiful. Several traditional buildings, ponds full of dishes, amazing example of lavish traditional Chinese lifestyle.

title: Tourist Attractions
content: This place was so crowded for the 2 days I visited despite it was drizzling but everyone don't seems to be bothered about getting wet.

title: Peaceful and worth the walk around
content: Worth a little walk around to appreciate the centuries of history sitting in this garden. Watch for the cat who is amazingly friendly!!!

title: A maze of footpaths and pools
content: This is a tourist trap. The garden is more like a maze and I saw only shrubs and trees - no flowers although it may have been the wrong time of year

title: Old Shanghai feeling
content: Yu garden is a beautiful oasis in the middle of the hustle and bustle of the town, however do not expect it to be a quiet zen place even in the middle of the week. Entrance fee is moderate and there is always something blooming at every season. Forget about the antiques shops in the garden, they are overpriced but if is a must see on your trip.

title: Maze of water gardens and courtyards
content: THis is an extensive meandering water garden connecting a series of old meeting halls and courtyards - lovely to visit on a hot day.

title: A Must in Shanghai
content: We went on a Saturday and it was extremely busy but worth the experience. An intricate and confusing maze of streets and buildings. We just walked an explored the streets. Definitely a must if visiting Shanghai.

title: Quiet spot in the city
content: Visited Yu Garden while my husband had class in Shanghai. It was a little confusing to find since I walked from People's Square but once there it was a great spot. Beautiful buildings with large koi ponds all over. Only 40yuan admittance was well worth it. One restroom towards the back of the garden and only one "western" style toilet. Make sure you grab your TP when you come in the door! Nice gift shop with reasonably priced souvenirs. There are literally hundreds of shops leading up the gardens but I don't enjoy haggling in the streets so I preferred the set price gift shop. Spent about $45 US and got gifts for several kids. If you have a couple hours to kill this is a great spot. I would recommend taking a taxi here to avoid all the street vendors if possible.

title: Ehh
content: If your only visit to Asia is shanghai, than Yu Garden is nice to see, but coming from Japan and seeing numerous temples way more impressive I would say it's a waste of time. That said the area surrounding the gardens is full of shops so might be interesting for that. Super crowded though

title: The Old Amidst The New
content: The park is centrally located, and close to the Bund. What is amazing is the conditions as to which the grounds are maintained. This is not just in respect to sweeping and removal of any small debris but actually cleaning the nooks and sides of the buildings. Entering the park before 9am afforded the opportunity to beat the crowds, which is also recommended by other reviewers (completely agree). The pictures that can be taken without scores of people are much better earlier in the day.

title: Interesting rocks all around.
content: The gardens are in the Old Quarter. Our guide said it was built during Ming dynasty by a wealthy warrior to honor his father. Yin and Yan is very dominant in China and in this park there are ponds with red fish, red is a color of power and good fortune. There are several pavilions all built in dark wood.

title: Peaceful visit in a bustling xity
content: A supremely peaceful and relaxing area in the Old Quarter of Shanghai. Full of shaded pavilions, leafy trees and blossoms, and pools of fish writhing just below the surface. This is a site worth paying for, although we were informed it can be very busy.

title: Because we were there
content: low price for pensioners....nice water features and Koi,turtle interesting rock formations and small buildings...lots of people so you won't find it meditative ...its ok but don't go especially

title: Disappointing
content: Once you enter it, you want to leave it. Artificial crap with no flair. Just that it takes some minutes to find your way out in that labyrinth. Honestly, it is "interesting" to see that the made this kind of part, but just don't expect too much..,

title: Beautiful, calming area!
content:
This place was so very serene, and peaceful.
It was very well groomed.
One of the highlights included on our tour.

title: Heavy Love rain moment even.
content: lovely garden even . similar like Osaka castle in Japan. but i fall in love all building around YU GARDEN , even heaven rain that day but i was enjoy shopping in many shops. you can find several of souvenir here.

title: Beautiful garden tucked away!
content: Traditional Chinese garden! Beautifully ornate, Well manicured gardens, with big pond and little bridge. Some fish, a tea house and a Place to grab a snack. Worth the time really interesting history here.

title: Brace yourself the crowds are coming
content: Navigating yourself to the Yu Garden through the immense crowds of the surrounding markets is something not for the faint hearted.

title: A small green and old place in the heart of Shanghai
content: Small but scenic enough,

title: Wonderful
content: Amazing and quiet garden near the centre of the city. If you're hungry, don't forget to buy the Xialong bao, my favorite dumplings in China !!

title: Nice Gardens!
content: Nice gardens! I went around 1pm and it was extremely full with loads of kids (Chinese School Holidays) it was not the tranquil experience I was expecting. Nice if you have an hour or so to kill and 30 yuans in your pocket.

title: "Great historic place"
content: We visited the Yu Garden in June, it was not so crowded and the weather was also OK, be careful, can be very hot and very crowded, so take care of your belongings and be prepared for the intense heat. The place is very nice, I recommend you to arrive while there is still good light so you can enjoy the beautiful views of the buildings and visit the stores around it, you can find good deals. Then enter to the garden, you will see great historic places, nice vegetation and lots of fish in the water, it is definitely a place to visit. After the sun goes down, you wait to take some good pictures with the night lighting, it is also awesome!

title: Beautiful garden!
content: A lovely garden right near the centre of Shanghai. Definitely worth a visit to appreciate the rich history of this now so modern city.

title: Beautiful Chinese styled garden
content: Had heard about this place and as a keen garden I was very keen to visit. Very different to what I had expected. Lots of small garden rooms with rocks, bridges and well placed trees. So many photos taken!

title: Lovely Chinese Garden
content: Lovely old chinese garden.  very picturesque  Nice shady spots and shelter from the busy market next to it

title: A nice break from the citylife
content: This garden is tucked away behind the many old buildings in the area. It is deceptively large and a real treat!

title: Mmmm not a garden!!
content: I have to admit I was expecting a garden - you know plants and flowers. Far from it. Basically a tourist bazaar. If you want to buy some overpriced tat - this is the place to go. Very busy and quite uncomfortable.

title: Lifestyl
content: A treasure. Believed to be built during the Ming Dynasty and that's a good number of years ago, the charm is still retained . The rock gardens amazing , the architecture is amazing and it Must have being wonderful to stay here in the earlier days. Take a slow walk around the YuYuan. One can't rush if one is to immense into this place . Lots of visitors even with an entrance fee of RMB 30 or 40 depending when one makes the visit . If you're there for photos, be patience as there's loads of people and loads of folks who will photo bomb you ! .

title: Rude staff
content: On entry they refused to accept our international student ID's despite advertising discounts for students on a sign right by their head. The student ID's were accepted all over Beijing and the guy just seemed to want to be difficult.

title: Traditional Chinese garden
content: It is the essential Chinese part of the town, beautiful and charming, with a lot of souvenir shops and traditional food. Highly recommend to visit if staying in Shanghai!

title: Wonderful
content: Yu Yuan Garden was a great attraction that gave a remarkably different perspective on Shanghai! Away from all the skyscrapers and city lights these gardens were tranquil and lovely to get lost in for a few hours - lots of buildings, paths and ponds to explore - pay to enter but cannot remember how much - it was not a lot!

title: Well worth a visit
content: The Yu Garden is beautiful, peaceful and had great architecture. It was also a great place to sit and think in the heat of the day.

title: Beautiful garden!
content: The garden was a lovely place to visit with quite a few perfect spots for pics.  The gift shop, actually a mini museum was a great stop to view art that they sell from a variety of artists.

title: A garden with some architectural interesting things
content: Honestly I was expecting a bit more during the visit of the garden. The garden is essentially made up of tiny lakes, small bridges, lot of fishes and turtles, small pagodas as well as some shops (for tourists, which I did not like), a few corners for a couple of pictures but that is it. Entry ticket costs 40 yuan (Sep'16). After few turnarounds I got a bit annoyed what you see does not basically change along the path.

title: Touristy but worth a visit
content: Beautiful garden and rebuilt old town that is focused on tourism but worth a visit. A good place to spend the afternoon to wander around, buy pearls or souvenirs, have a meal, or visit the City of God or the Gardens. Watch out for pick pockets, and don't pay full price for anything, be ready to negotiate and walk away if needed.

title: Take a rest in busy Shanghai
content: This is really a heaven of rest in the busy centre of Shanghai. Our tour guide led us trough this amazing park. Beautifull nature and authentic buildings of earlier Chinese genatations.

title: Great chinese garden in the middle of shanghai
content: The garden (against a fee) is in the middle of the yu garden area. It dates back centuries but had to be rebuilt several times because palaces and temples burnt down. You can take some nice pictures with the skyscrapers of Pudong as a backdrop.

title: Chinatown!
content: the only western shops here are starbucks and mcdonalds other shops are all chinese which is a ggod change. Very crowded at night, pay to see the gardens, good place to sit and have tea in the balconies overlooking the streets feels like your back in time.

title: Beautiful
content: Unique chinese Garden, I went there with my family and that was so beautifel, there was a Chinese restaurant which provide excellent Dim sum. No sure why some people approached us ask for shopping Chinese tea, but overall experience was excellent.

title: Escape the hustle and bustle
content: Had lovely relaxing walk through the gardens, with plenty of people watching opportunities. We watched the residents do Tai Chi, practice Kung Fu, sword play, crack whips and play Mah Jong. It also has a great kid's ride area, if you have little ones. Very attractive gardens right in the CBDs and a great place to just chill.

title: Unique Chinese Garden
content: Truly authentic Chinese rock garden in Shanghai. They have special attractions for Lunar New Year. You can spend many hours walking around and looking at all the natural formations and taking pictures.

title: Beautiful!
content: You wouldn't know you're in the middle of a huge city when you reach the gardens. They are amazing, the temples are fantastic. A very good day out!

title: A taste of old Chinese section of Shanghai
content: The garden itself is okay but the rows and rows of shops just outside the attraction is worth the visit. The siao long bao here is reputed to be the most authentic in town.

title: Excellent Place to Visit for Authentic China
content: As an oversea Chinese person, I recently visited here with the intention of reliving my childhood. I am particularly impressed by the authentic Chinese scenery. The shops are very well organized and the restaurants are classy and a great place to refresh yourself.

title: Oasis within a busy tourist district.
content: It took us a long time and many inquiries to find Yu Garden nestled amidst tons of shops. Signs are a bit cryptic, perhaps so visitors would spend more time shopping. Busy as it was, it gave us an idea of what a classical Chinese garden contains. Interestingly, this lovely garden is comprised of many smaller components (buildings, courtyards, gardens) and does not have any single expansive area.

title: Beautiful Gardens in the City
content: We visited this location during the day and it started to rain, so we had lunch at a nice restaurant and decided to return a different time. We joined business associated in the evening to this same location that evening only to find it beautifully lit and blanketed in street vendors and panhandlers. It was still very nice to visit as we returned the following afternoon to tour the gardens and temples.

title: Good to see but VERY Crowded
content: There are hundreds of hundreds of shops around the garden and there are thousands of visitors both Chinese and foreigners. Everybody's trying to sell us something all the way. The old Chinese architecture was worth a visit but would be much better without lots and lots of tourists. The garden itself was magnificent actually.

title: Fascinating
content: We had a private tour guide to take us around the old town and the Yu garden. Compared to the hustle and bustle of the old and new city the garden is a tranquil retreat full of history. The guide (in English) allowed us to fully understand and ask questions about the history of the beautiful area of Shanghai.

title: Nice gardens
content: This would be a very peaceful place for reflection and rest if it weren't so crowded. Interesting buildings, nice gardens, fish ponds. Located next to a tourist shopping area.

title: crowd detracts from the calm surroundings
content: A beautiful oasis in the middle of a busy city however, there are many tourists walking through this site right along side of you.  Worth the visit but possibly lacking the calm intended.

title: A quiet place in the middle of the noise
content: Loved the traditional wealthy house not so topical in Shanghai. Well worth. A visit . It is an isle of peace in the busy surrounding.

title: Amazing classical garden
content: An amazing garden in the heart of Shanghai. Surrounded by the old town with many shops. Close from the metro station. The fees is 30rmb if I recall correctly. Bought jade earrings from the shop inside.

title: Beautiful Landscape and History
content: If you are into Ancient Landscape Arcitecture, then Yu Gardens is for you. If you would like to walk around in a cool environment on a hot day and take in some history, then this is a nice stop. Stroll along the paths and find little alcoves and seating areas to just sit and take in the beauty, and the nature. The Architecture of the buildings is classic as is the craftmanship. The sculped figures that adorn the eaves and roof lines are incredible. I would suggest going on a NON-HOLIDAY weekday when the crowds are at a minimum so you can enjoy this feature. The paths and seating areas are small, but everything flows fairly well. I really took my time and spent about 2 hours there taking in the serenity of the surroundings. I think this would be very boring for children, except to run around the winding paths. But great for the many couples that were there. At only 30RMB for the entrance fee, this was very reasonable and well worth the price.

title: One of my fav places in Shanghai
content: While we loved to stroll on the Bund, Yu garden was perfect destination to see some old chinese building in the city. I bought some fridge magnets from the shops outside. Also bought some small souvenir to bring back home.

title: Beautiful day trip
content: It's a totally renewed "ancient" area like quite all the ancient places in China, but it is a nice day trip.

user_loc: 明尼苏达明尼阿波利斯
title: Because we were there.
content: The Yu Garden was very near our hotel in Shanghai. Jo and I were walking and taking in the sights of the shopping areas and Old Town. The entrance is tucked away. Because we are over 60 the admission to the Yu Garden was reduced to 30 Yuan for both of us. As we wandered through the garden we came upon trees of 4-600 years old as well as some planted in the last century.

title: Peacefull
content: If you visit the garden, is best if you go with a guide so he can explain the story and tales of all different spots. If you go without a guide, at least Google the information on the garden so you learn the story of the place which is very interesting.

title: Sightseeing at Yu Garden
content: During a business trip to China, we had an opportunity to tour Yu Garden.  It was very beautiful and historical.  We really enjoyed the morning that we spent at this location.

title: Amazing buildings
content: The restored buildings look amazing to us. Just imaging a big, outside open air market place with tons and tons of tourists. After the first "shock", we walked around and got ourselves some food. The food court was great. When we wanted to get something, the chef showed us another plate with the same. Apparently the plates we wanted to take were "out" for a couple of minutes and the food wouldn't taste the same. We thought this was very nice, instead of letting us eat the colder food.

title: Excellent venue
content: Excellent venue with plenty of arty building and styled garden which miracpusly survived the fury of the Regime in the 60ies and 70ies.

title: Lots to see
content: Spend a nice morning having a look around different rooms and walkways also some water features with fish.

title: Lots to see
content: Lots of temples and ponds not so much gardens. Quite a good souvenir shop. Quite the effort getting there, running the gauntlet of locals trying to sell you something arrh..........

title: Amazing part of history.
content:
This is a great place to visit. Lots of shopping and photo opportunities.
There are many people so take care of your bags and there are people wanting to sell you fake watches and bags.

title: Tranquil and proud Chinese history
content: This is truly a cute and quiet little gem in the middle of roaring Shanghai. It is not hidden though, there is always thousands of visitors and the experience is affected

title: Wonderful!
content: Arrived at the gardens first thing at opening (8:30). This was great as the place was nearly empty and still very quiet and peaceful, many small areas to explore and beautiful views to be had. This was actually one of our favourite experiences of our entire trip in China, likely because of the small crowds as everywhere else is way too crowded. Highly recommend arriving early! The market/bazaar itself which is free to enter was a good place for souvenier shopping, though felt a little fake and very touristy.

title: Tradition in the Middle of City
content: This cool garden is what you would expect when visiting an older part of China... pagoda's, lots of lion statues (tip: if lion has a ball under it's foot it's a male), koi ponds galore, and bridges and walkways that are fun to explore. It also has a lot of history... from learning about how visitors were treated if they weren't liked (served bad wine as a hint that they should not stay), to how old Chinese culture included sitting in a u-shape to chat, to the fact that zig-zag walkways are designed to help you linger on your walks and enjoy life. Worth a visit... but be prepared for major crowds. Even on an off day it was jam-packed. Go early to beat as many of the crowds as possible.

title: Busy Tourist Attraction
content: Spent a morning navigating this area just to soak up to the touristy atmosphere. The place was built as a replica of ancient Chinese buildings with Street food and souvenir stalls all over. A good place to enjoy the signature xiao long bao and grab some fridge magnet souvenirs for your friends back home.

title: This area is good for shopping and sightseeing
content: Many many tourists but check also inside the buildings. There are many whole sale sellers. Homes in area are authentic old Shanghai. Sellers dont push you to buy with ridiculous 10x prices. Mostly jewelry is sold but buildings near te station have all good stuffs like handicrafts.

title: A visit to 'Old Shanghai'
content: The Yu Garden is o must see when in Shanghai. The beautifully restored buildings and tea houses give an impression of the art of past centuries.

title: Crowds but a must stop
content: This is a must stop, but be prepared for large crowds no matter when you go.  It is free to walk around and shop, but to actually see the 'gardens' there is a charge.

title: a beautiful getaway from the busy city
content: If you are into chinese gardens or if you are looking for a getaway from the chinese concrete jungle, you should go an see the Yu Gardens. Even though there are tons of people and even though it is a very touristy place, it has a calming effect and made me feel like could slow down and relax. I love tis place. Good foto opportunities!

title: A stunning example of a traditional garden
content: The Yuyuan Garden is a haven of traditional beauty and repose in the middle of a bustling, modern city that is still expanding in all directions. Every turn and corner is designed to bring tranquility. It is a must-see attraction for a sense of traditional Shanghai.

title: A HISTORICAL GARDEN
content: This garden with ponds and building was built during the Ming dynasty.When we went it was crowded though there were spots which were secluded.This historical spot has been well maintained.

title: Quaint
content: An interesting and charming step back in time in this modern city. A small enough area to look around, and not too taxing.

title: Beautiful
content: We went to visit the Yuyuan Garden again as part of the Viking Cruise.  The gardens and the history of it made this very interesting

title: Lovely traditional chinese garden
content: The garden is lovely and it must be peaceful when it's not so crowded but in the high season it's really busy. The entrance is located near a souvenir shopping street. So, you can imagine how busy it is. Go there with a tour guide because there's history behind every single stone and sign used in the garden.

title: SO CROWDED
content: This place is never crowded, it seems. Cute little spot for out of towners who have never seen anything remotely chinese or oriental (wow houses floating on water!) but aside from the xiao long bao, I wouldn't come to this place just because of the sheer numebr of people there every single day.

title: Not as spectacular as exoected
content: Perhaps I was expecting too much but this place was not as amazing as I'd hoped. Gardens were pretty. Paths were crowded with tourists.

title: Part of our Fifteen day escorted tour of China
content: We visited Yu yuan garden as part of our itinerary of our Chinese tour and this is one of our last scheduled itinerary on our last leg which culminated in Shanghai. The garden is well preserved and typical of a Chinese Ming dynasty garden. It is tucked in the middle of the city which is adjacent to a buzzling bazaar where we managed to get a small jade figurine as a souvenir. Unfortunately it was raining that day but it didn't dampen our experience of visiting the place. It's definitely a must do when you're in Shanghai , so do visit the Yu yuan garden there's nothing like it anywhere in the world.

title: Old World
content: Visiting these gardens was certainly an eye opener. We hadn't realised that this is not just a garden, but a complex of beautiful ancient buildings, water ways and a glimpse of an ancient culture.

title: Excellent Garden Compound with a lot of things to do
content: Need to buy a ticket for this beautiful and peaceful garden, on the outside, you can find lots of little shops selling souvenirs, there are also so many things to eat! But one you have to try is the NanXiang XiaoLongBao. You will find a long queue near the garden.

title: Wonderful feature
content: interesting garden surrounded by old shanghai with its shops and colourful sellers.. great fun and the bartering is great too.

title: Lovely scenery
content: The scenery is lovely it feels like you have stepped away from the madness of Shanghai. But if you are a black person you have just attracted yourself a sheet load of an audience, you will feel like a celebrity with all the cameras flashing for some this is extremely annoying. Just behind the park there is a dense Chinese market you can get almost anything for reasonable prices.

title: A good place to visit
content: This is the very first time i visited similar place in China. The garden  is fascinating and good place to spend the relaxing afternoon.

title: Quiet place in big city
content: The weather in Shanghai in summer is very hot and it is very refreshing to find place like this in big skyscrapers city. Visit it and have little rest.

title: Beautiful Garden and Cultural Surrounding
content: The area around the Yu Garden is already a great cultural experience on its own. Quite crowded, but definitely worth to walk/look around and taste some food or buy some souvenirs.

title: Yuyuan garden
content: Old city of Shanghai with history and many shows and restaurants. Nice to see the architecture as well as the garden itself. This is complex of building and gardens in the Huangpu district and while very touristy is also part of city and china heritage. Even when attending business meetings , we came to eat for dinner and the local host selected this location.

title: Hidden pearl of Shanghai in the middle of the city
content: When we went to the garden we were expecting to see usual trees, walk roads etc..this garden definitely surprises with much more - made in unique chinese style with lakes, traditional houses, small and cousy roads - definitely worth to visit and go back in time!

title: Beautiful garden
content: Went here in June 2015. It was busy, but not as busy as the surrounding market streets of Old Shanghai. You need to pay to gain entry but I'm glad I did and it was nice to sit in the shade and watch the world go by.

title: Beautiful garden
content: Very unusual garden with ponds, rockery, and pagodas.  It is very easy to walk through.  You feel like you're in a place many years ago.

title: Nice to relax
content: it is in middle of the touristic old town area, not too expensive entrance and a Relaxing place with nice old Stone formations and gardens. certainly worth the Money and time to spend

title: very nice peaceful
content: Right in the centre of the city but in the same time peaceful and harmonic. Loved the place. Better that gardens in Suzhou

title: Do not miss this place
content: It is both a shopping place and an old city with the most incredable old chinese buildings!

title: Go early to enjoy it
content: First of all try and get there as it opens if you go in the summer months as it gets very busy later on.

title: beautiful garden in the middle of busy shanghai
content: once you stepped inside this garden, it is serene and peaceful. no noise and the scenery is so beautiful.  lots of photo opportunities.

title: Peacefull
content: Had a lovely walk in the beautiful Yu Garden. If you are looking for some quiet time? It's the place to be!

title: Enjoy the traditional China
content: If you really want to see and enjoy Shanghai in a traditional way then you must visit this place. A half day is enough and you make sure you visit the garden.

title: Weekend visit in Shanghai
content: We were in Shanghai and a weekend was in between. We choose to visit the Yu Garden. This place is full of small shops which have good options for buying random stuffs at a good price. I find the stuff to good also for the souvenir purpose

title: Maze like garden in tourist centre
content: Arrived at 10.30am after finding the entrance through a large arch into an area with some good tourist shops and the teahouse - great building on a lake then next to it found the entrance to the gardens, which only cost a little to enter. Once inside walked along the winding paths to secret areas seeing, rock sculptures, buildings, rock gardens, and a pavilion over a pond which you later find your way to, then you can walk over a bridge over the large pond which contains lots of fish and the odd turtle. We all enjoyed looking around the garden and even though it was hot and humid there was lots of cooler parts in the garden. Also there were groups of people, but if you walked in a clockwise direction the crowds did not seem too many as everybody was continuing walking. Outside of the gardens I also especially liked, lots of interesting buildings and some good tourist shops. Also out of the arch was a small city of god temple which is worth looking at. I love this area and would visit again. A great place for tourist to see China

title: Not just the garden visit the all area
content:
The Yuyuan Garden is average but he surrounded by very good  big markets
the garden is require a entry ticket . i recommend to see the area you don't have to go inside the garden is just a garden.

title: Superb and well worth a visit with the camera
content: Be prepared for the crowds and whilst wondering around- LOOK UP! There are some wonderful details in the rooflines and along the walls

user_loc: 加拿大不列颠哥伦比亚省
title: Classic Chinese Garden in the Center of Shanghai's Old City
content: The Yu Garden was a private garden of the Pan family during the Ming Dynasty and has six scenic areas: Dianchun Hall, Huijing Hall, Sansui Hall, Yuhua Hall, Wanhua Chamber, and the Inner Garden. It has a wonderful collection of classic Chinese traditional buildings with exquisite sculptures and carvings, glittering pools, with an exquisite 5 ton Jade Rock. The garden may seem small, but the there is a lot to see through the corridors, archways and along the zigzag bridges. A trip to Shanghai would not be complete if you missed the gem.

title: great shopping but prepare to bargain
content: Lots of little souvenir shops selling all sorts of souvenirs but gets repeated every few shops. Beware of touts offering t-shirts and bags, they may lead you elsewhere.

title: Typical chinese garden right in the heart of the city centre. Excellent visit.
content: We visited the Yu Garden and were very impressed by the garden and architecture. Visit late afternoon when it is not so hot. Usually in the mornings, there's too much crowd. Highly recommend this visit.

title: Stunning gardens.
content: Worth evey penny in going in.  It is in the center of a bustling city!  Do not miss during your visit to Shanghai!

title: Too crowded, super touristic
content: We found the atmosphere a bit suffocating as there were so many people bumping on you. Gardens beuatiful, the bazar around them overpriced.

title: A place to be visited
content:
Nice place, it seems small but you can be lost Easily inside this place, it is a nice environment, a bit hot during August but is ok 

You can take subway to reach the place

title: Interesting, not very garden-like
content: We visited the grounds with our 8-month old boy. Interesting and beautiful temple setting, though not very green. And super crowded. Not exactly easy to maneuver with a baby pushchair, especially in 38 degree heat...
