content: I have been at Yuyuan for the third time, but the first time in Summer. My other visits were in Spring, somewhat different impressions but I enjoyed both of my stays, unlike the neighborhood.

title: Beautiful Chinese garden
content: The garden is fab made up of many different style gardens connected together. Once you pay in 30 RMB its bit like a maze but fun to wander around. They don't offer maps and poorly sign posted inside but not too big you won't get lost. Lots of photo opportunities. Great spot to spend an hour exploring.

title: Always visit Yuyuan Gardens
content: Well, this is the place to buy all your touristy trinkets etc. Always interesting to see what is new. The 10 yuan shops are always soooo full of people - hahahaha. Good to wander and pick up the odd unusual bargain. Try different places for the dumplings as well

title: Huge and so well maintain!
content:
Beautiful garden!!
The garden  is really well maintained and serene. Just enjoy the greenery and sit around the benches and enjoy a great afternoon! Do remember to take a walk down the old street!

title: crowded and touristy
content: This place used to be great but now its a lot of tourists so they sell touristy items and the food now is just so so.  Too crowded for my taste and too expensive.

title: A wonderful exposure to Chinese culture
content: When we went to Shanghai last year, we had missed visiting Yuyuan. So this time it was on the top of our agenda. And it was well worth the wait. We had a fantastic time browsing around the shops and getting a glimpse into the Chinese culture in this place built hundreds of years ago. There's Chinese street food, Chinese arts and crafts and even Starbucks! An wonderful mix of the old and new. The architecture is great and must to be seen!

title: Timeless Tranquil Beauty
content: Constructed almost 500 years ago, this tranquil architectural marvel right in the middle of shanghai mega city gives a glimpse of Chinese architecture in the bygone era before steel and concrete changed the urban landscape. A must see in Shanghai. Most of the water based structures are accessible to the visitors. Expect long queues for the mouth watering dishes at the Chinese restaurants and bars dotting the tourist attraction. Nominal entry fee. Clean toilets. Must see.

title: beautiful
content: Worth a trip if you have the time.  Large and very well kept.  They have a little shop at the end where I bought hand painted silk sceen to hang up in the house.  Very reasonable prices.  So many lovely phot ops here.  Great history.

title: Old Shanghai
content: When you come in China and Shangai most of turist think that all Shanghai is like China town in US. This is wrong. Yu garden is one small part of Chinese history and on this place you will enjoy old China. Old buldings, great park with lakes and of course with a lot of shops and restauranth with chinese food. Must see place in Shanghai.

title: Peaceful Retreat
content: Very enjoyable stroll to pass an afternoon. There is a modest admission fee, but the layout of the garden is beautiful. It's a nice retreat from the hustle and bustle of the city.

title: pathetic
content: terrible thats the right word to use, entrance fees of 40 Yuan for no reason- bottles floated across the water body

title: Nice Old Traditional Garden
content: A person who visited Shanghai must visit this place. The garden is preserved in the old traditional way, having so many plants and the way inside the garden is also with a bit challenges to walk thru. There is an entrance fee of 40 RMB and it's worth spending that much. I liked this Garden very much.

title: Relaxing view of the garden
content: better to check this garden by spring, not during winter.... no flowers and trees were all dried out...

title: Peaceful escape in the centre of the city
content: It's a lovely peaceful, and old, corner of this modern bustling metropolis. Go early in the morning if you can, then it is less busy and cooler in the garden. Keep exploring the little corners of the garden, through each doorway is more to discover!

title: Great Garden
content: Very cool and relaxing garden to walk around and spend part of your day in. It also has a thriving shopping area around it which is fun to peruse, but make sure you a good haggler before you try to buy anything!

title: Beautiful place.
content: All immaculately kept. The locals' use all the parks around the city for relaxation and social activities.

title: Overly rated
content: Extremely crowded. Overly rated in my opinion. Forget about the famous xiaolongbao (pork dumplings), it's not the same as before.

title: An oasis of tranquility in Shanghai!
content: The Yu Garden was high on our to-do list, but we had no idea it would exceed all our expectations as it did!

title: Nice to See Traditional Garden
content: The garden is nice and it's an interesting place to see in Shanghai. You can partake the traditional xiao long bao (soup dumplings). They're fantastic. And you can get an idea of how the stinky tofu smells. Not fantastic. But it's a great place to check out. I wouldn't go during a holiday.

title: Old city
content: Great atmosphere of the chinese culture. Great to buy souvenirs and expire the old city next to it. Great contrast between the bund (modern) and the old city

title: Shanghai most exquisite private garden
content: This garden has a long history since 1559 during the Ming Dynasty! You have to pay 10 RMB for the garden and it is WORTH IT! If you enjoy ancient Chinese architecture, you would love this garden! Inside it is filled with ponds with gold fishes, little pavilions and bridges and rock design. I appreciate the beauty of this garden in conjunction with Chinese architecture. It is very relaxing here... Also the washrooms are much cleaner than outside washroom with toilet paper!

title: Nice area, but similar to other Chinese Gardens, very very crowded and dirty
content: Very crowded, couldn't get to see all of it, too crowded, very dirty. No one in cooee cleaning or picking up rubbish. A boy was seen weeing beside some of the trees, and another doing number two's at the side of the path, and the majority of the tourists were oblivious to it, we walked very quickly by, parents didn't get cleaners or make any attempt to rectify situation. Smelly, and really not worth it. We had been looking so forward to it after leaving home It was to be a highlight, but very let down.

title: Beautiful gardens, but not so peaceful!
content: The Yu gardens are very picturesque and serene, however when I visited they were extremely busy which detracted from the experience a little.

title: Nice area but very crowded.
content: Old town area. Nice architecture and gardens but extremely crowded area. We went on a Saturday morning and it was really crowded. It is in the middle of an area where there are many small shops and street vendors. Lots of people trying to sell cheap watches and knockoff handbags. Watch out for the low flying hovercraft also. If you like to watch people this is a good spot.

title: Wonderful and crowded
content: I really liked the feeling of this place, especially all the booths surrounding the beautiful garden. A very oriental feeling in the middle of a very modern city. Go therefor the contrast. A must i Shanghai.

title: famous park in shanghai
content: very nice park, with water inside and around, with typical chinese 'old' buildings and a wall surrounded by a dragon. Of course, it is called yu garden because of the big gold fishes swimming in the water paths in the park. All around the park you also can find shops and tea houses.

user_loc: 多米尼加共和国普拉塔港
title: Grand tour of China with Great Rail Journeys
content: This was lovely. A peaceful retreat in a hectic city a comparison of the old & the new. Well worth a visit

title: Get there early to avoid the crowds.
content: I was disappointed when I visited Yu Garden. (I live in Shanghai). Sadly it's become the latest attraction to fall to mass tourism. I was expecting a really authentic setting and was disappointed. Once I'd gotten over the centrally located Starbucks and hoards of market traders selling tacky souvenirs I managed to enjoy the No.1 dumpling experience. I would say get here early or even try and come on a weekday to avoid the crowds.

title: Traveling back in Time
content: In the middle of the garish and touristy Old Town in Shanghai, you'll find the Yu Garden. It's statuary, stone formations or scholars stones, carvings, and reflecting ponds take you back to the Ming and Qing dynasties. Built by a retired government minister, who must have done very well, you can imagine writing poetry or practicing calligraphy in the buildings amid the beautiful scenery. The dragon with 5 talons atop the wall is a must see as are the lintels and terracotta carvings. The ticket itself is a souvenir.

title: Tourist hot spot
content: Pleasant place to visit to escape the hustle and bustle of the city. Very hot and humid in August though so our visit wasn't too long. 30 yuan entrance fee

title: Beautiful but crowded
content: The Yu Garden itself is lovely, however very crowded so the romantic atmosphere is challenged a little by that. The surrounding market area is the only place in China where I felt there were pushy sales people, and extremely crowded! Well worth a visit though :)

title: Nice place to visit
content:
The garden is beautiful. Very crouded in the weekend but the Chinese people are polit and gentel.

Also the area around the garden is traditional and an exception to Shanghai.

title: Ancient China
content: On a holiday or a Sunday it is very crowded and it's not so nice. When it isn't that crowded then it's a nice place to visit.

title: Nice break in the day
content: Great stop for a bit of old Shanghai with a contrast to the new.   Worthy of a visit and nice when combined with the Old China Town.

title: Atmospheric place to bring guests visiting Shanghai
content: This gorgeous and ancient garden complex is fronted by a warren of streets with shops selling souvenirs and bric-a-brac. Although the gardens are picturesque the throbbing mob of people visiting the place ruins the experience. Come early, at opening hours to visit the gardens in relative tranquility, and by the time you are done all the shops and restaurants that surround the gardens will be open for business and your enjoyment.

title: Relaxing
content: The Yu Yuan is a beautiful garden. The old Chinese style makes it something I'd never seen before. The scenery is beautiful. Definitely something you shouldn't miss during your stay in Shanghai.

title: A great visit to Yuyuan Garden
content: Next we visited the Yu Garden. Yu means peaceful in Chinese. An officer in the Ming Dynasty built this beautiful garden for his parents to live a quiet and peaceful life here. The construction of the garden had to be stopped because the officer was transferred. He came back 20 years later and finished building the garden. His parents passed away a few years later. This garden changed hands and was severely damaged down the years and during the Great Cultural Revolution ( 1966—1976) .The government repaired the garden between 1986-93 and this is what we see today.

title: A Heaven amidst the Hustle and Bustle
content: This garden is a tranquil haven in the middle of Shanghai.  With its quaint buildings, its sheltered walkways, its decorative gardens and its lovely pools it is a great place to spend a morning in Shanghai.

title: amazing and cheap
content: Is a magic place, the gardens are so beautiful! Is a very quite place (although is freaking crowded), if you go to shanghai you HAVE TO go there. It's also very cheap, the entrance is 35 yuan (15 yuan for students).

title: Traveling solo? Watch for scams
content: The gardens area was beautiful but beware of the tea house scam! I am fresh of a scam where two very sweet young people talked me into going to a tea ceremony. It sounded very neat but they scam you into a high prices service and hi priced tea!! I am still feeling the pain from being so careless and naive. Stick to your own plan.

title: Nice imposant garden!
content: Very nice! Interesting garden. Sad storry abou it... Very Chinese :-) Ticket it's not expensive. Recomemded!

title: Relaxing afternoon
content: There are several gardens but they all look very similar. Nevertheless this is a nice place to walk around. The old buildings are nice to see. Close by there is also a market which is also nice to see and to buy some souveniers.

title: Hot and humid at an amazing garden.
content: It was very crowded. Hot and humid.  But amazing that one person built this for his parents. Narrow walk ways.  Nice little tourist shops outside and inside the garden. Picturesque.

title: Fun times
content: Great place to relax, drink tea and go shopping! Convenient location and a lovely place to spend the afternoon.

title: Hyped!
content: Is a bit hyped. Basically is a bunch of old buildings, some trees and  a water body with greenish water. Can skip it.

title: Peaceful corner of the city, shady and green.
content: It is worth visiting the garden early - both for the crowds, and the temperatures in the summer. The large tourist market around the market is busy and varied, inside the garden walls it is quiet and peaceful.

title: Wonderful !
content: I really and strongly, recommend you to visit this place. If you are in a trip to shanghai and miss visiting this place you will miss a lot. I like the shops, there are hundreds of chinese shops were you can hang around and see there. Dont miss it

title: Nice place to visit
content:
A place that I always go to visit, at least once during my visit to Shanghai.
Only be careful about weekends during school vacation when it gets really crowded.

title: the maze
content: This place is so special, has a very unique design and fantastic pools and gardens, waking around is like a maze.

title: Yu Garden sublime
content: A week ago my friends and I experienced the essence of an ordered Chinese garden with small cool pavilions, bridges over water filled with red carp and turtles and masses of lotus leaves with the odd pink blossom peeking through. The sculptures in the water were sublime. If only this could be experienced in quiet tranquillity, alone to contemplate, but alas, we seemed to be the only foreigners amid masses of Chinese carrying umbrellas !

title: Tourist shopping in Shanghai
content: Yu Garden is a hive of buying and selling activity where you choose how much you pay. If you have the energy to bargain then you can get some terrific deals on Chinese souveniers. Pearls, silk, tea, trinkets, fans, toys, computer gadgets, lucky charms, food, drinks and more are available in this old style shopping area. Behind the traditional oriental buildings is a charming garden area where it is worth taking a less hassled stroll. Be prepared to be one of a huge crowd. Disregard offers from roaming street vendors who have amazing resilience as they continue to offer access to tea houses, silk shops, watches and handbags located in 'out-of-the-way' buildings. Packed with people and opportunities!

title: Nice Gardens. Big Crowds
content: The gardens were nice. I can see why they are a big attraction. The one thing missing was any real sense of narrative that taught me about the buildings and their significance. I would have liked to be able to better connect them to history. Maybe I should have learned more before I went?!?

title: A must visit for Shanghai
content: Go early and avoid the queues, since it can get busy. The real attraction is the ambiance both cultural and thermic (cooler than outside) within the gardens. Although not big, it tricks us via the ingenious design of the pathways inside. The bazar just outside is not an interesting spot.

title: Beautiful Yuyuan Garden worth a visit
content: We went on a Sunday afternoon. Area outside the gate is absolutely packed with people. After you pay 30 RMB and get in (you don’t need advanced tickets or to buy through a broker), the crowds are OK. Beautiful examples of 17th century Chinese architecture and design. Plan on an hour or more to wander around through the different sections. There are some signs in English explaining what you are looking at, but I would have liked more or an option for an audio tour. TIP – get drinks before you get it. Prices are double inside the gate.

title: Definitely worth a visit.
content: Very cultural experience, it's nice to take a quick break from the hustle and bustle of the city. Definitely worth a visit.

title: The only water garden in city centre
content: This is one of the most beautiful garden in China and the only one water garden in the city centre of Shanghai. The architecture and scenery are very attractive. Beside the garden there are many local foods centres and shops around. So after visiting, you could spend your dinner and evening times here.

title: Nice garden in a very busy area
content: We were dropped off by the bus and walked through a very busy and rather run down area in order to get to the garden. The Pan family, rich ming dynasty officials founded the garden. It took from 1559-77 to be nurtured into existence. It was bombarded during the Opium War but was restored in 1842 to a true Ming Garden Design. It is tucked away off of a busy area of shops and eateries. People were everywhere and the garden was extremely crowded. There is a Tea House next to the Garden entrance..it was once part of the garden but is now one of the most famous and expensive in China. The garden has lovely buildings, flowers and a pond filled with so many coy it was sort of eerie! Because it is enclosed with walls, it can get rather warm in the garden.

title: Great if you love rock gardens.
content: The Yu Garden is worth the visit not only because it is a historic site but also because it is a place of relative calm in the hustle and bustle of Shanghai. The Yu Garden is essentially a series of rock gardens with no grass.

title: Peace all arround
content: We went to yu garden although it was drizzeling because we were on a tight schedule...even though we enjoyed it a great deal. There were a lot of people but it didn't feel too crowded as the gardens are quiet big, very peaceful

title: terrific little garden
content: Interesting little garden in the old section of Shanghai. Entrance fee is around 30-40 rmb per person. You have to walk through the Yuyuan old streets to get to this garden.

title: A great place
content: We were only in Shanghai one day as part of an Asia cruise, but we made time to spend an hour or two in this beautiful garden, parts of which can be pretty crowded other parts extremely tranquil. Plenty of places before and after to visit the shops, some of which have lovely things, bargaining very much the rule !

title: Lovely, even in the rain
content: The commercial area around the gardens was quite interesting & good for shopping (haggle!). The gardens themselves are a peaceful oasis (well in April anyway). It was very wet when we went, but somehow the dripping trees & wet rocks looked perfect.

title: Amazing garden. Really worth the visit.
content:
This is an amazing place to visit. Would got back for the peace and tranquillity. 

Had lunch in the Authentic Chinese restaurant which was OK, not great. Had better food elsewhere.

title: Nice architecture of China
content: The architecture and the building here are very nice, a lot of souvenirs shops and cullinary. If you want to buy souvenirs try to bargain first, at least you can start with 30% from the offering price. Some shops apply fix price.

user_loc: 明尼苏达明尼阿波利斯
title: New/Old China, and an experience not to be missed
content: Although there is nothing old about Yu Garden, it is very fun to see the recreation of the ancient juxtaposed with the skyline of Pudong, which can be seen over the top of the Teahouse in the center of Yuyuan. There are tons of people, tons of folks selling things, tons of strange foods, crazy smells, and a lovely garden and temple, all in one spot. If you visit Shanghai you must come here.

title: Really beautiful at night
content: Really beautiful place to visit. The old buildings lined with LED's made you feel like you were in a different world. It's a shame that people litter in the ponds.

title: Peaceful
content: The Yu Garden is one of the most beautiful parks in Shanghai.

title: Beautiful Garden
content: The garden itself is wonderful, as other reviewers mentioned before me. Try to read up about it before you go or hire a guide so that you can pay attention to the little details of the architecture and design of the garden. It also helps to understand the garden's history. The poignant tale behind the garden makes you see it from a different perspective. When you're done with the garden, there are plenty of shopping and dining outlets all around.

title: Stunning
content: The gardens were absolutely stunning, very beautifully traditional chinese gardens. The buildings around the gardens are also very stunning.

title: Lovley gardens with nice corners
content: We started our tour there entering trough a very lively market with Chinese style houses and many shops, the whole place is live and interesting and worth a visit. The gardens are small and cute with nice corners rocks and statues everywhere, watch the roofs. There is a Tao temple nearby worth a visit also

title: Just Okay
content: I enjoyed my visit. You see a lot of the same type of rock formations and plants throughout. Had I known this, I could have spent 15 minutes looking at the stuff in front and been done. It's a bit of a maze & took me awhile to find my way out, which was made more frustrating by the heavy crowd and lack of a place to buy a beverage. I'm glad I didn't have my kids with me. They would have been bored.

title: tranquillity in the middle of the city
content: I loved that this can be found in the middle of the city's hustle and bustle but . . . every tour goes there!

user_loc: 澳大利亚新南威尔士州
title: Beautiful Gardens
content: We thoroughly enjoyed the beautiful gardens, pagodas, rock formations, ponds, etc. This is also a "must" to see. If you feel like being squashed like a sardine, go outside to the Yuan Markets.

title: One of the must visit place while in Shanghai
content: This is one of the historical place in Shanghai, dated back to the era of dynasties. To enter the garden, you should purchase a ticket, but even the area surround the garden is also nice to try some local snack and shopping for some local souvenirs.

title: Peace in the midst of madness
content: Will visited Shanhai with friends for 4 days en route to ur son'a wedding in New Zealand. Apart from it being a great stop-over point, Shanghai is an amazing city with wonderful people and a great all-round cultural experience. With so many people though, and so much noise, it was heavenly to withdraw for a while into the peaceful garden, smack bang in the middle of the city. The architecture is fantastic: old sitting comfortably against the newer city-scape. The highlight was a visit to the tea house where we're totally absorbed in the ritual of tea preparation and drinking. There are some wonderful teas and tea making equipment for sale, though whilst I was able to purchase a tea bowl, I wasn't able to take tea into New Zealand. You can't visit Shanghai and not visit this place!

title: Yu
content: A beautiful and magnificent place in Shanghai including Traditional markets, visit able garden and too restaurant with beautiful view in center of bazaar.

user_loc: 阿根廷布宜诺斯艾利斯
title: Very Crowded
content: Yes, the gardens are nice and the mixture of nature in such an old setting its quite nice but there was simply too much people. It was hard enough to take a clear picture eradicating the only peace that this place used to have. Still, its a nice place to see if you never experience something like this but if you don't like crowds you might want to avoid this place.

title: Yu Garden
content: A quiet piece of old China in bustling Shanghai. We were lucky to go in 'low season' so pretty much had the place to ourselves.

title: Over-rated and too busy
content: Perhaps because it was a weekend, we found this place to be far too busy to be of much interest. As a result we walked quickly though from the Bund to Shanghai Old Street. Now that and the streets off it were much more interesting.

title: Lovely Oasis in a Bustling part of the City
content: The gardens themselves are a lovely respite from the markets surrounding the site with beautiful walled "rooms" and lovely ponds filled with coy and turtles. The architecture from the Qing and Ming Dynasties in each garden is worth seeing as you are able to get up close to it. Beware of the crowds and hawkers when approaching the gardens and it can get very crowded inside the gardens with tourist groups including large groups of local Chinese, but all in all well worth the visit.

title: Beware scams
content: Really enjoyed the old town, lots to see and buy. Watch out for students who speak excellent English and try to encourage you to go to a tea ceremony. We didn't accept but read about the expense incurred to others. They are very adept at being charming and separating you from your companion whilst talking all the time. Usually introduce themselves by asking you to take a picture of them as fellow visitors.

title: Beautiful garden and best pace to shop
content: A visit to the garden late in the afternoon and then the old city shops later in the evening is a must. Beautiful old oriental buildings which are shops and eateries.Ask for price of an item you want to buy atlest in 2 to 3 different shops as prices vary a lot , haggle hard.

title: Beautiful garden and good touristy shopping.
content: My husband and I visited this garden independently and were pleasantly surprised at the low cost and the beauty. There was quite a lot of Chinese tourists but all was civilised.... no pushing etc.

title: We enjoyed this
content: We enjoyed visiting the garden but oh the crowds! Getting across the zigzag bridge was a feat in itself. Still, once we were inside it is like an expanding garden, room after room. How lovely it would have been to have lived there.

title: Must to visit
content: I like the Zigzag Bridge and The Yu garden. Inside the garden it is very peaceful and it has a rich history. We had a personal tour guide with us who was very informative about the places we went.

title: Definitely a tourist place
content: The place shows Chinese culture and history as well. It is quite a beautiful place to visit with family and friends. A lot of shopping places but recommend that you haggle off the price. It can be quite pricey. A lot of good places to eat, a lot of choices

title: its a must
content: this garden is AMAZING ... fern the Bund we walked all the way to the garden, it is a little far if you are not used to walk long distances but it is DEfINETLY WORTH IT, you will find a big big a bunch of different stores as soon as you come and a lot of chinese style buildings that will make the view AMAZING i found the Stores very nice and with good prices so we decided t walk along the after we visited some of the stores we decided to go to the garden i don't really remember the price because it was 2 months ago but i remember it was under 100 yuan pp... once you are inside you forget everything it is AMAZING to walk through this place inside there are some te houses with are very nice, the only bad thing is that like all the touristic attractions in China it is packed, after you leave this place you can walk some more around and find some places to eat local food with are very nice and cheap, i Hope you enjoy this place as much as i did

title: peace
content: Lovely place to have a walk round, would not believe it is in the middle of Shanghai until you look up and see the tall buildings in the background. All the buildings are in the old Chinese style that makes them magical. There is water surrounding the buildings with gold fish swimming in groups hoping to be feed. A pleasant way to spend an hour or two. We thought out and worth going to.

title: Serene Experience
content: What a beautiful place to stroll and linger...a graceful garden offering many many photo opportunities around every corner!

title: Interesting!
content: Our tour went to this garden and the old town area of shops. The garden was well preserved and historically interesting. The "hawkers" at the shops were a little more aggressive than but I would still recommend going to this attractions. Be aware of pick pockets thought since this area is so crowded.

title: Nice but very crowded
content: the gardens are pretty but are very, very crowded, even on weekdays early morning. Still worth seeing

title: Traditional Chinese Scenery.
content: Beautiful scenic gardens set in yuyuan ancient shopping area.

title: So peaceful
content: You can't help but feel relaxed and at one with nature in this serene environment. It's a nice change of scenery from the chaos, noise, and constant development in shanghai. It's not uncommon for Chinese tourists to ask if they can take a picture of, or even with, westerners

title: nice scenery but very crowded
content: it is an ancient city. nice view. but very crowded. so many people. some of the building under renovation.

title: An oasis
content: Beautiful rooms with moon gate arches lead to sculpture gardens & coy ponds. Rockeries & cloisters adjoin streams.

title: Nice place for a stroll
content: This is a very beautiful area of Shanghai. Interesting features in the garden. Not too many flowers when we were there in March, but the rock formations and structures are beautiful.

title: One of my favourite places in Shanghai
content: There really is a sense of contentment when you walk into the gardens at YuYuan. The hustle and bustle that carries on behind the garden wall seems to disappear once you go through the entrance. It really is quite stunning and is a small piece of classical China in a modern city. I have never had a guide when I have been, and I have been quite a few times, and although you don't get all,of the history, if you take time to wander through at a leisurely pace and read the descriptions on the builidings. Just the atmosphere here takes you back in time! A great place to spend a couple of hours! I have taken teenagers, been with my husband, been with friends, taken mine and my husbands parents as well as going on my own and everybody has enjoyed it.

title: Gorgeous Garden
content: This is a lovely way to see ancient architecture and gardens. It is beautiful! I would recommend a guide to enrich the experience. Lovely afternoon!

title: Busy but satisfying
content: This beautiful garden gracefully combines diverse plants and flowers with beautiful landscaping strongly supported by exquisitely rich traditional architecture

title: Wonderful place, but chose your moment
content: The Yu garden has made a huge impression on me. Fortunately, I visited on a rainy Monday afternoon. As a result, there were only a few dozen other visitors, which meant I could wander around in peace and quiet. I can only imagine that the place is hardly impressive when the queue of tourists push you along its sites. But now that I was often alone in courtyards, the tranquility was amazing.

user_loc: 南卡罗来纳美特尔海滩
title: Beautifully Serene
content: Yuyuan Garden or Yu Garden was built during the Ming Dynasty by the high-ranking government official Pan Yunduan. Gardens total area occupies approximately 5 acres, and features pavilions, ponds, rockeries, cloisters and streams within 6 scenic zones, including the Sansui Hall and Wanhua Chamber. The 400 year old Garden was constructed for Pan's aging parents as a sanctuary in which to live out their lives. Signs in each pavilion or area give an understanding of the meaning behind each individual structure. Thoroughly enjoyed our couple of hours enjoying the gardens. Would highly recommend to anyone touring in this area.

title: Oasis in the City
content: National Geographic's guidebook highly recommended visiting this magnificent 7acre experience of 16th century Shanghai. It was a center for calligraphers and watercolorists and poets. A stunning collection of this work may be found on the second floor of the main building. You don't have to go to the gallery to appreciate Yu Gardens. It is enough to stroll through the paths, the rock outcrop pings, admiring the ancient trees, beautiful plan things and water elements, not to mention the ornate carvings adorning the rooftops of every building. The shops in the Gardens are interesting but my Chinese host warned me that the quality of what was on display was not high. So ok if you are looking for small souvenirs but not for major purchases of jewelry, carvings, or antiques.

title: A bit of china old architecture survived the bulldozer fuzz
content: This garden is really worth the 40RMB and the afternoon we spent there.

title: the best in Shanghai but if you are going to Suzhou skip it
content: Garden of Contentment is the best old style Chinese garden in Shanghai, period. the entrance fee is quite reasonable (20 RMB), and is well worth the visit if you are not planning to visit Suzhou. However, if you are visiting Suzhou, you might skip it and focus your energy on those gardens in Suzhou. They are much larger in scale and better arranged.

title: Busy Place with lots of shops
content: It's a busy place with many restaurants and shops for locals and tourists alike. I ate at the famous Nan Chong Dumpling place which is a bit overpriced and the food is average. The restaurant closes at 7:30 PM which was a surprise. We had to order quickly and get out promptly.

title: Worth the visit!
content: This garden and the Old Shanghai area surrounding it was truly a great way to get a feel for the history of Shanghai. Allow enough time to stroll around the streets around the gardens. We were on a tight time schedule and wish we'd allowed more time.

title: shopping streets were great
content: My son and I took the subway to the Yu Garden station on line 10. We took the Yu Garden exit, but instead of visiting the garden we strolled down toward Fang Bang Lu shopping street. This is where great bargains are to be found, and we hoped to find wushu imitation items e.g. swords, nunchuks. Although we did not find exactly what we wanted, we enjoyed walking in and out of shops and sampling the local cuisine. There are many 10 yuan shops, and bargains to be had. Clothing seemed particularly cheap, as ladies print blouses were being sold at 3 for 50 yuan, and wushu shoes were between 10-15 yuan.

title: Must see
content: What a relaxing and wonderful area to walk around. Although there are a lot of people here, you can walk in so many different directions and still find such serenity. This is not to be missed on any visit to Shanghai!

title: Beautiful!
content: Gorgeous gardens with many pretty buildings, ponds and rockeries. Kids especially enjoyed exploring tunnels through rockeries, as well as fish and turtles in ponds. Garden was quite crowded with tour groups.

title: Serene gardens.......
content: Loved it - take the time to visit the gardens, preferably with a guide to get a sense of the history of the place and it's story.

title: Worth a visit
content: Nice gardens set in a traditional area of authentic buildings. Nice to browse on a nice day and would recommend the tea ceremony at the Garden view tea rooms. Take some bread for the fish, you will attract many.

title: Crowded and touristy
content: We visited on a Sunday afternoon/evening and it was as expected, very crowded, with lots of tourists. Still, I supposed it is a 'must do' for Shanghai as it does have interesting architecture and lets you feel like you're seeing old Shanghai. It's good for people watching and wandering about as local Chinese people get wedding photos taken and old people sit around and drink tea.

title: An Escape from the Bustle of the City
content: We visited Yugarden on a Tuesday morning, before 10a.m., before the crowds began to assemble. The garden was constructed in the 16th century, and the city has taken great care to preserve its beauty and heritage.

title: Beautifull authentic
content: Very impressive and beautifull garden, tempels, statues.

title: Yu Garden
content: great garden very peaceful, also great gov run antique shops, oasis of tranquility in a very busy city.

title: Very nice, very old, authentic Chinese garden...but crowded.
content: This is a beautiful garden, with good plantings, interesting old buildings, a few ponds, twisty paths, etc. Also a lot of people. If you have in mind sitting in serene reflection on the beauty and tranquility around you...this is not your place. Worth a visit, but you will be fighting the crowds from beginning to end.

user_loc: 英国特伦特河畔斯托克
title: Very crowded
content: We remembered the tranquil nature of these gardens from a previous visit to Shanghai 8 years ago. The beauty remains but the tranquility has gone. There were so many people inside it was difficult to get around. Maybe it was because we visited on a Saturday.

title: A very crowded oasis
content: This garden was overrun with people and congestion but with imagination you could appreciate the tranquility it offered to the wealthy family of the past.

title: A must do in Shanghai!
content: The crowds in the bazaar outside were slightly offputting, but once inside the gardens there was no problem with crowding. Many of those in the bazaar obviously don't go into the gardens.

title: GO EARLY
content: We went at 8:30 a.m. when it opened and had the place nearly to ourselves. It was peaceful - and the trees were beginning to flower and leaf out- I loved the mosaics that have been created in the walkways. Avoided the tea ceremony that they try to get you to attend (Thank you Trip Advisor for this tip!)

title: Beautiful
content: This garden is absolutely beautiful. Tranquil (except for all of the tourists!) and filled with bonsai and plum trees. Just a really pretty spot to spend an hour or two walking through.

title: An Island Of Tranquility
content: Yu Yuan Garden's peaceful landscaping and paths are a breath of fresh air in the midst of the hustle & bustle of Shanghai. Take some time to stroll this wonderful green space.

title: DON'T MISS THIS
content: This was a highlight. You wander through the streets, lots of souvenir shops but there are a few that are great. If you look up you will see above the shops old buildings still existing.

title: A MUST-DO in Shanghai
content: LOVED the gardens and structures. Beautiful architecture, perfect bonsai cultivation, excellent gift shop with decent prices for quality goods. Definitely worth a stroll thru while in Shanghai.

title: Perfect place to buy traditional Chinese gift
content: its a nice walking street with lots of gift to shop for family, loved ones or friends with low price. the shop people are very smart they will stick to same price but if you are shopping anything above 5RMB than you can bargain even if you are buying 3 than you can say 3 for 10RMB and you can get in 12RMB :)

title: Don't miss this in downtown Shanghai...
content: If you are in downtown shanghai, don't miss this garden. Classical Chinese architecture with buildings, potted bonsai and trees. We were here in March when everything was just starting to bloom. A few more weeks and it would have been stunning, regardless it's well worth the visit. Lots of shopping just outside the garden. You can generally bargain with the vendors to at least 1/2 of what they are asking, sometimes more.

title: Must see place
content: Popular Chinese construction with the most traditional architecture and Chinese rooftop. Lots of Jewelry shops and gold decorations, it is a must see place near Shanghai downtown. Also some local souvenir shops with typical dresses, tea, and food.

title: shopping paradice to pick up gift articles
content: Never ending bargain, hard core sales people on the street, amazing varieties of prodcuts, toys to hi-tech gadgets, all under one place. Yu Yuan Garden at the centre is totally out of the whole sorrounding. Beatiful garden and great shopplng around.

title: Quiet and calm
content: A nice place within the big, noisy city of Shanghai. You should just avoid to go there during weekends or public holidays... Probably better to book a guide in case you want to learn more about the park and its builidings.

title: Iconic Shanghai
content: Like it or not, you have to go here if visiting Shanghai. Without a tour guide paying to enter the actual garden may not be worth it. There's plenty to do in the area, including the zig-zag bridge and just walking through and by the many shops is enough to provide hours of entertainment. (If you don't get irritated by the people jamming things in your face to buy first)

title: Beautiful!
content: This is a perfect place to visit while in Shanghai. A highlight on our trip. We arrived here in May 2013 and the place was packed! Very busy and quite hot but the gardens are still beautiful.

title: Very fun visit
content: We went to Yu Garden our last day. If you can avoid the shops which sell anything, and get to the museum, you can feel a little piece of what China probably used to feel like. Don't miss this attraction if in Shanghai.

title: Historic gardens
content: Water, stone, pagodas, bridges, secret passageways, plentiful koi, blossoms, dragons.....these gardens have it all. We visited twice it was so inspirational.

title: Requires time
content: You should be relaxed and take your time, it is a great experience to strall alonge and to admire nature and architecture. Also interesting to watch People.

title: Good one
content: A peaceful environment in shanghai. Authentic chinese infrastructure and life is the main attraction here.over all a good place to take a lot of picture

title: A lovely garden.
content: One cannot imagine such a tranquil spot in the middle of the chaotic streets of Shanghai.

title: Beautiful
content: This garden is well worth the admission. But be sure to go during a weekday when it is less likely to be crowded. At every turn you are met with a different environment and unique doorway. It is a wonderful place to wander and relax for a day as long as you can stay laid-back enough to let the crowds move around you.

title: A great place to explore
content: You need to pay a visit if you are in Shanghai;

title: Beautiful, Tranquil, Old....
content: Just beautiful, very old and historic. The blossoms smell so good. I highly recommend visiting the temple next door as well, plus the shops around this area. This is where you truly demonstrate your bargaining skills! A good trick is to show interest in an item, and say that "you'll think about it", or "will see", then begin to leave the store. From this point on, most of the shops will want you to come back at a more than half of the originally quoted price, even up to a third. They normally start at 10 yuan off, say something is 250, they say 240 for you. But not after you do the above: they'll be offering it to you at less than half. Have fun and be gentle!

title: A hidden gardens well worth the trip
content: Well worth the visit my tour guide was extremely informative, it was so peaceful knowing what was on the other side of the walls

user_loc: 加利福尼亚奥克斯纳德
title: A peaceful garden among the hustle and bustle of Shanghai
content: I was absolutely impressed with this traditional Chinese Garden. It sits in the middle of a very busy market/bazaar. The grounds took me me to ancient China and I could almost imagine what life was like for those lucky enough to visit this garden. There are a lot of flowers, artificial mountains, rock sculptures and lots of water. I strongly recommend visiting this garden in Shanghai! It' s a must see! After the visit to the garden we spend about an hour or so shopping at the Bazaar!

title: A relaxing garden in the heart of Shanghai
content: I am really happy I visited this garden. Despite the crowds in the surrounding commersial area, this is a quiet and relaxing place, full of plants, trees, fountains, ponds, bridges and small buildings. I definitely recommend it!

title: Lovely Garden
content: You need to go to this garden and see the beauty of it. It is very special and the kind of garden you dont see in the Western world. I highly recommend it

title: Nice traditional chinese garden in the centre of Shanghai
content: This is a nice garden built in traditional chinese style, complete with artificial "mountains", rock sculptures and formations, and lots and lots of water features, creeks, ponds, and of course bridges.

title: Great place to see and walk around
content: It's a beautiful place to walk around and learn some history of Yu garden. Outside the Yu garden, there are lots of shops and eatery. Great place to spend an afternoon and into the night.

title: Atmospheric if a little artifical. Enjoyable selfcontained market & garden
content: OK I bought a souvenir mug of a famous coffee chain as a momento so I did feel it was some where unique. the garden was enjoyable and quiet in comparison to the stores and market area. Be warned if you are 6ft the little cave area is pitch black and low ceiling !!! we made purchases on the market stalls and also in the large stores, we ate there also. It was very decorated for the Spring Festival but I think it would be enjoyable any time of year - there were many people but not uncomfortably so . I cannot say how easy it is to get there as we used a taxi but I did not try communicate . it is I guess square shaped with little lanes leading into it from different streets. You can just enjoy the atmosphere or haggle for a bargain..

user_loc: 德克萨斯州格雷普韦恩
title: Oasis in the City
content: Our last stop before leaving Shanghai was the Yu Garden. It is a really beautiful oasis in the city. The garden was first conceived in 1559 during the Ming Dynasty. The garden is pretty large, with lots of history and several buildings.

title: More than just a garden
content: This area is amazing not just a garden. The gardens are situated within a retail precinct which matches the beauty of the Yu gardens.

title: OF scenic spots and trees and little bridges.
content: The Subway station is located close to the garden.

title: Beautiful garden located in the middle of Yuyuan District
content: The day we went there was not too crowded and we were so happy that we were able to pay a visit to this lovely garden. It has beautiful ponds with many koi fish in it and the wisteria trees were blooming which made the garden more pleasant to visit. If you are a senior citizen, make sure to bring your ID card to show your age and you pay half the admission fee which is only 20 RMB/person.

title: Can't dampen the place
content: My wife and I were there in December 2013 and had a nice long tour. It was cold and rainy but we enjoyed it greatly. There are places in the garden to get out of the rain and sit and relax. There are so many different views from different locations.

title: An oasis in the hustle and bustle
content: The garden is so well planned to create an illusion of space.There are fabulous patterned pebbled walkways depicting birds and flowers.Typical scenic chinese wall murals,Winding alleyways and hidden courtyards amongst frangrant tress and shrubs of azelia,gineko and magnolia trees and of course streams and ponds of carp and limestone rock.

title: Stunning!
content: We really enjoyed this stop as part of a day tour we took - The Best of Shanghai. We were only in Shanghai for a little over a day and really wanted to see some highlights of the city. So glad we did and would definitely recommend it!

title: Beautiful, although more crowded than our last visit 4 years ago
content: Old Chinese architecture at its best. Finished in 1559 by a government officer of the Ming Dynasty. Views of pavilions, halls, rockeries, ponds and cloisters which all have unique characteristics. There are lovely tranquil areas, but you need to avoid the crowds to fully appreciate them. Circular doors and windows create opportunities for marvelous photos. Many goldfish/Coy Carp in the ponds, and the garden highlights the value placed, historically, by the Chinese in rocks of numerous shapes and sizes. There are plenty of plants but they are not as important/significant as the rocks.

title: Shanghai's Hustle Bustle
content: Its super crowded, lots of food and lots of queues around the stalls. Amazing architectures- chinese styled houses, shops. Tracking the actual garden was a little difficult- no guidance and no map. I would suggest having one in hand. Incase, you dont and you do not speak chinese, find anyone non-native to guide you. That trick always worked for me and everybody is very understanding.

title: Doorways
content: This garden had some of the most interesting doorways of all that we visited during our trip. The garden itself wasn't that spectacular. Some great souvenir bargains to be had in the shopping area right outside.

title: Beauty amidst vast crowd
content: It can be very busy which means you must pick a good time to go. This way you can enjoy the garden without the crowd. Great example of old Chinese gardens and view into the past. Its interesting to have skyscrapers as a back drop, but I like it.

title: Lovely gardens + a break from the bustling city
content: This is an enjoyable escape from the most-of-the-time overcrowded Yu Yuan market/souvenir/tourist trap (much as I enjoy it). The gardens are particularly peaceful in the winter months and very reasonably priced.

title: Lovely gardens, but be in your guard!
content: Had a lovely time strolling the gardens, having lunch at the dumpling place, and shopping for souvenirs, but beware of "friendly, helpful locals". Even though we had read about the scams, we almost fell for it once there and caught up in the moment. A friendly local businessman in a suit offered to take our photo, and chatted with us as we walked towards the gardens. He was kind enough to point us towards the entrance, and advised us to go straight to the 3rd floor of the dumpling restaurant, not wait in the long "take out" line, and was generally very helpful and pleasant, so when he offered to show us his office we almost went, then caught ourselves and told him we did not want to get caught up in the crowds, and needed to go straight to the gardens. Be careful, be in your guard, because even forewarned they are slick!

title: An oasis of calm
content: Such a contrast with the bustling bazaar nearby. Peaceful and a delight to discover at your leisure. It does absorb a lot of people but we found it was quieter in the morning.

title: Shopper's paradise
content: Plenty of small shops indoors and outdoors with a variety of goods to purchase. Wear comfortable shoes as there is much to see and very few places to sit!!

title: A Taste of Old Shanghai
content: This is a fun area to get a taste of old Shanghai. It is very touristy, but still good. My husband and I really enjoyed relaxing in the Tea House in the center of this area and we enjoyed window shopping in the stores, but did not buy anything.

title: A Garden by any other name
content: Not what I expected, When I visited the Forbidden City in Beijin, I thought they could make this more appealing by including stalls etc, add a little life, WELL life was really full on around the Yu Yyan Garden. while inside you can find the peace, the "at one with nature" feeling that makes the garden a lovely retreat, beforetackling the shops and stalls surrounding the complex

title: mesmerizing
content: You are in the bustling shanghai, full of noise, people, pollution and no rest. Feel like running away? Go take a stroll in Yu yuan first, peace will come. Better early in the morning or near closing time (to avoid crowds), but take at least 2 hours to enjoy the "contentment" of this place. Classic chinese garden, every courtyard leads to others and you can lose yourself happily, unaware of the world outside.

title: Contentment for sure
content: Before you go in, you travel with the masses taking in the sights and sounds. Upon entering you are transported. Our tour guide said some trees in this garden are over 100 years old. Don't miss it!

title: You saw one - you saw all of them
content: Of course all Chinese gardens a different, but details are common. If you have been in Forbidden City in Beijing, Yu Gardenn will not impress you too much. But if you are first time in China and think never come again – go to Yu garden, make some nice photos. Especially great to see skyscrapers under the ancient roofs of garden’s buildings.

title: There is a garden there you know
content: The Yu Yuan Garden is an ancient garden in the heart of Shanghai where centuries ago it was a private garden for the enjoyment of ministers. The Garden is now hidden within a maze of architecture of ancient looking shops built for tourists. Finding the garden itself is not inside as it is hidden inside the square of shops and it requires an entrance fee. The outside shops areas are filled with people while the garden itself is less crowded meaning most people visiting the place do not actually enter the garden rather than shopping at the shops.

title: The remarkable beauty of classical Chinese gardens is reflected here
content: Without some background, walking through a garden such as this may be less than meaningful. If possible, before your trip, do a little reading about the classical Chinese urban garden, often referred to as Suzhou garden style. One of the most interesting elements of such gardens is the way in which small spaces are designed so as to seem almost endless. To make small spaces seem larger, instead of the western way of opening it up, the Chinese divide it into smaller spaces that twist and turn while always giving glimpses of more to come through various techniques such as the windows that 'leak' the view from one place into another, the zig-zag paths that direct your view towards another direction. Stone is a major element inclassical gardens. These types of stones come from Lake Tai, near Suzhou and have been prized for over a thousand years.

user_loc: 广西壮族自治区桂林市
title: Being the first visitor pays back!
content: Been there twice, and this time I was trying to beat the crowds and I got there at 8am and spent 20 minutes at Starbuck nearby and successfully became the first person there. It was a totally rewarding visit coz I managed to take great photos, all quite and beautiful ones WITHOUT ANY TOURISTS inside the frame! I enjoyed it until 10am, couple of travel groups enter the garden... So my suggestion is, if you are traveling alone or just with a few friends, please be there as early as possible for the most tranquil views. If you are in a group, never mind, a group walk through the garden can still be fun when you can see some guy trying to catch a carp in the pond.

title: Avoid week ends
content: This beautiful garden is an "island" in Shanghai. I felt very peaceful at the beginning.. untill a group of tourists arrived and ruined everything with their loud talks

title: Worth the visit
content: After the "china town cliche" you can find in different places, this place is worth the visit, it is an authentic upscale house built by a successful business man for the enjoyment of his parents and family. The gardens and pagodas are unique, lovely to visit for a couple of hours or so.

title: not bad
content: not bad environment, colorful, it was too crowded when we were there. All kinds of food stalls and craft stalls you can find. not bad for a day time sightseeing.

title: Avoid it if you have visited Yu Garden 'Market'
content: Yu garden 'Market' which is just next to the Garden can give you the flavor of whats actually inside the garden. For Garden there is a fee of around 30RMB if am not wrong whereas the market is for free. I was attracted by the word 'contentment' but didn't find it as great especially after seeing the Market already.

title: Brilliant
content: It was wet and grey, but that didn't make a difference. This place is truly fascinating. The children loved zipping around discovering all the nooks and crannies. Definitely worth the adventure to find it!

title: Sensational, even with the crowds
content: The walk through the old market was made even more exciting as the streets and stream was decorated for the upcoming New Year celebrations. The gardens were a tranquil oasis in the centre of all that chaos, luckily we had a guide who explained the significance of the garden's features including the four hundred year old Ginko tree and the Jade Rock, a 3.3 mitre, 5 ton boulder with 71 holes, the more holes the more expensive the boulder!

title: Beautiful and impressive
content: Great place to visit in the middle of the busy city of Shanghai. The garden was like a time capsule for us to the history of old China empire. The City Temple and the photo booth in front of the temple was great too. The stall selling souvenirs need a high capability of bargain skill.

title: One of my Favourites
content: Yu Yuan Garden is one of my favourites in Shanghai. The zig zag bridge is awesome, never seen so many fish swimming around in such a frenzy, it's great to feed them and watch as the water appears to be boiling there is so much movement. Other than the fantastic bridge there is heaps to see at Yu garden, the beautiful Gardens and the great eateries, you've gotta do the Steam Bun Restaurant it's been operating for more than a hundred years and the food is sensational, a real fun experience eating them with chop sticks. The hundreds of stores/stalls is also a worthy experience, bartering is expected. Many times that I have visited Yu Yuan Garden and always been reminded to ensure security of valuables. I love the place and would never tire of visiting, if only to watch others.

title: Just beautiful
content: This is not only a piece of traditional architecture or beuatiful cultivated nature. It is a window in traditional chinese way of living, pieceful connecton with the nature that exists less and less in whole world. I recomend the sight to everybody but dont rush, sit and let the atmosphere enter your mind.

title: Fascinating memorial of a time lost
content: Part of our day tour. The park was fascinating, it takes you back to a time past. Very tranquil. There is alot of history and the Shanghais are very proud of it. The beginning of the park across the zig zag bridge from the market area was one of my best memories of Shanghai.

title: Nice garden in the heart of a shopping area!
content: This is a good change of scenery from all the shopping stalls and shops around it! I took some time to explore and enjoyed my afternoon there. The toilets were surprisingly clean and had paper!

title: Worth seeing
content: Yu Yuan Gardens and the neighboring streets are definitely worth seeing if you are in Shanghai. It offers you a view of traditional architecture, but also the expected tourist stuff like souvenir shops and eateries. It's a good place to say that you have seen.

title: Not big, but beautiful
content: Not a big garden, but I think it's the most beautiful garden in shanghai downtown. Always bring friends from other cities or countries to there, and everyone likes it.

title: Nice place to do quick shopping for souvenirs...
content: If you are looking for souvenir items, Yu Yuan garden is the place to go.From teh subway, there are a lot of stalls selling souvenir items at very cheap prices... inside the Yu Yuan, you need to haggle the price for items you fancy. My wife was able to buy a Jade bracelet at RMB 30, originally being offered to us at RMB 150. I think if I haggled for it at RMB 20, I might have been able to get it at that price. If you don’t want to haggle for price, just walk away and definitely, they will tell you their last price which actually can still be reduced father :)

title: Amazing place for tourist
content: Its a big garden and a big temple as well. Inside the temple, there alot of shops and even restaurants. The Starbucks design is so different, it looks very Chinese. There's a big pond and there will be a bridge for u to walk across the pond and its a good spot for photo taking. Many souvenir shops as well which can be purchase at the store (need to negotiate the price). Foods around there are amazing as well.

title: Another chinese garden
content: Take note of the opening hours and try to be early. I had to rush through the whole garden in 40mins.

title: if you want to escape the chaos
content: if you want to escape the chaos of Shanghai, go inside it's only a small entry fee (30rmb per person). It is a labyrinth of passages and small gardens rather than the open and grand gardens you normally find in China.

title: Surprisingly relaxing.....
content: Although the gardens are on most tourists list of must sees we found them to still be quire relaxing and beautiful - despite the number of visitors.

title: If you have been to Beijing - do not bother
content: This is a "relative" stop. If you have been to Beijing and the Forbidden City - skip this stop. It does not measure up. On the other hand, if you have not been - it will give you a feel of what you are missing and hopefully encourage you to make the trip to Beijing.

title: Very intersting
content: A lot of decorations makes a visit well worth doing. And dont miss the QLBs. The garden is pretty and has nice views.

title: A little ancient place in the center of big city
content: Beautiful ancient garden which is isolated from outer noisy modern world. A lot of tourists are there, but in case you are able to ignore them, you will see a beautiful piece of old China.

title: Worth a Look.
content: An area of peace adjacent to the hustle and bustle of one of Shanghai's shopping areas. Very intersting mix of styles and facilities.

title: Fun, everything you need - and don’t need but the touts are annoying
content: Great deal to see and buy. Love wandering around the little stores and little squares. Great to see locals buying things there. Lots of touts but manageable. Good food stalls too.

title: A relaxing garden
content: A relaxing garden to wind down and to day dream in the middle of city. However, I might not be visiting for the second time with the entrance fee charged.

title: Experiencing the Traditional China!
content: This small walled attraction is perfect for people who want to experience the old traditional China in a very touristy way. The Chinese architecture of the buildings, the souvenirs and the things sold here are perfect for this purpose. Once inside you can also pay to enter the Gardens; personally I loved getting lost in this maze gardens with several Chinese style buildings, lakes and plants, worth the pay. If you are not into Chinese street food you can find several chain restaurants here. We got a little lost trying to get from the subway station to the entrance, there were not enough signals for us, so if you can, check a map before going.

title: Do it once.
content: Crowded on weekends and you get heckled by people wanting to sell you fakes. But, it is a must see at least once and the adjacent Old Town is worth walking through to see the real Shanghai street markets.

title: excellent
content: Do not miss this place if you are coming to Shanghai. You may need to pay to enter Yu Yuan. A lot of street foods in the surrounding area.

title: Peaceful and Beautiful
content: I have been to Yu Garden Many times but had never actually gone into the Garden of Contentment until just recently -- and I can hardly believe I waited so long!

title: Ancient setting of high-class Shanghai
content: A brilliant place for photography and reminiscent of grand Shanghai in the past. This is a tourist spot where numerous wares / food are sold at 'tourist-prices'. Also, there are lots of food alternatives and visitor can find the famous Nanxiang Xiao Long Bao (Dumpling) restaurant nearby.

title: Historic and Real Chinese Experience
content: We traveled on the hottest month of the year so it was a bit upsetting. However, the place will help you endure the heat and the place outside the walls of the garden is a very busy place in which visitors have variety of choice for flea shopping. Make sure you know how to negotiate and you will surely get the rate you wanted. The restaurants are okay but make sure also to tell them what you really want. Otherwise, miscommunication will lead you to overspending!

title: Lovely Gardens
content:
Always a pleasure to visit.
Beautiful gardens, lovely bazaar for shopping, eating and drinking.
A must-do whilst in Shanghai.

title: again and again go there, always new experience
content: Beeing at that place again and beeing aware again, that this place is the real origin of Shanghai, give me a kick again and agian. Today it's very commercial and requries dirty negotiation skills if you want to buy something from the plenty souvenier shops at reasonable price.Don't go there to intentionally buy something useful or a gift if you are not local. You will find all but at inflationed price. Go there, to let you surprise.

title: Very busy
content: Enjoyed our visit here but it was very crowded though the tea house was a quiet oasis. Ordered tea which came with a variety of little cakes - enjoyable but pricey though as we sat by the window on the first floor it was worth it as we were able to watch the teaming masses below, especially the long queue at the famous dumpling shop. The gardens themselves were pretty.

title: Must Do!
content: One of the nicest parts of Shanghai and a "must do"! It gives you a real insight into the Shanghai of the past with beautiful trees, unique rocks, and ponds of water. We very much enjoyed this!

title: Tranquil and beautiful
content: Amazing sculptures, plenty of dragons, Chinese style traditional buildings very ornate set against a back drop of beautiful pools stocked with teaming coy carp. It did not disappoint everything you would expect.

title: Old world majesty.
content: For those who appreciate old chinese architecture, this place will truly give you a feel of old china. Well preserved and maintained, YuYuan is residential compound with tranquil gardens and houses. Surrounding the compound is a market mix of old and modern shops, restaurants, YES Starbucks! A nice area to buy souvenirs. This is where I had my chinese name carved on a jade seal, bought silk fans, horn combs, and the like. Do bargain. ;-)

title: A huge private garden
content: Yu Yuan Garden in a private garden from Ming Dynasty, it still keep old style so that you can have a feel of ancient times.

title: Beautiful tranquil gardens in a very busy old town area of Shanghai
content: Beautiful classical gardens in the centre of the Old Town. Not easy to find as it is a bustling area full of stalls selling everything from freshly cooked food to when we were there Xmas decorations. The gardens are laid out as is typical in China in small 'rooms' using water, a lot of large rocks, bridges and trees. The free map is helpful to guide you round. There are many pavilions in the gardens and a large stone dragon that curls along the wall.

title: Peaceful at times
content: A lovely little garden, amazingly peaceful considering it's in the middle of a huge, noisy chaotic city.

title: Busy market and tranquil gardens all in one.
content: The market is a busy place and interesting to see. The Mongolian ice cream stand was fun. The market is around a very tranquil garden so if the hustle and bustle of the market becomes too much you can escape to the gardens,

title: Beautiful & Scenic
content: The Garden is almost hidden inside of the bustling outer perimeter of shops and restaurants, but once inside, it is a beautiful garden in true Asian style. Every turn offers another photo opportunity so keep your camera out at all times. Definitely bring some crackers or chips as the pond has huge schools of poi that literally swim on top of each other to get to the grub. They will come as close as they can to get it; makes a great picture! If you have little ones, they will absolutely LOVE it! The adults get a charge out of it too :-). The cost is around $ 7 USD per person, definitely worth it.

title: Yu Yuan Garden
content: The garden is a little ancient and poetic island in the middle of the old town of Shanghai and a cluster of various lively markets. Unfortunately it is crowded and hardly enjoyable on the weekends.

title: Yu Yuan Garden is a tourist trap
content: Over priced pseudo "Chinese" area selling either overpriced or poor plastic trinkets and souvenirs .but still manages to have the usual fast food outlets you will see in your home country, so you don't have to experience anything Chinese! The Garden of Contentment sounds a lot better but really you can see and experience far better in Suzhou, less than an hour by train. Shanghai is first and foremost a commercial city and not representative of China.

title: As its in the guide books you need to go
content: A bit of a let down actually versus expectations. 40 RMP to enter. Some parts nice and some parts need renovating. Few signposts but you are never to far from shops selling souvenirs ! Area outside can also be very busy with lots of touts selling fake watches. You need to be firm to stop the touts following you

title: Beautiful garden
content: Beautiful garden hidden in the middle of the city. Very interestig place to visit and very easy to get there, as it is very close to other sighseeings.

title: It can be fun to explore, but go early
content: I visited the Garden at noon so the light was horrible for pictures. It was not very crowded, yet I felt like one would take more advantage of the place when no one is around. It is in fact a good place to getaway from the crowds outside and to breathe, hear and admire.

title: Nice place
content: It is really interesting to spend an hour or two away from the crowd to enjoy the peaceful and beautiful garden

title: Beautiful and peaceful
content: Wonderful  example of Chinese garden; the stonework on walls and pathways is really a testiment to beauty.

title: a place to relax
content: good place to relax and get away from the crowds, located in the city, but with its own special atmosphere

title: best place to visit
content: I adore such great place with nice view - tea shops - restaurants - a lots of Chinese structure buildings and nice lake

title: very wonderful views
content: Yu Garden is interesting. It's fairly large and a clash between old Asian charm and stark globalization. Garden was bigger than we expected, very wonderful views and spectacular place for getting nice pictures

title: An exquisite garden in the midst of a bazaar
content: The garden has beautiful landscaping. Has old Chinese culture and history associated with it. An unique place of visit in Shanghai

title: Exqusite Garden in Southern China
content: This garden expresses the essence of Ming and Qing Dynasty landscape design. There are halls, pavilions, streams, stone work and cultural symbols. Well worth a visit

title: Very beautiful
content:
Peaceful place and very nice to visit. Even when busy, you don't feel too crowded because it is very big. 
Good place to spend a couple of hours.

title: Yu Yuan Garden
content: Yu Yuan Garden is an amazing tourist destination in the center of Shanghai. There are all kinds of shops for purchasing souvenirs. They have little open window shops for noodles, dumplings, and all kinds of delicious street food. There is also a hinge cafeteria just off the main square. There must be hundreds of couches for lunch or dinner. There is also a big restaurant in the center for fine dining. Be sure to leave time for the side streets leading up the Garden. There are loads of little shops to visit just outside. The whole scene can be very crowded during Spring Festival.

title: Must See if first time in China
content: I live in Shanghai and am originally from America. I take all of my guest here to see the gardens and experience the different shops in the area. It is a must see for first timers.

title: Nice place to hang around...
content: The place is very well built and decorated. You will feel like you are being at a filming location. But the area is just full of shops selling food, souvenirs etc. If you like watching people, this is the place to be. I went to this place during the day time and night time and it's just so different. At night, it's so quiet and the lighting is very beautiful. At least, you can avoid the crowd at night (if you hate crowds). But most of the shops closed early. So, you will only get to stroll in the main garden at night. And the place is easy to get to. Shanghai's metro network are vast enough to have this covered. Take subway Line 10 and get off at Yuyuan Station. Just a short walk from there.

title: Garden founded in 1539
content: Worth the entry fee. A little difficult to navigate unless you have a map-available free if you ask. Fascinating ancient Chinese garden. Take a camera.

title: Traditional China and Good Shopping area
content: You can feel real China while walking in the streets and garden also the streets around has lots of thing to shop around. Many joints for food and also has ancient restaurant in area where bill Clinton also had visited

title: GREEN OASIS AMONGST HIGH RISE BUILDINGS
content: A beautiful garden with typical Chinese features such as ponds, trees and shrubs.  Mainly greenery with limited flowers on display. Pagoda style roofing attractive.  Close to French Concession quarter for shopping and restaurants.  Considerable redevelopment occurring in adjacent areas.

title: Classic One to try Classic Xiao Long Bao!!
content: Try xiao long bao that has long been a legend in Shanghai. A variety of small shops serve souvenirs and food. Clever bidding at a jade / jewelry store. Especially for those of you who do not know about it.

title: Nice place to take a couple of good pictures
content: Nice place. Many nice corners to take some pictures. Many people! Take a lot of care of your belongings....

title: A must visit if you are interested in architecture and garden design
content: I like architecture and garden design. I am also a avid gardener. When I get a chance, I would always visit a garden or two when I travel to a new city. This is a must see garden in Shanghai since it is a typical southern Chinese garden.

title: Garden and shopping and food
content: What better place to be. The big red bus stops here (day ticket Yuan 100 or less. Entrance fee's extra, But you may just walk thru the free portion of the park (crowded any time of the day) excellent food vendors, go to the one that have long lines. 10 Yuan stores with all kind of goodies to take home. Recommended MeuterMedia

title: Beautiful Garden tucked away behind tourist villa
content: Get past the touristy shops and you will find this beautiful garden in the middle of Shanghai's towering buildings. Not being a gardener, I was not very excited to visit this, but had been told it is a must see... and I agree and will return again next time in Shanghai. The buildings, koi ponds and rock formations were beautiful and romantic for a stroll.

title: Beautiful Chinese garden but spend no more than an hour....
content: It's a very nice and beautifully designed garden. It gets quite boring because all part of the gardens look the same. Take your photos and move on to the next attractions :p

title: A view into the past of shanghai
content: A wonderful example of an upper class Chinese' home from centuries past. Reading the other reviews, I think some clarifications are needed:

title: Spectacular place for some peace and quiet in Shanghai
content: What a beautiful place. Something to see around each corner. It is a hidden gem in the middle of a large shopping area. We spent a few hours here, mostly because we had to wait for some of the large crowds to clear to get a few photos without people everywhere. Take time to get off the regular path and find some of the back corners of this beautiful space in such a bustling city. This will be one of our families favorite memories of Shanghai.

title: Super crowded tourist spot
content: This is one of the main places to visit in Shanghai. The main little pond with pagoda is kind of pretty but small and tons of tourists. Every where around there people are trying to sell you junk and are very aggressive .

title: Not peaceful
content: I don't know what time you are 'supposed' to go and visit places such as this... but I went almost midday and it took us at least half an hour to get in because we could physically not walk there due to the large waves of crowds!!! The garden is pretty for sure and a treasure to booming shanghai, however maybe wake up super early because the business ruined my expectations and sanity!!

title: This is a beautiful spot not to be missed!
content: If you are going to be in Shanghai for any reason, you must make time to see Yu Garden.  You will remember its beauty for a long time to come.

title: Wonderful visit but crowded
content: This is a beautiful place with lots of history. However, it was so crowded, it was hard to move around. It was hard to enjoy parts of it due to the volume of people. However, it was very close to restaurants and lots of shopping. The nearly shops are the perfect place to buy gifts. If you are a history buff, it's definitely worth the time. I might think twice about it if I had to push a stroller, or was traveling with someone who couldn't get around easily.

title: Beautiful garden
content: Beautiful but busy garden unfortunately spoilt by rude citizens who are not used to western tourists and therefore stare

title: Relaxing from the crowds
content: Garden is located right in the middle of always busy and overcrowded Yuyuan market, so it is definitely worth a visit to get a little bit away from all the hassle.

title: 40.000.000 visitors / year
content:
get a little feeling of old china 
surrounded by a mass of tourists  , and enjoying the scenary and the shopping 
go to a tea house and shop for some golden jewelry

title: nice garden must visit!
content: interesting experience to visit Yu Garden. It makes me feel like i was in old days of China, the scene that only can see in the drama. The buildings and landscape in this garden also worth to visit. it is refreshing to rest awhile in this garden and enjoy the scene~

title: Awesome
content: What a nice garden in the middle of the city. Could be crowded over weekends but worth visiting it. Very well maintained.

title: basically its a carnival
content: old buildings but so commercial. the whole place was a disappointment, its like a mall. albeit the buildings are historic. people selling all sorts of electronics, cheap clothing, shoes, food etc. well, i guess, just go to check it out but dont expect too much. food is also overpriced. better off eating elsewhere for better value and quality. had the most awful steamed dumplings there! terrible! even had a stomachache after that meal! no good.

title: Peaceful in a busy city
content: Go a take look around these gardens it is an oasis in the middle of town. A visit to the tea house is worth it. There is a lot to look at and the water features are really very nice.

title: Interesting but crowdy
content: Yu Garden is an extensive Chinese garden located beside the City God Temple in the northeast of the Old City of Shanghai. It is accessible from the Shanghai Metro's Line 10 Yuyuan Garden Station.

title: Beautiful!
