content: Went there with our tour group. Enjoyed walking through the gardens and learning about its history.Photographer's dream.Not to be missed.

title: Peaceful
content: Was part of our day tour, learning the history of the garden was a good experience  and the Garden itself was a peaceful trip.

title: Close your eyes and imagine
content: Imagine what the garden of eden must have been like, Chinese style. This place would come to mind. Minus the mobs of people. The garden is beautifully landscaped with flowers, trees, rock gardens, pavillions and ponds. The coy fish here are HUGE & plentiful. The buildings are distinct and have fine detailed carvings. Eye catching statues abound. You'll want to take plenty of pictures, but your camera wont be able to capture the full beauty of this place.Take your time and stroll through here. If you are lucky, you can even find a place to sit and enjoy the moment. Just you and nature.......and hundreds of others. Haha

title: YU GARDEN - BUILDINGS WITH BITS OF A GARDEN
content: Not a garden in a Western sense - but a series of buildings - most of which I am sure are totally renovated with a certain amount of planting & water features. What you see has a style but our guide was working hard to keep us interested. Very crowded with twisty narrow pathways -not everybody felt safe. Worth a visit if you have the time but not a highlight.

title: Very Pleasant
content: A lovely spot to while away an hour or two. Lovely gardens and architecture - Compared to Japanese Gardens it was a bit more concrete based, less green & nature based.

title: "Heavenly Garden" a place must see to complete your tour in Shanghai, China
content: Yu Yuan Garden is a famous classical garden located in Anren Jie, Shanghai. It was finished in 1577 by a government officer of the Ming Dynasty (1368-1644) named Pan Yunduan. Yu in Chinese means pleasing and satisfying, and this garden was specially built for Pan's parents as a place for them to enjoy a tranquil and happy time in their old age.

title: Time goes slow at this heavenly place
content: The place is definitely worth a visit for me and I spent more than 2 hours over here. Walking around this traditional Chinese garden made me feel like going back to the 16th century. I am so impressed with many beautiful buildings, exquisite walkways and gates, garden maze and large rocks, plus the walks through over 40 scenic spots. Fantastic trees and resting pavilions everywhere!

title: Worth a visit, very touristy, eat dumplings and enjoy shopping for souvenirs
content: Try to go on a weekday to avoid the crowds. Lots of places to buy souvenirs, you may or may not get the best deals. Architecture is very good. A nice place to walk around, eat dumplings, and people watch.

title: BEAUTIFUL BUT BIT RUN DOWN
content: very beautiful garden, not very kept. very crowded , most of the site info was written in chinesse, not informative for tourist

title: YU Garden
content:
It’s located in the old city of Shanghai, built in 1559 virtual maze of caves, gardens, rockeries, paths, bridges, and lovely Chinese architecture buildings
A wonderful place to visit highly recommended, there is a museum inside the garden as well

title: Serene spot in Hectic Metropolis
content: Beautiful restored garden in Central area of Shanghai. Allow about 1 hour to wander through this lovely garden with many different areas.

title: Yu Garden
content: The Yu Garden is a traditional Chinese garden, with interesting architecture and history. It is usually quite crowded, so don't expect a lot of quiet spots. Still, definitely worth a visit if you are in Shanghai.

title: Cool place yet crowded
content: Yu Gardens could be really cool if the crowds were significantly less. Nevertheless, eac h garden area has a Zen feel and if you can imagine the serenity, especially back in the day, it's manageable. I think this attraction is just one of those place to tick off the list.

title: Head on a weekday, less crowded. Worth a visit.
content: Yu Yuan old town is lovely, and the Gardens are worth a visit. They are not strictly gardens, but a series of old religious buildings. Definitely worth wondering around. Treat yourself to some outstanding dumplings at Nanziang Steamed Bun restaurant while you are in the vicinity.

title: Yu Garden
content: Spectacular 2-hectare late-dynastic garden, a fine remaining gem from the late dynastic period. Terrific walls, cobbled paving, and buildings. Lots of twisty, winding, climbing paths to explore--utterly unsuited for those with mobility issues. Could barely hear the city around me as we walked. If you want to see old China, this is one place to do so.

title: Preferred over Summer Palace
content: I loved the garden.  While sprawling and definitely not made for a commoner, it had a homey feel, so different from palaces and summer palaces of Beijing.

title: Beautiful
content: The Yu gardens is a 400 years old garden and the most famous one in Shanghai. Being not a garden person, even i was struck by its beauty. It's filled with ponds, rockeries , pavilions and halls. The water bodies are filled with fishes, turtles and ducks. Loved the theme architecture each area head. Even though overcrowded you feel peaceful here.

title: Beautiful ancient Chinese garden
content: It was around 5 - 10 minutes walk from the Yu Yuan metro station. After the walk, we first reached the Yu Yuan Old Streets, where all the large tour groups will make a stop, making it very crowded.

title: Busy, interesting and beautiful
content: You Gardens is full of people and action, everyone going somewhere or enjoying the sites. We had a good time walking around and bought a few souvenirs to take to friends and family. It is a place where you bargain for the best price and never pay their first asking price. You will find some nice things, but be careful not to get inferior quality for the same price.

title: Sanctuary in Shangy
content: Shanghai is a large and bustling city. Cars, bicycles, scooters and rickshaws compete with pedestrians to get about. Needed is an escape to reflect and plan. Yu Garden is is that escape. Gentle rolling pathways reveal beautiful flowers, trees and grasses. Benches provide seating for the weary. I have arrived.

title: Serene and peaceful gardens away from the manic shops nearby
content: The gardens are peaceful and quiet with old and ornate  buildings.  Unfortunately you have to run the gauntlet of scam merchants to get to it (worth it).  Offered all kinds of good and try to drag you away.

title: Lovely Gradens
content: This is a lovely garden that isn't far from The Bund. The zigzag bridge is busy with people but that is because it is lovely to cross. There are nice restaurants around the area and the garden is a good size. If you are in Shanghai I would recommends making time to visit here.

title: Yu Garden
content: We got onto this Tour at the Airport. Took us by bus etc  Had a lovely Tea ceremony  overlooking the garden. And also a quick junket type ride. Let us browse at our own Leisure & the moved on to next stop

title: Amazing China in the heart of the City
content: This is a great thing to do on a non weekend if possible. The beauty here is great and its bustling on the outside with Chinese culture. A must do for those visiting for a short time.

title: Beautiful old garden in the middle of the city
content: This is a wonderful old garden hidden in the middle of the busy city. The garden itself is a quiet place surrounded by busy streets, many stores and even more tourists. The garden has a rich history and a wonderful story about a man who wanted to build a garden a long time ago. The garden is a nice place to relax and do people watching. The surrounding area is all but quiet. There are lots of stores selling pearls, tea and everything a tourist wants. There are probably more tourists than in any other place in Shanghai. But if you want to relax and see some real history, you should definitely visit the garden. I would probably do shopping and eating somewhere else though. The location is very nice too. You get there easily with metro 10, and it does not take more than 20 minutes to walk from Nanjing Road. The Bund is less than ten minutes away walking.

title: Beautiful Gardens, but Don't Come During a Holiday
content: So I have mixed feelings about the garden. I first came during National Holiday, when if I could see the ground for the feet of all the people, it was a rare occasion. So it can get *really* crowded, is what I'm saying.

title: Beautiful Garden with History
content: We had a tour guide so we knew what we were looking at. The gardens are unique in that fact that it was once a private garden where a family entertained guests. We learned about how the host sits in the east and the guests sit in the west. There were beautiful paths that led to small buildings and water pools. The architecture was amazing and it was interesting to see the new high rises peeking above the old pagodas. There was a dragon wall that was very interesting as well as some amazing sculptures on the roofs of the buildings. It was a pretty day and that made the gardens more beautiful.

title: interesting place
content: Very well presented example of old style chinese village life. A little hard on the feet to negotiate for an older person but well worth the effort.

title: Very ancient and unique. Gives window to ancient living in China
content: Its a must visit place to have a peek into the ancient living by a rich person who made this huge place for himself. Spread in over 20 acres, it comprises of very unique sculptures, falls, water channels, trees, etc. It gives you a good idea of how old and rich people can live a stylish life of their choice.

title: Lovely garden
content: You will get an idea of how "the other half "lived and see how gardens were designed.  Our local guide knew the place well as her mother had worked there when she was a child so we had her memories.

title: Break from the bustling city!
content: If you have already been to a few sacred gardens in China, then this repetitive. I suggest just walking around the old city area and grab some xiaolongbao because there might be a que in the summer high season. It is a nice garden to walk around in, we had a student discount and we thought we might as well.

title: Great Landscape
content: the Yu Garden tells the story of the culture of China with the solemn garden and the different hall exhibits.

title: Respite from the heat of Shanghai
content: Yu Garden is well worth the visit. Easy to find on the Metro with a station very close by. The surrounding area/marketplace is extremely busy with crowds of shoppers/sightseers, and can be a little overwhelming. But once you have paid your entry fee, the garden itself is lovely, with beautiful Chinese architecture/pavilions, interesting rockery, walkways and bridges over ponds filled with carp. Not exactly a "garden" in the Western sense, but enjoyable to wander and escape the heat of the city nonetheless. Watch out for touts and pickpockets in surrounding area though.

title: Beautiful ancient garden.
content: Went to yuyuan one of the mornings. Gives you a treat of the past nicely conserved garden right in the heart of the city . About 10 mins walk from metro.

title: Antique and Interesting Place
content: Used to be a Temple but now it is a very crowded tourist area. Interesting zigzagging bridges walk you thru the garden. Many small stores around the area selling local and inexpensive souvenirs. There is a famous dumpling and steamed bun place around the garden favorite of the locals and visitors alike. The waiting line is over 1 hour.

title: Beautiful
content: Really enjoyed the visit. It was crowded but the beauty of the place captivates you. Avoid buying things from the tourist trap surrounding the garden.

title: not one to miss
content: even visiting on a wet day in April the place was crowded but the gardens are indeed beautiful and the buildings are themselves interesting - again we were very rushed with the guide and could have spent a lot longer here to soak up the atmosphere

title: More then a garden
content: This beautiful place depicts the culture of China.

title: A gem in the middle of a 12million person city
content: This really is an oasis in the middle of a truly bustling city .....great walks through ancient ,restored buildings ;very crowded as it is popular with locals ...great water features ,too .

title: Very beautiful place
content: It is a very beautiful place to visit. Usually is very crowded, as usual in China, but it deserves a visit.

title: good fun for first time visitor
content: this is a big tourist spot for visitors in Shanghai. If you are the first time in Shanghai and dont mind be push around with thousand Chinese tourists might be good idea to pay a visit. Because this is only place that will looks like "China" in old imagination world in Shanghai

title: Very 'samey'
content: Beautiful for a photograph and for a walk around. However, everything here is very similar, the shops and the food.

title: So many beautiful vistas in this utterly charming little village
content: Our tour guide showed us this beautiful village. We were utterly enchanted with the ponds, lakes, the architecture, carvings and temples. This is the ultimate photo destination. If I could only see one place in Shanghai, this would be it! I will remember this day for the rest of my life.

title: A great place with lots of interesting history
content: The day we visited the gardens was very bust being Chinese New Year but that only added to the excitement. Even with the huge crowds, it was very well arranged & organised. This is the first place I will visit again when next in Shanghai.

title: Pretty and full of history
content: Going in through the entrance on a main road in Shanghai you can't believe that the gardens and temples inside are as pretty and steeped in history as they are.

title: Huge market place
content: Didn't go into the actual gardens. We didn't get past all of the market stalls and shops. It was a Sunday morning and there were heaps of people out and about.

title: Beautiful gardens and tons of shopping
content: If you only have a few hours or a day in Shanghai, I highly recommend going to the Yu Garden. This is one of the few "green" places in the city and next door are tons of shops for souvenirs and food. The garden closes around 7pm so I would recommend going in evening, enjoying the garden, and then shopping and dinner afterward. Available items include fans, silk, jade, chopsticks, and tea. There is a famous tea house you can also visit. Be ready for tons of people, but well worth the excursion.

title: Lovely gardens
content: Lovely gardens in a madness of lots of people. Take time to visit the gardens it is lovely and very peaceful. Do not visit on a public holiday as you cannot move

title: Calmness between the chaotic rush.
content: Yu Garden is an excellent stress buster place with a beautiful garden & huge greenery very well maintained.Surprisingly this garden is nestled between the chaotic market & the commercial area around the bund,but once inside,it is sheer bliss.Unfortunately the vendors trying to sell their wares are a bit of a bother.A nice must visit place.

title: Overwhelming but interesting
content: If you are a westerner be prepared for peopel to try to sell you watch and bags, I advise to just look past them like you dont hear or see them and they get the point otherwise they will continue to harass you. Lots and lots of tourists but beautiful garden and interesting buildings none the less. I highly suggest going here!

title: Holiday trip
content: This was an amazing place to visit, could have stayed there all day, it's full of history, the gardens are amazing, and very well layer out, you need a guide to tell you the full history,

title: Beautiful Surprises Around Every Turn
content: The Yu garden and home is one of Shanghai's shining jewels. If you are looking for a quiet natural experience rich with history the Yu garden is a great pick. I visited on a Saturday morning with a guide about 9:30am. It was not too busy and since I had a guide. I was able to ask a ton of questions. I got a nature walk, history lesson, and some great pictures. It took us about an hour and a quarter to tour the whole compound with all its twists and turns. It is also right next to the Yu Tourism Market which has a great selection of souvenir and artisan shops to visit. I thought it was the highest quality gift shops we visited in Shanghai or Beijing.

title: Serene and peaceful
content: The gardens are beautiful very well manicured. Very peaceful and comfortable atmosphere. I would highly recommend a visit

title: Excellent
content:
Beautiful house beautiful history 
Well worth the visit

Do not miss if ur in the area
Have some stunning pictures

title: Fantastic Garden but Not Maintained
content:
The garden is very spacious, located in the heart of shopping streets. Many spots to rest and take pictures, but also smelly and dusty...

It's so hot at noon, yet when sunset it can be really beautiful...

title: Very nice place to walk
content: This is a great place to expend the afternoon, a lot of different things to see, you can shop and eat at this place.

title: Ancient garden
content: This garden complex is built in the Ming Dynasty, more than 400 years ago. The design and architecture of the gardens, pavilions, halls, rock formations and ponds are classical Chinese. Look out specifically for the Exquisite Jade Rock located across from Yuhua Hall, one of the three famous rocks in this region.

title: Away from the hustle and bustle
content: Once you have passed through the mayhem of the Chinese market outside the entrance you will find peace and tranquillity in a this beautiful garden with its pavilions, viewpoints, plants, lakes and rooms. Traditional Chinese roofs adorn the buildings, look out for the figures on them, as you would expect koi carp make and appearance and there are figurative dragons - it's rather like being in a wonderful fairy tale! It's busy but still manages to retain an air of tranquillity, worth a visit.

title: Yu yuan
content: It's been years since I have been going to Yu Yuan.. It's evolved since the days we only got Chinese steam bread or dimsums.

title: Zig Zag bridge
content: The real fell of China here.  Lots of locals and beautiful gardens.  Try the zig zag bridge, amazing to see.

title: Wonderful place
content: Really famous place very crowded and popular for tourist . Many typical houses and shops in a very friendly and old tradition Chinese environments . I do definitely recommend to visit the garden .. not far from the city centre it definitely deserve a visit .

title: Ancient city
content: Visited here everytime I'm in Shanghai. Try the puppet show and dumplings for a unique experience. Great photo taking.

title: Excellent garden
content: Try to visit on a day non-weekend and non-holiday day. The gardens are not huge and too many people makes quite a crowd. But they are a must visit. Beautiful traditional Chinese gardens.

title: Outstanding
content: Very nice little place. Loved the architecture​ and tranquility. Easy to get lost and miss some of the structures. Must see if you visit Shanghai. Great little eating and shopping places around. Close to the metro line. Easy to find...as they say, just follow the crowd!

title: Piece of history in modern city
content: It was pleasant walk around little pools from one pavillion to another. I took interesting shots of historical corners with skyscrapers on the background. Shopping and eating nearby is enjoyable if you can stand the crowds of tourists.

title: Beautiful Garden & great place to shop too
content: Yu Yuan Garden is very close to the Metro station of the same name on line 10.

title: Nice place, but crowded on weekends
content: I've been there already a couple of times. It is really a good place for sightseeing, especially with all the things you can see and do around Yu Garden.

title: Beautiful historical gardens
content: What an amazing place situated in old Shanghai. We spent hours here and got amazing photos. It is such a tranquil place and not far away from the daily hustle and bustle.This is a place definitely worth visiting. It was recommended to us by a number of people, so here we are recommending it to you as a must see.

title: A welcome historical break from the crowds
content: This is not the easiest place to get to as there are no signs once you go out of Exit 1 at Yuyuan Garden Station. If you turn right you will eventually come across a signpost trail which will lead you into the bazaar and to the Gardens. Be wary of salespeople while walking through the bazaar, as they will target you if you stop to look at signs for even a moment. Being firm with them and saying 'not interested' generally worked.

title: Too crowded to visit on weekend
content: The place is not really worth to go due to too many peoples in weekends. There are mini shop you can buy survinor and place to rest like ice cream shop.

title: Amazing gardens built for an Emperor
content:
Amazing gardens built in old Shaghai.

It was built in 1559 during the Ming Dynasty. 

Many pools of koi fish and interesting rocks, including the "Jade Rock"

title: Been there..done that
content: Ok so this garden is a must do when in Shanghai, however, been to one Chinese garden been to them all. Nothing to me really stood out to me, but then again , im am not a garden guy. Still nice enough, and when you see it again on TV you too can say ..been there...done that!

title: Pleasing
content: Run the gauntlet of tourist traps and spend some time in a peaceful place and soak up the past. Look for the hidden gems, a guide is a must. The well placed mirrors, the jade stones, the pavilions, the dragons, the figurines, the deformed happy fish and the tortoises. Old China in its best preservation. Outside in the old town not the place for cold drinks on a hot day. Many of the drink fridges are for storage not cooling.

title: Must visit
content: A tourist place you can't miss in Shanghai. Its construction is very local but you'll find a Mc Donalds in the middle of it. Really nice contrast. I also recommend going inside the garden (you have to pay), much better if your traveling during springtime. You can find many souvenirs, nice tea shops. Generally is really crowded. Be aware with pickpockets!!

title: Yu Garden
content: I have been here twice once last November on a weekend and last week early on a weekday. The weekend was very crowded but the visit we had during the week at about 10am was much more pleasant. The garden is very nice and the dumplings at the famous shop near the pond were great. Advise you go early in the morning to avoid the crowds as by 1pm on the weekday it was very busy. This location attracts many Chinese tourists so it can be busy especially the food vendors. Worth the time to see the gardens.

title: Chinese landscaping
content: Lakes, pavilions and chinese architecture encompassed in one. Iconic views of traditional chinese buildings. Tourist traps all round. Great photogenic spot.

title: a slice of paradise in a crazy urban jungle
content: absolutley stunning garden and so peaceful. You can go here for some peace and quite and then go outside to enjoy the madness again and the crab soup dumplings

title: Wonderfull place
content:
Wonderfull place to visit when being in Shanhai.
Make sure you find a tour guide for the visit of the garden, this will give you some additional information.
It's an ocean of peace inside the busy tourstic district

title: Nice gardens...that's it !!
content:
Beautiful gardens but nothing spectacular...the market outside is good with many shops and restautants.
City God temple is very close as well.

title: Shopping better than the garden
content: We took more pics outside of the garden then inside.  Great souvenir shopping just outside of this garden.  As well as some really cool architecture.

title: Excellent Garden and Traditional Chinese craft
content: We reached here with a Tour on Hop on and hop off.Entry to exit the atmosphere is great!Their is vegetarian restaurant ,just ask any English speaking Chinese to write in Mandarin "Vegetarian noodle soup"The local people will show you the way!

title: Loved it!
content: Great authentic Chinese atmosphere while feeling safe and has very good eating options. I particularly enjoyed the famous steamed bun restaurant

title: Piece in the middle of the city
content: Even thought there were a lot of tourist in the garden, we could feel the piece inside it... lots of nature and history there. Better to check google while visiting to understand the history behind the garden because there is no info inside the garden, about the history. But very nice place to visit while in Shanghai!

title: Must visit
content: In OldTown Shanghai. Peaceful and educational. Closes at 4:30.B,e sure to go to the old tea house outside the gardens!

title: Wonderful gardens
content: This a great place to stroll around, lovely gardens, water features, buildings etc.  Very peaceful and tranquil.  A

title: Beautiful gardens with lots of history
content: This garden is very beautiful. It is advisable to get a local tour guide as there is a lot you will miss without this. There are some amazing Bonsai trees that are hundreds of years old worth seeing.

title: A beautiful setting not to be missed!
content: Good place to take photos. Try going there during nighttime to be able to get photos when everything is well lit. It is a must, recommend to everyone who loves beautiful place for relaxing mind

title: Affordable shopping place
content: A huge place to shop . At least stay for 3 hours enogh yo explre the place and shop. You can bargain but mostly not.

title: Yu Garden, French Concession and other Magnificent Surprises!
content: I spent one day in Shanghai, which was nowhere near sufficient to explore all the beauty and varied secrets it holds! I must plan a longer visit next time.

title: YU Garden - Beautiful Garden of Ming Dynasty filled with rocks, houses , trees and water
content: Amazing site seeing place within the city of Shanghai and not to be missed. Even though you are in Shanghai you feel you are entering an area of 15th century all of a sudden. well protected area and good for 2 to 3 hours spending. It was constructed during Ming Dynasty in 16th century, a place to comfort his father.

title: Iconic Old Shanghai
content: There are 3 must do things in any visit to Shanghai; riding the Maglev, walking along the bund and enjoying tea at the Yu Yuan (Yu Garden)

title: very affordable and beautifull gardens
content: nice afternoon viewing the gardens and relaxing by the water, excellent staff great to see located in a very busy tourist are of the city allow at least two hours hear if you want to take in everything this has to offer, brilliant shop that sells some one of pieces of art. Very relaxing and excellent plants and different flowers

title: WORTH THE VISIT
content: A traditional Chinese garden that is worth the visit, the design is structured like a maze so you might have to backtrack or you might miss something, there is a small entrance fee. The area is well known for its teahouse which sits in the middle of a small lake and is connected by a zigzag bridge. It can get pretty crowded but is a beautiful area to go to.

title: Great place to visit
content: Yu Garden is a MUST visit tourist place. Love the culture and the scenery. There are lots of little shops there where they sell interesting stuff. Love those silk scarfs and the prices are reasonable.

title: Beaitidul
content:
Beautiful architecture and higher end markets 
 Worth a visit to get crafts to take home, stamps, soaps, brushes,

title: Very Peaceful Place
content: I visited here in March 2017. Over the last 10 years I have visited here a number of times. The Yu Garden (Yuyuan) is a very peaceful place in the middle of a great modern city. You can simply explore the various Chinese gardens for as long as you want and even just sit and rest and meditate. You forget that you are in Shanghai until you look up and see tall buildings.

title: Take a tour over self-exploring
content: A good tour guide will be able to explain the meaning behind the layout of the premises.  In addition, one can find fine restaurants as well as touristy shops and shady knock-off vendors.  I recommend visiting in a group.

title: An oasis of tranquility
content: A must see in Shanghai - beautiful pavilions, gardens and water. An oasis of tranquility, even when very crowded.

title: Old Shanghai
content: Visited by train (good, clean and efficient. Dual language in train), a nice garden scenic walk towards the old hear of town.

title: Incredible place
content: One of my favorite place in Shanghai! not only an incredible huge scenic garden but also the entire area, with plenty of shops, restaurants, food stalls and the foodcourt! best time is afternoon so you can enjoy also the evening atmosphere with the unique lights, very romantic

title: don't miss it, it's fun
content: We visited several "gardens" in China. A garden is a walled compound built by a wealthy individual with several buildings and landscaped courtyards. This was a very nice one.

title: Spend a few pleasant hours here
content: Good place to visit in Shanghai, traditional buildings, food halls and cheap shopping. Must do on your list and this is a stop on the City Sightseeing Hop on Hop off Bus

title: Oasis in the city
content: This garden is quite large with beautiful lakes filled with fish and turtles. There are furnished buildings and even an outdoor opera theatre.

title: Must see Spot for first time traveller to Shanghai
content: They are closing in the evening but there are a lot of shops nearby.  Catered more for tourists their dumplings are still very good.   Must see as a spot.

title: Crowded and poor example of Chinese garden
content: I was disappointed. I have visited traditional Chinese gardens elsewhere in China and in the US and Canada. They are intended as places of retreat and calm. Yuyuan is in the middle of a tourist carnival. Hot, crowded, noisy, with cleaning supplies (mops, buckets) visible in many places.

title: A tranquil place of interest
content: It was raining on the day of our visit but it did not detract from this interesting garden and its connecting buildings. It is a combination of creative design and usage. Well worth a visit as it is part of history.

title: A tranquil break from a busy city
content:
A pleasant classical Chinese garden which is maintained beautifully and offers a view of the Shanghai of yesteryear.

For those that enjoy retail therapy a bustling array of tourist shops surround the gardens

title: The Views
content: Great place to visit and see lots of CHinese gardens . colour and peaceful place to visit. CAn get there easily with the train line and a very popular place by the locals

title: Hidden Gem Not to be Missed
content: This garden is an oasis and a great contrast to modern Shanghai. Hidden in the now very commercial market of old Shanghai, it's a haven of natural beauty; a labyrinth filled with ancient living quarters, corridors, ponds, stone structures and lots of charming nooks and crannies. We spent hours exploring its many twists and turns and beautiful settings. Every inch is picturesque and peaceful despite the throngs of people. From certain angles you could also see a skyscraper of two in the distance, which made for a great contrast. As impressive as those high rises are, you have to also appreciate the craftsmanship and creativity of what went into creating the Yu Garden. It must have really be a relaxing and luxurious setting back in the day. Now it is a gem not to be missed.

title: Yue Yuan Garden
content: Great place to spend an evening if you like old architecture and lights while not minding the souvenir shops.

title: It's Gardens
content: To get to the gardens you have to bypass hundreds of small shop owners. Everything is available here. The gardens cost 40 Chinese and well worth it.

title: Oasis in a busy city
content: A top sight in Shanghai, a beautiful Chinese garden to relax in. Even though it's crowded with tourists in the garden, there is still a feeling of peace and relaxation here, away from the busy traffic and loud noises.

title: Nice Garden
content: This garden was nice to walk through. There were a lot of people there. Signs in English to read about the garden which was nice!

title: Magnificent lanscaping
content: Love how it was being build. Each view is like painting. The scenery is just amazing. Ticket is cheap too

title: Beautiful Park
content: Nice area to visit, can get quite crowded though. Gardens, ponds and pavilions. Plenty of shops nearby for souvenirs and close to a metro station.

title: Crowded market place with some attractive architecture.
content: Crowded, over-priced shops and low-grade eateries. Some of the architecture was enjoyable, but this is a very commercial area and foot traffic was too crowded to enjoy the walk.

title: Beautiful
content: Such a delightful place to visit, very pretty gardens and loads of history.  An great place to visit.

title: Old Shanghai in the heart of a cosmopolitan
content: A trip to Shanghai without Yu Garden is incomplete. The locals have fond memories since this was quite centralize before the city expanded. Lots of interesting alleys, local eateries, old buildings, shopping for souvenirs (must bargain hard though!). The Bridge of Nine Turnings (no fee) must not be missed as this is where the locals believe that every turn of a new year (Spring Festival), they must walk through his bridge for good health and other good blessings/fortunes; a real tradition. Yu Garden has a fee to it and it costs RMB 40 per entry. The only highlight for me was the 'Dragon Wall' (as in the photo posted). If you have enough of gardens in this part of China, skip it and just roam around the former temple in the area which, is just as interesting. There is also a Taoist Temple called Chenghuangmiao in the area with RMB 10 entrance fee. This is where the locals come to worship. Within the vicinity there is a Mosque also. A good 2-3 hours of exploring.

title: Large Gardens
content: I was surprised how large the gardens were. Very nice. We visited on a Wednesday morning in late May. It was overcast and sprinkling on and off. Due to the weather the crowds were almost nonexistent. The weather didn't damper our touring though. Since everything is very covered in trees, you didn't really notice the overcast skies. And you didn't get very wet.

title: Must-go place, but put it necessarily on the top of your list
content: This is a must-go place, the garden is certainly worth a visit. However, it does cost you some money and it can be very crowded, as the place is surrounded by shopping areas as well. Best is to go in the off-season, and avoid the weekends.

title: A beautiful escape from the busyness of Shanghai.
content: Very ancient gardens with so much history and beauty.  We toured the gardens with an English speaking guide who made our visit so interesting with confucious tales & stories and loads of history.  Well worth visiting these gardens when in Shanghai.

title: Cultural trip
content: I must admit we didn't see the old tea house in the lake but that was because there was so much else to see! We arrived in the midst of the Dragon boat Festival so there were points of interests everywhere - from displays, to dragon boat like stages and the 3-Sided wrapped rice treats on sale.

title: too much people
content: it is suppose to be a zen place . Too much people are in the same place in the same time . but very beautiful place

title: Old part of Shanghai with nice Chinese Garden
content: Some may view this area to be a tourist trap and overly commercialized. However it is still one of this areas which one has to visit while in Shanghai. The old wooden structures are maintained and there are shops and restaurants inside the Yu Garden complex.

title: A small, intricate garden.
content: Worth a visit. Gives a good view of traditional Chinese gardens. Kinda nice how it's nestled in a major city.

title: Amazing
content: If you like history and architecture this a must see place. It's unbelievable the garden and the construction of it. We had a great time, there is a bazaar near where you can do also some shopping.

title: Absolutely beautiful!
content: These gardens were absolutely beautiful, I'd say in the top 3 of gardens I've ever visited! Typically Chinese, beautiful architectural style of pagodas etc. Just beautiful.

title: A Lovely Garden
content:
This Garden is certainly worth visiting.
It is very well laid out, with beautiful rockeries, plants, statues, shrubbery and ponds.
The architecture of the buildings complements the scenery.
A quiet respite from the Yu Yuan Market

title: Architectures, Souveniers, Foods
content: Love the buildings, my second times here. Remember to haggle for the souvenirs. Not all places serve delicious food, your best bet is to follow the long queue. I was lazy to wait and simply head into a low traffic restaurant, end up eating bad quality food. If you go outskirts of the main buildings, can get cheaper priced for the exact same items. Generally selling same things. The place itself is beautiful to see and be at. Enjoy your visit and take lots of photos.

title: Lovely
content: Really enjoyed this spot. However it is crawling with tourists. Go early to enjoy the peace and serenity.

title: Famous Yuyuan Gardens
content: The Yuyuan Gardens was built on 1559 by a previous Chinese Commissioner & owned by his family. It is presently preserved by the government. Within the confines of the gardens, aside from the plants, perfect landscaping & rock art are precious cultural relics & Chinese art work. This is a 'must' place to visit when in Shanghai.

title: This is a must visit
content: We went there many many times ! Very turístic area and with great snap views ! Is full of historic spots and highly recommended ! There are many different options of local food and we also loved to visit the temples around there . They are really nice ! Worth to visit !

title: Serenity...Sorta
content: The landscape and architectural design of the Yu Garden lends itself to what could be a beautifully serene stroll...except for the masses of local people who have no sense of walking decorum or personal space. If you can look beyond the people, you will be able to take away a bit of the serenity intended by the brilliant designer(s).

title: looking for time away from the hustle and bustle look no further
content: this garden is truly wonderful ... It has so many little outdoor rooms to explore. Most noticeably no traffic noise and the pace of life slows. It is well worth a visit and allow time not only to explore this huge garden but to stop along the way to "smell the roses"

title: A lovely oasis in the he middle of the city
content: Second time to this lovely garden in the city. Was quite crowded ,but still a must see.

title: This was divine
content: There are so many things to see in China it is impossible to tell you them all. I can simply say that everything we saw was outstanding and I cannot say enough about our Viking River Cruise but more especially our guide Leo! This was breathtaking and beautiful.

title: Extremely crowded, but worth a visit
content: The Garden itself is beautiful, a very well planned Chinese garden, but it is also extremely crowded, but still worth a visit (although I have to admit that I like these gardens).

title: A surprise in the biggest city in the world
content: Chinese Gardens everywhere are known for their power to induce serenity & calmness. Shanghai is such a modern & energetic city dedicated to shopping that you don't expect find such a place. It is amazing that a place like this has survived for hundreds of years.

title: Don't miss this
content: Exquisite retreat from the big city. Not mobbed (except for the overpriced markets around it). Serene taste if what Shanghai might have felt like before it became a metropolitan behemoth. We spent hours enjoying the garden, the ponds full of fish and turtles, and the wonderful Chinese architecture. Don't skip this--it was our favorite tourist spot.

title: Wet weather is a good time to visit
content: Fantastic taste of the Chinese quater in Shanghai. Stunning Chinese gardens built in the Ming Dynasty with water features, bonsai, pavilions and furniture.

title: Amazing Garden with historic importance
content: We had planned to visit Suzhou but had to skip it due to last minute changes and than Yu Yuyuan Garden was a choice to visit a Graden which is similar to that in Suzhou.

title: Packed with WOW features
content: From the entrance it does not seem like much until you walk through into the walled area with all different windows. Opening out onto a small lake that makes you stop and take a breath. There are paths, walkways, fruit and gardens of trees, boulders and a boat on the lake. The gardens and lake are ALL man made and a joy to behold even if you are not a gardener. It is remarkable what has been achieved. The big surprise awaits you outside the moon gate, a garden of Bonsai trees, camellias of all different shapes, colours and sizes, more water features and pebbled paths. Well worth the time and relaxation this garden provides.

title: Good architechture!
content: Its quite a big garden with amazing architechture and pond..pedestrian street offers variety of chinese traditions!

title: Loved this
content: The gardens are peaceful and beautiful with some lovely reconstructed buildings. Apparently it was quite damaged in an early war but has been rebuilt with many of the buildings still over 100 years old. It is also surrounded by a good shopping district.

title: cute garden which is like a maze
content: the garden is amidst crowded market and looks like a hidden gem. The  garden looks like a maze and you would definitely need a guide to take you along

title: Well done garden in city
content:
A nice serene place
Busy at times
Worth the visit 
Buildings are well preserved 
Gardens are nice 
Huge koi in ponds

title: Gorgeous Classical Chinese Gardens
content: These are very pretty Chinese gardens with a zig-zag bridge that evil spirits cannot negotiate, so they can't follow you. Evil spirits only travel in straight lines. Good to know. We walked through the gardens in a light rain and some of the rocks were slippery.

title: A very nice little place
content: Yu Garden is a very nice thing do to in the Yuan District. It also has an Art collection on the inside. It is a very inexpensive thing to do as well at 40 Yuan (approx £5)

title: Paaceful
content: Peaceful and nice. I recommend take a good book and enjoy there. Not expensive and a must to do in Shanghai

title: Good Photographic Opportunities
content: Not located too far from the spectacularly modern The Bund, these gardens offer a glimpse of the older Shanghai, along with some good photo opportunities, albeit in a crowded atmosphere.

user_loc: 斯洛伐克布拉迪斯拉发
title: Must see in shangai
content: This place is so nice, you can feel a lot of history here. Its very compact but every meter of garden is used with a lot of small details which are making this place so uniqe. And a lot off good street food and tourist shopping all round.

title: The shops are worth your time!
content: Got most of my souvenirs from the surrounding shops here. The stuff is pretty good and you get to bargain as well. Instead of spending a ridiculous 100-200 bucks at posh stores, you could spend the same amount and get 20 more items here. Nice tees, feng shui, magnets, toys, tea...

title: Great garden
content: Very cosy and ornate. Very reasonable entry fee - 40RMB from memory Get there early to avoid the bigger crowds

title: Lots of Interesting Buildings, Gardens, and Stonework
content: It is quite an old garden, really beautiful, with lovely ponds w/ BIG koi fish. It was a highlight of our tour, unfortunately, we were there on a Saturday afternoon and it was packed w/ tourists and locals. Could be very tranquil, so interesting that it is tucked near a extremely busy shopping area.

title: A quiet break from hectic shopping
content: The Yu Garden (豫园）is located near downtown Shanghai. Surrounding the gardens are shops selling goods to locals and tourists alike. The entrance to the garden is across a zigzag shaped bridge in the centre of the shopping area. The price of admission is 40 yuan. Inside the garden are ponds and creeks full of carp. There are many pavilions to explore and spots to relax and take it easy. If you are tired of the hectic shopping outside come to Yu Garden for a chance to recharge your batteries.

title: Good one time visit
content: Yu Garden offers a good quick view of China. They have local shops offering the most common tourist merchandise. The Buddist temple is nice and they have a couple of silk product stores. You can find fake product stores if you go to the right places. As many of the stores in China be ready for bargain and be careful when you purchase or you can easily be ripped off with high initial prices. Good for first time visitors.

title: Nice crowded area
content:
- nice place to visit if you come to Shanghai 
- but too crowded even in weekdays
- temple need to pay for rmb10 and garden is rmb40 (student price is rmb20)

title: Truly beautiful
content: The Yu Gardens are located in a very interesting part of town so even getting there makes for an interesting part of the day. The Gardens themselves are beautiful and the tranquility of the location is all the more fascinating and appreciated because of the location in a very busy part of a very busy city.

title: Fantastic Garden and History
content: Visited garden as part of Shanghai city tour. The garden is stunning, great photo spots. Maybe youll need 90mins in the garden and 60mins in the old town shopping area. Guide recommened for this tour.

title: Traditional tea ceremony.
content: Yu Garden is a must to visit when in Shanghai. We were lucky enough to experience a traditional tea ceremony in the teahouse that was used for VIP's who attended the Expo. Now it is open to the public. The gardens are beautiful with lots of children playing and adults with families strolling around the lovely ponds and water features. The souvenir shops are interesting with many selling similiar wares. Starbucks looks out of place with all the lovely old chinese buildings. Worth a day visit with plenty to see and do.

title: interesting spot to visit
content:
its a MUST GO spot to see in shanghai! traditional food r good， lots of sovernir to shop, old buildings n crafts r worth to know about ancient china!!

highly recommended for 1-day tour!!

title: Interesting and well-kept
content: The 'garden' is not a really a garden as I imagined it, but a collection of restored noble buildings dating from 1559.There is lots of water, and interesting nooks and crannies, and you can easily find a quiet spot to sit and take it in, even when it is busy, like the day we went there/

title: Unexpected gem
content: Found this place by wandering off my intended path. It is a treasure in the middle of a busy neighborhood.

title: An Oasis in a big city
content: Yu Gardens are a beautiful oasis in the very heart of Shanghai.

title: Amazing Place
content: What a stunning place. The entire area is really a must see while in Shanghai. The garden itself is just beautiful and shouldn't be missed.

title: Tranquil oasis in a bustling city.
content: Beautiful gardens surround a gorgeous old home all of which can be explored on foot. Simply beautiful lakes, water features, architecture and scenery.

title: It's not just a garden
content: Very interesting place for tourists. You can literally spend a few hours there, between visiting the garden, taking pics of old style architecture buildings, and shopping or sipping some tea in a tea house or even going to your favourite Starbucks coffee. Shopping for affordable souvenirs or even pearls with its variety in colours which come in different qualities, fresh water grown or sea water grown or fake. Watch what you buy and the way to know that is if they scratch it with a knife and powder comes down then its real.

title: Fortune teller told me to go to this bridge and walk through not stopping
content:
I walked through did not look back suppose to get rid of bad spirits 
Lots of little shops 
Great place to visit

title: A Hidden Gem
content: This was a great place to visit. The garden was exceptional. We were there when a fellow was doing a photo shoot of a young Chinese lady. Her reflection in the water made a beautiful picture for me.

title: Beautiful but busy!
content: A really beutiful garden and a very different side to Shanghai but it is definitely worth getting up early and beating the cowds I do not normally mind busy places however there were many parts of this garden where you had to shuffle single file along paths and bridges which really tarnished the visit.

title: Good spot to kill your phone & Camera
content: The architecture here create an impact especially during night time. There is shopping, restaurant and tourist attraction spot all in one area. But in return also mean a lot of people. Too many people that make me feel unsafe on my backpack or wallet. Those famous restaurant always need patient to wait for sit and sometimes it doesn't get what your expectation is after long hours of waiting.

title: Beautiful
content: The gardens are approached from a shopping mall via a zig-zag bridge over a pond containing goldfish and turtles. The grounds are absolutely amazing - a very small space laid out in such a way that you feel that the site is so much bigger. Many different and very interesting areas to be seen.

title: wonderful preserved old estate and garden
content: The garden gets very crowded so if you have the choice you should aim to go as soon as it opens in the morning. There are old buildings, walkways and ornamental ponds with huge quantities of Koi. There are information plaques situated periodically as you move around and these are in English and Chinese so you can get some idea of the history. However, we were in a tour party with a guide and learnt so much more.

title: Beatifically rockery if you like rockeries!
content: I really enjoyed visiting this garden. It is an oasis in the the middle of a very busy city. That said, you better like gardens, ponds, rockeries and pavilions because that's what it's all about.

title: Easy To Spend A Couple Hours Exploring
content: Very interesting garden with lots of history. Each building has a description in both Chinese and English. The ponds are magnificent, the koi are "huge" and it is a great place to sit and people watch.

title: Compact but plenty to see
content: Right in the middle of Shanghai but amazingly well preserved ancient garden. Must go early in the morning to avoid the huge crowds.

title: Oasis of calm but go early !
content: Quick trip around these gardens this morning - 09.00 Sunday - already busy so glad I want super early. Pleasant green spaces - with pavilions and ponds. Beautiful ancient stage. Quite a shock to emerge from garden into the mad bustle of tourist market alleyways that surround it.

title: Good example of Chinese garden in old Shanghai
content: Worth a quick visit.  A 16th century garden that was one of the best in its day.  Quite lovely.  A checkered past.  Almost didn't survive the tumultuous history of Shanghai.  Good Feng shui.  In a popular tourist location so easily accessible.

user_loc: 加利福尼亚纽波特海滩
title: Quick look into the past
content: Nice cultural excursion conveniently located in the heart of the city.  The structures are well maintained.  Recommend  going early since it can get crowded.  Lots of shops and food surrounding the property.

user_loc: 路易斯安那州新奥尔良
title: Quick Stop
content: Yu Gardens is a pretty small tract of Chinese gardens located next to a tourist shopping center disguised as classic architecture. The Gardens are fairly small in size and the attraction is a bit maze-like. I recall two big open areas and several smaller labyrinth paths. It is nice, but if you've ever seen a Chinese garden, you've probably seen something just like this. The best part is probably seeing two sides of Shanghai with these gardens in the foreground skyscrapers off in the background.

title: A Shanghai must see
content: Crowded but good for Shanghai photos. The streets behind the main area has an authentic food market with lots of photo ops. Wouldn't visit the temple as it's rather crowded. For the temple I prefer the Confucius temple in Shanghai.

title: Nice tourist area Chinese style buildings
content: One train station stop from people's square

title: Interesting Old World China
content: Takes you back to a time when Geishas were around. Lovely gardens...relaxing walks. Takes about 4-6 hours.

title: Well preserved Ming Dynasty estate & gardens
content: A calm oasis in the middle of hectic shopping area,  Beautiful gardens and buildings. We were with a tour group so we had a guide, which you would need as there are not signs explaining the history and symbolism of the architecture & garden features.

title: Wow!!
content:
Beautiful beautiful beautiful.....
Definitely a must see. Allow at least 1.5 hours for a leisurely stroll in the gardens.

title: Preserved old garden, best in Shanghai
content: Old buildings, paved ways, little lakes, old trees and strange stones, all together form interesting garden. Each step gives new view and different atmosphere. Take a lot of time to walk around and enjoy.

title: A beautiful gym tucked in a modern city.
content:
You must visit this place to get a feel for it. It was fantastic. 
Came here with the shanghai hightlights layover tour as solo traveller.

title: A view of old China
content: A very popular stop with all the architecture you associate with China and a really interesting garden. We would have appreciated having a guide as the signage was in Chinese. There are also very, very many shops selling every type of merchandise from jewellery to fabrics and souvenirs. There are bargains to be got if you take the streets outside the central area..

title: Stunning Gardens
content: Take your time, weave your way thru the numerous paths, don't forget to look up. It is a not to miss destination in Shanghai.

title: Popular tourist attraction
content: There is the paid area of the garden that is 50RMB where you can tour the 2 acre property that is meticulously maintained and there is a free area with the very popular tea house. I grabbed some of the to-go tea in a can and it was so refreshing on a hot day. Lots of people here so be prepared. to wait a bit to get a photo without tons of traffic.

title: This is an attraction not to be missed
content: If you are a visitor to Shanghai this is an attraction not to be missed. The garden is a 400 year old scholars garden that has wonderful vistas around every corner. As it is such a popular attraction it can be quite crowded however my experience is that it is far less crowded than the precinct outside the garden walls which is usually bustling with people. You need to keep a eye on your valuables as you make your way to the garden as often you will be shoulder to shoulder with the crowd. Don't let this put you off, the garden is fantastic and you are bound to leave it with lots of photos!

title: Yu Garden
content: It can be tricky finding this place, but it's well worth the effort. The Yu Garden is packed with tourists trying to get the perfect photo, but it doesn't distract from how beautiful the garden really is. Surrounding the garden is similar to a mini market with lots of little stalls, selling Chinese trinkets and food. Considering there isn't a huge amount of historical things to see in Shanghai, Yu Garden is a must.

user_loc: 密歇根西布鲁姆菲尔德
title: Beautiful place
content: Visited as part of a day touring with a local friend during the weekend between business meetings. Inside it is a beautiful place to walk around and explore, with lovely gardens. It gets crowded, so going earlier in the day is a good idea. Outside (the area approaching the Garden) is very touristy and less appealing. You could probably get lost and wander around here for a long time very happily, we had just under an hour and it was still enough time to enjoy it.

title: A great way to spend a half day with a relaxing walk
content: A very worthwhile visit, the palace grounds are beautiful, with a lot to see . The gardens are stunning, and the buildings and historical monuments worthwhile. It's certainly a nice way to spend a half day. Try to avoid weekends though as it gets very crowded.

title: a spot of calmness.
content: it is incredible. in the middle of a million-people town so nice and calm. green all around people sitting reading, singing Chinese folksongs, watching the koy-fish. I enjoyed it.

title: Beautifull gardens in the middle of a touristic area
content: At first I did not want to go as the entrance was not really cheap, but I was glad I did as it was a beautifull garden and really relaxing when compared to the touristic area around it. Don't miss it and go just before it closes around 16:30

title: Oasis
content: I visited these gardens in Shanghai 20 years ago and there are many more buildings in the surrounding area than on my first visit. The gardens however are still a quiet peaceful oasis. Well worth your time to admire their beauty or just enjoy the tranquil setting.

title: Old Chinese style gardens
content: These gardens are a small oasis in the centre of Shanghai featuring typical Chinese style buildings, water features, ornamental fish, dragon and lion statues etc. Plus the obligatory Buddha or two. Worth a visit.

title: Sardines in a Can
content: The best way to describe my experience of the Yu garden was like sardines in a can because you can hardly move there are so many people crammed into a small space. On weekends and holidays there is nothing restful about this garden. You can't stop to get a picture without being manhandled. While the Garden is beautiful go during the week and perhaps your experience will be different.

title: Peaceful and crowded at the same time
content: The architecture is stunning as it is in most of the ancient parts of the city. Good shopping and food. We enjoyed the tea room and silk shop although the prices were inflated for the tourist destination factor. I got several great souviners to bring home to the states from the street vendors. It was crowded but it IS China.

title: What a beautiful place!!
content: The Yu Garden is an amazing place!!   The garden is surrounded by many shops!!! To say the least. If you want to visit there get there early. It gets packed pretty quickly.

title: Hideaway
content: Nice hideaway in the middle of the noisy big city, albeit being in a extremely busy spot.. A must for tourists.

title: Beautiful garden amidst the skyscrapers
content: Beautiful garden amidst the skyscrapers - well worth the small entry fee to see the beautiful gardens! Very tranquil and reminiscent of traditional China.

title: Beautiful
content: A beautiful place, even with tourists around you can feel the magic of this place. The pavilions, the rocks, the trees, the lakes, everthing is designed to please the eye and calm the mind. Very, very nice

title: Beauty in a traditional Chinese garden
content: Many people think it is too crowded. But avoid the gift shops, go over the bridge (yes that is crowded) pay your entrance fee ( reduced with proof of age so have a copy of your passport) and go in the garden. If the cruise ships are in then yes it will be busy. But you can avoid them and find peace and tranquility. Wonderful!

title: Lovely gardens, go early!
content: Nice day out, and enjoyable to wander around. Water and rock features are interesting, and a some good kodak moments. Not many places to sit and enjoy, but a leisurely stroll and you'll be around in a couple of hours. Aim to get there before 10am, as by midday the crowds are overwhelming, and any hope of admiring the gardens in peace... hmmm!

title: Exotic historical garden
content: Absolutely loved this place. Stone through from our hotel, we visited this place in the midst of the public holiday period with crowds of people. But so organised in moving through we really didn't notice the as we were too enthralled by the history in this garden. The garden is a historical site that boasts hand made ponds, rockeries all around views from rooms that now each impart a small part of shangahai history. There are so many twists and turns that bring you to new gardens. The bonsai are gorgeous as well as the climbing rose that must be so old it has its own scaffold but still has a magnificent show. The zigzag bridge is quaint with views of the huge cod. Note the old and new from one corner... wooden Chinese eaves to the outside glass skyscraper...such stark contrast !

title: Serene garden
content: A gardens 400+ years old with ponds, pavilions, and colourful flowers.  Took many photos for memories.

title: Pleasant Introduction to Chinese Gardens
content: We visited on a pleasant Sunday afternoon. This is a popular destination so be prepared for crowds. The zig-zag bridge across to the old tea house and gardens beyond was shoulder to shoulder. Once inside the gardens it was less crowded. There are relaxing gazebos where one can sit and watch people or take in the intricate architecture and extensive rockeries. Feeding the coy is also very popular. It would be helpful to have a map because I'm not sure we saw the whole place. The fixation with venerating strange rock formations is curious - it'd be helpful to have a guide or more information to fully appreciate this attraction.

title: Hunting for Easter!
content: Many foreign guests may only know this as the name sake garden, best remaining of its kind, built by the children of a wealthy family for the retirement of their parents. Yes the gardens are large and is filled with paths and switch back through various buildings and courtyards.

title: Not too much to see
content: It is one of the most famous sightseeing in Shanghai but don't expect too much. Everything seems to be renovated - the buildings, the garden, the paths... There are lights on most of the buildings outside the garden which makes them​ a little but awkward. The garden itself is worth to be seen as it keeps part of the city history :)

title: Beautiful Garden Well Worth The Visit
content:
So many photographs to take here!  

It's hard to believe that these gardens are 400 years old. There are ponds, coi, pavilions, and flowers in this beautiful 5 acre park.

title: Serenity
content: As a group we were taken to the markets surrounding the Gardens, then through the gates across a zigzag bridge to the Yu Gardens, the serene spots in a garden built around rocks, water and contemplative areas. As it was spring the azaleas flowering in spots of colour. Unusual garden as Westerners might think, but beautiful place to wander and feel.

title: Peaceful but crowded garden in the middle of the city.
content: I was able to do some sightseeing on a recent work trip. This was one of a few places we checked out. All of the signs were in English and Chinese. There were a myriad of beautiful flowers and plants. There is an entrance fee but it was minimal. Be sure to look closely at the detail on the buildings. The craftsmanship is evident.

title: Best place in shanghai
content: Full of people but still the best place in shanghai,amazing garden ,and full of shops on its way...Definitely the with place wto come in Shanghai

title: Nice small pretty garden
content: Lovely flowers and buildings but small. What is more interesting is the shopping bazaar and buildings around it. All sorts of shops and restaurants and full of people shopping and just milling about . Mix of chains (ie. Starbucks) and small Chinese shops.

title: Nice Gardens
content: The gardens are very beautiful with rockeries, a koi pond and dragon wall. It gets very crowded, especially in the market area. I would go earlier in the day as we were there around 4pm and it was very hot and crowded, and also advise to not visit on a weekend. There is an entrance fee but not in the bazaar.

title: Beautiful garden
content: It is a beautiful Chinese garden, but on the weekends very crowded!! There are some art stores inside, but I am not sure about there authenticity. It is a quite place within the big city.

title: Beautiful tranquil area in the midst of chaos
content: We visited this lovely garden while in the middle of a day in the bazaar area in which it is located. So lovely and peaceful with a meandering koi pond flowing through the garden. Beautifully maintained structures and quite picturesque with curved doorways and rockery backgrounds.

title: Good food and lots of shopping
content: This is an outdoor collection of low Chinese styled buildings with a few famous soup dumpling houses and many shops.

title: Yu Gardens
content: On our first day in Shanghai, we visited this beautiful garden.  Our guide had presented a great wealth of knowledge and culture in order to appreciate it.  A busy place, but well worth the visit.

title: Highly recommended
content:
Nice for a visit,  try not to come at weekend since its very crowded,
Nice gardens. 
Nice architecture

title: Lost and Found
content: Finding the Garden on your own may be a bit daunting because it is surrounded by gaggles of shops and booths selling and more selling. Set your determination and keep looking because it is worth finding. Cost of entry 40 yuan and plan to spend at least an hour.

title: Interesting
content: On a weekend this attraction is mobbed by both locals & tourists, but it's interesting to see the many shops, peaceful gardens and the old style Chinese architecture.

title: Traditional Chinese Garden
content: This review is for the actual garden, not the overpriced tourist trap next door. My wife who is an avid gardener was blow away by the size and variety within the walls. There is a 60 RMB ticket price to get it but it is well worth the price. Our visit was on a July afternoon so it was very hot and humid. Plan ahead as 4 hours is a minimum to enjoy the entire gardens and taking time to stop for pictures and read the history. There are shops within the walls selling cheap to very expensive souvenirs but the quality is much better than those at the exit.

user_loc: 密歇根西布鲁姆菲尔德
title: Beautiful place
content: Beautiful garden and old Chinese architecture. Try to go earlier to escape very large crowd in the afternoon.

title: Lovely gardens
content: Enjoyable morning visit to Yu Garden before it got too busy. Even though it's small there are lots of paths and hidden areas to explore making it feel bigger. I especially loved all the fish in the pond and the turtles. Nice escape from the madness of the market outside.

title: Crowded
content: Always very crowded, the Yu garden is very nice but too many people. Indeed it is on all the tourists tours for chinese visiting shanghai.

title: Amazing, a must see
content: When in shanghai you must visit yu Garden, amazingly decorated and even though it is made for tourist it is still good to have a look, don't bother shopping in there all prices are jacked right up so do your shopping just down the street where there is no haggling it's just all cheap.

title: Beautiful chaos
content: Beautiful ancient buildings but beware its easy to get lost.  Also so many tourists that the day we were there it was claustrophobic. Go early to beay the crowds. Stall holders and hawkers add to the chaos but Im glad we saw it

title: Serenity in the middle of chaos
content: You walk through old Shanghai to get to the Yuyuan Garden.  It's a breath of calm and serenity in the middle of the chaos of "China Town".  Definitely worth a visit.

title: Yuyuan Garden
content: Nice place to visit. Gives you quick idea about old Chineese archetecture. In your way to the garden you will pass by the oldest part of Shanghai where many shops are there where you can buy traditional Chineese souvoneres. You have to bargain hard.

title: Another piece of beautiful Chinese architecture
content: Great history of China and definitely worthwhile for a visit while you can enjoy shopping and roaming around the streets.

title: Peace in the heart of the city
content: Step back in time into the "gardens". Beautiful courtyards, gorgeous halls and exquisite carvings. Very peaceful despite the crowds.

title: Portray to Chinese Culture !!!
content: It is very old area at modern Shanghai town. Here you can find the feeling of old Chinese culture. Here you can find some shops where you need to Bargain's lot.

title: Nice to See
content: The place is nice to see. It is located on old town with many shops and restaurants around it It was crowded since we visited on Saturday.

title: A hidden gem
content: Do not get distracted by all the noise and shops at the Yuyuan Gardens area / metro stop. You can look at those on your way out as they all stay open well past the 5.15pm closing time of the Yu Garden. Yu Garden is tiny, but spectacular. You could easily spend a whole day in there just admiring the different structures or if you are on a tight schedule, an hour would do also. There are lots of places to sit and if it gets hot, there are shady areas. No food available so bring water and a picnic. Toilets are traditional squat ones. The one Western one I spied was closed for repairs. Oh dear!

title: Scenic, Historic, but not tranquil
content: Visited on a Saturday morning and it was busy ! The surrounding area was packed with numerous tours, touts and sellers of everything and anything, commercial businesses shops and restaurants, Paying the small entry fee, the gardens are surprisingly large well laid out with lakes, buildings, gardens bridges and walkways that date back centuries. You have to keep owing due to the sheer number of people passing through, although everyone stops constantly for photos so it becomes a shuffle. Worth visiting for a view of ancient Shanghai in a unique historic setting, but don't expect tranquility or refuge from the crowds

title: You garden experience
content: We visited these gardens in April very typical of Chinese buildings unfortunately it was raining the day that we visited but the history behind the buildings were great there are lakes and small bridges to cross with a variety of trees, toilet facilities are quite limited and are at the end of the gardens with only one European type toilet for men the other toilets are typically a stand over type of toilets there are some great photos to take here, outside there are shops and eating places across the bridge

title: A must see
content: This is definitely worth a visit. Walk through lots of bazaar stalls to find it at the end.  Fab gardens, beautiful temple, couple of stalls etc.

title: Nice Rock based garden
content: Spring was a good time to visit. Flowers in bloom and leaves on most the trees. Worth a short stroll.

title: True beauty in the heart of Shanghai
content: This really is a beautiful garden tucked away in the heart of Shanghai. A traditional style Chinese Garden full of tradition, history and tranquillity tucked away in the centre of a shopping area. Take the time out and enjoy.

title: Old city at its best
content: The city was very vibrant with locals and tourists. Shops shops everywhere. Rates vary from the entrance to each street. How much ever you bargain the shops are the benefitor. We can be satisfied that some bargaining took place. Beware of fake notes and Taiwan currency being exchanged without your knowledge. But so many shops and streets to rome around. Crowded as expected. Would suggest pick your product at the entrance but buy at some shops close to the metro station for they seems to display lower rates.

title: Yu Garden
content: We really enjoyed the tour done by Apple from Jenny's Shanghai tours. This was very historical site with beautiful gardens and architecture. Well worth a visit.

title: Lovely place to Visit
content: Beautiful traditional garden at Shanghai, around the area there are hundreds of shops selling items from silk scarves to all sorts of souvenirs and antiques. There have many restaurant and i like the Xiao long Bao over there.

title: Very touristy and crowded...
content: Probably worth a visit but this is a very busy area and lots of tourist shops. If you are in Shanghai I guess you have to visit but if you have limited time there are nicer places to visit.

title: Beautiful You Garden
content: This amazing little pearl is  tucked away - so peaceful and tranquil and good coffee is available inside! The bonsai is simply amazing.

title: Chinatown in a chinese town
content: Apparently 100s of years old, most of it feels slightly 'more modern' than that, but a real maze of close knit buildings and walkways. so very different from the rest of Shanghai, even though it is always very busy it feels somehow more serene than the hustle and bustle of the main shopping areas. very much a tourist trap but done with care and a little style

title: A cultural treat
content: I came here early in the morning. I do not speak any local languages and managed to find my way around. The place is free and open to the public you do have to pay to go into the temple areas for prayer. I prayed to the gods, for love, maternity, peace, and health. This garden was constructed in the 1300s and reconstructed 5 times before being open to the public in the 1950s and the sense of spirituality is seriously strong here. A definite must see.

title: Nice garden, shopping approach not so much
content: The garden itself is nice but for us not really worth the crowded visit. We went early on a rainy weekday and it was still quite crowded.

title: Lives up to its name and reputation
content: We had trouble finding the garden at first, but after wandering around in the area eventually stumbled across the entrance. Our family absolutely loved visiting this garden and found it to be a pleasant and peaceful oasis in Shanghai.

title: and then visit here.
content: This place is so Chinese traditional !! You had better know the culture and history about Shanghai, it is good for feeling here. There are too many foreigners there.  The point is this place is near the Bond and just 15mins by walk.

title: much better than actually expected
content: Unsual. Special. Definitely worth a visit. Surprisingly big and diverse. 1 or rather 2 hours to visit. My first impression was that the "garden" seemed rather small but I was wrong. A lot of meanders. Many visitors but totally bearable. I was ther around 1:30 PM on a Wednesday. Certainly more serene in the morning. Entrance effectively not that easy to find. Outside the garden the "old town" is just for tourists and does not feel as safe as any other place I have visited in Shanghai, even remote. But I will certainly visit the garden again in the future. I will make sure I go early in the morning to fully enjoy it :)

title: Interesting
content: Out the back of the 'oldest' markets in shanghai and well worth a visit. Larger than we expected. Keep an eye on your handbags ladies

title: Tons of fun!
content: Very neat to see this small area of "old China" so close the city.  Keep in mind that the area immediately outside the gardens is not "historic", and if anyone approaches you in English, its a scam.  Gardens themselves, however, were great.

title: Pretty garden
content: This is a nice garden for a little stroll. We went at around 11am and it wasn't too crowded. Entry was cheap but the entrance is a little difficult to find! There are some famous rock formations as well as a pond with koi carp and lots of interesting buildings to look in. The garden is like a maze and is bigger than it looks! It is not too commercialized as it could be ruined with shops/ice cream stalls, etc inside, so it is a nice touch that it has been kept traditional. Worth a visit

title: Unbearable crowd and souvenir trap!
content: Yuyuan Garden is overfilled with tourists and you definitely cannot see Yuyuan Garden with little photo opportunity. There are literally thousand of shops littered with salesmen asking you to buy stuffs in aggressive manner. Skip this place for peace of mind.

title: A beautiful oasis
content: We visited about 10 am in the morning and the zigzag bridge was already very busy. Entry is about £4 per adult a very serene garden with beautiful Chinese temples and dragons. You will need to be patient to get good photos as the Chinese do love a selfie!

title: Worth the visit!
content: It is really crowded but it worth to visit it. In the shops near to the garden you can find souvenirs, sweets, jewelry, everything you want and you can negotiate the prices. It takes few minutes the walk on the zig-zag bridge over the water full of fish. So definitely you have to visit during your stay in Shanghai.

title: Go early and go during the week
content: Beautiful and extensive Chinese garden located beside the City God Temple BUT that is were it ends. It is a nightmare on the week-end when it seems the whole of China descends upon this area.

title: Go early.....
content: Garden opens at 0830 and suggest that is what you should target, otherwise the crowds arrive and it becomes unbearable. Surrounding area and streets are touristy but look up and see some great old architecture. A taste of what was the Old Shanghai but the best you can get in the new modern Shanghai

title: Tea and a view
content: It is always very busy at the garden . So take your time . We were lucky as the line was short . We could have tea in the teahouse where an eternal cup of tea costs 10 € - but you have an excellent view and two girls sing Chinese songs and play original instruments .

title: Beautiful
content: We wished we had more time to explore this beautiful site! I would recommend 2-3 hours at least. Lovely gardens and history here - right int he middle of the city. Go early to avoid the crowds. They tourist area nearby is also fun, but as the name implies - very touristy!

title: Walk in gardens
content: This place was hard to find after our taxi driver dropped us 2 streets away? The park is hidden inside a massive tourist shopping area which gets busy. The park is interesting and historic but lacks greenery and more rocks and buildings ? It's busy and we didn't stay long

title: Wonderful, but.......
content: Be very careful to pick the right time to visit Yu Gardens. I picked the wrong time this trip and it was overwhelmingly crowded. There were too many people and too small a place. Make sure you go early or late, but not mid day! The strollers the disabled the groups the crowd was oppressively burdensome.

title: Beautiful, peaceful local away from the hustle of 23M people
content: This is a gem of a location.  A small area where one can go to get away from the hustle of 23M people.  It is so peaceful and minimal people visiting.

title: Nice but crowded
content: Very nice garden but way to crowded. Would not say that it's a relaxed place in the middle of the city. The bazar around and the garden itself are some of the busiest places I went in Shanghai. It is nice to watch though and one of the "must sees", but nothing spectacular. We walked around the entire garden in maybe an hour and a half or so and enjoyed the nature and the houses.
