content: worth a visit, gets busy, but the gardens are just lovely, lots of water with fish and turtles in would recommend a trip

title: A great piece of Shanghai....
content: As part of our tour we were shown around the Yu gardens close by China town (yes, china town in china). The gardens were much bigger than i expected and very well kept.

title: Need no more than two hours here.
content: Yu garden is quite beautiful. It is not a very big place that overwhelms, but the landscape is breathtaking. A lot of people mistaken the outer area with the zig zag bridge as the garden. The Yu Garden has an entrance fee. I have seen friends pictures and they claimed to have have gone to the garden. Well, sadly, there were in the out court rubbing shoulders with the other tourists not realizing the actual Garden is only a few steps away. As the title states, one does not need more than two hours here unless you plan to have lunch here. While here, try the fried stinky tofu. Have fun!

title: Beautiful Countryside Garden nestled in the Heart of a bustling city.
content: The elements required for a great garden can all be found here: rocks, water, buildings, and plants. It was a stunning piece of history, even if there have been some renovations to it as of late. Try to go very early, or perhaps during the week, as it can get very crowded, even on a rainy Sunday Afternoon. Would love to visit again.

title: Yu Gardens
content:
We were in Shanghai for National Day 
It could have been worse loads of people 
The gardens are lovely but not so peaceful 
But again it is China's National Day

title: I Needed Another Day!
content: This is easily an ALL DAY affair! I went 3 times in two days (separated by work) and couldn't see or do it all. Huge and beautiful. At night I hear its even cooler. You can buy anything you could possible need there. Most stores you can haggle in. I refuse to buy anything in China without haggling the prices way down, and i still had a lot of stores to choose from. A lot of food options there and i highly suggest finding the elevators and hitting some of the top floor stores and restaurants. The backdrop of traditional buildings below and skyscrapers beyond is awesome!

user_loc: 加利福尼亚亨廷顿海滩
title: Hide, but crowded gem in Shanghai
content: Hidden in the midst of the very busy old section of Shanghai is the Yuyuan Garden. To find it, you can access the HoHo bus, get off in the old city area, and ask a vendor (who may or not speak your language) for directions. It is complicated. There is a moderate fee to enter.

title: Very crowded
content: This is a beautiful place and I would have enjoyed it more with less people. Outside the garden there are lots of tea rooms which will help you recover from the crowds. Also there are places selling the usual tourist stuff. This is a hectic place in the heart of the city, but worth a visit.

title: Traditional Chinese garden
content: Nice garden in the midst of the old Chinese neighborhood. Surrounded by a ton of shops cramped into smalle streets. If you are in the area anyways, it is worth seeing. I would not have walked specifically to this area but happened to walk through on my way from the Bund to the French Neighborhood. The area could have been better maintained. As someone else also mentions here, all the people visiting is tearing on the garden heavily.

title: Chinese garden in Shanghai
content: A very well preserved Chinese style garden in the middle of Old city. Beautiful and lots to see. Exhausted by the end of it

title: Crowded and nothing much to see
content: The place is quite interesting, but it is quite small and nothing much to be appreciated. Maybe the I could appreciate the garden more if there were not so many people in the relatively small site.

title: Garden VS Market
content: It's like Old Shanghai on steroids. The market is packed with shops of all kinds and people. It's still a great thing to see though. If you're wondering where's the garden, you need to keep walking past the shops and bridge. Make sure you arrive before the closing time (5PM).

title: Beautiful Chinese style garden with a touch of history
content: This is a typical Chinese style old garden with beautiful architechture , ponds , bridges etc . Originally built by the emperors , parts of it have been reconstructed again . If the weather is good you will have a great time .

title: chinese classical garden
content: This garden is very famous so i had a lot of expectation.It was nice .Very beautiful garden. its not a big garden you won't need longer than 3 hours to cover it.You can enjoy Chinese architecture, greenery and lake. Small old bridges on the lake.

title: A great place to see landscaping and architecture in the Ming Dynasty
content: Built in the 16th century during the Ming Dynasty, the Yu Garden used to be the private residence of a senior Government administrator in the Ming Dynasty which has been preserved in the old town of Shanghai allowing visitors to marvel at the architectural styles and meticulous landscaping of a bygone era. One could easily spend a couple of hours if you care to look at each of the buildings many connected by bridges on ponds over 2 hectares of land. It is rather conveniently located with subway access and then of course one would not miss the Yu Yuan Old Street with plenty of shops and eateries right adjacent to the Garden. Don't forget to bring your camera as the Garden offers a lot for the keen photographer.

title: An oasis of peace
content: As part of our Wendy Wu trip we had a chance to visit the Yu gardens in Shanghai. This was a really peaceful and tranquil experience after the hustle and bustle of Shanghai. The gardens have that essential Chinese trio of Rocks, Water and Plants that immediately calms you down. Well worth a visit.

title: Relaxing oasis in Shanghai
content: Nice relaxing oasis in Shanghai. Visited with a private guide which was nice, since there isn't any English signage. Interesting things were the several dragons on top of the walls and the rock that water pours through.

title: Beautiful Garden
content: Yu Garden is beautiful and peaceful place. Market area around the garden is very nice. People visiting Shanghai must visit Yu Garden.

title: Stunning...Beautiful Garden!
content: Enjoyed the visit despite the rain! If you want to escape the city Skyscrapers and still want to be in Shanghai then this is the place!

title: Different but not spectacular
content: It's hard to figure what the best feature is about Yu Garden. There are a couple of large trees, some stone work, a koi pond, and a couple of small buildings with displays. Then again there are rest rooms (that I did not visit), the area seems clean and kept up so a clean rest room could be worth the price of admission.

title: interesting to visit
content: visited the old city with the market were you can buy souvenirs, tea, visit the silk exhibition. at the end we visited the garden which is crowded but has the residence of a wealthy person and several buildings inside. worth visiting if you are in the area.

title: Crowded, Tiring Shanghai Must
content: Everyone recommends going to Yu Garden in Shanghai. It is on the hop on hop off bus routes. It is in every guide book. It is a must see. But it can be exhausting! I went here long ago, in 2002 and again in 2005. My recent visit was with my curly, fair haired daughter and while in the market area and on the zig zag bridge, the attention she received was on the aggressive side. Not threatening. But with the crush of people, it was hard. Some sellers with toys also have a hard time taking no for an answer. Inside the gardens the crowds were smaller and volume less deafening. I do love the set up of the gardens and my daughter enjoyed them - carp in the water, flowers, little stepping stones across ponds. I cannot recommend you skip it, just come prepared for the Chinese hoards.

title: Beautiful morning in Shanghai!
content: Coming to Shanghai from central China, I really felt the city was detached.. I could have been in any large city in the world.. Until Yugarden. The hustle and bustle of the market with the multiple choices of local cuisine and then the actual garden(it's worth paying in), is serene, a joy to stroll around in the midday heat. An absolute pleasure.

title: Beautiful, can get crowded
content: Overall it's a lovely place. Be selective of when you go. Saturdays are chaos. But it's one of the more unique gardens in China. The surrounding shopping area, however, is pretty tacky :(

title: May Day Retreat
content: We went here on May Day-busiest day of the year. Weather was beautiful and every resident of Shanghai must have been out walking. We could hardly get to the front gate of the Yu Garden and almost gave up. Glad we didn't. It was peaceful and quiet inside any not crowded at all. Magnificent variety in vegetation and architecture. Hated to leave this lovely haven. We went to a fantastic candy store right after and bought White Rabbit candy which we had never heard of before but is a Shanghai staple.

title: The place you make you amuzed
content: Its a great place for nature walker and full of chinese things which you can barely see in the town and the greatest thing is in some part you are able to see the traditional building and just behind it you ll see modern building which is cool. It will take you more than 3 hours to visit all and you might be lost but its kind of intresting. I assume if you want to see sth wonderful and enjoy your day you should visit there. Also I might add dont go there in sat and sun and try to go there in morning its much quieter and you can enjoy the blue sky beside the great chinese nature.the other great thing is that you can enjoy some chinese food just right outside and there aresome big mal that you can buy some suviner

title: A beautiful piece of historic paradise
content: This is an original garden that belonged to one family for many years, a high ranking government official from the last dynasty.   Walking through the the front gate you are brought back hundreds of years.   It is picturesque and not to be missed.

title: A must see spot for any Shanghai tourist
content: A visit to the Yuyuan gardens is a must see for any tourist to Shanghai. I've been to Shanghai many time and this was probably my fourth visit. Try to visit earlier or later in the day to avoid the crowds. Also, consider having some bug spray on hand. I did not get bitten but my wife and kids did.

title: YU Gardens
content: Very interesting tour and experience of shopping in a historical garden & buildings setting.  More shopping than Gardens.

title: Beautiful and interesting history
content: This garden is a must if you are in Shanghai.constructed in the 1500's this 5 acre garden has numerous attractive features,the pavilions,ponds with gold fish a big rockery and bridges,there are decorative archways,look out for the dragons heads, that take you to the 6 sections of the garden,the only problem we had were the crowds, take your time and take it all in,its worth it,there are toilets available and quite clean.Out side of the garden is the Yuyuan bazaar which is interesting due to its age, with its many shops selling all sorts of souvenirs, there is also a Starbucks to be found there.

title: Busy , could do with a bit of TLC
content: These gardens are stunning when you consider their age and location, parts are truly beautiful. We went on our own mid week so not too busy. However the area surrounding is packed and very un harmonious. The gardens should be appreciated due to their beauty age and history but the upkeep was significantly different to a garden we saw up at one of the water villages which although smaller , was truly stunning . Glad we saw iyu gardens but realise now it would not be end of world if didn't get around to it. You don't need guide, can do quite easily on own

title: super crowded - tourist kitsch
content: Its completely filled to the gills with tourists and shop after shop of junk to buy. NOt worth the visit

title: Design ideas everywhere
content: This incredible garden was the best of several we visited in China. Large and diverse, it exhibited many gracious design notes and was charming throughout. The garden was not too crowded but its good to go early in the day.

title: You have to go here!
content: This is a spectacular large, traditional Chinese garden that by some miracle has survived the "urban renewal" of Shanghai. It's an oasis in the heart of the city. It's very popular and therefore somewhat crowded but this doesn't diminish the experience. It many buildings are grouped around courtyards, ponds and pathways. Really very beautiful and a very welcome respite from the heat of Shanghai in July!

title: Enjoyed Yu Gardens
content: Yu Gardens was a positive experience in that one is able to see how not only the classic Chinese gardens but the home of a government official during the Ming Dynasty.  If time is available, there seems to be ample shopping available.

title: A pleasant oasis within walking distance of the riverside and central Shanghai
content: An unusual mix of new and old in the commercial centre near Yu Garden. A great place to see how the people of Shanghai make urban life enjoyable. But be careful of the Shanghai thieves - young people who will approach unsuspecting older tourists with their friendliness. The usual trick is a tea ceremony where you will suddenly be confronted, under great social pressure, to pay outrageous thievery amounts for some tea; the thieves receiving the benefit of your wallet. Don't let it happen. If it does, get up and walk away no matter what they might say. They will only have fear that you will go to the police, though in fact the police have long since given up dealing with these sweet talking thieves.

user_loc: 加利福尼亚芒特沙斯塔
title: Relaxing and beautiful
content: Yuyuan was my favorite place to visit in Shanghai, I went there many times and each visit I learned something new and was awestruck by a different building, pond, sculpture, or view. It is a rather large garden with a lot to see and much to learn, if you are in Shanghai I highly recommend you visit Yuyuan as soon as possible and plan to spend your whole day exploring its beauty.

title: old shanghai !  local food and old buildings. nice time
content: nice pictures, ate good food and desserts. lots of photos. crowded people watching. old time city views

title: Highly recommend.
content: Something to see when in Shanghai. Amazing that this is in the middle of the city. Do not really need a guide to enjoy. Does not take long amount of time.

title: Hot & a little rundown
content: We spent 1.5 hours walking and dealing with lots of people to see gardens designed and built long ago. July is not the time to be here since it is extremely hot and muggy (and we are from Miami!). It could be a better experience in the Spring with flowers and cooler weather. By the time we completed the circuit we were soaking wet with sweat.

title: Very small garden!
content: The small garden in the shopping area. You need to pay for the entrance ticket to see the small garden inside.  If you really want to see the nice stone garden you should go to Su Joe!!

title: Forget the tourist tat and listen to the history
content: If you want a central location for tourist baubles then this is a good place. Always very crowded. The real attraction is Yu Garden which is a separate courtyard. The silence is pleasant, the history and archtecture is interesing. The museum shop has interesting artifiacts for those wanting to start a collection.

title: The serenity was lost in the crowds
content: We visited at the end of June. The gardens and architecture are beautiful but the crowds made them hard to appreciate. The (relatively) small scale of the place let us see it all in about an hour. Our guide explained many things that would have gone unnoticed otherwise.

title: Nice garden but you can find better
content: This is one of the most popular garden for tourists but over priced and crowdy. avoid to go there during chinese holiday.

title: Beautiful Scenic Spot
content: Enjoyed my visit here and have revisited the site several times, it is very nice and peaceful along with being well maintained. There are toilet facilities on site which are remarkably clean for China and the people are friendly. The only downside is that the tickets are fairly expensive for what is only a 45 minute activity.

title: Touristic visit
content: Very nice contrast versus the Bund area is this old garden Palace.

title: Peaceful Refuge
content: We visited the Yu Gardens in Shanghai as part of our Viking tour of the city. It was a lovely experience and very welcome after the bustle of the city. The trees, ponds, and Chinese architecture provided many places for photos. We loved discovering the quietude that can be created through plantings and design. We enjoyed it very much!

title: Garden in the city
content: This place was our first place to visit in Shanghai and was a good choice. An easy to get there by taxi, plenty of shopping area surrounding the garden, interesting places inside the gardens. It is worth the visit.

title: Trip back in time...
content: .....and important break from busy Shanghai! Beautiful, restful, lots of places to sit, great photo settings. Loved imagining a busy court going about its business here. Inside the garden, there was very pleasant souvenir shopping too. (Crazy wild shopping just outside also, w/great street food) One of our best activities in Shanghai. We went at 8:30 am on a Sunday...perfect choice!

title: It's A bit hidden, but worth searching
content: There's a hint of old chinese culture in Yu Garden. It's almost the only place in the heart of Shanghai that has the historical feeling. Nice oasis in the middle of the hectic city.

title: Serenity
content: A little too crowded to enjoy the serenity it is meant to convey. Interesting to visit though early in the morning before the tourists arrive.

title: Unbelievable--a must see for visitors!
content: Absolutely stunning and beautiful!  Truly depicts what China was during the Qing dynasty.  It is best to go with a tour guide who can explain the history and significance of the garden.  I will return here.

title: Oh SO hot!
content: Our host said that we were visiting on the hottest day of the year. That it was!! It was beautiful but almost too hot to enjoy! Built in the 1500s, there was something to be said for experiencing the history of the garden. However, the heat and humidity was stifling.

title: The Chinatown of Shanghai
content: The are around Yu Garden is the only place I have found in Shanghai that looks like the China I actually wanted to see...China the way you sort of imagine it in your mind. Cheap and not so cheap touristy stuff sold everywhere, way too many people and traditional Chinese architecture.

title: A beautiful garden in the middle of the city
content: The Yu Garden (Yu Yuan) is a very nice garden in the middle of Shanghai. We were impressed by the way the garden looks today. We are always astonished seeing so much green in a city where the price for a square meter is so high.

user_loc: 新西兰奥克兰中心地区
title: Angels, composition, history, classic China moment
content: Extraordinairy time, had guide from China highlights travel service, Jen, she was amazing. Very tolerant and aware of what it takes for mixed group in ages and fitness. Her knowledge and English second to none. Loved the shots we got.

title: Interesting place
content: Besides the attraction itself, if you are also looking to buy some souvenirs in Shanghai, I thought this was the best place.

title: Over commercialized
content: This is an over commercialized attraction. Avoid weekends as the place is packed to the brim. The buildings outside the garden are clearly modern replication just to give the area an old world feel. All in, just a classical Chinese style garden.

title: A market square called Yu Garden
content: Although named Yu Garden, it is a market square where numerous shops are located. The structures are not old but designed like old ones and attracts large number of visitors.

title: Simply lovely
content: So many beautiful spots to see. Bring your camera for some great shots, but expect lots of other visitors too. Allow time to relax and enjoy the lovely spots.

title: Peaceful
content: An oasis in the middle of the busy life of a city. I appreciated the vision of long ago and the fact that the people and especially the government has left this beauty alone. I would have liked a bench or two to rest and absorb the peaceful surroundings.

title: Beautiful, but the rain wasn't good
content: I went in a rainy day unfortunaitely. The place is beautiful, inside and outside. There are some stores, but it isn't the cheapest place to buy souvenirs.

title: Nice gardens in the center of Shanghai
content: In the middle of the urbanite Shanghai, you can find this beautiful Chinese typical gardens. The place is sorrounded by a market with a lot of amenities. Even though it feels a bit 'false' it is still one of the most special places in the city.

title: A bit of Oriental China in a very westernised Shanghai
content: For those looking for a peep into the ancient China, of the movies and books, this is the place.

title: A MUST when in Shanghai
content: This centrally located garden brings you back 5 or 600 years. Beautifully arranged traditional garden, probably a bit overrun on busy days, but definitely a MUST when in Shanghai. Be aware of the large number of hookers who try to sell you something on the way into the Garden

user_loc: 菲律宾马尼拉大都会区
title: bargain!
content: a lot of good. pick up some of the shanghai lady vanishing cream here. works wonders for your skin. and eat at the food hall! don't miss the tea house and the nanxiang steam buns

title: Nice touristic place to visit
content: Very quiet gardens in the middle of a busy city. It's the perfect place to relax in the middle of such a crazy town as Shanghai. I totally recommend to visit this place for tourist travelling with families or friends.

title: Shopping for soveneirs
content:
Very crowded, mainly for shopping and eating. Too commercial nowadays. Yu garden needed entrance fee. Worth or not
worth ? I did not go in.

title: A Nice and Classic Garden
content: It's a place that you can experience the ancient China, Well-preserved in old style. The only problem is there are quite a lot of tourist groups at the time we are visiting. Outside the garden, there is busy market where you can walk for a gift shopping tour.

title: Touristy
content: I visited this very pretty area in the middle of Shanghai with restaurants the first time in 1988 and made sure it was on my list to revisit. It is now a very crowded and very touristy site where it no longer seems like it is a tranquil place. It is within easy reach of the subway but you must know how to get there once you exit subway because there are no signs that tell you which way to go. There are lots of shops selling souvenirs and such but it is way pricier there as they know it is a very touristy area. It was extremely crowded in the evening when we went and it made it harder when people crowd around you and insist on taking photos at each and every site. There are much nicer areas around.

title: Chinese Tourists Heaven
content: So many great photo opportunities - peaceful - well planned and would be a great place for afternoon pickup,

user_loc: 德国达姆施塔特行政区
title: Getting away from the city hassle!
content: If you want to feel more like you are in China while in Shanghai, this is a good place to visit. Chinese architecture, lots of local food and shops inside and outside.

title: Beautiful but limited access
content: We visited at 10am in the morning on a weekday which was not very crowded. Entrance to the garden and ticket booth was in front of the iconic zig zag bridge in Yuyuan Old Town.

title: nice garden
content: Review about this place more, but the thing that I will never forget is the walking road in the garden that make with river small stone that you have to walk on this with out shoe, So this is foot nature massage

title: Very nicy tranquility in the middle of Shanghai
content: Very nice garden in the middle of Old town Shanghai. A must see for tourists. Nice contrast between modern Shanghai with its high rises and the old town with the garden sity right in den middle

title: beautiful garden in shaghai
content: very beautiful garden. far from yu garden mtr station. taking a taxi is better. tea house in yu garden is great, recommend flower tea

title: A well preserved area of historical significance
content: A well preserved and a beautiful garden but crowds make it chaotic with narrow paths. The children add to the chaos, not to mention the enthusiastic tourists keen to take photographs at each and every corner. But overall a great experience.

title: Bliss amidst the Chaos
content: The Gardens are beautiful - the way to enjoy it is to imagine if this was your backyard - for in many ways, this WAS a private garden. Imagine what you would do, enjoy the gardens, the pavillions and the lose yourself in the nooks and crannies.

title: Beautiful garden and for shopping
content:
This place is mainly for sightseeing and shopping. There are traditional buildings and beautiful with small lakes. For shopping is better to bargain until 50 percent with the sellers.
Is next to the metro Yuyuan. We enjoyed walking around.

title: Chinese Garden
content: The Yu yuan itself is a very good exemple of chinese ancient house. Used to be a residence of a shanghainese trader. With traditional chinese garden, inside the walls...several lakes and stones typical of that times. Worth the visit to know despite the number of visitors. Be prepared to a very crowd place.

title: Nice green maze in downtown
content: It is like a small green village in the crowded downtown. Really like a maze where you will love getting lost. Lots of temples and houses to visit. Some shops where you can find art and craft stores. The surroundings are like a outdoor mall where you can do local shopping.

title: Very busy, tired and scruffy
content: I was here two years ago and now it looks more scruffy and tired looking, you get bombarded with sellers trying to sell you watches and bags. Very very busy so go first thing in morning. The gardens themselfs takes you about a hour to get round. Tired and crowded there are better places to go. One of these places you kinda have to go see but I wouldn't rush!

title: Nice garden walk
content: Small & big shops around and one of the place to see when in Shanghai. The place is bustling busy town with many tourist. If you want ancient things and to see traditional  ancient old buildings, this is not to be missed.

title: Crowded by still very nice to visit
content:
It is indeed a very touristy area. The inside of the garden is quieter, but still.
It is Beautiful and worth the entrance fee. I won't tell more

title: You garden not worth missing
content: One of the largest Chinese gardens in China.  Old and lots of history.  Do it with a guide if you can.  Give yourself time to roam the garden.

title: Nice place but VERY touristic
content:
The garden it self is nice and quiet. So buy a ticket and enjoy the more quiet spots. 
The rest of the area is very very crowded and touristic. There is a starbucks and a lot of souvenir shops.

title: You Garden
content: Absolutely beautiful. Defietely a highlight of our China trip & in the middle of an amazing market. Not to be missed .

title: Ancient and overly crowded
content: Lots of beautiful gardens, lakes, little bridges and stones. Lots of Chinese History as the tour of the garden pushed through. There were so many people, shops and photo opportunities. Stone gargoyle 's watch over this garden.

title: Busy Garden
content: If you want traditional gardens, go to Suzhou- my favorite and also know as the Garden Capital. This might seem like a nice break away from the busy city and commotion but hey, there are just as many people inside. Nevertheless, a bit of green and water is better than concrete and it is located in the middle of a very busy shopping area....worth a stop

title: Gorgeous Garden!
content: Must visit! About $18 to enter and definitely go during the week day to avoid the crowd. Walk at a leisurely pace and watch out for uneven walk ways. This place screams photo ops! Gorgeous park settings and to think it was a home!

title: A relaxing break from the hustle and bustle
content: I visited Yu Gardens during the Dragon Boat festival weekend and as such was actually extremely busy. But looking beyond one of Shanghai's biggest public holidays I could see that this was a beautiful relaxing environment to spend a couple of hours. The surrounding area of Yu Yuan is full of all the usual terrible tourist stores selling cheap tourist gifts interspersed with some good looking restaurants and "hole in the wall" eateries and I'm sure with a bit of exploration you could find some not so cheap looking gifts for friends and family back home. There is also the usual western style places like starbucks if thats your kinda thing. This area while made to look traditional doesn't appear that old and this makes it seem a little like a movie set.

title: As quiet as could be
content: Right in the middle of a modern bustling city is a small part of old China. As a westerner I didn't fully understand all that had happened there over time, but clearly to the local people this was a place of some significance. It's well kept and nice and tidy, highly recommend it for a quiet afternoon stroll.

title: Good ancient area
content: First of all you can get there by subway line 10 (purple), then it's about 5 mins walk to reach the area. The area contains the bazar and the garden just inside it and close to entrance/exit 4, The place has a lot of shopping options with very affordable prices, you may spend there around 3-4 hrs, couple of international coffee shops and ice creams available, like DQ and hagen-daz ice cream, Starbucks. With addition to the big collection of the chines food restaurants.

title: Lovely Oasis, even on a busy rainy day
content: Unfortunately it was raining on one of the days we were in Shanghai, in fact the only rainy day of our entire trip to China. The Yu Garden is a beautiful Oasis right in the middle of this very busy city. In fact we had to walk through a very touristy market to get there . It was built about 500 years ago and has a very nice collection of gardens, sculptures, ponds with lots of Koi and buildings. It was crowded but not as bad as the markets and was very enjoyable. It would have been much more enjoyable on a sunny day.

title: Seriously underwhelming
content: There are some fantastic gardens in the Orient. This is not one of them. For some reason the Chinese wanted to import a Japanese style garden to the throbbing metropolis that is Shanghai. Understandable. The garden is located in the old part of Shanghai.However the problem is that Shanghai is not very old! Perhaps 150 years. There simply is no history other than colonial history in Shanghai.

title: Always entrancing
content: A must visit whilst in Shanghai. Have been numerous times and never tire of visiting this amazing tranquil place in the bustling city.

title: Ok but not amazing
content: It's one of Shanghai's more important sights, but honestly not so great. Don't go on a crowded weekend.

title: Very nice in a busy shopping area
content: Lots of shops around the garden made it a little tricky to find the entrance of the gardens

title: Traditional-looking mall
content: Yu Garden is not a garden, but buildings in a traditional-looking Chinese style which house an open-air mall of souvenir shops and fast/street food. It's very much aimed at tourists: it looks pretty, but I think you will probably find more authentic food and merchandise elsewhere. Worth a look if you are in the area.

title: Great Place to visit
content: Very interesting old gardens set in the middle of Shanghai, very busy and it started to rain so was very crowded with everyones umbrellas.  Lots of very pushy street sellers in the surrounding market/shops area.

title: disappointed
content: disappointed ,commercial garden ,crowded ,don't waste your time here, go SuZhou u will found the real garden in China.

title: Shopping and take lunch with shanghai soewlongpao
content: If you want to taste a shanghai seo-long-pao (dim sum), you'll go to a restaurant at yu yuan garden. When you eat them full, you can shopping goods as tea, gifts, toys, etc. I suggest you need time for 1 hour or more to spend your money along the little road in front of the garden.

user_loc: 印第安那印第安纳波利斯
title: The Yu Garden Was Designed for Tranquility, However...
content: The Yu Garden is an extraordinary example of what those with wealth and power can accomplish. The garden is extensive with some beautiful architecture. It was designed 400 years ago to be a place of refuge for its owner and family. It was captivating. However, many tourists have little reverence for the peaceful atmosphere that can be found here. As with many attractions, there is a lot of rushing around and picture taking.

title: Good good good
content:
Both the yu garden and the place behing that (shopping and walking) are needed to visit 
Specially in rainy days it will be much more nicer

title: nice but much more crowded than I anticipated
content: for some reason I expected this to be a lovely and relatively quiet escape from the bustle of Shanghai.was actually very crowded and nothing like I expected.lots of food vendors and crowded shopping areas.market would probably be a good place for shopping on a quieter day

title: Veeery busy, but a neat experience.
content: The Yu Garden was quite peaceful, even with the throngs of tourists. Most of the buildings seemed fairly new, but there were some interesting old gardens that looked very old. It's all built around streams and rock formations.

title: Chinese Garden
content: If you have seen Chinese gardens before then this is not essential to see. It has a rockery, some ponds with bridges etc.

title: A different garden
content: Spent couple of hours at the much talked about Yuyuan garden.

title: Traditional view in City Center
content:
The nearest place with good access to see old town (Traditional View)
You can buy anything for trip gift and enjoy deferent food courts in center of garden

The crowded place is near the lake of goldfishes .

title: This is a beautiful gem right in the city!
content: Great history and beautiful gardens all around.  Our visit was dampened by hard rain; but on a nice day this would be a wonderful place to visit.  Very peaceful.

title: Easy walk
content: This garden was a nice place to visit. It was not overly crowded on the weekend and we were able to walk through very comfortably. Nice restaurants as well as fast food surround the area. Lots of great photo opportunities.

title: Lovely place and very peaceful
content: Very tranquil in comparison to the outside but I really enjoyed seeing this place. there are not any gardens in Shanghai (only those that are roof top) so seeing plants and trees is fantastic. The fishes come out of the water to greet you but I was sure if they were just hungry. I loved seeing the Turtle and baby on it's back (see photo). I just hope the animals are well looked after. I was nominated for employee of the year award. Unfortunately I didn't win but I felt and was treated like a winner. I was flown out to Shanghai from the UK and stayed at the Marriott Hotel in the Financial District. The room was bigger than my flat at home! This trip was the best consolation prize :-)

title: Pretty Cool
content: This was packed with people but well worth a visit. I liked the contrast of the gardens then the towering architecture of new Shanghai in the background.

title: It is old, right? Or is it Disney?
content: I have to say I am confused by this place. It seems remarkably well-preserved for how old it is supposed to be. But if it's the real deal then it's a great walk around. The buildings and garden are very photogenic and you can certainly wander aimlessly.

title: China in a nutshell
content: Despite the crowds that visited the same time we did, the Yu Garden represents a true highlight of Shanghai. The garden boasts marvelous historical buildings, representing a sea of tranquility in the middle of the world's largest city. Take your camera. And shop afterward in the adjoining market, where it's fine to haggle, even necessary.

title: Nice but not great
content:
It's a nice garden, but quite busy.
Lots of buildings with furniture in then and not much in the way of explanation.
Unless you have a guide, you're are pretty much at sea.
Quite busy, but so is everywhere else.

title: Peaceful escape from the tourist shops next door
content: Nice a calm walk through the ponds and gardens. Odd that the map of the layout was available next to the exit, and not the entrance-unless I missed it.

title: Buildings are well preserve including the garden
content: Buildings, structure, bridges all are surprisingly well preserve after 300 years. This is a garden of an ambassador back in Ming Dynasty. For visitors that has limited knowledge on the Chinese cultures are highly suggested to go with a narrator for complete experience. The ticket is RMB40 for peak season.

title: Well maintained gardens
content: Lots of see, gardens well kept, interesting buildings and sculptures. Lots of fish in the ponds. Strange situation in the middle of town. Definitely made a nice break from the busy chaos that is Shanghai. We visited on a rainy day but would be even better if the weather was good

title: Lots of tourists, not much serenity
content: I liked this garden. It has all the classic elements of a Chinese garden - water, stone, bamboo, balance, light ... and dragons.  But it was packed with folks.  Perhaps because it was a Chinese holiday.  Worth a visit, but check the calendar.

title: Serene extensive garden
content: Once you make it through the bazaar this is a haven. The garden entry was a little difficult to find from the subway. There was a directional sign when we emerged and followed the crowd. But then we were at a busy street with no idea where to go. Fortunately a policeman directed us the way to go, and once in the bazaar area found some signs to the garden entry. The Huxinting Teahouse is just outside the admission gate. Take note of the Yuyuan doorways.

title: Must go...
content: Everybody goes there, for chinese food, buns, tea. I love sitting at the old shop house, sip tea eat snack and watch the ppl go by. Compared to 6 years ago, ppl here are more biz minded. Some stores are like the 2 dollars stores you find in jpn.

title: Must see
content: A must see attraction in the middle of the city. Walk thru beautiful gardens and see the great architecture. Just outside there are plenty of street food. Enjoy.

title: INTERESTING
content:
Awesome architecture.
Lots of shops, but they are pretty much all selling the same products.
It's worth a visit just for the scenery inside the complex

title: Full of tourist
content: The place is full of tourists!  The outside area is full of tourist shops selling all kinds of trinkets.  Worth a visit if you want to catch a rare glimpse of old chinese architecture in this city.

title: Real Chinese history
content: This garden was a neat place to visit.  It was free to walk around but would be worth a tour guide telling you about the garden and the history.

title: Yu Garden
content: The garden is beautiful, with many traditional buildings, mature trees, a price less limestone rock with dozens of "lucky" holes, prestigious Chinese "lions" and dragon sculptures reclining on top of the undulating walls. Fascinating.

title: Beautiful place
content: Visited this place during my first travel to Shanghai in March 2016. This place gives you a glimpse of Chinese culture, food and beauty. Must go place on your travel to Shanghai

title: tea house temple shops in one.
content: Great place to see all in one. The teahouse was very old and full of culture.  The monastery was full of surprises. Shops wee the usual mix of cheap stuff with occasional quality pieces.

title: Good and Fake!
content: You've just got to go do this place. It's a place that is necessary to visit when you come to Shanghai. It's cultural, although not necessarily authentic. The City Temple is a need-to-go-to place.

title: Natural Chinese Style Garden
content: Amazing Garden, favorite place in Shanghai, popular tourist destination with plenty of foreign and local tourist during holiday season.

title: Amazing scenery worth seeing.
content: Definitely a place worth visiting for the entrance fee of 30 yuan. Rich in history by itself and beautifully surrounded by the traditional architecture. A must visit for those visiting Shanghai. Try spotting the Huxinting Teahouse just opposite the entrance to the garden. Pay attention to the details of dragons around the garden's walls.

title: Nice historical building, but too crowed.
content: The building is well under care. However, be prepared over crowded and stuffy. Advise come drop-by the site around 8am to avoid the crowd.

title: Nice outing
content: Beautiful older part of central Shanghai were you can enjoy the beauty of the older architecture. A great place to stop and enjoy tea at the tea house while watching the fish, turtles and of course the people. Plenty of shopping for that special keepsake. As with most places in Shanghai the prices are on the higher side.

title: Zig zag bridge
content: Great place to visit to see zig zag bridge as well as do loads of shopping. Ideally located near metro station , within easy reach in Shanghai. Don't purchase at face value. Bargain hard and you can get products at 20% of price quoted. Starbucks have prominent presence here. Also don't miss out on wholesale market just opp gate 1 of Yu garden.

title: This deserves to be Wonder of the World
content:
Bueatiful, historic, ancient, romantic, lovely
This is a must visit

It was very crowded on the Sunday we went, but you cannot miss it.

title: Amazing gardens, great tea experience
content: The gardens are well worth a stroll around, especially if you are coming from the bazaar next door. Despite the popularity, the price seems to put some people off, and there is no where near the number of people inside as there is around the bazaar so it feels like an escape from Shanghai.

title: FOOOOOOOOD
content: so much food everywhere. gift shop are also everywhere. prices are more expensive as it is a popular tourist destination

title: What a garden!
content: a must go in shanghai. a place where natural beauty and architecture meet. a place of peace and very picturesque.

title: great place for trinkets
content: shanghai is modern and chic, not know for ancient chinese history or artifact .. yu garden is probably the only place you'll find in SH that is traditional architecture. but for a lark, it is small and I remarkable (you have to go to BJ to see that) but it is THE place for trinkets/souvenir ........chinese kind. they also have some nice chinese restaurant that sell famous SH soup dumplings and soft hairy crabs (when in season) but it is touristy swamped with a lot of domestic out-of-towner travelers. but if you don't mind that, it is fun to spend a couple of hours there. you never know what may catch your eye.

title: Yes...
content: ...a chinese garden it is but i have seen more intresting gardens in sweden england usa spain germany and so on...save your money and time...go somewhere else ;-)

title: Walking history!
content: One of the oldest historic landmarks of Shanghai and the place is a must to know about the medieval Ming dynasty. This old garden with its famous zigzag pool and a bustling array of typical chinese wood carved buildings are bound to make you spellbound. Not very far from the hustle and bustle of the Bund and the busy East Nanjing Road, it's a priority sightseeing spot in your itinerary.

title: Serenity
content: What a cool place to stroll and take in the beauty of the nature blended with art and card game playing groups of retirees.

title: Intriguing
content: It is easy to imagine yourself as an emperor or courtier enjoying this beautiful garden a few hundred years ago. There are lovely things to see around every corner, though not all of them are well looked after. The main man who built this place really loved his big limestone rocks, which are not to everybody's taste. However there's plenty of other stuff, particularly bridges and rooms in their original condition and decoration.

title: The fake old city center of Shanghai
content: I like Shanghai - having previously lived here for 6 years straight. And I love visiting both new and old sites of the city, having often business as well as private visitors to tour guide for.

user_loc: 加利福尼亚蒙特利公园
title: Shanghai Old Town and Yu Garden
content: This Place its so cool, you can shop, eat, see the Yu Garden. 2 Starbucks store here. Something old and new. We came here 4 times during our stays in Shanghai.

title: Confined spaces can be crowded
content: Go early if a holiday or weekend OR wait until tours are finished and go layer in the day. The Ming rock gardens and a couple of the water features were the most interesting parts for us. The entrance to the gardens is inside the Bazaar area and can be difficult to locate even with signs. The bazaar has lots of souvenir shops and places to eat. Yu Gardens (and Bazaar) could be missed if you do not like places that are quite "touristy".

title: Taste of the past
content: Shanghai is a very new city and a lot of what strikes you is the fantastic new architecture. Yu Garden is a taste of the old Shanghai. Smack bang in the middle of a bustling touristy area with all of the shopping stalls and shops you can imagine is a lovely peaceful rock garden with many little bridges criss crossing a lovely little lake. The koi laze about waiting to be fed and the paths meander through an ancient rock garden. I didn't have a guide but I did hear that all of the rock structures were held together by a mixture of egg white and rice flour. How cool is that.

title: A must see in Shanghai
content: It feels like you are in an enormous palace garden, but it is artfully designed to seem much bigger than it is. A great example of an Asian garden, interesting for the plants, the ponds and the architecture. Good for all ages, especially photographers.

title: Yu Garden
content: What a tranquil and beautifully sculptured garden. I could have spent hours in this serene sanctuary.

title: Stunning Architecture and Design
content: On a rainy afternoon, I debated with myself over whether to leave the house to visit Yu Yuan or stay at home like a bum. I am so happy I decided to get out and see this beautiful garden. Although I had heard it was nice, I did not realize it was so beautiful until I entered the place. Straight away, the architecture struck as being incredibly intricate. When you look at the architecture, make sure to look both at the big picture and at the small details, like the wood carvings on the doors or the miniature statues on the roofs. It was really stunning to think about how much detail these builders put into this garden hundreds of years ago. All in all, except for the crowds, this garden really fulfilled my expectations of what a classical Chinese garden should look like and I definitely recommend it to anyone who comes to Shanghai.

title: Super Hidden Garden
content:
This is a Real Treasure and a Must but best to go Early in the morning as it gets really busy with Locals later in the Day. 

It is amazing how much is in the Garden and Really how interesting it is.

title: Picturesque
content: We visited this garden during light rain but it was still very pretty to see.  A very attractive and well laid out garden.

title: Crowded, but a lovely garden
content: Lots of interesting features to this garden. Defiantly worth a visit, but avoid all of the junky stands outside.

title: Historic, unique and so interesting
content: What magical gardens that sum up exactly what I expected of a typically chinese garden.  Amazing architecture with footpaths that weave their way through grottos of rock and sculptures, amazing bonsai style plantings. Get there early in the morning as it gets busy

title: Beautiful garden with city scape back drop
content: Stroll through beautiful gardens with amazing views of sky scrapers nearby. Great market near by for souvenir shopping. Lots of bargaining there so he garden was a good break!

title: Sanctuary in a crowded city
content: We reached the garden at 3pm on a day that was 29 degrees celcius. It was a relief to find a spot with shady trees and the water. We sat on the rocks next to the lake watching the giant koi swim by. The magnificent buildings and carvings transported me back to a time when the dynasties ruled. Spent two hours in the garden and didn't want to leave

title: Stunning gardens
content: Definitely worth the visit. Absolutely beautiful garden to stroll around in. Take your time and enjoy the tranquility in the midst of a bustling city

title: It's crowded...but a must-see
content: Yu Garden is THE tourist spot to visit. Don't miss it. Also ..if you have the time...join the queue and eat the best Xiao Long Baos out of a styrofoam box you have ever had. Browse the many more-or-less fake shops and by all means visit the actual garden as well.

title: Interesting slice of history
content: I went on a half-day SHanghai tour that included the garden, and I think the experience would be entirely dependent on the tour guide. Ours was good, and it was interesting, a bit of mix of history, nature and, of course, shopping. He helped with the purchase of goods, but I felt they were way over-priced, which was a shame; I'd prefer to buy souvenirs from a place like that, rather than the dodgy markets. Still, it was enjoyable.

title: Great time.  Neat place
content: Had fun here, was a great atmosphere to be in, enjoyed all the sights and sounds, good shopping, and don't forget to cross the bridge of seven turns to get rid of those evil spirits!

title: A famous private garden in Shanghai
content: Have visited it for several times and never felt boring. I love Yu Garden from my teenage. It is located in the old city of Shanghai. Travelers can buy all kinds of typical shanghainese food around out of the garden. The garden was built in Ming dynasty. It is a Suzhou traditional garden, quite different from the imperial garden such as the summer garden in Beijing. Recommend it~ if it's your first time visiting Shanghai or China!

title: I could live here if I were in the past
content: Great Escape from the hustle and heat of the streets outside. Best visited in the mornings or early afternoons, otherwise it gets crowded (like I'm noticing a trend here I think..!), and thegarden loses its tranquility. Like the title says, I could see myself living in this garden if I was from the Qing dynasty.. It's beautiful.. And huge.. It took me 1.5hrs to finish the whole garden.. I got lost, distracted and generally mesmerized.. It was like your own period drama set!

title: good place fro sightseeing, shopping and eating
content: very good tourist attraction... its quite big and you would need 2-3 hours to explore the place.. part from the garden there is temple and lot of shopping areas around it.... if you are adventurous enough you can also try lot of local food.... its also a good place to buy souvenirs

title: A classical chinese garden
content: These gardens are about 450 years old and located in the old part of Shanghai. They are a good example of the way of life of the elite in the later part of the Ming dynasty. As these were personal gardens there are a number of pavilions with some interesting old furniture.

title: Lovely formal gardens
content: Well worth the 40 RMB entrance fee, this is a series of natural & structural displays connected by walkways. Go to enjoy the coming together of natural and structural artistry unique to China.

title: Planning and Recommendations
content: Should you go?

title: Incredible architecture.
content: I really loved this place. From the outside of Yuu Garden with all the overly-populated bridges and beautiful fish to the inside that looked like you were in a fairytale. We had to take some wrong turns to find our way out but that was part of the fun too I believe.

title: Peace and harmony
content: Take a few time and go to see this place! It's calm and beautiful! Its a nice spot to visit! We can take good pics but like many others places there are a lot of tourist...lol

title: Not worth seeing
content:
Garden and temple of Yuyuan are too small as compared to shopping area and eateries.

The whole area is overshadowed by food stalls, flee market

title: Wundefull garden
content: A very good place to spend an afternoon an to dive into the Chinese culture. Can be crowded on a weekend but this is quite normal for most places in Shanghai

title: Beautiful Chinese Garden
content: Yu Garden is a very beautiful Chinese style garden with a lot of history. The bezaar area is nice place to walk around.

title: BEAUTIFUL BUT HAWKERS DO SPOIL THE EXPERINCE
content: We had a quick visit to the gardens, and the visit is well worth while.

title: Must go at night also
content: We visited in the day and then likes the building and place so must that we decided to go at night also. Believe me at night it was more beautiful. Must see at night so .very well connected by tube .

title: Hated It
content: If you're been to Beijing and you've visited all the amazing historical palaces, temples and the Forbidden city, then give this a miss. Extremely busy with tourists and really nothing you haven't already seen. Food in the area is also gross and I would not bother queuing up at dumpling joints, even the so called famous ones.

title: Väl omhändertaget
content: The area outside the garden had beautiful buildings and a cozy market. Beware the scammers that want to sell you tea. They will rip you off. They do this to tourists!

title: 3 stories food galore of China multiple cities cuisines
content: The ever crowded yu garden, just for non stop shopping or food hunting, you will never feel enough! From Entrance #7, you will notice a 3 stories food complex, clean, efficient, fast service and very reasonable pricing for locals and tourists alike. It's over 100 types of selections you can choose from!

title: Nice, but busy
content: A small corner of the city that has escaped the developer's wrecking ball, well worth seeing, but is overcrowded.

title: An oasis in a bustling city
content: The Yu Garden was absolutely beautiful. The variety of plants and the architecture are stunning. It is very relaxing and is a real treat to take a break by the ponds.

title: Nice but to crowded
content:
Not recommend to visit on weekends, theres to many people and its difficult to enjoy the place and find nice souvenirs.

But its a nice place to visit to see the old China surrounded by the modern city

title: A must visit place, traditional place in Shanghai
content: Yu Yuan is a must place to visit if you visit Shanghai. There are many traditional buildings, and so many shops that sell traditional gifts and food.

title: wonderful gaden
content: Beautiful and wonderful garden is possible to see and spend two hours with the view of small lakes and names colored rare, the big hard rock rare, outside the park there are old market and beautiful goods diversified see shops silk, ceramics, and many types of Chinese clothing, there is a Starbucks as well.

title: One last remaining Emperor gardens in Shanghai.
content: Its cheap to enter and you can walk the garden leisurely in about 4 hours or more. The Bone Stone throughout is amazing. The views are beautiful, it really is one of those places you should visit if in Shanghai.

title: Edo's visit Sganghai
content: Interesting historical pretty garden full of great places to rest and look. Some great pieces of historical furniture.

title: Beautiful
content: We visited as part of our day trip in Shanghai with a guide and it was worth having the insider knowledge to explain the background the site. She also had mosquito repellent which would be advised when it's warm. Amazing photos to be had here!

title: Another cultural must
content: It's a bit hard to find as the door is within a shopping complex. Once located it is unlike most gardens in as much as it contains trees, shrubs, waterways etc but the old halls and furniture mark it as a place of rest and contemplation.

title: Don't go to Shanghai without visiting!
content: Yu Yuan is one of Shanghai's great offerings.

title: lovely
content: this garden is just lovely.  we had a bit of a hard time finding it though.  it's built in the middle of a little shopping area...but, once you're there it's a traditional chinese garden...it's just lovely...with a little pond with fish...plants, pretty little buildings...very nice.

title: Wonderful views at every turn.
content: An outstanding garden in the Chinese style.  Quite small, but the arrangement of the paths and buildings made it seem much larger.  The only problem was that the crowds of people took away from the atmosphere that should have been quite and contemplative.

title: An absolute Highlight but very badly signposted for individual travellers
content: I have been living in Shanghai for 11 years, The Administrator's garden and the adjacent City God Temple is a highlight I always take my visiting friends to on the first day of their visit. I just really wish the local govt would sign post the actual Yuyuan better. From our Western perspective we think of a "garden" as a place with trees and lawns etc. The Yu Yuan is a Chinese garden enclosed behind walls and with secret nooks and crooks. It is NOT visible from the street. Sitting in the adjacent Gucun Park (which looks like a park with trees and lawns) on my off days I have to direct dozens of foreigners back and away towards the walled garden. Come on SH Govt ... we are a city visited by millions from around the world every month .... get someone to write your English directions as understood by foreigners. The same is true of the information boxes inside the Garden. The Chinese is very explanatory but the English is limited and rather Chinglish-like leaving the (non-tour group) foreign visitor perplexed and confused and rather uninformed despite the visit. The same is true for 90% of museums in Shanghai. The English used is bad, brief and uninformative.

title: Excellent value attraction
content: Well worth visiting if in Shanghai, make it one of the priorities even if only in Shanghai for a couple of days. Beautiful gardens, I imagine it can be fairly crowded at times but wasn't too bad when we went, possibly due to the rain.

title: Stunning
content: Should not be missed on a visit to Shanghai. Absolutely stunning . The buildings and gardens are so beautiful you won't want to leave. There are ponds dotted about with brightly coloured carp and turtles. But also it is worth looking up as the roofs of the buildings are really ornate and decorated some with warriors, others with elephants or dragons. Only problem is very uneven ground which was fine for us being able bodied but we saw a family having a real problem with a wheelchair.

title: Very Beautiful Garden and Meeting Rooms
content: This attraction consists of beautiful gardens dotted with many meeting rooms. We probably didn't appreciate their historical or architectural significance, but it was wonderful to explore. There was even an exhibit on the second floor of one of the buildings that had paintings of flowers that seemed to be off the tour path, so we had the rooms all to ourselves.

title: First of many peaceful gardens and temples.......
content: We were part of a tour groups and this was one of the first attractions we went to. We were warned about the stall operators, and you do tend to get hassled a bit as you walk past, but you get used to it and you just need to be forceful and not engage (unless you want to haggle for a bargain price). The gardens are peaceful and serene and our English speaking guides were able to give a very good run down of the place for us.

title: Beautiful, yet crowded
content: These stunning gardens are definitely worth a visit. They are perfectly kept and hold many incredible sights. Carp ponds, temples, bridges and nature. All in one place. As a bonus, it's stuck right in the middle of the old bazaar which is also an incredible place to visit. All that said, the place is far too small for the hordes of people that visit it everyday. So it's virtually impossible to enjoy it or even take a picture that doesn't contain hundreds of strangers in it.

title: Peace & beauty in the city
content: Definitely worth visiting when you're in Shanghai. Very peaceful and everything works together to create a harmonious garden with spaces for meditation and relaxing.

title: Great walk. Although very busy.
content: Enjoyed the estate and the gardens. The shopping was cool too. Take your time and enjoy the displays. Interesting to watch the silversmiths and the chopstick makers. Amazing detail, but was informed that the apprentices work the public displays most of the time.

title: Beautiful traditional chinese garden
content: Yu gardens are easily found in the centre of Shanghai. It costs 40rmb to go in. It was really worth it. Around every corner is another surprise. Beautifully restored buildings, trees, ponds and bridges. So quiet and calm, and just next to the old town which is full of tourist shops and restaurants.

title: A Classic
content: Shanghai is so fantastically modern in many ways that you really feel like you've traveled back in time visiting Yuyuan Garden. It's beautiful and peaceful. A side benefit: you can knock off a lot of your shopping in the little boutiques that line the streets leading to the garden.

title: Eh - if you're a tourist...
content: Every tourist goes here for 'authentic China' in Shanghai. That said, the hawkers are out in force at all times. The hundreds of shops in the area are hit or miss. They have some unique stuff, but you have to wade through a lot to find anything good. The tea shop in the center has good dumplings, but the wait is long (typically) to get in and you feel rushed.

title: So astoundingly, well, Chinese!
content: We don't get this kind of history in the US: A garden created in the 16th century for an aging father, that took over 20 years to finish and eventually impoverished its creators, that was used by the British during the Opium Wars (1832-1842), was destroyed in the Taiping Rebellion (1853), was rebuilt, and was destroyed again during the Japanese invasion (1942), and rebuilt again. And it's gorgeous. And as original an architectural garden of delights as one could hope to see. Such focus, creativity and endurance seems to be uniquely Chinese. I am so glad I had the chance to see it.

title: Beautiful Garden undoubtedly!
content: Yu Garden is located in the old Shanghai. It is a never missed place if one is visiting Shanghai. It just cost few Yuan to enter, which is worth paying. It is a mix of flora fauna and architecture domains.

title: Awesome place
content: This is one my favorite places in Shanghai. The old town mixed with the modernity of Shanghai buildings is just amazing!

title: A Classic Chinese Garden
content:
A stunning old world garden. It was once a home for a Mandarin, his wives and concubines. Try and get here at 8.30 am when it opens before it gets too crowded.
After visiting you spend time at the market surrounding the garden.

title: Serenity not to be missed!
content: The Yu Gardens are so beautiful, and the most perfect escape from Shanghai's bustling, crowded, noisy streets. Even though the gardens were busy, there was always a corner to escape to that was your own. With secret paths to discover, truly beautiful landscaping, a true balance of man and nature, this is one place not to be missed.

title: An oasis of peace.
content: We spent a very happy two to three hours here. You go through a busy bazaar to reach the entrance before entering another world. It is so quiet (apart from the crowds) given it's location. It is a wonder of different buildings and gardens. We had a guide who explained how it was built for a governor who then lost it through gambling. I would suggest a guide or guidebook unless you research it before going. You can of course just wander around soaking it in. It can get very busy and you are best taking water with you. Also in a couple of places the stones are very slippy even in dry weather as they have been worn smooth over the centuries.

title: Little piece of heaven amongst the high rises
content:
The Yu Garden is both beautiful and peaceful inside a small area where just metres outside the gates are hustle and bustle of souvenir shops, tourist traps, restaurants  and food vendors.
Really enjoyable couple of hours here

title: Old Shangai
content: Still the old charm is maintained but this place is very crowded. Fast food joints, sovenier shops add colour.

title: a well Preserved the heritage
content: I visited Shanghai Jan 2016 with My hubby... its a very nice place to visit. you can see China rich cultural heritage... I love the way they preserved & maintained this garden...

user_loc: 加利福尼亚艾尔赛里托
title: Small and crowded popular garden
content: If you were able to see the Yu Gardens before the crowds arrived, it would no doubt be very beautiful and peaceful. While it is hard to appreciate with tons of people around on a hot and humid day, you can begin to see the beauty and the symbolism of this meaningful and classic Chinese garden. It is really not a large area (5 acres), but the maze-like arrangement is used to create self-contained landscapes with view-revealing windows.

title: Stunning and well worn.
content: A trip to the Yu Garden is most exciting by the trip through the neighborhood to get there. It is nestled within a warren of old streets festooned with shops of all kinds. The gardens themselves are serene and staid. You take a circuitous path through which leads across a lake filled with koi and turtles. The buildings are old and decorative. Many of the rocks are well displayed and filled with holes. It is not hard to imagine a family relaxing and meditating there.

title: Good Tourist Spot /Historical site
content: One of the most famous location of Old Shanghai Town with a Very Small Garden and their Famous PORK & Seafood juicy Dumplings. A must try. If you want it cheap or average you need to queue longer. Don't get on the wrong queues. There is this 3 storey restaurant near this Yu Garden that offers you a choice of your budget for their Tim Sum which includes their famous Dumplings (soupy). Crowded but nice to try. You can go for the RMB80 or RMB100 choice set per person. Price may differ due to inflation. Better than joining cheaper but very very long queue. Lots of shopping and bargains. Careful not to be conned into paying higher for your purchases. You need bargaining a lot at roadside stalls for souvenirs.

title: Beautiful Buildings... Lots of people
content: Lots of people taking selfies, souvenir shops, a few interesting folk artists showing off their talents, fast food places, koi fish, gardens and tea houses and MANY visitors. Nearby tourist hotels and a Metro stop make it an easy to spot landmark. Worth a quick visit.

title: Lovely little garden
content: A very nice little garden full of little surprises. The reception hall, former library, other rooms, a pond, lots of decorations like stones, bridges, trees etc. Nice to visit.

title: Walked around in the evening.
content: Good atmosphere,

title: A must visit for. Visitors !!!
content: Great history with the gardens , and buildings , tea house , and plenty of shopping and food .

title: Nice Break From Downtown Shanghai
content: Yu Garden is a nice relaxing break from the hustle and bustle of downtown Shanghai. It was peaceful and serene with nicely laid out ponds and interesting architecture on the houses that are scattered throughout the garden. There was some really intricate carvings including a dragon guarding a wall.

title: Tourist Trap
content: Easy access to Subway Line 2, a good 2 hours for some photos and visit to famous restaurants serving xiao long baos. Nothing much to see but expect the crowd as bus loads of locals and tourists would always include this on their itinerary. Goods sold inside the complex were a bit expensive, best to find time to roam at stores outside the complex...it would give you the best bargain.

title: Rainy Day Blues
content: Went there on a rainy day which made what would otherwise have been a negative experience even worse. The architecture is worth seeing as well as the history, but the hawking of cheap junk and the crowds over came any positives. I would avoid this "attraction" unless you like the manic stage of life.

title: Peaceful
content: Strolled around the Yu Garden after dinner. Very peaceful. Really admire the quality of the reliefs and the ancient architecture.

title: Imperial Garden in Shanghai
content: Close to the Bund area, a recreational park of the imperial kings of china... Nice place for a visit. Dont expect more... the area around is a crowded place.

title: Touristy
content: Lovely old previously privately owned gardens, which is a little oasis in a bustling city. Lovely to gain some peace and quiet but be prepared for the crowds in the market at the exit...

title: Yu Garden (Yuyuan)
content: Is there a more peaceful and serene place on this earth than Yu Garden. A memorable place and a must to experience.

title: So very, very good!
content: My wife and I just loved this place! Again our guide Harris Gu accompanied us and we learnt so much from him and saw the most beautiful buildings, natural rock sculptures, gardens and learnt so much from our time here!

title: Don't miss it
content: From east nanjing transfer to. Line 10 the next stop will be the yu yuan garden . Join the crowd and explore the streets outside the garden where you can find different kind of food , souvenirs etc,,, must try their famous "shao long pa0"

title: Best one stop shopping we did in China though not for the "high quality" stuff
content: If you are in Shanghai, especially if you are on a tour that takes you to all the "factory" places, then come here to get your low priced bargains though the quality will not be as good. I did find a good quality tea shop with decent prices. It was a medium sized rectangular store on a corner with 2 entrances. The tea is at one entrance and the "White Rabbit" candies (good souvenir candies) are at the other entrance. I will try to attach pics. They will let you try the tea, which is a good sign. Their teas are in glass jars, which is not ideal if they sit for days, but they seemed to have good turnover. I tried and bought their ginseng oolong, which they have in factory sealed bags of 250g or you can buy custom amounts and they will scoop it into a bag and seal it for you. The cost on the ginseng oolong was 36 yuan for 50g or 180 yuan for the 250g bag. We bought 3 of the 250g bags so we bargained for a discount down to 160 yuan per bag (incidentally this was roughly the same price as our tea factory and about half the price as other top quality places we saw elsewhere). There were a few tea chain stores with cute boxes and good smelling tea, but people said that tea was cheap tea and you couldn't try it there (though the price was right at 25 yuan for a little 75g tin...half the price of the good tea that I did get). I actually bought a couple of these as well before I knew better.

title: Busy
content: The Yu Garden are very busy, a lot of people walking around. It is a bit difficult to find, because of the language.and the information. Sometimes you see a directioninformation but then it stops all of a sudden and you have to find your own way further. It is very nice to visit but beware of pickpocked in the croud. There are a lot of souvenirsshops alos

title: Must visit Chinese garden!
content: I recommend to visit Yu Garden in the morning since otherwise the que to the ticket office is very very long and takes the whole day. Be there by 9:00 am and you get a great experience! The garden itself is very beautiful and it is enough to visit it once in life.There is also a tea house on the way to the garden which has very high prices, I do not recommend that.

title: Best two hours of Shanghai
content: Once you are inside the gardens it is calm and very beautiful. Outside is vary hectic with all of the stores and people. Great place to get your souvenirs (outside). Be wary of the art dealers inside they are very overpriced. You can find the same stuff other places in the city for significantly less. Also beware of people selling you stuff as you are walking down the street. Offer about 10-20% of what they ask and keep walking. If you really want what they are selling stay firm. If you hand them money and they need to make change one of the tricks is to show you a ripped 100 and ask for a different one, it is more than likely a fake, just refuse and ask for your change. Also, make sure before they leave that they actually give you RMB back as they like to give rupees or some other currency with the same numbers on it.

title: Old World Charm
content: Excellent garden! Go in the morning, before 10 am. Less crowded and definitely more pleasant! Best enjoyed slowly. Stop and rest at one of the pretty pavilions too!

title: Nice place, just don't go on a weekend.
content: Interesting complex with ancient chines culture, great food and shopping. It's free entrance but shopping or dining inside it's surely not cheap. Not to mention the great amount of tourists that are constely there.

title: A busy busy place. But worth the visit.
content: I really like this area. There is nice architecture, little stalls and shops, plenty of food and some really nice Artist stalls. I feel overall it is reasonably priced considering the high volume of tourist traffic.

title: Quiet moments in a beautiful setting
content: The Yuyuan Garden is a memorable garden because of its serenity, calm, and peacefulness. We have beautiful Asian gardens in Seattle also but when you get to this garden you will want to take your time and stay. Everywhere you look there is beauty surrounding you along with it's history. Be sure to take you camera for many photo opportunities.

title: Nice but overcrowded
content: As was staying in ren nearby went here for a visit, the overal area is very nice, the gardens are extraordinary, but be prepared for crowds of people, but was worth it.

title: Old, old Shanghai
content: Not only it housed one of the historical houses with beautiful garden and a twisting bridge leading to the house, it is surrounded by beautifully restored old buildings and lots , lots of shopping and restaurants. I especially like the Nan Xian soup dumplings place, very Shanghai, very local.

title: Tranquil and traditional
content: Amazing to see the old garden with the new Shanghai in the background. It was busy but I am sure it always is. I had a guide take me round so it was so good to have the figures and architecture explained otherwise I would have missed so much of the history and superstition associated with Chinese people.

title: A lovely glimpse of living art from 500 years ago.
content: The Yu Garden encapsulates the art of gardening with a LONG term view. I expected flowers, but when you build a garden to last centuries, you're thinking of beauty that lasts, so the focus is on rocks and water and trees. Overall a wonderful experience, especially if you bring a tour guide like "Miki tours!"

title: awesome
content: We made it early morning after breakfast at 9:45 am but the place was quite crowded. Lot of old people and locals and tourists.The place was bustling. The place showcases the old history elements of the chinese . The place is quite big .There are enough shaded places where you can relax and buy some softdrinks and rest as you walk along.

title: Old Shanghai
content: A glimse of old Shanghai. LuBulong Restaurant, reservations required. If you have the patience, stand in line for dumplings. I've been 3 times and have yet to have dumplings. Gardens are beautiful, go early to avoid the crowds.

title: Fascinating, but crowded place to visit
content: This was a nice place to visit, especially on a hot day as the trees provide some welcome shade and the various water features bring a sense of cool relief.

title: Beautiful
content: The area around Yu Gardens made me think of Bladerunner, it is so busy and so lively but then you have this oasis where you can escape and enjoy the beautiful gardens. Great for a wander and to take in the type of scenery you have probably came here for.

title: Historical and unique place
content: It is cultural heritage place. The buildings are of various shape depicts chinese heritage. Shoping is fun here. Be aware on weekends. It will be two crowded. Metro line is near to this so easy to reach here.

title: wish i was born during that period
content: it is a must see site if you can stand walking along narrow walkway with other tourists pushing you around. the architect and furniture are beautiful like what i used to see in traditional chinese soap opera. there are plenty of places to buy unique souvenirs like chinese stamp with your name engraved, jade, palm drawing painting. be sure to bargain down at least 60 to 70% of the asking price.

title: Well, you have to go
content: I'm not big on this place, but you do have to go there, if only just to have gone there.  It's highly touristed, by westerners and Asians alike.

title: Too many people, too much cheap hussel
content: maybe I went on a bad day but there were way too many people and way too many touts.  Was not enjoyable.

title: Too much trouble with dealers
content: It's a cool place with loads of shops to buy souvenirs and local food as well. But it's really hard to get rid of the street dealers who follows you even for few kilometers. One of my friends bought a fake Rolex watch for 400 yuan and it was broken even before we leave the garden. They didn't refund either. Be careful with the stuff here. But it's a great place to purchase cheap souvenirs. Use common sense and do it. Everything will be fine.

title: Nice Place
content: This place becomes so lively with lots of decorations and people around during Chinese festival New year. And there are also some events going on inside this place but it becomes so crowded and hard to get inside and watch.

title: Very relaxing
content: I would recommend a visit to Yu Garden. It is an extensive garden with nice bridges, well-kept shrubbery, 100 year old trees, the unique rock formations, and lots of fish. I thought it was a nice stop from the crowdedness nearby.

title: Go midweek for best experience
content: This is a tourist mecca. There are other places that are more authentic, but if you want a bit of fun and a shopping experience go here. The weekend is very busy but the weekdays are good. The garden in the middle is a pleasant interlude. Bargain, bargain, bargain.....have fun. You will get bugged every 5 seconds to buy a cheap watch, bag, go to tea house....just keep moving.

title: Crowded and beautiful
