content: A touch of 16th century, but living like the modrrn parts of Shanghai. It has an unrepeatable atmosphere and is highly suitable for those searching for some tourist souvenits from China.

title: A must see!
content: Amazing - an extensive Chinese garden located beside the City God Temple in the northeast of the Old City of Shanghai. It was a peak into what China was in the years when it was ruled by Emperors.

title: Lovely but Terribly Crowded
content: We arrived around 9:30 am, but was already many people. It's a special place, very beautiful and unique architectural styles, but just too many people squeezed into the space.

title: Stunning gardens
content: These gardens are stunning and are surrounded by Old Chinatown and all the beautiful buildings. Worthy of a visit.

title: Past cultures
content: A visit to the Yu Garden gives a partial insight to the lifestyle of a culture now passed. Well worth the time to go there.

user_loc: 菲律宾达斯马里尼亚斯市
title: back to the past
content: it was a peak into what China was in the years when it was ruled by Emperors. The garden a good place to relax and meditate. The tour guide also explained how guests were situated when being received by people of importance. He also said that Japanese language came from the Chinese? hmmmm

title: Loved the Koi!
content: Our tour of China would be complete without a tour of the Yu Garden. Lots of history here! My highlight was the Koi fish pond in the center of the garden. We followed up our tour with wonderful shopping for silk! An outstanding day in Shanghai!

title: Quiet oasis in the throng of a tourist trap
content: On my first attempt to visit I was disappointed to find the gardens closed for the afternoon so instead was stuck in a very touristy marketplace. Some interesting vendors to be found - all willing to haggle on price - but overall just store owners yelling at you to get you in their stores. The next I returned and made it into the gardens. It may hav been because it was a rainy day, but I was in th egarden with several guided groups and yet was still able to find many quiet corners. I took hundreds of pics of the traditional architecture and manicured gardens, many without a single soul in them. After the crush of people every where else in the city it was such a quiet reprieve. From the outside you wouldn't know it, but inside because of the layout and intersecting pathways I found that it seemed huge on the inside and spent a couple of hours strolling around. Highly recommended.

title: Peacefull
content: Very Peacefull place in the midst of a bustling city. Lovely buildings and ponds with loads of koi a bit difficult to find entrance

title: Tranquil heaven
content: a stunning Garden in the middle of this metropolis. The a walk around this park. Indulge in some food.

title: Nice
content: Nice and calm for a brisk walk in the garden. One of shanghai attraction not to be missed off! A combination of nature and old building.

title: Very nice area
content: Very interesting place. The beautiful buildings, amazing tearoom and... crowds of tourists. Be sure after visiting the Yu Garden to make round the small streets.You can see real life and real people.

title: Too busy
content: It's just not nice enough here to make it worth dealing with the throngs of people that come here. Perhaps if you find a time of day that's not wall to wall with people, it's worth it. But if you're in Shanghai or China for awhile I'd suggest getting your Chinese garden fix elsewhere.

title: Beautiful Yu Garden
content: This is a must see.  Beautiful gardens and structures.  If you are a shopper, you can spend a week in the area around Yu Garden for fantastic bargains.

title: Great Area
content: Interesting Chinese architecture area with ponds and bridges.  Lots of places to eat and shop.  Very busy and a bit 'touristy' but fun and well work a visit

title: Nice garden but surrounding area was crowded
content: Yu garden and the temple outside is beautiful. However, this should be a tranquil experience but this was ruined by the overcrowding. We went mid-week and after 1 (12 is when chinese normally have their lunch).

title: Very quiet beautiful garden
content: This garden was very similar to the one we saw in Vancouver last September. Unlike the garden in Vancouver, many of the sandstones in the Yu Yuan Gardens are from Shanghai. Very nice peaceful place; at times, the drizzle did make it "more like a garden", though obviously, it would have been nicer photo-taking without the rains.

title: Best thing to visit in Shanghai
content: I love this place, i have been to Shanghai few times and to me, it is definitely the best thing to visit. So nice, relaxing, beautiful.

title: Must do in Shanghai!
content: I visited the Yu Gardens as part of a business trip to Shanghai. It's a day well spent. The ticket to the garden is not expensive - Rmb 50. The gardens are gorgeous and well maintained and you get to appreciate the traditional architecture. There are many interesting souvenir shops, representing traditional Chinese crafts, leading up to the Yu garden. Ended up buying some stuff for home. Overall, it's an day well spent away from the flashy malls and tall buildings. This is a part of Shanghai you don't want to miss.

title: A bit of a tourist trap
content: This is a bit of a tourist trap. A lot of cheap Chinese goods that are worthy of the dollar store. Has a flea market atmosphere

title: Real Chinese experience
content: If you want to have a feel of real china and its architecture then u must visit this place.. Right in middle of the most modern shanghai...

title: A Small yet Beautiful Gardens
content: We visited this garden late afternoon, very popular with the locals takes about 45mins to go round slowly, there are toilets on site

title: Very Enjoyable Visit
content: If you find yourself in Shanghai with a couple of hours on your hands, I would definitely recommend a visit to the Yu Garden. It is not a garden in the Western sense, but rather the home of a once prominent Shanghai resident. There are beautiful ponds, sculpture, vegetation and old structures to visit. It can get crowded so perhaps try a early day weekday visit, but any chance you have I would take it. The Yu Garden is surrounded by some restaurants and shopping, so you can enjoy time with that as well.

title: The peace is gone
content: When we lived here 5 years ago Yu Garden still offered a sense of peace amid the bustle of Shanghai. You could wander to a corner of the gardens and be alone, of nearly alone even near the main bridge. Now everything was crowded and noisy. It is still a top Shanghai sight, but based on this visit it would be hard to envision the peaceful enclave it was meant to be.

title: Beautiful in the spring.
content: I am from the United States where this type of garden is not common but represents much of the style of gardens in China. The paths take you multiple places so the exploring there can take some time. Please give yourselves enough time to be able to enjoy the many plants, trees,blooms and ponds.

title: We are so pleased the past has been saved
content: Maybe a bit busy but well worth a visit. Our guide gave us the history then time to look around I feel rushed it. Thank you for saving some of your history.

title: A peaceful place in the middle of a busy city
content: Beautiful gardens and peaceful setting.  A wide variety of sculptures. Pools with fish and turtles and beautiful flowers.

title: On Tour Wendy Wu
content: It would be a tranquil beautiful place if there were no visitors. However it was a most interesting place to visit and glad we did. Its very busy ,wall to wall people but we managed to get round alright as it is really quite small.

title: Beautiful tranquil park and gardens.
content: This is a beautiful park and garden with traditional buildings, bridges, ponds and walkways, right next to a popular shopping district. You could spend an half-day enjoying the tranquility. We were lucky to be there when it was not too crowded. One does pay to enter.

title: A taste of China in the heart of a busy western style city
content: Actually you may not feel that you are in China when you visit British or French Concession or many shopping streets in Shanghai. So finding a Chinese Garden in the heart of a busy city is a great opportunity. The design of the garden makes you feel relaxed and fresh. The garden is full of trees and Chinese pavilion decorated with rock stones and beautiful river with many red fish inside.

title: Needs maintenance
content: It is easy to see that the gardens once were quite impressive.  But the buildings are in major need of maintenance.  The shops in the garden carry very authentic items, unlike the fakes of the shops leading up to the entrance.

title: A MUST visit
content: Exquisite and intricate layout, beautiful shrubbery and plants of all shapes, sizes and hues make you forget you are on earth. The artistic style of the garden architecture have made the garden one of the highlights that every tourist must see and spend hours.

title: Beautiful
content: This place is sooo beautiful, peaceful and lovely. A great day out walking and exploring. Full of history and beauty. You can sit and relax or keep waking but a must when in Shanghai.

title: So touristy
content: Take a beautiful garden, kept for centuries then throw in like a million tourists a year and see what happens.

title: Impressive garden in the middle of the city
content: Hade a guided tour through the garden. It was very interesting learning about the ancient culture and quite beautiful.

title: A Worth the evening Visit.
content: One can easily make perfect study of Historical Place of Shanghai , the Ancient Art Heritage of China

title: Shopping and religion
content: Thus part seems to be the old city with classical chinese buildings. It was busy with tourists and locals. Make sure you take a pic of the map so you don't get lost. There is a temple on site, which draws many people. As you get out you will find a mosque on your left about 250 m walk and halaal restaurants to your right about 150 m walk. Good experience, good shopping.

title: Good place to spend the afternoon
content: There is a fee for this, but worth the money.  The garden displays a great deal of Chineese culture and a nice place to relax and reflect.

title: Nice spot but always busy.
content: Reviews say to avoid like the plague on the weekend -so we did. Was still busy but we had freedom to go where we wanted and not dictated by the crowd! Was a nice place. Surrounded by great buildings and shopping district which was fun haggling. A nice spot very different to the rest of the city. Cost about £4 (40 Yuan) to get in.

title: Beauty in the heart of the city.
content: We were taken to these gardens by our guide and we were very pleased she did so. The gardens are beautiful and well worth a visit but the volume of people who were also there does detract from them. It is difficult to imagine the serenity that a garden like this was built for but as I've said it is worth a visit. The surrounding area is extremely busy and full of shops selling souvenirs. This is best avoided!

title: An idyllic garden in the heart of a busy city
content: This a perfect place just to get away from the hustle and bustle of Shanghai city life and completely forget for moments where you actually are. It is stunning to the eye and just shows you the traditional architecture that China is so famous for. It is easy to get to it, just a short walk from the Yuyuan Garden metro station just be careful of scammers outside of the station and around the garden. We knew someone who fell for it - known as the tea scam - it's easy to do. Just avoid anyone or any couple who asks for you to join them at a tea room or tea festival. Be persistent and they'll leave you be.

title: Go to Yu Garden.. An oasis in the middle of the city!
content: Yu Garden was a very nice surprise. We were wondering around old Shanghai before hotel check out and almost didn't pay to go into the garden. This is an oasis in the middle of a big city. Beautiful gardens, buildings and we were entertained by live music. You can see it all quickly in 30 minutes, but I would recommend at least an hour to really enjoy it all.

user_loc: 加利福尼亚埃尔塞贡多
title: Garden is good but the area is a bit overwhelming
content: Lots of tourists and big groups. We did go through the garden but probably did not need to since we went to Suzhou and the Humble Administrators garden that had all these features and more. Area surrounding is just lots of shopping and lots of crowds.

title: Took a stroll and found this Gem
content: Yu Garden is amazing, but very very touristy with people asking if you want a watch all the time, although they did pick out the English more!  expect it to be very busy, but be prepared to be amazed

title: Garden like no other!
content: While every city builds gardens, this garden is like no other. Do not miss this and the near by old street. These are very well preserved pieces of history of the city that makes it different from the rest. We went on a weekday and I guess that is why we were able to enjoy more. There was no rush to go through and we spent almost an hour going through.

title: Much more than a garden
content: We went expecting an oriental garden. Yuyuan is a whole bustling district with the garden at its centre. If on your own, as we were, you have to search for the garden entrance, as the only direction signs are in Chinese. The gardens, once found are really interesting with lots of old buildings, pools and oriental gardens. The whole district is one large Chinese shopping area (for tourists). It has bustling pedestrianized narrow streets and squares with lots of arcade style shops. It is not a market. We thoroughly enjoyed our time there. Allow at least 3 hours. Entrance fee to the actual garden 40 yuan 20 for older citizens.

title: beatiful gardens. busy market
content: The gardens are ancient and beatiful and worth a tour. The market around is crazily busy. Do not come on weekends

title: Stunning gardens
content: Went to Yu Gardens on Tomb sweeping day so it was especially busy. The day was sunny and we had a fantastic time walking the perimeters of the gardens, grabbing some delicious bowza and dumplings along the way. From my personal experience I would try and visit the gardens when the day doesn't fall on a public holiday!

title: Beautiful Residence and Garden with Fascinating History
content: The Yuyuan Gardens were our first "gardens" in China. (We didn't realize that these were actually the historic private residences of wealthy business people and political leaders, as opposed to actual botanic gardens, when we booked our tour.) The history was fascinating and we loved learning about all the different symbols that were incorporated into its design.

title: Relaxed walk and easy accessable, but not no unforgetable experience
content:
Nice and relaxing place in the middle of Shanghai. Many tourist, but not a blow away expenerience in gardening, architecture or history

However, not expensive, so value for money

title: The Fascinating Yu Garden
content: I found the Yu Garden to be extraordinary. I couldn't resist taking photos and I must have taken 100 of them.

user_loc: 新西兰奥克兰中心地区
title: Yu Garden
content: Want to see old China this is the place to visit.   Tourist attraction great place to get cheap souvenirs   We spent 4 hours in the area this was enough.

user_loc: 新西兰奥克兰中心地区
title: History right in front of you
content: If you go to Shanghai you can't miss visiting here. You'll want to allow at least a couple of hours and you'll also find plenty of places to eat. Didn't seem to get hassled here to buy 'knock off' watches etc.

title: Escorted tour of Yu Garden
content: It was raining hard when we took the escorted through Yu Garden. Because each garden is connected by covered walkways, we rarely needed our umbrellas. The history of the garden is interesting and it has some very large koi. I enjoyed the visit so much that we returned the next day without the rain. The gardens are surrounded by a marketplace where you can find just about any souvenir. You need to bargain for the prices. Do not pay the first price, bargaining is part of the fun. They enjoy it with you.

title: Garden in a bustling city
content: As I have some spare time, I decided that I should make a trip to Yu Garden. I read reviews about Yu Garden, interestingly which are both negatives and positives.

title: Charming & tranquil garden - worth the visit!
content: This garden is an peaceful and green oasis tucked in the midst of Shanghai cosmopolitan city life and busy streets. There is plenty to see - splendid rockery (the most exquisite is the Jade Rock), ponds teeming with koi fish, manicured gardens, century old furniture, calligraphy, paintings and brick carvings.

title: A little bit of paradise in the heart of old Shanghai
content: Was not sure whether to go into the gardens as there was a long line up to get in. However I am so glad I did. While it was busy, it allows one to step back in time and experience the beautiful architecture and layout of an authentic chinese garden.

title: Very hectic and a bit overwhelming
content: if you want to tick this off your list then go for it...for us it was hot over crowded and not worth it! rather go shopping in tianzifang!

title: Oasis of beauty if the big city
content: What a wonderful discovery in the heart of bustling shanghai. Beautiful buildings and pavillions scattered in a small peaceful elegantly appointed garden. Despite the bustle just beyound the walls, there are a multitude of quiet nooks and crannies to explore and places to sit and enjoy the beauty of the fish pond , the wonderful dragon sculpture atop the inner walls of the garden and the joyful the singing of the birds . Perfection; except for all the tourists!

title: soon relaxing
content: You wouldn't think you were in the middle of a bustling city like Shanghai in this garden, considering it is located almost centrally and right next to the Old Town Market.

title: Be aware of Crowds
content: Ok, don't go on a Sunday or Public holiday. It's a very nice location and in essence also beautiful, but the number of people there leaves you no other choice than tick it off the list and move on. Sorry.

title: Best plce in Shanghai
content: This is the best place to know the local culture and to do shopping, it looks like here is the place that the local go, very few tourist.

title: Connecting fly
content: Quit busy place it's easy to find peaceful and relaxing spot and enjoy the majestic of this place. Most Asian tourism. Very affordable like $8,00 US dollars and NO MUCH English language staff to help.

title: A Great Chinese Garden
content: This was a fantastic area to visit giving insight into the various aspects of chinese garden structures. Was very busy on our visit. Lovely area.

title: Beautiful piece of horticultural history
content: Very lovely gardens set out in the classic, traditional style. Can get very crowded however. Beautiful nevertheless!

title: More bang for the buck
content: I love it when you get shopping and history and scenery all in one place. Yu Garden is very near the oldest street in China. This is so interesting and historical and very picturesque. The prices are pretty much set here and very low so shop here first and you know what prices to haggle down to at the other markets. Most locals shop on this street. If you shop at Yu Garden prices are inflated because this is a tourist spot so take a short walk to the oldest street for great shopping and be sure to go into the temple. Yu Garden is absolutely gorgeous a must see while in Shanghai. Great photo ops. Pay to go in well with it and plan a little extra time it's bigger than you think.

title: Historical place
content: A beautiful place attracts lot of tourist to spend some time to do local shopping and local Chinese food and can take nice photos

title: Interesting place but very crowded
content: My boyfriend and I went there in a Sunday and it was too crowded. I even couldn't recognize the place because it became so commercial that historical part seems to be hide... Anyway it is a good place to buy cheap pearls and silk things.

title: Tranquility in a Hectic City
content: What a great place. Its tucked away in the corner of a really busy shopping area and initially I thought it was going to be just as crazy but once inside the gates, the peace and quiet is amazing! (small entrance fee, around £3-4 if I remember - well worth it)

title: Nice park
content: Nice Chinese park worse a visit. The surrounding place is super touristy so make sure you are ready to face it. I prefer the late afternoon (3:30) when it is less crowded.

title: Beautiful and peaceful
content: Centrally located, this harden is definitely worth a visit.  It is beautiful and by design peaceful but it can get very crowded!

title: Beautiful garden that looms a bit Japanese too.
content: You can spend an hour or two wandering through these beautiful Gardens. Koi carps, old trees, bonsai, houses, all old and very Nice to look at. We made Some very Nice pictures.

title: A bit touristy but must do
content: I'm not sure what to make of Yu Garden. It's nice and all but it feels like a tourist trap. Way too many scammers and overpriced cheap food and merchants. However it's so interesting to see and walk around. There's a temple and tea house that gets a megaton of crowds visiting and all sorts of small goods market stuff in the area. A must see and well worth at least a visit.

title: Crazy crowded
content: It's worth seeing especially at night, but be prepared for crowds and very aggressive souvenir sales people. They never should have let Starbucks and Dairy Queen go in there. It's a strange juxtaposition when you have antiquity and beauty combined with crass commercialism

title: Aprilo
content:
Place is very nice
Service is ok
Food is the best
The people around is chick and pretty
Little expensive but ok

title: beautiful garden
content: This garden is set right in the middle of a shopping distract. The flora and the architecture of the old buildings is gorgeous. With that said, however, even on grey days (which I believe they all are) it is very crowded.

title: Beautiful ancient Chinese garden
content: Beautiful gardens with some stunning areas. A large site with great photo opportunities. Very nice traditional Chinese buildings and lovely use of water. Lots of people but not over crowded.

title: Pretty Garden, Good Tourist Shopping and Very crowded
content: This is a fun tourist place in Shanghai.  Be prepared for a crowded experience.  The garden was impressive given the time period it was built.  We enjoyed a cup of tea, shopping and local dumplings.

title: Beautiful but crowded
content: The garden itself is beautiful, but very crowded with tourits. Its a must if you want to see old chinese houses and a bit of history. The surrounding area was good lots of food drinks and shopping. The food here is pretty average (from what we experiences) nobody speaks english so we had problems ordering food.

title: Kitch
content: Went in the evening. Anything but peaceful. If Starbucks and souvenirs in faux old building setting is your thing, no harm having a go. Otherwise, avoid. So many other better options elsewhere. Avoid also the main food court.

title: Mixed bag
content: We visited this several times. The gardens and the architecture are beautiful and well worth seeing. The downside is that every time we have been there it is orderly packed with visitors. Most appear to be Chinese. It is almost impossible to enjoy a quiet, tranquil moment in the Gardens. People are everywhere. Chinese have a delightful habit shoving and shouting. Really a strange contrast to the tranquility of the gardens.

title: The surrounding areas
content:
You will have many reviews on Yu Gardens and its dumplings. But I love the surrounding lanes and shops even more. There are many interesting shops, malls and tea shops. 

Go explore!

title: A peaceful garden
content: This garden is so peaceful and set out with lots of separate outdoor rooms that flow on from each other.  A beautiful place to walk around and enjoy the gardens, lakes and ponds and different types of paved courtyards and paths.

title: Too touristy
content: Filled with Chinese tourists and lost its previous charm. Nothing interesting to see or buy. prefer Tianzifang.

title: The most authentic part of Shanghai
content: I wouldn't say I had a fantastic experience considering it was an very rainy day and a Saturday so you mix an extremely packed day with way too many umbrellas it makes you just want to start hitting everyone.

title: Must see
content: Absolute must for couples or photographers. Lots of great photo opps. Very inexpensive day trip (40 yuan per person). I arrived around noon on a Thursday & was pleasantly surprised that the place was not at all packed. Definitely a tourist must see.

title: Quiet and Scenic!!
content: The garden was beautiful. We stayed in shanghai for 2 days and added in our tour plan and it was no ordinary. Also the place is a bit crowded on weekends so plan accordingly.

title: Loved it! Worth the visit.
content: This garden will amaze you with its beautiful features. There are many beautiful flowers, trees, fish ponds, and places to discover around every corner.

title: Beautiful Garden - a Must see
content: This stop should be part of any trip to Shanghai.  This beautiful garden has it's own metro stop, so it's easily accessible and definitely worth your time.

title: Amazing
content:
One of the highlights of our trip...
We were visiting from the US had a few hours in between other activities. We took the subway to the Yuyuan Gardens.... Stunning. Well kept and worth the time to get there. Overall experience was great!

title: Nice to explore
content: A lovely garden in a very busy touristy area. Interesting nooks and crannies to explore, lots of good photo opportunities. Lots of people the day I was there but not overly crowded, there is a fee to get in. If you like gardens this is a good place to visit.

title: Smaller than expected but worth the visit
content: It is definitely a place to visit, it is full of history and ancient tradition so ot is better if you go with a guide. I saw many guide services offered on TripAdv so have a look

title: Beautiful but crowded
content: We made a mistake by visiting during the Chinese New Year since it was too crowded. Though it is quite beautiful and have unique architecture, I would rather suggest investing some time in places like Zhujiaojiao, which allow you to enjoy the walk without getting pushed.

title: Don't go on a weekend!
content: Very beautiful and  a must do but its a jam packed during the weekend so try and do this during the week. Otherwise get there as early as possible to beat the crowds.

title: Visit on week days preferably at morning time
content: If there is small number of visitors, you will enjoy your moments in here specially if you are with your family or friends. Entry fee is 40 RMB. There are about 40 places/houses (connected to each other by Verandah or small corridor) to see in here. You can take some beautiful photo in different location of this garden. Take time in your hand as some people continue their photo session for prolong time in some spectacular areas.

title: Great for an afternoon
content: This is the place to go if you are looking for some Chinese history and architecture.

title: Typical old time place
content: Very touristy and very crowded.Had to see because it was recommended.Nothing great about it.Good for people who would like the old world charm.

title: Classic Beauty
content: Yu Garden is a well preserved Classical Chinese garden architecture of 15th Century. It's built on an area of over two hectares by a wealthy noble of that time, Pan Yunduan, who was then the administration commissioner of Sichuan province. The garden boasts of jade boulders, water bodies, old living areas, and many cultural relics showing classic Chinese architecture and art. The garden also houses an array of exquisite Bonsais.

title: Beauty and Tranquility in the Center of Modern Shanghai
content: The Yuyuan Garden is honestly one of the most beautiful places. It is like one secret garden after another. In fact, it is a maze that was once a person's home. We were lucky because it wasn't crowded and we actually had secret places to ourselves. I would say that it should be the #1 stop in Shanghai.

title: Serenity in the Midst of a Bustling City
content: The Yu Gardens are beautiful; sectioned into different areas for Emperors, Wives, Concubines and Officials. The exhibits of sitting rooms were interesting and the thoughtful placement of natural stone sculpture was fascinating. It was crowded, but no pushing or shoving like you can experience in other crowded areas of China. Notice how dragons are used to decorate the tops of the walls and create boundaries.

title: Tranquility in the city
content: A delightful small garden which surprises at every corner, providing a peaceful oasis in a hectic city

title: A Wonderful Way to understand a famous book
content: If you have read the classic novel 'Dream of Red Mansions', you will better appreciate this garden and the intricacies of the different pavilions and sceneries.

title: A beautiful Chinese garden in Shanghai
content: The area around the garden is very crowded with lots of small shops. There is an entrance fee to be paid. Once you are inside, it is a pleasure to visit this beautiful garden with the lovely pavilions that hold some nice furniture. You discover bridges, arcades, trees, rocks, water ponds etc. Allow for some time to enjoy this garden and to visit the art gallery where it is possible to buy some paintings.

title: Interesting History
content: Our guide informed us that this was once a private garden and then under Mao it was open to the public. It is amazing that this once belonged to one family. We were there is March so there wasn't much in bloom but the gardens and architecture were very impressive. We especially enjoyed the unique figures on the roofs.

title: Quite good
content: The garden is good but nothing special in it. If you like the old tradition, this is the right place to visit

title: Beautiful architecture in the middle of the city!
content: Once you enter Yuyuan (or Jade Garden), you will be soaked by the tranquility pass the buzziness at Old Shanghai Town. This ancient garden, once the habitat of a Sichuan governor is really beautiful and like entering a making of medival Chinese movie/drama. There are many rooms you can explore and full of exquisite rocks and trees, do not miss the Pavilion of Listening to the Billows and also the music recital (at a stage, I think every few hours of the day). Nice place to be with family.

title: Very nice
content:
Visited it during my business trip to Shanghai.
I strongly suggest to visit it to anyone. Also neighbor streets are worth the time I spend there.

title: Last outpost of old Shanghai
content: Rare example of old style Shanghai, interesting Chinese traditional architecture, extremely popular and touristy, but worth enduring the crowds. Go early.

title: Not only the gardens but the surroundings
content: What an incredible place. It's not exactly right at the metro station. Takes a little walking to get there from the station maybe about 3 blocks thru markets. The entire area architecturally is fascinating. You can easily spend half a day here. Plenty of shops and food and of coarse the entry to the gardens the main attraction. Another must go place while in Shanghai. Highly recommended.

title: Yu Garden, never visit on weekend! Too crowded and smelling....
content: I lived in Shanghai 3 years and had visited Yu Garden a couple of times. Well, one visit is enough, not much too see. In fact there are many more gardens similar to Yu Garden in Suzhou and they are actually more beautiful and more worthwhile to see. Never go on Saturday or Sunday, it's packed with local people. It's crowded, noisy with children screaming, smelling especially in the summer due to perspiration, and most local men smell of local cigarette. I just wanted to leave immediately. After the tour, if you want to shop outside this place, DO REMEMBER TO BARGAIN! It's a reap off. At least 30-70% below the price.. And be careful of eating food outside as you can get diarrhea easily, it's not so hygienic and clean.

title: Nice to see
content: A garden built by someone for parents to enjoy... You would not think this is it.. It is huge.. Has quite a bit of history.. Tian zi fang is next to it so see that and then go there would be a good combo

title: So fun, but a little overwhelming
content: I went to Yu Garden to do a little shopping while in Shanghai on business. It was a very fun experience with so many things to see and do and buy! There are so many people there, it can be a little overwhelming. Also, a few cautions... if you are a tourist, you will be approached constantly either by people selling goods or people inviting you to a Tea Ceremony (be very wary as this is a common scam). Once you get used to this, it was actually really fun. I love to shop and walked away with tons of fun souvenirs. The area is made up of really cool Chinese buildings which makes for an interesting change from the skyscrapers of Shanghai.

title: Loved this Garden
content: This is a very tiny compact and crowded garden but despite the crowds and noise I loved it. Little windy paths, some a tad narrow and slippery from years of foot traffic, magic koi ponds, beautiful architecture and plants and quirky designs, loved the dragon trailing his tail along the roof line. Despite all the hubbub it was easy to imagine how serene and quiet the garden could be. If you love gardens and can zone out the pedestrian action you will enjoy this garden, should I visit again I would be there when the gates opened.

title: Rocks and carp
content: Winding paths through rookeries and old Chinese architecture, this place is something of an anomaly in the middle of a bazaar. It gets crowded so probably one to hit early if possible. The carp in the last pond are mega and fight to get to the surface if anyone throws in food.

title: Beautiful - better than expected!
content: We really enjoyed walking through the Yu Gardens. The architecture and beautiful ponds and gardens are well worth visit while in Shanghai. We and a tour guide and would recommend as there is a great deal of history to the gardens and architecture (for instance - why is there a rock pearl in the dragons mouth and a frog under the dragons mouth). The gardens get VERY busy and the walkways narrow so I would recommend going early in the day before all the tour groups. This was the favorite places went to in Shanghai!

title: Ancient China revisited (but so did the Clinton's)
content: You feel like you've gone back centuries and feel the character of an ancient Chinese city. Eat here for sure, Bill and Hillary did.

title: Yu yuan
content: Around is Good old buildings , good for time killing and look around and have some snacks... Can easily spend 2-3 h , inside at the middle there is a palace and must pay and go inside ... Weekend very crowded... Recommended week days but must visit around small sellers and gift shops...

title: Avoid
content: Crushing crowds on holidays and weekends. Bad service at interior restaurants. Not much to see at all. Skip this for the Chenghuang Miao temple around back.

title: Yu gardens - go early, directions to ticket office
content: I read the warnings on the reviews and went early - around 8am. It was still bustling but not jam packed, as others had described. The Yu gardens are worth seeing and tranquil, if not badly maintained (the dirty walls, crumbling facade, and inexplicable signs). There are numerous small displays within the Yu garden itself, with calligraphy and art displays. These were all for sale, and I saw an older American couple get talked into getting some calligraphy prints made. They are certainly very enthusiastic sellers - even within the gardens!

title: Beautiful peaceful garden
content: I would highly recommend seeing this garden. You come off a busy shopping area to a garden that is very tranquil even though there might be a lot of people inside. The gardens are filled with wonderful foliage and small ponds and streams filled with carp. The stones throughout the gardens are amazing. The buildings are filled with antiques.

title: only 'old'historical area left in Shanghai
content:
Historical center of Shanghai, but people must understand that the majoritee of the buildings are new!
Too many shop, if not only shops and very touristic and crowdy

title: In love with this place
content:
If u like to sewing and crafting, u have big market there. Design like old time China and beautiful at night time as well..
Amazing !!! Bargain.

title: Visit if you're in the area but don't make it on your must-visits
content: Entry cost 30RMB pp. It's like one of those old homes/estates own by the rich chinese back in the days. You can say it's the chinese version of a mansion. Worth seeing some of the antiques and how smart chinese use to be. It shows a series of refined craftsmanship that you don't see now days. Best to follow a tour guide and hear them explain if you get the chance as they don't really have displays that tells its histories.

title: Touristy spot but worth going
content: it's a very touristy spot. The architecture and the chinese authentic garden is definitely worth seeing!

title: Zig Zag Bridge
content: There is Zig Zag bridge in the garden. There is tea house in the middle. We couldn't visit the whole garden due to rain.

title: Nice, but too crowdy
content: nice place to visit for the traditional part of the city, but very crowded on a saturday. a lot of shops around, places to eat, everything that you need

title: Peaceful.
content: Beautiful gardens to walk around and enjoy the scenery and  a pretty place.  Length of time spent walking around 1-2 hours.

title: What a beautiful place!
content: I visited this garden with musicians friends in the winter. It is very nice to see it and walk through it. It has different sections divided by walls, bridges, and gardens. When we visited it was winter and the flowers did not bloom, but i can only imagine how beautiful this is in the spring and summer after the flowers had bloomed. The serpent on top of the wall was amazing and difficult to take into one picture. You can see how Chinese rooms were created, the walls, the walkways with diminutive stones forming designs in the floor. The roofs of the buildings, with designs in each corner. Very ornate and beautiful. A really enjoyable walk, just remember, this is a garden that probably flourishes in the spring and summer!

title: Nice on a weekday
content: This place is great to walk and shop. Be wary of going on a weekend however. Crowds can be oppressive and suck the enjoyment away.

title: Dated Tourist trap
content: It is flooded with tourists, busloads and truckoads of them. If you enjoy jostling with the hoards of tourists, you can go ahead.

title: Beautiful , classic and super central
content: So the Gardens themselves as nice, calm , peaceful and pretty. Classic not spectacular and generally nice. Downsides, the entry fee but mostly... number of people. however this is China and there are always lots of people . But it can be quieter than expected , week days, early and at times mid day (when everyones having lunch or in the surrounding markets).

title: Lovely Garden in Old Shaghai
content: It's a bit difficult to find the entrance, but it is definitely worth the search. Beautiful foliage, ponds, gazebos and stonework. Don't forget your camera!

title: Authentic Chinese "gardens"
content: Its more of a rockery than a garden tbh. It has some fantastic architecture and buildings in the gardens. Really old and cool stuff. Its worth a visit, its on those tourist bus routes and you would spend a few hours there. It also has some of the biggest goldfish Ive ever seen.

title: Beautiful
content: The garden itself is lovely, and its sixteenth-century buildings are quite charming.  The five-acre site is relatively small, however, and visiting the garden is less pleasant than it could be because everyone else in Shanghai seems to want to be there too.

title: Astonishing
content: A little bit difficult to find, but it provides a beautiful scenery in the middle of a very crowded city. Definitely worth going there and enjody the walk.

title: Too touristic
content: One of the must sees in Shanghai. However, be aware the it is a bit of a tourist trap though. Better to take a walk in the area with old houses nearby.

title: A haven in the world city
content: This is one of the most famous gardens in China, and as they always are - concerned with trradition and perfection in detail. Go to the old town and visit the old tea house, still standing, where many famous people have sipped a cup of tea - the Queen ov England for example. Just beside the beautiful dam on which it is situated, lies the entrance to the garden. Try to go in bad weather or early in the morning, then you might feel the harmony and peacefulness throughout the whole visit. Follow the mighty dragon wall and enjoy the exquisite taste of the Chinese architects. Admire the several hundred years old ginko tree and wander the paths, the salons and the little bridges over the koi fish slowly swimming or being fed by generous people. This is China at its best.

title: Very Cool place
content: Lots of Stores and places to see here. You can grab something to eat from the local stands and go to the 4th floor to eat and grab a cup of tea. I recommend the tea ceremony where you can try a variety of tea's and the local waitress explains about the traits of each kind

title: Good Fun
content: The gardens were lovely ,very crowded,lots to see,but what we liked best of all were the little stalls outside,with lots of "stuff"to buy for the folks back home but we loved the way everyone wanted to know where you were from and if you liked Shanghai,they all were happy to point out the best place for photos and really loved being in that photo too.

title: Yu Garden visit
content: Ok, not what I expected.  Expected more, went shopping on famous shopping street afterwards.  Typical tourist shops.

title: Busy, busy, busy
content: In order to really enjoy the Yu Gardens you need to be there when they open first thing in the morning, otherwise it is bedlam. The crowds were too much for us and we left after a short time. To get a photo without someone in it was a real achievement. It was just chaos, very claustrophobic as it is quite a confined space. I didn't regret visiting there but just felt it was not a pleasurable experience due to the crowds.

title: Amazing!
content: Nice area, lots of things to see/ had a really pleasant time at the YU Garden Area. There is food/drinks/Starbucks/local foods.

title: Really nice if you love crowds
content: Venue may be interesting if you want to see a more "traditional" part of Shanghai. Very crowded even on a weekday so there is a possibility of getting jostled around when you're making your way from one area to another.

title: Nice garden, but the shopping and food outside is better !!
content: A really nice place, centrally located. And a great example of how an area of historic importance can be presented in such a fashion that the founders would drool over it. Lovely architecture, great shopping and amazing local food which you can munch on while enjoying the sights. The garden is great, better for young children, and is a lovely experience. But if you are short on time, the market outside is an attraction worthy enough

title: A simply amazing and beautiful place
content: This is a very simple but elegant place to rest your mind with the history of calmness. We visited on a rainy day which added to the overall atmosphere. Very very special.

title: A haven
content:
This exquisite garden has so many surprises. Brilliant old China in the middle of brand new Shanghai
April was a perfect time to visit, wonderful blossom. 
An oasis.

title: Garden with a lot of things to see
content:
The garden itself is beautiful. Went there in August, if you want to see flowers should come here in spring time.

There's some old building Chinese architecture. Also some ponds.

If you bring children pls mind them, not to fall into the pond.

title: Must See
content: This was a gem - tranquility in a sea of Chinese hustle. Beautiful and interesting to juxtapose against the Shanghai skyline...the era's of Chinese development are interesting to consider. We spent a couple of hours. Bonus: the shopping around the area was ok also, a little better bargains than in some other areas of town.

title: A must go area !
content: You should visit this area when you are in Shanghai. There will be plenty of people so if you are not one that will like to be in a crowed you might not go. We had a very nice time and got a lot of nice things for almost no money.

title: Amazing place
content: Amazing place to see in the city! Must see in Shanghai! I've visited on a Sunday and it was packed. Better try a week day, maybe Monday. But it's China.. So probably always crowded. But even is one of the best points in Shanghai!

title: Great taste of China in modern Shanghai
content: Wish we had more time before catching our flight to Tokyo, but this garden was a wonderful introduction to traditional Chinese architecture. It is hard to find traditional China in modern Shanghai but this fit the bill for our two day Shanghai layover trip.

title: A tranquil gem within a busy area of Shanghai
content: We visited the Yu Garden when having a tour around the markets area of Shanghai just next to here. To go from the busy and hectic markets to this fairly quiet and peaceful area was a lovely change of scenery and pace. The size of the gardens was very appropriate for a busy day, as you could see everything within an hour or two, but take your time if you wanted to absorb the area a little better. If you're in the area then the Yu Garden is certainly a must see (especially for the amazing dragon wall!).

title: Nicely done urban oasis
content: Classic Chinese garden hidden away behind a screen of tourist shops and hawkers. It's one time I liked the fact you had to pay to get in,otherwise the chaos outside the walls would be all over the garden itself. I would recommend reading about the history and design before hand if you're not going with a guide

title: A classical garden
content: The garden is a classic in the middle of the old part of Shanghai so it is very convenient to visit as there are many other interesting places to see nearby. The garden itself is typical, but no less interesting for that. Some of the stonework depicting dragons on the tops of the walls is very impressive. Our visit was on a grey wet day in one of the coldest winters for 60 years, but it was still quite possible to appreciate the garden. I would imagine it would be stunning when the flowers are out and it was a bright day. Not to be missed.

title: Interesting Oasis
content: It's pretty amazing that a hidden gem like this exists amount a major city! The gardens and peaceful area full of greenery, rockers, ponds full of fish swimming around and of course ancient history. It is a must see when here. There is plenty of food outlets present here. Would recommend to visit if in the area.

title: Must see at Shaghai
content: Enjoyable site with real history which date back to years ahead ! The only issue is the crowd is beyond imagination due to Chinese mass tourism policy you are pushed around !but the tea shops sell good tea ! Enjoyed

title: A must-see attraction in Shanghai!
content: Amazed at this extensive famous classical garden of 2 hectares offering charming and pleasant views with noble flora (though plants needs more maintenance and watering), exotic rocks of all sizes, fish ponds with gold fishes (fish ponds also need constant maintenance) and several halls and nice buildings of interest.

title: Great place
content: We visited the place during Chinese New Year in Feb. It was well decorated with many lanterns and characters for Year of Monkey. There are many shops, snack place, tea house and restaurants. The location is close to subway and in the heart of Shanghai. Great tourist attraction!

title: A little oasis in the town
content: Shanghai offered many options to go sightseeing, but as we exhibited on a trade show and only had one week in Shanghai, we relied on the recommendations of my local customers. The admission to Yuyuan is quite cheap compared to the beautiful and calm area that is offered by this location. Wonderful traditional buildings, construction and landscaping.

title: We got lost!
content: Very beautiful garden.  Not a lot of signage or anything,  but a nice place to roam.  It is so big and there are no exit signs that I saw. We seriously spent 10 minutes actively trying to get out.

title: Arenson
content: Crystal Cruise arranged excursion. Fabulous guide great experience highly recommend for anyone visiting Shanghai. A must see!

title: Limited Tourist Exhibit
content: Perhaps we are spoilt with our Botanical Garden areas. Even though it was Autumn the Garden Area was more a Rockery area with various sculptured symbols. We were pushed along by our guide and covered the area in 20 minutes. There were no garden areas to walk through & enjoy perhaps at the back of the area however our guide was not interested in doing this. For Tourists wanting to see an extensive garden area this spot will not satisfy. We felt let down

title: A taste of the past
content: A taste of the past within a very modern city. A pleasent way to spend an afternoon. Our visit was guided but this would not be necessary to enjoy the gardens.

title: Beautiful
content: Very beautiful garden,one of the most interesting places in Shanghai,and one of my favorite,but is too crowded unfortunately

title: Peace and quite in the centre of Shanghai
content: Nice and seemed to be fairly quiet.  Felt relaxing in the hustle and bustle of central Shanghai.  Good value too.

title: A neat Shanghai feature
content: This is an interesting aesthetic experience, with a combination of seemingly old structures nestled in amongst artificial rock walls and hills. It creates a bit of a maze-like effect, allowing you to get lost in there for an hour or two while you explore the different spaces.

title: Well worth the money
content: Upon entering the garden I was thinking for myself "I wonder if this will be worth the 40 yuan it costs or if it will be as packed as the streets outside".

title: Wonderful walled garden
content: The Yu Garden really is a must see on a visit to Shanghai. The walled garden dates from the Ming Dynasty era in the 1550s and is located next to the old town shopping bazaar also worth a visit. The garden is a delightful mixture of pools, caverns, pavilions, flowering plants, nooks and crannies that seem to go on for ever. We spent a delightful hour or so here mid to late morning. Apparently it gets really busy weekends and in the afternoons, so plan your visit accordingly.

title: Great to learn of the history.
content: We had an English speaking guide who took us around the garden which was very interesting. She explained all of the history to us including the different shaped doorways and the significance of the dragons. Without the guide it would have been disappointing.

title: Artificial, crowded, yawn
content: It's a pretty garden, but there's no real history here. Yes, the replica is down well, and yes, great photos and relaxing to stroll around. But it gets awfully crowded, especially on weekends. I recommend a weekday visit. If you're a history lover though, I don't recommend coming here as it's very commercial. There are plenty of other places that deserve your attention.

title: Yu Garden is a must see in Shanghai
content: Beautiful area with some nice examples of Chinese architecture and attention to detail as well as the beliefs that guide many Chinese. The story behind the gardens and the house are interesting.

title: Busy but worth seeing
content:
The crowd was quite well behaved and the garden and tea pavilions all very classical.
Large ponds for fish and turtles.

title: Traditional buildings in a peaceful park
content: This place appears to be hidden away just off the busy streets of Shanghai. There is a charge for entrance but this was paid for by my colleague so I have no idea of cost.

title: Hard to find
content: It took us a while to find the real Yu Garden, being hidden in a small street behind all the shops and traditional buildings.

title: Yuyuan Garden
content:
It was nice but if you want to go there please don't choose chines holidays.
And also you have to take good guide tour for explain all stories of there I like my guide his name is chiris thank you

title: Beautiful but crowded
content: This area should be the old part of Shanghai, which you still can see from the beautiful houses. Weekends are too crowded though and recommend everyone to visit this place in the afternoon.

title: The second visit which I like more
content: Crowded as usual even I was visit on Thursday which is not holiday. This is the second visit , so I can enjoy more for details of the garden. My first visit was last year and so rush .. So I was only hurry to take a photo.

title: Lovely and serene
content: Beautiful gardens, old buildings, bridges and ponds in the middle of the bustle of Shanghai. Its surrounded by a maze of tiny streets, with fascinating shops (clearly catering to tourists, but still), and tons of street food. I loved walking here and losing myself in the streets early in the morning, and also later in the day when the crowds came in.

title: Wonderful Traditional Chinese Gaden
content: Designed in the 16th Century for an official in the Ming Dynesty this garden is a peaceful, gracious place in Old Town. So beautiful with magnificent rocks, ponds, pavilions, zig zag bridges and trees along with the residences of the original owner. You feel that you have gone back in time to hundreds of years ago in old China. A real respite in a busy city just steps from the hustle of the markets of Old Town.

user_loc: 德克萨斯州北里奇兰希尔斯
title: Nice peaceful gardens in the middle of shopping.
content: If you have a guide you will learn about the history and the symbolism of the gardens, ponds, rocks, and bridges. Be sure to bring your camera... look for the buddhist symbol for "eternity," you'll recognize it, the nazi's used in WWII.

title: Serenity and Elegance
content: The Yu Garden are magnificent. Travel through time as you discover the wonders of this traditional garden with ponds, passageways and rock gardens.

title: Better than another mall but that's about it, "old city" style shops gardens are ponds with carp
content: The actual garden is a semi restored feudalist residence surrounded by rock gardens, poorly maintained and somewhat redundant. Tickets are now 40 yen ($6.40 US). It is a break from the crowds. The old architecture blocks around the city are filled with shops selling trinkets and street food to Chinese tourists. If you have been to other "old China" sites, that's anything before 1959, you don't need to go.

title: Beautiful garden in heart of a busy city
content: This is a beautiful quite large garden area in the heart of a modern busy city. It has wonderful bridges, ponds and buildings from another time. Worth a visit!

title: Peaceful setting in the middle of the city
content: Very beautiful gardens created for the use of one emperor. Rock formations, ponds, flowers and interesting architecture. Next to "China Town" the old city with shops and food.

title: A change for the kids to hang out in
content: A change of scenery from the concrete jungle surrounding Shanghai. Worth to spend an hour or two to just sit back and enjoy the green.

title: Full of ancient culture, high desnity of beauty and inside a building sells affordable local art
content: Definitely one of the top five places to visit in Shanghai. Also consider supporting local artists by buying amazing and affordable local Chinese painting from the top Shanghai artists. Prices range from $20-a few hundred dollars.

title: Too Crowded, Not Preety Enough for the Crowd
content: IMHO visiting Yu Garden is not worth suffering the crowd. It's waaay less preety than The Humble Administrator's Garden in SuZhou. It looks dirtier and less well maintained than HAG.

title: Great for shopping souvenirs
content: Yuyuan Garden is a small park in the bustling city of Shanghai. The garden is in the middle of the old Chinese buildings where lots of souvenir shops are located. I bought cheap shawls here. There are also lots of food stalls where one can try Chinese street food. I tried some like squid and fish balls and these tasted good. However, when going there, be early to avoid the crowd.

title: Very easy to miss
content: Very nice to look at, would be nicer without thousands of people around!

title: Shopping at very low cost!
content: Need locals or friends living there to bring you around. Besides the garden and xiao long bao, which are fairly ordinary, the buildings actually house many wholesalers. 1001 things to purchase to decorate your home or for daily use at very low cost.

user_loc: 加利福尼亚雷东多海滩
title: Peace and grace in the middle of one of the largest cities.!
content: Tradition.  Peaceful haven.  Lovely grounds.  Incredible range of plants, flowers, trees.  You will not want to leave.

title: Stunning gardens
content: Saw the gardens as part of a tour, would definitely recommend a guided tour as you would miss so much without one. Everywhere you look there are spectacular dragons and beautiful peaceful scenes which is remarkable considering how busy it was.

title: A Delightful Garden in the city
content: The garden is almost hidden because of the market that surrounds it.  Go early and avoid the crowds.  A garden should have some peace!

title: Delightfull
content: Great that it has been preserved amongst all of the development. Likewise the Old Town just around the corner, which whilst now very 'touristy) is a good complement.

title: Crowded but fun
content: Gardens are nice but really crowded. Going past the market and people watching is half the fun! Pick up some fish food and feed the goldfish. There are tonnes of them inside Yu Garden. They are huge and hungry and go crazy if you give them fish food.

title: Cultural Tour
content: Shanghai is a very modern bustling city like many others but if you take some time to visit the Yu Garden it will take you back in time to appreciate the ancient Chinese culture a bit more on your visit as you walk through this ancient garden and learn about its rich history. I spent a couple of days at the Renaissance Yu Gardens which is a very nice 4 star hotel and just blocks away from the garden.

title: Beautiful
content: This is definately a must do while in Shanghai!

title: Very nice garden!
content: Very unexpected great visit! Beautiful garden within the old city! Will take you a couple of hours or more, discovering all little passages carved in the stone through out these garden. Kind of a peaceful oasis in the chaos of the old city! For $ 7 dollars you can't go wrong!

title: Beautiful gardens
content: This was an unexpected gem. A small garden in the midst of a noisy bazaar area. The rocks and gardens were unusual and beautiful. Worth the visit.

title: Transport to a Different Time and Place
content: Yuyuan Garden is one of the better, if not the best, tourist attractions in Shanghai. It is one of the few places in Shanghai that actually feels like "old" China, if that makes sense (i.e., the rest of Shanghai feels like almost any other big city). It'd lose to other gardens in Suzhou, but for Shanghai, they are spectacular.

title: Interesting place, even if somewhat odd
content: Went on a Sunday and there were people sitting all along the wall lining the walkway with open umbrellas with printouts attached. It seemed odd, there were many people walking around reading the printouts at each. Found out later it was parents trying to match make their children. The pond area was nice with children and adults catching minnows with small nets. While there we sat down for a rest and were immediately approached on either side by gentlemen that just struck up conversations with my friend and me. Talked politics, everything, that's where I found out about the umbrellas. Talking with my friend later I was informed they were practicing their English. It was good conversation and not at all threatening. As I said it was an interesting place to visit.

title: Beautiful rock garden to hand out for a day
content: I visited this garden with my family. Very well maintained and designed garden with ancient design and furniture.

title: WOW !!!
content:
Refreshing walk in midst of market place.  Garden is very well maintained with lush greenary giving a pleasant peace to mind.  

Even enjoyed the surrounding market area.  Definately a must visit in Shanghai.

title: Beautiful and tranquil.
content: This is a beautiful and tranquil spot in the middle of a vibrant city. Walking through the old Yu streets and getting in was very nice.

title: A open air museum of old china houses and garden
content: I'm not super impressed with this garden. Dont expect a botanical or green garden. This is more of an open air museum of old Chinese houses and their gardens. Yes, its pretty nice to walk around and get a feeling of the old China. The stone structures and walls are really nice and together with the old houses its a nice place.

user_loc: 澳大利亚大墨尔本地区
title: Yu Garden great
content: Wonderful history beautifully presented. It was extremely busy with tourists from many countries but it all flowed easily

user_loc: 弗吉尼亚弗吉尼亚海滩
title: Sophie Lee from China Highlights gave us a great tour!
content: Our tour started with the TV station then we went to the bund and ended in old Shanghai with the Yu Garden. All places were beautiful and are recommended if you want to see different aspects of Shanghai. There are plenty of shops and trinkets and food vendors in the area if you need a minute to take a seat and have a Starbucks coffee or local tea.

title: Tranquility in a bustling city
content: The garden is very peaceful area with trees, rockeries, ponds and ancient buildings. It is also a bit of a maze as you can follow a path then branches 2 or 3 different ways.

title: The old city of Shanghai, beautifully preserved.
content: There is a garden, which used to be a ministers residential area. Outside that is the old city. Now it is more of a tourist attraction. Very nice heritage tour a day highly recommended.

title: Great oasis
content:
What an incredible oasis in the midst of a bustling metropolis.  Quaint and bursting with tradition, colors of the koi fish, the dragon atop the encircling wall is complete with scales and his many heads stretch out to greet or frighten the visitors.

Wonderful.

title: Yu Garden a nice place for touris
content: Yu Garden is a very nice place for visit. However, there are too many people and hard to take any picture

title: Magical setting
content: A must visit when you travel to Shanghai. A typical Asian garden with historical value. The area is very close to the tourist traditional market so you can go shopping, eating too.

title: Nice garden if you love people
content: Interesting place but perhaps visit in a weekday. On Sunday when we went the crowd was so thick you had to shuffle through the area. The tranquility of the garden was a little lost in the chaos.

title: Beautiful Gardens
content: Yu Garden is a beautiful compound. It's is definitely worth the price of admission, be sure to take your camera as there are a ton of pretty vantage points to photograph.

title: Nice quiet place in the middle of a hectic market
content: Nice and would recommend to travelers looking to get some peace in a hectic setting. That said - it did smell quite a bit in certain areas.

title: Wonderful gardens!
content: Beautiful part of Shanghai with loads of characteristics. Such a pity that gets crowded but one can still feel the peace and admire the beauty and the history of the gardens. Most certainly a must for the visitor. If you are a senior person don't forget to ask for the discount (50%). This applies in fact to lots of entrance fees to various places including the MRT tickets (It is under Concession ticket) if you buy it from the ticket vending machine.

title: Nice Area
content: This is a nice area to visit in the heart of Shanghai.  Lots of souvenir shopping opportunities around, as usual.  There is some nice architecture to see.

title: A maze of gardens
content: Huge shopping area to wind through just to get to the entrance but worth getting there. Pretty gardens but no signage to lead you, so pretty much left to wander around. Several areas of crafts on display all of which are available in the main market. We had the great fortune of visiting on a special sale day with huge discounts

title: Oasis in the City
content: Simply a quiet break from the nearby shopping and dining area. Feel the serenity of the plants and water garden while getting a feel of old Chinese tradition and artistry. A famous must see destination in Shanghai.

title: Food and Shopping Paradise .
content: This place signifies Chinese tradition , Culture and Food . Very Nice experience . The place is very lively in the evening . Get the map from your hotel . lots of shopping places ; bargain too .

title: A secret garden
content: The yu garden reveals itself, one vignette at a time, through little arches and tunnels. It draws you in deeper and deeper into quiet pools of carp, draping willows, and quaint pavilions, tranquil and somehow insulated from the maddening throngs that you encounter just outside, I am truly amazed how large this garden actually feels.

title: Peaceful and rich culture .. must see
content: I was staying at Renaissance Yu Garden, so it was very convenient to walk less than 5 minutes to enjoy the beautiful Yu Garden. Not expensive (RMB40), this attraction is good to relax and appreciate the culture of Shanghai, from Ming Dynasty, probably from more than 00 years ago. And also you can enjoy the great neighborhood with many local stores, buy souvenirs, have a coffee and eat something different. I wish I had more time to explore the area, but stayed few hours but strongly recommend the visit.

title: Hidden gem of history
content: The only problem with this place are tourists. Overcrowded with foreigners and locals who are noisy, so can't find your piece there. However, strongly recommended to visit and admire to amazing garden, tress and architecture.

title: An oasis, but...
content: The Yu garden is a beautiful garden well worth a visit, but unfortunately like all other attractions in central Shanghai usually extremely crowded. Try to visit the garden in the morning of a normal working day before the crowds occupy it.

title: Tourist place, but worht a visit
content: The "gardens" are mostly traditional buildings (refurbished) but includes rockeries and ponds with plenty of goldfish (I like goldfish). Around the gardens are various tourist shops, McDonald's and Starbucks, but also street food and souvenirs. If you are holidaying in Shanghai, this is one of the places you should see.

title: Lots of People
content:
A must see for a tourist in Shanghai. 

Lots of tourists and the shopping is hectic. 

Garden is such a contrast from the hectic commercialism of this area. 
Important to spend time understand the significance of the gardens. 

Chinese tea afterwards was lovely.

title: Authentic
content: I really enjoyed our tour of this attraction. There's a bit of information in the brochure and a few interpretive signs around. It's beautifully preserved.

title: Must see attraction in Shanghai
content: I never get tired of visiting the exquisite Yu Graden in the city. It has a wonderful combination of history and culture, foods covering a wide range, and shopping too. The gardens themselves take on a truly different meaning if you take a guided tour - which we did for the first time in this our third visit. Learned do much that we'd missed the first two times.

title: Very interesting
content: Been to Shanghai only for 2 days. Yu garden was really Nice to visit and the market around perfect for gift shopping! Remember to negociate everything!

title: A favorite
content: One of my favorite stops in Shanghai. Lots to do, surrounded by loads of activities and filled with tourists and yet at any given moment you can find yourself alone in a grotto or building and somehow feel at peace in the garden's beautiful setting. Don't be afraid to venture a little further afield, it's a great part of town.

title: A photo opportunity around every corner
content: Very tranquill gardens with a viewpoint round each corner. It wasn't very busy and workmen were repairing parts of the garden. We enjoyed looking at the bonsai trees.

title: Great and Peaceful Place To visit.
content:
Loved this place in Shanghai. 
It is surrunded by great shopping and once you are inside the garden it feels like you are in a totally different and peaceful place

title: Beautiful Gardens and Buildings
content: Peaceful and some amazing trees and plants. The water flows gently and it is a calm oasis in the middle of a bustling city area.

title: Calm waters
content: When entering the garden area from the madness of the bund you get the feeling of moving into a quieter space.

title: Nice to see some history and green in the modern Shanghai
content: I have been to Yu garden many times, I like this place and area due to the historical buildings, trees, flowers, its mood, you can have a nice little walk. Of course it is better in good, sunny weather. Please note the place close at 16:30!

title: Symbol of generosity
content: Yu garden rapresents the symbol of Chinese generosity: it belonged to a rich and noble man, but he decided to donate it to the society.

title: A massive tourist trap and run down gardens
content: I would not be rushing here. In order to get into the gardens you have to go through this totally inauthentic touristy 'historic' mall pumping with shops and people trying to sell you things. The gardens themselves were crowded and run down. Wish we hadn't have gone

title: Not best gardens but interesting
content: The gardens are accessed via the old town shopping area packed with tourists and tat. Entry is 30rmb. The garden is fairly typical, lots of rocks, lakes and relatively little planting. Numerous chambers are linked by winding paths and bridges. Its actually a bit dark and claustrophobic, and you need to dodge the numerous selfie sticks!

title: Very touristy with many gift inspirations
content: It's a Chinatown inside a Chinatown- if you see what I mean.

title: Spectacular
content: Beautiful pictures at every stop with historic pagoda houses,fish ponds, plant placements and rock formations.

title: A magical insight into Old Shanghai
content: A peaceful beautiful spot to spend a few hours of calm in busy Shanghai.  Gardens are magnificent anytime of the year. Very cheap admittance fee and after a old around the very busy tourist shops and some great restaurants.

title: Tacky but worth strolling through
content: Lots of tourist stores, lots of people.  Good dumplings.  If you need souvenirs, go here, lots of choices in a pleasant milieu, when not crowded.

title: Quite nice, Chinese style ;)
content:
It's a nice place . You can see small temples , Chinese style gardens.. Also the houses that are around there , there are also nice .
You find few souvenirs shops too ..

If you go to Shanghai pass by this garden

title: Good but not what exactly expected!
content: The Yu Garden, ahh what to say, its a nice place, worth visiting, but I think it has a certain time of the year to visit, in March its still early, no flowers anywhere, so unless you are interested in rocks, dont go before full spring time.

title: Very traditional spot!
content: A classic Chinese garden, very beautiful but crowded. It closes early so do not leave it as a late afternoon activity.

title: Beautiful and fascinating
content: Crowded during our Sunday visit, but not overwhelming.  Beautifully created rock formations, with small buildings meant for relaxation and meditation.   Loved the dragons "guarding" the roof lines, as well as the juxtaposition of old Shanghai with the new.

title: Perfect place for an early morning stroll.
content: The Yu Garden (Yuyuan) is a beautiful, serene, and history-filled space situated in a very busy part of Shanghai. It is a wonderful place to spend 1-2 hours strolling and taking in the pretty landscapes, but I do recommend visiting early in the morning as it fills it quickly with tourists by early afternoon. I arrived between 9 and 10 am and only felt crowded toward the end of my visit. It's easy to miss as it's situated behind the very busy Yu Bazaar, but be sure to check the signs around the bazaar to find an entrance. It's worth looking for and the entry fee is only about $5 USD!

title: A must
content: Great place to visit. Sometimes very crowded, but if you are lucky to hit a less crowded time, it is relaxing to be in the lovely gardens.

title: Gem in the midlle of shanghai
content: It was not my first visit but evetytime i wander on beauty of that place....its a hidden gem frozen back in time ...its a need to visit when in Shanghai...

title: Very nice place in a busy city
content: This is a great garden to visit, and it's refreshing in a busy city. However, there may be tons of people in there with you, and that kills the enjoyment. If you can, ask the locals when is the "down time" so you can actually enjoy the serenity the garden is meant to provide. They should really put a limit on how many people can be in there at once. Once I went and it was literally a zoo.

title: 5 acres of restful beauty!
content: This is an intricate historical garden and buildings which were built originally around 600 years ago. You can easily spend 2 hours walking, viewing the rock formations and koi ponds, and enjoying the beautiful architecture.  This is another Shanghai must see!!

title: Rustic Antiquity at the City Center
content: A beautiful, crowded place to visit. The garden itself is lovely, with old Gingko trees, shrines and fascinating rock formations. Just outside the garden is a souvenir and snack area, with authentic stalls selling shanghainese food, including extra large soupy buns with straws for slurping!

title: Beautiful garden in the touristic area of Shanghai
content: I visited the garden on a Sunday morning. There were not a lot of people visiting at that time. So you really could walk the garden and enjoy the sights. The garden is bigger than expected. Beautiful houses and small temples (which can also be entered). Also with art displays inside. Watch out for the tourist trap when leaving the garden!

title: Impressive and tranquil gardens and amazing architecture
content: given the fact that this Garden was once a private residence It is amazing. Very calmimng place in a crowded City.

title: Peace and quiet
content: Went on a Tuesday morning and we were one of a few people in there. By the time we had finished the garden, the bazaar outside was gearing up for a busy day..... What's with that blaring music in the bazaar tho.?!!

title: Beautiful.. But extremely busy!
content: We visited on a Monday morning and still had to push through the crowds! The gardens themselves you have to pay for and aren't as busy (although still very busy!) as the bazaar around it which was packed. Do not visit here on the weekend I can only imagine how horribly busy it would be... However even with the crowds it was still beautiful and I'm so happy I visited here. It also had a taoist temple, which was so peaceful (always needed in shanghai!). You have to haggle to buy anything, not my forte however there were a few in my group of friends that absolutely loved the 'to and fro'.

title: Very nice in the middle of the city
content: Very nice atmosphere and nice surroundings. Very authentic and just nice to get away from the too busy city.

title: Worth a Look
content: This place is worth look around for some traditional sites in a very cosmopolitan city. The shops and food on offer are also good!

title: Quirky and interesting attraction
content: Yu garden is possibly of interest to history lovers as well as nature lovers because the gardens have a number of towers and halls which have period furniture from various times of Chinese history. It is more of a walking tour and while it is a garden, it is quite different from the usual gardens which are more green and focused on plants. Nonetheless, it is worth visiting.

title: Stunning
content:
Stunning gardens In Shanghai
Close to old town which is also worth visit
Blossom and magnolia trees look good in the spring

title: Nice little gem
content: We visited this place on a guided tour and greatly enjoyed the place. There is a great sense of history attached to the place and it has been preserved very well. Must visit.

title: Lovely!
content: Great visit, one of our favourite places in Shanghai. So beautiful, peaceful and typically Chinese. An oasis far from the hustle and bustle of the Old Town streets. A must see!

title: Ancient Architeture
content: It was a nice experience looking into the ancient architecture but compared to places like Suzhou, its a far cry. If yo do not have time to travel out of Shanghai, this may be a good place to start for a brief experience into ancient buildings.

title: Worth a trip, if you can find it!
content: We walked along Fuyou Rd, looking for the entrance, and ended up following the building around to the Shanghai temple of the town God (which is also worth a look), and eventually ended up in the large shopping plaza that is to the west of the gardens.

title: Beautiful gardens
content: Wow, this garden winds around and around. It's easy to get lost. Between the rock sculptures, the flowing water with koi, and the historic architecture, you will be amazed at every turn. This is a beautiful area within the city.

title: Beautiful Chinese garden
content: Don't miss, but get there early. We arrived at 9.00 and within an hour the crowds were so big that it was hard to enjoy the peace and tranquility that are the main characteristics of this beautiful place

title: A place to feel old Chinese atmosphere, 充滿中國味道的地方
content: 雖然入園要人民幣30元，但是園內古典優雅。這次去還有春梅盛開，各種不同的梅花妝點著古色古香的園林，很值得在裡面散步。請務必待久一點，好好體會中國園林風味！

title: Yu Garden well worth the visit
content: Beautiful views and well maintained.  Spend 1 hour or several hours and take in the garden.  A must see if you are in Shanghai.  Just outside the garden enjoy the multiple food vendors and shops then walk over to the Bund.

title: Interesting History and Gardens Near the Bund Shanghai
content: Squeezed into space ringed by commercial shops near the Bund in Shanghai, the historic Yu Gardens are worth a visit. Currently 30 RMB to enter, the space is filled with artificial rock walls, pavillions of beautiful wood furniture and chandeliers and interesting trees and vistas.
