There is a subway stop just steps away from this garden and it is announced on the subway and written in English. Easy to find.tons of shops outside to get a meal and shopping galore. We enjoyed our visit

title: Boring
content: Visited this garden,quite extensive,but generally very grey and a bit shabby,if you want to pass some time then go but have we en far better gardens in Sydney and Hong kong

user_loc: 新西兰奥克兰中心地区
title: old china
content: a must see place.

user_loc: 加利福尼亚亨廷顿海滩
title: Avoid at weekends
content: Beautiful garden.Well worth a visit. Surrounding area with traditional buildings and shops very popular and worth to see but much too busy to visit during weekends or public holidays.

title: Crowded, Commercialized, but Must-Do
content: Starbucks, Dairy Queen, and McDonalds? All present. Shoulder-to-shoulder people? Yes, that as well. But don't let that keep you from paying a visit to these beautiful gardens. One of the perks of the commercialization of this place is that it's impeccably maintained. The architecture is classic and the ponds are stocked with fish and ducks. There are also some great local foods to sample while you're there.

title: A garden oasis...
content: Beautiful gardens in the old part of Shanghai, very peaceful and relaxing. Yuyuan old street with its bustling touristy shops is also nearby.

title: Breathtaking design
content: This is to my point of view the only must thing to do in Shanghai other than walking the Bund.  Incredible attention to detail

title: Stunning Chinese Garden
content: Visiting this gorgeous garden is like taking a course in Feng Shui. Lots of rocks, water, shrubs, flowers and trees assembled in perfect balance. Beautiful and peaceful. Don't miss.

title: Old Shanghai -like popular TV drama
content: This is such a tourist and local favourite hot spot. All the buildings is like from the last century with beautiful gardens, secluded from the outside world. Very peaceful and calming place. A bit unusual to have McDonald in such such a place, but that's commercialisation for you.

title: Very beautiful and peaceful
content:
Shanghai it's a big and busy city it's great to past a moment in a quiet place important we went there on a Monday afternoon in the low season in November
But even I the busy season it's a most !

title: Magical city garden
content: For a visitor to the city who does not speak Chinese, it was a little off the beaten path to find. But a super friendly volunteer with limited English made sure that we stopped into the garden. It was amazing. It's just a cute magical garden in the middle of the city. There are historical buildings, beautiful plants, and just a lot of very traditional sights to see. It is well worth the money and the time and is perhaps the highlight of my trip to Shanghai.

title: Oriental beauty in the heart of the city
content: A good way to spend the afternoon even if you travel alone like I did.

title: Too many people
content: Yu garden area is nice, specially old houses. This is one of must popular turist place in Shanghai so there have many peoples.Indide in park you have more space to walk without any watch seller

title: Lovely ancient garden
content: Located in Old Shanghai, this is a beautiful garden with meandering paths, water features, reflections rooms, decent restrooms.  It is by a fun area with kitschy tourist things to buy and snack food for sale (and Starbucks). Be prepared for lots of people though.

title: Great 1-2 hr stroll if you avoid the crowds
content: The gardens are lots of little set piece areas each slightly different with their own charm. A common theme of water and fish gives the place an air of tranquility an escape from rest of Shanghai hustle and bustle. I expect you need to go when not busy otherwise the charm of the place could be drowned in selfie sticks. Weekday mornings outside peak season worked great for us.

title: Beautiful at night, but touristy
content: If you want to feel transported back in time, the Yu Yuan Gardens are your ticket. Lovely old architecture, but unfortunately filled to the brim with touristy trinket shops. Go early if you want to see inside the historic garden area, go late if you want to see the place lit up at night.

title: An oasis of peace and quiet
content: This is a true gem of a treasure and we were not disappointed with our visit.

title: Very peaceful garden to visit
content: This is a must see in Shanghai, it is surrounded by a bustling area where it is perfect to get street food. The peaceful beautiful gardens and buildings are brilliant to explore. Sometimes the little bridges can get a little busy particularly when some silly people block the path photographing the fish.

title: Crowded
content: I visited the garden during the weekend and it was super crowded. Though it was worth the waiting to see this beautiful garden in Shanghai. Really convenient to reach the garden by subway but quite hard to find the entrance since signalization is very bad. Many people try to sell things at very high prices so don't forget to discuss about the prices, even in the official shops in the gardens.

title: Too busy so enjoyment of the garden was compromised
content: This could have been better. Just so many people taking selfie photographs that the tranquility has gone. I think maybe an early visit is the best bet. Shuffling over the bridge with throngs of others did not really live up to my expectations and we did see more tranquil gardens near Chengdu. The garden also felt over-restored and not wholly authentic. I am, however, glad it has survived (so much in China has not) and it does give an accurate representation of the layout and requirements of a Chinese garden. It is not a zen garden.

title: Anthony Bourdain.....
content: This was a good place to meander after a long-haul flight on a Monday night. We arrived on an early evening flight and wanted to adjust by not going to sleep too soon. Going on a weeknight also meant fewer crowds too. Our hotel was just steps away, so it was easy to return a few more times over the course of a 7-night stay in Shanghai. Returning on the weekend found it bloated of tourists and very long queue to a xiaolongbao dumpling joint that Anthony Bourdain did a segment on for his "Parts Unknown" Shanghai venture. This is also a good place for picking up treats and trinkets to bring back to work colleagues.

title: Beautiful & Historical!
content: The Yu Garden is beautiful! I highly recommend exploring the grounds during your visit to Shanghai. The gardens and buildings are immaculate and historical. Be aware that the area surrounding the garden is a touristy open air shopping plaza with many people trying to scam you. Now they are trying to get people to take a 'free' elevator to the top of a building to experience beautiful city views. This is merely an attempt to lure you into a tea room and extort money from you. Do not fall for it!

title: Nice Garden
content: The garden itself is beautiful. Lots of trees, ponds and trails to enjoy. The surrounding area of shops and restaurants is a very popular as well.

title: Loved it
content: So cute - a little greenery in a big city is appreciated. It was zen and busy at the same time. Definitely a must see!

title: Tranquil garden in hectic shopping market
content: Best of both worlds. Survive the hectic market and shops selling tourist gifts for travelers desperate to take something Chinese back to their homeland. Then experience the relative tranquility of a traditional Chinese garden, fish ponds and jade gardens with no hassle. Well worth it.

title: Spectacular
content: What a gorgeous garden! The gardens are just spectacular, the number of carp fish amazing and the atmosphere sublime. Don't miss trying the steamed buns either. Great place to spend a morning + lunch.

title: Yuyuan Garden
content: The garden is divided into six areas, including halls, gardens, rockeries and ponds. Walking through the area is very peaceful and relaxing.

title: The prettiest of the gardens
content: This was the best garden we saw and as the others were beautiful words cannot describe this.  Four hundred years old plus with four hundred day old building behind it.  A big contrast.  Again Chinese design at it's best.

title: A haven of peace and tranquillity.
content: We got here early and were waiting when it opened at 8:30am. It was intriguing from the start, walking over a zig-zag bridge designed to keep evil spirits out. Chinese evil spirits are strange. It seems they have to travel in straight lines, and can't jump.

title: busy but fun
content: this is not correct photo this area is for shopping for Holiday gifts and is very busy with local people and avoid at chinese holidays go over the road to the flea market for some good cheep gifts and bargain with local people

title: Quick gifts
content: I made a quick visit here to get gifts for family. Great spot to make fast purchases with all kind of Nic nacs and souvenirs for tourists. Some places you can bargain others are fixed price which is nice. Watch out for taxis on the way out. They will ask for triple priced fares with no metre running.

title: An Oasis in the City
content: This is an oasis in the city and a calm, meditative place to gather thoughts and reflect. It begs photographs as it is so grows so beautifully and in keeping with the surroundings. It is a restful place to revive you when sight seeing, walking or shopping.

user_loc: 阿根廷布宜诺斯艾利斯
title: Very nice to see a different part of Shanghai
content: Old buildings, lots of stores to see thing we usually dont see, numerous options of food,  it gets a little crowded on weekends, try to go on a week day

title: Labyrinthic! Worth a visit
content: Beautifully designed Chinese Garden. If you visit only one Chinese Garden, make it be this one! Compared to the surrounding Old Town area this place is somewhat quieter (because there is an entrance fee of 40RMB to pay).

title: Quiet Getaway in Ancient Surroundings
content: For a bit of history and quiet retreat, the Yu Gardens are well worth a visit. Give yourself at least two hours for a leisurely stroll thru' the various gardens. It is well maintained with pavilions, water features landscapes and plants, some being over 100 yr. old. Don't forget your camera. It gives you a feel of being a Eunuch in the Imperial household. The negative is the crowd and insufficient English translations,

title: Simply Beautiful
content: My favourite place in Shanghai. The buildings and artefacts are spectacular.The actual gardens are lovely with the biggest gold fish i have seen. The artwork is beautiful. depending on which gate you come out it is surrounded with different markets on three side, The antique market is my favourite. some genuine antiques some hot off the press. The clothing market side is like everywhere else in Shanghai and the souvenir side is just plain expensive avoid that side

title: Excellent!! Impressive olden days building..
content:
This is a good choice for first time traveler to Shanghai as can see olden days buildings.
Can easily find souvenirs here and lots of food stalls.

title: Amazing
content: Great garden, really nice and tidy, amazing scenery and plantlife. You can easily spend couple of hours here!

title: A cultural must - when in Shanghai.
content: This place is an absolute delight - from crafty exhibits to food to cultural scenery. The well known dumpling shop - u'ii find it has a continuous 100 people in the purchase que. At, i think $3 for one dozen steamed dumplings - you have to. I was told they make 10,000 daily!!!! All taxi drivers know this area "Yu Huayuan" - tell him.

title: Must try the Dumpling
content: It was pricey but decided to try it anyway. It looks like a huge dumpling when served but the container is elevated at the bottom so it's gone after about one gulp. Taste wise is average and over rated. But I guess that doesn't stop the queues that form. Do not expect friendly service as you won't get it here. It's order, pay, food delivered and bye.

title: nice classical garden and shopping for local stuffs
content: the area is very commercial but still, it is very convenient to get souvenirs. good place to taste the shanghai area type of food too. if u r short on time, yu garden makes up for yr miss of those classical gardens in suzhou. then u can spend more time on the water villages.

title: Worth the time and visit
content: This was a very lovely garden in the middle of Shanghai. As you wander through the garden, you get a great perspective of the peacefulness and harmony which the Chinese people attempt to live their lives. I wish we had more places like this in the US. Also a nice, quite, place away from the hustle and bustle of the surrounding rea.

title: Chinese gardens are gorgeous!
content: Another stunning Chinese garden - in the heart of Shanghai. The rocks, water features, plants, all melded together to create this tranquil garden are beautiful. A real credit to the creators of such a stunning site. I love gardens, and this is a beautiful place to stroll around and enjoy the peace.

title: Holiday
content: Historic garden where family use to live for peace. Highlight for me is Dragon on the wall whose length and ending you cannot find. Out side is very very lively shopping street with souvenir toys garments shops. Very good eateries specially a dim sum(dumpling) shop which you cant miss as you will find long queue.

title: Fantastic place!
content: One of my most favourite places in China, not only in Shanghai. Beautifully done, a garden within a garden, al those small secret places to explore, such a serenity. If it is a quiet day with less people, i could spend there a whole day and never get tired or bored of it. Beauty and serenity.

title: Nice park which gives an idea about old china
content:
Peaceful place in a loud and busy city. Ideal to relax a bit and come down.

It gives you an idea how China must have looked like 150 years ago.

Entrance fee was 40 rmb which is still ok

title: Awesome garden tucked away in suburbia
content: I stumbled upon this although I was recommended to go there. For 40RMB - it was well worth it. Lots of beautiful trees as you wind around this wonderful garden. A definite must when in Shanghai

title: Not just a gorgeous garden but great shopping!
content: This garden is lovely and very authentic in spite of the tourists from all over. And it is not just this garden - this is great shopping for jewelry, clothes, and just all those little trinkets and gifts to bring home!

title: Very tourist but worth a visit
content: It's a very touristic place but if it's your first time in China then is a must see. Outside the garden you will get crazy with how commercial it is. They will try to sell you fake bags, food etc

title: Beautiful Little Oasis
content: The Yu Garden is located in the middle of a pedestrian mall area. The gardens consist of buildings, water and numerous trees and plants. Feng Shui at it's best.

title: Beautiful Gardens Next to Shopping & Famous Restaurant
content: Our group got dropped off here to enjoy the beautiful gardens, take in some shopping and deals and then end the day with great Shanghai cuisine in the LuBoLang Restaurant. The gardens have lots of water features which was perfect on the overcast drizzly day we were there.

title: Yu need this place!
content: Aside from a restroom stall, there are few places you can go to find serenity among a city of 24 million people. Yu Garden is one of them.

title: Peace and Tranquility...Almost
content: Well worth a visit as its a bit of a haven in the city, even though there's loads of people it still has that feeling of peace and tranquility. Interesting history behind it as well and lots of nooks and crannies to explore. We had a tour guide to take us round, which I would recommend or else you could easily miss some of it.

title: lots of tourists but plenty to see
content: we were staying close to this area and visited for shops and sadly (as typically british) for a starbucks and cake. There are lots of shops and generally you have to haggle to buy anything. Prices come down to 25% to 50% of the original start.

title: a must go
content: there are two parts on the Yugarden, the free one with all the shops and the food vendors (be careful on the Stinky Tofu smell...hahaha) and the "ancient" city. I guess it has been built according to what it might have looked like but it worth to visit.

title: Beautiful garden!
content: Definitely take time to wander thru Yuyuan Garden.  Visit the tea house, sea the school of hungry carp practically crawling on top of each other to get food.

title: lots of local food
content: you should be there for a visit in shanghai. there is a lot of nice local food, nice traditional buildings and lots of stuff to buy from there.

title: Amazing architecture
content: A must see when visiting Shanghai! Really beautiful place offering all kinds of food, drinks and desserts! So many shops so there is something for everyone!

title: Extremely busy but worth it
content: Beautiful gardens full of buildings, water areas (huge fish jumping out of the water to be fed) plants, trees, sculptures, walkways. Extremely busy on the day we went (and apparently that wasn't a busy day!!) but well worth a visit. Just stroll, sit and enjoy the atmosphere along the way because once you come out you cannot go back in again on the same ticket

title: Peace and relax in the center of Shanghai
content: Very very peaceful place, where you can take a breath and relax from the big noisy city. It shows the authentic way of life of old chinese people, The place may be too crowded sometimes, but anyway it is worth visiting.

title: Wonderful setting
content: The gardens are well designed and very interesting. There are lots of pools with fish (Koi) and turtles as well as interesting architectural features. The small figurines on the roofs as well as the dragon features on the walls are very impressive. There was a free exhibition of gifts given to the last empress of the Qing dynasty when we were there, which was an added bonus

title: Too crowded
content:
The place is amazing but I don't know if because was Sunday or this is every day but was too crowded to appreciate in detail. 
Everything happens on the streets. The food, the shopping and the shows. 
The place place is energetic.

title: Beautiful gardens
content: Beautiful tranquil gardens in the centre of Shanghai. Does get quite busy during the day as I foundn best to go first thing when it opens. Definitely a must see!

title: The only authentic Chinese place in Shanghai
content: If you are tired of high rises and department stores (a million of them in Shanghai) and you are wondering where is China, go to the yu yoon, bypass all the fake new old looking buildings full of tchotchkes and go to the ACTUAL garden in the middle of the tourist traps. Amazing calm will immediately surround you. Be one with it, sit in front of one of the ponds and let your troubles melt.

title: Don't Miss the Details!
content: We toured Yu Garden with a guide and it was fascinating. Every shape, movement, decoration, placement, animal, etc. has a deep meaning that originates in ancient Chinese culture. We would have missed it all if we hadn't toured the garden with a guide. I suspect most do miss the real Yu Garden!

title: Busy but worth the visit!
content:
Beautiful gardens and traditional buildings, found in the middel of this crazy busy city.
Yes it's a tourist hot spot and can get quite busy (especially in the square just outside of the gardens), but it's very much worth it.

title: Old and relaxing
content: Worth a visit for the old buildings and trees. A good place for photos. Many shops surrounding this attraction. Easy to walk around yourself but a guide would be useful to explain things. Next time I would get a guide to show me around to get a better der standing of this accent place

title: Chill out atmosphere
content: Historical place inside the nature. You enter and time stops. Relaxing atmosphere with lakes and flowers. Ancient temples

title: Nice among the busy city
content: I like this traditional garden, was so interesting to see the place where Royal family were relaxing before, the structure of the complex was really impression...they have also many souvenir shop inside...it's nice indeed

title: Fantastic
content: One can not imagine this place in the center of the busy Shanghai city, loved the cultural touch to the place. The Yu garden has an entery ticket and trust me you would not regret paying for it. Fantastic old time Chinese tea houses, nice ponds, zig zag bridges and very peaceful and scenic views. The markets around the garden are beautiful, interesting sights around and some good bargains as well. Th garden has an entry fee of around 40 RMB. Easiest local transport Yuyuan Garden Metro/Subway station on Line 10

title: Not Modern Shanghai
content: Shanghai's hustle and bustle can be rather overwhelming for the tourist at times (and sometimes even the local). Enormous crowds, packed wall-to-wall in small subway cars or along narrow busy streets, sometimes with a layer of haze that comes with a cough, the Yu Gardens are a lovely contrast to this. Directly north of the City God temple, the Yu Temple is a remnant of pre-modern China that is becoming rarer and rarer as the Shanghai Sprawl expands more and more.

title: The hotel is reinnovating
content: The hotel is located in Xintiandi area which is a famous tourist place. It is also located next to the metro so you can easily travel around the city by the metro (line7). The minus point is that it is under construction. Therefore, you cannot feel all of its beautiful.

title: "The" place to shop in Shanghai.
content: Near the centre on the Bund.  Atmosphere that a westerner would expect from China.  Great architecture, lots and lots of stores of various kinds.  Merchants who love to haggle.  Pit yourself against them.  You will have fun and you might even get a bargain!

title: Too many organised tourist parties!
content: Very nice and interesting place, but honestly there were just too many tourist parties being led around but tour guides.

title: Very pretty
content: Gardens are not set out in the European or Western way .It was interesting the water ,rocks and pavilions make up the garden but it is  still beautiful.

title: The last Emperor and Empress Cixi
content: What a beautiful garden. One is left with a sense of wonder. Dowager Cixi was the last of the Qing dynasty before the Republic was formed. She certainly lived well. Once can almost imagine what life was like especially those who have seen the Hollywood movie " The last Emperor". Yu Gardens where Cixi often lived is an unmissable experience.

title: Oasis in a sea of turmoil
content: A lovely quiet area to stroll around.  A guide is really useful as there is a lot of history here.  There's also a group that place traditional music in the central courtyard area.

title: A glimpse of a traditional Chinese garden
content: Despite the throngs of tourists shuffling their way along the paths and over the little stone bridges, the Yu Gardens do offer a glimpse into a traditional Chinese garden with rockeries, pools and pagodas. In its time it must have indeed been an oasis of serenity and calm compared to the bustling city beyond its walls. To some extent it still is, the intensively renovated and commercial old city surrounding it being noisy and even more packed. It's definitely worth a visit but it takes a leap of imagination to picture it in more tranquil times. Perhaps if one went just as it opened...?

title: A nce garden that is less appealing due to the touriist shops and aggressive freelance sales people
content: I was first taken to Yu Garden and prepped that it is a very, very - did I mention very famous and sacred place for the Chinese peoples history. Though it does have beautiful aspects they are all quite diminished by the ever aggressive sales people peddling 'Watches & Bags" - fake ones, at that.

title: Journey back into the history
content: Went on a Saturday, despite being used to crowd, this was new to me. Too many people but then this is China for you anyways.

title: Has become long in the tooth
content: It's not that expensive but frankly speaking it's not worth the money. We were expeting something more authentic...

title: Interesting Garden
content: A pleasant little oasis in downtown Shanghai,well worth a few minutes to soak up the atmosphere.Great to kery

title: Beautiful
content: Definitely worth seeing. Beautiful gardens with old style buildings, surrounded by the old street area, giving a feel of old Shanghai.

title: Very nice
content: Great rockery...is surely worth a visit ..seems like a maze .....lots of photo ops....take one hour for it

title: Nothing spectacular, but nice to visit when in the area
content: Small chinese garden in the middle of the crowded 'Shanghai old street Yu yuan area'. Although at some times crowded itself it is a resingt point from the crowded 'tourist' area and a nice example of what can be done on a small area.Nothing spectacular , but nice and worthwhile visiting when in the area.

title: Great to visit
content: I really enjoyed Yu Garden. Very pretty architecture with interesting spaces to wander through. Interesting to enter through the temple and then exit through the bazaar. Interesting place to visit!

title: Peace and tranquility in Shanghai
content: It was lovely and peaceful to walk through the beautifully kept Yu gardens. Another highlight was watching the children feed the fish in the same way that we would feed the ducks here in the UK. There are plenty of shops outside the gardens selling food and souvenirs too.

title: A magic atmosphere
content: I visited the Yu Garden today with my colleagues. Very nice place, a must for foreign people coming to Shanghai for business or pleasure.

title: A must in Shanghai
content: Ignore the "mall" atmosphere and head strait to the garden. The historical buildings and gardens are beautiful and best portray old China while the adjoining shops are nice to visit but too new,

title: Nice, but Better An Hour Away
content: Nice gardens in the middle of Shanghai if you are unable to travel out of the city. Humble Administrator's Garden in Suzhou and water town of Tongli are much more impressive and not as busy. But if you are limited to Shanghai, then this is a stop not to be missed. In the midst of old Shanghai where there are all sorts of shops and storefront restaurants.

title: Beautiful garden and quiet place
content: Worth a visit to see a quiet, beautiful space near China town. Trees and rocks are lovely. Good to sit and rest on a hot day. Fish feeding area just outside is excellent for children.

title: Ultimate tourist trap shopping mecca
content: The place to get all of your cheap, cheaply made souvenirs. It is billed as a place to see traditional buildings and gardens, which it is not.  Go to shop and eat.  Do not go expecting to see anything interesting.

title: Beautiful Place
content: It took me a while to realized that Yu Garden was inside Old Town. I always though the Old Town was called Yu Garden and I was wrong.

title: A must-see magical monument to the past
content: Beautiful and tranquil. At night, I have never see anything so beautiful. You can shop, eat or just relax. You here to see it to believe it.

title: Dissapointing
content: Well, if you have nothing else to do it's good for killing time, but completely without the charm of something old and original.

title: One visit is all you need
content: You see one and you see it all. This is not my first Chinese garden. It is worth a visit and try out the food. The xiao long pao is popular with a long line up. I enjoyed trying out the food more than the sightseeing.

title: Hope you aren't closterphobic
content: Can't say too much about a 600y/o? Garden. I can somewhat see what it might have looked like way back then (as a private garden) however that is no longer the case. This is probably due to no apparent pop cap on the amount of ppl in the garden at one time. As such, we could barely move around inside...and the smell(shudder) prob good on a rainy day, but if you see a big crowd, I'd advise you to wait till another time.

title: Beautiful traditional Chinese Gardens
content: This Garden was very enjoyable.  Several different areas and nice for a relaxing hour. Had several different areas with some familiar plantings and several unfamiliar.  Some bonsai which we had thought were first done byJapanese but  Chinese claim they did first.

title: Ancient garden in the old city of Shanghai
content: Well worth visiting and easy to access. These gardens date back hundreds of years. There is an entry fee but cheap. Great place for photographers!

title: garden in the midst of the city
content: nice classical garden in the midst of the city. You can slowly walk around and enjoy the flowers and the layout of the garden, with some classical pavilions,

title: Beautiful, but very crowded on a Saturday
content: Picturesque scenery and great backgrounds for photos. History leading to creation of Garden is interesting if you have a guide with you explaining it and significance of the layout and design. Feed the fish and was amazed by their size.

title: An oasis of tranquility
content: A must see, especially in the morning before the crowds.  Interesting architecture as well as the gardens.

title: Very Beautiful Gardens
content: Being a UNESCO World Heritage Site says it all.  Fantastic gardens.   Very nice casual walk allows you to quietly absorb all of the beauty.  The work trim work is special.

title: Lovely
content: Great spot for pictures but huge crowds everywhere. Lots of paths, and easy to get lost. Ca. Sit and have tea or a drink.

title: Go there!
content: Despite the many visitors, locals and foreigners, the garden still manages to feel tranquil and is well worth a visit. Plenty of shopping opportunities exist outside the gardens too, if that is of interest!

title: Makes you feel peaceful
content: This historic and unique garden feels visitors peaceful. Picturesque views inside old town are great. A must see location in Shanghai. Easy to reach by underground.

title: Way too crowded
content: By the time we made it to Yu Garden, we'd already seen a few others, so perhaps we were a bit jaded, but the crowds chased us away. We were there maybe 30-45 minutes.

title: Around every corner something different
content: Great place to wonder around, around every corner something different with surprises. Very interesting.

title: Beautiful gardens, old world charm but overcrowded
content: A must see in downtown Shanghai especially for the gardens itself and it is recommended to visit it with a good tour guide who can explain the history of the gardens in detail and every aspect of it. This is a 2 in one place meaning you enter first and there is the shopping outlets and then a eating area like our regular food court and a beautiful garden setting which eventually leads to the actual gardens that were created through the Ming Dynasty. The space features the following things to see within the gardens: Sansui Hall, Yangshan Hall, Huge Rockery,Yule Pavilion

title: Classic Chinatown in Shanghai
content: Yu Garden is worth the visit especially with a tour guide who knows the history and can explain details, our group was joined by others who felt listening to Christy explain the aspects in detail, we didn't mind because the guide was quite knowledgeable her explanations were appreciated by all.

title: Beautiful!
content: A beautiful and amazingly peaceful oasis in crowded and chaotic Old Town. The Starbucks here has a special mug for Yu Garden for those who collect them.

title: Lovely Garden Worth Fighting the Crowds for
content: This garden is absolutely lovely. However to reach it you have to go through huge crowds and long narrow shopping areas. It is worth it. Take a tour guide the guide can help you cut through the crowds to see the garden and all the enchanting places. Surprisingly there are a much less people in the park than outside. There is also a small fee.

title: Beatiful Garden with their longstanding trees and stones
content: A must to see while visiting Shanghai . A garden full of trees and the Gingko was one of our favorites , due to the male and female trees.

title: Classic chinese garden
content:
The garden itself is very nice. Classic chinese garden that still keeps the traditional heritage.
However before entering the garden, the path is full with many shops, food stalls, and a bit dirty and smelly.

title: Nice garden in a tourist area
content: Yu garden is located in a turist area with the typical restaurants, food stalls you would expect in such a area. There are also countless souvenir shops which sell all the crap you`ll never need. The garden itself is nice and gives you a good impression of Chinse horticulture in past and present.

user_loc: 文莱达鲁萨兰斯里巴加湾
title: A must visit
content: A must visit when you are in Shanghai. Lots of shopping around and a good eatery places. There are worshipping Buddha place to see and garden was okay. A historical place to visit in Shanghai

title: Went on a bit
content: To start with I was quite enjoying the visit. The story behind the garden is interesting. But it's quite big and after a while you do get a bit fed up with yet another pavilion and another tree Tec.

title: Zen in the City
content: Great place to take a walk and escape the chaos of the city. It can get crowded, but remains quiet (until you exit into the bazaar. Find a nice spot to sit and really enjoy the beauty around the garden. Stunning architecture in a relatively small space designed to appear much larger.

title: Important
content: Shanghai is not only shopping and night life. It is also history. The Yu garden shows just this other side of the city. Very interesting and medidative.

user_loc: 文莱达鲁萨兰斯里巴加湾
title: Small taste of old China
content: Great garden with well preserved buildings. Several quiet areas on the grounds where you can relax in pease and enjoy the souroundings. Come earlier in the morning and you will miss the crowds that come after 12:00. Don't forget to buy some fish food before you go in to feed the go,d fish.

title: This is awesome
content: Not to be missed if you happen to be in Shanghai, Amazing Chinese locale quite extensive with lots of tourists.

title: Too many people
content: Yu Garden would be a perfect place to stroll and look at the old Chinese architecture and garden if you could walk around there alone. There are hordes of tourists unfortunately. But you have to go there anyway. It´s a nice garden with old Chinese houses and some small museums. I liked it a lot.

title: Yu Garden
content: The garden is OK. We have seen much better gardens, but it is nice to do a quick visit. Surrounded this area, are plenty of shops and eating places, so make the trip more interesting. It is a pain trying to flag down a taxi from here. You just need to be aggressive in order to get a taxi, or you will wait forever!

title: Beautiful oasis away from the craziness of the Yuyuan Bazaar
content: SCAM! Just a warning first, when I arrived at Yuyuan Garden station, I was subjected to a tea ceremony scam by the entrance gate of this China town area. A young Chinese couple asked me to take their photo and introduced themselves as fellow tourists from another region of China. They spoke fluent English and were so friendly. These things should have been red flags. They informed me they were off to see a performance. Then they said I could join them. I followed them down an excalator to a shopping center and into a tiny room with a small table on which a Chinese speaking woman was preparing teas for the ceremony. In the end they tried to charge me the equivalent of about 500 RMB (about $80 for the ceremony as well as the extortionate price for a tin of tea. They got quite angry and aggressive in their approach. I finally left insisting I would only pay $25. That could have ended so much worse! Can't believe I was scammed like that! Beware these are pros!

title: A Pleasant Walk Around These Gardens!
content: Despite the large groups circulating these gardens, it was very enjoyable walking through and admiring the beautiful greenery and interesting design of the buildings.

title: Tourist Garden
content: Visited on a sunday, has a festive / carnival like feel though there wasnt any street performances. Very crowded especially during lunch hour, you could hardly walk. If you are there to eat brunch would be good like 10to11am.

title: A Very Busy Place but worth going to
content: Go during the week, weekends are worse on amount of people there.....this is a great place to see historic buildings, etc....there's lots of shops also to do some great shopping at reasonable prices for gifts to take back home.

title: Yuyuan Garden
content: The Yu or Yuyuan Garden is a maze of Classical Chinese rockery, ponds, fish, trees, and pagodas. Lots of touristy shops and traditional Chinese shops in the area. A little disappointing as it was not as large an area as we expected, so it was crowded and very touristy. Beautiful to see, though.

title: Interesting and pretty gardens!
content: Although the gardens and courtyards were really pretty, there are so many people. The surrounding area around the gardens can get so crowded! A lot of Chinese tourists. You can get really good dumplings and walk around. Make sure your purse is zipped up and in the front of you because there are a lot of pick-pockets. Also, you can go in a nice tea house, but make sure its a legitimate one.

title: Qing Dynasty Park Turned to Mega Ancient Mall
content: Love this place a good place for tourists to shop and enjoy the old atmosphere of China. You can enjoy the Yu Garden and later on shop for local goods. There is a popular dumpling shop. Try to avoid it during lunch as ti gets really crowded.

title: Busy!
content: I have been to this location a couple of times once in the week and once on the weekend. Both times it was extremely busy to the point that the beauty of the garden was hard to appreciate. Worth a visit you if you don't have time to go the countryside or visit other traditional gardens in China. Find a quite corner and get of the main path. There are plenty of smaller quieter paths if you look around.

title: Peaceful Getaway
content: Great garden to relax and unwind outside of the streets of Shanghai! A nice set of history to it as well. Would recommend

title: Back in history
content: This was one of my favorite places we visited.  The gardens are beautiful and very quiet.  We found a man in the gift shop that painted using only his nail, go by at visit him and his artwork.

title: toooo crowded
content: Maybe is a must see if you visit Shanghai but i guess is really not necessary to go there. Tooooo crowded, tooooo loud, tooooo many small shops and tooooo expensive. The only special thing are the nice buildings.

title: historical and interesting!!
content:
historical and a " a much needed way to see Shanghai's past"! 
We had a guide who explained the significance of the entire complex.  Recommend it!

title: Interesting garden in the midst of shanghai
content: If you want to see a classic Chinese garden in shanghai then this is the place to go. It's like a huge koi pond. peaceful place to take a stroll. Entrance fee is 30CNY per head. Entrance is near the zig zag bridge.

title: lovely garden with fish
content: Lovely place with ponds, obviously crowded but, what do yo spect? It's China!!

title: Gorgeous buildings ruined by dense crowds
content: Beautiful buildings and gardens impossible to appreciate because of dense throngs of people. Should have gone at 8:30 a.m. as recommended by Rough Guide

title: Taste of local cuisine and lifestyle
content: Be prepared for crowds and lineups as you experience local cuisine and lifestyle.  Well worth the time.

title: Get your souvenir list here ticked
content: It might be a bit to touristic but you can really get your souvenir shopping list here done. T-shirt, stamps, cups, etc. can be found and bought there. Of course bargaining is a must at some shops where there's no price tag: be hard. Snack stops are everywhere and also some cultural things can be seen.

title: If you Iike shopping this is the place
content: A huge variety of shopping for every type of gift you could ask for

title: Lovely- but not the national trust
content: These gardens are lovely and very Chinese. They are full of Chinese "rooms" and little nooks and crannies. Don't forget to look for the dragon on the walls and admire the exotic and lovely stones.Look up and you can see some of the tallest skyscrapers in the world but if you don't look up, you'd never know. These gardens are a wonderful escape from the bustle of the Yu Gardens Bazaar. However, do not expect perfect maintenance- they look a little neglected and suffer from being subject to a huge footfall- though the "little rooms" mean you don't see the crowds en masse.

title: Good for pics
content: Came her with my sister who lives in China. It was very busy due to some holiday. Too crowded so wasn't able to take as many pics as a would have liked. The area surrounding the garden is full,of shops and restaurants so good area to visit.

title: A real commercialized place
content: The supposedly famous xiaolongbao (pork bun) in Nanxiang Restaurant is not good, not even close those from Dingtaifeng in Taiwan or Jade in Hong Kong.

title: Great place to relax
content: A huge traditional garden which is very well maintained. Hundreds of local and foreign visitors come here every day, especially during summer and autumn.

title: just average..
content: this is becoming more commercial place now.. nothing much, if for photo shooting that is good, but if u would want to learn the Chinese history, that is not the right place.

title: Over crowded yet beautiful
content: Please avoid kids with strollers... the crowd grows to such proportions that you'll regret having one! Else, a great blend of modernity with traditional Chinese architecture and culture in a relatively large area full of local street food and hawkers peddling the latest fake goods. The garden itself needs a paid admission and is quite serene and tranquil in the middle of the city... but if you have seen one, you've seen them all! Don't miss the opportunity to get some pictures taken with traditional costumes and accoutrements. And do not follow the pimps and hawkers... you never know what you'll end up with!

title: Beautiful Garden in the middle of the the city
content: Not to be missed! A stroll through the Yu Yuan garden is beautiful and peaceful despite the crowds of people. Outside of the garden are numerous shops and restaurants in architectually stunning builldings. A few blocks away is an antique market street worth the walk.

title: Lovely walk as long as you go early. Be there when they open but especially on weekends. Nice spots to take pictures as
content: Take Uber but choose where to be picked and dropped carefully. It can be difficult to meet the driver in a crowded place.

title: Yu Gardens
content: Beautiful peaceful place and lovely to see all age groups participating in Tai Chi. Great atmosphere and a real sense of mindfulness and calm

title: Nice
content: A bit expensive and crowded but nice to have a walk in a classic garden inside the city walls. Nice in good weather

title: Cosy area in the downtown of Shanghai
content: If you want a break from all honking cars this is a good spot. However - it's usually quite busy with people so be prepared for that. Heaps of stores and fast food restaurants close to the garden itself.

title: An island of tradition and greenery in Shanghai center
content: Amazing combination of traditional Chinese mansion and characterful park with skyscrapers to be seen above that. Surely an experience you shouldn't miss, strongly enhancing the concept that the foundations of now a days super power lay in the past.

user_loc: 阿根廷布宜诺斯艾利斯省
title: The tea room at the Yu Garden
content: The Yu Garden dated back to 1560 is the No 1 most interesting ,historical sight in Shanghai and in the midst of it there is a quaint wooden tea house which is a little known MUST to visit. You are seated in hundreds of years setting and offered a variety of 100 teas served in the traditional style. A mini jewel of the old Shanghai .

title: Green and quiet part of the city center
content: If you have enough of noise of the shanghai streets, the yu yan garden is the right place to relax. You can simply sit in one of many garden buildings or watch the golden fishes in water.

title: Always very crowd
content: No matter whenever you visit Yu garden, always many many people there. You can buy some Chinese traditional stuffs there, but better to bargain a lot. Let's say if they said 100, you better ask for 30-50. At least half price.

title: Loved the band, full of people like me though....
content: It was ok I would say. Touristy and not a patch on the Heavenly and Summer Palaces of Beijing.

title: Very Crowded
content: Such a nice garden to visit but you shouldn't expect to have some chilled out time here. It's full of tourists just like you. Planning for early morning might be a better choice.

title: A little "calm" in shanghai
content: This gem is not to be missed. Step out of the 100 year old market into this large, beautiful, expansive classical garden. Keep wandering around until you find the dragon.

title: Danger, Danger, Danger
content: One of the main tourist meccas in Shanghai. Go see it, Bargain hard with the shop/street vendors. Do not be thrown off by their "anger" at you being so cheap! There is someone else 20 feet away selling the same item. Biggest danger is local people being nice. It is a trap!! Never,Never,Never go with anyone to a tea house under any situation. It is a trap! Can be very expensive. Bottom line, just do not do it. You are missing nothing!

title: Tourist Area
content: This is a really busy, tourist area. Western food brand offerings along with 'street food' food courts. Neat to see the bridge, although it will be crowded. Food eaten here was terrible and expensive compared with other 'street' food in Shanghai.

title: Fun, but avoid if you hate crowds.
content: Yuyuan Gardens are in the centre of old Shanghai right in the middle of an "old" bazaar. In fact the bazaar is a modern made to look old tourist trap with all the usual scams and tat, but is a holiday complete without that? It depends on your outlook. The gardens themselves are classic Chinese with some beautiful stones and buildings. You are led from "room" to "room" through gateways in walls and along outdoor corridors, the stuff secret gardens are made of. Those who have experienced the Summer Palace in Beijing may be disappointed by the size of the garden, but I thought it was a little pearl.

user_loc: 德克萨斯州圣安东尼奥市
title: Nice Place to visit but very crowded
content: It was too crowded to enjoy.  Much history but too cramped to enjoy the beauty of the garden.  If you enjoy history you will enjoy this site.

title: All days busy local 'shopping street'
content: Beside taking picture on some building and gardens, you may experience a fresh and delicious dumping after a long hour waiting /Queuing

title: Amazing park in the middle of the city
content: We visited the Yu Gardens on the Chinese National holiday. Outside around the garden there is a big shopping area built in old Chinese style. It was packed with thousands of people.. However as we entersd the gardens it was not so crowded and we could enjoy the beutiful place.

title: Beautiful gardens in the centre of old Shanghai
content: Well worth the low admission price. Gets you away from the crowded streets. Great historic buildings, tranquil ponds, good exhibitions. We did the tea ceremony which was really worth it.

title: Nicer than Expected
content: Not a Suzhou level but an Oasis in this bustling city, worth the trip if you have time and need a break

title: Beautiful Gardens surrounded by Shopping and Restaurants!
content: A must see in Shanghai, a whole district of gardens, stalls and restaurants! Really a special place to visit in cosmopolitan like Shanghai!!

title: Lovely place to visit
content: These very nice gardens are a peaceful oasis in Shanghai and even include the Willow Pattern bridge.

title: Serene and Peaceful
content: I must do in Shanghai. The gardens are a perfect relief to the hustle and bustle outside the walls. The gardens and pavilions are gorgeous and perfect examples of Ming dynasty architecture

title: Definitly a must while in Shanghai
content: Definitely suggest going first thing in the morning, this is a huge tourist attraction and gets more crowded as the day goes on. It is super close to the metro as well. The streets leading up to the Garden also have some nice shops on them as well. The tourist area has lots of food and souvenir shops, and a starbucks. The bridge over the water is nice but hard to get a picture with so many people. You must pay to get into the actual garden and it is well worth it. I think a lot of people miss this as it was so peaceful while we walked around the garden. The only negative was no map...you never knew where you were going, if you were in a dead end or even how to get out of there. Once in the garden there are koi fish you can hand feed, peaceful areas to sit, great architecture and many photo opportunities. Do find the small Chinese tea room and sit down while they go about their selling speech. It was nice to sit down and relax with a variety of teas. This is a must see!

title: nice architectures, a bit crowded
content: very crowded site, our guide mentioned that it was tourist peak time. very nice architectures. my colleague is a great fan of that.

title: The oldest attraction in the City
content: Interesting architecture and nice surroundings. The National holiday made walking very inconvenient to say politely.

title: Beautiful garden
content: Beautiful garden, with an interesting history in the midst of Shanghai. The garden itself is restful and serene, although generally crowded. Best time to visit is early, and with a guide if possible to learn the history of the structures and the garden itself.

title: Authentic Garden
content: Chinese gardens are very different from the gardens North Americans are used to in that there aren't flowers but rather the most unusual rock formations and of course water. Our guide referred to the rock formations as "grotesque"; I think he meant very different. The garden contains may beautiful Chinese pavillions, bridges and lots and lots of people! Even though it was crowded it was still a pleasant escape from the towering skyscrapers of Shanghai. The market surrounding the gardens are hectic, over-priced but somehow captivating.

title: Beautiful garden in the center of old Shanghai
content: Beautiful gardens and authentic old Shanghai buildings.  Can be very crowded during holiday weeks.  Worth visiting!

title: only a few centuries old
content: This is the best place I visited here in Shanghai. It's an easy walk from the Bund. It's a huge many hundred year old garden. Very beautifully laid out. Very Chinese. A refreshing change from the Starbucks and all the other western influenced cityscape. It's also surrounded by a market that is, again, very Chinese. The merchandise for sale is crap but the ambiance is fun and the buildings attractive. Just watch that a drone doesn't hit you in the head!

title: I'd love to return
content: If you can get used to the fact that gardens in China do not mean lots of flowers but crowds of people you are part way to enjoying this garden. There are tremendous rocks, placed to decorate and to stimulate. They decorate the gardens as they have since the 1500s, and they stimulate the viewer's brain to see the weird and wonderful that nature can create. it's a lot easier than some of the gardens, and is not expensive to visit. I'd love to return and see some more of it.

title: one of the rare green spots of Shanghai
content: A little green garden inmidst Shanghai City, good for relaxation, with a few nice things to see. Inside there is some old furniture, in the garden there is a little lake with a walk passage, a few statues (lion, dragon) and some large stonge collections.

title: Lots of fun shops
content: If you do not mind the people this is a great place to buy gifts and souvenirs. Please keep in mind to bargain. They want you to bargain. Do try to get something for nothing but you can get some great stuff for very inexpensive prices. Also some fun places to eat. Just look for quality restaurants.

title: Beautiful landscaping
content: This garden took 18 years to build (according to the local guide) and has the largest Currow stone in China (3,5 m). The garden is VERY beautiful and if you choose to visit on the week-end (like I did) very crowded. It's definitely worth visiting for the beautiful landscaping and the contrast it makes against the surrounding tall, modern buildings.

title: A Glimpse of Old Shanghai
content: Lots of local food that is delicious and affordable, nice view and one of the best place for shopping

title: China... years ago
content:
More than Yu garden,  the bazar and local stand up food worth to see.
The atmosphere of yu buildings kinda attracts you more than the garden itself.

title: Nice.
content: Tea House! very nice. A lot of shopping in the area. Also a show in the garden. Many restaurants to choose from.

title: In a word, fascinating!
content: So much packed into such a small area....the thought of having it to oneself instead of sharing with half the world can only be a pipe dream, I know, but very occasionally even among the hordes you can get a glimpse of what it must have been like originally. Peace & serenity.

title: Not exceptionnal but may be worth seeing if you have time
content: The place is becoming way too commercial ad it spoils the "ancient looking" impression which is a real pity. Everything looks a bit fabricated even if some areas are still worth looking. The whole impression is really mixed.

title: Beautiful gardens, lots to see, can be crowded
content: I went here on a weekend after visiting Hangzhou with some work colleagues. I have been here before, but every time you see more beautiful things around every corner. The weather on the day I visited was somewhat cloudy and hazy, but in the middle of the afternoon, the skies opened up enough to allow some sun to fall on the gardens. It made the views even more spectacular. It's a great oasis in the middle of the busy city, and a good escape from the hordes of tourists enjoying the tourist shopping just outside the gardens.

title: lovely peace full and historic park
content: One of the best well maintained historic place in the city of shanghai.A must visit many attractions are on walking distance from yu park like city of gods temple and old street.Best time to visit is evening very peaceful and lovely environment.

title: Must see
content: Beautifull place to visit and walk around. The old town is a nice combination of old architecture and modern shops and food. The park is great it makes you feel like you are back in time. Must see when you are in Shanghai.

title: beauty and tranquility
content: A peaceful visit with lots to take in, probably appreciated more by those who are more informed on the subject. I was more drawn to the ducks than the botany.

title: A must visit
content: This beautiful garden is an oasis in the middle of bustling Shanghai. It dates from the 1500s and features many beautiful structures, gardens, rock formations and ponds. There is a tea room in the gardens and many places to sit down and just take in the beauty.

title: Peaceful Place
content: Tranquil and serene place to visit in shanghai. Hidden place, can feel ancient chinese garden. Outside Yu Garden, you can find the crowded market selling anything you want.

title: Cosy and peaceful
content: This garden is really old - 16th century - so it's perfect for experiencing an authentical Chinese graden. The square and shop area just outside the gates are really crowded, almost to the point of crazy, but don't let this deter you. The garden in itself is, although also quite crowded, actually quite peaceful and it is possible to enjoy its tranquility and take nice photos.

title: Favourite part of Shanghai
content: Yu Harden and the Yuyuan tourist market were my favourite thing in Shanghai. The busy tourist market and the quiet and absolutely stunning garden made for a perfect mix and I thoroughly recommend both.

title: Wonderful
content: This is an interesting place to go for a visit in Shanghai. It is like a historical place. This place had been a resident for noble people in the olden days. Enjoy spending time for walking. Don't forget to eat a soft cake in a shape of a bell. It is really yummy, I love it !

title: BEST DIMSUM
content: Probably the Best Dimsum i have ever tried, you need to queue for this Dimsum it might be almost 20 minutes but its worth waiting for.Please secure your belongings too crowded and full of tourists..I did enjoyed my Dimsum very much.....

title: Old home garden in the middle of busy Shanghai
content: An interesting garden of an ancient land owner near the Bund. It was a little difficult to find the entrance when we didn't know where to look. The entrance is located in the center of the shopping district. Entrance fee is 30RMB per person.

title: Beautiful.
content:
Liked:  Historical site with beautiful greenery.

Disliked: Hard to get to and stuck in the middle of a tourist trap.  Be prepared to have merchants trying to sell you everything from fake watches to selfie-sticks.

title: The most beautiful garden in Shanghai
content: Just go there and you won't regret for every penny and every second and every step you spend.

title: Nice Place to Visit
content: This is another popular tourist area in Shanghai. If you only have a chance to visit this park once, i would recommended you to visit it at night. The night view is better than day view. But due to Yu Garden is close around 5pm, you might consider visiting the place after lunch, so you can enjoy the night view of the building after dark.

title: Very touristy, but I would definitely put it on your do-list when visiting Shanghai
content: It's a must to visit when you're in Shanghai, but it is very touristy. The place is full of shops and restaurants focused on tourists. It can also be very busy.

title: Beautiful garden!
content: My family really enjoyed seeing all the beauty of this amazing garden!  Definitely an attraction not to be missed.

title: Hidden Gem
content: Beautiful garden in the centre of the old part of Shanghi. You really need half a day to really appreciate all the nooks and crannies. A guide would also be a good idea to ensure you don't miss any details

title: Oasis in the hustle and bustle of Shanghai
content: This is a lovely green oasis in the heart of shanghai. It did get quite packed with tourists while we were there but it was still very relaxing and there are lots of parts to explore. The map is all in Chinese so a touch difficult for non Chinese readers to work out where you are but getting lost in this place is no bad thing. There are ponds, rock gardens, beautiful buildings and a few shops inside. Every so often you can see the skyscrapers in the distance and you're reminded just where you are.

title: Great place to get lost in
content: Beautiful gardens that are full of twists and turns and it's very easy to lose your bearings but that's not always a bad thing. Took so many photos in here as well as taking some time to chill out, came out at lunchtime just as it became busy and the first of the tour groups arrived.

title: Very nice Gardens
content: This is a nice place to visit for a relaxing time. You can take 30 minutes to see the gardens or take 3/4 hours to stroll around. Lots of fish in the ponds with nice lilies which were in flower at the time.

title: Too crowded...
content: Yu Garden was on our list as some of my friends had not yet been. We arrived relatively early and the place was crowded already. I feel it has lost it "zen", quiet appeal due to the large number of people allowed in at the same time. At certain spots of the garden we could barely move without being bumped into or hit by a selfie stick. We visited the little shops around it and had a traditional "xiao long bao" after battling through a very long line. I honestly think this place is no longer worth visiting if you only have limited time in Shanghai.

title: Crowded shopping
content:
Be prepared to bargain 
Very touristy but the garden itself worth a trip 
Also a temple 
Worth one quick visit to shop for souvenirs 
Can take metro there 
Preferred shopping at science museum metro stop

title: Lovely Place!
content:
An amazing Oasis inside the craziness of Shanghai.

Full of story, and some lovely work of arts.

When we went there was raining a lot, however the beautiful statues, furniture and most of all beautiful lake and green environment was worth it.

title: Beautiful gardens and Pavilions to explore
content: Yu Garden was first created in 1559 during the Ming Dynasty by Pan Yunduan. Heavily damaged during WWII and restored in the late 50s, these are a real treasure. So many interesting rock and stone walls, bridges and sculptures with lovely trees and plantings. There is quite a shopping area outside of the main gardens that will be fun and tempting, something for everyone. Busy for sure, but very enjoyable none the less.

title: Must visit
content: The garden is located in the Old City. I wasnt sure what to expect inside at first because I didnt plan the visit, but this is one of the most impressive sites in SH. We got no maps, but kind of trying to follow the crowd. It is a big complex, but not repetitive at all. You can sit down almost anywhere and just enjoy the view and the atmosphere.

title: A very nice oasis in Shanghai
content: This is a very nice oasis in the middle of a city that can sometimes pass for a living version of Blade Runner. Well maintained grounds, lots of photo ops and not terribly crowded even in the middle of Golden Week. Good way to spend an afternoon.

title: Nice garden
content: Its a big garden in city center near the bond area.

title: Oasis in the City
content: Beautiful garden to explore right in the middle of the crazy Yu market.  Go early or late to avoid crowds.

title: Great historical attraction
content: Beautiful old Chinese pavilions and gardens built for the aging parents of a high ranking chinese official in the 1500's. I can't help but wonder what it was like then before the shops, crowds, and food vendors. It was crowded when we were there but apparently it was not considered a busy day. I am thankful we could enjoy this remarkable place in relative peace. The buildings and gardens really are wonderful ............ especially liked the dragon gates.

title: Great touristy area
content: Despite the old town being a touristy area it was great fun, fabulous knick knack shopping with vendors who enjoy a good haggle. Be aware that the advertised price on most of the stuff has abut 70% mark up so bargain hard in good faith. Great food, excellent dumpling shop by the carp pond and garden. Enjoy!

title: Hmmm
content: Your view of the Yu Garden will probably depend on whether you like oriental gardens with special stones and raked white gravel or western style gardens with greenery. Surrounded by glitzy trashy plastic tourist rubbish.

title: Nice Tourist Trap
content: I am not sure which one is the real attraction : the garden, the shopping plaza, or the old temple. They are all good. We were there around 10am on a weekday. The crowd wasn't too bad. By the time we left around noon, people were everywhere. Be sure to bargain, I bought small souvenirs for $10 rmb with a price tag of $58 rmb. You may not get a big discount in smaller stores, but it does not hurt to try.

title: Must visit!
content:
So nice
So quiet
So magic
So relaxing
Typical Chinese garden and architecture.
A lot of traditional shops, small restaurants....

title: What I thought China would be!
content: As to explain myself, this place has everything. Culture, trade, gardens, buildings, souvenirs, etc. If I only had time to do one thing in Shanghai, I would come here. Very convenient to get here by metro or taxi, easy to walk through and lots of things to browse or purchase. It was not as full as I would expect, but grab your children's hands, and enjoy yourself.

title: Lovely Gardens in the middle of a giant tourist trap
content: We visited during Golden Week so the area was extremely busy. However we managed to get inside the gardens about 10 minutes after they opened in the morning so the experience was relatively peaceful. 40RMB entry gives you access to a lovely series of historic walled gardens and courtyards with various buildings to explore. We had a relaxing stroll and took lots of pictures, but by the time we were leaving the hordes of tourists had arrived which changed the atmosphere completely. So I would highly recommend you get here as close to the 8.30am opening time as possible. The surrounding area of shops & restaurants is extremely busy, but lots of cheap souvenirs available if you know how to bargain.

title: Crowded but nice
content: If you like gardens and traditional style buildings this is the place to visit. The Yu Garden has a lot of stores and places to eat, we had a great dumpling lunch here with the view of the central pool. Feed the fish and walk around. Interesting and crowded.

title: Must visit in Shanghai !
content:
beautiful gardens with fascinating history, you can spend easily 3-4 hours if you choose to learn about the history, admire the detailed architecture and enjoy a good crash course on the magic of Tea drinking.

dont rush !

title: Beautiful oasis in a busy city
content: This house and garden built in the Ming Dynasty is a quiet, well designed maze of paths, buildings, ponds and trees. You could imagine the extremely wealthy women strolling around. Although it is not a large piece of land, it is imaginatively landscaped to give the illusions of being bigger than it is.

title: My visit in June 2015
content: A typical Chinese garden, surrounded by lots of shops and all sorts of goodies - try the dumplings - might have to stand in line, after you visit the garden.

title: Yu garden
content: An oasis of beauty, peace & tranquility in the middle of Chinatown, Shanghai.it was an amazingly beautiful place with gorgeous architecture, gardens, water bodies... ! Every inch is like a picture postcard! A must see when in Shanghai. Also the best Chinatown in the world.

title: Peacheful and beautiful
content: We strolled about 2 hour though these gardens and we can imagine, what peaceful it must be when nobody is around. But as it is one of the biggest tourist attractions of Shanghai, we had to fantasise about the peacefulness. A must go attraction

title: Large Private Gardens, now open for a small fee.
content: A step back in time, to see the private gardens on Chinese nobility from long ago. Lots of ponds, pools, and bridges, fairly crowded, but manageable. Many old historic buildings that have been restored to their former beauty. An excellent gift shop with historical collectibles. Tea houses and refreshment stands are all around. One way in, and after much walking, the other way out. An interesting visit, worth a stop.

title: Beautiful gardens rich in history
content: These gardens have survived centuries of Shanghai history. You can come for a traditional, beautiful place to relax, or come with a good tour guide in order to immerse yourself in the history and cultural represented within these garden walls.

title: Visit to Yu Garden
content: I had visited the garden before. I decided to visit it again. I don't remember all the shops from the last time but I was with my girl friend. It is very nice and I like how some of the shops on the outside are built like the old buildings from ancient china. It does give it that feel that you are in the past. The pond was very nice and I did enjoy the scenery.

title: Beautiful but zone out the Tourist Groups on loud speakers!
content: It's such a beautiful peaceful garden in a bustling bazaar. Get there early to avoid large groups spoiling the tranquil atmosphere which is priceless in The city.

title: Worth a visit in fine weather
content: Fascinating place but not in the pouring rain.  The place was very crowded, risking getting poked in the eye with umbrellas or selfie sticks!

title: Bored of the busy, bustling Bazaar? Hide here.
content: Oddly the Bazaar and market that surrounds this ancient garden is, more often than not, packed. However the garden is peaceful.

title: Please do decide to visit and spend atleast half a day here
content: From the latest in technology to preserving the tradition of the country Shanghai in China definitely leads the way!

title: Peaceful and cool
content: Lovely example of Chinese garden. It also was nice to visit on a warm day as the temperature in the garden is cooler. It's very well maintained, just a shame that parts of the garden aren't open to the public.

title: busy but to be expected as every guide book recommends it
content: A new place to walk, quiet, peaceful after the hustle and bustle of the yuan bazaar,the staff are informative and they have good English. We asked in the shop why there were four monkeys not three as we had grown up knowing. He told us that we were correct with speak no, see no and hear no evil, the fourth was do nothing, well you learn something new every day.

title: Sightseeing at Yu Garden
content: As first timer, it was a splendid day to spend at Yu Garden. It was crowded and plenty of things to see, eat and buy. Outside Yu Garden, there was a multi level mall selling vey cheap momentos like paper fans, female accessories, female stockings, shoes, cheap shoes, bags, etc etc.You need to bargain and choose from so many outlets in the mall. If you are not happy with the ones that you visited, just move on to the next one. Most of them close by 5pm. It could be a good place to shop indoor since it is raining season currently. Also available nearby are small restaurants to eat beef noodles/rice, McD, finger food; they all are located just outside Yu Garden area and they are less touristy in terms of prices. If you eat and shop inside Yu Garden, it will definitely be of higher price and harder to stage your bargain power to suit to your budget. Overall, it is a good place to eat and shop and take photos.

title: Beautiful place, INCREDIBLY overcrowded.
content: I first visited Yu Garden 10 years ago; it was beautiful and serene place. When you are inside it is hard to believe how small is the place; you can easily get lost there and forget about the surrounding metropolis. You discover new, surprising view literally on every step.

title: The perfect garden!
content: This is one attraction, you should see in Shanghai. When you cross the threshold you go from chaos to calm almost instantly. There was a lot of tourists there but isn't there everywhere in shanghai. The garden seemed to swallow them up and it was sporadically busy then quiet and back again. A great place to wander for an hour and you can sample so good quality teas while your in there. Hundreds of shops and stalls surround it and there's a temple very close as well. Worth spending the afternoon in the area.

title: Great place to walkabout & best for xiao long bao!!!
content: My last visit was last April where I had visitors from Melbourne. It was a good, beautiful historical garden that took 2 hours to really appreciate the surroundings n history.

title: Must go place when you come to visit Shanghai
content: I went there times. Sometime i go alone, just for my favorite xiaolongbao. Sometimes i go with my foriegn friends, helping them shoping and do some guideness.

title: Magic atmosphere, beautiful and peaceful gardens although crowded
content: it's a real pearl in the ancient Chinese gardening architecture of the 16th century. Small, bright green married with the water and the stones to reach the perfect equilibrium. Great pieces of furniture, you can almost feel the life it had 600 years ago. Yes It-s crowded, but you could stay there just walking, sitting, enjoying. Outside it, classical tea shops and souvenirs, but people are not insisting nor bothering. We got our guide inviting us to a tea house and we had to buy tea, but it was worth doing it. A place to go.

title: amazing, peacefull place
content:
The Yu garden is one of the most popular attraction in Shanghai.
A mix of various Chinese pavillons, bridges, stones and plants. The Dragon Wall is particularly an highlight. Very good place to have a rest, far away from the turmoil of the city

title: Very well maintained Garden
content: Been here during my business visit to Shanghai. One can see lot buildings with  Old Chinese cultural architecture. Lot of walking....

title: A must do!
content:
This is a very peaceful place to visit in the busy city. You must visit if in Shanghai.
You can also join in a tea tasting ceremony in the gardens, which is pretty cheap.
Lovely photo opportunities.

title: Well worth a visit
content: its a lovely look at life as it was. With a good guide to explain its former use, it's easy to imagine the life thr aristocrat who had it built, must have lived. I came away enchanted but so much more aware of how lucky we are.

title: Expansive and Lovely.
content: The Garden goes on and on with many spots of interest such as fish ponds, private function areas and performance theaters, tiled symbols underfoot, and sections of rock and plants of interest. A lovely experience full of history and symbolism.

title: The traditional Shanghaiese market place that you should visit
content: It's a good place to go if you want to see how the traditional Chinese architecture and market place in Shanghai looks like. However, it's crowded with tourists 24/7 so make sure you don't go on a weekend. There are different kinds of small shops and food stalls inside the garden - most of which are pricey. All in all, it's a different face of modern Shanghai and worths you visiting

title: Must visit
content: An ancient chinese garden which should not be missed to visit, there are many souvenier shops nearby that you could buy something would remind you china, a must visit if you are in shanghai

title: IN SEARCH OF PEACE AND HAPPINESS .
content: Awesome place to understand the Buddhist culture and unique sculpture .Buddha Jade statue is toooo good and gives lot of reflection on peace and serenity . Must visit place in shanghai after a busy life. you may find your call for your life and ts value. Guided tour is recommended for better and interesting understanding of Buddhism.

title: Not worth a visit.
content: This is a cheap fake Chinese street. The smell here is really bad and the atmosphere is definitely not so "Chinese" as commercial. I don't think tourists who would like something cultural should visit this horrible place. The food here isn't that good either. The crowd would ruin everything.

title: Not really a garden - just another tourist trap.
content: We couldn't get to the garden, the whole place was heaving with noisy tourists and touts asking you to buy fake bags and watches and sodding selfie sticks....avoid it like the plague,

title: Just another Chinese garden!
content: It is no doubt a wonderful garden and a peaceful (relatively!) haven in the middle of Shanghai. But the problem is to get to the front entrance of the garden, you must pass through lots of stores, restaurants, Starbucks(!), and busloads of Chinese and Western tourists. I have been to this area about 4 times and everytime it was packed, even when I went at 9am. it is an interesting area to visit if you are short on time, but there are other better gardens in Shanghai.

title: Well worth a visit
content: Really lovely - reviews don't give a full impression. Very busy and touristy but inside really beautiful.

title: Must visit!!
content: I was terribly impressed by the Yu Gardens! The place is very 'ZEN' with plants, rocks and water all over! I definitely recommend visiting this place!!

title: Overrated landmark of Shanghai
content: Don't get me wrong, I love the actual garden at Yuyuan Garden, but in order to get to it you must fight to get through the crowds (it's crowded on any given day, not to mention during Chinese New Year or Golden Week). I actually live in Shanghai and I've visited this place many times with friends and family visiting, but it never offers anything new.

title: Beautiful and Peaceful Chinese Garden
content: This is a great place to visit for many reasons if you are interested in gardens, Chinese culture and history, want a peaceful rest from the throngs on a weekday, escape to a shaded oasis. The rockwork, paving patterns, gates, temples, dragons, pond, and plantings are amazing to see. Plan to spend a lot of time here as each unique garden room opens to another and you want to sit in each and take it all in!

title: Perfect for bargain shopping.
content: Go for the shopping and try the food stalls. You will get a very nice surprise with the variety of restaurants.

title: Oriental Ancient Market
content: Good chinese artifacts, tea and other items in the old market. A nice evening walk, with good local food and clean streets. Recommended when in Shanghai. Local flavour at its best!

title: Yu Garden good for shopping
content: This area contains many old traditional Chinese style buildings.  The shopping is very good but it gets very crowded.

title: lovely architecture and symbols
content:
one of the best lovers garden , 
do not miss feeding the big fishes. 
lovely architecture and symbols .

title: Brilliant, if you can find it
content: You wouldn't believe something so big would be so hard to find! Study the map carefully for how to get to the entrance, it's behind a wall so while you think you will just see it from the street, actually you don't. When we went it was tipping with rain, but this actually worked in our favour as it wasn't heaving with people, as I understand it is most of the rest of the time! Still amazing though and definitely worth doing. Beware, they only take cash, but there is a cashpoint/ATM nearby in the YuYuan Bazaar.

title: Interesting and pleasant walk, a mini Forbidden City
content: An interesting wander round old China. It is a bit of a mini Forbidden City. Well worth a visit and relaxing time.

title: So pretty
content: The Yu Gardens are so beautiful and quite subtlety designed that it's hard to believe that they are not natural. It's delightful to wander slowly through smallish gardens, admiring the planting,,the pools and rocks, turn a corner and find another delightful scene.

title: Worth to visit
content: A traditional place with lots of shops. Good for bargaining. There is one branch of 361° which you can buy discounted shoes.

title: Tourist Paradise
content: Lots of shopping and traditional buildings to take photos of/with. Don't be afraid to bargain in the shops and be friendly :)

title: Touristy but Cool
