content: Our trip to yuyuan garden was typical. The garden was huge and interesting but the xiao long bao was a bit expensive sitting in the restruant but it was a brilliant experience that My family, friends and I may never forget.

title: "Shoppers Stop"
content: A very good place for souvenir shopping. if you are good at bargaining, its worth being there. do spend atleast 3 hrs and you will get gifts for your near and dear ones.

title: Touristic but nice garden
content: Yu Garden is connected with a bunch fake ancient Chinese buildings with tourist shops, it can be lovely for photos but other than that, I was not very impressed. The garden is very nice if this is like your first time in China.

title: Not that huge experience, but definetely visit area
content: The area of ancient old town is nice, you will get typical chinise constructions and tea houses, but Yu Garden itself if not in very good conditions nowadays, walking inside is quiet short and not so many interesting things, no guide, etc.

title: Beautiful
content:
The Yu Garden is a must visit.

As well as some good touristy shopping near by. This is a beautifully peaceful place to visit.

Expect crowds but is well worth it.

title: Too crowded
content: Ticket is CNY 40 per person. The sheer number of people inside takes away the tranquility of the garden. Once inside, one can get lost in the crowds and the maze of walkways.

title: Too Touristy, Missed the "old" Yu Gardens...
content: Yu Gardens is a massive number of shops in a couple of square blocks of ancient looking storied pagoda-like buildings. We missed the original Yu Garden property that goes back hundreds of years. Shame! We were told it is the best part of visiting this area.

title: Must see during the day and night
content: This is an awesome place to visit!  A famous tea house that Clinton visited and Shanghai dumplings!  Starbucks available as well as other American favourites if you just have to have it!  China offers so much, nice mix of old and new China!

title: lovely in-city garden, very crowded
content: We enjoyed our visit to the garden, which is tucked away in the corner of a busy shopping area. It took a bit of effort to find the entrance, but once we did we enjoyed the lovely stone structures, buildings, greenery, and water areas. It was very crowded and a rowdy tour group and omnipresent selfie sticks somewhat ruined the peaceful vibe. Also, there were people napping in other parts of the gardens (leaning on a bench or railing), which seems in appropriate. A few times we managed to wander around and have a little area to ourselves, and those moments were really nice.

title: Smaller than I thought
content: It is a wonderful garden area. And, for a garden, it is large. But, I was hoping for more. And, many areas are restricted from access. The price was a bit steep for what this attraction is. You will have plenty of great picture opportunities. And, it is a great escape from all the tourists shopping in the markets outside of the gates.

user_loc: 哥伦比亚特区华盛顿特区
title: You will like the architecture and the food
content: This is part of the old city of Shanghai--it may be the only place you will see what China looked like 100 years ago--they have modernize so quickly they didn't save much of the old city. There is a great little tea house and dumpling restaurant here--worth the trip.

title: Beautiful oasis, lost in time.
content: Chinese gardens are always beautiful and a fantastic place to find peace and harmony. Yuyuan Garden is one of these places you want to stay, walk all along, find a nice spot, open a book and let the time fly. Forget about the crowded outside area full of tourists and shops. You have to pay the entrance fee, but definitely worth the price.

title: Yu Gardens
content: Took a while to find as the hotels free tourist map had a very strange idea of scale, and missed out lots of places. But the gardens and surrounding tourist areas are beautiful, though very busy when we visited.

title: Green and Cool Oasis in Middle of Hot and Vibrant City
content: Travelled to Shanghai and came across these gardens in our travels. What a beautiful green and serene place to be found in a very vibrant city. Wonderful relaxing amongst the plants and scenery and enjoyed the cool atmosphere of the place. A really lovely place to visit to explore and keep cool.

title: Too croweded to enjoy
content: I believe this is a beautiful place. I only walked via the nine turns bridge which brings into the gardens. This was nice, but due to the holiday (Dragon boat festival) vacation everything was so crowded that it was impossible to continue and I decided to quit before really entering the gardens.

title: Quick Drop-By While In-Town
content: A fine sample of traditional Chinese garden in the middle of city center. Well preserved and well kept. The place is not big and can be done in an hour or two. Good for those who cannot afford the time to travel to the bigger heritage sites out of town.

title: Ok for Tourist
content: There are many tourist store and food shop. Your need to bargain when buying tourist stuff here. The garden not as I expect as full greenery.

title: Preserved "ancient wall"  a major plus for this area.
content: Wasn't easy to find, but once there, you can get lost in time just wandering and admiring the preserved remnants of ancient society.  Seems a bit dull for the vibrant traveller, but serene and soothing on the mind.

title: So many people!
content: I heard a lot about the people coming to this garden before I was leaving for Shanghai, but didn't expect this. It is a beautiful area and a beautiful garden. The garden is not the massive garden that you can normally find in China but that makes it more worth seeing. However, there were too many people compared to the size of the place and would not like to go there again.

title: Very peaceful and pretty
content: This garden is in the middle of the city and so worth a visit. The pathways meander around a lake and man made, almost, mountains. Through buildings. It has the biggest goldfish and turtles. The day we were there it rained, hard. But it was still full of visitors. Make sure you have a guide, the story of the place is very interesting.

title: Great place to shop
content: Many cheap shopping options for cheap local stuff three of four buildings of many gifts stationary and other stuff a place to finish all your shopping needs in a few hours

title: Built to look like old China, but it's modern
content: It's a shopping centre area built in the old Chinese building style around water with loads of carp. Makes for a good atmosphere but feels very commercialised, not the real China.

title: A little piece of heaven
content: This was a great place to visit. It is peaceful and so beautiful. We spent about 90 minutes and really thought it was excellent. Take your camera! Great.

title: Beautiful beyond the crowds
content: If you can figure out a time to visit when the crowds are lighter, then Yu Garden is absolutely beautiful, and one can spend hours wandering the twists and turns and finding corners of hidden beauty. But if you can steel yourself for the people, then it is always a pleasure.

title: Authentic gardens
content: We thought the gardens to be authentic but the outside surroundings were so "manufactured" that the greater overall experience was somewhat spoiled. The surrounding markets are crowded with tourists and the associated shops selling the usual key rings, magnets and T shirts. Inside when one eventually finds the entrance, the gardens are worth the visit and are a peaceful contrast.

user_loc: 新西兰奥克兰中心地区
title: Excellent
content: There magnificent gardens date back to the Ming Emperor, 1559, there is over two hectares of different gardens and buildings that you enter through small cave like entry's.

title: Former Home, elegant gardens, and lakes with golden fish fish
content: The imaginative structure of the building was exceeded only by the wonder of the sculpture, sometimes defining space between garden rooms. Particularly astonishing was a steel dragon, snaking along the top of a wall. His head came into view just by the gate, and his feelers and head gear and menacing teeth where so elegantly done--and fearsome too. The Chinese Garden always has ornamental hardscape--mosaic walkways, walls, sometime natural rock formations creating non-referential heaps of sandstone. But the balance and harmony of the bridges, walls, fencing against a watery backdrop and green setting let you forget you were in a city of 26 Million people.

title: Nice park, commercial area also
content:
The garden itself costs entry fee, but is very nice. Some exhibition of houses and interieur. Nice ponds, impressive chinese garden culture. Silent corners.
Outside is a commercial market center for shopping.

title: Beautiful and Serene
content: Let me start by saying that my wife and I are big fans of gardens of all sorts. While in Shanghai we could not miss the chance to visit Yu Garden and we were not disappointed. This in town gem is not to be missed.

title: Garden Playground
content: A beautiful place with rich history. If there be a guide, it will be a wonderful learning experience.

title: Excellent!
content: Get there early in the morning to avoid the crowds as by the time I left around noon, it was packed with people.

title: Beautiful gardens and buildings
content: This place is a ten minute walk from the bund and worth a visit for an hour or so. Entry is cheap and the gardens are great. Surrounding them is a touristy shopping area and cafes to relax in.

title: China At Its Best & Worst
content: Summary: The gardens themselves are a good representation of a traditional Chinese rock garden. It's beautiful and well-maintained. The structures on the site are all nice and well-maintained. It's a must-see if you can't make it to other parts of China. But try to come her without the crowds. Avoid holidays or weekends. Thousands of people visit here at once. Come early to really enjoy the tranquility. Or you'll be sharing your visit standing shoulder to shoulder with people.

title: Understanding Historical Yuyuan Garden
content: Since I first time to visit this location on 1994, I never look inside this garden, This June 2015 I have a change to see what are inside this garden, Oh so good to understand the history why this garden built.

title: Beautiful 500 year old Chinese Garden
content: We had a brilliant day out at Yu Gardens and the surrounding traditional Chinese Streets. Be prepared though it gets extremely busy, luckily we chose a day which was not so hot. On the approach to the main attraction, you walk through bustling streets full of shops selling Chinese Souvenirs. The whole area is a maze of streets, it's certainly a sensory experience! We found a great Volunteer Guide, who offered us some great advice! Don't be led into a shop, just walk in off the street, stay on the ground floor, don't go upstairs or below the shop! She pointed us in the right direction and off we went! The Zig Zag bridge entrance is amazing and really crowded! The parents had their first experience of having their photos took with the locals! They felt like Superstars. The Garden is amazing! Overflowing with a 500 year old history this place is amazing. The buildings are beautiful, there are Art Galleries and Tea Houses that you can wonder around. You can easily lose a couple of hours wondering around and taking in the surroundings. We all throughly enjoyed the day and can highly recommend it! Enjoy......

title: Good Value for Money
content: Arrived early'ish by taxi and as the day wore on it got busier and busier. I found the locals friendly and more than helpful when looking for a throat lozenge for a cough, was personally guided up 2 flights to a small traditional pharmacy. Same with the tea house we couldn't find. Locals show you without expectation of reward for this. Great for souvenirs for friends and family. Taxi return to hotel easy to find and same cost as taxi ride from hotel RY35, for a half hour drive.

title: Too loud music from the vendors!
content:
They have fish ponds! Me and my daughter enjoyed watching the fishes and turtles down the walking bridge. Beautiful old chinese buildings around.

But why there are so much shopping area there? Sellers are annoying!

title: A Taste of Old Shanghai
content: Yu Gardens and the area around it offers a bustling and appealing taste of what Shanghai was like before modernization.  My wife and I spent several enjoyable hours there.

title: Must see in Shanghai
content: Nice gardens, good for photos. Donwload a guide to if you are interested in the history. Make sure to explore around and try the dumplings which are amazing.

title: Over Crowded Tourist Trap
content: Love the garden, the historic buildings but, hate the crowds, 10 yuan shops of junk goods killing the experience.

title: Nice place
content: This place is a must for tourists. The lighting in the evening is very nice. I had been there 1 hour only, i wish i could stay more. Only the bazaar which is very near to Yu Garden should be seen.

title: China town in Shanghai
content: Yuyuan garden is located in China town of Shanghai. One can reach here by Metro line 10. Nice place to buy souvenirs

title: Total peace
content: This garden is a beautiful, magical place. Entering it from a busy, noisy, bustling street, you immediately feel the tranquility and peace, with no sound what-so-ever from the street.

title: Great oasis in the middle of the crowded city
content: Beautifull place in the middle of very crowded tourist area. It's just great to go there and get few minutes of break in a tranquil surroundings. It is full of beautiful ponds fulfilled with colorful koi - fishes. Great old chinese architecture mixed with old plants and beautiful rock-stone elements.

title: Yu Garden...beautiful & enigmatic gardens...
content: Must see when in Shanghai. We went in March (cool & misty), but it was still well worth the visit. Beautiful & enigmatic.

title: a traditional market place inmidst a modern downtown
content: a beautiful contrast to the modern, stylish architecture when you pass through the streets of this wonderful traditional marketplace, with a number of small shops, restaurants, and handcraft productions. Everything is fit in the architecture of traditional old chinese houses. A very nice atmosphere - take your time

title: Oasis in the heart of Shanghai
content: Great place and you can easily spend a day there. Great exhibitions and shops with quality items (not cheap, but the value is worth it). While some tranquil places are really worth spending quite some time contemplating, the garden is surrounded by quite some sky-scrapers and also some of the buildings require some renovation. The rockery is a bit pale (hence only 4 stars), not sure if it's the result of smog or it was always like that and I am just not prepared to perceive this Chinese beauty. Great old style busy quarter outside of the garden adds up to the experience.

title: Huge garden with good history
content: The garden was full of history. It is the main attraction of Shanghai to local people. I really like how the garden was arranged. It seemed that the garden was designed with pedestrian path and labyrinth. If you just follow the path, you wont be lost and will end up on the exit anyway.

title: Great peaceful area
content: We visited this as one of our all inclusive tours on a Archers / Cosmos holiday and it was a lovely area of old houses and gardens with both stunning photo opportunities and areas of peace and tranquillity. It certainly helped having a local guide to explain the area and history as well. Can get busy so keep together as you can easily get lost in the twists and turns.

title: Yuyuan
content: After reading reviews, I thought it would be really crowded, but it actually wasn't. It was very nice, beautiful gardens and structures. It is very well kept, and there were also some small ponds there. It was very relaxing, but the people with the selfie sticks kind of ruined it. there is a street filled with shops leading to the garden entrance that used to be a big temple.

title: A place you must visit
content: Used to be house of a rich and famous family, worth to have a look how traditional Chinese lived. Then have a taste of local snack at The City Temple of Shanghai which's right next.

title: Back in the time
content: So nice to be here. This place has a very tranquil feeling to it, which is very nice after a day of hecticness in busy Shanghai city! From the buildings in old style to the green water from the algea, everything is very well preserved and matches the style

title: Crowd, cheap gifts, sharpen your bargaining skills
content: It is a place to buy cheap gifts in Shanghai. Very crowded, make sure you know how to bargain in China, this is where you can find stuff to bring home for friends and co-workers. Food is not that great in the bazaar area.

title: First time visit
content: What a crazy place! 5 stars if you love being jammed up with thousands of people bargain hunting from hundreds of knick knack vendors surrounding the actual garden area, and all around the perimeter and for blocks down the road. Cannot get to the garden entrance without navigating a maze of vendors. The garden itself is quite lovely but if you get there when a bus load of tourists enter, take a break, the passageways inside are quite narrow and try to avoid the megaphone group tour leaders if you seek to discover the tranquility of the place. As far as shopping, bargain hard. There is a great dumpling restaurant there (expect long lines) and a temple for public worship and to make offerings. Check out the artisan craftsmen for personalized caricature art, jewelry and souvenirs.

title: A day well spend!!!
content: Yu garden is very beautiful...lot of greenry and beautiful ponds full of colorful fishes...there is a 40yuan ticket to enter the garden which is worth spending...and then there is huge market with lot of food options...chinese artifacts...its a really nice place for shopping and rates are quite fair..but you can always bargain

title: A glimpse of the old
content: This place is quite a good visit. The whole garden area is amazing and well kept. The ponds have lots of fish and the area generally looks good. Remeniscent of old Shanghai....

title: Relaxing
content: This place is nice if you want a break from all the buildings. Its like a secluded little house filled with gardens and rocks that give it a serene sense of beauty. Great place for photos

title: Lovely attraction and next to the faux 'China Town' area
content: These are lovely gardens - actually a number of tea rooms surrounded by ponds. Well worth a visit and relatively cheap. It takes around an hour I would say, but you can also visit the local 'China Town' area of the older traditional buildings - whilst the gardens are locked off and so you are free to wonder without hastle, the outside area is the prime tourist district with loads of stalls and people selling 'Rolex'. A lovely garden though and well worth a visit.

title: beautiful
content: Definitely worth a visit. Beautiful gardens and buildings, all derived from feng shui  design. Rock gardens and little bridges.

title: Quiet and calm in the center of the city
content: This beautiful formal garden is a place to relax and find calm in the middle of huge Shanghai. Go early, when it opens, and move ahead of the tour groups. You can explore the many small grottoes and buildings and imagine you are royalty in the 16th Century. There is good shopping toward the exit, too.

title: Interesting--not a top attraction if you are pressed for time.
content: The interior garden gives a nice feel for historical Chinese architecture and gardens. It is small and was very crowded the day we were there. Surrounding it is a vast collection of souvenir and tourist-food shops. Beware the aggressive street sellers of expensive watches--the watches are of course not real and the sellers will try and get you to follow them to an interior locaton. I found the shops cloying because you could not pause without a salesperson making a pitch or an offer.

title: Yu Garden
content: this was one of my favorites. So peaceful, the foliage and ponds are well taken care of. Sophie was great at explaining the history of the garden. Took great pictures. Just by being there you could understand why the Emperor decided to build it.

title: Serene oasis amidst all that shopping
content: Somewhere admidst all the shopping Is the entrance to the Yu Garden. There is a small fee to visit the Garden. When I first entered the Yu Garden, I was not impressed. It was packed full of people and there was a tour group from Europe with a tour guide using a microphone to guide her group. It was noise polution at its worst. Fortunately, we went the other way around the pound and didn't see many people. Maybe we were going against traffic. It's not a big garden but the windy paths make it seem larger. There are two ponds - a smaller one with lotus and koi at the entrance and the other more beautiful and larger pound with a pagoda like structure. I went across the pound and took some beautiful photos with the pagoda as the backdrop and children feeding koi at the edge of the pond. Just an idyllic scene. It may not be the most beautiful garden but since my time was limited and did not allow a visit to other gardens until a much later date, I was happy to have spent some time there.

title: Interesting site
content: Beautiful gardens combined with many shops should be visited in the morning--gets very crowded---some restaurants and many gift shops---can bargain for price

title: A different aspect of "garden"
content: Visitors came to Shanghai most probably also visited many other famous Gardens.

title: Nice
content: Nice place to walk around if you want the feel of old Shanghai against the backdrop of the modern one. A lot of shops outside the Garden itself. Make sure to look for the Chinese craftsmen! They can make personalised items for you.

title: Typical chinese garden. It should be seen
content: This was a very quiet afternoon in a busy city. It's not a gardens like westerners think of a garden but it was beautiful.

title: Always crowded, but fun to walk around
content: This place is one of the few parts of "old China" left in Shanghai. The area is always crowded with domestic and international tourists, but worth a visit. There are nearby shops you can bargain in (just off the main square). We always walk the bridge but skip the actual gardens (which have an entrance fee). Walk over to the nearby City Temple of Shanghai and pay their entrance fee instead.

title: Another nice garden to visit
content: A nice garden with more rockformations, water and so on. Nice rooftops and we also went to the old city and market so we have pictures of the old and new buildings in the background

title: A Must See
content: Above all reviews I want to add that the long waiting time for the dumplings is absolutely worth! Best dumplings East of Xian!

title: Very Tourist-y
content: It was very busy, and so many people trying to sell you things make it difficult to enjoy.Went to a teahouse there but the food was not great and it was really a case of get as many people served as possible and take the money.

title: Overcrowded and expensive
content: This was my second visit and unlike the first it was way overcrowded with tour groups. So not easy to relax and enjoy unless you go very early in the morning.

title: Tourist trap
content: Very busy on the weekends and during holidays.  Hoards of people and many trying to sell you useless stuff.  Be weary of the tea scammers.  Still, though it is a beautiful place if you catch it on a low day with beautiful blue skies.

title: Beautiful but maybe boring for some.
content: The garden is pretty nice but nothing more special, you can also walk around, shopping, eating. They also have a lot of souvenir shop here but the goods is the all the same.

title: Nice but not much to see
content: It's a nice day out, but that's about it. I've been to many Chinese gardens and this ranks much lower than the ones I've seen. The best part (for me) was the walkway across the pond towards the main entrance of the garden, it's beautiful. It isn't overly expensive but if I had knew what was in the garden before I paid, I wouldn't of entered.

title: Well worth a visit despite the crowds
content: I have reviewed both the garden and bazaar together since I don't think you can visit one without at least walking through the other. The rating is more for the gardens. The bazaar is basically shops and food vendors in ornate, old-fashioned looking but modern buildings. The area is very large and crowded but makes for an interesting visit. The gardens are surrounded by the bazaar and are also crowded but are quite a surprise – beautifully sculptured plants, water and rock features, architecturally interesting structures and very peaceful and serene, despite being in the middle of a huge shopping area and in the heart of Shanghai. The gardens seemed to be a decent size with lots of beautiful places to sit and enjoy the views.

title: Not tourist friendly
content: Nice place with nice garden but there is not really that much to see. I went in april which is supposed to be the slow period, but still to me it was too crowded. If you go here I recommend to go with a guide, otherwise you have no idea what you are seeing. I went to qibao city and i liked this a bit more.

title: A favorite tourist trap
content: Yuyuan is one of my favorite tourist traps. It really is very tourist. It's a center with a lot of shops and eats. We typically like to go there for Nanxiang Soupy Dumplings (but really there are tons of chains throughout Shanghai). It's kind of become a family tradition that when we stop by Shanghai, we try to make a point of coming out here for the dumplings. There are lots of other small and big eats. Lots of shops for good souvenir products. It has changed a lot over the years. Now there's big brand names like starbucks and dairy queen.

title: Not for wheelchairs
content: In a very busy shopping/ eating area. Fascinating but almost impossible for wheelchairs due to the sheer number of people but still worth a short visit just for the experience. Was able to see very little of the gardens. The entrance was not accessible and needed great amount of manhandling just to get in but then could only travel a very short distance owing to steps etc. No one available to suggest any alternate routes but doubt any exist. Other visitors really enjoyed the Gardens

title: Nice place !
content: Nice place to enjoy chinese culture and garden atmosphere. Try to avoid weekends and national holidays otherwise it can be very crowded.

title: a truly historical place definatelt worth to visit
content: Yu Garden were saved in the very last moment from the bouldozers that were to distroy it during the Cultural Revolution. They represent an architectural gem of design of Chinese landlord living place. Combination of mistery walls, rooms/pavillions, ponds, vegetation and famous dragons on the walls will make you feel in the very true China, maybe like in no other place in China. Every newcomer to Shanghai shall put it into the tour intinerary! It is perfect introduction to Chinese history and culture of living.

title: Try to visit on a weekday
content: Gardens were nice and shopping area around it was fun, but we were there on a Saturday and it was SO packed it was hard to enjoy it.  Still worth going for sure.

title: This is lovely area
content: Yu Gardens is surrounded by a very touristy shopping bazaar. I would give the bazaar a miss, but definitely see the Huxingting Teahouse built in 1784 by cotton merchants. It is reached by the famous zig zag bridge to protect the building from evil spirits which cannot turn corners. Yu Gardens is a quiet haven within the hustle and bustle of Shanghai and the shopping bazaar. The Gardens are from the Ming Dynasty period and took 18 years to build. It is 5 acres of serenity. There are lots of miniature landscapes built by the Mings to recall peaks, caves and gorges of Southern China.

title: NIce place to go
content: The garden is very quiet in a bustling city. The garden is beautiful and very serene. It's also nice because it's inside a shopping area where you can by souvenirs and walk around browsing shops and eateries.

title: Tour
content: The garden was designed centuries ago and has stood the test of the time.  Some great views and photo opportunities.  My visit was spoilt by some tour guides using microphone/portable speaker which spoilt the ambience and opportunity to sit & reflect in this wonderful garden.

title: Great place to wander around
content: Great place to wander around. I have been there many times and like to "lose" myself in this fantastic labyrinth. Very nice pavilions.

title: Shopping place for local Chinese items
content: Has been to this place on a business visit luckily by searching a toy car for my son...

title: Wow! Over the top gardens.
content: The Yu Garden is unlike any other garden you might have seen. Great Chinese buildings, trees,rocks, walkways, ponds, fish, and plantings. Try to get there early in the day as it gets very crowded. Outside the gardens are Chinese style buildings which are made into a very large shopping area. Plan to spend a couple of hours there.

title: Pretty Garden
content: This is a very traditional setting for a Chinese garden. It would be nice to visit on a quiet day but we visited on a Sunday and it was packed. Beautiful rock formations and buildings reflected on the ponds.

title: Beautiful , classic, well-preserved garden - if you can filter out the crowds
content: It is hard to tell from the absolutely beautiful pictures I got here, that I spent a great deal of time trying not to go ballistic from the crowds. Go as early as you can, and for goodness sake avoid weekends and holidays. The hurly burly shopping outside is almost easier to deal with because it is as it is supposed to be.

title: Beautiful peaceful gardens
content: After the busy Yu Bazaar it is so peaceful in these beautiful classic gardens which were originally built in 1577 & renovated in 1956. They are in traditional Chinese style with numerous weathered rocks like sculptures, walled tree gardens, water features & numerous doorways & zigzagging bridges separating the various gardens & pavilions.

title: Must to visit place
content: A Great place for shopping, temple, garden, Chinese architect, food. Keep at least 3 hours with you to enjoy this place.

title: Good walk
content: Nice place to walk through and a bit of shopping. But the stuff I bought here for 20 Yuan I bought it for 10 in Suzhou. So try to bargain.

title: Wonderful place
content: Ignoring the shopping area in the middle and the exit, this place is very well preserved and classic example of what one did 100 years ago in China with too much money :)

title: A beautiful garden and shopping place
content: A great place to kick back and relax at pond. A beautifully designed garden. Shopping at this place was also very interesting. Beware, there is plenty of bargaining.

title: Very lovely
content: A very interesting tour of Yu Garden.  Lots of big Koi.  Lots of people were visiting but it could be a very peaceful place.  We enjoyed it.

title: Like Old Shanghai
content: If you want to know How Old Shanghai looks like? Just come here and enjoy the foods, bridge and garden. And you also can buy many traditional Chinese souvenirs.

title: an oasis in the heart of modern Shanghai
content: It is really amazing of the impression you get when you enter the Yuyan garden in Shanghai.

title: Quintessential Chinese city market!
content: Mostly cheap shopping but super fun, and there are higher end shops as well. This is a budget-friendly area. Save room in your tummy to eat as much street food in Yu Garden district as possible. There is an incredible cafeteria style food court place that has the most amazing dishes. They send carts around with fresh juice. Spent a few hours in this area and it was a great first experience in China! If you only have a day in Shanghai, add this to your agenda.

title: Cast of thousands!!
content: Shared some wonderful time in this park with my tour group of 21 people, but it was the other "million" or so in this park that made it difficult to really appreciate all it had to other. Never the less, a wonderful and inspirational garden carefully laid out to make the best of the rock and water features. Would highly recommend a visit there, provided you are OK with large crowds!

title: Spend a fun 1/2 day here!
content: One of Shanghai's most famous attractions, Yu Yuan, which means Peace Garden, can actually be sectioned into 3 main areas of interest: Yu Yuan Garden, Yu Yuan Temple (Chenghuang Miao or City God Temple) and Yu Yuan Market. You need to buy a ticket to get into the Garden and the Temple. For those who love to shop, Yu Yuan offers you hectic crazy shopping - from brand names like H&M and high-end gold jewelry shops, to a 3-storey wholesale market where you can buy anything and everything from ribbons and plastic bags to wigs and little party favours. However do note that this place is NOT wheelchair or stroller-friendly.

title: crowded and dirty
content: so many out of town locals are yelling and running...they tried to cut in our line when we bought the dumpliings, very rude tourists from all over China. ruin our mood to explore the temple, the garden inside is also very small compared with what we visit in SuZhou.

title: Dissapointed
content: Having to run the gamut of street vendors, takes away for what could have been a relaxing location. Did this as part of a hop on, hop off tour. The organiser can drop this from there schedule.

title: Good family outing and great shopping area
content: Yu Garden is not your typical garden. Also not stroller friendly. Although we used 3 strollers, the kids had rough ride. But I would still recommend taking a stroller.

title: Best Place in Shanghai
content: If you visit Shanghai, you can get bored of the dominance of modern lifestyle and architecture all around. When you go to Yu Garden, you will feel more like in Traditional China. You can see the real Chinese architecture eventhough all brands occupied this nice area as well like you see Starbucks, Haagen Das and many other shops and stores.

title: Shoppers paradise, however remember the main attraction is Garden
content: This place can be both creepy, crowded nightmare for some and paradise for others who enjoy shopping, shops for cloths, souvenirs, electronic gadgets, you name it and you have it here, just don;t forget to bargain and with that i mean bargain hard, to almost 60% of the quoted price.

title: Wow!
content: Bring your camera!  This is where history, nature, and architecture come together beautifully.  A must see!

title: A great example of a Chinese Garden
content: This garden with its many buildings is fantastic in its variety of plants and trees, water, and architecture.

title: Calm space surrounded by crazy shopping!
content: Shopping and eateries all around till you enter the gardens. It's an lovely old house with beautiful garden full of lovely trees, water bodies, bridges and koi fishes!

title: CHINESE MARKET
content: The Gardens are nice but it is too touristy and full of stands selling chinese stuff. i went by night and it was too crowded.

title: What garden, never made it past the shopping.
content: This is the place to go for souvenirs or any other item you may want to buy for friends and family back home. Just be prepared for a lot of attention and many choices. Take your time to look around before you buy as you will undoubtedly have someone try to guide you to their stores. If you find one that has excellent language skills and a business card, then give them a try as they may help you find items quickly. If they simply approach you with a fold out guide for a watch, then I would move on.

title: very nice gardens and shops
content: Amazing Architecture, very nice shops outside the gardens. I think it is the best think to do in Shanghai! We have really enjoyed it. It could get quite crowded though...

title: It was Nice !
content: It was crowded , the place smelled bad and alot of beggars were so annoying but the place was nice it was an experience

title: Nicely laid out small garden
content: This is only a small garden in a land that cherishes its many gardens but the layout is cleverly done to make it feel much larger. The meandering paths - again common in China to mislead the spirits - and layout of shrubs and rocks means you walk and see different aspects of this garden than you would along a more direct route.

title: Yuyuan garden- old Shanghai
content: Fun and pleasant way to spend a rainy morning in the city. Obviously touristy but you can find some good buys especially on silk scarves and casual clothing. Remember to start with 50% of the asking price and prepared to walk away if they don't come down; they will!!

title: Like Walking Through A Chinese Painting
content: Bring your camera for 100s of photo opportunities in this delightful garden.  Linger on a bench and just savor its beauty.

title: Nice garden with interesting surrounding shops
content: Went on a rainy day which may explain why the crowds are thin. This is a paid attraction.

title: I was expecting a bit more of it.
content: Nice architecture around and loads of small shops. It was absolutely crowded and I believe doesn't matter the time you go, it will be crowded anyway. The water garden itself is big and lovely, it feels peaceful, despite the amount of people walking around. It is nice to spend a couple of hours in a relaxing atmosphere, and if you are very keen to walk through the crowd, you can have some fun at the shops.

title: Mostly shopping, some nice stores, lots of knockoffs.
content: There are very pretty parts of the area, but in general it is one giant maze of shops. There are nice stores here, my wife bought a double layer silk scarf at one, and a number of buildings with vendors selling knock off merchandise and souvenirs. Be careful staying too late, we found it very difficult to get a cab back to our hotel.

title: A maze of wonder in a busy quarter of Old Town Shanghai
content: The entrance to this sits in the centre of the old town square and you have to cross a few narrow bridges over a lake filled with coy carp and turtles. Through the gate at the end you have a maze of walkways and routes through this lovely water garden. There are a lot of ornaments and exhibits of art in the ornate houses within, but the route can be a little confusing at times and you could end up coming back on yourself. Stone dragons and lions are present on walls, and at entryways and the trees and plants are delicately dotted about the garden.

title: A beautiful oasis of tranquility
content: Worth a visit to see how the other half lived in the past. This was a merchants private garden which no one could enter unless invited. Now you just need to pay the entrance fee to enjoy a wonderful experience. There is a tea room too.

title: Nice quiet spot once you get past the vendors
content: There were places inside you could sit and relax by the pond or bridge which was nice to get away from the hustle and bustle of the bazaar outside. I was looking forward to having tea at the tea house but our guide recommended another tea house that she said was free except they want you to buy their products afterwards. I never knew how expensive tea and tea pots were!

title: Great place to spend a day
content: There is a lot going on in the Yu Garden area. The garden is lovely and is surrounded by other attractions. The temple of the city god is an attraction on its own and well worth a visit. The Yu garden is lovely with carp ponds, bridges (bridge of nine turnings), rockeries and interesting pavilions.

title: Beautiful Gardens Rich with Symbolism
content: We had a guided tour of these beautiful gardens and it was surprising how big the area seemed tucked into Shanghai. My favorite part was seeing the different dragons throughout the garden and the guardians on the top of the houses.

title: Beautiful oasis in Shanghai
content: great place to a wonderful garden in the city... busy place but well worth a couple of hours appreciating the beautiful gardens, waterfalls, and interesting architecture.

user_loc: 明尼苏达明尼阿波利斯
title: Beautiful garden, but so crowded
content: This was a beautiful destination for a solo outing, but would have been even more fun with a friend. The gardens feature ancient hardscape dating back to Ming and Song dynasties, pools of koi and turtles, and tranquil plantings. It took a long time to FIND the entrance to the actual garden, however, as the surrounding area is overwhelmed with vendors and souvenir shopping. There is multilingual signage but it doesn't include your current position as a point of reference. Worth seeing!

title: Very interesting
content: Loved walking through Old Shanghai and the Garden. Beware of the little shops around every bend inside of the garden, however the fish, old stone and trees and sculptures were really charming

title: Classic Chinese garden in the central city area
content: We were taken to Yu Garden as part of a tour of Shanghai, organised as part of our Viking River Cruises Tour. This classic garden is designed as central to an old upper class house, with rooms opening multiple doors into the garden as part of the living space. You need a guide to make the most of this fascinating insight into the traditional Chinese lifestyle. The elements of shrubs, stone, water and the interplay between them is well worth observing and taking the time to reflect. Details such as the zig-zag bridge (difficult for ghosts to cross) or the high thresholds (difficult for ghosts & tourists!) would be missed without a guide. Advice. Take time here, wait for the tours to pass to see properly. There are steps and uneven areas to negotiate. Look up and notice the modern buildings of Shanghai against the traditional roofs of the house & garden. The exit is straight into the market area, so the serenity wears off quickly!

title: Who knew?
content: Who knew, or knows, what the Shanghai culture was capable of had it been allowed to develop unimpeded by China's withdrawal from the world?

title: Go Early!
content: Get there before the crowds arrive; go directly to the peaceful Ming dynasty gardens for lovely photos and then shop the large Bazaar. Be sure to see the Dragon Wall, Ming rockeries, goldfish ponds, pavilions, and towers. You will be tempted to stop by the lovely shop displays and fancy architecture. Prices here are not the greatest but at some shops you can haggle. Merchandise of all types can be found here.

title: Not very exciting
content: Maybe the season was not right but there was not much to see after walking around a little bit. Live attractions etc would make the place more interesting.

title: Shoppers paradise
content: As Shanghai was our group's first stop and this spot was our first shopping experience in Shanghai, everyone was eager to do shopping as there was a lot of variety. This was our first experience at bargaining-it just shows how much the prices are inflated when you ask the price before bargaining.

title: Very crowded tourist destination
content: This is clearly a tourist trap, full of cheap souvenirs and massive crowds. Even the taxis charge considerably more if they pick you up from the area! The architecture is interesting, but it has been created purely for the tourists and does not have an authentic feel.

title: Gardens.
content: What can you say, these massive gardens were once a private garden and must be seen to be believed, waterfalls, gardens, trees, buildings, absolutely stunning.

title: A gem within the city
content: We could really enjoy the old an new here. The garden and the surrounding areas are old china co existing with the urban shanghai jungle. Also the garden is very well maintained and is well worth the visit

title: Crowded, and not much to see
content: There was't much to see. Didn't feel like it was really a historical spot with all of the hawkers of crappy stuff. Super crowded, and really not an enjoyable experience.

title: Beautiful and peaceful
content: Peaceful until the bus loads of other tourists arrive. Get there as soon as it opens and you'll have an hour or so to wander around in relative seclusion. You'll then exit to see a huge line for admission, and spend the next 30 minutes fighting your way through a dense crowd of sightseers and shoppers to get to the street again, and not to mention the want-to-buy-a-watch crowd.

title: People everywhere
content: So much crowded and so many people. Beautiful place with historical buildings but in every picture u will not be alone..a lot of things to buy but prices are higher

title: Wonderful Garden
content: I went with group tour ,I saw many things: old building,furniture,painting,very beautiful scenes,rocks with different shapes,trees, flowers . It was crowded but very interesting.

title: Another average attraction in Shanghai
content: nothing great about this garden. It may have historical significance but doesn't really look like a great garden that we expected. Just average. The shops around it selling souvenirs and other stuff are lively and one can spend an hour or so buying tit bits.

title: Peace and tranquility
content: This garden path wound its way around showing different views and places to sit and contemplate your surroundings. The rocks with their weird and wonderful shapes and the planting of shrubs and flowers as well as the pagodas were gorgeous.

title: Not much to see
content: It's a park, pure and simple. Nothing unique and not worth a special trip. But if you're in the area, you may just want to stop by and check it off your list. More interesting is the walk from metro to the park- you see lots of street vendors pedaling ... Well ... Items of limited use :).

title: Lovely
content: Great photo opportunities here , lots of eateries around .plenty to see and do. Beware of girls who ask you to go with them for tea

title: Peace amongst the chaos
content: The garden was such a contrast to the hustle and bustle of the surrounding market. Though there were plenty of visitors the gardens were big enough not to feel too crowded. There were a bewildering number of nooks and crannies to explore and many beautiful scenes.

title: Amazing ancient buildings
content: Pay RMB40 to enter the Yu garden. Let your eyes feast on the ancient buildings of black and white. Take note of the figurines and dragons on the roof tops, and symbols on the stone floor. Meander around the stone mazes to find little pavilions or mini water falls. Cross the small pond with orange koi fish and turtle swimming.

title: Beautiful garden, historic, well preserved
content: I was considering of not going here, since it is very touristy and flooded with many people. However, i went there early morning at 830 am (Open 830am-530pm). There weren't too many tourist at that time.. The garden is definitely very interesting, sometimes I get confused and lost inside the garden, even though it is not very big. The gold fish in the pond are huge and you can feed them and touch them too.

title: Nicely preserved piece of history
content: The garden is not too big nor too small per se, but is nice for just wandering around. Would recommend a guide, so that you get more in depth understanding of what you're looking at, and also explanations of some myths that one would not have known without the guide. The garden and the pavilions are nicely preserved, while the shopping/eateries outside of the garden proves a tourist attraction too. Do expect a lot of tourists at all times of the day, especially on weekends. If you are buying anything from the shops outside of the garden, note that they are open for price haggling.

title: Tranquility
content: The garden is a classic chinese garden built in 1559.

title: Beautiful but very busy
content: The whole vibe around the old town area was exciting and I do regret that we did not have more time to spend there as we kept coming across interesting things - a temple with a ceremony happening etc. We only had a couple of hours which was not enough. The gardens are lovely but as others have said quite crowded and so not very relaxing. We visited classical gardens in other parts of China which were much larger and more peaceful. Had a strange experience in the 'tea house' by the gardens. Given two mugs of tea which cost 50 CNY each!! The lady seemed to note our surprise and disappointment and then did a whole Chinese tea ceremony thing for us - for free. My advice is - visit this part of Shanghai because it is so different - but allow loads of time (it's quite a walk from the Metro to start off with) and be prepared for a vibrant, buzzing experience not a relaxing one.

title: Crowded but beautiful
content: It was weekend so it was crowded, but it delighted us anyway. Lots of hidden places to sit and think, lots of beautiful and very old plants. Very Chinese in traditional style.

title: Beautiful and tranquil
content: This was our first experience of a Chinese garden and we loved this place. It was so quiet and tranquil in the middle of the hustle and bustle of Shanghai. Beautiful traditional Chinese buildings with examples of Chinese furniture. The garden had stunning flowers (April was a good time to visit for flower blooms), rockeries, streams and water features. The garden contains an opera house and the white walls in the garden are designed with dragons on top of them. The garden dates back to the 16th century and was built by a wealthy man in the Ming era for his father so it is very opulent. The bazaar outside of the gardens is also worth a visit. In the bazaar is the Hunxinting teahouse and a square where you can find modern shops in traditional Chinese buildings. Beautiful setting - well worth a visit.

title: Worth a visit
content:
crowded but well worth a visit 
Loved the historic buildings and the large stone dragons that where on top of a large wall

title: Beautiful but be careful
content: Wonderful place - The garden is beautiful to walk through and so is the surrounding marketplace. However, be careful as there are cheats all round the place preying on innocent tourists. Common scams

title: Beautifully photogenic and peaceful
content: This was a fantastic sight.  I think some of the best photos of my entire trip to China occurred here.  It is a fantastic and peaceful place in the middle of hectic Shanghai.

title: Would be 5 star except for the crowds
content: One must see Yu Garden - it is a simply terrific place. However, the huge crowds [and this was a weekday afternoon] make appreciating this marvel difficult.

title: Typical Chinese Garden
content: I have visited a few Chinese Garden like Linger Garden in Suzhou. This garden does not give me the WOW factor. It is another typical Chinese garden. If you have visited one of the famous garden in China, you may want to skip this one and spend your time in other attractions.

title: Gardens and shopping galore
content: I really felt like I was in China, at least what I had imagined China to be like before I arrived. The rest of the city is modern, clean and lively. This garden is very serene in contrast to the packed shopping area outside the grounds. We bought some local art inside the garden's art shop, very relaxed shopping, and then outside the garden, haggling, loud, crowded, but stil fun. The garden has signs in English which explain the interesting history of how the gardens and temples survived. It is definitely worth a visit. There is also a pleasant tea house in the garden. Outside, there's a Starbucks, large stores and small shops, kiosks with good prices on souvenirs, and throngs of shoppers.

title: Delightful gardens
content: It took a while to find this as it was hidden in then middle of a busy shopping area. But there are signposts, just need to look carefully. Well worth a visit. Personally my favourite place that we visited in Shanghai.

title: Beautiful and Serene
content: This is a garden surrounded by a must visit of shops and restaurants. It can be crowded with both international as well as local visitors on the weekend. It is fun and inside the garden is a serene and beautiful example of a high end home.

title: I was just there ... 30 minutes ago
content: Teeming with Chinese internal tourists! Very few foreigners.

title: Peace & tranquility just over a fence
content: This place is amazing. This might be a controversial statements - but I like to tell friends - why go all the way to Suzhou for more 'traditional chinese gardens' when you can find the best in the region just here in Shanghai. The twists and turns in this place offer a new photogenic shot every few metres and as an escape from the hustle bustle outside this place is a masterpiece in design and escape.

title: Peaceful haven
content: A lovely garden in typical Chinese style, away from the hustle and bustle of modern China. Worth a visit, time to reflect and relax.

title: Overcrowded
content: Yuyuan is overcrowded in general, as one of Shanghai's main attractions and very much advertised, full of tourists, cheap souvenir shops, not a place where one could relax when you can hardly even move. Nevertheless, the old gardens as well as the temple and a tea house are well preserved and worth a visit. Personally I believe there are other parks in the city, where you get more of a feel of people relaxing and enjoying themselves, maybe not as historical as this one. If you have a half a day to spare, I'd drive to Suzhou (1,5 h or 20 min on a speed train) that has a lot nicer parks.

title: Interesting
content: There were so crowded of people. An interesting place. This place also completed with a very large souvenir market. Just don't get lost your group there.

title: Don't forget the Garden
content: Visiting Yuyuan is a must do Shanghai experience, but do not forget to get past the crowded shopping and dining and visit the historic formal gardens. The entry fee is low and once you step inside you are in a tranquil setting, a welcome escape from the crush outside. Wander among the various gardens and buildings and see the architecture and garden designs that will take you to a different era of Chinese history.

title: Oasis among the old town mayhem!
content: It's plonk in the middle of a massive market/shopping area and as such, once you're inside it's like a world removed.

title: Have to do Shanghai thing
content: Yu Gardens is great place to visit. The shops are selling all sorts of food and gifts. You can get some real quirky Chinese gifts here. There is a small fee to get into the actual garden. Worth a visit if you are here as a tourist. However the highlight is the tea house in the middle of the lake. You access via the zig-zag bridge.Because evil spirits can only travel in a straight line they can not make it taccross this bridge to the tea house. So you will be perfectly safe there.

title: Over Rated
content: this is a crowded tourist spot with low level goods. you must bargain to get a good price or you will be taken advantage of time after time. i liked it better before they"fixed" it and the surrounding streets.

title: Amazing day
content: Between the glorious garden area, the nearby Bund, the cluster of shops around the gardens and the dumpling restaurant that has been there over 100 years, this was probably the best day we had in our entire trip of China

title: [close to] original Chinese Architecture
content: A really great place to visit to see some (close to) original Chinese Architecture, right in the middle of the City. Be aware of pushy sellers, never buy from the first shop, not a lot of pick pockets, but be careful just the same, good to visit and buy those last minute nick nacks to stuff into a loaded suit case. Try not to go on a public holiday and better if you can go during a local work day.

title: Beware of scams at Yu garden
content: I will let the other reviewers write about the place and concentrate on the scams I witnessed 3 times in 2 hours. Basically you can be approached by either a couple or 2 girls. They will wave their cell phone asking you to take a picture of them. Then, a trained speech will start.

title: Yu Garden (Yuyuan Shanghai China)
content: Absolutely blown away by this garden / parkland. Surrounded by many very special sights and a large skyline this Garden is peaceful, quiet and tranquil. Simply an amazing place to relax and unwind

title: Leave the beaten path
content: This is one of the most fascinating places when you explore the side streets around the tourist trap. Yuyuan is full of tourists, cheap souvenirs and overcrowded in general. Nevertheless, the old gardens in the center as well as the temple are true gems. Many people miss them, because they are kind of hidden within all the shops and masses. The side streets around resemble the true attraction, since there are a piece of intact old Shanghai. Go into one of the small alleyways that are to small for cars and let yourself drift through that old housing area. A microcosm of street life, shoe makers, gambling huts, shady massage mini massage parlors and cheap local restaurants...I love the atmosphere. I have done it 50 times and always find something new that I have missed before.

title: well preserved chinese garden
content: If Shangai is the only spot you visit in China  you can find a  nice typical Chinese garden.Otherwise wait Beijing

title: Peaceful
content: Came here on my second day in China. Lovely peaceful setting and lovely introduction to a Chinese garden.  Different " rooms" within the garden.

title: Crowded but a great place to take pictures
content: Yes, you will see a lot of tourists come to this place. However, there are so many things I liked about this place. I loved the bridge, the pond, rock carvings, and the Chinese architecture from the Ming Dynasty. This is a pretty nice place despite it being situated in the hustle and bustle area of Shanghai. It's 5 acres and was built in 1577. It's just a few blocks south of the Bund.

title: despite crowds a break from some madness
content: Yu Garden is attached but separate from Old Town. Yu Garden is not everyone's cup of tea but has beautiful grounds of ponds, flora, rocks and buildings as well as history behind it. without the crowds it would be serene but you are unlikely to be there in such a state. traditional chinese design present everywhere. care must be taken to traverse some of the paths (rocks over a pond) as people are coming and going. the grounds are more extensive than one would think and there is no specific path to follow.

title: A Shanghai Must See
content: There are several areas of Yu Yuan Garden. The garden is surrounded by a shopping area for momentos. Chinese clothing. chopsticks, chops. food, toys ... At the end of the street is a great building with antiques, jewelry, beads, coral ... A great experience of Shanghai. Avoid on the weekend as it gets much to busy to enjoy it.

title: Go early and try to avoid the weekend...
content: Amused myself by seeing how I could take snapshots W I T H O U T people in the picture - it was ideal weather, peak time on a weekend and the place was REALLY mobbed - actually it is rather vast and great place to get lost in (nearly a maze) and kids would really like it (give thumbs-up for a tour with the offspring) as they clearly seemed to - it felt a bit tired (and the sales people were sleeping propped up behind the counters) and worn but it is most certainly not without charm or intrigue - hawkers abound everywhere around this place and you will have to don your titanium shield of impenetrability (as you can't even communicate to them: "Do I even LOOK like somebody who is S H O P P I N G?")

title: larger than i expected
content: but as others have mentioned, very crowded.  if you want to take pictures, try to get ahead of the crowd or double back…amazing rocks.  may was a good time to visit as the blooming azaleas added bright spots of color to an otherwise monochromatic scene.

title: If you can see only one typical Chinese garden
content: This is probably the best traditional Chinese garden in Shanghai.

title: Immerse yourself in the buzzling Yu Garden
content: No doubt the Yu Garden (Yuyuan) is one of the must-see landmarks in Shanghai.

title: Traditional Cultural Chinese Market
content: The famous Nanxiang restaurant is near the entrance of Yu Garden, selling various types of delicious steamed dumplings. The tasty food attracts a swarm of locals and tourists. The Temple of the City God, Shanghai Old Street and Chenxiangge Nunnery are also near Yuyuan Garden and all these sites represent typical Shanghai.

title: Yuyuan Garden in Shanghai
content: This garden used to be a private garden that took 20 years to build. Beautiful but you need a guide to explain the meaning of what you see inside the garden like why a dragon has 3 claws and another has 4 claws. The openings or portals along the walls serve as frames for what you see beyond the "holes". The trees and the rockeries are well chosen. I'm sure this garden was a source of peace and quiet meditation for the owner! It's just sad that the father for whom this garden was built did not see its completion.

title: Beautiful
content: Yu Yuan is full of small little shops with beautiful Chinese architectures. There's a really nice restaurant called Lvbolang restaurant. It has really nice Shanghai food. It is worth doing, you can take beautiful pictures and walk around the areas, with small little shops. You can also have some nice Shanghai dumplings here!

user_loc: 英国埃文河畔布德拉夫
title: Highly recommended
content: A good place to visit.  Several souvenir shops, nice food places and great to take in the sights.  Of course, not forgetting the famous Shanghai Dumplings restaurant.

title: Peaceful
content: Although there were a great deal of people visiting the garden I was able to experience the serenity and peacefulness that the garden provided for its visitors in the past

title: great garden
content: nice garden, this is a most in Shanghai, beautiful traditional garden .. Try to avoid shops on the main routes as they will be the most expensive. or really bargin if they ask for  20 go to at least 8.

title: Chinese Garden
content: Interesting walk through the market place surrounding the Yu Garden.  The historic buildings and garden is beautifully maintained and a must visit site.

title: The ancient garden worth the visit !!
content: Pay to get in ! But lots of history inside ! Amazing garden with bluffing contrast between ancient construction and modern buildings !

title: Very historic place.
content: The Yu Garden  has many old building and beautiful architect. Also a main shopping area where you can buy everything from small thing to all kind of name brand watches

title: Go early! Awesome gardens!
content: Such a wonderful garden! We were lucky to go with no crowd! Enjoyed this visit!  So nice to get away right in downtown! Beautiful

title: Another must see
content: Our tour only visit 3 areas while we were in shanghai:

title: Good shopping but avoid weekends
content: This is a good place to bring guests or to check out if you're a tourist. Try to avoid shops on the main routes as they will be the most expensive. Use Chinese to bargain. If you can't speak Mandarin, try to bring a friend to help you bargain. Avoid weekends and holidays as the crowds are quite overwhelming.

title: Its ok to have a look around
content: The garden is a nice getaway from all the hordes, but you may find the hordes with you. its a nice garden in the middle of a shopping for trinkets area. If shopping haggle like there is no tomorrow and never ever pay full price

title: Magnificent
content: The intricacies of this Chinese garden are truly stunning, and a total contrast from the surrounding area of old Shanghai. There were large tour groups when we were there - better to go when it is quieter, probably early in the morning. This is a must if you haven't visited Shanghai before

title: Crowded but beautiful
content: Typical Chinese private garden... Worth a visit. Especially recommended with a tour guide... You can see the 5 classical elements of water, wood, gold, earth and plants represented. The scenry changes at every turn... For families with children: could be fun to feed the enormous fish in the pond...

title: 豫园必看哦！Lovely garden and souvenir shops
content: This is definitely one of the most visited spots in Shanghai! In walking distance from the Westin Hotel in Shanghai which costs around 1500yuan per night, Yu Yuan has many tourist shops for souvenirs, jewelries, and other fancy restaurants! I first visited back in Aug 2010, and it was so CROWDED AND HOT!! Recommending coming here in autumn, winter, or spring instead because it's NOT as crowded. Here there are Baozi restaurants that have straws in their to suck the soup out)) Visited also in Nov 2012, Dec 2011, and Mar 2014.

title: Crowded, noisy, touristy, beautiful.....
content: First visit the labyrinth of narrow streets with shops and vendors, feel the smell of street food and see the colors of the market , ant then enjoy the peace of the garden. Unique experience!

title: Great place to visit
content: From what I can tell there are different parts of the Yu Gardens.. The part I visited wasn't much of a garden, but rather an area of shops and souvenir vendors. I really enjoyed exploring the streets and making some purchases, but from what I've read in other comments, there are also actual "gardens".

title: Magnificent Place!
content: Not only are there gardens but bridges, stones, pagodas and streams filled with large fish and turtles. This is surrounded by a very large touristy market area filled with interesting small shops as well as 2 Starbucks and even the only Hagen Daz we saw during our 2 weeks in China.

title: Beautiful, crowded
content: It is better to have an explanation in english. The garden itself is beautiful, with ¥40 per person for admission. But due to the crowded, i wasn't enjoying much of the garden view. Inside, there're so many paths. It is better to provide an efficient way to pass all the site inside garden, coz one can easily get lost inside. If you haven't see any chinese garden, this is a recommended, otherwise the fee is not worth to pay.

title: Romantic garden
content:
Well kept, small but flowery. The historic touch adds to the flavour.
The path to the garden through the market area is equally pleasant.

title: Just FABULOUS place
content: A visit to the Yuyan Gardens is amazing,best part is the tea house in the middle of the pond in the public shopping bazaar,the bazaar has the best shopping for things,I loved is there I went 2 days shopping there.A must for any visitor,just haggle for everything. Note, if strangers ask you to take photos of or with them be suspicious,they try to lure you somewhere with conversation.

title: Pretty buildings but commercialised
content: This is an area of old fashioned Chinese buildings with tea houses and shops selling pearls, silk and other souvenirs. Very commercial now with MacDonalds, Starbucks and Dairy Queen but it's still worthwhile. I have been during the day and at night when it is all lit up and both are beautiful. The restaurant over the koi pond is nice and fairly reasonable as well as the food court on the middle

title: Peaceful retreat
content: These gardens are in the centre of the Old Town of Puli. There is an entrance fee for admission to the gardens. There are all sorts of small, secret areas which you find as you walk around. The ponds, with their fish, are very attractive to children. It is a very relaxing place in the centre of a bustling shopping centre.

title: A Shanghai must visit
content: One of the most lovely gardens I've seen in China.  Surprisingly tranquil in parts given the large numbers of people that can be there.  A nice way to spend a couple of hours in Shanghai.

title: too mani visitors
content: Beautiful place, but horders of tourists make it like an italian beach in full summer.Try to go very early in the morning and if you are lucky you can hear the birds...

title: Over-rated and rather small
content: You Yuan Garden is pleasant enough but nothing special compared, for instance to the classic formal gardens of Suzhou. Bus loads of tourists flock here but spend most of their time in the mock- classic streets of the Bazaar.

title: Traditional Chinese style garden close to Wai Tan
content: Traditional Chinese style garden that at times when crowded is a little tight to walk around and enjoy. It costs 40RMB to enter the gardens but well worth it when not visiting on a holiday. Has its own metro stop so easy to get to and worth a visit.

title: May Day
content: i dont know why but i happened to land here on may day.the place was full.we were packed like a can of sardines .hundreds in line to cross the zig zag bridge.but it was worth the wait.the garden is small but fantastic

title: Beautiful!
content: The Yu Garden is a must go for all travellers. The garden is beautiful and very well mantained. The shopping area outside the garden is a paradise for shoppers offering cheap and good quality electronic gadgets.

title: Better not on a Sunday
content: I went to the Yu Yuan five years ago on a weekend and it really was a lovely experience of being in a tranquil Chinese garden. Last Sunday I went with some friends, including one who is 75 years old. It took us the better part of 90 minutes to find the entrance, we began to think it was a little like the Harry Potter movies trying to find platform 103/4. Indeed the entrance is a lot smaller than the surrounding shops and there are lots these days.

title: Cultural heritage
content: The tour of the garden reflects on the culture and heritage of China...Also a guided tour is recommended coz you u only get to know the significance of the symbols, architecture and other important things at this place.Beware of the fakes and tourist traps around this place...there is lot of shopping around this place and ensure you bargain well...(100 = 20!! yeah u read it right....)

title: The Crowds, The Crowds!!
content: The crowds are impossible to escape and even in a serene garden you are being pushed and jostled. The garden itself is quite pretty and is an escape from all the surrounding hawkers and shops. I would visit during the week and not on a weekend.

title: Pleasant spot in the middle of the city
content: Pretty garden oasis in the middle of downtown chaos. Temple is right near the gardens.. There is a very busy market that surrounds the gardens.

title: Not quite what we expected
content: Busy with people so tranquility hard to find. Hidden shops every turn too. I would send more time looking at the side streets and the nearby temple than visiting here.

title: Attractive, but very crowded
content: The gardens are traditional Chinese style and beautiful. But they are surrounded by a very tacky area of tourist shops, and because they are small and widely advertised they were absolutely heaving with people when we visited. We preferred our visits to many other Shanghai parks, where we got more of a feel of people relaxing and enjoying themselves.

title: A beautiful oasis in the city
content: This is a lovely garden, even with the crowds of Shanghai. The curling dragon along the top of the courtyard wall, the ponds and bright coy, the pavilions and halls, the shaded gardens, the covered pathway, the Jade Rock, are all beautiful. Definitely would have liked more time to explore and sit and soak in the atmosphere and hope to in the future.

title: Beautiful garden.
content: I loved so much about the garden.  I loved the statues, the rock formations, the flowers , the meandering path and the buildings in the area.  It was a nice contrast to the hustle and bustle of Shanghai.

title: Lovely peaceful garden
content: We received a very interesting talk from our guide on history of garden and the feng shui principles used in the garden layout. Very attractive.

title: Most beautiful
content: An absolute must to see, so worth the visit and surrounding area too a wonderful find.  Beware though thousands and thousands of people congregate here.

title: A Maze of Eastern Delights
content: The garden is delightful -once you get to it. It is really crowded but worth seeing. I made that my first destination and then took my time to wonder the maze of food, clothes, instruments - you name it, they have it there. It is a great way to spend a day. The buildings alone are worth seeing- great detail and craftmanship. It is a huge tourist attraction, in fact the signs to this destination says "Tourist Mart. Regardless, it is an enjoyable spot to experience.

title: Wish I had more time here...
content: There's a lot to see. From trying unique snacks (huge lines for the popular ones), to shopping at little shops...everything is quite cheap.

title: BEAUTIFUL! :)
content: Located in the heart of the most traditional area of Shanghai, Yu Gardens is simply beautiful. Only 40 Chinese Yaun to go in, you are able to wonder around someones old gardens and parts of their home. All traditional Chinese symbols (lions guarding the doors, dragon protecting the home, different shaped doors, frog symbols on the ground for good luck) and temples are here and the flowers and rivers are beautiful.

title: Lovely place to visit.
content: An oasis of beauty in the midst of a very busy city!  Beautiful old trees, buildings, gardens, ponds and fish.  If you haven't seen anything like this before I would definitely recommend you go.

title: Yu Garden
content: The gardens are in the middle of chaos.  But they were beautiful.  There is shopping surrounding the gardens.

title: Nice Garden and well maintained
content: Nice garden and a really cool place to visit in Shanghai. You can see crockery here. This garden was a private property before, later on Chinese govt helping to maintain it. Very happy to be here.

title: Gardens
content: This place is paradise on Earth, A very pleasant walk around the gardens gives you a refreshingly peaceful start to any day

title: Nice but could do with some maintenance
content: The gardens were really busy with organized tours so hard to appreciate. The buildings are a little run down. Pleasant place to spend a couple of hours.

title: One of the unique environments in the World on Saturdays and Sundays
content: It was our first visit to this place in Shanghai on Saturday! and we were all shocked by what we saw! Hundreds of almost old people with Thousands of A4 handwritten ads in Chinese were sitting all over the park, and hundreds of other people were visiting them. Go there to figure out what is happening :).

title: Nice garden in the middle of chaos
content: Once you get to the area where you need to a ticket to enter the Garden, it is beautiful and peaceful. The garden itself contains lots of small buildings, small bridges, trees, etc. Although not big, it is definitely worth seeing. You can hire some student-volunteers on site to take you around the garden but make sure they're wearing a badge.

title: Great spot to visit with a few hours
content: Beautiful spot in the middle of a busy city.  Most of the signs have English, so I was able to get by on my own.  Crazy, touristy shopping right outside.

title: Beautiful Chinese settings waiting for you to photograph
content: This is a wonderful Chinese garden just waiting for you to photograph each beautiful setting, one after another, and the architectural details are just gorgeous. Look for the smallest details on some of the structures, if you enjoy that. Plenty of perfect photographic backgrounds, and each spot takes you back to years and years ago when this garden was created. So glad we enjoyed it all.

title: An Oasis in the Middle of One of the World's Biggest Cities
content: While YuYuan can be very touristy, it is worth the trouble if for no other reason than to get out of the hustle and bustle of Shanghai. Go early in the day for smaller crowds and cooler temperatures. There are two entrances to the actual gardens. If you are sixty or older it's worth learning how to tell them that in Chinese because you get in for half-price. Once inside just wander around until you find your way out again. The garden is quite old and the buildings are great examples of classic Chinese architecture.

title: Ying and Yang...Zig and Zag
content:
Loved the zig-zag bridge built to guard off evil spirits.  The Yu Gardens are a tranquil spot .
Enjoyed wandering thru the beautiful gardens.

title: Peaceful and gracious
content: Now this is a place you need time to appreciate how the wealthy lived in the past. What a tranquil place with such interesting little places to visit and explore. take at least a full morning to explore to truly appreciate the Gardens and their beauty

user_loc: 斯洛伐克布拉迪斯拉发
title: Beautiful place
content: I loved to walk in this area. Recalls old time charm and is build to impress tourist. Was crowded and noisy but charming. Small shops and restaurants with great food.

title: Beautiful gardens
content: Really atmospheric garden with beautiful architecture and steeped in history and cultural significance. A must see.

title: The bazaar is full of touts
content: I went to the Bazaar around 3 times but didnt make it to the Gardens which I regret. The bazaar will give you the sh@ts if you hate being pestered as you will be approached over and over again but touts wanting to sell you selfie sticks or flashing roller skates. The bazaar itself is nice to look at but go early or else you will bump into people all the time if you are looking at the buildings The buildings are full of souviners, and the streets outside the bazaar are full of 10y shops. This is an attraction purely to take money out of your wallet. I found nothing attractive about it, which is why I regret not going to the gardens as this could of changed my perspective.

title: China: repetition and repeat.
content: Chinese landmarks are not there for you. They are there to make money from domestic tourists. Yu Garden is a perfect example of this: fake ancient buildings built to give locals the feelings that the long for, but alongside 20 million other locals all bustling, jostling, and longing for the same thing. Read all the other review for what is good here (everything being able to be found at more reasonable locations and at better prices), and learn from this review that it's a place you ought only visit once, just like the people from every other province in China.

title: Nice garden
content: Overall the garden is amazing but the rest of the temple is too commercial. If you are in Shanghai you should go. If you walk East from the Garden you will find yourself in some of the Old Hutongs (Old houses) which are fun to walk through.

title: If you need souvenirs
content: Small Garden is just a part of this place. The other part is souvenir area within an old traditional closed block. Lots of things, which is nice. But loooots of people. Be ready to work out your elbows through the crowd.

title: This is Qing China as Disney would see it
content: Two things spoilt our trip to Yu Gardens. It is on all the coach tour group itineraries so there are huge numbers of tourists.
