We were there on a Friday but apparently at the weekend it is worse. Okay, we were also there as tourists and so contributed to the numbers but peaceful it isn't. The second thing is that it all appears so perfectly preserved and presented that it could be in Disneyland along with hundreds of tourists shops in the area outside the garden. Just didn't feel authentic. Our guide told us that it had all been rebuilt/renovated relatively recently so may be that's why. There are better things in Shanghai.

title: An interesting place to visit
content: This garden is a peaceful place away from the hustle and bustle outside. It is easy to walk around and the spring flowers and trees were lovely. There are different halls in different areas of the garden that are of historical importance. You can sit down in various places around the gardens to enjoy the peace and quiet. There is a souvenir shop within the garden area. This was a lovely, peaceful place to visit in Shanghai.

title: wow, interesting peaceful place
content: loved the nooks and crannies, how the trees and foliage and buildings all seemed to merge together. could have used a map as it was difficult to find the place where our group agreed to meet. and a bit too many people. still, quite spots could be found.

title: Amazing Garden
content: Even though it was drizzling the gardens were magnificent. The flowers in spring are devine and i have never seen so many fish! A must see and after you can shop to your hearts content. But you will find barganung hard.

title: Childhood memories...
content: For someone growing up in Shanghai as a child, coming back to this place brought a lot of memories. Grandpa was used to take me here for XiaoLongBao - the famous steam bun with soup inside. You will see the line up for them but you MUST try. If you don't want to line up for 40 minutes, just go upstairs to sit down and have them brought them to your table - but at much higher price - I think about US$20/pp. But worth every penny.

title: A little disappointing....
content: We were actually a little disappointed in this garden. First of all we actually had a hard time finding it. You must walk through the bazaar and while I did some shopping, then merchants were quite persistent and more then a little annoying. On the up side, they will take almost anything you offer them...just keep walking from one to the next and bargain as hard as you can. When you walk away they call you back!!

title: Hidden Gem
content: Quite a surprise to come across these beautiful gardens in the middle of a bustling city like Shanghai. Very pretty and serene.

title: Oasis in Shanghai
content: Interesting architecture and sights of interest. The gardens are a welcome break from the bustle of the city. Many markets, street vendors and shops in the area.

title: beauty in the heart of shanghai
content: really beautiful and everything you expect of a chinese garden, try to go in the morning or afternoon to avoid the crowds and busses. The tea house is always packed and so is the garden itself. You can get amazing pictures there. Remember the cost of everything there is going to be more expensive. Be aware of the prices and tourist traps.

title: Just another tourist joint
content: You can walk around the garden and enjoy touching the fish in the pond.  out side there are shops for souvenirs and many restaurants includingStarbuck

title: A ROMANTIC PLACE
content: it's Full Of Lamp on the Building ...  so many food around here ... Xiao Long Bao & DIM SUM, its a GOOD Choice ... We'll be here again when visiting Shanghai...

title: Go here for shopping and Bazaars and see gardens too
content: Best shopping in China so far, lovely setting with the hustle and bustle but not just set up for tourists that all the guides take you to.

title: Yu Garden is a "Must See" in Shanghai
content: Step back into the Ming Dynasty as you enter the Yu Gardens. This beautiful home and gardens takes you back over 500 years to how old Shanghai once was. It's an incredible place to visit and a "must see" if you really want to explore Shanghai/ It will be crowded with locals and tourists, so take your time (one hour is plenty) and be sure to stop by the famous shops as you exit. There's also a Starbucks there if you crave some good old American coffee. Of course, the Starbucks is less than 500 years old! But, it fits in nicely among the ancient shops.

title: Great Visit to Yu Garden
content: Every time we visit Shanghai we have come to the Yu Garden. My wife likes the shopping in the area as well as the sculptures and ponds in the garden complex itself. There is some very nice Asian art to view and for sale in some of the shops in the garden. It is also a good opportunity for an energetic walk in Shanghai with lots to see.

title: Park is nice, but the shopping is better
content: walk through the park, but look for the small multi-floored shopping center where you can find great souvenirs for very little money

title: don't bother
content: Lots of people, but nothing special. If you have seen the gardens in Beijing, or the Forbidden City, than give this a miss. Better to spend your time in the nearby market. Now that was exciting!

title: Idyllic and romantic
content: It is one of the most beautiful places to visit in Shanghai. We loved the various gardens, lakes and buildings. It looks like a large maze and you move through the various gardens, each is different.

title: Happy shopping
content: Here you can buy very traditional stuffs from Shanghai, see what the local culture is, make sure you pay for a manpower "taxi" for a short tour inside of the garden.

title: Always a great place to visit
content: The Yu Gardens and surrounding markets are always fun to visit. On this particular time it was very busy because it was a holiday. You could hardly move. We went to a tea house close to the entry for the Yu Gardens and have a tea ceremony. It was lovely and the girl was very knowledgable.

title: A old garden made for tourist
content: This is a tourist attraction spot. It has a lot of shop which sell souvenir, snack and food, and it is better to visit at night, as the view is more better with the lighting. Those love stinky tofu, try the stinky tofu! This place is overcrowded but it is worth to visit to try all the street food snack! If you want, you can stay at Ibis Yu Garden, it is a 3 minute walk to Yu Garden!

title: Not much for the temple, but the shopping around is amazing!
content: There are many commodity markets around here. If you ignore the smells and sounds, one can find whatever literally!

title: A garden that should be visited
content: Yu Garden is in the top 5 places to be visited in Shanghai. You enter this garden throuh the old streets full of tourist shops. The watch sellers can annoy you with their persistency. Try to visit the garden during weekdays to avoid weekend crowds. You can see people from all around the world while strolling through the narrow paths in the garden. The red fishes in the pond before entering the garden make a marvellous picture. The inside is quite relaxing. You can enjoy seeing many different flowers and greenery. There are also old style houses full of old furnitures and Buddhas. This place is a must see attraction for every Shanghai visitors.

title: Well worth visiting but be prepared for the crowds
content: This garden is a must when visiting Shanghai but get there early to avoid the crowds. Situated in the old city, the garden is the central part of a massive complex of shops, temples and tea houses all built in the pagoda style. You can easily spend a full day wandering around here. Spring is a great time to visit as the blossom trees are blooming and look lovely.

title: Nice, but touristy and very busy
content: Certainly worth a visit, and a great backdrop for your photos, but get there early!!! This is a huge tourist destination and the area fills up to capacity quickly. Arrive before the Yu Garden opens to take a few shots of the pretty buildings in the surrounding shopping plazas, admire the koi fish and turtles along the zig-zag walkway, avoid the many old men hawking watches and chinsy toys, and then duck into the paid Garden area as early as possible to ensure a leisurely stroll within the picturesque and peaceful walled enclosure.

title: Gardens interesting if a little crowded
content: The retail area outside is very popular with Chinese tourists plus caters for a few Westerners. It was very crowded and a bit of a tourist trap filled with tacky souvenirs and fast food. We wouldn't return.

title: The Rocky Wall--amazing
content: This small garden is fascinating. We saw old furniture of the colonial (and before) days, we saw old architecture, more jade and buddhas, and most particularly the Rocky Walls, all hand built many years ago and now preserved. You can have tea in the tea garden, sit in different places, but you cannot get away from the crowds. I would highly recommend not going on a weekend if you can help it as Sunday seemed to be a peak day and people do not hesitate to push and shove. But it was very very interesting. No regrets. And, make sure to show an ID testifying that you are over 60 if you are as you get a half price ticket!!!

title: Winter best time to visit to avoid crowds
content: I lived in Shanghai and avoided this place in the warm months when it was shoulder to shoulder people.  Best to visit in winter when you can explore the many alleys and buildings with some solidarity to take in the beauty.

title: Peaceful garden in the middle of "old town"
content: Yu garden is quite big area, it has some kind of calming tranquility and peacefulness. The old town can feel crowded and chaotic, but this garden is separated by high walls and you can well rest here and even enjoy a thé ceremony in one of their pavillions at moderate price of something like 30 juan per person for selection of average 5 different thés, at least during my two or three visits recently. Good area to take photos and have a small break in one of the many buildings. Area is a bit like a labyrint, maybe that is one reason why it is so faschinating.

title: The best place by far !!
content: I loved this place and the surrounding market, it was so much fun! And they have all sorts of street food, Starbucks and all you can eats.

title: A must stop when in shanghai
content: So many things to do here . Great history and gardens to view , lots of shopping for souvenirs , many kinds of foods including those famous soup dumplings found on TV in the USA and certainly people watching , tourists from all over the world can be seen here .

title: Beautiful oasis in the middle of city
content: Traditional feel of the garden.  However, too crowded to get any nice pictures.  Crowd can be quite rowdy.  Surrounding the garden is full of shops selling traditional crafts to very modern stuff too

title: Very good history of generational perspective
content: Beautifully set up, very interesting history on protection against "ghosts," the different symbols of dragons, education

title: Garden Interesting buildings and rock formations
content: Entrance is located at the end of the zigzag walkway. 40-CNY for entrance. This garden is a classical Chinese garden built in 1559. It gets crowded so go early or late in the afternoon. Tour groups and those taking selfies tend to block the narrow walkways. It is a worthwhile visit.

title: Too beautiful
content: It is hard to imagine this peaceful beautiful garden in the middle of a busy city and adjoining a busy shopping area.  The beautiful structures, ponds, gardens and walkways make for a most enjoyable visit.

title: A haven of calm inside the bustle
content: Lovely gardens with ponds and rivers full of carp. Lots of blossom when we visited in spring. Interesting corners with lots tucked into a small space. Concession for over 60's, even non- Chinese.

title: Beautifull
content: Too many people makes visit not exelent

title: Very impressive attraction, worth the time.
content: We spent the best part of the morning walking around this garden. It was very attractive and had much to see -- good for photographers.

title: Real great old Chinese house complex
content: We thought seeing a garden, and we saw a garden, but you mostly see the house of a very rich Chinese in older times, and it's garden surrounding the houses , and it's really worth seeing it, so many trees, flowers, fish, monuments.

title: Fascinating garden
content: I have to admit I did not have a high level of expectation when visiting this garden as it was near the end of our tour, but after entering and seeing the huge lake inside filled with coy fish and turtles I was pleasantly surprised. I really enjoyed walking down the many pathways and finding a different surprise around each corner. It was also nice to walk through the old town to get there. The bathrooms were also very nice there.

title: Beautiful Garden
content:
The Garden and buildings are amazing, even though they have had to be rebuilt, they are still over 100 yrs old.  Very peaceful area in the middle of crazy shopping area.  
However AVOID the weekends if crowds make you crazy.

title: Inventive, Beautiful, Historic
content: Built by a private individual for the peace of his parents in their old age, it is one of the few remaining examples of its kind. Located in "Old Town" Shanghai, the buildings are ornate, the waterways convoluted to make them seem larger than they are. Stunning carvings in wood and stone, dragons galore, ancient trees and colorful flowers. great was to spend a couple of hours and surrender to the tranquility and peace in the garden.

title: Worth the visit
content: Lot's to see and plenty of good pictures to be taken here. Expect to see Traditional Chinese buildings, trees, flowers, lake with fish, caves and much more.

title: Wonderful Garden in the Middle of Shanghai
content: If you are in the Yu Yuan Market you have to make a stop at its garden - it's extensive so set aside at least 2hrs to 3hrs to fully enjoy it, take pictures, and sit and have a small snack. Hire a private tour guide but don't pay more than 10usd. Entrance fee is about 5usd. If you are inside the market finding the entrance could be difficult - my advice is to exit the market and take the road where your bearings are easier to manage (take a tourist map or find the market maps which are located in each of the market entrances). My advice is to get there early - right when it opens since by 1030am-1130am the tour buses arrive one after another until closing time. After the gardens, you can stroll the market, have lunch there and visit the world famous tea houses!!!

title: Oasis in the middle of Shanghai
content: Aside from The Bund and the Pudong side of Shanghai, this would be my other must-see in Shanghai. Housed in a stunning complex of shops and restaurants built with traditional Chinese pagoda-style architecture and replete with a multitude of vendors selling everything from selfie sticks to fine silk scarves to delicious dumplings, the Yu Garden was a highlight of our stay in Shanghai.

title: Tranquility in the midst of a bustling city.
content: Located in the midst of a bustling city surrounded by shopping and street food vendors. For 40 yuan entrance fee, you get a glimpse of old times buildings, ponds and trees. For us going in April,we got spring blooms and good weather. Bathrooms are NICE and alone worth the 40 yuans...

title: Beautiful little oasis
content: This is a beautiful oasis of calm tucked away in a bustling city. The gardens are wonderful and the buildings give a brief glimpse of history. I could have spent all day there.

title: Lots of beauty to see
content: This garden has a few hundred years of history (1559) dating back to the Ming Dynasty when a government officer had it built for his aging parents. There are plenty of little spaces to explore and experience.

title: Beautiful
content: This is a beautiful garden with lots of history. The shopping when you enter or leave is high pressure but they are definitely willing and wanting to bicker and bargain. Don't pay more than half for anything!

title: wonderful gardens
content: I was lucky enough to be there on a warm and sunny day and I was not disappointed. I followed the advice of my guide which suggested to go there early to avoid crowds and tour groups. The gardens are well taken care of and you can see many turtles swimming in the ponds.

title: Atmospheric
content: It was very busy the day we visited but an excellent buzz. The tea ceremony we visited was delightful. Keep your belongings safe while here.

user_loc: 明尼苏达明尼阿波利斯
title: Gorgeous Garden
content: This is a must in my opinion for any traveler to Shanghai. Especially if you can't make it to the gardens in Suzhou, come here for a taste of traditional Chinese garden design. The garden is lovely in itself, but it's also a nice break from the craziness of the big city. Do be careful of a couple things: it's really difficult to find the garden (you have to go through a maze of shops and a huge crowd by some old tea house), and we also got lost trying to find our way out (try to get a map as you go in - we missed that somehow). Besides that, though, the garden was fantastic! Great for tons of pictures and fun for all ages.

title: A lot of garden in a small place
content: Very well designed garden with lots of features and spaces. Worth a visit if you are in the area. Hard to believe one if the buildings would have been the highest point in Shanghai 400 years ago

title: spectacular
content: worth a visit, a quite oasis in the world's biggest city! unfortunately many other tourists had the same idea at the same time.

title: Beautiful Tranquil Garden Surrounded in Chaos
content: Lovely garden in the middle of the crazy busy city, past a market, lines of people waiting for steamed buns, koi fish, hundreds of market stalls selling tourist trinkets and food on sticks. Don't go at the weekend or a bank holiday as you will come across all the hordes of cruise ship tourists as well as Chinese tourists, and Europeans with their guides. Worth visiting and going with your own guide to be able to understand the history and traditions that made this garden so special.

title: Yu Gardens, Shanghai
content: Beautiful gardens with crowds of people. historically speaking,it was an  amazing maze of pavillions andsetions to explore. Definitely worth a visit.

title: Shops and culture
content: I enjoyed the shops around more than the garden. More culture with the locals and haggling! Maybe if the garden was not so busy you could get some better pictures and view

title: Great Garden, only saw a very small part of it.
content: This is a must see, its very touristy, but it has some very neat shops to browse around, and what we saw of the garden was nice. We only had an hour to walk around, and it was mostly spent shopping. We went to the Starbucks there and bought a beautiful mug that had a painting of Yu Garden on the side. The mugs are a series of different places around the world. We didn't realize that we could probably only get this mug inside Yu Garden as none of the other Shanghai Starbucks carried this one, glad we bought it.

title: Oasis in a sea of tourist traps.
content: This is a beautiful, peaceful, garden in the middle of a bazaar.  It was somewhat crowded but much nicer than the melee outside! The rock formations and plants were impressive and the winding paths were very interesting as were the buildings.

title: Surprisingly Excellent!
content: The Yu garden are surprisingly excellent. The Yu garden is large. We spent about 2 hours at the garden. There are many ancient houses in the garden. We walked to the Bund after we finished the Yu Garden.

title: Well worth a visit
content: Push through the throng in the Yu Gardens shoppng area and you're rewarded with this lovely reconstructed garden. There are some really interesting architectural features like the zig-zag passageway and the stage/private theatre is really something else! Make sure you walk right up to the stage and look up at the carved ceiling!

title: I found a pretty part of Shanghai
content: Today I had a lovely morning wondering around the Yu Gardens. As many of the reviews say this is defiantly a prime tourist spot but I think going mid morning on a weekday helped with the crowds.

title: Lovely, but very busy.
content: These gardens have an interesting history and are a lovely oasis in the middle of this astonishing city. What I find surprising is how they appear to have escaped the Cultural Revolution unscathed (as I was told was the case).

title: Beautiful, but grossly overcrowded
content: It is very difficult to believe that you are in the middle of one of the biggest cities in the world in this beautiful garden which was built in the Ming Dynasty. No high rise buildings are visible, and no traffic noise is heard. The layout is stunning and very, very Chinese. However, I am reminded of a humorous travel brochure quotation - "People flock here in their millions to enjoy the solitude and tranquility". It is just too crowded. That aside, the garden is well worth seeing.

title: Busy but beautiful
content: The gardens are right next to a shopping area with many restaurants and stalls. Upon entering you feel a respite from the hustle and bustle in a tranquil setting. The day we visited had fewer people than expected. It was a nice easy walk with plenty of time and without feeling pushed or jostled about. There are places to sit and just let your thoughts go.

title: Beautiful setting
content: We really enjoyed strolling through the gardens. This place had very interesting architecture with lots of dragons. The ponds were great and had turtles in them. The historical rooms were well kept and had good info sheets for each room. The shops nearby were nice as well. This is definitely a touristy area, but I think it is a must see if you are going to Shanghai.

title: This provided a lovely opportunity for a walk around a Chinese garden.
content: A lovely garden with interesting stone formations, plants and fountains. It certainly helps to have a guide to explain the history and some of the symbolism in the garden as there are no Engish translations. The sculptures are fascinating but again, I am pleased we had a guide.

title: Beautiful gardens
content: My husband and I really enjoyed wandering around these beautiful gardens today. The gardens reflect a traditional design and you really felt like you were in China rather than any big city around the world.

title: Good place to visit
content: Peaceful atmosphere but packed with tourist. If this is the first time you visit Shanghai. This is the place you should visit.

user_loc: 德克萨斯州新布朗费尔斯
title: Definitely touristy
content: It's a beautiful garden with rocks, ponds, architecture and hordes of tourists. I was a tourist in March with a bus tour. I knew I was in trouble when I entered a queue that snaked back and forth before coming onto a pathway along a small lake going ONE WAY with security guards every few feet pushing the crowds along. I wouldn't have known where to sit down and enjoy the turtles and fish swimming around. Maybe go early in the morning if you want some peaceful time to yourself. The crowds around the garden itself were heavy too and again no where to sit down unless you were lucky enough to snag a seat at Starbucks. KFC was walk in only. We finally found a table and a beer around the corner in the not so busy area of Yu Yuan Garden Bazaar at a local establishment whose proprietor chased anyone off not buying from her. I totally get it, her tables, her drinks or out you go!

title: Beautiful Chinese Garden
content: yu garden is very beautiful and very crowded but you should see it because its a good way to know Chinese gardens,

title: Number 1 place to visit in Shanghai
content: The garden and the buildings around it were AWSOME.

title: beautiful yet crowded
content: The entire area is beautiful, designed like traditional Chinese area. Lot's of places to shop, eat and drink around. The garden is very pretty and well designed yet very crowded with tourists. great for a one time visit.

title: There is a fun market outside where you can buy anything
content: I spent an hour or so wandering around the Yu Garden Market. There are shops selling everything you can think of, including food. It is very crowed and they try to get you in there shops as you walk by, but overall safe. You will pay less than half of whatever they say the price is, sometimes significantly less than half. Make sure you barter. This is a great place to people watch and pick up your souvenirs. People sell all kinds of things on the street. We were even shown prices for women. Lots of fake goods, but it is dirt cheap. Get the kids a "Rolex"

title: Beautiful and relaxing garden in the city
content: If you looking to a diffrent area in shangai, more chinese traditional style, without tall buildings and shopping, yu garden it's the place you are looking for. the garden was built in 1559 in the Ming dinasty, and occupies an area of 2 hectares. the buildings are traditionally old chinese style, inside you can find lots of restaurants in the meantime you having a tour of the pavilions and the halls. it's for sure a great place where to spend a day in shangai, definetely worth it.

title: Very touristy, but surprisingly nice
content: You might have to beat the crowd as this is one of Shanghai's top tourist attractions. The surroundings are not really old and have hundreds of small shops selling all kinds of souvenirs. It is worth negotiating!

title: Tranquility
content: The Yugarden transports into a bygone era with its amazing architecture.A must visit while in Shanghai. Not only the garden but the area around has temples, excellent food and interesting shopping options like souvenirs, pearls and not to forget Chinese tea!

title: Market with all facets of chinese life
content: It is a very big market for allmost everything. You can buy clothes, kitchenware, books, ... and can enjoy many restaurants with different Food orientiation. There are also many artists there, which make right on the spot jewellery, porcelain, umbrellas, ...

title: A delight
content: Yu Garden is lovely. From its rockeries to quaint little bridges to weeping willows and bonsai

title: The Garden of Contentment is well named!
content: This is a garden unlike any other I have visited, so tranquil and calm.

title: One Man's Dream in Reality
content: This garden was built by one wealthy business man for his father, who actually never lived long enough to see it finished.

title: Garden of Contentment - A Quiet Trip Through Time
content: The Yu Garden located adjacent to the bustling Yuyuan Tourist Mart provides a quiet juxtaposition against the chaotic bramble of shops outside. While the haggling was fun, the garden provided a pleasant counterpoint. The centuries old garden is filled with interesting architecture, plants and hidden passages.

title: Almost like a maze
content: 30 rmb for admision price or 15 rmb with student Id. The entrance is located near the old tea place with small bridges or the famous dumpling place.

title: Reminder of historic Shanghai.
content: The garden itself is peaceful and contains structures from the Ming and Qing Dynasties. It is amazing to see something like this that has existed for hundreds of years in the middle of modern Shanghai and is worth a visit; however, the garden is surrounded by a faux Chinese touristy shopping area full of street vendors, tourist shops, restaurants, and touts, so be prepared.

title: Great area to walk around
content: Great area to walk around, walked from the bund to Yu Garden..The area not just inside Yu Garden, but the area around the garden is a great place to shop and find souvenirs...

title: One of the few gardens in Shanghai.
content: We spent a couple of hours wandering around the Yu Gardens in spring. It is nice but I would not call it world class as far as Chinese gardens go. It is government owned and not really that well maintained. I hope that they realise what a potential treasure they have on their hands and start to maintain and restore it. But all in all it is a nice escape in this bustling city.

title: Peaceful in the heart of shanghai
content: Very busy, but certainly worth the hustle and bustle to get there, once inside relaxing and peaceful. Beautiful and re energising

title: Alright
content: I was underwhelmed by this garden. The architecture wasn't that impressive, the greenery was less than spectacular, and it all has a slightly worn look. And it's full of people pushing along the narrow paths. It was still worth going, especially since it's right next to the Old Town, which is fun. But, unless you've never seen a Chinese garden, don't expect to be blown away.

title: Get an old taste of Shanghai, in the middle of a modern city
content: Yu Garden is a must visit for all travellers to Shanghai for the first time. The local food along with all the little stores selling the typical Chinese souvenire makes this an interesting visit for all ages. Yu Garden is always crowded with visitors, foreign and domestic, and makes it an interesting place for people watching as well.

title: Very nice place
content: The garden itself is very nice. The very concept of little ponds, small houses, nice hidden passages is very appealing. And then here is the "China town" in China - the merchant street outside of the garden - you can find everything there.

title: Excellent Classic Chinese Garden
content: This is worth seeing as an example of a Chinese garden.  Most of Shanghai was destroyed in World War II, so there is not that much original from before then like this

title: Lovely Garden near the crazy shopping area
content: This garden is well worth a visit. Tucked away in the middle of the big city, it offers a little respite from the crowds. The design is very clever, creating a faux hillside, and I loved the dragon wall. Most all of the plants are labelled and there were numerous flowering bonsai displayed throughout the garden. The shopping streets immediately adjacent to the garden are very busy and full of souvenir shops, this seemed calm by comparison even though there were a lot of people there.

title: Beautiful but very crowded
content: The garden is really beautiful and serene but most of the fun was gone because it was so crowded. So avoid it during weekends. The adjoining market is great and its close to the Bund.

title: Nice gardens and amazing bazaar
content: The Garden is really nice with typical Chinese buildings and temples, a lot of green spaces and lakes. There is a very fun bazar to buy all kind of Chinese souvenirs and really nice clothes. The only thins is that is a little bit crowded. But very recommendable!

title: Night time fun -
content: Loads of shoppers - alway bargain--no matter where you go - get some pretty pearls or eat some exotic foods --- or just go look at the people --- there are tons to enjoy!

title: Peaceful and Beautiful
content: Although we went during the worse time, as it was the end of winter and before anything was in bloom, we are glad we went. It is amazingly peaceful in the center of a bustling city!

title: Very crowded and too commercial
content: It is easy access with subway.It is very crowded even on weekday. Very hard to find a good spot that you can take picture quietly.

title: Beautiful and tranquil
content: Definitely worth paying admission -- the garden is opulent and full of character. I was there with a few friends and we were happily soaking up all the flowers and the rock formations.

title: Really cool area
content: Even though this is all new and recreated to look old it is still really cool to visit. Try and pick a time when it isn't at peak business though. As it can get a bit crazy. Great for photos.

title: Nice Garden
content: A very nice garden. Good for education especially for my son. Almost every plant and trees have a tag, we can explore and eduate our son. We come in early spring, flower start blossom already, there are so many colourful flower in the garden.

title: Zen-like experience
content: As part of our Best of Shanghai tour we went to the YuGarden with Daniel Hannah of Newman Tours, I can honestly say, it was one of the few but pleasant "touchy- feely" experiences of my life. I tend to be a pragmatic and realistic individual and rarely feel personally "moved" by inanimate objects and gardens, although I can appreciate their beauty. Imagine my surprise to feel and experience peace and tranquility in this beautiful setting. I honestly could have.spent much more time here than I did.

title: Lovely place to visit, but not in the middle of Chinese New Year!
content: This is a beautiful place, and right in the heart of the old town. Great buildings, lots of little lakes, plenty of beautiful Bonsai trees in all shapes, sizes and colours. Defiantly make the time to visit here, just make sure not to do it in the middle of the Chinese New Year. Loved it.

title: Beautiful space in Shanghai
content: Just beautiful, even in the rain. This little gem is often overlooked. A peaceful little spot in a gigantic city. Outside the garden are shops galore selling lots of tourist trinkets. The buildings ain't old, but charming all the same. Can't remember the entrance fee, but it's nominal.

title: Much more than a garden-a marvellous place
content: Aptly named Garden of Contentment, one can spend hours here and still would not feel bored, with gardens, nice water bodies with myriad fish, in it, nice Chinese buildings, large number of shops selling curios and old Chinese art and culture, even magic and folklore!! Drawing a large crowd throughout the year because of its beauty, one has to squeeze his way through sometimes, its a great visit worth remembering, but better not to go with children below 5 years as you might not be able to enjoy the full extent of this beautiful place

title: True Shanghai
content: Been to Yugarden countless times and every time I visit, there's always something new to see. The architecture is beautiful and would recommend it to anyone who wants to get a taste of the true Shanghai culture without leaving the city. It is easily accessible by transport and the people are extremely friendly.

title: A nice place to visit and spend some time...
content: It’s been years since my last visit to the garden. Getting to the garden is easy by taxi and the underground. However, if you really want the Shanghai experience and aren’t faint at heart, ride a bike. Arriving early is the best way to avoid the crowds of people who come here each day. The shops are pretty much the same as you’ll see all over China peddling the same products. The shop keepers are willing to negotiate prices so feel free to dicker as their starting prices are higher than you’ll find elsewhere. I would not recommend buying any jewelry at the garden unless you’re looking for just costume. Save your money and buy jewelry at a well established shop. Or do a jewelry tour in Hong Kong. In the past when visiting the garden there were a lot of handicapped people begging money but saw only a couple this trip. As you stroll around the garden you’ll see some well maintained Chinese architecture. I’m always amazed at how old the buildings are, yet they can look almost new.

title: Lovely garden
content: so fascinating to see the old contrasted with the new outside the walls. Serene and peaceful inside bustling outside. would recommend you visit YuGarden

title: Beautiful, peaceful gardens in the middle of this busy city.
content: A calm, quiet oasis in the middle of Shanghai, the Yu Gardens were a wonderful, relaxing respite from the fast pace of busy, bustling Shanghai.

title: a lovely bit of old Shanghai
content: Unfortunately it was pouring with rain during our visit or we would have stayed longer but is was a fascinating hour and a half. Built by a very wealthy Chinese several hundred years ago it has pons with large carp, rock structures and a number of classical Chinese buildings.

title: Nice escape from shanghai crowds
content: While the crowds in the surrounding shopping areas were massive, even in the rain, inside the gardens it was calm and peaceful. Though smaller than the major gardens in Suzhou, this is very representative of a typical chinese garden. If you don't have the time to drive out to Suzhou, you should absolutely visit this garden.

title: Lovely place very very busy
content: Like above very busy but great fun, beware of touts using wanting to improve their English taking you to tea tastings

title: Yu garden
content: Fantastic place. Not only the garden but also the whole ancient area.

title: Beautiful place to relax for a few hours.
content: I was surprised that the garden wasn't too crowded as we visited over CNY. Very pretty and peaceful. Choose a dry day to visit. Good location for some fantastic photographs.

title: Crowds but otherwise an oasis of calm ...
content: Yuyuan gardens is a beautiful oasis of Chinese traditional culture in the middle of Shanghai. The place is a labyrinth with one garden leading to another along winding paths and arched bridges and beautiful vistas galore. With all the craft shops outside the garden I was a little disappointed to see one inside. However, I was surprised to find its worth a look as they have some quality goods. There is a tea house there too with high quality tea - but at a price..! definitely worth a visit if you are in Shanghai

title: A Beautiful place
content: Beautiful Chinese gardens. A definite must see if this is your first time in Shanghai/China. With bamboo, koi ponds, Chinese walkways, rock formations, bridges and willows its makes nice spot for photos and to take a tranquil walk. You do have to pay to enter and it can get busy. We went in winter but even then there was decent amount of people, I can only imagine what high season is like.

title: Cool place to take a few photos
content: this is a good place to visit and take a few photos. It is really busy on the weekend with tourists and other visitors from all over. Shopping near by is reasonably priced and a good place for souveneers. Be warned there are many people that want to sell you fake luxury brand items, tea, paintings, and whatever, that can be pretty annoying.

title: Typical Chinese garden
content: Well if you're in Shanghai and you've never seen Chinese gardens, go for it. If you've been to Suzhou or anywhere else and visited a few already, no need to bother. Gardens are gardens.

title: Small, but nice
content: I went through the Garden on my own one Monday afternoon. February is a rotten time to visit a garden in China as the blooms aren't out yet. Still, it was nice to sit in the sun and watch the kids play near the koi ponds, or wander down the pathways. The Garden is a pain to find, tucked in the Yu Bazaar at the end of a street. Signs are in English and Chinese, but you still don't get much out of them. There is also a Calligraphy display within the Garden, and that was interesting. Be ware that the public toilets are the Asian "squat" kind, and not the Western "sit" kind. This is a cute small Garden but I imagine in the summer it gets very crowded and I wouldn't necessarily want to be there at that time.

title: Good way to gain an insight into 'Old' Architecture..
content: Arrived at YuYuan one early morning and had breakfast there- Taking in the 'famed' Xiao Long Bao. Food was good, and more importantly, YuYuan is a good place ot be able to experience some of the old charm of Shanghai admist an obvious tourist set up. The greater fun is to walk the aisles outside of the main square and explore some of the older shops! Definitely worth a visit to experince it! It is a busy place though!

title: noid42@gmx.net
content: It is a real nice park area. You will also find may quite touristic shops and snack bars in the area around

title: very small
content: surrounded by a lot of touristy shops and very overcrowded underwhelmed buy the gardens which though very attractive a 10 minute walk through.Maybe in Spring they will have colour.

title: elegant gardens
content: Visiting the gardens is absolutely facinating at the style of the buildings and what you see inside them. it is also a lovely place to walk around, can be crowded, BUT be prepared for the bathroom facilities they have eastern style toilets !! rather than our western toilets.

title: The Best
content: Everything in this garden is typical. All the buildings, doors, drawings, paintings, lake with fish and many others. Thousands of tourists around. Really a great place. Many shops to buy food, memorial traditional cards and many photographers. A must visit. Care about vendors. More bad experience in cheating and bargaining.

title: Old Shanghai
content: This area gives a nice, although partly artificial view of Old Shanghai: very crowded, very commercial, with mostly domestic tourists, but pleasant to stroll along the streets.

title: Shopping
content: We loved the entrance and exit areas to Yu Garden. It's a tourist trap !!! We got batteries, chops, tshirts, swords, magnets, & tea. They sell everything there! It's very crowded.

title: Beautiful
content: The Garden is very nice. Crowded due to narrow walkways. You can not really find serenity here due to the crowd but still a good place to visit.

title: Nice and green - peaceful
content: This is a nice oasis in the middle of the concrete jungle that is shanghai; Lots of green and water makes this place a good place to go to after roaming through various streets in downtown Shanghai.

title: Go early - miss the crowds
content: Yu Garden can get REALLY crowded - think Tokyo subway car crowded. So it's best to plan your trip around potential down times, like first think when it opens.

title: GOOOOOD!
content: A place where you can buy a lot of present to bring back home, starting from Chinese scarfs, ending with tea. Here you have to remember that you have to bargain!!!!

title: Typical even if really touristic
content: Touristic trap but a touch of old China in the middle of modern, grey buildings.

title: Stunning :-) beautiful traditional Shanghai
content: Beautiful and right in the middle of one of the biggest and busiest cities in world... Huge skyscrapers everywhere then out of nowhere a maze of beauty, peace and tradition :-) loved it here and looking forward to going back next week with my girlfriend when she arrives.. A definite must see for all visitors to the city x

title: Beautiful architecture
content: This rather big Chinese classical garden, 5 acres, has several buildings and settings with unique character. The garden dates back to 1577. It is a very harmonious place, beautiful gardens, rock formation and ponds. It can get very busy, which makes the place less tranquil than what it deserves to be. I would recommend to get here when it first opens to beat the crowd.

title: A "must" visiting Shanghai
content: It is an unique place that you should not miss when visiting Shanghai; in strong contrast with the modern city and high skykrapers, this place maintains the old typical chinese architecture and environment; there are many interesting shops and restaurants in the big sourronding area and you can walk for hours discovering interesting things and places...

title: I Felt Relaxed After Leaving Garden!
content: The Garden of Contentment is connected by the ZigZag Bridge (small walking bridge where you can look a Koi fish) from the Yuyuan Old Street -- a great place for souvenir shopping. It was primarily a large rock and tree garden with old building structures (check out my pics). I went with about 6 people so we had time to stop and take pictures (it wasn't too crowded during a Tuesday late morning) and I really enjoyed the stop. The picture taking was amazing and I enjoyed having this garden in the middle of Shanghai, and then looking past the garden into the background you could see large modern buildings and skyscrapers quite the contrast. It definitely is touristy but I was a tourist so I guess it worked. I would definitely add this to your list of things to see (along with the connected zigzap bridge and Yuyuan road) when you are in Shanghai.

title: Busy at Weekends
content: Attractive area - not actually that old, but does give the sense of old China. I visited at the weekend and found it to be extremely busy, It is a must see area, especially if you don't have much time. While in the area check out some of the small shops and market stalls where a bargain can be had

user_loc: 哥伦比亚特区华盛顿特区
title: Awesome Traditional Chinese Garden
content: A super traditional Chinese garden. It is not the garden from The Story of the Stone, but if you want a great example of classical Chinese gardens. At its best in the spring with the flowering of the variety of ornamental fruit trees. The pavilions and halls have been ill-used over the years but still provide tantalizing glimpses of what is used to be. The gardens are packed in the summer and on nice weekends, so the best time to see them is during the cooler months - while not at its best, the trip is still worthwhile. Very young kids will get bored easily, but middle and older ones will enjoy the history and the surprises design elements.

title: Amazed
content: The Yu Garden is not just another typical classical chinese garden. More than 2 hectares in area, it was a private garden, not the residence, of a commissioner in the Ming dynasty. I am amazed and impressed by the details in the planning and design of the garden.

title: Beautiful gardens
content: If visiting shanghai this is a must. The street around are bustling and interesting. The gardens are very crowded but well worth seeing, they feature rocks which are like sculptures and are seen in many gardens in China.

title: A traditionally styled garden
content: A beautiful garden in the traditional style. Paths, bridges, intricate walls, stones all make for a truly beautiful environment. Well worth a few hours of ones time. Take the time to explore and savory this jewel.

title: Contented with the surrounding beauty
content: This is a very beautiful garden made by Mr Pan for his parents. Even though it takes him ages to do, especially for his father who did not get to see it before it finished, the garden is well endowed with nice rocks and trees. The houses and sceneries are calm and beautiful. Very nice and peaceful surrounding if one is to stay there.

title: Very nice
content: Beautiful architecture, very interesting place to visit. Highly recommend but unfortunately it's mobbed with people. Taurus all go there. I suppose there's a reason they all go there. It is beautiful

title: A must visit even if the surrounding area is touristy
content: Don't be put off by the over the top touristy overload around the gardens, once you enter it is very different. The gardens in my opinion are a must visit if you only have 2 or 3 days in Shanghai, if you stay for longer you can go further afield. The gardens are well kept and provide very good photo opportunities in many cases. The area is small geographically but they way it has been designed it makes it feel much much bigger. I would recommend 1 to 2 hours for this attraction.

title: First place to start you Shanghai tour
content: yu yuan garden gives you an idea how Shanghai locals lived in the past. Spend around 1-2 hours going around the garden then enjoy the numerous restaurants and shops outside. Stills would recommend you to buy your souvenirs in tian zi fang

user_loc: 路易斯安那州斯莱德尔
title: Beautiful but crowded
content: The garden is beautiful and would be peaceful except for the hoards of tourists. Not sure if we went at a very busy time (late afternoon) or if it is always very busy.

title: Lovely Architecture
content: This is a nice garden in the middle of the city.

title: We visited twice it was so inspirational
content: Water, stone, pagodas, bridges, secret passageways, plentiful koi, blossoms, dragons.....these gardens have it all.

title: Beautiful and serene
content: Despite the crowds, found this site so beautiful and serene I actually felt the urge to sit in a corner and do a very deep 20 minute meditation! It's not a garden as much as grounds will lots of very old Chinese 'halls' with intricate decoration on the grounds and the buildings themselves. Particularly loved the roofs of the buildings and the tea ceremony within the grounds. Would recommend to all.

title: Amazing garden hidden away in a city
content: Behind the walls hides this amazing garden. Every turn reveals a different element of the garden. Chinese love of natural rock sculptures is a major element of this garden. It is nice to step away from the markets and appreciate the beauty. The market area was given a make over for the Olympic games so it's got a modern twist on the old chinese style. These markets get very crowded and rather expensive. Loved the street food - dim sum. All very interesting and well worth a visit.

title: Nice garden in the middle of the city
content: Once again I've been countless times to Yu Garden since 2011 and it's a good place to bring visitors to when the weather or pollution is not too bad. You can pair it with a visit to the wholesale markets in the ugly buildings around the garden. The garden itself is well-maintained and very pretty, ancient and classical enough with the usual ponds and rocks, but I guess that after Suzhou, it started looking pretty average to me but then what do I know? Whatever you do, don't queue up for the famous but horrible Nanxiang dumplings near the garden, cross the road and eat them at Din Tai Fung instead. Do visit the Chenghuang Temple next door too, it would make the visit quite complete.

title: traditional
content: If you are looking for good traditional chinese treats, you can find it here. Only, you need to bear with the smoking crowd even inside the stores and restaurants.

title: nice place but just too crowded!
content: nice architecture and streets... but unfortunately just too crowded! we went pretty early and it was also crowded.

title: WILLOW PATTERN GARDEN
content: This garden is billed as being the inspiration for the willow pattern china an d you can see why. It is delightful. Lots of different areas and lots of water features. Outside the gardens is a big shopping area, worth a wander.

title: Yu Garden, Shanghai
content: It is easy to reach this place, you can use taxi or MRT line 10 (purple line) and get down at yuyuan garden station.

title: Good location, but full of people!
content: Went on a Sunday with my friend. This place was packed with people. Also everything in this area is a tourist trap and VERY expensive. Nice place to visit but would avoid on a weekend. Also it costs 30 RMB to enter.

title: Beautiful oriental garden!
content: This is definitely is more beautiful in Spring as you cannot see any flowers now in winter. It was nice in any case and we liked our walk crossing small ponds and walk between rocks. It's definitely one of the worthy visits while in Shanghai. Beware that there are small buildings identified with a sign outside as calligraphy museum but when you enter is actually a shop and people inside try to sell you prints, paintings and jewellery once you show a bit of interest. This is a bit misleading for tourists in my opinion. It worths to enter and see a bit though.

title: Garden of Contentment (Yugarden)
content: The Garden of Contentment (Yugarden), is a must go attraction in Shanghai.

title: One of the p;aces to see in Shanghai -
content: The Yu Garden is one of the places to see. Walking through the shopping areas to get there is nice. Take a nice day to stroll around and not a rainy one!

title: Place to visit
content: Like the Chinese say, "People mountain People sea". Lots and lots people are there. Many fun shops to visit and yummy food to try. It's a must stop place.

title: Surprisingly Very Interesting
content: We did not know what to expect and really love these gardens. We had a guide "Travel China Guide" and it made it much more interesting. These are some of the best pictures from the city!

title: Garden of delight
content: we toured this in September 2013. It's a beautiful garden filled with ponds, lovely trees. There were some people dressed in period clothing, and playing some traditional music. It's located in the city and hard to believe it when you see it. Its a place that should be visited.

title: GOOD GARDEN
content: This is one of the very good Chinese garden in town.Must visit walk and enjoy.Very well designed and well maintained.Very pretty.

title: Would be better in the summer
content: I toured this garden while on a one day tour of Shanghai. I think the architecture proved impressive and very traditional Chinese. The gardens are probably beautiful in the summer, but I happened to be there in January. The limestone is very ornate and beautiful, as are the rooftops and buildings. My guide explained a lot of the symbolism of the dragon, the lions and other parts of the garden and I found it interesting that the area was originally built in the 1500's.

title: The best part of old SHANGHAI
content: If you taking a trip to the old SHANGHAI area this garden is not to be missed. There is an admission but it's not much and worth every penny. The Inside is a huge garden with lots of rock work and ponds and fishes to feed. You get some excellent shots with the old buildings.

title: A glimpse of the old life style
content: Before reaching the garden you have to pass through the old center with a very busy area of shops and restaurants both traditional and modern. The atmosphere is amazing if you don't mind being in busy areas. The garden itself is quite interesting to just imagine the traditional life of the chinese.

title: Traditional Chinese gardens
content: It is definitely worth going here if only for an hour or so. The area surrounding the gardens is all traditional buildings and the city temple is right nearby. The entry fee was 30 per person

title: Beautiful but very busy - avoid public holidays
content: I visited here on New Years Day and the crowds were unbelievable. You could not walk anywhere outside the gardens, it was simply packed, so I strongly avoid visiting on any local Chinese or major public holiday.

title: Leave yourself go in this garden
content: Wonderful, probably one of the last remains of the old Shanghai. Even some temples in the city have been restored so much that nothing original can be seen. I don´t think you need a guide except if you´re too much interested on go deeper. I preferred to stroll around the garden before visiting it, eat some food, smell the busy atmosphere of the shopping area and even try to understand one of the public shows that are performing since centuries ago. Then, you get in and all your senses get overwhelmed by beauty, peace, and your spirit blows away thinking of how much knowledge is behind that architecture and civilization.

title: Learn about Chinese-style "Gardens"
content: This is NOT like the French palace gardens. You will not see neat rows of manicured trees, bushes or flowers. You will see unusual (to Western eyes) piles of white rocks with not particular shape or beauty. But, you will see tranquil ponds and water lillies and lotus blossom, depending on the time of year. You will probably, like me, feel calm and happy. And, it is a QUIET place within a noisy city of 25 million ! You will probably need a guide to explain what you are seeing, and a bit of the 2,000 year history that evolved into this type of garden. This garden will give you a surprise view at every corner, and there are MANY corners within this beautiful garden.

title: Beautiful
content: hidden gem of Shanghai...The garden mixes stone, water, bridges and trees to create a quiet oasis...A must see

title: A must visit
content: The garden has many statues and buildings going back centuries. I visited on a cold, mid December day which is perhaps not the best time to view a garden but was blown away by the architecture and design of the gardens. It was built by a wealthy individual 400+ years ago with pavilions, theatre and separate houses for his various family members. Minimalist is descriptive of the plants used and it has been done beautifully with each tree or shrub positioned such that its beauty complements the setting or archway....thoroughly recommend a visit.

title: Beautiful garden
content: Beautiful garden in the center of old town Shanghai.

title: Definately a must see
content: beautiful gardens, huge market for shopping. There is a maze of little streets for shopping, don't forget to bargain for your treasures.

title: Classic Garden in Shanghai
content: Yu garden is one the famous classic gardens in China, and most famous garden in Shanghai. We could see mini gardens in garden, together with very classic decoration, such as dragon. Recently one thing no good is many areas closed due to maintenance or other reason

title: Great place to visit for tourist, just make sure you bargain!
content: This is a great place for locals and tourists. All sorts of food and things to buy but make sure you bargain (I managed to get as much as 70% discount). We have a 7 year old so we went early to avoid the crowds.

title: A beautiful oasis in the middle of a vibrant city.
content: we strolled around this beautiful garden for quite some time. It was peaceful and just lovely, situated in the intriguing old town. Take your time and enjoy the intricate stone formations and the greenery. Worth at least an hour.

title: Very croudy, but also very nice
content: Yu gardens is like a geant marking place. Also lots of Yu, goldfish and carp in the pond and canals. Great place for souvenir hunt. We also went to a shop that sell freshwater pearls. They cut the oyster open in front of your eyes.

title: ancient place with extremely old style chinese touch
content: You can marvel and get a taste of a typical chinese garden and pavillions. Although Suzhou is famous for its gardens, if you do not have time to travel to Suzhou which is just a bullet train ride away(less than an hour) this is worth a visit.

user_loc: 印第安那印第安纳波利斯
title: Yu Gardens- Exceptional!
content: I stayed near the Yu Gardens on this trip to Shanghai and I am so glad I did! The gardens are just beautiful and it is a very popular spot within only a few steps from my hotel! The tea house and zig-zag walkway is not to be missed, and it really is a tranquil spot amongsth the chaos of Shanghai!

title: Beautiful
content: Absolutely lovely, the architecture and style is a delight but only if you can make your way through the crowds.

title: A Gem in Shanghai
content: These gardens are a great way to spend 90 minutes and escape from the Shanghai crowds!

title: Traditional buildings neatly tucked in the city
content: Was such a beautiful place, a lot of visitors on a chilly evening. Most of the buildings are traditional and are restored neatly. One can even find a starbucks there!

title: Great deal
content: Paid RMB 30 to get in which is a steal. Very interesting architecture and grounds. Get a tour guide for a better experience.

title: One of my favorite sights in the city!
content: There's some things one must see and do when visiting a city. In Shanghai, it's things such as the Bund, Huangpu River, People's Square and Yu Yuan Gardens. I love this part of the city! If you like to eat and shop, then there's not that much better. I couldn't achieve it all in a day and had to go back for another try at her. Great shops, architecture and food.

title: Worth a visit
content: We went in early December and the crowds were heaving in and around the garden though surprisingly not so much in the garden itself.

title: Beautiful Garden
content: If you can manage to get through the crowds of the market this little garden is a very peaceful and beautiful garden to visit, we spent a couple of hours walking around, there was a small musical group performing and the sound of their instruments was amazing.

title: Not THAT amazing.
content: Just visited this place today. To be honest, I was looking forward to this place because I have read good reviews on it and it is quite popular, but I was disappointed when I came here. The area is quite smelly, definitely not the place for people who are grossed easily. (people spitting here and there, it is also very smelly!) The garden itself was okay, should definitely visit the teahouse and get a taste of what the locals are drinking. The shopkeeper even gave us a mini tour of the garden and she was quite friendly. Tons of souvenir shops and you can bargain there. There are also Jade jewelry stores and Pearl jewelry stores.

title: 100% definitely visit
content: Fascinating area - first of all you arrive at a shopping neighborhood that has been developed to look like the original architecture. Its a tourists heaven/trap, with all sorts of shops from starbucks down to little tat shops (which are probably most likely overpriced and attractive to tourists).

title: beautiful garden
content: A Beautiful Place in the city to just walk around in. It is calm and quit even if there is alot of people. This Place tells a lot how the chineese people Think and relate to different things. Go there.

title: A great place in Shanghai
content: I like the garden very much as it shows a different side of Shanghai.

title: Contentment in the Middle of a Busy World
content: Tucked into a small but well designed spot is a garden that is hard to imagine without seeing it. Passageways and walls direct you through several small garden settings that each had its own special feeling. It was once for one family and it is amazing - and right in the midst of all the business of Shanghai! ENJOY!

title: Nice building
content: Not sure about everyone, but I like to see this type of old and well preserved building. You can never imagine that you're in Shanghai when you see the whole street with old and very Chinese building. That is exactly why I am here for! There is also lots of souvenir stores along the street.

title: Peaceful Experience
content: This is an impressive example of a classical Chinese garden with its many pavilions connected by various walkways and bridges over fish ponds stocked with large amounts of enormous koi carp. This is a really peaceful place to visit in the midst of the hustle bustle and crowded markets and shopping streets of the Old Chinese City area of Shanghai.

title: lovely
content: lovely garden to take a leisurely stroll through when visiting Shanghai. Surrounded by tourist shops and a busy area, Yu Garden is like an oasis of peace within Shanghai.

title: Definitely worth going in!
content: The Yu garden is within the wider area of shops and we almost didn't go in, thinking that it would be similar to the outside area. We are so glad we did. The place is very large, with many areas interlaced with historical halls (living rooms), man-made streams and lakes, and beautiful landscaped gardens. We look so many picture and it was one of the highlights of our trip in shanghai. Definitely go in. It's worth the admission fee.

title: Can be crowded
content: This classic garden in the city should not be missed. Best to visit on a non festival day due to overcrowding.

title: beautiful garden and temple hidden behind retail
content: The very beautiful historic Yu Garden and adjacent temple are almost hard to find in the sea of fake old shopping center buildings surrounding them. But do look for the garden and temple as they are enchanting and much less crowded than the shopping areas around. Even if the gardens looked a bit worn in December when we visited. Definitely worth seeing!

title: Great chinese architecture
content: By far the Yuyuan Garden is one of the most beautiful place i have seen in Shanghai. The architecture of buildings there is just marvelous. Its worth spending couple of hours there just walking around the compound. There are a couple of good restaurants there though a bit pricey. You will get the locals hawking stuffs to you all the time but always wait for a better bargain. Also it tends to be crowded all the time.

title: Very nice garden - Recommend to go in spring
content: I recommend to go in spring time when the garden is blooming. When I was there it was a bit grey. hjjj

title: Beautiful Architecture and shopping area near by
content: At the entrance itself you will see very beautiful Chinese architecture. Quite a busy and famous place. The surrounding water body is adding too it. I really liked this place. But all around is now shopping area and lot of noise. You can shop here but you may have to bargain.

title: Calm respite once you have made it through the crowds
content: Shanghai is not really the best city for tourists, outside of the shopping and nightlife there is little to see. Yu Garden is one of the places you are sure to end up at some point. Don't be put off by the rampant consumerism and tackiness outside. Push your way through the crowds and make your way inside and you will find a little oasis of calm in the city center. For those who have visited Beijing already, you will be reminded of the Forbidden City but on a much smaller scale. It is interesting to stand in an ancient house and gaze through the window at a massive skyscraper - that juxtaposition makes the trip worthwhile. It is also nice to sit by the coy ponds and feed the fish.

title: Beautiful place
content: To get to the garden, you have to walk through shopping area. You can get there nice souvenirs, take some nice pictures. Lots of people selling bags, watches, so be ready for them. There is also nine corners bridge, which is also nice. Pot with lots of fishes, fountain, tea house. There is a fee, I can't remember how much it was, but it is totally worth it.

title: A must see!
content: Visited January 2015! Stunning site! You walk through a shopping area hosted by ancient (Ming/Qing style) houses are attractive to tourists where you can buy souvenirs. Then you arrive at the entrance to this traditional preserved garden, which are..... . The gardens are full of little rooms, small gardens, courtyards, ponds, trees, fish, etc. Just peaceful and fascinating. I recommend that every family / friends come to Shanghai must visit this garden.

title: peacefull place downtown shanghai
content: that is a nice place to relax and find some quiet area when shopping in the Yuyuan commercial area of the city.

title: Nice place, but overrated
content: The place is for tourists, the old garden is nice, but in internet reviews, it is rated too high. Otherwise a good place for shopping commercial (and expensive) stuff. Traditional Chinese handmade things are missing

title: Unexpected surprise
content: Must see , purely based on the location of the garden ... Have the fun is finding it in the first place

title: Excellent views, not too crowded
content: As it says in the title, great views of some amazing structures/gardens, at a very reasonable price. Also not too crowded even on the weekend, which is a plus.

title: Beautiful Garden in old Chinese Style
content: the Yugarden in the heart of bustling Shanghai is an must see for every tourist interested in Chinese Gardens. It's full of beautiful ponds and huge old trees. Especially the old pavilions with there elegantly shaped roofs were worth the visit.

title: Beautiful to walk through!
content: Great to take pictures and relax. Love coming here and always find something new to see! Beautiful garden with water feature and sculpture.

title: Must see attraction in Shanghai
content: This is an ancient garden hidden in Old Shanghai. My best advice is to

title: Lovely to look at.
content: Beautiful garden and best to visit as soon as it opens as it gets very busy. You can wander at your own pace but as it gets busier it's become difficult to enjoy the tranquility. Worth a visit if you can.

title: Interesting Look of Old China Wealth
content: Although you must fight your way through a myriad of vendors, some of them in your face, to get there, Yu Gardens have some lovely carved wooden buildings and nicely kept plants. I suppose that it could be kept up a little better but it was still worth the visit.

title: Take your camera
content: Beautiful traditional Chinese gardens with six different areas over 2 ha. Finished in 1577 by an officer in the Ming Dynasty who designed and built it for his elderly parents to enjoy. It is close to the metro in old Shanghai. Lots of traditional tea houses, rockeries, gardens etc, so make sure you take your camera!

title: Interesting
content: Better to go with a guide to understand better. The guide explains the history of the garden, the how's and the why's. Good for taking pictures.

title: YuYuan--one of my all time favorite gardens
content: The attention to detail by the builders many, many centuries ago is amazing--variety of doorways, floor designs, arrangement of rocks in rock gardens, etc. was mind-blowing

title: Beautiful Garden!
content: The gardens are fabulous and I could have spent hours wandering through.

title: easy way out of noise and chaotic traffic
content: plus interesting historic fatcs, unique plant species and nice architecture. Like going back in time in the middle of modern days.

title: Not So Contented
content: First of all, you have to wade through a horrible bazaar to get to the gardens. The architecture is stunning but the beggars, thieves and proliferation of Starbucks, McDonalds and Dairy Queens is really offputting. I was so rattled by the time I got to the actual garden, it was hard to relax enough to enjoy it. Plus it seemed a tad worn down at the heels, not because it is so old but because the caretakers aren't doing a great job. There are better, quieter gardens so go THERE rather than HERE.

title: A nice piece of old China in Shanghai
content: Beautiful and peaceful place in Old Shanghai. A nice mixture of ponds, bridges, water and rock structures, plus some delightful old buildings. It can be very crowded with visitors, so go as early in the morning as you can to enjoy its peacefulness. It's surrounded by "Chinatown" with lots of souvenir shops, jewelry stores, and restaurants. Very enjoyable.

title: Well maintained, value for money.
content: One of the most famous tourist landmark in Shanghai. Entry is RMB40 per pax, which you probably can spend about one to two hours in there, experiencing the luxury life of the ancient days in Shanghai. Meantime, you may also impressed with the architecture and craftmanship of every structure and building in the Garden.

title: Not that original or fantastic
content: The gardens are nice, but not a must see. A bit run down. Too many people, and really, the grounds are ok, but no wao factor.

title: This is how I imagined China
content: Shanghai is a very modern city,yet stepping into Yu garden, is stepping back in time. The architecture around the buildings and one the roof tops are exquisite. The gardens are very peaceful and are a pleasure to wonder around.

title: Quaint shops and history in one place
content: We went to Yugardaen to see the rockeries, ponds and "relaxation rooms" build by Chinese Emperors. That was interesting. The government run shops selling antiquities and local jewelry and art, were surprisingly open to barter, if you don't like to barter ask whether they are having a sale! We went to the tea house for tea, only to find that it is for selling tea leaves, not drinking it. The polite descriptions and offers to have some tea in the small lounge settings are to get you to buy a tin for about $50. This garden is surrounded by a typically Chinese shopping area, small shops in narrow alleys with the products China is famous for readily available, and a huge koi pond for good measure. If you only see one thing in Shanghai, see this;f you have time for 2 things walk down to the Bund.

title: Happy Garden :)
content: Honestly I did not know that Yuyuan Garden means Garden of Happiness, & it lives upto its name. Surrounded by all the flea markets selling comparatively very cheap souvenirs – the place gives you a taste of ancient old Chinese culture. The history behind is equally golden and one shall feel the traces as you start walking into the premises of the garden temple. The Yu garden pavilion is divided into 6 parts. The entire premise is so very rich and aesthetic. My personal favourite part was The Pavilion of Listening to Billows – had rockeries, ponds, pavilions, and towers keeping a very rhythmatic flow and maintains a visual balance. The large scale temple garden pavilion is such a smooth blend of art, architecture, nature, old city surroundings - giving a very earthy feeling, well hats off to the ancient planners for giving us this place to visit in the present day.

title: Traditional Chinese Garden in Shanghai
content: We had already been to many Chinese gardens before we went to this one. Still, I never tire of the beauty of such places. While far from the nicest garden that we visited in China, this one was still serene and beautiful. If you only visit Shanghai, then this is a must-see; if you tour lots of gardens, then it is simply nice (but not a must).

title: Hidden garden
content: This place is amazing! The buildings and garden design are mind boggling. Notice the changing stone designs in each section as well as the varied doorway shapes. Don't attempt to use a wheelchair here as there are numerous thresholds and stairs. Be warned that most buildings contain gift shops. Speaking of which, the area surrounding the gardens is jammed pack full of tourists, shops, and restaurants. It can be overwhelming.

title: Overcrowded yet beautiful historical place
content: An old beautiful Chinese garden with many water ponds full of koi carps. Very Chinese indeed.

title: Surprisingly enchanting maze of gardens and pavilions
content: The shops and restaurants surrounding the garden can be easily mistaken for the actual Yu Garden. The pictures of a zig-zag bridge over a pond is actually a pathway that leads to the garden.

title: Amazing
content: Well worth a visit if you have time whilst your their. Ideally try and have a tour so that you get the maximum benefit of your visit

title: Allow yourself time to wander and relax
content: We visited as part of a tour group and although we enjoyed the visit, we would have liked to have lingered longer. The garden is very water orientated and full of fascinating buildings with dragons, etc. We went on a miserable day in November, and the garden was busy, so I should imagine it would be pretty unbearable on a nice summer's day. It is surrounded by a market and food stalls but when inside you forget they are there.

title: Very Good
content: The garden is like any other garden in China, and it's not so big because it was a private garden...

title: In the midst of tourist madness
content: Calling it a garden seems pretty absurd as there is very little plant life there. Quite a few rock sculptures and some quaint old-style Chinese buildings. A bit of respite from the noise and bustle of the nearby area

title: Pretty garden but very crowded
content: Pretty garden but very crowded! Worth the trip though. There is a lot of good shopping in the area as well. Fine to do on your own or with a group.

title: Loose yourself
content: entrée fee 40 Rmb and the garden is stunning beautifull,full of hidden corners, ponds, fish , dragon gates...really nice!

title: Spectacular
content: a very nice, peaceful garden , totally different from other gardens in Europe. You will take lovely photos from Yu garden.

title: Wonderful and busy in the Bund
content: Yu garden is surrounded by a busy commercial area around with nice buildings in classic Chinese style. The Garden itself is really worthwhile (take care since it closes by 5 pm) and you get in after buying tickets. It is really close to the river so we did it before going for a river cruise in the evening ...

title: A must see in Shanghai
content: A little oasis in an enormous city.Located in or near the bazaar the Yu gardens are a separate attraction with a small entrance fee. Magical and beautiful.give yourself a full morning to explore both the gardens and bazaar and the surrounding area thenaneasy walk to the bund.

title: One of the Best Traditional Chinese Gardens Ever!
content: The garden itself is wondrous as long as you realize it embodies ancient Chinese gardening concepts and not at all what Western gardens embody. Also, it is only enjoyable if you can manage to go when it is not swelling with tourists. When it's very crowded, it can be so blocked that it's impossible to walk and very frustrating and/or upsetting to folks who can not tolerate tightly packed spaces. Try to go at an off time when most people would not be there and just wander. You might enjoy it more if you do a bit of research beforehand about the elements of a Chinese landscape.

title: Quiet Stroll around a tranquil garden.
content: Lovely place just off a bustling square in the heart of Shanghai. Going back to the ming dynasty . A lovely quiet stroll around this lovely garden full of history. With beautiful plants, huge coy carp and turtles in the ponds. Dragons and lions carved into walls and buildings. Just lovely, not to be missed.

title: Not what you'd expect in the middle of an up and coming city
content: A Unique old garden steeped in history that with the right guide can be totally mind blowing.

title: Beautiful garden with flowers, old buildings and old rock
content: In the middle of the city, close to the Bund is this old garden were you can walk for a while to relax. What I did not like is the tourist shops in the garden which are totally overpriced.

title: Worth a visit!
content: I really enjoyed walking through this garden (even though it was more of a stone and pavement garden as it had no grass). We went with a tour so it was really interesting learning the history behind it at the same time. Like most places tourist places in China it was very busy but worth a visit.

title: Not worth the money
content: For what it is, it is pretty pricy. Would not recommend it unless you really enjoy Chinese architechture which can also be seen in the free areas surrounding the garden. Highlight was the comical co-location of 'the room of a thousand flowers' and the toilets.

title: An interesting garden
content: I thought the gardens were ok but not very attractive. Needed a bit of a re vamp. Paint was rough and it looked tired.

title: Calm in the midst of Shanghai
content: Just off the side of the bustling (and a bit tacky) old town area is this oasis of calm.

title: Wonderful piece of History
content: This is a little oasis in the centre of the thriving and bustling city of Shanghai. You can go back thousands of years by simply taking 10 or 20 steps.

title: A pearl in the middle of the madness
content: Truly a garden of contentment, in the middle of all the Yuyuan crowds and craziness. Really peaceful and with some good history (helpful to go with a guide). . .

title: Beautiful Chinese Garden
content: Wow. This is a large and beautiful Chinese garden right in the middle of Shanghai. Walking thru the gate the rush of people in the Bazar outside just melts away. Highly reccomended. Liked this garden lots better than the ones we went all the way to Shozu to visit.

title: An oasis in downtown Shanghai
content: Yu Garden (or YuYuan) was built in 1577 during the Ming Dynasty.
