It has been altered and reconstructed over the years (the most extensive being in the 1950s) but still has maintained some charm and definitely an oasis of tranquility. You have to enter through a busy shopping area to gain access and there's few times during the day when it isn't jammed with people. The gardens are comprised or many historic structures, rockeries, small gardens, bonsai trees and statues. It's easy to walk through the complex but not advisable for those who have mobility issues given some stairs and obstacles. The teeming masses do detract from the experience which is perhaps the greatest negative.

title: Worth a visit but expect a busy visit whatever time of day.
content: Interesting mixing history and commercialism. The garden itself is very good just follow the path as it winds through the garden. The traders outside sell just about everything but generally cheap overpriced tat.

title: Not what I expected from Garden
content: A pocket for history in a modern city. It was crowded on the day I was there which takes away from some of the tranquility that it might have otherwise had. It was more of a rockery then a garden. The unusual rock formations seemed to be the focal point. The unusual bridges were fun. The highlight was a band playing music in the open theater area. They were excellent and helped transport me to a different time.

title: Wow!
content: I spent there one hour and a half, more or less but it was fantastic! It's a beautiful garden sorrounded by a very particular oriental atmosphere. I would go if I were you!

title: Lovely Garden
content: Nice garden for a stroll. It's hard to imagine that all of this once belonged to an individual. Now it could use a bit of upkeep, especially in the pools, but it is worth a look-see.

title: Must see - worth the tranquility
content: To escape bustling Shanghai, this garden is really worth a visit. Even if there are lots of visitors, you can find some peaceful areas. It is pretty with lots of little pretty buildings and and picturesque gardens.

title: Commercialized but a much see
content: This ancient garden is now absolutely commercialized...the surrounding shops and vibrant life being more interesting than the Garden itself. Everyone will enjoy a walk, to see life in Shanghai, and locals and tourists mixed. For fist time visitors this is a must...Shanghai unlike Beijing doesn't offer much historical monuments anyway. Try some of the snacks sold in various restaurants, food halls, and stalls. There is an entrance fee to the Park, but the attraction is outside it not inside.

title: Crazy busy - but worth it
content: The lead up to the entrance, across the zig zag bridge is pretty solid with people most of the time - once you pay the small fee and enter the gardens, it is a lot quieter. Some very interesting buildings and architecture in the gardens themselves. The buildings are set up as sort of museum exhibits - all well set with english signs and explanations

title: nice, not amazing
content: nice and relaxing typical Chinese garden. On the other hand it was not too exciting. The garden is located within a touristic shopping area which could be very crowded, probably on weekends more than weekdays.

title: Must see in Shanghai
content: An ancient Chinese garden near the Bund. Very crowded everyday. surrounded by many Chinese food and drinks places, shops of gifts and art crafts and local markets. In walking distance, there is a small temple and a underground silk museum If you would not mind the crowd and the noise, it would be a fun place to go. Otherwise, avoid it.

title: My favourite attraction in Shanghai
content: Go early in the morning. beat the crowds. Go to the ancient teahouse first and admire the scenery, then walk through to the main merchants compound.

title: Exotic Chinese garden
content: The sets are beautiful and demonstrated a nice mixture of garden sets which foreigner at any age will find fascinating. Though sometimes the crowd of tourists may be irritating for a intentioned quiet stay in this beautiful garden. Market outside garden is a good place to buy shanghai souvenir and I recommend pear paste which my family find effective to curb coughing lol

title: Nice place but crowdy
content: This is a peaceful garden with lots of different buildings around small ponds and garden. As other people said, the entrance is not so easy to find. However, people find it eventually because

title: Nice to see the historical garden it's another form of art
content: Nice garden, big and beautiful. Another form of Chinese Art. The entrance is quite difficult to find as it's in the middle of shops and market.

title: Large and peaceful even with crowds
content: These gardens were larger than I expected, we wandered around for an hour and still didn't get a chance to see everything. Although they were crowded, we were still able to find a few spots of near solitude, and the gardens felt like a peaceful spot even with the crowds around.

title: Its like walking through a Willow pattern plate!!!!!
content: ......amidst a thriving, beautiful and historic market area, you suddenly see the famous tea house, you step onto the zig-zag bridge (evil spirits can only walk in straight lines) and once you have fed the carp, you find yourself in a historic garden that is so hard to describe. Yes, a willow pattern plate that you have seen brought back to life!

title: Must to visit
content: with many samll funs, well decorated, gem in Shanghai

title: Worth it
content: Beautiful and interesting but nearly always spoilt by the crowds. The bazaar you have to negotiate in order to get there can be a nightmare but put your head down and push on.

title: Yuyuan Garden - Beautiful Traditional Chinese Garden
content: We visited this garden during November so there were not too many tourists which made it much more enjoyable. Getting to the garden was still difficult as we had to fight our way through throngs of people in the market, however, once we were inside we were able to enjoy the solitude offered by this gem in the middle of the city. The way the garden is divided up into multiple small sections and the extensive use of borrowed scenery makes it seem much larger than it really is. The combination of architecture and nature were astounding and we could see why our guide told us a Chinese gardener must first be an artist. If you are anywhere near eastern Shanghai (just west of The Bund), make this garden (and the nearby market) a stop on your list.

title: Nice place with a lot of shops and fish
content: It's must have to see in Shaghai. Nice architecture, cool fish :) Good photos, many shops. Have a good time there!

title: amazing garden
content: One of the most beautiful garden i have ever seen. This is the place to go in shanghai and my favourite, do not miss it!

title: Good for street shopping but bargain.
content: Yugraden is very crowded tourist attraction. The garden is as such worth visiting.

title: A Must See
content: Peace an Quite in the middle of crowded, hectic Yuyuan. Shouldn't be missed! Even in the garden, don't forget to bargain while buying stuff. We bought tea from the tea house inside, and I believe we were cheated. But the seller was wonderful and kind, so maybe she deserved the extra money.

title: Beautiful
content: This was one of my favorite parts of my entire trip and Wish I could have spent more time there. I thought it was very peaceful. Just beautiful!

title: Scrappy
content: I visited in the afternoon and the garden was busy, so busy that its many bottlenecks were often inhabited by someone posing for a photo.

title: A tranquil spot
content: After winding our way through the bazaar of the Old City, we came to a bridge that led to a wonderful garden created and built from 1559 to 1579. The Yu Garden consists of winding walkways, stone bridges, and wonderful old buildings depicting the life during the Ming Dynasty. Since we went fairly early in the morning the garden was not crowded and we could wander at our leisure. Would recommend the Yu Garden as an important Shanghai stop.

title: Artistic and huge
content: Didn't expect such a huge market in Yugarden, we are looking for the garden actually, but all are very unique Chinese style buildings very artistic, nice for taking photo. All shop selling the same thing ad we have try some sea food, its quite nice but lots of snacks look yummy but actually not nice . taxi is difficult to find after office hours and lots of driver try to cheat by over very high price.

title: Peaceful Oasis in the Midst of Tourist Shops
content: Beautiful garden with ponds and a rich history. Easy access from the Yu Garden subway station (on the lilac line). Walked around crossing bridges and feeding fish. Go early. We went in the afternoon and it was packed!

title: Very bad experience
content: I read lot of good reviews about this place and really the Yu Garden is a great place to be at in Shanghai but we had very bad experience here. When we entered, our first impression was 'wow', the buildings, the architectures are just great and we started taking photographs but suddenly as we reached near McDonald, two Chinese girls approached my wife to take their picture and my wife did so, then one girl among them started talking about where we are from and what places we have been so far, in which hotel we are staying and did we visited the garden ect. then she asked do we know about Chinese Tea Festival and when I heard tea festival I immediately remembered about reading such scams on TA before leaving for Shanghai and right after I told them that we are getting late and went inside McDonald. I am really thankful to TA and reviewer that they saved us from lot of trouble. Another incident happened in the evening when we were returning after visiting the garden, we were very happy that we got chance to see such beautiful place but then suddenly one projector pointer seller started following us and keep forcing to buy and keep touching me. I asked for price and he said ¥200 and I said I don't want to buy but he kept following us and forcing to buy, then I said I will give ¥20 for it and he said ok, when I gave him money he said US$20 not ¥20 and started hitting on my head then me and my shouted and said we are calling the police and we started walking and didn't look back. So please be careful of all this things while visiting Yu Garden. It's surrounding is not safe for solo traveller and not good for foreign couple travellers.

title: A beautiful garden, but very busy
content: The Yu gardens were in walking distance from our hotel, so we thought we'd take a stroll through them. Like most tourist attractions we found in China, the gardens were very popular with large groups of local Chinese tourists. The crowds made the site less than relaxing.

title: Yu Gardens
content: The gardens were from the Ming Dynasty by government officer named Pan Yunduan. Yu in Chinese means pleasing and satisfying and this garden was for his parents so that they could enjoy tranquil and happy time in their old age. The famous zig zag bridge is also there

title: Fun shopping at bazaar type shops and stands
content: Great place to pick up those small souvenirs and gifts. Traditional style Chinese buildings that are great for pictures. Can be very crowded at times, hold your purse tight. Make sure you plan on bartering hard, I got many items at 50% of the marked price but some of the shops have fixed prices.

title: A must to visit
content: It is located in the city . I visited this place during the day. I heard that it is always crowded and noisy.I suggest to go early in the morning and during weekdays to fully appreciate this wonderful garden.

title: Contented
content: I wouldn't say it's a necessary stop but if you are already at the Yuyuan Bazaar, it's worth your time (especially since the entrance fee isn't much). Personally, I think it would be better if you had a guide with you to further explain the history and meaning behind the olden days architectures and styles. Otherwise, it isn't exactly tranquil because of the crowd, unless you avoid the weekends.

title: Not only beautiful, but filled with history
content: Our guide took us to the garden and explained how living during the earlier centuries might have been. We felt that we could well imagine the people walking and talking, just as we were, so many centuries ago. The day that we were there was a particularly nice day (meaning that the smog was not overbearing) and I suppose that made quite a difference to us, but we would certainly want to return in the future.

title: Beautiful refuge in busy city
content: This garden is so quiet and pieceful, right in the middle of a city of 20 plus million. A must see. Great place to take photos.

title: Be Sure Not Too Miss It When Visiting Shanghai
content: The history behind the Yugarden is fascinating and provides an oasis of tranquility in the city centre. When walking round the gardens you would think you were in in the countryside if it was not for the high-rise buildings all around.

title: Old city in New city!
content: If you came to China wanting to see the old Chinese style houses, palaces and have seen only concrete sky scrappers then Yugarden is the place to head to! It like mysteriously entering the Old world Chinese civilization from the modern habitat! The Garden and the market are located centrally in a huge buildings which also acst as fence between the inside and outside and you have to entre through many of the gates. This is the place to buy souvenirs...I spent half a day shopping here, and you need to have great bargaining skills!

title: Nice and quite gardens
content: nice to walk around and enjoy the calmness and rest in the speed city of shanghai. On a lovely sunny day, near to the temple of God, a nice place to be.

title: A must
content: So much calm in such a bustling city. You need some form of guide, either a person or book, to make the most of the garden. Go early morning as is gets VERY busy. Remember to take some bread or cake for the fish!

title: Sight seeing in Shanghai
content: Our first free day in Shanghai on this trip so we took an English speaking guide to drive us around and explain what we were seeing We went here first and having the guide to walk with us and explain the history of the site made a big difference. It is a great way to spend an hour or so and experience the ancient Chinese way of life

title: Lovely relaxing garden
content: This garden was like a hidden gem. When inside it went back to old China. Lots of little buildings, water features. If we had more time would have liked to spent a couple of hours here. A must to visit if in Shanghai

title: Very interesting but packed with people
content: Not too far from the Bund, this Garden/home/estate is an interesting example of how the wealthy lived at one time in Shanghai. The rockery, wood woodwork, dragon gargoyles, symbolic designs and fish ponds create a very peaceful scene. However when we were there, the crowds were significant and took something away from all that. Try to get there on a less crowded day.

title: Nice but was busy
content: The day we went there was the national day so there was a million people outside creating a crush of people and a few hundred thousand inside. The gardens are not like a park with grass but more a tranquil maze of buildings, ponds and trees; at least it would have been tranquil without all the people. Was a nice old garden but nothing special.

title: YuGarden
content: A great place to visit. Lots to see. The gardens are beautiful. Next to Yu Gardens there is lots of shopping. You could spend a day there

title: If you go gaga for old China this is the place
content: A very nice garden to visit in Shanghai. Very picturesque. Close to Yuyuan Old Street, all very tourist-y but did not bother me too much. It looks like "old China".

title: Tourists...
content: Yu garden is definitely one of Shanghai`s pearls. Old chinese architecture, and the garden is simply breathtaking. But since there is always a ton of tourists and chinese souvenir sellers, you might have a hard time seeing any of the beauty of Yu garden....

title: Avarage gardens in the middle of Shanghai
content: You get to see water and trees and stuff like that but it is not worth it. The area around it more interesting. You get to see more people and more culture.

title: Rocks and wood and lots of charm
content: Yuyuan Garden is located in the center of Shanghai's Old City, a few blocks south of the Bund. It has a total area of about two hectares (five acres) with more than 40 attractions.

title: A bit overrated
content: The garden was beautiful but the experience was diminished the amount of tourists walking about. The garden itself was beautiful, but we've seen much nicer places elsewhere in China. It's worth a trip as the markets around the garden is pretty amusing, but don't expect the gardens to be a tranquil oasis in Shanghai.

title: A lovely place of refuge in a huge bustling city
content: Although it was very crowded outside this garden once inside it was quiet, peaceful and beautiful. We loved the buildings and plantings.

title: Must see as a tourist of Shanghai!
content: This entire "Garden" Experience was actually a lot of fun! The historical garden itself is very interesting as I am from a young country. But the tourist-y shopping experience was interestingly as engaging! There is a teahouse up and in the back that performs a complete tea ceremony. (As one of the Volunteers how to locate the shop.) I'm not officially a tea snob. We stayed about five hours, my grown son and I. It's a spectacle for the eyes. This is the perfect location to purchase some sort of "trinket" or souvenir of Shanghai. Bring your own toilet paper for the facilities. (They were out in the men & women facilities.) And of course... bring a camera!

title: A Top Destination
content: Yu'an Gardens is a must see place in the heart of Shanghai. This will give you a glimpse into what ancient China was like and it even has a Tea house for drinking and buying teas. There is much to see and there are old bridges to walk over the many streams. It will be very crowded when you so plan to take your time.

title: A garden with a lost of charm!
content: Am so glad we went. It is near the old town, usually people get enchanted with the old town and forget about this garden. Please don't! It has a lot of charm, perhaps it is one of the best we have seen in China. Give your self an hour and treat your eyes with what this garden has to offer.

title: the back bazzar is more intresting
content: Yu garden is a beautiful one if you do not visit in rush timeit is one of traditional parts in shanghai but the bazzar behind the garden is amazing you can find any kind of handicraft s there but dont forget the bargaining

title: Fantastic gardens like nowhere else in the world
content: These gardens cost 40 RMB to tour. There was old buildings/salons, a wide variety of ancient and gorgeous trees, dragon walls, rockeries, ponds with fish and turtles... Although most of the written material was in Chinese, there were many tour guides, so I followed behind to listen in English and/or Spanish. These gardens are impressive; I strongly recommend that you consider hiring a personal tour guide for your preferred language. One Chinese tour guide spoke flawless Spanish (that he learned while living in China). I'm not sure how to find them.

title: Nice experience of Chinese architecture and atmosphere
content: We only visited the vibrant bazaar and not the garden itself. Lots of fun souvenir shopping. Great local snacks.

title: Nice area to window shop
content: The shops at Yuyuan has a very ancient architecture. There are plenty of art shops as well as tourist souvenir shops. For the authentic art shops, prices are pretty fixed. However, for the souvenir shops, you can bargain down the price quite a lot. Plenty of nice eateries also.

title: a little disappointed
content: Crowded of foreign tourists. But actually this is not the real Chinese heritage. It lacks of the real spirits and rebuilt too much times. More likely to say it's a huge boutique shop for foreigners. Locals will be disappointed if they visit there.

title: Dumplings!
content: Second time here. The gardens here are beautiful, but packed. There is a restaurant here famous for dumplings, I can't recall the name, but when you see the line up you'll know which one... Last time i queued for nearly 1.5 hrs, this time i found the staircase to the seated area upstairs. Go to the VIP seated area, line is the shortest, maybe a 30% price loading, but that's nothing and well worth it! Gardens are worth a walk around (40yuan entry) and the street stalls have a plethora of things to buy, some haggling may be needed tho...

title: The Secret Xanadu of a Bustling Metropolis
content: It's too "discovered" to serve its key purpose (hardly as serene as its meant to be with 189 tourists running around taking selfies or using tripods), but it's still a vision of beauty, well worth a visit.

title: Touristy but a must
content: Crowded, but a Must. Lots of food and thinks to see. You can also have a nice tea ceremony in one of the tea houses, but be aware of scam, always ask the price first.

title: Beautiful Architecture and Landscaping.
content: This would have been a place I could have sat and mulled over life for hours if it hadn't been so jammed with tourists. It was just like the travel brochures portray old China. Just peaceful and beautiful to the max. Very odd though how it appears out of nowhere at the end of a market street packed elbow to elbow with shoppers looking for a bargain and the local street hustlers trying to scam the glassy eyed tourists. Would love to replicate the beautiful gardens and ponds in my backyard.

title: Beautiful and peaceful
content: A beautiful and peaceful spot to spend a few hours. The gardens are gorgeous and inspire meditation.

title: Peaceful Garden
content: The gardens are small, but very pretty. There is a lot of history crammed into the space, so there is plenty to look at. It gave a good glimpse of how China used to look. It was really interesting to see the old architecture mixed with the new shiny skyscrapers in the background. This was one of my favorite areas in Shanghai. It was a nice place to spend an hour or two away from the heavy traffic of the city.

title: An easy walk from the Bund
content: These gardens are small but unique in a city that is being urbanised as we read this review. Located just off the Bund a walk thru gives you tranquility in a bustling city. The gardens lead to the old town markets and are worth a visit. These gardens are well kept and give visitors an insight to traditional Chinese gardens.

user_loc: 哥伦比亚特区华盛顿特区
title: Touristy and annoying
content: This reminds me of a Disney Epcot Center version of what China should be. Sadly, everything you see is basically fake. Nice for photos and facebook updates ("Look Ma, China!"), but genuinely inauthentic. If you want to buy trinkets and souvenirs that you can probably find elsewhere, and if you're interested in being shoved around by the often claustrophobia-inducing crowds, check it out!

title: Amazing garden in urban Shanghai
content: Spent about an hour and a half walking through this quiet, amazing, historical Chinese garden after the hussle and bussle of the vendors area. This 550 year old garden beautifully displays the four basics required, which i believe are trees, water, stone, and structure (don't quote me on that....). A rainy fall day when we were there, it must be even more stunning in the summer.

title: Beautiful Oasis of Calm
content: Lovely space to spend a couple of hours - very peaceful and historic, with the classic style of Chinese architecture.

title: Refreshing, welcomed sanctuary.
content: It will cost you 6 yuan, nothing, or $1.20 to wander these beautiful gardens where Shanghai seems a world away

title: Enjoy, but drive a hard bargain!
content: Beautifully laid out gardens nestled in the centre of a bustling authentic "chintown"

title: A beautiful oasis within the city centre of one of the largest cities in the world
content: It has a lot of traditional Chinese architects and wonderful and elegant gardens that take us back many centuries ago.

title: Beautiful
content: This was one of the favorite places we visited in Shanghai.  The architecture and gardens were lovely.  Don't miss this!

title: Calm in the Middle of a Storm!
content: Garden is lovely, but to get inside you must get past the throngs of people in Old Town. Worth it! Bring some cookies or crackers to feed the Koi...they are huge, and will swarm I. Front of your eyes...really cool!

title: Yu Garden, YuYuan Garden, Garden of Contentment
content: The garden is small, quiet and tranquil, nestled in the center of the massive sprawling bazaar and surrounding markets. To see a review of the bazaar, check my profile.

title: Mesmerising
content: We were shown round this oasis of calm in a bustling city by a most knowledgeable local guide. Even in pouring rain it was a truly uplifting experience, very calming

title: Very beautiful
content: I liked this garden a lot. It was hard to find as the signs for it aren't easy to see- make sure you ask for directions or know exactly where you are going. Once there though it is worth it as the gardens are so tranquil and beautiful. In some areas its a bit annoying as people try to sell you things i.e.. paintings, chinese tea etc. Worth a visit. Cheap to get in as takes over 2 hours to explore completely.

title: Quite spot in the middle of old China town.
content: Nice retreat in the middle of the crazy old China town area. Take a break from vendors and the heat and explore these gardens. Lots of Koi fish and little bridges. Entry fee was not much and seniors with any I.D get 50% off I believe. I would have wished they had maps of the gardens as there are a few paths and not sure which way to go at times. Enjoy. Cheer and Happy travels.

title: LOVELY GARDENS
content: Highly recommend this attraction in Shanghai, however suggest you get there very early in the morning as the crowds including locals and tourists build up very quickly. Hard to believe this is such a beautiful serene place when the streets outside are so chaotic.

title: Make sure you be there early
content: Yu garden represents Shang hai's original taste of garden arrangement. Make sure you get yourself be there as early as possible to avoid the crowds. You will enjoy more with less people.

title: A beautiful space
content: Very interesting to explore, with lots of "rooms" you could spend a long time discovering here. Be careful of the uneven paving and steps when your gaze is upwards! Was quite crowded, although we visited in the morning.

title: an OASIS
content: This is a very serene and beautiful place to spend some time. However it is a zoo to get to it and it is extremely crowded inside which detracts from the overall experience.

title: Amazing
content: I was there on a sunday. I was overwhelmed by the of local visitors in the gardens and in the shopping complex around the gardens. A place bustling with activity. The gardens have a beautiful layout, with little pagodas and bridges crossing the creeks and lakes. It's really what you expect from a chinese garden. Once you've been through, adventure yourself into the hundreds of shops selling trinkets, but also some shops with amazing chinese articles with high quality and prices. Don't miss the bun restaurant. You can't miss it, there is always a line to go in. But don't let it put you off. Many people in the line are just buying takeout. Or you can try and go straight to the third floor and have the best variety of great buns in Shanghai.

title: Zen place in chaotic bazaar.
content: Yu garden is a nice quiet place. However, I love the bazaar outside the garden. It is my favorite place for people watching. It could get very crowded but this is Shanghai. Food from some eateries are great but be prepare to eat while standing.

title: Garden Beautiful
content: The Garden of Contentment was very beautiful and we enjoyed strolling around inside. It was a little crowded but I would recommend a visit. The only negative issue is that the vendors outside are very aggressive.

title: Go Early
content: These are a great garden to walk around and see old buildings and designed pathways. Unlike many attractions in Asia there are no guides trying to take you around, so either come with a group or just wander around. To avoid the crowds, get here very early. There are a ton of tourist shops around and if you walk not too far, some good street food.

title: Little Piece of Paradise in midst of Chaotic City street
content: Our trip to the Yu Garden was a pleasant surprise in a city that does not have much of the old China left. This 500 plus year old garden was located in a very busy area of shops and tourist traps in old or old looking Chinese buildings. It was a real trip back in time and well worth the visit.

title: Amazing garden!!
content: This is a beautiful piece of chinese gardening that really makes you forget you're in the middle of a huge city. Some of the best pictures I took in the whole China trip came from this garden!!!

title: I Would Come Here Every Day
content: Let me start by saying that I am a giant fan of traditional Chinese gardens. I've gone out of my way to visit them all over the world, and I have several books on the subject. If I ever had a spare million and the space, I would definitely build my own. That said, this is the nicest one I've ever seen. Chinese gardens have a very specific format, which includes creating "views" and comfortable nooks for contemplation every time a visitor turns a corner. This garden has a hundred places where I felt I could stop and spend time, just looking and listening and spending time with my own thoughts. If I lived in Shanghai I'd own an annual pass and go there every day.

title: Gardens are nice but the bazaar is very crowded
content: The gardens and immediate buildings are beautiful and it would be tranquil but the crowds can be quite overwhelming in parts of the garden and the bazaar area . Sellers in the bazaar can be quite forceful and to be honest this soured my trip to here.

title: Idyllic site in the city
content: You'll be among many others but it's a quite walk in an ancient site. There are some selling concessions within the park that look a little like an art exhibit before you enter. Once inside you'll have the opportunity to buy jade or paintings or some etched stones with your name in Chinese characters. If you're shopping, ok. If you're there for the gardens, stay on the path.

title: Hard to see the gardens through all the visitors
content: Although we arrived around 9am it was very crowded, China style crowded! full of tour groups with guides speaking either loudly or into loud speakers. Not at all peaceful. The maze like garden arrangement is lovely and there are dome truly gorgeous buildings, but having been to a lot of gardens already in China this is far from the best. If you can get there very early in the day before the crowds it would be better. Probably not suited to those with limited mobility, uneven surfaces and steps abound.

title: Too Busy
content: Whilst the gardens and buildings are fascinating and a little oasis in the bustling city, it is a nightmare to walk through during summer. The crowds are stifling. There was no chance of enjoying the peace that you would expect in a garden.

title: Peaceful garden in the middle of the chaos
content: Surprising to find this peaceful garden in the centre. Serene and secluded, with exhibition plants, trees and streams and lakes and streams full of koi and goldfish, dotted with the odd ancient pagoda. Lovely.

title: Serenity in the Midst of Bustling Shanghai
content: Yu Garden dates back to the 1500's and provides you with an excellent example of the ancient gardens for which China is known. Lovely buildings date back to the Ming dynasty and are set in a beautifully sculptured landscape. Ponds teaming with Koi, lush plants, beautiful flowers, bridges and sculptures of stone -- nature's elements brought together in perfect harmony. This is one of Shanghai's must-sees. It's also conveniently adjacent to the Yuyuan Tourist Mart -- shops and restaurants in old-style buildings -- and a great place to purchase souvenires.

title: Go early in the day
content: We got there as part of a Viking cruise tour early in the morning, before the surrounding shops were open and this was a brilliant strategy. By about 10 am things get going and by 11 am the place is very crowded. On the other hand it is a good place to have dumplings for lunch, but be prepared for mobs of tourists.

title: Find the Dragon
content: Very well looked after, and not far from The Bund or The Pedestrian Street or the Museum. This is not as large as the scholar gardens of Suzhou which you also must see, but it contains all the elements of the gardens of the wealthy. Appreciate the traditional vase and mirror representing peace and tranquility.

title: A must in Shanghai
content: This is truly one of the most memorable things I visited in China. The architecture is stunning, and the layout of the garden reflects peace and tranquility.

title: Lovely!
content: Not to be missed, but go early before the crowds arrive. Give yourself an hour or so to wander around and to take advantage of the "Kodak moments." The gardens are not well-signed and finding the exit was a bit of a challenge.

title: Interesting Place to Visit
content: We visited Yugarden 2 times. It is a large area with lots of stores, The Huxinting Teahouse, the City God Temple and Yu Gardens itself. We bargained in stores for some souvenirs. A very famous Shanghai dumpling restaurant is in the area and we watched them make dumplings. If you miss home there is a Starbucks for a coffee or tea break.

title: Nice stroll but lack of explanation and buildings not well maintained
content: Of course I wasn't going to miss visiting the Yu Garden. I mistook the Shanghai Garden a little bit further down the road for the Yu Garden so luckily I ran into a Chinese couple who asked if I was going to the Yu Garden when I thought I was already there since I did not find any sign translated in English. If you did not walk through very small alleys crammed with small shops selling all kinds of souvenirs you're not at the Yu Garden. The bazar around is nice to visit too, it's more a thing where locals shop for fish, rice or nuts or have a local meal on the street.

title: piece of Heaven
content: this is a must-see before leaving Shanghai..when you visit this place make sure you're not in a rush as the place needs good 2-3 hours just to enjoy the surroundings. Make sure you visit the 100 years Tea House, and enjoy shopping at the market.

title: Good place to get good pics!
content: I recommend seeing this during the night, it looks nicer than the day. Might get crowded too! Try the famous shanghai dumplings at the Nanxiang restaurant, don't queue downstairs, pay a little bit more for better shanghai dumplings upstairs!

title: Go Early to Avoid Suffucating Crowds
content: Every city has a place like this, stall after stall of tourist junk and trinkets you'll wish you didn't buy once you get home. The buildings and gardens themselves are very nice when you can see them through the crowds

title: Beautiful Spot
content: An extensive garden with exotic flowers and rocks is stunning with the good number of structures set against the hi-rise buildings of the city in the background. The centerpiece of the garden and photo shoot is the large stone boulder that has quite the story as we were told by our gate1 guide.

title: Beautiful water garden
content: Its a beautiful water garden. You will see ancient Chinese architecture in the garden. Some small stone mountains some beautiful orange fish ponds. Small wish wells. If you want the know the ancient sculpture of Chinese in Shanghai then, this the best spot to visit. Outside the garden there are so many food and gift articles shop. You can enjoy the food and buy momentous for your friends. The street itself is so beautiful you will find yourself truly in ancient China.

title: The gardens are beautiful
content: Water, stone, pagodas, bridges, secret passageways, plentiful koi, blossoms, dragons.....these gardens have it all. We visited twice it was so inspirational.

title: Nice to do if you got time....
content: It's a very nice garden with lot of shops around to buy anything you want but be prepared to see a lot of people....

title: Interesting
content: A slight refuge from the crowds outside. Interesting mix of old buildings and gardens with all the modern skyscrapers outside. Useful to have a guide to interpret.

title: A plain stone garden
content: A bit overrated but I would not say it is not worth the price. Entrance fee is 40 yuan and if you have a student card you only pay half the price. There are few flowers although it is in summer and the exhibitions inside are quite uninteresting. Nevertheless, the exhibitions make a good spot to cool your body temperature before you venture out into the hot weather.

title: Not so great
content: Yugarden is one of those places that you either love or hate. Yugarden is in the middle of the chaotic area of the Yuyuan Market, which is always crowded, so the Yugarden is a big change. The garden itself was more peaceful than the market (but I did not feel it as serene as other reviewers said, too hot, too many people) and far from being relaxing it ended up being the opposite.

title: Go feed the fish!
content: This garden is surrounded by an overwhelmingly busy tourist shopping area, which we reached as part of our hop on/hop off Big Bus tour. Would like to tell you that it was quieter inside but actually there seemed little respite from the crowds. The centerpiece is a large tall stone - the Currow ancient stone - but such was the volume of people we missed it first time round. There are also various halls and chambers to look at and some screens and pottery. Actually what was best was that we had the foresight to buy a loaf of bread and this accompanied by an on site purchase of some fish pellets meant we could entertain ourselves (and all our fellow tourists) feeding the hundreds of fish & turtles.

title: The Ancient Part
content: The place it's the symbol of the old town and the old life like it was several yeas ago in town.

title: A beautiful garden in the middle of a very busy city
content: We were going to see old town or china town as our guide called it. We had planned to see the Yu garden on our own. This was a special surprise as the garden is right on the edge of old town. This was a great example of a true chinese garden but on a slightly smaller scale. It has all the components that make up a garden. First it's overall design fits in the existing landscape of the land it occupies. It contains all the elements of a garden. Rocks, water, and plants were skillfully placed in balance with bridges and buildings in authentic architectural design. It's very relaxing walking through and exploring the garden. You need to see it for yourself.

title: Loved Yu Garden in the early morning
content: We arrived at Yu Garden with Sunny Chang from Toursbylocals when it opened and it was just wonderful to go through without any crowds. It was raining a little but this didn't spoil our visit. I'd recommend doing this with a guide (ie. like Sunny) so you could better understand all the intricacies. Certainly a break away from the hustle and bustle of Shanghai.

title: Liked the gardens
content: Overall it was a good experience, and RMB60 well spent. The gardens give you a chance to explore how people in the Ming and Qing dynasties spent time relaxing. The park had a large number of koi fish and a really good layout as such. Quite different from what you would find in a garden that belongs to western royalty.

title: Travel to real CHINA
content: Yuyuan Garden is located in the center of Shanghai's Old City.It's a must to go...There is nothing that will disappoint you!!!Pavilion in Lake Center Tea House is the oldest extant tea house in Shanghai.

title: Beautiful garden
content: Situated next to cheng huang miao, this garden is beautiful and exquisite. Can take a stroll in the garden if weather is good. Great for photo taking too.

title: Wonderful garden
content: This park is really beautiful! You have to pay for the entrace, but the price is not high, so it's definitely worth paying. I liked everything there. Peaceful and relaxing place.

title: Very beautiful garden & views located middle of crowded market area
content: The market area surrounding Yuyuan Garden was very crowded during the visit and probably always is but the garden itself was little bit calmer and was well worth the visit. Very nice views and old Chinese architecture & small passageways made of rocks. Might be tricky getting around with strollers or wheelchair.. There are also some Chinese art shops inside some of the buildings.

title: Good place to hang around and eat xiao long pao
content: We went here last December and had a nice afternoon stroll. The place sells products that are a little expensive (it's a tourist site after all). But what we enjoyed most is the Xiao Long pao.

title: Beautiful place!
content: In the middle of a great city like Shanghai, a peaceful like place. It was a beautiful and sunny day, so the visit was amazing. The region has many stores and is crowded. Beyong the gardens, the Ming Dinasty architecture is one of the best things there.

title: Calm oasis in busy city
content: The Yugarden is a lovely quiet spot adjacent to the Old Town, but within its walls a calm peacefulness exists (even with a constant parade of people and tour groups wandering through it. There are a number of buildings (with limited access) throughout the garden, along with a number of ponds and cool shady places to stop and sit. The layout means that you are in different enclosures, housing different aspects of the Chinese garden styles, with water featuring prominently.

title: Outside the Yu Garden
content: Outside the Yu Garden. as I said, eh, we are not on an actual garden but wandering around outside among all the fine houses and shops. a good place to buy some tourist things. to get into the garden, you have to pay. worth to visit, I think

title: One of the most beautiful places in the city
content: I went there and though it was crouded like crazy, its insanely beautiful! The smells (not always good) the people and the arquitecture make it a unique place! Just loved it!

title: Magnificent garden and Temple.
content: We had a guide from Shanghai Lander, Jean who showed us around and took so much time explaining the difference to me in different periods of furniture in the Temple and also the details of all the rooms. I really feel this tour which included the market which is right next to the Temple was superb, and I think going with a guide made all the difference. The rock formations were exquisite as were the gardens, although I never saw any other gardens to compare this to.

title: A Ming-style shopping area
content: The beautiful buildings and gardens were crowded yet everyone was friendly and enjoying themselves. We had delicious Shanghai dumplings and a selection of other wonderful dishes. We enjoyed bargaining with the street vendors. Shopping tip - buy one of an item and then you can get a better deal on the next ones.

title: Good place to visit, but caveat emptor..
content: Have taken visitors to Shanghai here often. It is really worth the visit. Just 2 things to consider:

title: Walking and resting in YuYuan
content: Interesting construction in the city. Building a full garden of rocks with zigzaging paths and traditional wood pavillion as if we were far from the dynamic city. Walking inside the garden to look at what the designers proposed, then sitting to see everyone passing by and finally sleeping in the shadow of a pavillion. But it is quicly quite monotonous even if rocks arrangement are often quite interesting.

title: Excellent gardens
content: Very peaceful beautiful relaxing gardens with amazing stone works and a wall the has a dragon on the wall on the top

title: Nice Garden
content: For me i didn't find this garden special by any means and its just normal small garden, i was really expecting nicer garden but the fact that its not really well maintained and the water is not clean. since i was in the market and this garden is in the middle of it i didn't find harm to visit it

title: well preserved place
content: very nicely maintained. even though it is very old, they have kept

title: Beautiful Garden
content: The gardens are historic and beautiful. Worth a trip when visiting Shanghai.

title: Beautiful Chinese Garden
content: This is well worth fighting the crowds to enjoy this bit of tranquility. Yes it is crowded, yes there are vendors, but that should not daunt one from spending some quality time absorbing this unique spot. Shanghai can be a bit much, and it is easy to lose sight of the fact that this city has a long and rich city that predates Hermes, Prada, and Tiffany. Go and enjoy.

title: The closest to traditional Chinese culture in Shanghai
content: Having travelled and lived in various places around China, I can tell you this is the closest you will get to traditional Chinese buildings and courtyard houses in Shanghai.

title: Yu Gardens are beautiful, and surrounded by tons of shopping
content: The gardens are beautiful, but pretty crowded. This is a wonderful example of Shanghai history and worth a visit if you are in Shanghai. There is a Starbucks inside, but be prepared for fairly long lines, although they move pretty fast. All around the perimeter of the Yu Gardens, there are tons of shopping booths and stores. Things get less expensive as you move farther out from the gardens and main Garden entrances. Lots of purses, sunglasses, electronics, clothes, and nick knacks.

title: Should be called "Garden of MassTourism"
content: This could have been a great attraction, but for the new "pretend buildings", built to look old, the high volume of tourist shops all selling low quality, useless items and the vast number of tourists from both China and overseas flooding the area. This makes it very uncomfortable to walk around and certainly denies you any tranquility, which was probably one of the key goals behind the initial concept. There are better ways to spend a few hours in Shanghai.

title: Real Shanghai
content: For a real look of this town, YuGarden should be the best example.

title: old-fashion, history
content: Great place to get the best shanghai-style dumpling. Love the dumpling there. I would recommend to pay a bit more to sit upstair for a better environment.

title: A Beautiful Oasis
content: This is a beautiful collection of buildings set in gardens. We visited early in the morning and virtually had the place to ourselves, On a return visit to the area some days later we observed long queues of people goint in to the site so go early!

title: Beautiful Traditional Chinese Garden
content: Very tranquil place and beautifully laid out traditional Chinese gardens but, one of the drawbacks of being a world famous attraction, it does get ridiculously busy.

title: Another over rated ....
content: Another over rated Tourist Trap. The plus, it shows you the older china culture, and so does another 100 of them in the area, the minus, the tourist shop may just chew off an arm or a foot for those useless stuff.

title: One of the main attractions in Shnghai
content: Well you cannot leave Shanghai before visiting the Yu Gardens. As mentioned in other reviews, you need for sure 1-2 hours (I would say closer to the 2 hour end) to enjoy the magnificent gardens and buildings. Be noted that it is over crowded though and this can be some times difficult for non-Chinese travelers who are not used to. All in all it is an ideal place for picture taking so make sure to enjoy the combination of plants, water, rock and buildings. It is very humid so on a hot day it can be difficult to go around.

title: Go early to enjoy the peacefulness of the Garden!
content: As with almost every other big attraction in China, it is good to go early. If you can arrive before the buses of tourist come then you have a great advantage! This is especially true for sights such as the Yu Garden. It is absolutely beautiful and as others have said an ideal spot for picture taking. We had no trouble with crowds until the very end of our visit... but they were arriving as we were leaving!

title: The most famous garden in Shanghai
content: This is one of the most famous gardens in China (the other two being in Suzhou, China). The main elements to design a proper garden (plants, rock, water) are all here in designer style.

title: Living in the past
content: The place is so unique. Give us a glimpse of the past. So many details in that house that we still can enjoy it.

title: YuYuan Garden, not just YuYuan Tourist Mart and City God Temple
content: YuYuan Garden is a deal compared to the tourist tat just outside. It's definitely worth the price ($5-6 US, cheaper for students) to enter the beautiful Ming Dynasty, Suzhou- style garden adjacent to the City God Temple (Chenghuang Miao) and YuYuan Tourist Mart. The 5 acre garden is an oasis in the middle of very urban Shanghai. It has stone boats, towers and bridges, dragon walls, pavilions, halls, a 5- ton boulder, plants and water, all beautifully integrated within the overall design. Turn a corner, and a different scene appears. This is the second time I have visited - YuYuan Garden seems to have improved in the last 10 years. Great value compared to other gardens popular in Europe and US. The City God Temple is fabulous as well- it just suffers a bit from being on top of the tourist mart shops. Line 10 YuYuan Garden stop.

title: Touristy and crowded but great if this is your first time in Shanghai
content: Growing up with Asian culture, definitely have been to many high quality gardens. The area surrounding Yu Garden is a lot of commercial buildings with touristy stores. This is not a place I would recommend for my family or those who are very familiar with Chinese culture but is a great place to visit for my 3 friends who have not had much exposure to Chinese culture before. Yu Garden is about 400 years old with architectural elements from Ming and Qing dynasties and classic design of lots of turns and twists and ever-changing views-- typified by the phrase near the entry "峰迴路轉" which means the circulating roads going up the mountains and the roads that keep changing the directions--also signifies that the circumstances you are going through right now may change completely with the next turn of the corners--often used to encourage folks who are going through hard time in life that the next turn of road could bring you a completely different and there maybe very bright future ahead of you. Expect to bargain in all the stores, would recommend to start at 40-50% of the asking price.

title: Nice look into the China of yesterday
content: we were there on an extremely hot day. The gardens are very nice as are the buildings. we really enjoyed the shops in the area as well.

title: Unexpected tranquility amidst the urban maelstrom
content: The Ming Dynasty buildings, bridges nad walks are fascinating ! My excellent guide could even fill us in on factoids such as the benches being used by courtesans who could not hobble very far onn their bound feet- their three inch golden lotuses !-in days of antiquity. The Garden is actuallya sheltered and quite cool refuge amidst the stupefying heat and chaos of Shanghai in July !

title: Lovely gardens and architecture
content: Very busy attraction, but we really enjoyed strolling around at a leisurely pace taking in the atmosphere and different perspectives of the impressive architecture. A must do.

title: An oasis of calm in the crazy area...take the aerogard
content: We wandered in here for a few hours of quite, cool and calm. Very quiet and fascinating landscape architecture. Spend a moment watching the carp being fed, insane. Lots of bugs so use some repellant. Not easy to find by signage in amongst the shops but keep asking people. Spend a good deal of time here but the shops dotted throughout a very expensive.

title: Yakitty yak
content: Beautiful garden wasted by Chinese people screaming YAKKITY YAK into their i-phones and paying no attention to the serene beauty around them. Go very early morning.

title: delicious
content: An old town temple full of lovely food vendors. Very traditional and always very packed on a good day. Steamed dumplings are absolutely great!

title: A sea of persons
content: Yugarden is an extensive Chinese garden located in the Old City of Shanghai (near the City God Temple). We walked to the Garden from our hotel picking a day where, what appeared to thousand of persons had the same idea. A moving sea of people that occupied almost every space in the 5 hectares of garden and all roads leading to the garden. The halls and Chamber on view each have their own individual story and are separated from each other by dragon walls. We found the crowd pressing but they did not detract from the experience. A must visit.

title: Beautiful water garden
content: Well worth a visit when your in Shanghai. The gardens are beautiful and surprisingly bigger than expected. We enjoyed watching people feed the fish.

title: Get Inspired!
content: Well, i have visited this garden 3 times and i will keep visitng every time i am in Shanghai. Packed with people and you can always find a spot that you will be alone to enjoy the good architecture, the trees or the fish...Definately a must see if you want to clear your mind and get inspired

title: Nice place to visit - pity about the shops
content: Interesting architecture and the gardens are great to see but as others have said it isn't a place to go on weekends or holidays. The crowds are horrendous. The staff in the souvenir shops are also a bit of an issue as some of them are quite "pushy" with trying to sell you something.

title: Amazing garden with ancient history
content: Loved this historic garden. Although it was packed with people we have enjoyed our afternoon exploring the garden and its history. It was not quiet or serene but it was very nice and authentic nonetheless! The markets surrounding the garden only added to our experience. Definitely recommend to visit!

title: Avoid public hollidays
content: The gardens are pretty nice, but please avoid to go there during Chinese public holidays. There are some souvenir shops around if you like to buy some...

title: Relaxing time in Yu Garden
content: This is a beutiful place where you just can walk around and relax. Here you can see a lot of "old" chinese culture, beatiful buildings and small water ponds. You can also buy a lot of things, but don't forget to discuss prices. Prices that are on the price tags are never correct.

title: Attractive well laid out garden.
content: A peaceful garden well laid out .....tranquil place to step into away from the hustle & bustle of Shanghai's old city which is crowded with shops for tourists.

title: Well worth a look
content: Rained all day the day we went but could see it would be great for photography. Had a free no obligation tea tasting experience as well. Area is surrounded by shops where you bargain for a good deal. Plenty of places to eat.

title: Enchanting Garden
content: We looked forward to seeing the Oriental Garden, as is often the case we interpret our expectation to what we would expect back home.Surprise the garden is of limited in size , surrounding ponds of enormous carp and various temples etc. Interesting to look at the roof designs with various animals shown.

title: Worth a visit
content: A nice oasis in this busy city. Not spacious but nicely segmented to provide a quality place to visit. We'd recommend a visit

user_loc: 弗吉尼亚弗吉尼亚海滩
title: Culture and Color!
content: This garden was one of our first sites to visit in Shanghai.This appears to be a very popular tourist spot, so expect large crowds. The gardens are divided into several sections engulfed with luscious green foliage and vibrant florals. There's also a bridge that crosses over a lovely Koi fish pond filled with these huge and hungry Koi fish. There's a residential section where you can't enter, but can look into some of the ornately decorated quarters. There are some bumpy ,uneven areas to walk over, so flat shoes with some support are recommended . When visiting Shanghai, these gardens are a must.

title: Garden
content: Part of old Shanghai.Necessary to see to understand some of the history.It shows the way of life in former times.

title: Wonderful Chinese garden
content: If you love China history and nature this place is right for you!

title: Old style, modern
content: Beautiful old buildings utilised as a modern mall, be prepared for lots of people to the point of crowding. It is a maze that zig zags to take you around the complex and therefore enjoy the views, bird life, fish(koi) and the sights and sounds. Quite good bargains to be had at this market.

title: Serene spot in the city but go early
content: Having read others' reviews about how crowded it gets, so I went on a Monday morning soon after it opened. I did not realize until the very end that I had toured the garden backwards from the exit to the entrance (there was a ticket stand at the exit and they let me in). This actually turned out to be a good move because for a good part of my time there, it felt serene and quiet.

title: The place you would like to spend more time than expected
content: A very unique authentic place, calm and beautiful. The close very neatly, at 17:00, so please come in advance, at least 1 hour prior to closing.

title: A Cultural delight
content: The weather was surprising wonderful despite a short rain shower. The garden was beautiful and definitely showed Feng Shui. The old buildings and landscaping was worth experiencing. We had an excellent tour guide which made the history and tour even more wonderful.

title: Serenity in a city of 40,000,000
content: A delightful spot in a teeming city. It's adjacent to Shanghai's Chinatown. Still not sure how a city in China could be called "Chinatown". With soothing Koi ponds and ancient architecture it's a "must " on any tour of this immense city.

title: Busy!!!
content: Even on a rainy day and at 10am the place is busy.

user_loc: 佛罗里达哈伦代尔海滩
title: A beautiful example of ancient Chinese feng shui
content: This magnificent garden is a tranquil reminder of old China as it existed hundreds of years ago right smack in the midst of one of the present day busy city.

title: Don't be put off by the busy shopping area outside.
content: This garden was a welcome relief from the hustle and bustle of Chinatown shopping right at its gate. There were parts where you could sit and feed the fish and study the gardens built by a very wealthy merchant. Nothing was spared in his house. Was also cool inside. Nice that it has been kept so close to the inner city.

title: A beautiful restored gardens in the heart of Shanghai
content: This was a sight-seeing trip as part of a family wedding in the area, and staying locally for a few days.

title: Awesome Serenity
content: This is a very serene piece of quiet paradise in the middle of the crowded hustle bustle of the touristy bazaar area with the aggressive sales people trying to get you to go to the tea house or buy a watch. I had some difficulty finding the entrance, it is a tiny ticket booth with no English signage. Once I stepped past the entrance, I was in paradise. The summer rain made it seem even more mystical and serene, as not only did that keep the crowds out, but there is something about the beauty in the garden and the soft rain that made it just feel good for my soul. Almost everywhere I looked seemed like a photo out of a perfect Chinese garden magazine. If only I could have this for my back yard! If you want to escape the frenzy of the bazaar and relax, then it's worth spending an hour or more here.

title: A Classical ancient Chinese Rock Garden
content: We visited this garden on June 6, 2014. The entrance to the garden was in the heart of a tourist shopping mall area where you could walk the streets. The entrance has a large pool with ducks, sculpture bridges and fountain. Although noisy and busy, the entrance was surrounded by highly lacquered wooden buildings. The garden is fairly large and has extensive walkways. It is primarily a rock garden with ponds and interesting and ancient Chinese-style buildings. It is worth seeing. You wind through a maze of walkways and areas which give the garden a peaceful and restful feeling. There are several ancient Chinese buildings with the tile roofs and the curled up roof corners. There is a nice pond in the center of the garden with waterfalls and lots of different rocks. The garden also has a couple of typical Chinese lions (male on the left and woman on the right) and a large dragon edging a roof. There is not much English to explain the meanings of the garden elements and the brochure is mostly in Chinese with only a small bit of English. It is probably worth a visit for and hour or a little more.

title: Scenic maze
content: Quiet piece of China in the middle of Shanghai.

title: beautiful
content: definitely worth having a look such a beautiful look into how the wealthy would have lived before Shanghai became what it is now

title: Beautiful but too many people
content: This place is a very nice place in Shanghai and shows a lot of beautiful Chinese Architecture. The only thing is that the place is crowded with people.

title: Okay but not Great
content: The garden is a nice way to spend a couple of hours but wasn't the type of "garden" I was expecting. If you're expecting beautiful flowers and landscaping, this isn't it. It does have neat buildings, great photo opps, and old stones. But is not what I would call tranquil, quiet, or breath taking. Was just "okay" but worth the price of entry and a nice diversion from the crowded tourist trap that awaits on the other side of the wall.

title: Beautiful gardens, so much to see
content: We enjoyed the gardens immensely.... so much to offer with ponds, very old trees, interesting rocks and temples. It is very popular and therefore very busy but that is what you have to expect in such a large country (most of the visitors are local). Go with the flow and enjoy.

title: Disappointing
content: - one of the over-hyped places in Shanghai

title: If you could get rid of the tourists,it would be idyllic
content: We visited many gardens while in China and this was by far the most beautiful.

title: Beautiful gardens
content: Expect a lot of people in this area. The gardens are quite beautiful and nicely maintained. However, I'm not sure about the pond though - looks very dirty. We found this area to be great for photography - great views overlooking beautiful architecture.

title: Just to say you have been there..
content: go early when it is quiet and empty...   there are other interests nearby so it's worth a quick run through.

title: Peaceful
content: After crossing the zigzag bridge you enter into the Yugarden, a peaceful oasis in a busy city. Go with a guide to get the full experience

title: Old world charm
content: Good n old garden full of Chinese history . Good shopping area outside the garden to spend time . Nice area to spend time.

title: An old Chinese architecture
content: This place used to be the resident house for a general. The place is well decorated with man made structure with lovely interior deco, ponds and garden. In short, is a Chinese Mansion in a heart of a busy city. The entrance fee is not really expensive and worth the visit. Be there early to avoid the crowd.

title: Peaceful
content: Yugarden was one of my favorite spots in Shanghai. There are many restaurants and shops around the entrance, and LOTS of people. This is a major tourist attraction for Chinese and foreigners alike. We were warned to safeguard our wallets/purses in this area. The tea house at the entrance is the one depicted on old Blue Willow China- make sure to take time to appreciate its architecture. Inside the garden the noise disappears and quiet reigns. This is a huge garden with many areas, so it never seemed crowded. Everywhere you look there is a wonder- ponds full of koi, small pavilions, stone bridges, secret gardens. The flowers were lovely, and I really enjoyed the stone/rock formations. The bonsai collection was also a favorite. Make sure you look up- every rooftop is adorned with magical little figurines. For a great, inexpensive meal, visit the cafeteria on the second floor of the building across from the entrance to the park. This is where the Chinese eat and the food is good and authentic- we were the only Westerners there.

title: Beautiful garden
content: This garden is a must see in Shanghai. Although touristic, you will find very quiet places for a walk, to relax or to rest, to have a picnic, great to spend some time here in the garden with flowers, old trees, rocks, pavilions, water and fish. You end up at the tea house and in the centre of old Shanghai, lot of souvenir shops, restaurants and lot of people.

title: Contentment?
content: Many words describe this garden, but contentment is not one of them! Crowded, heaving, packed, loud and selfie are words that spring to mind when thinking about this place.

title: Much bigger than I though
content: Wow, this garden is huge and to think it was made for a single family. There were many different paths winding through the garden; I am not sure that I even saw the whole garden and I was there for a couple of hours. It would be a very peaceful place if there weren't so many people. I enjoyed finding small little paths that no one else was on. The rocks, plants, and water are beautiful. I would like to back again this time not on a holiday weekend.

user_loc: 路易斯安那州新奥尔良
title: Beautiful despite Wars and Hordes
content: Yuyuan is a Ming Dynasty classical Chinese Garden, designed by a high official as a place for serenity and contemplation. Perhaps he should have consulted a better feng shui master before he broke ground; the garden has had more than its fair share of misfortune, up to and including currently being overrun by hordes of tourists like me. Nevertheless, I strongly recommend it. Despite all its woes over the years, it still provides its visitors an excellent ramble through a Ming mandarin's private garden. Particularly useful if you aren't going on to the gardens in Suzhou.

title: Nice garden but loved the markets.
content: I walked along the Bund to find the garden and first came upon the markets. It's a bit like stepping back in time with the traditional Chinese architecture and all the market stalls. I really loved the hustle and bustle of it all. I then checked out the garden which was quite nice with its plants and ponds. It wasn't very big and there didn't seem any logical way around it, but it was an oasis from the markets.

title: Lovely
content: This spot is so lovey - a perfect respite in the busy city. I was visiting on a super hot day and surprisingly, in the garden, it almost seemed cooler.

user_loc: 印第安那印第安纳波利斯
title: Get there EARLY
content: The YuYuan Gardens open at 8:30 am and if you're trying to enjoy the tranquility and be able to see the gardens and surroundings, you'll be there at 8:30 to get in before the crowds. The garden is definitely worth your time - absolutely stunning. The most disappointing part of it all is that you have to wind through mazes of trinket shops and people trying to sell you stuff to get to it. There are tons and tons of shops within the "city area" and along the block around the garden itself. It's sad that so much commercialization has overtaken this natural beauty.

title: A break from the craziness outside the walls!
content: There are a lot of pavilions and rock gardens and little paths throughout the garden. It is a nice break from the commercial craziness outside the walls. Worth the entry fee and your time. Saturday afternoon may not be an ideal due to the crowds, but don't miss it!

title: Relaxing....
content: Like many of the chinese gardens this one is both pretty and relaxing. It is very old and has some interesting history if you have a good guide to explain it.

title: Peace and Harmony amid the chaos
content: The Market area around this garden is crammed, wall to wall with shops and people. It was very nice to step over the threshold and enjoy a bit of space and peace of this delightful garden.

user_loc: 哥伦比亚特区华盛顿特区
title: Crowds!
content: A beautiful place, but crowded no matter when you go. Go for a stroll and pictures, but don't expect much history or serenity.

title: Peace in the City
content: Classic Chinese garden in the centre of Shanghai that's a great place to escape for an hour or two from the hassle and bustle of Yu Garden and, indeed, Shanghai as a whole. Our advice, meander at your own pace, find a few spots to perch and take in the peace and tranquility as you won't get it again until you move on from Shanghai!

title: imagine serenity...
content: ...because there will be too many tourists to find the gardens serene. That said, the layout is beautiful

title: So pretty
content: Such a pretty and peaceful spot! it's hard to imagine you're actually still in Shanghai (but could be quite busy, depending on the time; went there in december and was actually quite OK).

title: Yu Gardens
content: Allow a couple of hours to view this excellent example of Chinese gardens. It is beautiful and relatively crowd free ( as compared to the crowds outside). The markets outside seem to offer better value than those in other parts of Shanghai.

title: A great intro to China
content: My husband and I spent the first afternoon in China at this garden, and after a holiday of 2 weeks it is still one of my favourite places. I can't understand some of the other reviews though, the garden does cost 40 RMB but i think it was well worth it. it is situated inside a public park and next to a bazaar, but you can visit both of the former for free, there are no stalls or shopping, or refreshments inside the garden itself. You need at least 1hr 30 mins for your visit. There are loads of old pagoda style buildings with pretty rock gardens in between them and several ponds and water features full of koi carp. There are also bonsai trees. Every window or corner presents another photo opportunity. One of the buildings is a traditional tea house and if your not chinese, they will do a tea ceremony for you, but they do expect you to look at the 'shop' afterwards. The loos are clean but chinse (

title: this is a most if you go to shanghai
content: great experience

title: Not so attractive
content: Entrance fee is RMB40. Dont expect to see like the Japanese garden. Quite an ordinary garden with few old houses/architecture. Visitors should be given a simple guide leaflet to roam around.

title: Great place to see the local relaxing
content: There was not much to the gardens but it was just nice to see the locals relaxing in the park. Playing card, singing and you can have a beer in the court yard.

title: Shopping
content: Gardens are nice, this is where the shopping for trinkets is best though. There are plenty of shops and stalls, so look around and most definitely haggle.

title: Beautiful garden in middle of busy Shanghai
content: Went here on a Saturday together with many other people who had the same idea. Still the garden is beautiful, full of history and gets you out of the busy streets outside the garden.

title: Nice garden to spend an afternoon in
content: Very pretty garden with a reasonable admission price that you can spend the afternoon walking around in. It was spring so many of the flowers and the trees were just beginning to bloom. Definitely worth the walk!

title: Best example of a classical Chinese scholars garden.
content: If you don't go to Suzhou, the Yu Yuan garden is the best alternative for seeing a classical garden design. The twists and turns, pavillions, use of stone and spare use of plantings, give you a sense of what it was like in Ming dynasty China, at least for a rich family. Take your time, do not rush through.

title: Nice gardens in the center of the city
content: beautiful gardens and many many shops for tourists.  lots to see and do within an easy walk from the Bund

title: A garden of its own type
content: The beauty of Shanghai is its well-connectivity. Easily accessible by metro, these gardens lock out the outside noise and market bustle. The garden is beautiful and extremely well designed - after every 8-10 minutes, they have set up pagodas or benches for visitors to relax. There is also a tea house where you can not only try different Chinese tea but can also buy what you like.

title: Tea house tricksters
content: The gardens was interesting, however,we were caught by con artist, young English speaking Chinese , asking you to take a photo and striking up a conversation, then inviting you to join them for a tea ceremony. We ending sharing an exorbitant bill with then. ($400,00) . We recovered the money the next day reporting it to the police, and ad

title: Yu Garden visit
content: Ok to visit once. This garden gives you feel of old Chines architecture. But not extra ordinary. Yu market next to this garden was good. Lot many shops, old Chinese buildings well maintained can be seen here. Zig zag bridge was worth visiting.

title: Beautiful - so don't hurry through it
content: This was an oasis in the city. Every turn in the garden led to new things to look at. We even developed an appreciation for the Chinese rock garden. Be sure to note all the windows and door openings which are different in size and shape - designed to create their own "picture" when you look through them.

title: Enchanting place
content: My first time I been there it was 13 years ago, but every time I am in the area with my family we go there. I was so lucky because some year ago it was snowing and we was there, there was a magic atmosphere.

title: Beautiful and peaceful garden in the city
content: Many tourists there, but still one of my favorites in shanghai!

title: A pearl inside the chaos of market
content: This garden is really a breath of oxygen when you find it in between the huge quantity of souvenir shops. When you arrive in Yu Garden area probably your will be chocked by the noise and the "pushing" style of shops owners. Do not get scared and go straight inside the heart of it, you will find this beautiful garden. Do not expect a typical green garden, but it an exquisite sequences of rocks and pavilions, and small lakes and passage in typical Chinese style. Chinese do not love sun and sunlight so their idea of garden is very different from our. It is full of small corners and passages, From some part you can see the incredible contrast between this old beauty and the skyline of Pudong on the landscape, it can create fabulous impressive pictures. Immediately outside there is the old house of tea ( you recognise it cause it's I I the middle of a small lake with zigzag passage; this because they thought bad spirit can walk only in line not going zigzag, so the house is supposed to be preserved by bad spirit :). Excellent to take a tea fare the visit

title: Very pretty and worth lingering at
content: The location of these gardens is quite unexpected. You end up in a crowded part of town, weave your way through sets of busy alleyways filled with shops and customers and remarkably end up at this peaceful and unlikely oasis.

title: China town in China
content: very authentic , must see places.. lots of silk, jewellery.. Lots of traditional food .. Bargaining is must, it is pushing your imagination. 6-7 times higher asking price... Don't scare to turn back, they drop the price instantly like %80..

title: Worth seeing
content: I was hoping it would be more of a garden, but it was still lovely and there are trees and plants, ponds, koi, and architecture to appreciate, as well as displays of artwork. We were here on a Saturday afternoon and it was crowded but not so that we couldn't appreciate the views. It's sort of maze-like as you walk though, there are narrow halls and doorways that you progress around and through.

title: Interesting complex
content: The garden is a collection of buildings with plantings and water weaving through them. It is peaceful and attractive and represents an older era. But do not expect massive plantings of flowers and decorative arrangements. It is not that kind of garden.

title: Tranquility midst Chaos
content: Nothing could have prepared me for the beautiful gardens that come after you navigate through a bustling are filled with shops, shoppers and everything you want to shop! These gardens had amazing rocks, gorgeous trees and peaceful vistas that include lakes and gorgeous well appointed sculptures. The fact that these gardens, like everything else in China, have a history makes them that much more exotic!

title: Fell in love!
content: This is Shanghai's gem. It is a piece of old China lost in the middle of the cosmopolitan Shanghai. It is beautiful, peaceful, totally a must see.

title: A sightseeing highlight of Shanghai
content: The Yu Yuan Garden is probably the best of Shanghai's ancient gardens, located in the heart of the old city and surrounded by an interesting and safe shopping area. The garden was originally created back in the 16th century and features many excellent areas like the dragon wall; the moon gate, the long-roofed corridor bridge and a brilliant collection of garden windows and doors.

title: Lovely peaceful place
content: Lovely peaceful place, despite the crowds of people, they seem to have packed a lot in a small area very clever design.

title: Quintessential Chinese Garden Among Shopping Land
content: This decently-sized Chinese park is a wonderful oasis from the hustle and energy of Old Shanghai City shopping district that surrounds it. While the park is authentically historical, the surrounding shopping district, no matter how convincing the architecture appears, is definitely not. From American fast-food restaurants to quality high-end clothing to mass produced trinkets, the shopping area is a vast area you will have to navigate to get to the garden. There are many food shops in the area once you enter the garden so you can easily plan to eat before or after your visit to the garden. I'm not aware of any food offered for sale once inside so plan accordingly.

title: Old China in the middle of Metropolitan
content: where the place must visit in Shanghai, and you'll be found an Chinese Garden with old style. Many local shop who sold China merchandise, little bit cheap than any else place. One thing that I really loves about this place was the buildings and garden, looks so peaceful and awesome. Bamboo everywhere look, and said This is China.

title: Beautiful garden
content: Very nice garden, it could be quiet i suppose.

title: Excellent place
content: Not only the garden, but the shopping is fantastic, those new building looking old with a variety of souvenir shops, food, drink, tea shop, curiosity shop, this little street are full of people, it is a place to see.

title: Very pretty, but crowded
