content: We were impressed by the artful garden construction and placid water element in Yu Garden. It is aptly named the Garden of Contentment. There are lovely trees and pagodas and period furniture to see, but we chose a time of day when it was crowded ( late afternoon). I would recommend trying another time of day, perhaps in the morning. We were able to capture a few images for posterity and my amateur photography hobby, and my son was impressed with the striking views and smart use of space. Lovely. I'd like to return in the spring to see it in full bloom.

title: Yu (Yu Yuan) Garden. Glory & Surprise at every turn
content: Yu Gardens, "Garden of contentment" 218 Anren St, Huangpu, Shanghai, China, +86 21 6326 0830, or Shanghai Metro line 10, Yugarden station. Entry 40CNY. Conceived in the mid 16th C, Ming dynasty, and in the 18th C. Taiping rebelion & damaged in the 19th C. Opium wars, it is now pristine and glorious. The gardens consist of pools of Koi carp and waterfalls surrounded by boardwalks and pavilions. As you walk along the boards, you have to make sudden turns around buildings to be surprised by a new vista, different from all others. The rockeries add depth and perspective and the brightly coloured pagodas are a real treat. This is not just a garden, it is a work, or should I say collection of works of art, architecture and landscaping. In a city justly proud of its history, culture, cuisine and architecture (old and new). the Yugarden is a "Must see". The only sour note, a McDonalds at the exit. It is like spray painting grafitti on the alter, but it is called "Progress" instead. Still, the entrance/exit is at the market, so you can leave McD to the culinary barbarians and buy from the locals.

title: Very Pretty
content: This is such a nice contrast to the busy Shanghai city life. The landscape was covered in koi ponds, zigzag bridges, rockeries and blooming flowers. The crowds were minimal and my time spent here was very peaceful.

title: Historical buildings meet shopping area
content: great garden with fantastic architecture and nice garden layout. the garden closes already at 5 PM, and we still had to pay the full price despite we entered it only at 4 PM.

title: Yu Garden
content: Great place, an oasis in the middle of the city. Visit the Bazaar and great place for a tea ceremony - try the Ginseng Oolong tea - fantastic:-))

title: Peaceful
content: Very peaceful and beautiful. Lots of detail. Fun to wander and get lost in its maze of paths. Many of the temple looking buildings had Ming dynasty era furniture etc on display. Great picture taking opportunities all around. I love the rockery.

title: If you could only visit one thing in town...
content: No wonder so many state guests and presidents are shown this site: in this huge city that seems to change its skyline every couple of moths, this small park, its paths, ponds and pagoda halls, is the closest any part of town gets to "old" and sculpted China. Foto opportunities galore, and soothing on the mind, despite the hordes of tourists - national and foreign - that wish to experience this nice place. Definitely worth seeing, even though the massive new Disneyland "Chinese fantasy"- like tourist zone just outside with zillions of shops and food stands can be a bit overwhelming. Again: if there is only one thing you can see in town...

title: Amazing garden
content: We only had one day to explore Shanghai, but we spent a good deal of our time exploring the garden. A real treasure.

title: Gorgeous
content: I loved walking through the Yu Garden, it was so peaceful. The nearby market was great to find all those souvenirs too.

title: Must See!
content: This is a must see for first time visitors to Shanghai. It is an opportunity to witness the juxtaposition of modern and ancient cultures in one breathtaking space.

title: Already seen quite a few gardens
content: It is a pleasant garden and with our guide it was quite interesting - we had already seen a couple of much larger and better gardens in other cities.

title: Average
content: It's a average Chinese garden, it's not very big , lots of people of course but its not anything great not many signs explaining the different plants in English ,

title: Ancient street with a modern feel
content: From the looks of it, it's like an ancient Shanghai streets but they have lots of modern things such as clothes, jewelleries, china waves, clothes etc selling there. You have to bargain if not you'll have to pay high exorbitant prices. Some of the ladies clothes are very nice but not all retailers are willing to give discount.

title: Nice Garden!!
content: the Yu-Yuan Garden is one of chinas best gardens of the qin-dinasty and is located in the old town of Shanghai. the entrance fee is 5€ or less, but not more ;) just be warned, its allways full with tourists and before you enter the garden sellers follow you and try to sell you something because you are from the west ^^ inside the garden its beautiful with all the nature and the little ponds... its one of the top attractions!

title: The most remembered
content: The Yuyuangarden was in our list from the very beginning.

title: Excellent Garden and Architecture
content: Yuyuan Garden is well worth including on your itinerary in Shanghai and it is close to the Yuyaun Bazaar with which you can combine a shopping visit and also see the Town Shine. It is a classical Chinese garden and captures the essence of the past both in the architecture and garden design. For this whole area it is probably worth allowing 3 - 4 hours.

title: Learn more about the Dynasties
content: Great pictures to take at this place while you learnedbuilt during the Ming Dynasty by the high-ranking government official Pan Yunduan. The Gardens' total area occupies approximately five acres, and features pavilions, ponds, rockeries, cloisters, and streams all within six scenic zones, including the Sansui Hall and Wanhua Chamber. In existence for 400 years, the Gardens were specifically constructed for Pan's aging parents as a sanctuary in which to live out their lives

title: A little inner city magic
content: Seems a little bit of tradition preserved within the metropolis.The side streets surrounding the Yugarden are well worth exploring.

title: As the name suggests.
content: Nice place to visit. Some of the architecture is amazing. Decent way to spend half day. Loads of tourists. Gets crowded. Must it's worth a visit.

title: Crowded
content: Typical tourist trap. Not much to see in the gardens themselves except tour groups. The real attraction is the shopping nearby.

title: Not what I expected
content: Although the gardens were very nice, they were much smaller than I expected. We were through to the end within five minutes!

title: Beautiful
content: Took a guided tour around here. It is certainly steeped in history and shows some wonderful architecture. The nearby stalls or tourist shops are a bit of a rip off but still worth a look. Bargain, bargain, bargain to get the best price.

title: Nice garden
content: The garden is located in the city center. The Garden of Contentment is a nice place where you can find some peace in a location where there is a lot of confusion. The entrance fee is 40 RMB. The garden is made ​​up of several pagodas, numerous small lakes and many flowers and plants. There are also bonsai trees.

title: Harmony and Feng Shui
content: This is a quiet oasis in the middle of a very busy city. I visited with a guide and it was great to have detailed explanations of the many symbolic features of the garden

title: Awesome place... but sooooo busy!
content: The gardens and waterscapes are beautiful, and walking across the bridges is great. The only problem is the crowds... there is considerable congestion. Never the less, this is well worth a visit. Nice place to have an alfresco lunch or drink.

title: Nice, but crowded
content: Yu Yuan Garden is a very nice experience with its architecture and pleasant environment. Good for a slow walk and visit to a restaurant.

title: Beautiful gardens
content: Beautiful gardens and buildings surrounded by lots of touristy restaurants and souvenir shops. Beautiful to see, and great spot for photos. A bit of old Shanghai surrounding the new city.

title: A little bit of the REAL Shanghai
content: The Yu Yuan Garden area is definitely one of the must sees in Shanghai! The whole area is still quite original and has a lot of traditional shops and attractions as well as some of the most amazing street food in the city. Especially if you are on the hunt for small souvenirs to take home, this is the place to go! Also take a look at the garden itself and the city god temple. Can spend easily a full afternoon there, but plan it at least 2 hours!

title: Peaceful oasis in a busy city
content: Once you enter Yu Yuan Garden you eave the busy city behind Small ponds, beautiful sights, scenic trees, all contribute to a felling of serenity

title: An oasis in the middle of mayhem
content: Yu Yuan Garden is smack in the middle of the most touristy shopping place.Once you enter,it is calm,quite and a restful place.Great architecture

title: Realaxing walk in gardens, very peaceful.
content: Enjoyable experience walking in the gardens.

title: A walk in the past
content: This is definitely a must if you are in shanghai. It is like taking a walk in an ancient city that you can only see in a chinese drama series.

title: Lovely gardens and........a shopping bazaar
content: Lovely gardens that were completed in 1577 - so have been in existence for over 400 years. There are a number of different scenic areas to visit - pools, streams, courtyards, rockeries, gardens and halls. It is best known, I believe, for its Great Rockery and Exquisite Jade Rock. I thoroughly enjoyed visiting the gardens - though, with so many tourists, they are certainly not as serene and peaceful as I'm sure they once were. This is due, in no large part, to the shopping bazaar located just outside the gardens - selling ice cream, food - including a very famous dumpling restaurant, pearls, chopsticks, paintings, fans - and many other Chinese treasures. The area is definitely tourist central and a study in contrasts - the lovely gardens vs. the chaotic shopping area! Definitely worth the visit - for both.

title: Haven of peace in spite of the crowds…
content: The Garden of Contentment is a fascinating place, if only because you discover that it is actually possible to experience the power of Feng Shui in the midst of tourist pragmatism. It is a very popular place for tourists and we had lots and lots of company when we visited. In spite of that, it was very clear the power of its design for peace of spirit and contentment. The layout of the garden, pavilions, water and walkways are all conducive to thoughtfulness and peace. Of course, as one of many visitors bumping into each other and rubbing shoulders, elbows, backs and hips, one can only imagine what it must have been like for the scholars who peopled it back in the day. But, really, don't be put off by this! It is not to be missed, is a beautiful place and very worth your while.

title: Beautiful spot right in the city
content: Loved walking around the gardens. There were so many beautiful things to see. Very serene, calm and quiet place--except for all the tourists.

title: Wonderful!
content: This was such a surprise. Wasn't going to visit, but so glad we did! The garden is beautiful! A wonderful place to spend a little quiet time away from the crowds (there were a lot of visitors here, but not like the area surrounding the garden!).

title: Old and beautiful Chinese style
content: I really recommend visiting the garden and the market/streets around the garden, if you are in Shanghai. It is a huge contrast to find this beautiful old Chinese arquitectural style in this modern city. We really enjoyed just wondering the streets around the garden (in fact we had to do that to be able to find the entrance to the garden, not that easy to find, however we really enjoyed the busy life of those streets, and the beautiful old buildings). The garden was another maze to enjoy a stroll in, of course it is busy, this is very touristic area, don't expect to be by yourself in the garden, just enjoy it ...

title: Tranquility - the contrasts of Shanghai
content: Like many other reviewers I also found this a little crowded, but if you take your time and avoid the big tour groups you can get lost in the tranquility. The garden is 2 hectares and not well sign posted. There are many little nooks and crannies to sit and savour the serenity.

title: Nice garden, beware of scams!
content: The garden is worth seeing. However just like others before me wrote: beware of the tea garden scam!!!

title: Chinese temple and garden
content: This place is very touristic and yet beautiful. We had never seen so many koi fish(Japanese carps) before and the garden itself is very relaxing. We spent a whole day visiting the garden and the nearby City Temple Of God. The shops in the surroundings are great for shopping. This was a great DIY tour we had.

title: Too crowded! Not worth the money!
content: Too many people inspite of the price that you pay to enter (40 RMB). Its not as quiet as its made out to be. Lots and lots of tourists and locals inside the garden. Its difficult to locate as its inside one of the little lanes off the main road. The little vendors on the way to the garden try hard to fleece you once they've made out you're not a local. For example - this lady quoted RMB 350 for a fridge magnet and sold it to me for RMB 5 as i started to walk away. Another vendor tried to sell me something that he said was RMB 1200. He finally came down to a price of RMB 100. Great place to bargain and buy if thats what you like doing and good place to see what old china must've been.

title: Nice garden but too crowded
content: It is indeed the great garden in the old time but due to lots of tourist, it feels like a market or bazaar. The market outside the garden is really crowded for sure. the price is a little too high. It's hard to take a nice shot among the sea of heads

title: Historical Beauty
content: Wow this place just took me back in time and is absolutely amazing!! Every visitor in Shanghai must experience this beautiful garden of gorgeous Chinese history and shops. Truly a wonderful experience nestled away in the midst of an ultra sophisticated and gorgeous city.

title: Absolutely amazing
content: This is a place everyone should see visiting Shanghai.. Many souvenir shops surrounding the garden are a real tourist attraction. One of the most famous dim sum restaurants is located at this area. You gotta have time to wait for long lines to get your delicious dim sum.

title: Absolutely stunning.
content: Our tour guide started off our tour with this phrase, "If you don't visit the Yu Yuan Garden while you're in Shanghai, then you never went to Shanghai." She was absolutely right. Before finding the entrance to the garden, you have to walk through busy crowds and shops. It was extremely busy due to the dim sum festival that was taking place (the dim sum was delicious!). Once you find the garden, it really will take your breath away. You forget that you are in a busy city. Make sure to get a tour guide who can explain all the amazing details.

title: Serene and beautiful not to be missed
content: The gardens are serene and really beautiful The surrounding area is gorgeous with ancient typical Chinese buildings around. You do not see many of these old Chinese architecture buildings in China any longer Well worth the visit

title: Originally place in the middle of a busy city
content: a hint how old China could have been, special atmosphere, very quiet and inspiring place - unfortunately located within a very touristic, busy and insistent neighborhood, but this should be no reason to avoid Yu Yuan Garden

title: Garden amidst a modern and progressive city
content: The beauty of this place is its irony of the luscious and traditional garden infused in a modern and progressive city. The entrance to the garden is not easy to find. You have to go through the shops and small streets that will direct you to it. The good thing about this place as well is that there are shops and food stalls located within its surroundings. You can buy cheap items around.

title: Lovely
content: Beautifullly laid garden and the name is very apt as you feel very content and peaceful in middle of this bustling city with lots of shopping around it.

title: Shopping is extraordinary here
content: The architecture is extraordinary here. Its 3-5 streets that wind around with quaint one of a kind shops, tea shops and restaurants. Bring your camera and take tons of photos because this is what you expect china to be.

title: Single Tourists Beware!
content: Please read other reviews for the actual garden description; my concern is with the tourist shops surrounding it -- which you must pass through to get there. Beware of "Tea-tasting" fraud, taking the form of an elaborate ruse. I was hustled by a couple English-speaking "Students" who befriended me and told me about a tea-sampling opportunity which only happened once a year. They took me to a shop where the three of us were entertained for the better part of an hour (in a small, closed room) by a young woman who gave us samples of several teas. The cost was presented up-front as $8 for tea, and $7 for the presenter -- only later (when the bill comes) are you advised that each tea is charged separately, and you now owe them more than $50. I found it easier to fork over the cash than risk unknown consequences of refusal, but needless to say, I was not a happy camper. Until the Chinese get better at self-policing the rampant fraud in their cities, I would advise travelers to visit more hospitable and civilized places, like Singapore and Japan -- there is a big difference in cultures!

title: Really loved this garden and the old city
content: This is a great place to wander around and enjoy the beauty gardens and tranquility of the surroundings....I even loved making my way through the multitude of shops that surround the gardens as the architecture is so interesting and really gives you a glimpse into the 'old' style of buildings that must have made up a big part of Shanghai in times gone by.

title: Peaceful and beautiful
content: A relaxing place to spend a few hours taking in the sights of beautiful gardens and amazing buildings.

title: Wonderful Oasis in the middle of a huge city!
content: We had a wonderful time at this garden. It is located near a fantastic bizaar and tons of fun shopping. It was peaceful and quiet and enjoyable. It was a highlight of our stay in Shanghai. We were there for business and had limited time to enjoy the city. This was a great pick!

title: Nice enough
content: Very touristy, but worth a visit. Can be done in less than two hours, and definitely not worth more than one visit.

title: The most important thing to visit here
content: Beside the down town area, that is better to see at night, these gardens are the best attraction of the city. Built in an area that is old and it has been very well preserved, the gardens are a very nice place to relax. Try the local food when you get out of these gardens: one of the best I've eaten in China

title: A piece of old Shanghai
content: This is a nicely preserved garden situated next to a lively market. Our Viking tour guide was most helpful in explaining the arrangement of many elements in the garden-- things I would not have known on my own. The market and shops surrounding the gardens are exciting, but also populated by the usual hawkers and do remember to watch for pickpockets! This is a popular stop for tourists but there are an abundance of local shoppers there, too

title: Yu need to visit
content: Easily accessed by the metro or taxi from central Shanghai. Host of historical buildings,water features and couple of better class souvenir and gift shops.We were surprised that by presentation of our Australian drivers licence it enabled us to a discounted entry charge.If you are over 60, over there, just enquire about discount at public attractions.

user_loc: 阿根廷布宜诺斯艾利斯
title: peaceful walk
content: the place is a peaceful spot in a restless city, go there and you'll find out why. I recommend to visit it.

title: on a week day
content: enjoy some time in one of the most beautiful gardens of Shanghai.

title: Tourist, Tourist, Tourist
content: Crowds will be insane and you will likely find no relief from those selling trinkets, but it is necessary to go in order to check it off the list. It is a good place to go to get worthless trinkets for those back home who want something "Chinese" - just negotiate with sellers (but do realize that some shops do not negotiate because they get so many Western tourists).

title: Beautiful
content: What an amazing residence! Traditional architecture, water features and quaint interiors - you feel like you are in ancient china! The street markets just outside also make it worth a visit! Lovely!

title: Peaceful garden on a quiet day
content: It was very busy when we visited. You cross a large courtyard of pagodas before you cross the bridge to the gardens. The pagodas alone were awesome.

title: Beautiful local "Disney World"
content: This was an amazing site, really pretty with the buildings, flowers, and ponds. But the number of people in the marketplace and the garden was completely overwhelming! You literally could not move. Maybe because it was a weekend or maybe it is always like this. Do not wear a backpack here! Remember to barter with all of the vendors. We paid 1/4 of the list price on almost everything.

title: Far too touristy to be good
content: Fighting our way through the tourist markets to get to the Yu Yuan Garden was hell on earth! If people think this is the real China they are WRONG!!!!

title: Beautiful!
content: Yu Yuan Garden is simply beautiful! One of the places I most liked in Shanghai. The garden is so peaceful, everything comes together and synchronises. It's a walk through the past, very interesting. Then you get to walk through the old town which is amazing too.

title: One of the better and more interesting Chinese Gardens
content: Liked that it was historic, family started, and in very good shape.

title: Amazing old garden in the middle of the bustle
content: On our first day in Shanghai we found our way to Yu garden which cost about 100 rmb each to enter.

title: "Chinatown in China!"
content: The garden area was fantastic with beautiful views, large pools, interesting bridges and scenic spots for photos. One of the walls has a gigantic dragon's head over the gate and the entire wall was the dragon's undulating back - definitely something to see. Immediately outside the garden is the "china town" area filled with shops, restaurants, dumplings; you name it, you can find it. We sampled some of the street food with interesting results. This is an area frequented by Chinese tourists, so English speakers were limited in the shops. We just pointed, paid and ate whatever looked interesting. A few surprises, but a great adventure.

title: Ancient garden of heaven
content: This was my first trip to Shanghai for a 4 days conference, and I was so anxious to visit one of those famous ancient gardens of China. Yu Yuan Garden was one of those. It was wonderful and so amazing that China people in the past was so artistic and so precise to build the beatiful garden. Outside the garden there were so many dim sum shops, then I tried one big juicy xiao long bao with a straw sticking in it. Hmm, the soup was so delicious! Then I took a walk through the small streets where other shops sells many traditional delicacies.

title: Don't miss it
content: After 10 days on my China tour, I had seen lots of gardens and historic buildings, so I was expecting more of the same. The Yu Gardens are special and should not be missed. They are a beautiful texture of garden, water, buildings and passageways. Almost every view feels sublime. I recommend getting there early to avoid the crowds.

title: Labirynth of picteresque spots
content: Liked everything except the crowd. But if you are there at 8.30 a.m. when it opens - for the first hour you can freely walk and even relax

title: Gorgeous Garden Surrounded by a Flea Market-Only in China
content: The Yu Garden is a beautiful respite in the middle of Shanghai, the bizarre part is that one has to enter and exit through a good size shopping bazaar that is loaded with everything and anything you never thought you needed. As far as the garden goes, it's classic and beautiful, a lovely rock garden just past the entrance pagoda is both interesting and memorable while there are many beautiful plantings, a tranquil lake chock full of coy and an overall atmosphere of relation teeming with tourists.

title: Cheap and a decent time killer if your in the area.
content: When seeing the old part of the city (Chinatown) this is certainly a descent place to visit. Cost about 10-15 RMB to enter and you can certainly use an hour there no problem.

title: Worth a look-see
content: A must see when here in Shanghai. You can go to the shops outside of the Garden and buy plenty of souvenirs for the family and friends and then go into the Garden itself, wait! better yet go to the Garden first because there are going to be a lot of people in that area for you to try and get through. Shop later for sure. Take a camera, you'll be sorry if you don't. A lot of nice architecture in that area for pics. If you are brave try some of the street food, I did and it was great! There are plenty of places to get something to eat in the area so don't eat before you get there unless you are not into the local cuisine. I've been here for 9 months and have learned where to eat and where not to and I have never had a problem in this area so eat, shop and have a great time!

title: hidden jewel
content: We nearly missed these gardens and that would have been a shame. As seniors they only charged a reduced fee. You can spend hours there and still miss something. It is right nest door to the markets and the subway will take you there for a little cost. On a hot day all the pools and greenery are heaven.

title: Nice but busy
content: Went on a saturday afternoon, so maybe busier than normal. Although it was busy, you could still find quiet spots and it was most enjoyable. Most irritating when tour groups suddenly swamped an area.

title: Beautiful
content: Highly recommend this beautiful garden in the middle of a huge city. The people and scenery are extraordinary.....

title: A Beatiful Peaceful Place, Despite the Crowds
content: Most beautiful gardens, an oasis of tranquillity in the heart of this most vibrant of cities right next to the bustling bazaar.

title: souvenir and old temple
content: old temple building! we like it and you can found everything here! everything! tea and food was so memorable!

title: big areas
content: Yuyuan garden is a famous attraction there...you can take metro till yuyuan garden (line 10 ). I like to spend my time not in the garden..because it's very expensive..I like to see/enjoy my time to walk and see in the other stores besides yuyuan garden.. There are many large buildings there..and you can enter and find cheaper than in the garden..

title: nostalgic and beautiful
content: This was the best attraction on my visit to Shanghai. It reminded me so much of the old movies I have watched about the city and kungfu fighting. The architecture is beautiful and there is lots to see and buy. It was rather crowded when I visited, so I don't know if the traffic of people ever quiets down. Wear comfortable shoes and take a camera with as there are lots of ponds, waterways and koi fish swimming around.

title: A tiny bit of paradise on earth
content: The YU TUAN garden is one of the most beautiful gardens I have ever been to. The tranquility and peace is unbelievable. The garden was layed out by a government official for his parents to enjoy in their old age...what a delightful sentiment! It's in the middle of a vibrant city teaming with so many people that it's hard to believe that there exists this oasis of peace and quiet!

user_loc: 哥伦比亚特区华盛顿特区
title: Pretty
content: We enjoyed the gardens with all the greenery, ponds and rock formations. You have to pay to enter, but it's not that much -- I think maybe $40 USD per person, but I can't remember exactly. The gardens are sort of like a maze. The gardens are surrounded by a shopping area much like Nanjing Lu, but with less high end shops. FYI, finding the gardens through the shopping area and finding your way out can be a little bit tricky.

title: Can be a relaxing getaway if you go at the right time!
content: The Yu Yuan garden is a lovely site, but, as with most of Shanghai, very crowded. If you go when it's hot outside (spring/summer, or pretty much most of the year!), there are long lines and crowds of people. If you go in the wintertime, say, November or December, you'll enjoy it much more, as it can be romantic and even poetic and peaceful. In any case, it's a worthwhile site in the midst of all of the malls and shopping and commercialism that is modern day Shanghai. The goldfish ponds are full of huge and beautiful fish, and the buildings have interesting elements in every corner and roof (look up!). Gorgeous huge old doors and also very old trees and root systems intermingled with rocks. Be sure to peak in every nook, cave and cranny!

title: Interesting place
content: One always thinks of chinese gardens in terms of exquistness. In this case this aspect is not there but otherwise generally worth visiting. For a tourist from outside China it is worth a visit but it is an average sight. The area surrounding the Yuan Gardens are more interesting, and is of course free.

title: Great gardens
content: The gardens are quite large and are well laid out. Lots of good photo opportunities.

user_loc: 广西壮族自治区南宁市
title: glorious stately retreat in buzzing tourist quarter
content: This well maintained former administrator's home is a surprisingly relaxing and peaceful escape from the buzzing tourist traps that surround it. The variety of gardens and water features woven into the well preserved working and living quarters of a former time's privileged class are excellent examples of balance and harmony that feature so much in old China's culture. A surprisingly modest fee ensures a necessary escape from the throbbing tourist trade outside that saps your energy, especially in the extreme heat of a summer visit!

title: Yu Garden, Sights and Shop
content: Food, snacks, souvenir, clothes, tea and all. You need to spend 1 day there. Be there early at 8:30am as it can get crowded with tourists later in the day.

title: A place of tranquility in a busy city
content: Nice gardens with lakes stocked with plenty of fish and turtles, this location was built by it's owner as a place for his parents to enjoy their retirement, plenty to look at including buildings, bridges stone features and even an art gallery. Set in the central tourist market district this is a place of tranquility and it seams totally out of place now! In the old part of the city as you can see the new sky scrapers on the skyline all around but well worth a visit and the 40 rem admission price.

title: Very pretty
content: We went during the holidays so not the best time to visit, but it was the only time we could go. The crowds were unbelievable. You had to maneuver your way around and hope to not get stepped on. However, it had nice scenery and the gardens were pretty. There were lots of shops and restaurants to visit. Good pictures if you go on a day where it is not busy. Getting over the bridge was a challenge for us. They have plenty of stores for shopping, but you can get things cheaper at other places.

title: Tourist-o-rama
content: This felt a bit like Disney World to me. But I love Disney World. Tons of tourists, and really geared for your wallet. Is it the real Shanghai? I didn't feel it, but it was a great stop. Had tea in the tea house, and had our best vegetarian food.

title: Best attended outside holiday seasons
content: During national holiday week the area it was a zoo at the Yunan marketplace but the gardens did provide a bit of peace justifying the inflated holiday admission price. It was a beautiful setting which morphed from garden areas to rockscapes to waterscapes with interesting structures interspersed. Had there been less people it would have been more enjoyable and contemplative but it was still very worthwhile.

title: Nice place
content: It's a nice place. worth visiting.

title: A peaceful garden in a busy city
content: We came here because our tour guide recommended it, we wouldn't have heard of it otherwise. The gardens were absolutely stunning and gave some insight into the splendour that China once had, at least amongst the rich and royals since this is where they went to relax. There are several different halls throughout, some with explanatory signs, and some stunning rock gardens and pools. The Koi carp are huge and we spent a while watching them.

title: It's all in the name
content: This garden is absolutely magnificent. right in the bustle ofthe old Chinese section. Surrounded by shops and tea houses. Then, once inside- tranquility itself. Avoid the overpriced prints for sale and the over-enthusiastic approach of the selling staff. Otherwise just relax, stroll around and take it all in. Incredible. Watch out for the Dragon wall!

title: My favorite place in Shanghai
content: Compared with the surrounding this is a haven of tranquility and I have visited each time I have been to Shanghai. To me its like being transported out of the city the moment you walk through the entrance, can be very busy with guided tours but just wonder round and enjoy it

title: Oasis in the middle of the bustle of Shanghai
content: Great gardens with lots of interesting areas. These are beautifully laid out Chinese gardens, with the usual mix of traditional buildings ancient trees and architectural rocks with pools and bridges to explore. All this with the modern skyline of Shanghai as a stark backdrop.

title: An oasis of calm....
content: Yes, it was crowded but there are areas within the walled confines where you can savour the peace and tranquility of the beautiful gardens and water features,

title: An excellent garden
content: Yu yang Is an exceptional botanical garden in old town Shanghai. Just next-door to the nine corners bridge, The gardens are well worth the entrance fee

title: oasis in a bustling city
content: Don't be put off by the touristy bric a brac all around the outside.In side is a haven. Afterwards go beyond the tourists to the surrounding markets and Old St where the street food is amazing and you see how many people still live in Shanghai

title: Definitely worth a visit
content: If you are in Shanghai for a few days and would like to experience traditional Chinese gardens and architecture then the gardens and the surrounding area are worth a visit.

title: A Wonderful attraction! NOT to be missed!
content: This garden is HUGE...and it was a Private Garden! Which I find Amazing. It is full of ponds, rock grottos, pavilions, bridges to cross, arches to walk through, trees and gardens..and lovely 'niches' to sit down in. It is a Quiet spot just next to the Very Very Busy Yu Yuan Garden "Shops"! Well worth the fee paid!

title: Good place for a walk, shopping and sightseeing
content: Like : Great Chinese food restaurant and local stuffs shopping. It is very good scenery to visit till late evening when they put light on.

title: Lovely
content: One of our first stops in Shanghai was this beautiful garden. It was a delightful look into the past of an elegant lifestyle. Made me feel like I was really in China. Enjoy the landscapes and lovely botanicals.

title: Unexpected Surprise
content: My wife and I visited this Garden one morning while staying in Shanghai for a 3 day trip. I hadn't really heard of this place and thought it may end up being just a quick walk through. However, my wife and I found this garden to be extremely beautiful and relaxing. It is shaded which cuts back on the summer temperature and provides many different photo ops which higlight the nice architecture around the garden. Visitors should get there early to avoid the long lines and to fully appreciate the beauty of they will be seeing.

title: Very nice garden
content: The garden is a pretty and relaxing area. Worth your time to wander through to enjoy the beauty of the sight. A good contrast to the busy shops and streets just outside is gates.

title: Don't miss it!
content: It is the most beautiful garden I have ever seen. It is worth a visit !

title: Very nice garden
content: I visited a few gardens and this is one of the best. If it's your first time in China, it's a good impression; the neighborhood around it it's very interesting too.

title: My favourite Temple visit!
content: During our trip we visited countless temples in Xian, Beijing and Shanghai. Yu Yuan was my favourite.

title: Try and go on a weekday.
content: This place is amazingly beautiful. It has been there for hundreds of years and you can see the work that was put it into then and since to keep it so lovely. it is so totally opposite of what is just outside the walls. You can see the glass the metal buildings towering in the background and it is nice to know that something of old Shanghai still remains. An oasis for plants, fish, turtles and birds.

title: Delightful gardens
content: It's a bit of a maze to find the gardens within the bazaar. I couldn't even begin to describe how we found it, apart from every so often we found a random street sign sending us int he right direction. Entrance is 40yuan each and many people seem to bypass the gardens and stay in the bazaar, so it is a lot quieter as soon as you step within the garden walls. From what I read there are six main courtyards, which doesn't sound a lot but they are a good size. Plus the gardens are almost like a maze. So you can end up in the same garden more than once, but as you approach it from a different direction each time, it looks like a new garden!! We gave up trying to trace our paths and just wondered through every little path and cave we could find. It's a great way to explore!

title: Peaceful
content: Besides all the hustle and bustle, this is such a peaceful place in a beautiful setting - really worthwhile visiting.

title: Nice garden
content: It is a very nice garden with numerous rock and tree garden areas, ponds, dragon-lined walls and zigzagging bridges separating various garden areas and pavilions. The fishes in the pond were so pleasing the watching eyes. Our tourist guide said that the inner and outer gardens were both built in the Ming Dynasty .Exquisite Jade Rock & antiques were superb.

title: Go first thing in the morning
content: You should be there before it opens (8:30 I think) - that's the best way to catch it before the rest of the tourists get in. In the first half hour you can get some quiet time away from the crowds. Also, if you come to the area of the garden very early - like 6-6:30, you can catch locals enjoying their city: playing badminton, doing tai chi, walking their puppies. Later in the day the whole area becomes overrun with tourists

title: Very nice gardens
content: I´ve been to several gardens during my stay in China, but I especially liked this one. It is a peaceful place full of marvelous plants, decorations and trees. There was a bonsai exhibition during our visit - art of its cultivation just fascinates me and there were like 150 of these charming little trees.

title: Shanghai Sept 2013
content: I took an Hop on hop off tour (Big Bus which is expansive about 200 Yuan considering Shanghai Sightseeing costs 30 yuan and brings you more or less on the same places)

title: Very pretty
content: Such a peaceful and pretty garden with so many different faces.  Totally different to the surrounding area

title: Good for a nice stroll
content: Well maintained garden with a few ponds. Very peaceful place in the middle of a very busy area. Right outside there is a huge market and an awesome dumpling restaurant.

title: Yuyuan garden
content: Could be a really tranquil oasis in the middle of the city. Avoid on holidays, when it is too busy. Great area for spending a few hours, with good local food.

title: nice and relaxing site
content: It is a mixture of buildings, walls, water, large rocks and well manicured plants. If you were there by yourself, it would be so peaceful and serene, but it does attract a lot of people. The rocks are a main feature, the taller the better and the more holes in them, the better, for luck.

title: nice tourist area for seeing "Old Shanghai"
content: at first I was resistant to going to such a tourist area but actually it was worth it. The surrounding area before going into the garden is fun and full of street vendors, the gardens are beautiful and peaceful. Well worth the visit

title: beautiful. A little piece of tranditional chinese in a modern city
content: It was lovely visiting the gardens. I really wanted to see a piece of ancient china while in shanghai but its hard to come by in such a modern city. The gardens are just what I thought a chinese gardens would be like. Beautful walk ways, statues, flowers, pools with brightly coloured fish. I highly recommend a visit.

title: Cute Garden!
content: This was a nice relaxing site to visit to break up the day! More than your typical garden. Beautiful small ponds with Koi fish and nice architect surrounding. A must do while in Shanghai!

title: Well wort a visit.
content: "Yu" in Chinese means Pleasing & Satisfying,(That's what I was told) So is this beautiful garden, full of historical value & there is so much to see. Although crowded with visitors, a must see when in Shanghai. Well maintained, lovely to take photos for souvenirs. enjoyed the tour very much. Well worth a visit.

title: Contentment is an Understatement
content: Oh my! This garden is a must-do in Shanghai. No way did we ever expect such a intricately detailed garden spot to be nestled in the middle of the hustle and bustle of the old city streets. This is a delightful place to spend a few hours. We strolled and enjoyed every path. Just as you think you have covered the entire area, you turn another corner and the beauty draws you right in. This is a perfect photo shoot for couples, families, or anyone really. Sweet doorways, winding corridors, interesting walls...all delightful. Go there.

title: Like a labyrinth ;-)
content: The Garden itself has an entrance fee of 40 Yuan but it is worth it. First you enter a place with a bid stone and a house and thing ... hmmm ... this is it ? but there are two ways going deeper into the labyrinth of different places with beautiful houses, sculptures and other things.

title: Too many people
content: Lots of souvenirs, some exactly the same ones you get from Tian Zi Fang but cheaper. Dont forget to bargain!!!

title: Too touristy
content: I think this place lost its charm... It doesn't really look that chinese anymore. So many foreign shops (Esprit, cold stone etc.), too crowded on the weekend and wayyy overpriced souvenirs.

title: Very beautiful
content: We got the run around trying to find this attraction,, One sign shows YuYuan Gardens but doesnt say which way to go.. We asked the locals who sent us on a wild goose chase back and forth until we finally found it by ourselves. It was worth it in the end and we could even get a Seniors card discount on the entry fee. The surrounding shops were a delight.. so charming and what great variety..

title: Natural Beauty in Busy Shanghai
content: What a wonderful experience to find such natural garden beauty in the midst of Shanghai. Of course, the visitor is advised to select non-humid weather to enjoy this site to the fullness. The water lilies and the mini-bridges and pavilions are truly works of artistic design. And to imagine these are over 500 years old (built in 1559)

title: Standard tourist venue - nothing great
content: 40 RMB per person to enter - along with large tour-guided groups of mainly Chinese tourists many of whom lack any sense of empathy with others visiting. A succession of old Chinese rooms decorated in ancient style interspersed with Koi pools and ornamental trees. Several tourist trap venues along the way - tea sampling with an option to buy, jade display - with an option to buy, gift shop, etc. The entrance is deep into a very tacky maze of cheap trinket shops - and on exit you are funnelled through some more. Less of a national attraction - more of a tourist magnet to place spenders close to buying opportunities. Forget any notion of tranquil ponds of serenity and ancient vistas - plain and simple visitor centre created for tourists, visit if you like that kind of thing - give it a miss if you are not interested in the tourist herd. May be worth a look as Shanghai undergoes massive demolition and rebuild - not many old buildings left to see.

title: A haven in a sea of humanity!
content: Just returned from a trip to china which included a few days in shanghai. Whilst the scale of growth in the city is staggering (15 years ago the 'new' city didn't exist !) don't miss out on the chance to visit 'old' shanghai including the zig zag bridge and tea garden and especially the Yu garden. It is located right in the heart of the old city and s amazing for the immediate calm and tranquility that embraces you as you step from the hussle and bustle of the ancient streets into the garden itself. It is laid out beautifully along the fang shui principle and it really works! The landscaped gardens and koi carp stocked ponds are breathtaking and you feel a sense of peace immediately. We spent an hour or so and did not visit all the various buildings and areas.....a real gem, don't miss it!

title: Watch out for the watch sellers
content: Great place to see the mix of Chinese architecture against the backdrop of the various tall buildings in Pudong. Constantly pestered by people selling watches and other fake goods, something that I didn't really witness elsewhere in Shanghai during my visit

title: Nice place for a quick visit
content: I couldn't spend much time here, but the market area around this place was very interesting. A wide variety of items on sale, starting from pearls to collectibles to cheap food, this area is like a window to Shanghai.

title: a must see in Shanghai
content: I could not complete my visit here due to shortage of time.a good market nearby. See the temple too.

title: picture perfect
content: yes it is a small garden -compared to others in Beijing- but with very significant character and serenity. everywhere around this garden is an opportunity for a great photo, it was a highlight in our trip to shanghai.

title: yu garden of shanghai
content: it was nice seeing Chinese architecture in the middle of a modern day city. audio guide should be introduced. leaflet showed 50 places to see in garden but no locations had tallying numbers. should have arrowed paths for route around garden. the shortest route to "yu garden" is not pointed out when you exit the metro station. great place for souvenir shopping but one must bargain well.

title: So pretty....
content: This incredible garden is located in the middle of the city. The fountain, the plants, the flowers, the trees... Even the paintings... Everything is so beautiful... A must see...

title: fab oriental garden
content: really well preserved and presented this lovely up to 4o yr old shanghai garden was the highlight of my ( limited ) Shanghai tourism

title: Peaceful, except for the other tourists
content: This is tucked away in the old city of Shanghai. I really enjoyed walking around the garden and waterways. Learning about the history of this formerly private garden.

title: not what we expected
content: ok but the chinese tea experience was quite ordinary.  any tea shop could be similar.  seen better gardens in guangzhou

title: Peaceful gardens before the crowds come
content: A long established garden with a pond full of fish and many walk ways and rock formations to explore. The garden has many old trees and buildings. It is located in the middle of a busy tourist area with many shops.

title: Great in the morning before the tourist busses come
content: Yu Yuan is a charming Chinese garden, but it needs to be seen slowly, and hopefully, without the masses of tourists that are often there. If you go at 8:30 when the garden opens, the visit will be more pleasant.

title: Tourist Area, but for good reason
content: Great attraction to wander around and transport yourself back in time a couple hundred years. The extent of detail can satisfy whoever is inclined to take the time to observe its subtlety. At the same time, for those less patient, it still affords plenty of ambience ...

title: Pleasant but not inspiring
content: Provided it is not a busy time the gardens are nice to walk round and are a rest from the bustle of the city. The rocks are said to resemble animals etc but can be difficult to decipher. Ok if you are nearby but not worth a special journey.

title: Beautiful garden.
content: It was pretty cheap to get in (30 RMB), they also offer discounts to certain people like OAPs. You could spend hors walking about the maze-like garden through ponds and wooden bridges and stone paths (definitely not wheelchair accessible unfortunately). There is so much of this place, just when you think youre reaching the end, you find even more to explore. I would say it is definitely worth a couple of hours of your time, on a nice day. Even the surrounding streets are good to see, and lots of souvenirs on offer too.

title: Food Heaven
content: Excellent place if you want to get local food. Price range around RMB 10-100 but really tasty! A lot of tourist will definitely visit this hot spot to try Chinese local food.

title: Beautiful attraction
content: Great place to visit and take in the beauty of the gardens! Fabulous photo ops!A definite must see while in Shanghai!

title: Yu Yuan gardens and market
content: The market is very colourful with lots of small shops and beautiful buildings.

title: Architect Works Garden
content: If you like history & old architectural works Then It is recommended to visit otherwise utilize your time to discover the old city.

title: Small but contentment
content: Historic gardens displaying historic but joyous gardens. Easy to get around but beautiful at all times

title: Beautiful but crowded
content: If you are in Shanghai on business and want a green break from the business center, this is the place to go. Lush gardens and flowing ponds stocked with fish eager to be fed. However, because it is a popular attraction, it can be very crowded.If you have extra time, I would suggest walking through the local hutong nearby before it is gone, for a taste of the culture.

user_loc: 南卡罗来纳希尔顿头岛
title: Ed & Eileen's tour
content: The gardens could be cleaner.  It was fascinating to tour considering its age and the culture of the times.

title: Lots of rocks and very crowded !
content: It would seem impossible to gain much peace and contentment because you have to follow a crocodile of people around from one part of the garden to the next. Each section has artistically placed ancient rocks. These are highly prized and are said to resemble dragons, animals etc. I must be very unimaginative because I couldn't see any. Worth a visit but don't expect to be wowed and watch out for hawkers outside; they're very persistent.

title: just ok
content: I believe it's not what you need to see in SH, especially if you have shot of time - the old city is much better in BJ or others, so it was ok, but nothing outstanding.

title: View off-peak for best experience
content: Had a chance to visit Shanghai during a 9-hour layover in February (on a Tuesday) and given my short time there a friend recommended that my first stop be the Yu Yuan Garden so that I could get a feeling of "traditional" China without having to travel outside of the city center. Waited a few minutes in the Market until it opened at 8:30am and was very fortunate to be what appeared to be the only person in the Gardens for my entire visit! This made it even more peaceful and enjoyable - the ability to soak in the tranquility and the beauty without the crowds! I know this is unusual based on previous reviews, but if you do have an opportunity to view the Gardens at an off-peak time I believe you will find them even more enjoyable!

title: Peace and Happiness
content: The garden is well worth a visit. It has a calm tranquil atmosphere with many features to look at and wonder through. The dragon walls that separate each area provide release from the sun and, even though we were there in a very busy period, the calmness of the garden does not escape you. It is also astonishing that outside the garden is the hustle, bustle and noise of the lively old town market and beyond that the huge skyscralers that fill Shanghai's skyline. A guide makes the visit more worthwhile as you gain a deeper understanding of the purpose of each area which is fascinating.

title: Yu garden and shanghai thieves everywhere -chinese thieves everywhere and dirtyness
content: What i can say i traveled all over the world.shanghai i thought was something special but with the excemption the bund,the people were animals,the hotel yuns paradise so dirty breakfast and finally what ever we bought with electronics esp memory cards they dont work after a day.i went to vietnam what nice people and i lost all my photos bkz of the ...., chinese who sold us damaged memory cards

title: Special Place
content: One has to admire such well kept gardens and associated buildings of a past dynasty. The condition and serenity of this special place is outstanding. Unbelievable architecture and engineering, 400 years old. A true gem in the cultural history of this great nation and a credit to all who manage it. The craftsmanship is outstanding and world class.

title: Yu Yuan Gardens
content: This Garden is surrounded by beautiful buildings and shops..I loved wondering around the shops and seeing the garden..

title: very very good
content: That's really a nice place which I can feel the Chinese culture deeply.So many delicious food. I bought many gifts for my family.I hope them like it,.

title: Loved this Garden
content: The Yu Yuan Garden is a beautiful oasis in the midst of a bustling modern city. I loved the architecture, maintenance of the grounds and ponds. Also, appreciated that all tourists were respectful of the building and surrounding gardens. Our guide was very informative about the history of the building.

title: The best elements of a traditional Chinese garden, in a compact package
content: This is the second time we visited the Yu Yuan Garden. Located in the center of Shanghai, the architecture encompasses the best parts of a traditional Chinese garden in a compact place that can be easily seen in an hour. Every part of the garden is finely developed in detail. This will save you the time of going through some of the larger gardens in Suzhou which take much more time but are not so finely detailed. There is also a sort of bazaar/ small shop area outside the garden where you can purchase souvenirs, albeit at tourist prices. The only shops worth looking at are the silk comforter shop (they ship overseas at a reasonable rate if you can wait a month or so for shipping by sea), which are the best, hypoallergenic comforter filling ever, and the rice paste sweets shops and salted/dried plum and olive snack shops. These treats are only available in the Shanghai area and are mentioned in traditional literature.

title: like it (Y)
content: very nice, but gets crowded when the sun goes down ... alot of souvenir shops, some have fixed price items and some shops you can do some really good bargaining and get stuff for half price.

title: Lots of people
content: The whole area is huge comprising of the old streets with souvenir shops and eateries and the actual Yu Yuan garden and the Cheng Huang Miao temple.

title: This is a beautiful glimpse of the old China.
content: A stunning example of the beautiful gardens of the old China. It could be a peaceful respite except it, like everywhere during the summer, very crowded

title: Failed to Feel the Magic
content: The Yu Yuan Garden is located in the middle of the Old City of Shanghai, and entrance costs money. This is a very good thing in this case because it is supposed to be a quiet garden and the cost keeps away lots of people from the crowded outside. Even so, the garden can become quite crowded.

title: old chinese mansion
content: old chinese mansion, had lovely gardens and ponds, each room had explanation on its design. there are souvenir shops inside.

title: Very pleasant gardens in Central Shanghai
content: Funny being in the centre of a somewhat hectic city yet being surrounded by a very surreal, calming garden. The fish in the many pools are something I've never seen before - crazy!

title: Nice garden to wander around at your own pace
content: Nice attraction to wander around for an hour or more. Make sure you get a brochure / map so you know where you are heading. Did become a little repetitive towards the end but was a very hot day so maybe just me. There were tour groups walking around near me with an English speaking guide so if you want to know the what's and why's then suggest you organise to join one of these.

title: Well worth a visit
content: The architecture around here is very appealing with old style buildings with interesting roofs. The shops around here peddle everything from souvenirs to Chinese medicines, all at inflated prices. Do visit the Gardens and you won't be disappointed.

title: excellent place to see the old culture of shanghai
content: the old ethnicity of the place.....  gardens....the meanings....symbols of the dragons and structures....etc....

title: Amazing!
content: So old!- one has to admire and enjoy! Really enjoyed the garden.If I have to complain, then I wish there had been less people so that we could enjoy the tranquility of the garden more.

title: Oasis
content: An extensive classical garden in the old city. Hard to find the entrance without a detailed map. Interesting rocks and pools and many traditional buildings. A quiet oasis in the middle of the bustling old Chinese quarter.

title: Peaceful place in hot shanghai
content: We had a wonderful moment at the Yu Yuan garden, ending a hot and humid Shanghai afternoon old city visit. Do it early evening.

title: Brimming over with people
content: It was so crowded that I started to feel claustrophobic. I didn't bother entering Yu Yuan, I only admired the garden from the outside. It seemed so overrated and I couldn't get good pictures of the structure without someone photobombing my shots. sigh.

title: Good place to visit
content: There were many shops and we would see the old shanghai building. I first been there 15 years old but it seems not much change

title: A must visit place for foreigners
content: Be warned, a very crowded place and lot of cheaters who try to sell-off fake goods. Prefeably, go with a friend who knows local language. Otherwise, more often than not, one will regret shopping there :)

title: nice place for visiting, nice garden
content: nice place for visiting and relax. Classical Chinese gardening architecture. good restaurants in surroundings and possibility to find authentic silk for sale

title: Worth a visit if you're in the area
content: I liked this little garden, it was cute. However, it was also a bit crowded and busy, but not as crowded as the shopping area outside. I wouldn't say this is a must see, but if you're in the area shopping then you might want to check it out to get away from the people chasing you down with knock-offs.

title: A little artificial
content: It was nice and tranquil but the fake rocks (I think they were fake) didn't do it for me. Felt a bit cramped as well. (It may have also been we'd been in Yangshuo the previous day whic was perfection).

title: Calm in the midst of the crowds
content: When you enter the gates into this garden you leave the crowds, noise and shopping behind and find a beautiful Chinese garden. It is well worth the vist and is not crowded, even on those holidays when the shops around the garden are jam packed. There are ample places to enjoy the design elements and the beauty of the stone and plants. It is a traditional garden and has all the elements of one, so take time and enjoy.

title: Must see in Shanghai but watch out for girls talking Tea Ceremony
content: First off, be aware that the friendly girls asking for a picture will try to scam you into a Tea Ceremony scam. The area outside the Yuyuan Gardens and the Nanjing Road area are non stop, in your face, relentless street vendors who will pester you to buy their stuff which is extremely overpriced. You have to learn how to do the Not Interested wave, which is like the little hello/ goodbye wave. And completely ignore them and look/move elsewhere. Be aware that once you say anything, even No, you now engaged and it is much more difficult to walk away.

title: Nice respite.
content: Beautiful gardens inside the yu gardens shopping area.lovely break from the hustle of shanghai.  Liked the koi in the ponds.

title: A little piece of yesteryear
content: A gorgeous little place in the middle of the hustle and bustle, but don't expect it to be quiet, people everywhere. There are some nice little nooks and crannies where you can sit back and enjoy the view.

title: Lovely Classical Chinese Garden
content: Yuyuan Garden is one of the 5 classical Chinese gardens left in the Shanghai area. The others are in the suburbs and are excellent, but for a tourist with limited time, not so easy to access. The other 4 are in Jiading, Nanxiang, Qingpu, and Songjiang. A book called "Beyond the Concessions" may help to locate them.

title: Peaceful and serene
content: Words cannot describe it this ancient garden from the Ming Dynasty. Great to see and next to Chinatown shopping precinct.

title: shopping
content: confiscate your wife's credit card, keep you hands in pockets and remember you are restricted in how much you can carry on flights, But seriously this is brilliant and worth going to Shanghai just to visit

title: Relaxing! Beautiful!
content: I need to warn you !!!!

title: A jewel in the center of Shanghai Chinatown
content: In the midst of the commercial, touristy Chinatown of shanghai, you will find a peaceful garden, with some old period structure. The place is cool, due to trees and ponds with Koi fish. A nice relaxing one hour visit will do. I did not expect it in that area, as it seems like from a different era, and so peaceful....

title: Come here to see colourful carp and thousands of tourists - an experience not to miss
content: This is great little garden - but seriously worn at the edges thanks to the huge numbers of visitors all enjoying this sublime sights. You need to arrive as early to opening time as possible to avoid the increasing build-up of visitors. The toilets are spotlessly clean and modern. Refreshments can be purchased in the gardens. The coloured carp are spectacular and kids love to feed them. Tea tasting is available to try and to purchase - the staff are a little pushy albeit friendly. The gardens are completely surrounded by the city - with incongruous views of modern skyscrapers in the distance; and a homely apartment building overlooking the rear of the gardens - all of which add to the interesting juxtaposition of things in Shanghai. We spent a couple of hours happily wandering throughout the maze of paths and buildings - recommend this place as an essential not-to-be-missed part of a Shanghai visit.

title: quiet and beautiful gardens in the middle of the action
content: a beautiful little oasis of MIng dynasty gardens in central Shanghai! a little tricky to find coming on foot from the metro, but once we did we were in awe! it was quite crowded, but you get used to that with tourist sites in China. very much worth the entrance fee, the gardens are immaculate and extremely lush. lots of shade (shanghai was baking in a heat wave when we were there so it was much needed) and well manicured gardens. we spent a good two hours just sitting by the pond in the central part of the gardens. the famous tea house at it's centre is quite expensive - but if you aren't travelling with much of a budget, seems like a great idea. an excellent place to spend an afternoon cooling off and winding down from the busy city!

title: a beautiful old and quiet place
content: the place in itself is charming, lot of small ways throught trees and pools with tons of fishes. There is an entrance fee but it worth it and the area around the park is great for shopping and chinese food, a Chinatown like in Shanghai.

title: Lovely (and peaceful!) introduction to Shanghai.
content: We had just arrived in Shanghai from London....at the beginning of a tour of China...exhausted and/or jetlagged. The walk from the coach to the Garden was just crazy! I had never experienced anything like it in my life even though I am very used to the craziness of London! We had to walk through tiny back streets, cut across a park, and zig zag in and out of what seemed like thousands of Chinese all intent on selling us wheels to add to our trainers and other dubious accessories....some were jovial and pleasant....others were actually quite unpleasant, shouting in our faces and jostling us roughly. As a first experience of China it was a culture shock! I wish it had been possible to walk slowly and take in the scene as we were actually walking through what appeared to be the real Shanghai....people buying goods from tiny back street shops and hanging their laundry (yes including their bras and pants!) along the park railings to dry in the sun!). Anyway we were pleased to be inside the beautiful Yu Yuan Gardens....really peaceful and beautiful (in April)....and really enjoyed wandering along the little paths and around the ponds and bridges. Our tour guide did an excellent job of filling us in with all the historical facts. We found it very atmospheric...and quite bizarre in that such a tranquil ancient place looked as if it had been dropped into one of the noisiest, crowded spots on earth (obviously it was there first but it was slightly incongruous!). We came out of the back door....and were thrust into the frenzy again! Hoards of (mainly Chinese) tourists fighting for space around the famous tea house, the zig zag bridge, and the souvenir/food shops. At that time we appeared to be the only European tourists there, and we were a source of great amusement and curiosity to the Chinese tourists (not the city people) who variously stared or asked to take photos of us! I absolutely loved our stay in Shanghai (as my dad had done many years before!) it was as crazy, frenetic and noisy as I'd imagined.......and the Yu Yuan Gardens are a lovely oasis of calm in the midst of it all!

title: This place you can relax away from the large crowds and also see the government building close by
content: This place you can relax away from the large crowds and also see the government building close by. Really lovely Historic buildings.

title: A calm and peaceful place
content: Don't confuse Yu Yuan shopping area with the gardens, most people take a while to find the gardens or even realise they exist. Yu Yuan itself is a chaotic place but the gardens are lovely and peaceful in stark contrast to this. Everyone I have sent to the gardens has said they love it. Its a good place to visit to see a bit of culture but it is also good for the soul as well as is serene and relaxing. obviously if you go on the weekend it might not be so relaxing as there will be a lot of people there. If you can , go on a week day not a public holiday. I visited during a cold month and it was lovely then so I am sure you can go anytime of the year and enjoy the experience.

title: Well worth a look while in the rather touristy market
content: At very busy times the Yu Yuan market can get terrifyingly crowded, especially during peak Chinese holidays. Although the garden is well worth a visit in its own right, it really is a great bolt hold when the pressure is on outside in the market.

title: Beautifull place
content: Yu Yuan garden is a real great place to visit. Easy to reach by metro, as everything in shanghai. The buildings are beautifull to see, the hole atmosphere is great. But please take care of the chinese holidays at that time it is so crowded that it is no fun at all!! So if you have a change to go make sure you are there in early morning time.

title: A must-go place if you wanna see the traditional side of Shanghai
content: Yu Garden is a traditional ancient garden owned by someone rich hundreds years ago. Now with the modernization of the city, traditional architecture is less easy to find. Yu Garden is one of the typical traditional architecture that still remained. But if you go there on weekends, it might be very crowded.

title: Complexity and Contemplation
content: It is difficult to acheive a full understanding of this immensely rich garden as one attempts to visit this most precious site along with say many other thousand visitors on any given day. However, this garden was an introduction to many other like sites that require concentration. Therefore, the complexity of this place peaks my curiosity and I am now more eager to read and learn about this garden once I am back in my elements. What I gathered rather haphazardly is that the pathways are carefully revealing different vistas whilst hiding others. The threshholds or portal between the various sectors of the garden create a sense of being transported to another place, because the shape and cut out quality denotes a curious entry way. The interplay of vegetation, pavilions, bridges and water, steam, haze create a dream like vision with the late setting sun. I am excited to learn more of its history, its aura, and it's context.

title: Beautiful
content: Following old Chinese urban architecture. This area is especially beautiful when decorated for the annual lantern festival, one week after spring festival.

title: Peaceful Garden
content: It is not that large of a garden but the surrounding area and shops are extensive old and traditional. It is an older style Chinese garden and represented rather well. Peaceful, quiet, and worth a visit walk through.

title: Overcrowded
content: Lovely Historic buildings but there were just so many people and it was a hot hot day which made it more uncomfortable.

title: One of the only interesteting tourist attraction in Shanghai
content: Yu Yuan Garden is surely a place to visit in Shanghai.

title: Love this garden!
content: How to reach this garden if you go by yourself without tour assistance will be a challenge! But it will pay off when you already inside the garden. When you're inside the garden you will feel like you're one of actor/actrees in chinese kung fu movie set. The garden has so many doors with different shapes. Each shapes just invited you to take the picture of it. The bamboo and other plants grow beautifully. Luckily inside the garden still maintained clean. Outside the garden you will find a lot of stalls and the crowded just drive you crazy.

title: Relaxing
content: Beautiful garden. As I was walking along, I was surprised how can a relaxing place like this situated in one of the most busiest city in the world. Recommended to visit early in the morning...because there is no crowds such as group tour. If you want to really enjoy the real quiet relaxing place...then this is the one! Don't miss.

title: Chinese garden in the heart of the city
content: A beautiful garden in the heart of the Megapolis to calm down your nerves and get a glimpse of nature - trees, ponds with fish, bridges, Chinese houses and flowers.

title: Amazing history
content: The gardens are beautiful, with so much history evident in the rocks and stone work. But there are a lot of vendors outside waiting to sell their items.

title: Amazing building!
content: Amazing historical place in the center of a modern city! the building clearly shows the architectural skill of old chinese people and its must see place in Shanghai.

title: Tourist Attraction
content: it is worth a visit as this place is very popular with the locals, you'll see busloads of tourists (locals)

title: Very pleasant, but busy
content: A very traditional area to visit with the "Nine Turnings Bridge" and the water, Good variety of shops in the area and a good selection of gifts to take home, but do haggle as the price will come down.

title: Well maintain and beautiful.
content: Beautiful and very Chinese building, many small shops and food stalls around. There is a well known restaurant '南翔小笼', should not be missed.

title: Beautiful and Serene
content: It was amazing that such a beautiful and serene place can exist in a busy and modern city such as Shanghai

title: Garden of Contentment
content: Magic place when you feel the presence of real old China. Beatiful plants and trees. It's a must when visiting Shanghai.

title: "The Garden" of Shanghai
content: You can't say you've been to Shanghai if you won't visit Yu Yuan Garden.

title: Great but get there early to avoid the crowds!
content: The Yu Yuan Garden is a very pretty and historic sight in Shanghai but is somewhat contaminated after about 1000 on weekends when it becomes packed with package tours and other tourists! My advice is get there early when you can enjoy the restored garden´s serenity and architecture.

title: Nice Garden - Beware of Scams outside
content: Yu Garden is a beautiful peaceful Chinese garden and defintiely worth a look. The area outside however is a busy tourist shopping area, with lots of people trying to sell you souvenirs. We heard from another couple that there is a regular scam here, where 'students' engage you in conversation in English then invite you for some traditional tea. When you get the bill, hey-ho! You've just bought the most expensive tea in China and need to pay the shop 500USD. Judging by the amount of times 'students' asked us to take a picture for them and somehow got around to the tea conversation, i reckon there are many, many people who are doing this scam. Beware!!!!

title: You got to have a great tour guide...
content: The garden is wonderful, cool (to avoid some of the summer humidity), and a quick green get away hidden in the city but you must have a tour guide to get all the good history and backstory to the the place. Darren Gao was our guide and made it far more interesting than just walking through the zig-zag pathways and bridges.

title: Tranquil
content: Beautiful garden on a hot hot day in July. We strolled through with our guide pointing out the details of buildings and beauty of the water, trees and dowery rocks. Every little detail means something in China so pay attention to the details. Our guide was smart, we went at lunch when most people were eating so no crowds and we went in the out and out the in which seemed to work for our group, she mentioned this is a trick she uses to make her tour better?? Not sure how that works BUT not crowed and never had another tour group talking as we toured. Lovely.

title: My Least Favorite Attraction in Shanghai
content: This area has been talked up by locals and foreigners alike as being the place in Shanghai. I disagree. The area is nothing more than a flee market of fake Chinese goods. My recommendation, if you like markets and really want to say that you had made it to Yu Yuan Garden, take the Subway Line ten to Yu Yuan, stay for about 10 minutes, then get right back on the subway and head over to Tian Zi Fang instead.

title: Green & Peace
content: Stepping into the garden, you will find yourself amazed with the greeneries and amazing sculpture. It is purely a Garden of Contentment and you can easily lost yourself in there. You leave behind the steel jungle of Shanghai, rejuvenate yourself and soak up the calm and peace in the garden. There are many ornate carvings of window frame, very detailed. A place not to be missed.

title: Every twist of the path presents a new surprise
content: If you wish to experience landscaping ingenuity, make sure you visit Yu Garden!

title: Very nice scenery
content: The gardens are well kept and clean. It is really a relaxing outing to wander through. It can be crowded during weekends.

title: Relax in the Garden and save time for shopping
content: The Garden is a walk back in time. It is serene and beautiful. Here, it is easy to envision tea ceremonies and the chatter of concubines. It's also a respite from the business of new Shanghai. Then as you emerge to the busy area of the shops you will notice both places for souvenirs as well as shops that fuse east and west for those special "gifts for you".

title: Peaceful
content: In spite of the oppressing heat, this garden was quite enjoyable. The water, rocks, trees, and plants are well arranged and the fung shei of the garden is interesting to learn about. The buildings in the garden are fascinating. I really like the double corridor with one side for men and the other for women with open spots to greet one another along the way. Beautiful koi fish everywhere. Don't miss the dragon!

title: Interesting area to visit
content: The gardens are part of a larger area which also has a bit of shopping, dining and a temple in close proximity.

title: Peaceful and beautiful garden.
content: Get there early to avoid the crowds. From about 11 the place is crawling!

title: Tranquil Gardens
content: We visited the gardens as part of a tour booked by our travel agent. Upon entering you meander through shops and hawkers and then through different parts of the garden. Not like an English garden but beautiful just the same, a lifetimes work has gone into the garden and the sense of peace and tranquillity amongst the hustle and bustle beyond the walls is quite amazing.

title: Peaceful and beautiful
content: To get to these gardens you must walk through a not so quiet market area. There are a few beggers on the way too and 'looky looky' men trying to sell the latest plastic gadget...rollers for shoes???

title: Very beautiful
content: A MUST IN SHANGHAI! Always very busy but it's one of the best places to see "the ancient China" in the city, totally worh it to pay to get into the garden!

title: Beautiful Gardens
content: A very peaceful garden set in the middle of a very busy shopping area. It was built in the 1500s by a wealthy man for his parents so they could live out their years in style, but they died before it was completed. It has been restored and is a lovely place to walk around.

title: Real sense of how powerful officials could live
content: The extravagance of this garden and how it shows that one family can get so much power and wealth was a very interesting point. You get the feeling you are touring a government sponsored site and when you realize that one family's ambition built it all, it is very hard to grasp.

title: Sense of Peace and dream place! Gardens to spend hours
content: What a place in the world! Wish We can go back!! And learn more about this unique green place In. A busy touristic area

title: Not worth the crowd and tea scammers
