content: Too many people and tea scammers etc. trying to sell you something. It's so crowded it's no fun or joy.

title: eh
content: i guess it's pretty, but it doesn't feel old or ancient or historical to me. the area around it is horrifying, like an EPCOT center version of china with all american fast-food chains & people trying to scam you. to me shanghai is futuristic, modern, skyscrapers surrounding plazas, cosmopolitan. the whole area considered "old shanghai" can be skipped, it's not what it's sold as.

title: If you want a short break from the city hustle ...
content: If you want a short break from the city hustle you can take 1-2 hours in these beautiful garden. The place is designed as a traditional Chinese garden, including water ponds, bonsai trees, gold (koi) fish, stones etc

title: Beautiful
content: Beautiful tranquility in the middle of Shanghai well worth a visit and try to choose a time when it is not filled with visitors

title: A piece of tranquility in the midst if shanghai madness!
content: A beautiful garden area, with stunning scenery set in the middle of tourist chaos. The surrounding streets are full of tourists and vendors, but the gardens themselves are well worth a visit

title: The china you imagine
content: Very pretty gardens and old Chinese style buildings in the middle of bustling shanghai. It's in a very touristy area, full of souvenir shops, but the gardens and building are lovely.., china of long ago.

title: Nice Old Chinese Buildings, but sometimes overcrowded
content: I visited Yuyuan for a few times while I lived in Shanghai. It was nice to see the buildings, the shops, the snacks, one of the place that you can feel that you are in China. But, I went there once the day after Chinese New Year, it was a bad idea, because there were thousands of people, we couldn't even walk, we had to push to pass. On one corner before we left, there were so many pushing that my feet actually didn't even touch the ground, just got pressed from all sides, it was not good. But other times, it was better.

title: Beautiful Garden
content: Yu Garden is beautiful. On weekends it does become overcrowded and recommend that one visits it during the week. The ponds are full of fish and to my delight there were turtles too. The art and jade "museums" are stores.

title: It's all in the name...contentment
content: The Yu Yuan Garden is a must see in Shanghai. These Ming Dynasty era gardens are very formal with trees and koi ponds, buildings and rock formations, all meant for contemplation. Part of the Temple of the Town God, the garden is meant to help you in your contemplation. Yu Yuan is one of the places in Shanghai to become acquainted with old China. During the Taiping Rebellion, the Small Swords Society made Dianchun Hall its headquarters.

title: A haven of tranquility.
content: An amazing place, right in the heart of the "tourist market". As with most places in China, there seems to be a great deal in a small area. It's probably best to get there early, if possible. Due to the nature of the place, it can become very crowded very quickly, especially when coach parties arrive. Once you're in there, you can easily forget where you are. There's hardly any noise from the crowds and traffic on the other side of the wall.

title: Beautiful Gardens
content: Very pretty with Koi ponds and old pagodas. Built in the 1500's. The bazaar has lots of shopping and street food.

title: I wish this was relaxing
content: The gardens are beautiful. They just admit too many people and it really distracts from the place. Would like a quite moment here but I don't think that is possible.

title: Excellent place to visit
content: Fantastic area to visit. Looks small from the outside, but huge when you get inside. Loads of different areas there to see. Only downside is that there is nowhere really inside to stop for a coffee and snack.

title: A refreshing place
content: Suddenly, as you enter this park, you are transported into an old charm world. Beautifully maintained, offers great photo ops.

title: peacefull
content: Although planned to visit, came upon the entrance quite by chance after browsing the many shops on route. Really enjoyed spending time here, twists and turns, small bridges, places to sit and watch, interesting architicture. Worth the visit. PS if you are over 60 and have a copy of your passport, half price!!

title: Nice place to visit!!
content: We enjoyed strolling through the gardens and there were some great photo opportunities although it can get very crowded which is typical of China. We took the metro to the gardens and westerners need to be aware of being approached by locals asking them to 'take their photo' , they strike up a conversation and then ask to go with you to your destination. They are only interested in trying to sell you something.

title: Place of contrasts
content: The Yu garden is a wonderful place of calmness and relaxation in this never-sleeping town. From the garden you see the towers of Pudong which even increases the contrast.

title: ENJOYABLE
content: Nothing much to say other than it was a very enjoyable visit. Well worth your visit. It is a real glimpse how the very wealthy in China used to live.

title: A great place to visit in Shanghai
content: We did not go to Suzhou, so this was the best garden we saw in China. Nestled in the heart of the Yu Yuan shopping area, it is a beautiful place, with different views at every turn. My understanding is that it gets more crowded as the day goes on, so early is best. I loved the dragon walls and the Chinese Opera stage. Worth a visit.

title: Atmosphere..
content: If you are tired of the hassle of the big city in Shanghai proper, walking through the Yu Yuan Gardens will help you find your tranquil place. The design of the paths, the plants and the waters falls etc. make it impossible to do anything but relax.

title: Very pretty, crowded
content: This is a very pretty spot, located in the middle of many shops, restaurants.....even a Starbucks by the entrance. Plan to see the gardens and then browse a bit when you're done. The gardens are lovely, the buildings fascinating, but go early or at off times to avoid the throngs of tourists.

title: beautiful
content: Was a lovely garden with lots of shops surrounding it. We went with a viator tour group and is our guide hadn't been more worried about conning us into a tea ceremony we would of enjoyed it more

title: Yu Yuan Garden and Area In A Wheelchair
content: I am going to start this review of my recent visit to Yu Yuan with a caveat. And I think it important. If you are a wheelchair user, cannot stand and cannot speak Chinese or you are not with anyone who can speak Chinese, do NOT come to China just yet.

title: A stunning oasis in the middle of the city
content: Yu Yuan Garden is a masterpiece of stunning architecture and art right in the heart of Shanghai. If you could only do one thing or see one thing - this for me would be it. This is a "don't miss" if you love Chinese architecture and Chinese art.

title: Pretty gardens but overcrowded
content: The gardens themselves are lovely but very overcrowded- I much preferred our day trip to Tongli and the gardens in this beautiful canal town.

title: gorgeous and peaceful
content: I would definitely recommend this garden. I went with a guide, which was nice because I got to understand about the history and the buildings. It was so peaceful--even through there were a fair amount of tourists, they were spread out so it never felt crowded. I couldn't believe a sanctuary like this existed in the middle of busy Shanghai.

title: Tranquil spot in the heart of bustling market
content: I love tranquil gardens and this one is outstanding. Filled with ponds and mini lakes, beautiful rocks and plants it is a work of art

title: Beautiful calm quiet garden inthe middle of the bustling city
content: There is a zig zag bridge leading you over the lake to the garden which is beautifully preserved and contains myriad rocks water features and shady nooks. Very peaceful

title: a hidden gem
content: this garden (and the surrounding area) is really worth a visit, but try and get a local guide to explain all the history to the garden to get the most from your time here. definitely include as part of your itinerary.

title: Unbelievable for both main stores and street market
content: Liked the sheer atmosphere and buzz of the place, the variety and volume of goods for sale and the bargaining with sellers even in stores to get best price. There was even a temple in the centre area alongside a Marks and Spencer and a Tesco Express !

title: AustFarmer75
content: Plenty of people but it al flowed seemlessly. Could appreciate the feeling of peace that these gardens do convey and from a country with a short history it was great to see something from way back

title: Beautiful
content: A lovely oasis in the middle of a crazy city, would be great to be there alone but it wasn't too bad. The market area next to it is terrific.

title: Must see
content: this sight is absolutely stunning, trees 300 and 500 years old. To get the most out of this garden, try to get a tour guide. Superbly built a real testament to the Chinese people that this place still exist. I have been there twice, the last time with a young Chinese lady from Beijing and it blew her away. Allow yourself about two to three hours. A seldom noticed part of this beautiful place is the paving. Hand laid pebble paths so intricate and varied, the windows designed to appear as a series of paintings, built to resemble many different rooms, a truly remarkable visual treat. TOLD YOU SO

title: Go early - can get crowded
content: If you can get there before it gets to busy then you will really be able to experience the ambience and aura of the place. The nooks and crannies and the amazing rocks. Watch the huge 'trash fish' (carp) scavenging for tourist food - they nearly come out of the water to grab what's on offer. This is an amazing garden only spoiled by the huge numbers visiting.

title: An oasis of tranquility
content: Beautiful pools and lovely architecture, this place leaves you very relaxed after the hustle and bustle of the city. when leaving you enter a shopping centre great for all your souvenirs. Bargain hard its part of the experience, but be aware of people that are over friendly!! we were warned by a lady who was a volunteer, that these 3 very friendly young people that had been talking to us were in fact con men. remember be careful.

title: Very beautiful but crowded
content: These are magnificent gardens with many interesting buildings . However at weekends the crowds are massive and enjoyment very difficult. Weekdays first thing in the morning is best. All the toilets we have used were Chinese sqat type-but very clean . Many restaurants in the area.

title: Yuyuan garden is a wonderful experience despite all imitation
content: Yuyuan garden, a major tourist attraction, it is very busy, not only with the Chinese. It is a walled park with a few small buildings (including a tea house) and some nice ponds with bridges. It all looks very Chinese, not everything seems initially. Restoration is a profession, there is unfortunately a lot messed, including making dragons of concrete. The famous teahouse seems to be rebuilt Despite the crowds the park is very photogenic. Many new commercial buildings were put to service tourists. In a tourist restaurant we ate dumpling. A Chinese lady from Hong Kong took us in tow and "forced" us to eat a specialty from the region: dumpling filled with bouillon, very tasty. Despite all imitation Yuyuan garden is a wonderful experience. Outside the park there are taxis that do not use the meter, they have doubled their rate.

title: Shopper paradise
content: The market there was so civilised. All separate shops with some amazing gifts and silk wear. Always very busy mainly with Chinese tourist. Definitely worth a trip

title: Beautiful little oasis in big Shanghai
content: Thanks to a great tour guide, we saw this amazing historical set of old Chinese buildings thoroughly but efficiently. The day was grey and drizzly, but we still saw some amazing stone carvings as well as the natural stone monuments the ancient Chinese valued so highly. A definite must if you want a taste of China before it became so industrialized and overcrowded.

title: Fantastic few hours of beauty and greenery
content: Yes, it can be crowded, but worth it - and much more than a garden, it's really the complete estate dating back hundreds of years. There are multiple buildings to see and acres of gardens, ponds and art. It was our first stop with our private guide and we're happy we had a guide, since we saw a great deal more than we would have noticed on our own.....the different types of architecture of the different dynasties, all the Chinese sayings that are incorporated into buildings and gates, all the architectural details that tell so much about old China and old ways of life. You'll get more out of it with a guide, but even if not, it's a beautiful introduction to Chinese traditions.

title: Very nice and quite place in the city center
content: This garden is situated about 15 min walk from the bund. It is one of the most beautiful garden I have seen. It is better to go there with a guide p in order not to miss all the sights. There are a lot of tourists there but the roots are made so, that it doesn't bother. You should definitely spend several hours there.

title: Nice Classical Chinese Garden
content: We have a small Chinese Classical Garden in Vancouver (The Sun Yat-Sen Garden) so we were interested to see a large one. There is certainly a lot of it. There were also a lot of people. Definitely worth a visit, but be prepared for the crowds--you won't be doing much quiet contemplating here.

title: Gardens atmospheric in the rain
content: We had a great tour of the gardens and loved the Rockery with its Great Rockery, 14 meters high. The gardens are 400 years old. The Jade Rock is 3.3 metres high and has 72 holes. It is one of three famous rocks in the southern region of the Yangtze.

title: Lovely
content: Lovely Chinese garden, once belonging to a private household and enjoyed for its quiet serenity and seclusion. Wonderful old trees and rock formations and wonderful architecture. Loved the library/classroom as a highlight.

title: Peace and tranquility
content: Well worth the visit. Close to Metro station and surrounded by shops and Chinese markets. Affordable entrance fee to experience this peace and tranquillity dating back to the Ming Dynasty. Several restaurants and other attractions in the area.

title: Just Beautiful
content: This was the only Chinese garden I visited on my trip. It is adjacent to the Bazaar and it's many shoppers and vendors. The peace and beauty of the garden are in sharp contrast to the activities just beyond its entrance. It is what you would expect of a Chinese garden but that doesn't make it any less spectacular. Well-kept with stunning features and surprisingly uncrowded given its location. It is worth the time you will miss at the bazaar.

title: Great trip to the past
content: It is very quiet although in the very city center. Very relaxing place, lots of flowers, trees, hidden gardens.

title: Well worth a visit
content: Very different to other gardens I've visited in China - but equally impressive with the craftsmanship and quality. It's relatively speaking very small but laid out in such a way as it feels much bigger with plenty of eye-candy in every direction. Truly impressive.

title: Beautiful garden, well maintained, photogenic
content: A classic garden with abundant flowers, buildings, rock formations, pools. Take your time and wander around and imagine what it must of have been like in the past.

user_loc: 阿根廷布宜诺斯艾利斯
title: Beautiful Chinese garden
content: Beautiful place to visit.

title: Very nice
content: The garden and around it are a real pleasure. In the pond the grey fish is 51 year old. The atmosphere is romantic. The area around the garden, with its market, shops and restaurant is unique. Worth a visit. Go to the near restaurant lu Bo Lang

title: More than just a garden
content: Very pretty but most important shows you some aspects of the history in which it was built and how the elite lived thier lives. Enjoyed walking around it, having a rest under the trees and looking at the beautiful Japanese fish in the ponds. Absolutely beautiful and serene..

title: Been over here a few times
content: Well this area has lots of shopping and restaurants. You can get lost for hours shopping (and negotiating) and eating around here. Its very pretty.

title: Chinese Culture
content: In The Modern China , if you want to get the real feel of china , must visit Yu Yuan Gardens

title: One of the most beautiful gardens in the world
content: Yu Garden is a very beautiful Chinese private garden. It was first built in the Ming Dynasty which is almost 500 years ago. There are many courtyards inside. It lookes like the garden is very big because of the continueing courtyards.

title: A grat garden in downtown
content: Magnificent garden and beautiful traditional buildings in the most attractive part of the old city. Spare sometime to stroll in and around the gardens. Also, you can eat at any of the restaurants that cook fresh seafood just outside the gardens.

title: Contentment it was...
content: Again, very festive and busy. Lovely atmosphere and everyone friendly and helpful. Although it was busy this did not detract from the spiritual and thoughtful layout of the garden.

title: Peaceful Retreat Near Busy Bazaar
content: Yu Yuan Garden is a great escape from the frenetic shopping activity just beyond its walls. The garden is very beautiful and nicely laid out. When designed and constructed, it was privately owned and took 18 years to complete, but is now open to the public. Despite a number of other people touring the garden, it still provides a most pleasant and peaceful setting. The garden is located in the Yu Yuan district which is referred to as Old City or Chinatown of Shanghai. There are a large number of handicraft shops and restaurants comprising this sprawling area. Go prepared for waves of people milling around.

user_loc: 德克萨斯州圣安东尼奥市
title: Beautiful in spring
content: Great to see flowers with old architecture. It can be very crowded, but it's a gem in this busy district near tea gardens.

title: Lovely place.
content: Lovely place to walk and to check out ancient Chinese architecture and furniture. Worth of the entrance payment of 40 yuan.

title: breathtaking wiew of flowers and odors
content: Not only seeing but also smelling ,I felt dizzy :)))That was wonderful for me to see nature,architecture,smelling ,watching people... Very surprisingly after greeting a young Aussie boy while buying cofeee,Ilearned that his grand mom is a Turkish woman,what a small world !

title: Worth the search
content: We set out to look for this but got thoroughly lost the first time, though did manage to find the old 'China Town' that surrounds the Garden. Next day we'd almost given up when suddenly came upon the entrance to Yu Yuan Garden, and were so happy to have found it. Beautiful surroundings, a lovely spot to wander around - with no traffic and therefore no nervous glances around for the next thing that's trying to run you over!

title: pretty place
content: the Yu Yuan Garden is a must see when visiting area. The are around it is called "old Shanghai" and is mainly just old buildings converted into tourist stores and restaurants. Many American chains are found in this area.

title: A real gem in a busy shopping area
content: Thanks to our guide, we found this garden to be very interesting. She was able to give us some of the history which made it even more interesting. It is such a maze that one would need a guide in order not to just go in circles. This garden is definitely worth a visit if you have an extra hour or so in Shanghai

title: Beautiful Serene yet Crowded
content: This serene garden was very crowded in mid-morning on a week day yet we could find quite corners. It isn't very big yet the layout is such a puzzle of buildings, ponds and plants that you feel it is larger. We walked away with a lot of pictures. We did not take a tour so I don't know if we missed much history beyond what we read in the travel guides.

title: Worth the visit-but watch out for tea ceremony scammers
content: Lovely tranquil gardens designed to make you walk in circles though! We were almost scammed by a young couple posing as students who asked us to take their photo. They started chatting to us and when we said we were going to visit YuYuan gardens that said that they had just come from there and it was really really busy. They had heard that there was a good tea room close by with a ceremony going on so we agreed to walk with them-I know we should have known better -but they were very good. We cottoned on just as we reached the tea room as a girl opened the door as if expecting us. The penny dropped and we made a swift departure. We returned the next day to go back to the gardens and spotted the same couple talking to another westerner at the top of the exit freom the subway-presumably spinning the same yarn.

title: Very interesting
content: The gardens were a little hard for us to find. The gate is in the shopping. The garden it like a maze with many different sections, each one different than the next. It's a great place to take photos.

title: Small garden but with so much to explore around it...
content: Closes early..but it's a small garden - so you can pretty much see all of it in 15-30 minutes. There's so much to do around this area though ... Make sure to bargain when shopping for souvenirs.. Don't hesitate to bargain at least half their price..it'll be wise to buy more on the second day..when you've already adjusted to the culture and bargaining style:) some of the sellers are sweet enough to actually give things to you at a lower rate if they see you're polite enough...

title: One Time Visit tourist place
content: I and my wife visited the garden on April 30th 2013. Firstly its very tricky to find the place and many locals didn't know the actual garden and they kept pointing us to the shops on the street around. We finally found the tourist information center and they guided us to reach the place. The garden itself has lot of cultural value, but as a place we found it just OK. Its not big and can be seen in about an hour at the max. The pavilion hall entrance was way to crowded. So as a tourist, its good for a one time visit to wipe it off your check list in places to see in Shanghai.

title: A nice place for tourists
content: I think this place suit tourists in the sense that you can feel and see the old city, thought there're couple of things new. I found this place is amusing and found so many interesting shops inside.

title: Pleasant place to stroll
content: It's quite crowded but still a nice place to walk around or sit for a couple of hours. You can find quiet corners to relax in and just enjoy the scenery and old buildings. At 40 yuan fr adult it's not too bad

title: beautiful, great place to seat and relax
content: I used the metro to get there. I remember walking across a park...and then facing a big intersection and walking toward the flow of people....once there, there are some signs about the Yu garden...the bazar/street vendors are everywhere, with the rest of China. Very busy area!

title: Beautiful garden
content: Looking for a bright spot on a rainy day in Shanghai? The gardens are wonderful. You won't see floral gardens but gardens featuring rocks, bridges, buildings, trees, shrubs and colorful umbrellas. Yes, it's crowded even on a rainy day. Loved it!

title: Definitely a must see
content: A wonderful place for meditation, even if it's crowded. The place is a best one for having a romantic stroll with your significant other - in spring, summer and autumn there's lotsa flowers and trees in bloom, juicy colors on a greyish rocky background. A perfect place for having a photo session as well

title: I really did enjoy this
content: Away from the City; this is what i expected to see when I came to China. Traditional shopping areas, food, lots of people, great tourist attraction. I want back to this place 3 times; great place for shopping.

title: Just another garden
content: I went to visit Yu Yuan Garden on April 17, 2013. It is located in the Old Shanghai Town area. It is a little tacky to get to the Garden, since the garden is kind of well-hidden among the shops and restaurants that made up the Old Shanghai Town. The entrance ticket is RMB 40 (USD 7). The garden is quite small. There are few areas that are restricted to the visitors. Great to take pictures and getting an idea of how the garden used to look like back in the 1960s. The garden is a bit dirty (since there are a lot of people eating inside the garden). It doesn't look like it is well taken-care of. It took me about 15 minutes to finish taking a look and taking pictures. For me the attraction is the outside area. There are lots of foods and shops.

title: great tourist site
content: good to visit but it can get really crowded especially on holidays and weekends. A lot of touristy items and shops in the vicinity that somehow looses its character. The garden itself is worth a visit as they have art shows inside, you pay a minimal amount to get in.

title: beautiful gardens-although little interpretation
content: The area of shops outside the real gardens copies the style of old buildings, but they are fake! Most shops selling the same thing! many street sellers bothering you all the time to buy rubbish!

title: Lovely garden! A must see!
content: This is such a lovely garden which is apparently 500 years old. Very clean and well maintained. We loved the traditional roofs and the little ponds scattered throughout the garden. Great place to take pictures!

title: Excellent place to eat and buy souvenir items coz many restos and shops nearby!
content: It was our second time in Shanghai and this time we went to Yu Yuan at least 4 times coz it is conveniently located near the hotel we stayed in. Better go there earlier in the day around 8am or later around 6pm to avoid the huge crowd coz the place is always full of tourists. Around its vicinity are at least 2 Starbucks, 2 Dairy Queen, 2 McDo and many more. Good place to eat coz many restos around including Din Tai Fong and convenient place to buy souvenir items coz many shops around too!

title: Don't miss this!
content: The garden is surrounded by a market which is very pretty with colourful replica buildings and this garden in the middle is an absolute gem.

title: Time for reflection
content: ThenYu Yuan garden was built in the Ming dynasty by a Pan family scion to honour his parents. It took 20 years to complete but from the results, it was well worth the time and money spent. The garden is in traditional Chinese style and from what our guide said, was the best in the Shanghai area. It is in the midst of the City God temple area - the entrance to the garden does not reflect what is I side the walls. We visited in spring when the plants were in full bloom but I would bet that the garden would still look as gorgeous in any season. Go during a weekday and enjoy the tranquility but becareful of personal belongings.

title: Fabulous!!
content: If you like gardens, don't miss Yu. As far as I'm concerned it is a cool as the Bund at night and way better than the Pearl tower. But if gardens bore you, this will be no exception.

title: Very nice and delicate garden but too crowded!!!!!!
content: The garden is interspersed with a collection of gardens, Koi fish pounds and exquisite Southern Chinese architecture. The design really shows an expert way of creating visual space and perspective despite being at most 1/20th of London's Hyde Park. Best visit during non-peak period for picturesque photo taking opportunities.

title: Very nice complex of Chinese gardens
content: The garden is very nice place in the heart of Shanghai and you can see so many interesting buildings, secluded places and trees. This place is usually crowded but really worth it. The best time to visit is the morning before the travel coaches coming.

title: A jewel within old town of Shanghai
content: The charm is forever there and intact despite of the ever increasing hustles and bustles outside. Good job the local government protecting this ancient, southern Chinese style garden dating back to 16th century. It is of typical southern Chinese style garden with ponds with gold fish, zigzaging cobbled paths and covered walkways and bridges through bushes, flowers and trees. Just fascinating. It is within easy reach of public transit such as subway and bus. it is walkable from the Bund, the waterfront of Huang Pu River filled with skyscrapers.Child's memory was vividly brought back for sure...

title: Photographic Gem in the Heart of Ticky Tacky Tourist Area
content: Make your way through the aisles of tacky vendors to the garden. Typical Chinese garden with lots of opportunity for photos and exploration. We visited on a Monday and found the crowds ample -- can't imagine what a weekend visit would be like.

title: Fascinating maze of garden pathways
content: The gardens were a fascinating maze of pathways. Definetly a must see while in Shanghai. We paid the senior rate and saved on admittance price.. The shopping area outside the gardens is congested but offers a large variety of goods.

title: Nice oasis in the centre of bustling shops
content: This garden is a typical Chinese garden with ponds and pavillions, Have to pay a small entrance fee. It is a good introduction to a Chinese garden but nothing too grand or spectacular. Its location is quite interesting, we could not find it at first. It is located in the centre of bustling shops and eateries. Ok to spend an hour or two here.

title: Too Crowded
content: This is a well known tourist attraction. It is a really beautiful example of the old Shanghai and of great historical significance. However-it is now far too crowded and full of cheap trinket shops.The real value and enjoyment is in the tea houses -enjoying endless cups of tea with little snacks talking with friends.

title: Beautiful? Maybe. Tranquil? Like a chicken coop
content: Granted, if this was your neighbor's garden in their backyard, this would be pretty impressive. If your neighbor charged you 40 yuan to hang out there, you'd be peeved. If he invited all of Shanghai to do the same, you'd be downright vexed.

title: Just wander around,quite beautiful
content: Best to go with a tour guide-the story of this person's garden & house built hundreds of years ago is fascinating. So many small details. Everything is starting to bloom, azealas-peonies-wisteria. Magical, in the middle of chaos at the bazaar. So many dragons to see. And all the Koi fish!!

title: Change of Pace
content: This great little Chinese village and Garden were a nice change of pace from the modern city environment. We all thoroughly enjoyed the surroundings and would recommend that if you are looking for a more traditional view of China in Shanghai city this is not a bad representation. Well worth a look around, with plenty of street sellers to keep you entertained as well.

title: Fake and overcrowded
content: if you go to Shanghai for few days, don't waste your time there. This is very fake and overcrowded. One of the most touristy area of the city.

title: Busy Urban Garden
content: There's a small fee to pay to enter the garden, but once inside its as busy as the tourist area outside it. As a private garden, I'm sure it was a nice area, but as a public attraction, I found it disappointing. The tourist shops outside are worth visiting for souvenirs, but don't bother going in the garden.

title: Peaceful
content: Lovely tranquil gardens in the middle of Shanghai madness. Didn't seem to see it all, needed a map. Were the gardens of a private home long ago. Chinese architecture...love it.

title: Essential for a Shanghai Itinerary
content: These Gardens are beautiful and peaceful and are in stark contrast to the nearby somewhat chaotic Shopping Bazaar.

title: Tranquil and beautiful
content: We headed off this morning not know what to expect; had to go back to hotel to get some stunning pictures of the flora and buildings. The Koi carp are in abundance, take some food to feed them.

title: Beautiful
content: We went an hour before it closed and although we were short on time it was nice because it was not crowded. Beautiful gardens. Very enjoyable!

title: this is so lovely
content: There is lots to learn here about Chinese gardens from symbolism, forms, etc. if you have a guide. Or just enjoy this garden/property which was where a family once enjoyed their spare time (?). It can get busy, so try to find a quieter time.

title: Last bit of old China in Shangahi
content: This is the last area in Shanghai that has not been built ups with modern structures. It is too bad that at this point in time, they are no longer planing the gardens with seasonal flowers. There are only the plants that are permanent. It could be so much more spectacular if they planted display flowers here and there, as I am sure the gardens once proudly displayed. It looked rather drab as a garden. The original architecture however is all still intact and quite well maintained.

title: Serene Spot
content: A beautiful garden. A little crowded when we went, but we were still able to capture very nice photographs. I could imagine it would be lovely later in the spring, before it gets too warm.

title: Happy Fish
content: This one time imperial retreat is now rather crowded and is accessed through an extensive complex of shops and restaurants, modern, but in traditional style. All in all, not a restful experience, but fun and picturesque. The Happy Fish Pavilion features a landscaped pool in which the many resident carp seem decoratively at ease.

title: Nice stop after a long flight
content: I am a hobby gardener, so of course finding a garden in a city makes me happy. We were here right before the spring burst. Not as much garden as I had thought (thinking japanese?) but we were brought by the tour company and ushered thru. Thus, I don't know the entrance fee or the value. The rocks were amazing. Not too big for those that tolerate gardens for their loved one's sake. Nice photo ops, but crowded, which takes the serenity out of it.

title: Nice Spot (just nice !!!)
content: Yu Yuang and Yu Yuang Garden are on every tourist's list for Shanghai. The Yu Yuang district is called Chinatown of Shanghai. Today it is one large souvenirs' shops compound. You are really better off buying chinese tea at the airport in Shanghai than in Yu Yuang shopping area. At the airport prices are the same or the smaller, but the quality is higher and the packaging is much, much nicer !!!. Same goes for souvenirs.

title: Well worth a visit
content: On the tourist trail, but well worth a visit. Best to go early in the day or late to get best feel of the place.

title: Good overall
content: Mid March there were only a few flowering shrubs but otherwise it was a typical Chinese garden with many shrubs, rocks, bridges, water and fish. Lots of lovely photo opportunities despite it being busier than expected on the Friday afternoon we were there.

title: peaceful interlude
content: Interesting history and in the heart of Shanghi. Make sure you leave time to shop outside the garden as this is one of the best places to find fine handicrafts of China

title: Yu Gardens
content: This is quite an amazing place to see. The beauty of this spring time of the year. Flowers were gorgeous and seemed to be in full bloom. The shopping at the Yu Gardens was just the best. I got a lot of gifts for family, friends and myself here. I look forward to going back here again someday!

title: Nice gardens but a tad crowded
content: Chinese architecture, well groomed gardens, artistically sculptured roofs and buildings.

title: Such a peaceful spot in the center of busy Shanghaii
content: All around the YuYuan garden there are shops of trinkets, food, tea and just about everything. But once you enter the gardens you are taken to another time. The place is vast and a great time to explore the different areas all different. The building, bridges, gardens each have their own personality. Take your time and enjoy!!!!

title: A gem
content: This is quite difficult to find, as you need to brave the very busy alleyways, full of people flogging Rolex watches, toys and jewellery - but it is worth it.

title: Loved it
content: Getting there is half the fun of the experience and given the hustle and bustle outside the garden, makes this garden even better. The best one in Shanghai, you don;t want to miss the whole experience. Make sure you allow plenty of time.

title: Old Chinese Complex
content: It's an original chinese complex, where we can find so many things to buy and food to eat.. Interesting place to visit

title: Pretty garden
content: Lovely Chinese garden with the pre-requisite rocks, water , plants & trees. There's a lovely view at every turn & lots of photo opportunities. The buildings, corridors & tea house are all beautiful. Gets very crowded but still very worthwhile.

title: Don't Miss It
content: Admission to Yu Yuan Garden is RMB 40, half price for elderly over 60 years old even you are a foreigner. By paying a small sum , you will be surprised and satisfied for all you will discover in the garden. Yu Yuan has more than 400 years history from Ming and Qing dynasties, its architecture of halls, pavilions, rockeries, flowing streams and many others to form a typical garden of the past. Don't miss it, it is as good as Suzhou Garden.

user_loc: 明尼苏达明尼阿波利斯
title: Beautiful oasis
content: Very beautiful former private garden. Rocks, water, fish, greenery and old buildings combine to create an oasis in a sprawling metropolis. A nice spot to sit and relax. There is an old tea house opposite the entrance, grab a tea to go and sit down in the garden. Very peaceful.

title: Beautiful garden, worth the money to go inside
content: While Yu Bazaar was a bit of a crazy mess (I was there on a weekday morning, it was crowded like the weekend!), Yu Garden was completely tranquil, all for RMB30! The place was beautiful, its architecture was preserved very well and I really enjoyed it. Highly recommend!

title: A dream made real
content: With a drammatic origin, enclaved in the old city and now surrounded by merchants is this original garden that has impressive views every step. Definetly, a must in your trip.

title: Difficult to find
content: This garden is actually very difficult to find for tourists coz it is located really inside a maze of shops/bazaar with thousands of people approaching you to sell cheap stuffs.Honestly I didn't find the garden too attractive. In fact the pond was quite dirty.If you wish to visit for the sake of saying that I have been to Yu Yuan garden, plz visit but you won't miss much if you give it a miss also.

title: Peaceful oasis
content: What a beautiful jewel of a garden. We visited just as the spring blossoms were starting. A great way to see traditional architecture and beautiful arrangements of rocks, trees, and flowers. It was especially welcome as a respite against the crowds elsewhere. It isn't very large but next time I would allow more time to really soak up the serenity on offer here. Ground is uneven in many places so watch your step.

title: Crowded and confuse
content: Be carefully to buy thing or souvenir there because the price make me sick!!! They gave me the high price! They cannot speak English well.

title: If you love Chinese Gardens, this is a must see
content: I am not a huge fan of Chinese gardens, they feel very contrived and unnatural. When I listen to those who love them they talk about how natural they look and feel. It is a nice space and if you are in the old city it is not costly and so worth a visit.

title: A must to do in Shanghai
content: Yu Garden and its area is s nicr place to go and spend time to see real China. The garden is beautiful with old Chinese type houses, trees, small bridges over small lakes and with red fishes in the water. There is a kind of bazaar outside of the actual garden which is also interesting to visit.. Highly recommended..

title: China
content: In the center of Old Town which can offer you relaxation, health and peace, proof of its name, and taste of old China in modern Newyorkwise Shangai. Minimum 2-3 hours needed to explore. It is close to the Bazaar which you can find so many things in terms of food, souveniours.

title: Oasis amongst the shops
content: Yu Yuan is a very beautifully, constructed garden, from the Ming era. It is a mixture of buildings, walls, water, large rocks and well manicured plants. If you were there by yourself, it would be so peaceful and serene, but it does attract a lot of people. The rocks are a main feature, the taller the better and the more holes in them, the better, for luck.

title: Quintessential Classic Chinese Garden
content: Fabulous place to visit in order to get a feel for the sort of gardens that made the Jiangnan region famous. Similar in some ways to the gardens of Suzhou, but more convenient if you are in Shanghai for business or leisure and don't want to take a trip out of town.

user_loc: 加利福尼亚纽波特海滩
title: Beautiful Gardens
content: Must see this when in Shanghai. They are amazing and just beautiful. The way the water and nature ties in with the architecture is just astounding. Truly unique.

title: Always interesting
content: It is a place you must visit when you come to Shanghai and make sure you try out the local dumplings. Careful of pick-pocket because it is very crowded.

title: Go for the Lantern Festival!
content: A great place to visit, but if you get a chance, go during the Lantern Festival. Very crowded, but the crowd was fun (many happy drunks!) and the lanterns amazing. I could not stop taking photos!

title: Tranquil
content: This garden was superb and just moving into Spring the blossom was coming out and as fairly quiet time of year not to many people around. An incredible layout and structure of this garden in our opinion much better than the garden at the forbidden palace. A quit spot amongst the teeming masses.

title: Amazing Chinese New Year
content: the garden and the old city outside are always beautiful but during Spring Festival they are astonishing with their decorations. your camera needs lots of memory to impress all. old city is almost commercial and you can find every sort of souvenir but be aware that here everything is more expensive. you can buy the same thing for a cheaper price in many other different places around shanghai. anyway I have to admit that the quality here is sometimes better than others, especially art crafts and jade.

title: Very interesting to visit, but it can get VERY crowded.
content: Architecture and gardens are something you need to see - it's been preserved and is very peaceful to walk through. HOWEVER, it can get crowded. We walked through the bridge leading to the gardens, paid the fee to enter, and spent two hours walking through the gardens. It's well worth the entry fee! Try to visit in Spring when the trees are blooming.

title: Classic China in a contemporary city
content: Yu Garden reminded me of all the types of sights found everywhere in Beijing, but are not as common in Shanghai. Step back in time when you enter Yu Garden and enjoy the amazing buildings, gardens, ponds, fountains, winding paths. A great way to spend time.

title: A Shanghai must see
content: A beautiful place to wonder for a couple of hours. But AVOID on weekends and holidays. There are lots of other things to do and see in the area and amazing food options too. Taking a tuk tuk ride is a must... you get a really good tour of the area outside of the garden. I have been twice and i'm sure i'll go again!

title: Don't go on weekends or holidays.
content: We went twice, once on a weekend with thousands of people, and once during the week. It was amazing the difference!

title: Beautiful, but busy
content: I spent a free morning on my business trip wandering around the Yu Yuan Garden. I had been disappointed that I wasn't able to find the time to visit Suzhou so I was pleased that our host was able to fit in a visit to the gardens.

title: what a lovely garden
content: Visited with wendy wu tour, the gardens were absolutely magnificent. How they design the gardens is amazing. Well worth a visit one of the highlights of shanghai

title: Great Ancient and Colorful Garden in the center of Modern City
content: I am here this noon, and it cost me 30 RMB (yuan) to enter the museum. It is really worthed because I see a beautiful old and colorful chinese temple and beautiful gardens inside the modern shanghai. Very Good!

title: Very beautiful
content: A very beautiful old garden and temple right in the middle of all the hustle and bustle. Large garden with lots of nooks and crannies and places to sit and enjoy the site. Amazing rock formations and tunnels and walk through which open up into beautiful little areas with blossoming trees. Pond full of Koi Carp and were in their hundreds when fed.

title: A beautiful garden but tons of people
content: A beautiful typical Chinese garden. But with all the tourists around you and souvenirs shops, it really fells like Disneyland. I prefer the gardens in Suzhou.

title: A quiet area in the centre of the city
content: The garden is a true oasis in the middle of a very vibrant area of Shanghai. We visited in Jan/Feb so it was Winter but I would imagine that in Spring this is truly spectacular. Lots of twists and turns with areas to sit and reflect... just beautiful!

title: Lovely, but busy!
content: Worth a visit, but oh dear, it's packed with people! Also watch out for annoying people who pester you to buy watches etc. Vacation time is a no go zone! You may be lucky to have even a square meter to yourself! Some good opportunities to pick up a bargain or two at the local markets without the pushy street sellers who chase after you even after a firm ' no!' Proceed with caution and go with a group!

title: Oasis in a busy city
content: This was a lovely quiet visit. The bazaar outside is a jungle and so crowded with people and it was wonderful to escape into the peace of the gardens for a wander around. The kids enjoyed exploring all the twists and turns.

title: intricate garden design, well worth a visit
content: Great little garden in the middle of shanghai near the new Bund area. Square footage wise its much smaller than any other summer gardens in China, but it is packed with exquisite architecture (doors shaped like lamps, Chinese characters all over the facade, etc) and densely packed garden with fauna and flora makes this a haven in the bustling city of shanghai. A great way to wind down and relax after a stroll across the Bund and Nanjing shopping street.

title: Just ok, nothing spectacular
content: The gardens themselves are ok. We went at about 4pm and it was only 15 yuan each (with student dicount) wouldnt have paid any more than that and didnt need more that 45 minutes to walk through. Lots of stalls to look at around the area so definitely worth browsing around the area but if you're short of time it is definitely not a must see.

title: Pleasant visit
content: In a busy part of town, it is a relief to get away from the crowds - however, there is the chance that the crowds are there too.

title: A piece of serenity inside the city!
content: Def check out this place! It's a garden that belonged to some high ranked man in the early 19 century.

title: Beautiful but crowded
content: Try to go there during lunchtime to avoid the crowds. The area around the Yu Garden is also well worth spending some time in.

title: Nice, but busy and like many other gardens.
content: If you only have a few days in Shanghai, this might be a nice spot to go to and combine it with the Old Town. Offcourse its very touristy and you might get caught by big groups. But still, the garden is nice.

title: Nicely placed garden in the urban jungle
content: YuYuan Garden is perfectly situated in the heart of Shanghai - between all the sky-scrapers and constantly rush for money. The garden takes you back in time and gives you a hint what Shanghai really looked like before it became a soulless urban jungle.

title: A Tourist Destination To Check the Box
content: Yu Garden is not something you should miss but it isn't something I would plan my trip around. Tea tasting is a fun experience -- even our kids enjoyed it. If it is Chinese New Year, then you are in for a treat. Crowded but beautiful. The Lanterns are lovely and a picture you must have in your folio. And, be sure to get the xiaolongbao!

title: A step back in time
content:
This was a very interesting and provided beautiful landscape of
pagodas, pavilions, rockeries, fountains, ancient trees and precious flowers.

title: Stunning
content: Place is very serene.

title: beautiful
content: Very nice for a relaxing walk and also if you want to do some shopping this is a good place but i would say bargain atleast 60 percent less than what they ask for.

title: A bit gaudy
content: Nice ancient buildings but somewhat spoiled by all the pushy people trying to sell you stuff. Some good photo opportunities though.

title: Didn't feel contentment
content: At any tourist attraction in Shanghai you will always be huddled up with about 8 million other people. It's just the way it is, no point in complaining. But, there's not much to see in this garden. I'd skip it and skip this particular crowd.

title: Not worth the time..
content: I honestly don't see the attraction to this place. Yes, it's got a place with the fish in it.. yes it has a famous Crab Meat Xiao Long Bao (Shanghai style dumplings) restaurant and yes there are tourist shops.. but it's a very tiny place, separated by a 20 to 30 minute walk from the other attractions in Shanghai and not particularly easy to get to without a taxi/tour-bus. I didn't bother to visit this location until my 3rd visit to Shanghai and only then because a friend wanted to go for a walk around.. so this is definitely one that can be skipped if you are pushing for time on your trip.

title: Yu Yan is Heaven
content: This Garden is really amazing with beautiful plants and fascinating chinees architecture. there is a good shopping area around this garden with nice souvenirs and chinees handmade.

title: So so, and beware of the con shops inside
content: I guess this is very interesting if you are very into old typical SH house, however, there are many places that you can't go inside to have a browse so it's limited to browsing around the garden. In addition, the souvenir shop inside sells "con" goods, and the things are exactly the same as those cheaply made goods outside around the old street, but priced up 10 times, so don't bother browsing. If you want genunine well-made goods, go to Tian Zi Fang (田子坊) or 1911, redtown etc.

title: A must see in Shanghai
content: It is so beautiful and big, the experience includes the garden visit for the best pictures of your Shanghai visit, some great food and shopping for Chinese traditional stuff such as silk, art, etc. Save at least 3 hours for this location

title: Winter time not a great time to visit
content: We visited the gardens in January and while it was great that it was not crowded, i suspect it is much more beautiful in the spring or summer. It was still very pretty and quite interesting.

title: Gives a good feel for the old Shanghai
content: I've been here many times and continue to enjoy it. You can walk around on your own or go with a tour group. The gardens are unique and beautiful at any time of the year. The views from inside the walls are very unique, you can get great pictures of the modern Shanghai skyline behind the dragon wall within the garden.

title: Good price for tipical Shanghai food
content: I like the steam dumpling which was with soup inside it; the smell bean curve which was tasty and crispy and the bean milk. I could walk around to observe traditional Chinese cultural and buy souvenior in the shops of the area. However, it was a bit too crowded.

title: Gorgeous
content: Went in Jan. and even though it was super cold outside, it still felt very much like a summer garden and is a photographer's dream.

title: You have got to be kidding!
content: Let me share a story...

title: Beautiful Peace amist Chaos
content: We thought we wouldbe here for just an hour or so but ended up spending hours in this little peace of culture bang in the middle of tourism central. Take the time to sit and take it in. Don't just look around as you walk. Stop, breath (well, maybe not!!!!) and enjoy. lovely day with the family. Kids loved the fish.

title: Place to get souvenirs and other items
content: This is the place to get souvenirs, snacks and other accessories but make sure to go with Chinese speaking person. If you are a foreigner, you look around what you like and let your Chinese companion know and let him/her go ask how much it is without you. Because most of items have price stickers but those are way more expensive than the price the sellers offer to locals. For example, I saw price tag of 168 CNY for chinese doll but when local asked the seller, the seller offered 60 CNY. We negotiated it down to 30 CNY. This tells you how much you could pay more just by being a foreigner.

title: Very Nice and also quite large
content: Decided we had to make a quick stop at Yu Yuan, The garden was wonderful and we ended up spending over an hour there exploring. Saw lots of goldfish, rockeries, the turning bridge and the tea house. Also had lunch here. The bazaar is commerical but it was nicer than I expected. Glad we made the time to see it.

title: A must on a visit to Shanghai
content: Yu Yuan Garden is a must on any visit to Shanghai. It's quite beautiful at night. There is a subway station about a block away and many many shops to wander through. If feels like you can get lost in the maze but not really. It's all inside a square block. Just pick a direction and go. Look for upstairs shops too. There are pearl shops and others that are above the ground floor shops. Many are really nice and worth visiting as well.

title: Beautiful gardens, tourist surroundings
content: Don't come to this area expecting everything to be historic- a lot of the tourist infrastructure is more modern and just designed to look like old fashioned architecture. So when you first approach the market, be warned that a lot of the "classic" buildings aren't really that old.

title: niiiice
content: a sense of peace in the middle of the unbelievably hectic and crowded yu yuan garden area, which is basically like a huge marketplace. but the gardn is kept nicely

title: Bring your camera
content: This was a really fun place to go exploring. There's lots of beautiful old buildings and there are many sort of "hidden" pathways around the garden. The scenery is really beautiful, so be sure to bring your camera.

title: Very crowded
content: Perhaps I would have enjoyed this garden more had it been my first visit to a classic Chinese garden. However, this garden, while lovely and very large, pales when compared to the Master of Nets garden in Souzhou or the lovely, tranquil gardens in Tongli. Worth a visit, but not my favorite

title: Surprisingly Good
content: I'm not the greatest fan of gardens - typical 'bloke' but this is very special. An oasis of old China amongst the madness of Yu Yuan which is crazy. The grdens are very beautiful and interesting.

title: Peaceful and educational - great place to visit.
content: Go with the right guide and you will get so much more by visiting the YuYuan Gardens then just walking it yourself. There is so much history and education in one small place. And if you are lucky as we were there were moments that it was only us in the peaceful setting of the gardens and grounds. Worth the visit.

title: The Can't-Miss Spot in Shanghai
content: If you can only see one thing in Shanghai, this is probably it. If you are visiting on business, this is likely where your hosts will bring you if you have a little bit of leisure time. The gardens are a very nice spot for a stroll and the old Chinese shopping area outside is something you will not see anywhere else.

title: Yu Yuan Garden
content: I first thought that this was a botanical garden but decided to just pay it a visit. I was amazed by the great buildings this place has and businesses selling almost everything.The architecture is so amazing.

title: Very typical chinatown.
content: The siao long pao is good but the line is too long. Very touristy and with lots of tourist that is gets crowded.

title: A wonderful window into the past
content: Like a few of the older buildings, the ones in the garden were rebuilt about 200 years ago, due to the fact that the original buildings built of wood, couldn't last more that 200-250 years. My husband and I really enjoyed the walk with our tour guide through the gardens and pathways. He was very knowledgable which was also nice as we learnt some of the history behind the buildings, gardens and feng shui. We especially thought the yin/yang tree (or husband/wife tree) was very sweet (one tree with half green leaves and other half maroon coloured leaves). Wonderful place but we were told can be quite busy in summer time. Small entrance fee.

title: Cool Place - Don't Shop
content: Tourist place with lots to see, but the prices are high. The dumplings we had were just ok. Good photo opportunity thats about it.

title: Yu Yuan Garden
content: Cost us 20 yuan to get in as we showed our pension card. So well worth a visit. Built during the Ming dynasty as a private garden. Garden is famous for The Big Rockery, the Naturally Hollowed Jade Boulder, The ancient hall and opera stage. Is about 2 hectares and takes about one hour to stroll around.

title: A must see in Shanghai!
content: The garden is really beautiful. It is one of the very few places in a modern city like shanghai, that you can get a glimpse of old china. Get your cameras ready and shoot!

title: Beautiful garden with nooks and crannies all over the place to discover
content: This garden is an amazing oasis from the hustle and bustle of the big city. You can't hear any traffic or outside noise and can really enjoy your time there. The garden itself is divided into several smaller separate gardens so while its easy to get lost, it's also wonderfully easy to find yourself a private corner and relax. The market around it also makes for some nice shopping.

title: Scam artists galore
content: Please be careful when visiting most tourists attractions in Shanghai. Anyone asking you to take a picture for them in ENGLISH is trying to Scam you. I got asked about 10 times in a space of half an hour so I can only imagine how many scammers are in the area. The old style building create a nice atmosphere, but don't let it fool you because it is just another market. you should ALWAYS negotiate the prices. I don't know about you but seeing a Starbucks or Macdonalds in a place like that really detracts for me, from the authenticity of the gardens.

title: 豫园Guarden
content: This is was my favourite thing about my holiday in Shanghai. I spent several hours losing myself to the beauty of the garden. When you're satisfied with your time spent gorging in the beauty you can visit the nearby markets, where people sell fine tailored dresses and other various wares. I enjoyed bartering prices in the many shops. You can't be disappointed.

title: so beautiful
content: Loved these gardens. A little touch of old China in this very modern city. We had a guide with us and that gave us wonderful feel for the garden.

title: Ancient and modern all in one
content: Loved the building, the structure and how they all come together at night when the lights go up. You should totally go to the Starbucks at Yu Yuan, it's unique. Be sure to bargain with the pushcarts shop owner, slash the price by 30-50%. I absolutely love shopping there. It's a definite must-go!!

title: Tourist
content: Not enough variety. Every shop seemed to sell the same thing. Bargaining was quite fun. Too crowded. Sales staff not really to friendly at some stores. Spend a couple of hours no more.

title: Great Escape from the Bustling Modern City
content: Have been to the garden twice, once with a tour guide and once without. It is much more interesting to hear the history from a guide than to just walk through and admire the historical gardens. In order to get to the gardens you have to walk through lots of Chinese peddlers who can sometimes be aggressive, but avoid eye contact, keep moving and you'll enjoy the gardens and hearing about how and why it was built.

title: Fun stop
content: It was a fun stop to go to Yu Yuan Garden. There's shops and restaurants outside the garden so there's something for everyone. I very much enjoyed the visit!

title: A must see landmark
content: If you think that the garden was built almost 500 years ago, you will feel how small creatures we really are. In the heart of the city but wouldn't hear a noise from outside, I assume a visit in Spring gives one a more spectacular experience.

title: Pretty and enchanting
content: I love the look of ancient Chinese building,

title: Loved it, hated it
content: I loved it, my daughter hated it. I loved the traditional architecture, gardens, endless stalls and cool chinese stuff I bought there--like traditional paintings, calligraphy, silk wrapped journals, Chinese stamps and other unique souvenirs. My daughter was repulsed by seeing snack foods like small birds(?) roasted on sticks, the smells, the calling out from the stalls, the haggling and the endless, claustrophobic sea of people. Love it? Hate it? You decide.

title: Dont Miss it
content: One of the nice traditional Bazaars in all over Asia. You can see and buy lots of nice handicrafts that you may not find in other capital cities of china with a good Bargaining price.

title: Fascinating. ..
content: Visited on a damp squib of a Sunday afternoon. It was packed to the rafters. Neverless, it was thoroughly enjoyable. Plenty of shops selling the wierd and wonderful. Tried the shanghai dumplings which were very nice and then made a success of throwing coins at the statue in the middle of the lake. Didn't realise I could then make a wish!!!!!

title: Tranquility in the heart of the city
content: Well laid out. Part of the rich history of the city. A nice contrast to the "house of crap". Gardens, pathways, architecture, antiques, sculpture. Worth the visit.

title: OK place
content: It's a good place to view some traditional Chinese architecture. There are lots of shops selling trinkets and souvenirs. This is also where the famous mini bun restaurant located and the queue is very long. Anyway, the mini bun is no where near as good as Ding Tai Fung's. It's worth a visit, not twice.

title: Beautiful gardens
content: We spent much a a day here, it was a nice sanctuary in a busy city. There were many beautiful buildings, trees and flowers. Yu Yuan is a great place to take photos. Avoid the gift shops within the Gardens- they are very overpriced. You can find the same items in other parts of the city for much less- try the outdoor markets.

title: Nice and Away fom the Crowds
content: It was very interesting and you will get some awesome photos. It is also nice to get away from the crowds in the market. It is amazing how peaceful it was given it proximity to the markets.

title: Good place for lunch
content: A well preserved look at an old chinese palace. The best Shanghai dumplings you can find. Good place to by some souveniers. A must visit destination if you are staying in Shanghai.

title: Hmmm.
content: Not for me. Maybe I went at the wrong time... but the Yu Garden was really really disappointing, and was one part of the trip I was really looking forward to. Walking over the zig zag bridge took a VERY long time - it was literally just so crowded, I was feeling very claustrophobic... ugh. So make sure you go early and avoid the crowds. I was there in November, so I can only dare to think of what it would be like in the middle of summer.

title: Casual Stroll.
content: Beautiful Chinese garden, though aspects of westernization can be seen. For example, in a big court with traditional Chinese food stalls, there is a Starbucks in the very centre. The area also houses a very popular xiaolongbao restuarant! nice gardens and good for photos

title: Small
content: Ticket cost 30 yuen per person and it has many great shape of stones in there. Totally look like during Ming Dynasty. But bad thing is that, it was small and easy get crowded. Hard to snap best view.

title: You haven't been to Shanghai without going to Yu Yuan!
content: That's very quantencential Shanghai! Big crowd, lots of shops, a temple and a small garden. It's like a condensed version of Shanghai jammed into one square mile!

title: Favorite Shanghai Experience
content: Also known as the Garden of Contentment, the Yuyuan Garden is quite possibly my favorite thing we saw in Shanghai. The entrance fee is about 40 RMB and is absolutely worth it. The garden is located in the center of the Yuyuan Bazaar in Old City near the zig-zag bridge, and is a serene refuge from the hectic shopping market. Once a privately owned estate it is now maintained by the government and is in near perfect condition. The garden is an intricate 5-acre maze of small buildings, bridges and trees hovering over ponds filled with brightly colored koi fish. I highly recommend stopping here.

title: Disneyland China
content: I visited one evening around 21:00 and the tourist shops were closing. The good thing was that there were very few people around so it was a good time to visit and avoid the crowds. The "feel" of the place is that of a built environment and a bit of a tourist trap. Too many buildings and shops around what was once probably a very nice natural garden. The lanterns and lighting was nice for Chinese New year

title: Peaceful garden in the centre
content: One must go. It is a peaceful and beautiful place. One can spend few hours in the garden. Beware though, they invite you to drink tea "for free" and if you do not buy, they get a bit funny.

title: Like Monty Python, something different
content: Entrance tucked away, hard to find. An interesting private park, full of carved and assembled stone sculptures, quite beautiful. Take a camera. Enjoyed the visit even in the rain.

title: Yu Yuan - dont buy just see
content: Visited on 3 Dec 2012. It is less crowded on a weekday morning. The place houses interesting shops and a great variety of merchandise. The ponds, buildings and architecture are interesting too.

title: An amazing garden that takes you back in time
content: A wonderful places to go..Takes you back in time in a city of skyscrapers everywhere. If you are a photographer, enjoy the perspectives through the various shape entrances and lots of photo spots in this place..

title: Beautiful but hard to find
content: I can't imagine finding this place without help of a guide, or a taxi driver perhaps. It's a beautiful garden with oodles of Chinese history, buried deep inside old Shanghai. You'll be smothered by lots of natives selling their wares, even inside Yu Garden. I would definitely suggest using the knowledge of a tour guide because there is no audio headset system and signage lacks in many areas. Overall, though, no trip to China would be complete without spending some time in a garden like this. A tip as you move from room to room -- watch the thresholds, they are customery and signify the importance and power of the owners (the higher the threshold, the more important the owner).

title: Definitely worth the visit
content: Yu Yuan is a must on a first visit to Shanghai - we really enjoyed it. The only time during our stay in the city that we felt that we were in "Old China". Beautiful buildings, ponds and lakes and lovely gardens. Peaceful atmosphere and not too noisy despite the crowds. It was fairly crowded on a warm Monday at noon in mid-October, but not too bad. Probably best to avoid weekends, however...

title: avoid going onn weekend
content: enjoy the stop here - lot of things to see n buy i.e gifts etc. the old shanghai street is jz nearby so do go there for local snacks.....

title: Beautiful
content: Crowded but beautiful with many shops. We also walked to Temple area, lots a fun and delicious dumplings

title: Lovely Garden
content: It is the must seem city highlights in Shanghai, perhaps a bit more touristy but still worth a visit. Recommending you to hire a guide, so you will be able to understand and know so much more than simply see the building.

title: Must see.
content: Good nature with old buildings. Many tourists, but it is really beautiful place. You should go there. It is better to go not late, because they close it at 4 pm.

title: peace and health
content: I arrived to shangahai and visited Yuyuan Garden. It was believed to have been built in the Ming Dynasty, more than 400 years ago. The name meant "peace and health"-- a place of peace and comfort. The exquisite layout, beautiful scenery and the artistic style of the garden architecture had made outstanding. One of the highlights of the garden was the Exquisite Jade Rock characterized by its wrinkled appearance, slender shape, translucent nature and numerous holes eroded by water. The surrounding you will find good shopping opportunities, where traditional Chinese products, gold and jewels were on sale. It opened 08:30 to 17:00. I recomend you to come at night for it's romance. Nice place I ever seen before.

title: even good in the rain
content: we went there just to go to the tea house and the Dumpling restaurant. The tea house was wonderful as was the tea. and the Dumpling House was great.Do not leave the Dumpling House when you see the queue this is for takeaway just go straight in the restaurant and enjoy

title: Beautiful gardens
content: I loved these gardens, and it was very cheap to enter. It was very peaceful and a nice place to spend a few hours. I was alone, but taking a partner would be a great idea!

title: A Must-See in Shanghai
content: This is best seen with a guide who can explain the various areas. It is incredibly beautiful. Everywhere you look, from every angle, there is a picture to be taken and cherished. Very crowded at times, it still retains an air of peacefulness, and if there is time, a few minutes spent standing or sitting in contemplation can be very calming. The surrounding bazaar area has many shops, including places to sit and have tea, and is a fascinating place to look for "real, fake, and real-fake" items. I found worthwhile bargains on some exquisite old-style Chinese landscape paintings. My wife went for the tea-pots!

title: Crowded tourist haunt
content: Be prepared for the crowds as this is popular with both locals and tourists. The HuXinTing teahouse, right in the centre of the Garden, charges very high prices for its tea and no sharing is allowed. So be warned. The food court looks promising but the food is nothing to shout about. Lots of things to see and eat here, but choose wisely.

title: Nothing special
content: If you're a China noob then add an extra star, as this is a perfectly pretty and typical example of a Chinese garden, with all the pavilions, willows and water features you could hope for. If you've been around the Chinese block a few times though, this is nothing you haven't seen a million times before.

title: Very nice and pretty
content: Well upkeep - was very nice to spend some quiet time. Great place to just wonder around. Careful of those wanting to sell souveniors

title: Phenomenal and breathtaking
content: Imagine all the films you've seen depicting the magic of China. Then go to the Yu Yuan Gardens where this is surpassed tenfold.

title: Beautiful and quiet...
content: Definitely a Must see when in Shanghai.

title: Aptly named
content: Our shedule in Shanghai was crazy - meetings, concerts and events from first thing in the morning until late at night and in a city that is filled to the brim with hustle and bustle. My wife and I took a couple of hours off and visited the Yu Yuan Garden. It is large, complex and beautiful. I could have easily spent a few more hours just sitting by the beautiful pools and contemplating the interesting rock formations. Outside the gardens is alive with retail and restaurants so when one feels ready, one can insert oneself back into the hustle and bustle and get a great deal on a watch or handbag!

title: An exquisite garden
content: This is a very tranquil place to wander around but there just seemed to be too many people to really relax and enjoy the tranquility. the architecture with the dragons esconced on the roofs was fascinating and of course each statue or figure has a story.

title: Small and nice
content: This beautiful little garden is a kind of oasis in the middle of the busy city. Visit after your tiring sightseeings and you will breath a sight of relief

title: Pretty garden, tons of tourists
content: The nice thing about this garden is that is very beautifully designed and different from gardens in other cities like Beijing. It's also nice that it is in the middle of Old Town because you can see two places at once. Be prepared for tons of tourists in a somewhat small location.

title: Nothing much to see
content: I followed my colleague there and didn't expect much. We went on Sunday and the place was very crowded with tourist. There was a restaurant selling dumplings, the queue for takeaway was super long. We dine in, the food was far from good, not worth the long waiting time.

title: Nice place to see Old china
content: This place is very beautiful and transports you back into old times. Dragon headed rooftops, red fish (this is the only thing that the chineese do not eat :)) add to the charm of the place.

title: Pleasurable wandering, watch the scammers!
content: Lovely buildings around here, lots of shops to test your bargaining skills.

title: Crowded garden with lots of people trying to escape it all
content: This was a beautiful garden, but fairly crowded, which made it difficult to enjoy its peaceful intent. We did stop at the famous Nanxiang Steamed Bun restaurant in the long take-out line. Buns were good, but not fantastic.

title: Photographers playground
content: If you have the patience to wait for the many, many people who visit these gardens to past by you can get some fabulous photos.

title: My Second Favorite Thing In Shanghai
content: I love these type of parks so I am biased. I like to slowly wander around these zen touched spaces. They are particularly lovely when you are alone and the weather is misty and keeps the tourists out. These spaces are not good when they are crowded so go at off-peak times. By the way my favorite thing was simply walking through the real neighborhoods of the city. Where regular people shopped and lived. Have to just wander off the beaten path.

title: Pretty
content: The garden is pretty big but most of all quite tranquil and beautiful. The only thing I would critique(which there is nothing that can be done) is that while I was trying to get my breathtaking photos I see big modern buildings in the background ruining my shot :/ Like I said, nothing that can be done but wish the beauty of the garden wasn't ruined by the modern surroundings.

title: Beautiful Garden
content: A must see. Very beautiful, just what you thing a Chinese garden should look like. Have stood the time over 600 years and to think a man built it for his father all those years ago.

title: Unexpected Gem
content: I honestly did not expect to be so impressed by a garden in the city, but this one is worth the trip WITH A GUIDE. The garden in beautiful in it's own right, but a guide will add so much to your understanding of the place. Also, the surround area is everything Shanghai smooshed together, from street food to toddlers pooping in the street to high end stores and McDonalds. Worth it.

title: A beautiful garden
content: Yu Garden is not far from Nanjing Road shopping area. It is a classical private garden in southern China, packed with halls, pavilions, ponds, bridges, rocks, and trees. Every corner of the garden is picture perfect. The garden was built during Ming Dynasty (more than 500 years old), but well preserved today. In here, you can relax and enjoy.

title: Lovely garden
content: Lovely garden in the middle of the city. Typical Chinese garden with beautiful vistas at each turn. Enjoy the tea house at the start and the tea ceremony.

title: Silence!
content: A great get away from all the noise in Shanghai. Gave me a good idea of what I want my future garden to look like. Has to be seen!

title: Great buildings
content: Here's where we met that interesting combination of age and modernity. Beautiful old buildings restored well in restored streets with modern retail commerce being conducted at many levels. We loved the restaurant where you wandered along and chose what you wanted to eat with spaces for the traveller and a more upmarket section for diners who wanted silver style service. The food was delicious, varied, well cooked and tasty. The staff were pleasant and we found it relaxing.

title: Traquil spot
content: This classical Chinese garden has fine pavilions, cloisters, decorated walls and a beautiful crystal pond. It is an oasis in the middle of the bustling city.

title: Nice garden - pushy people selling stuff in the area
content: Although it's a nice place, there are some cons here. It's really crowded, especially at the weekends so you don't really get great photo opportunities. It's basically a lot of people pushing around on narrow footpaths trying to take as many pictures as possible. I suppose the garden is much nicer in spring but we enjoyed it anyway. If you long for some peace and quiet, try the Confucian Temple (Wen Miao Temple) instead where you can walk around in pretty surroundings. We finished in an hour or so. There is an RMB30 admission fee.

title: pleasant
content: One of the best places to visit in shanghai.Walking in a wonderful garden with catchy ponds and trees is all what u needs to relax your thoughts.

title: Nice place
content: Visit the temple to see the deity of Shanghai city.. In eastern culture, every village and city used to have a deity. Similar to our Indian tradition; Shanghai too has its deity in Yu Yuan garden!

title: Must visit the dumpling restaurant
content: What a business, the take away window has people lined up 2 deep and 30-40 meters long every time I have visited this place. Upstairs is not much better, some times I have waited 15 minutes to get a table, but the wait is worth it. Fresh dumplings or all sorts are being made in front of your eyes, cooked and eaten within minutes of completion. If you like seafood try the soup dumplings, they are filled with a seafood broth and arrive piping hot with a straw poking out of the top, beware you do not burn your tongue.

title: Nice but too touristy
content: It's definately really beautiful but I found it very tourist driven with shops and vendors selling things all over the place. We went when it was super busy so I lost motiviation and didn't see as much as I wanted. Will probably try to go back some time.
