title: Attractive architecture
content: Place look very attractive, however be prepared for pushy and ignorant people trying to convince you to follow them to buy fake goods. If you can manage to ignore them, you will enjoy this place

title: Confucius
content: This garden has all the elements of Confucius' teachings, a good place to sit and meditate. The koi were beautiful, the rock formations spectacular, something new at every turn.

title: nice but crowded
content: the garden as such is very nice and an experience I can only recommend! Same goes for the area around it!

title: An Oasis in the City
content: We thoroughly enjoyed our visit to the Yu Gardens. They were truly an oasis in Shanghai. The way it's designed, there are many twists and turns that lead to quiet places where you can enjoy a moment to reflect and enjoy the location. We really forgot we were in the middle of an enormous city while we were there.

title: A beautiful garden
content: Well worth searching for in the middle of an overly commercialized zone of tourist shops. It is a glorious island of beauty and tranquility. Go early to avoid the crowds.

title: Nice place to walk around - bad experienced
content: Nice place to walk around ... Beautiful place and many shops.

title: Beautiful Garden!
content: This is a beautiful garden to see somemtraditional Chinese buildings and garden. The winding paths and little nooks and craneys make a relaxing visit. The value for money is very good. There are some uneven walk ways and a few steps that may make it more difficult for disabled people. This is well woth a visit.

title: Must see of old Shanghai
content: Five acres of Chinese gardens with Koi ponds, intricate roof tops , multiple bridges and tea house.

user_loc: 哥伦比亚特区华盛顿特区
title: Touristy but worth the visit!
content: Yes, yes..... everyone goes there. But it's nice! Apart from the annoying fake Rolex vendors, the buildings are nice. I go there every time I visit to but the cheap souvenirs to take back home. There's also some good stuff to buy. I don't recommend wasting your money on any "fake" items. Last year bought a copy of Beats by Dr. Dre headphones for my son. Lasted 1 month and could't get them fixed.

title: Dream Garden
content: So many tourists, because the place is really a must see in Shanghai! Know more about the garden with a guide, and you'll be amazed how and why was this built. There are also explanations in every section.

title: Beautiful!
content: Loved to see the old architecture and the structures that bring out Chinese culture. Very relaxed atmosphere - feels like you are transported back in time!

title: Very nice typical chinese gardens
content: We really enjoyed our excursions in the Yu Gardens. You are in a little haven in the middle of Shanghai city!! Really a must see!!!

title: Little piece of old China
content: Being in Shanghai, you deffinitely need to visit Yu Yuan Garden. It may be crowded and you have to pay the entrance fee, but this is a place where you can find most of the shights that are associated with China-buildings with its tipical roofs, ponds with goldfish, trees, flowers, bridges..You can also pay a visit to a nearby tea house where you can watch how to brew different types of green tea. Souvenirs are quite expensive here, but if you are lucky, you can get something unique and hand-made

title: It's a garden that you have to pay to get into, great..
content: There are a few perks to this park, but that being said.. it's definitely not worth the 50-60 rmb entry fee that you have to pay in order to enter.

title: Must-do area but only ok . . .
content: A visit to this area is a must in touring Shanghai; it seems to be on every tour itinerary. The old garden is no big deal compared to others in China. The made-to-look-old buildings around it is good for touristy kitsch and souvenirs. Try shopping in the shops in the lanes surrounding the outside area for more interesting buys. Avoid eating in any restaurant here: Queue for hours for horrible condescending patronizing service coupled with expensive and AWFUL food.

title: Beautfiul place!
content: A must visit for anyone who visits Shanghai. It's really nice to see ancient chinese monuments right in the heart of ultra-modern Shanghai.

title: Chinese classical garden
content: yu yuan garden is chinese classical garden. It is a quiet and elegant place surrounded by old trees. but lack of maintenance i think :(. Around the garden there are lots of shops.

title: Worth a visit if stopping near the bund
content: I didn't find to be quite as peaceful as I see in other reviews due to the quantity of people and tourists. Still is a beautiful place to walk around in an area right near the bund with classic architecture that is full of shops and restaurants. Directly facing the entrance towards the bund, don't miss the famous dumpling restaurant that you'll see a gigantic line of people waiting for take-out (line to get a table is inside upstairs and not that bad).

title: Old Shanghai down town
content: This area is totally different compared from modern band area. There are many shops and restanrants, and always full of people including Chinese people and foreigner people. The structure of those buiding show classic style or authentic style of Shanghai, especially their roof. In the night, there are light up those building, they looks more beautiful than day time. Also there are great dumpling places over there you can get snack.

title: Favorite gardens in China
content: I saw several gardens in China but this one was my favorite. There is a fee to enter. It is huge with lots of areas to explore so allow enough time. Every area was landscaped beautifully. The flowers were blooming which added to the beauty. The gardens appeared to be well kept. It was crowded but not oppressively crowded. I highly recommend the gardens.

title: Old city in Shanghai
content: It is a very nice place with some history and around you find the so called old city with lots of traditional shopping and great architectural buildings old Chinese style.

title: A must visit during your stay in shanghai
content: This is the evidence of ancient Shanghai governmental rulers.

title: All bark.
content: I guess that can be taken in one of two ways:

title: Peaceful
content: This is somewhere you can spend so much time. Outside is the hustle/bustle of modern China, inside is a peaceful retreat, with great history, beautiful rooms and pools.

title: The beauty of Yu Garden - Introduction
content: Yu Garden, located at No. 132, Anrenfang Street in the center of the Old City, is regarded as one of the most lavish and finest Chinese gardens. The garden was constructed in 1559 of Ming Dynasty as the private garden by Pan Yunduan who spent almost 20 years to build the garden to make his parents happy. The garden is separated into four sections including the western, eastern, central and the internal areas. Sansui Hall in the western section was built in 11760 and was originally used to entertain the guests. Later, it turned into ceremonial hall for the gentlemen and bookmen. Exquisite Jade Rock is the real treasure in Yu Garden and also one of the famous rocks along the Yangtze River. The rock is about 3.3 meters high and has 72 holes. The wonder of the rock lie in the smoke can float from all holes when you burn a joss stick below the rock.

title: Shanghai Hilite
content: Just got back from China and these gardens were one of the hilites of our visit to China (wonderful country and people) and Shanghai (ancient and very very modern). Peaceful and relaxing in spite of the crowds. Would love to experience it just by ouselves, just for a few hours.

title: a zen experience
content: A gorgeous garden with lovely water features. Try and go early and avoid the crowds. It is a great place to take a deep breath, relax and take a step back in history.

title: Perfect place for photography
content: Its really re-present the shanghai or even China itself. I really amaze how they can preserve the antics (maybe more than 200 years old). The entrance will charge you for RMB40.

title: Yu Gardens
content: These famous gardens show you how much the Chinese love and use their gardens they seem to appreciate weathered rocks. These are always featured. Water, bridges and plants are also obvious features. Well worththe visit. Can be very busy with tourists from China itself, especially during Golden week.

title: Traditional Chinese Garden
content: Yu Yuan Gardens is a beautiful Chinese garden with shopping right outside its gates. Definitely worth a visit if you haven't been to anything similar before. Chinese gardens are quite delicate and relaxing to wander around.

title: Beautiful
content: Don't miss it! Stone dragons, water features, carefully chosen and placed rocks and lovely pavilions.

title: Worth the visit but beware of the crowds
content: Beautiful historical gardens with so much to see. Wish I spent more time enjoying the scenery than waiting in line for dumplings and battling the crowded streets.

title: Worth a visit
content: Loved this place with the buildings and the little shops however we were there during a national holiday and it was so crowded it was unbelievable. This is where we found that the Chinese people think nothing of pushing you out of the way. Even though it was busy we felt very safe

user_loc: 路易斯安那州巴吞鲁日
title: Interesting
content: The gardens are beautiful and full of history! We learned so much about the culture and the old town area was a great experience as well.

title: Left me contented
content: While it is crowded, as so many attractions in China are, it was an impressive collection of buildings and gardens. You are able to relax, rest and contemplate, even in a crowded space. I also loved all the Chinese stores just around it. Lots of fun to bargain and shop.

title: So peaceful
content: For a busy city like Shanghai, this is a real refuge from the noise and bustle. You wouldn't think that you were in the middle of the City as the garden is so peaceful and calming. We loved the sense that we had travelled back in time - definitely a garden of Contentment. If you can find a quieter day, all the better. We've been there twice-the first time it was full of tour parties which took some of the atmosphere away, the second time it was raining, which meant less people.

title: Nice for a wander
content: Nice for a wander but without being part of a tour we weren't too sure what we were looking at. Also be aware of people peddling the 'tea house scam' outside.

title: Beautiful!
content: Amazing tranquility in the overcrowded city surrounding. Wonderful ornaments and symbolic details - the real mystery of Cina.

title: The core is nice, but the shopping outside is not...
content: Way too many people around not-interesting shops. But the inside 'real' yu garden is a really nice and quiet place that is worth a visit for sure. Just try to get there straight, maybe eat a few dumplings on the way, but don't go to the shops...

title: Beautiful!!
content: The day we spent there was very rainy. We where all wet... but the beautiful garden made us forget all about it. It was not easy to find the gardens, even though we had a tourist map. Luckily we met someone who spoke English..

title: An oasis in the middle of Shanghai
content: This small garden in the middle of the Old Town is an oasis in the middle of Shanghai. Once you've fought your way through shops, restaurants, food stalls and crowds of people, it's like breathing a sigh of relief. A lovely spot to wander around for half an hour and enjoy the calm!

title: If you want to bargain
content: Wonderful place to walk around and enjoy the gardens and some great places to eat. Make sure when shopping that you pay no more than 30% if their asking price. Start at about 20% and work upwards.

title: beautiful respite with "old town" right outside the gates
content: Wonderful garden with many pavillions and nooks and crannies to explore - every aspect different from the last. Excellent place to wander around at leisure, plenty of sitting spots to rest and contemplate the surrounding beauty.

user_loc: 哥伦比亚特区华盛顿特区
title: An oasis of peace in the center of Shanghai
content: We thoroughly enjoyed our visit of Yu Yuan garden. It is reached by walking through a recreated old Chinese buildings type of area, full of tourist shops and restaurants. But the garden itself, divided into several different sections, is an oasis of peace and makes for an enjoyable walk.

title: The Garden & Adjacent shopping complex
content: Yu Yuan is a garden within a shopping complex known as the bazaar, which also encompassed the City of God Temple.

title: oasis
content: Wow what a find. A bit tucked away just off the Bund, this has to be a must visit. A little tricky to find surrounded by the market and its own walls, you walk through the entrance and it is like another world, stepping back in time. a maze of ponds and coutyards with traditional buildings, inticate statues and the tucked away temple.

title: Nothing much to see
content: Old building with lot many rooms or Chambers with water bodies a place once owned by the city Governor..20 Yuan entry not worth..

title: A wonderful retreat in the city
content: This beautiful house and garden, originally built in the 1500' s as a retirement home for the owner's father, is a beautiful and peaceful retreat in the middle of busy Shanghai city. It is full of gorgeous and sometimes surprising scenes, and the use of water is blissful. Highly recommended !

title: All-year-long big attraction
content: You have to find some time (1 - 2,5 h) to get there and take your time for nice slow walk among all those nice rocks, water, trees and bushes. Take pictures and contemplate. This might be quite crowded place but anyways you will like it. Really fantastic place to be.

title: Pretty gardens
content: Very pretty gardens in the middle of the city. Great photo opportunities with the contrast of the old and new buildings in the back drop. Some fab little alley ways of market stalls and shops to wander through on way out of gardens

title: Not my style of garden
content: Being on a tour we were at the mercy of the local guide. We were in the garden for much too long and would like to have had the opportunity to see the surrounding area and the market.

title: Lots of people, shops and food on sticks
content: Enjoy the evening shopping atmosphere and ancient chinese architecture. This area is specially catered for the tourist. This is one place you should visit if you are in Shanghai.

title: Beautiful Place
content: You have to go to this place when you are in Shanghai. The Garden is beautiful and if you zone out all the tourists you can imagine a life within the gardens and what it must have been like. There is plenty to do before you enter the Garden as well. The experience is worth the price of admission and I suggest you slow down and notice every little detail once inside. Overall, it is a highly recommended place and I will definitely be returning there when in Shanghai.

title: A must attraction in Shanghai
content: I like urban areas, but Yu Yuan gardens are must if you visit Shanghai. The tickets to the gardens cost 40rmb and if you are a student you can get 50% off. The gardens has a very big chinese influance and although it has a lot of visitors you can still find a peaceful place to relax from the bustling city. Outside the gardens you'll find a lot of shops situated in a chinese-like buildings, I don't think it's a good place to do shopping, but feel free to check and advise.

title: Must go
content: This is a must if you are in Shanghai. Looking at building surroundings will bring us back in time hundred of years ago. Things are sold at a bargain price, you need to really bargain as prices could be 1/3 of starting price. Good place to get some souvenir back home.

title: The Best Garden
content: We were guided by my friend boss who hosted our visit.

title: lovely
content: this is different from other chinese garden I visited. very charming and relaxed. a lot of restaurants all around, and a very old tea house. just try not to go over the week end, it's packed and crowded with any kind of people, from tourists to tourinst-hunters!

title: Free guides at the main entry before 15:00
content: Nice garden. If you visit Shanghai, don't miss it.

title: Wonderful garden
content: We got it without excepting anything but we were so impressed with the scenarios inside. There are a lot of beautiful chinese-style buildings and gardens. I made more than 500 photos with the wonderful background inside this garden! The stuff sold inside this garden is however too over-priced, but they claimed that they are hand-made. You could get similar things outside in a lot cheaper prices

title: Tranquility in the midst of busy city
content: If you are interested in old and peacefull environment this is the place. We loved it but my teenage kids didn't say the samething. It is worth a visit. Becarefull with the touts

title: Great place to visit
content: Yu Yuan is such a great place to visit, it has rich history, Chinese style architectures and garden arts, ponds. It is a scenery and quiet place contrast to bustling shanghai shops, markets just outside of it walls.

title: Do not miss this.
content: You Yuan Garden is a wonderful compact trip to the past in a modern Shanghai. Avoid getting there during the weekend and if you realy like to enjoy the garden take your time. Just sitting for a while in a quiet corner, will probably give you a better idea about what this place is like than being hurried along by a guide that rather sees you shopping around the corner.

title: Yu the Man!!!
content: Yu Yuan garden is a definite must-go when in Shanghai. there are touts everywhere though and they're quite persistent. There are also all these pesky people shoving phamplets and flyers of god-knows-what into your hand. sometimes bordering on the intrusive, offensive and rude. Dont they even care that they're giving chinese flyers to foreigners?

title: Haven
content: It's extremely picturesque and is a haven in the middle of bustling Shanghai, faclities are good so are shops and restaurants.

title: Lively
content: though it is new, as almost everything in Shanghai, it is built in chinese style. It is a busy place, full of shops, and at the end a beautiful house and its gardens, it shows a traditional chinese vila. Good place to go, day and night

title: An Oasis in the middle of the biggest city in the world
content: Even when the surrounding shops are packed to gills, this garden offers a relaxing escape. Get "lost" on the paths as you wander in and out of gardens, koi ponds, over brides, and through small pagodas. Buy some fish food and just chill.

title: way too crowded
content: It is a beautiful garden / mansion. But I didn't know how to enjoy it with sooo many tourists bumping on each other and it was freaking hot in a summer afternoon. It would have been a lot more enjoyable if you visit this place on a weekday in the spring / fall.

title: Tranquil gardens, authentic China
content: Just a short walk from our hotel we entered busy tourism precinct, interesting to see the old architecture being redeveloped. The gardens were a haven within, and we really enjoyed the combination of buildings, lakes, plants and rocks, despite the rain.

title: Exceptional
content: This review is for the Yu Gardens proper … there is a very reasonable admission charge to this locale (unlike the surrounding shopping area which is free). The gardens are spectacular, and even though I visited on a very crowded Saturday, it is very relaxing to walk through these grounds and enjoy the sights.

title: A green jewel in the midst of a swirl of old China shopping district
content: Off Fan Bang street, tonnes of shoping and dining in this older area. The garden is zen like. Lots of carp, trees and limestone monoiliths.

title: Wonderful place to go early in the day
content: Wonderful place to go in Shanghai - but be sure to arrive very early, as it opens, in order to avoid crowds. And don't miss the Hu Xin Ting teahouse in the middle of the lake - an essential part of the experience.

title: Great Walk. Super-Crowded Neighborhood.
content: Go early. Otherwise you will have hordes of people in front of your lens and no clear picture or view of the magnificent gardens and beautiful buildings on them.

title: big garden with different parts
content: It's a nice place with different architecture and area. Nice to relax with lakes, fishes and spring to throw coins and make a wish.

title: A must see - although very busy and noisy
content: Very commercialised and busy so difficult to feel the tranquility and ambiance but one can't visit Shanghai without visiting. The garden is very small

title: The old Shanghai
content: Yu Yuan Garden was a surprised. We stayed far from The Bund and Pudong area. Our hotel was located in a new area and when our taxi stoped in Huangpu District in the middle of a crowded street I thought: now I am in China.

title: You feel that you are in China
content: The buildings , architecture , every shop and restaurent is traditional Chinese. With modern buildings in Shanghai otherwise you feel as if you are in Europe or America but here you get the real touch of China.

title: Nice place to go
content: Worth visiting Yu Garden, waiting for an hour for their famous NanXiang Xiao Long but is was just average and not worth the price.

title: So nice.
content: Peaceful. Serene. Watch as residents go about their day exercising, playing, reading, relaxing, walking, enjoying life.

title: A beautiful garden close to downtown Shanghai
content: This is a beautiful garden, and I have visited quite a few during my trips to China. Very accessible, i was staying at the Salvo hotel, very close to the Bund, and it took me a very pleasant 15 minute stroll to get there - and my sense of navigation isn't great! It is supposed to be where the willow tree patter originated from and it was just a delight to walk around and there were a number of seating areas that you could just sit down, rest and take in the views, I enjoyed the walk there and only had slight problems once i arrived at the main area just checking which path to take - but I had taken an enlarged map with me and found this helpful with all of my sightseeing in Shanghai.

title: More than a Tourist Attraction
content: Though it is a stop for tours, the Yu Yuan Garden is really worth the time and effort. It is quite extensive and you can easily spend a couple of hours there. Something of a maze, it's fun to explore and discover on your own, no map needed. Guides, of course, can give you a great deal of history and explanation but a guide is not essential. Outstanding photo ops at nearly every turn. The ponds, bridges, walkways, doorways and buildings are all intriguing, but the huge pieces of sandstone create unusual and delightful works of art. The circular doorway "promotes harmony," so my son had his whole family stand in the doorway for a photo op. He said they could use a good dose of harmony and hoped the door would help!

title: Beautiful Quiet in the midst of Old Town
content: Please visit this amazingly beautiful gardens ... leave the noisy but fun Old town and enter the quiet of this old gardens

title: Interesting and difficult to find
content: The garden is very difficult to find, and you have to pass through a million shops before you find it. Don't confuse this with the commercialised small temple you have to pay to see, which has a much clearer entrance. The garden is beautiful with many interesting traditional buildings and a beautiful outdoor theatre. Price 30 yuan for adult, 50% discount for students and children.

title: Way too commercialised and touristy
content: I really hated how commercialised and touristy the place was. The views werent as great as many other gardens out there, and at the same time, you're hoarded by masses of tourists invading the place. The shops there seemed to exist just to chew off an arm and a leg of general tourists. I'd definitely not miss this place.

title: Interesting Walk
content: Beautiful scenery, went early and the only people I bumped into were other tourists trying to beat the crowds (which showed up as I was leaving). Amazing views of historic architecture with the financial district's skyscrapers looming across the river. The gift shops are packed with the same generic souvenirs that you find at nearly every shop in town.

title: Lovely
content: Don't miss the streets around here before you visit the gardens as they are a wonderful experience and a great place for bargains!

title: Old meets new
content: This is a lovely part of Shanghai if you can avoid all the fake handbag sellers! There are plenty of shops here but be prepared to haggle - the vendors expect it! Plenty of places to eat here too - from traditional Chinese restaurants to Western favourites such as McDonalds and Starbucks. Definitely bring your camera if you come here as you will not want to miss an opportunity to capture some of the beautiful traditional chinese architecture. Visit during the day and at night if you can as they are both very different experiences.

title: Beautiful gardens
content: Very beautiful, tranquil gardens in the middle of Shanghai. Not so tranquil when it gets swarming with tourists though. Get there early to avoid the crowds.

title: An Oasis in the Madness
content: At the heart of a complex that is very Chineese in that it looks ancient but is actually only 20 years old sits this beautiful Garden.

title: Very Busy
content: The garden was very busy when we visited during the week in August 2012, so trying to get photos which don't have other visitors included is almost impossible. The famous tea house Huxin Ting is not inside the garden, so you can visit it without having to pay the entrance fee to the garden. The tea house is worth a visit - the tea price is a little high (about RMB50 per person), but this is for unlimited tea plus a few nibbles. When we were there they had a group of musicians performing on old Chinese instruments - this more than compensated for the expensive cup of tea and made for a very pleasant experience.

title: Local Chinese tourists crowded this place out
content: It was a charming historical experience but very popular. Situated in the busy eating and shopping area it was well worth the visit. We had tea in the central tea house and spent ages just chatting and people watching.

title: Beautiful gardens and very good tourist shopping next door
content: The gardens are well manicured and tranquil, and you can go with the crowds next door to shop for souvenirs.

title: Saw all Sans the Garden
content: Basically went for shopping. Found all kinds of touts ranging from those who give fake currencies in lieu of the change after the goods are purchased. The place is with all ancient type building and a good place to have shopping as well.

title: Cannot miss Yu Yuan Garden
content: They say there are 3 things that you cannot miss in Shanghai (Bund, Xintiandi & the Yu Yuang Garden). I like the Yu Yuan Garden because of the nice souveneirs that one can buy as gifts for friends and family - and the famous xia long bao restaurant (be sure to go on the 2nd floor) near the zig zag pond. one block away is the antique market (in fang bang road) and it is always good to go to the 3rd floor of the antique market one block away - it is very similar to the flea market in the western world. You need to go just for the xiao long bao or the shopping, there is also a temple inside for the "underworld" definitely worth seeing

title: beautiful garden
content: a vast beautiful garden!

title: A perfect place to spend a whole day !
content: The Yu Yuan garden was original built as a recluse for royalty to chill out and relax. Though, one cannot relax in their anymore, its a brilliant place to just walk around and explore. Brilliantly maintained by the local government, the garden has many interesting plants and architectural elements which relate to Chinese history.

title: a glorious garden
content: Such a beautiful garden. so relaxing with magical views wherever you look. Could have stayed there for hours.

title: This Garden has V good collection of trees & plants. The main attraction of the Jade stone.
content: This garden is a must see place in Shanghai. surrounded by best shopping place & old Chinese structures, The garden closes at 5 PM so make sure you enter the place before 4 PM.

title: Bit of a let down
content: I had heard of this garden and was looking forward to seeing it, but it was really small. My sister and I walked from one end to the other and thought we must of missed something, but once we walked around we knew that was it. not really worth the 45 minute walk it took us to get there.

title: Loved everything here!!!
content: The Yuyuan Gardens are amazing! It's an old look town, with really good priced souveniers in the perimeter of the main square. There are a TON of restaurants inside of the main area (everything from a Dairy Queen to Chinese food a la cafeteria style). They sell EVERYTHING inside... tea sets, stamps, jade, pearls, paintings, etc. Then you go into the garden itself. Usually there's not that many people inside, although you'd think it would be packed judging from the people outside. Inside of the gardens there are several shops and "exhibitions". DO NOT buy anything inside unless it's a painting or something you MUST have. Let's just say that although I pride myself on my shopping skills, it was my first stop in China and I bought chopsticks for 100 yuan (down from 170, what a deal....yeah right) which I then saw outside of the main perimeter for 8 yuans. Yes, 8 yuans.... please learn from my mistakes! Otherwise, enjoy this beautiful place, and make sure to look at the architecture above, lots of the stores are on the second or third floors as well.

title: Should be higher on the list of Attractions in Shanghai
content: This should be on anyones list when they visit Shanghai. Try and go during a weekday during the day to avoid crowds.

title: exciting and unique experience
content: I loved this place for its beautiful gardens. There are a lot fancy but inexpensive staff here. Pearls, silk bags etc. But you need to bargin. I picked up a few paintings and Chinese embroidery on silk and have framed them , simply awesome. Bargin really hard, if you are not sure whether you're ripped off, it is a good idea to consult the tour guide with you.It was exciting and unique and very beautiful. We had lunch at the tea house in the middle of the gardens. The food was outstanding.

title: Very good and you can feel China.
content:
Many restaurant and shops are there. And the buidings are so unique.
I can highly recommend you to go there.

title: Beautiful Garden
content: These gardens are beautiful, well kept and are lovely to wander round.  Lots of photo opportunities and interesting architecture.

title: Gardens of Serenity
content: The Yuan Gardens is where every tourist needs to visit to round off your trip, but be careful of vendors trying to pawn off 100 yuan notes that are actually Korean 100 notes. You can find food, tourist junk and serenity here.

title: Shanghai Oasis
content: Surprisingly nestled in Shanghai is a 4-acre (2 hectar) garden from the 15th century. This is nice on a warm day, offering shade and a maze of walkways and old chinese classic style buildings, plenty of small lakes. Surrounding the gardens are shops and eateries.

title: A beautiful traditional garden
content: This was a beautiful traditional garden to walk through in the middle of a market area bustling with activity. Feeding the koi was a highlight. There were so many of them.

title: excellent place to visit
content: after our visit to Beijing we came to Shanghai by train traveling 6 hours.the next day we been visit this brilliant garden,we went in many places and gardens but in my opinion that's the best i ever visit so real so nice as soon as you go inside you feel relax and nice.is brilliant for photos

title: A must visit
content: Definitely worth the time and money. The garden compound is surrounded by a larger compound of traditional oriental looking shops which are very impressive. The gardens themselves are very large and you can get lost between all the different halls, ponds and rock mazes. It's very tranquil and beautiful, and totally different then the modern city outside. It has ponds with fish and turtles you can feed and even ducks. All in all we had a great time and took some great photos.

title: To many tourist
content: It’s a nice little garden but when we were there it was packed with other tourist.

title: Ya Yuan Garden
content: take metro 10 to Yu Yuan Garden. Try to be there early in the day, since it is a major site also for chinese tourists. do not miss the lantern festival during chinese New Year. You need a special ticket to visit the garden itself, but it is absolutely worthwhile. Take something to drink during summer, because it is harly possible to get something inside the garden

title: Yu Garden - Great tourist attaraction
content: Not so much of garden but a great place to visit with large pond area and plenty of shopping for all tourist nics and nacs and eating snacks as well. Yuan Garden is very close to Old Shanghai Street which is great for very cheap shopping and not to be missed.

title: Nice, but skip-able
content: The gardens give a taste of traditional China and has some pretty views. But does it worth your time? Probably not...

title: Hardly a Garden of Contentment during lunchtime
content: Go here early, or don't go. It is PACKED with mostly Chinese tourists at midday. It isn't what I expected, although the architecture and planned garden is impressive. There are loads of trinket/snack shops in the first levels of all of the buildings, which is a real shame. It is a national treasure and should feel more like a museum than just another tacky theme park.

title: Nice Garden
content: A nice blend of the surrounding architecture and the garden design. Not so many floral arrangements but the blend with rocks water and the circulation is nice

title: Nice, but not spectacular
content: It's a nice garden. Is it worth the entry fee? I don't think so. The area around the garden is very interesting.

title: Yu Gardens
content: Well worth a visit. Didn't know what to expect but was pleasantly surprised. A quaint and interesting place.

title: Great 1/2 day trip
content: I was staying nearby so I walked to the Yu Garden. It was pretty hard to find, as first I ended up in a park and realized that wasnt it. I then walked deeper into the direction and found the building which were styled after the old Shanghai, and that ended up being the Bizarre Market. The Yu Garden, was deeply hidden inside the market area. It cost 30 RMB (about $5 USD) to tour it. It was EVERYTHING you see in the photos- Beautiful! It was very busy on the Saturday I went, which I heard it wasn't too busy during the week. I loved the Koi and architect buildings. It was also very neat I was touring a 500-700 year old garden. This is a Koi lover's dream. The market was also neat, but packed with people. It had modern places like Starbucks, Dairy Queen, etc also with many local shops. The locals love to approch you and ask if you want an IPAD or ROLEX. I guess those are popular knock offs there. It was fun at first, but got quiet annoying with the people pecking you wanting to sale something. If you have trouble with people doing that, or you have trouble saying "No" or just walking off, then this isnt the place you you.

title: A taste of old China
content: Weekend crowds are not very nice, but the old buildings are great and there is plenty of foods to try.

title: Must see in old city
content: Also in summer a must

title: Something different
content: Arrived on an extremely hot day so was nice to find lots of shaded areas, ponds with masses of fish and little temples. Very crowded in parts and almost like a maze as we discovered as we tried to find our way out! A must to do in Shanghai.

title: Great Attraction In Old Town were the locals and tourist go
content: This complex was really bustling with local chinese and tourists. The myriad of shops were adjacent to the Gardens that had the famous Tea House, beautiful architecture, gardens, sculptures throughout the complex. We had a great time wandering around the grounds and then around the shops on the perimeter of the complex. There's a fee to go into the Gardens but the perimeter and old town are a free for all.

title: Beautiful Place
content: I came in the afternoon, and find this is one of must see place in tehe town. Use Shanghai Metro and take a litlle walk after that to reach this place.

title: A Landscape Garden
content: The garden is just a few minutes walk from the Ibis Yuyuan Hotel. It is rather old and I was not really impressed. It is not a floral garden but one which has rocks and pools and has landscape design. Be forewarned if you need to use the toilet. Although it is clean, it cannot flush.

title: Worth a visit
content:
So many interesting things inside.  Lovely trees.   Rocks.   Design.
Overall. A. Bit. Small. Area.  For. Gardens

title: Visit the tea shop outside
content: A pretty garden with lots of twists and turns – i don’t think you could walk more than 10 metres without having to turn a corner! At times it felt we were walking in circles! Surprisingly clean bathrooms if you get caught short during your visit.

title: View of old China
content: Worth seeing if view it as a window into China of a century ago. Somewhat run down but you can still sense the grandeur. Multiple paths wind around a carp filled set of pools. Gift shop and museum on site. Not at all peaceful on weekends as this is a popular spot for in-country tourists. Outside the garden is a warren of small shops and food vendors. Very colorful and as worth strolling through as the Garden.

title: traditional chinese
content: a must-see place in shanghai. traditional Chinese buildings/garden. very crowded. a lot of stores

title: Interesting
content: Garden with lot of rockery and flowers, arches, bridges, ponds...beautiful! We enjoyed the market outside the garden and had delicious dumplings for lunch!

title: Many small paths in a confined area
content: How many different pathways can you design in a small and confined area? Thus was the garden of a high ranked administrator, and it is absolutely gorgeous. What is more, the little shops that surround this area make it even more attractive. It is my number one spot in Shanghai.

title: Great garden in Shanghai
content: What a surprise to find this oasis in the middle of the city! The park provides a good example of the park system in China and how parks are used: for Tai Chi, Dance, socializing, exercising, singing, etc. Make sure to find out hours of operation as we were shooed out by police at sunset and had to cut our visit short. Take the metro as it is conveniently located near public transportation.

title: Peacefully set in the heart of the city...I'd recommend a visit!
content: For me, the whole experience of getting to the garden contributed to my enjoyment of this attraction. It is set RIGHT in the heart of a VERY BUSY and hectic shopping area within Shanghai. So, when my guide was assisting me to traverse through the shopping area, I had NO IDEA that this BEAUTIFULLY tranquil garden would greet me once I passed through the gates. While there are certainly more beautiful gardens elsewhere in China, I think it's the setting of this one that makes it special. I'd certainly recommend visiting!

title: Peaceful and Quiet Attraction within the City
content: This garden is located within the city but once you enter into the garden all the car noise and vendor's voice seems to be blocked out as the garden emits a sense of peace and tranquilty

title: Ancient Garden
content: Pretty, but if you've seen gardens before this one is not especially big or exciting.

title: Lovely
content: In an area I named to myself "Chinese Chester", the Yu Gardens are simply magical!

title: Absolutely beautiful garden.
content: I would like to have visited this garden when it wasn't so crowded. It was meant as a tranquil spot to live and relax, and that is evident, though you have to share it with several thousand of your closest friends on the weekend. Architecture, trees, flowers, fish ponds, must have given many years of joy to its creator.

title: A sanctuary ina frenetic city
content: Miss out the touristy bazaar and get into the garden for peace, love and zen!!!!

title: Dunno y it's called garden!!!
content: This place has nothing from a garden except few trees here and there, and a filthy "river" in the middle! Other than that it is old architecture houses but used to open all kind of stores inside!!!

title: peaceful
content: you have to go and just sit, its so quiet for being in the middle of a  bustling shopping centre

title: An Island of tranquility in the city
content: Situated in the old part of Shanghai and in the middle of a shopping area, this is a typical chinese garden with interesting rock formations, bridges and water features.

title: Eat, shop, play ... all in one place
content: Yu Yuan garden is charming and has a pretty authentic feel to the place. I'm not referring to the tourists and shops of course. The buildings are beautiful to look at and the gardens themselves help evoke imageries of what it must have been like to walk through 300+ years earlier. I thought some of the tourist shops were a little more unique than those found elsewhere. Don't miss the steamed xiao lung baos (little dragon buns) at Nanxiang Steamed Bun Restaurant.

title: Yu Garden and Old Town
content: The old town area was awesome with its old looking chinese buildings and shops galore. The Yu Garden was impressive for its location and fish ponds. Makes a wonderful afternoon stroll with lots to see and do.

title: Very lovely, but crowded.
content: Despite blazing heat and arriving early in the day, it was crowded. It also is not hundreds of years old -- it was redone relatively recently. But worth seeing if you aren't getting outside of Shanghai. Look for the "tea school" and "silk museum" for some interesting explanation about those topics and the freshest tea I ever had.

title: Must see
content: Beautiful and delightful place. A must do and see in shanghai. Well worth a visit.

title: Autumn foliage is quite nice
content: In autumn, inside the Garden where you pay a fee to enter, there are nice photo opps. Also when you need solitude from the hordes at Yu Yuan, entering the rock garden and sitting down admiring the many rocks might give you some relief.

title: Packed with tourists
content: It's a very popular tourist spot and at time, I literally couldn't see the trees for the tourists!

title: Lovely
content: Well worth a visit, lots to see, the markets are very good, you must barter hard at the markets, it is expected. There are lots of very nice places to eat.

title: Shopping heaven
content:
Basically you can find almost everything here, from Cheongsam to helicopters, fridge magnets, etc. 

love it!

title: Busy busy venue , very touristy Chinese " garden "
content: If ou are a first time visitor to Shanghai, then you must make a visit there. Very busy and manic enviroment . Went to a Chinese restaurant that served very traditional hand made shanghainise dumplings, delicious !

title: beautiful
content: It's a beautiful place to visit but too many people and touristy

title: Different & Interesting
content: Not a western idea of a garden - rocks, corridors, water - but peaceful (depending on the number of tourists) and interesting. We really liked it. Outside are the markets - which are the usual bedlam of snacks & souvenirs & hawkers - not relaxing but always fun & unavoidable in China. As everywhere, if you want peace & quiet, don't come to China, especially a city - many of which have at least half the population of Australia.

title: Chinese style garden
content: The you garden is right in the middle of shanghai. It's a garden which was designed in the olden days. It's very pleasing Chinese style garden - lots of rock formations, koi pond. Lots of Chinese trinkets shops around the garden. Best place to pick up souvenirs for back home.

title: Interesting and beautiful
content: They had a bridge that is good luck to walk over called "9 Turn Bridge" It must have been good luck. I didn't see anyone fall in the water. The grounds were beautiful and the 500 year old buildings were very interesting. Also there was a market attached to the guardens that was fun to shop in.

title: Pretty and interesting but kitschy
content: It was a beautiful place, but it felt a bit kitschy and full of trinket shops and the usual "rolex, bag bag" hawkers. Try the nanxiang steamed bun restaurant

title: I expected more from a Historical landmark
content: Maybe I was expecting more from a Qing-dynasty historical garden, but I was hoping to see some fine chinese architecture and learn some history. As it turns out, this was a highly-commercialised tourist hotspot (imagine a Haagen Daz signboard on an ancient chinese building). For photography purists this would not really be ideal.

title: Interesting, touristy
content: What might have been a usual nobleman's garden from a bygone era has been preserved and packaged for the modern-day tourist. Interesting to observe the architecture and landscaping.... don't look for peaceful beauty, as it is overrun by noisy tourists!

title: Hard to Like
content: I surprised myself because I love gadens but I found this place hard to enjoy. It is certainly historic, and is said to be the best example of this type of garden. But I found it confusing (possibly thats deliberate), and so alien to my idea of a garden that it was not easy to apprecaite.

title: Chinese Chotzkes a plenty
content: Spend a few hours here. The best way is to hop on the City Tour for 30 RMB and you can hop back on when you are done-then head off to another Shanghai attraction.

title: Cute Garden, Best Shopping for Souvenir
content: The garden was pretty and tranquil. Walking could be a challenge for those with difficulty walking due to unevent surface. Love to shop and bargain in little shops/kiosks surrounding the garden.

title: Peaceful
content: We went here first thing in the morning with a private guide and it was so tranquil--every turn you make before you is a picture postcard scene. A lovely contrast with the crowded and bustling area outside.

title: pleasant place
content: Very nice place, but too many visitors! Nice small lakes and very interesting old things.

title: Touristic and not that old...
content: This place is only to attract tourists and does not represent Shanghai at all...

title: Another Tourist Trap
content: An entrance fee into the Garden at least keeps the volume of people low compared to the many hundreds of people caught in the touristy shops that surround these gardens.

title: Well maintained historical garden but....
content: I think the entrance fee was over priced. There are tour groups and every where and it's not possible to get a good picture without someone getting in the way. Interesting to visit once just for its namesake.

title: Garden of People
content: We took the subway here from people''s square on a Saturday morning, It was about a 550m walk from the Yu Garden station, on a street lined with shops selling souvenirs mostly.

title: Peaceful oasis
content: The garden itself is a welcome respite for tired tourists - often, you can find quiet spots away from the hustle and bustle of the surrounding area around the zigzag bridge and its tea house

title: This really is a shopper's paradise
content: The garden is worth a visit but the main reason to go here is the shopping; also the architecture. This looks how you would imagine old China and there is plenty of atmosphere - a Chinese eqivalent of a souk. The shops and bargains are endless but you must be prepared to barter. You will be offered endless opportunites for fake bags, purses, etc. You really need to know what you're doing if buying, e.g., pearls, jade. I would recommend this for buying things that don't cost much and not for any major or special purchase - go to a reputable shop for those. The Silk Market is well worth going to - the silk quilts are a particularly good buy if you have room in your suitcase or hand luggage. Also take a look at the folk hand painting pictures - incredible. We bought two. They need reframing but were so cheap that doesn't matter - they look great at home. Well worth a visit - we went twice!

title: A Shopper's Paradise
content: It is so BIGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGG!!! We could never see it all. So much fun. The long line of people wanting to buy the famous "steamed dumplings" was unreal.

title: A must
content: Not only because of the garden and the construction which are really impressive but the whole surroundings are a experience you should try.

title: Fabulous Garden
content: The garden is located in the middle of the famous old Shanghai city. The classic architecture of the buildings surrounding the gardens speaks volumes about the imperial oppulance of oriental old China and Shanghai. A place not to be missed by anyone who visit Shanghai. Superb location for your travel photographs. Ther are many palces aound for snacks and drinks in the old city but not within the gardens.

title: This is a winner
content: Well worth any time you can spare to see this wonderful place.

title: Pleasant
content: A travel agent,took us on a day tour.She had a very good knolledge of the history of the garden.I will recommend that you visit the garden with a tour guide.You will miss a lot of what everything meens if you just go by yourself.

title: Just Breathtaking A Must Visit
content: Small but every single plant planted for a reason, creating the harmony a joy to walk around with breath taking views just a sheer joy to be there. We went early in the morning before the crowds and saw the fence of the dragon without anyone else around so our photographs were not full of lots of other tourists.

title: Nice relaxing park in the centre of Shanghai.
content: Not very large, so don,t anticipate spending the day here. We spent an hour here, and sat and watched the locals go about their daily routines.

title: good value and take your time
content: a lovely centrally located spot simple yet elegant

title: Interesting Garden
content: Worth having a look at for sure and a nice break from the Chaoz of the bazar

title: Wonderful and Well Worth a Visit
content: At 40 Yuan (just over $6 U.S.) a visit to Yu Yuan is well worth it. Architecture and landscaping dating back to the Ming Dynasty (1577). The pavillions, fish ponds, rockeries waterfalls, and the great halls were all magnificent.

title: Very good, very busy
content: OK, busy here!

title: See an authentic Chinese Garden
content: Suzhou has many old traditional Chinese gardens. But this one in Shanghai is worth to visit as well especially if one is not planning to visit Suzhou. And while visiting the Yu Yuan garden, enjoy some tea and traditional snacks in the teahouse in the middle of the pond.

title: Crowded, but nice garden
content: Before going to Shanghai, this was a must see on list. Unfortunatly it seems it was on everyone elses list also. Very crouded but you can shop some souveniers if you don't mind a crowd. The famous bridge was so crouded you could bearly take pictures. The garden had a entrence fee of 40CNY, but was the highlight of the visit, with less people and more relaxed atmosphere.

title: Beautiful
content: The gardens were a stop on our tour and I must say it was worth seeing. It was raining the entire time we were there and crowded. It would have been much more enjoyable on a clear day with less people, but it was still beautiful and interesting. There was a huge marketplace with plenty of shops, restaurents and a Tea House

title: Great Place, give your self ample time
content: The garden went on, and on, and on. But in a good way. There are so many different passage ways. I can't imagine the man who built this garden for his parents. This garden was quite immense, and went on passage way after passage. Its like you are in a serene maze. I only gave myself an hour to tour the garden. However, I could have easily spent 2 hours if I took my time, and sat at some of the locations.

title: The best example of Chines gardens
content: That garden represents the lifestile of the rich chinese families. It is planned so, that after every corner you find a new point of view on an artificial landscape, with wonderfull shapes of rocks, plants, pavilions and if you look at the roofs, strange mystical creatures statues. The garden located in the center of the renewed chinatown that functions as a big bazar. a realy must in Shanghai.

title: Excellent Garden
content: We were truly fascinated with the preservation and maintenance of the gardens.

title: Beautiful but crowded
content: The gardens are entered by passing through an area that looks as if it could be 200 years old but was in fact only built 30 years ago. There are masses of souvenir shops, street vendors and street performers. The gardens are really beautiful but even in April, the low season, there were an awful lot of visitors. Just to see the Koi made the visit worthwhile. The gardens are best appreciated if you have a guide, there aren't many information notices.

title: Beautiful
content: Stopped off here as part of the Big Bus Tour hop on hop off and it is definitely worth seeing. The area around the gardens is also very cool with lots of chinese style buildings and arts and crafts. The gardens themselves are huge. Its like a little maze but very nice and unique and I would highly recommend visiting them.

title: A Classic Classical, Chinese Garden
content: Very crowded, so not very serene

title: interesting experience
content: Very nice mix of tradition and modern.

title: very nice garden in the old town
content: take a guided tour thru the garden cause without explanation its just a nice garden

title: A Must
content: This is another of the many places that are in the "Must" catagory. Take time to go early as later in the day it becomes very busy.

title: Up charge to the max
content: The way they put the price is pretty scary. It not only double or triple bu it's multiple. Really need to bargain to at leat quarter frm the offered price.

title: Yu Yuan Gardens is so exciting.
content: i always go here to get my silk items for gifts. The dumplings here are famous. Low end to high end pearls. Do not go to Shanghai and not visit this place. The gardens are beautiful.

title: Lovely gardens
content: Beautiful space.  Best to go on a weekday as it gets very very crowded with local tourists on the weekends

title: A quiet haven in the middle of a madhouse...
content: This place is a maze- even though it's not huge, you can easily get lost within its walls. It IS a very welcomed break from the surrounding craziness. If you're tired of brushing up against people, getting cut off and cut in front of- shoved around and coughed on... I suggest hopping in for your peace of mind. The garden is beautiful- and offers plenty of shade on hot sunny days.

title: excellent example of classical chinese garden
content: Lovely garden with all the elements that constitute a classic garden, like bridges, ponds, pavillions, covered corridors, rockeries and even a theatre. Hard to believe that such beauty can be hidden in the centre of the city. Centrally located. Crowded on weekends and public holidays.

title: Happy to walk around the beautiful ancient garden in Shanghai old town
content: We were in Shanghai last weekend, it was an unexpected freezing weather in almost summer - because it was raining and windy. Still there was so many people at the garden, lots of foreigners too.

title: Not a must see if you dont have time.
content: The garden is big, releatively clean but I was not lucky because I went on a Saturday which was a weekend, very crowded to the extent that you cant enjoy from the crowds. Even the surronding area was croweded. But its worth going if you are in Shangahi and have the time to see it.

title: Not safe neighborhood.
content: this garden is so amazing with a lovely story. old city is so beautiful but watch out your bag and money.

title: Busy, busy, busy.
content: Not for the shy but many shops to enjoy and take time to relax in the old Tea house as we'll as going in to the gardens themself.

title: Beautiful patch of old China
content: Take a stroll through these lovely gardens when you need a break from the modern city.

title: Serenity in Madness
content: What a beautiful place - RIGHT in the middle of the market, noise and madness.... Once you enter the Yu Garden, it changes! Yes, there may be many visitors, but the serenity, the beauty and the architecture are marvellous.

title: Nice surrounding to shop for your souvenirs and to try out the famous dumplings
content: Berepared the the shops are very touristic and the famous dumpling shops have long waiting list. Watch out for pickpocket too.

title: Stunning
content: Get the feel of the old town while getting lost at YuYuan Garden. Shop for some souvenirs, eat some local food, take snap shots of the beautiful buildings but do avoid on the weekend and public holidays then the beautiful surroundings are clouded by a sea of bobbing dark heads.

title: Shanghai must see on tourist trail
content: The garden itself was fairly quiet on Saturday lunch time (you have to pay a small fee to get in) but the streets around it were heaving with people which spolied the experience a little.

title: Beautiful Gardens so well layed out with many many buildings
content: Walking by the Tea House and all the big orange fish in the pond was quite a sight to see. The ever winding gardens were lovely,

title: A very touristy place
content: Beautiful layout and could be a peaceful oasis, ruined by too many isitors and guides with portable loudspeakers

title: A lovely respite in a private garden restored and open for visiting
content: Right outside, the neighborhood is filled with shops and people but inside the garden there is peace and calm.

title: A Lovely Oasis
content: This is a beautifully landscaped park adjacent to a shopping area (that is pretty much designed for tourists). The park is historic and a great example of Chinese landscape design. It makes for a pretty half hour walk in between busy commercial Shanghai stops along the way.

title: Wonderful
content: My favourite attraction in Shanghai. The gardens are delightful and shops inside sell quality historical Chinese items. The teahouse and markets were great, I loved the place.

title: We loved this garden
content: It was very intimate and pretty and we enjoyed taking photographs here.

title: Better than other gardens in the area
content: Liked this garden more than the ones we saw on the day tour.

title: Wow what a great garden
content: This garden is a series of gardens within gardens and took some 18 years to build. There are water features and amazing shaped rocks, all natural but not local, which blend in so well and allow a peace full walking place in which to get lost.

title: Could be preserved.
content: Looks green and good but not worth the walk... Not preserved as it should have been done...or maybe ive seen better places than this thus did not like the visit.

title: Pricy little place
content: Yu Yuan Garden has beautiful architecture that gives you an age-old feel of China...however, since it has a lot of shopping places in it, haggling is a must...also you can get better deals outside of the garden.

title: must see
content: a large area with lots of shopping and in the middle is the garden. you have to pay to enter. really cool. plenty of temples

title: A must-see attraction in Shanghai
content: Yu Yuan Garden has beautiful temples, Chinese gardens and lots of stalls that offer local street foods and souvenirs (learn to haggle for the souvenirs could be pricey). Language could be problem though. Overall this is a must see attraction in Shanghai, it is easily accessible through MTR, just follow the signs.

title: tradition....of China....you must see and do a bit of shopping around Yu Garden
content: compact and exquisite, and the rocks, pavilions, ornamental ponds and flower walls offer some of the most attractive sceneries in Yuyuan Garden

title: The history preserved in the middle of the Mega City
content: Its an excellent garden. A must see for everyone. The Lantern Festival during the Spring Festival Holiday is worth Seeing. Good place to buy Chinese Souvenirs

title: A glimpse of the past
content: If you enjoy a stroll or walking, you can walk to Yu Yuan from The Bund (that's what we did).

title: Should have been a nice place for relaxation if not for the crowd.
content: This garden was just a stone's throw away from our hotel and we visited it in the morning as soon as it opened, hoping to enjoy the place and its tranquility. We were wrong. About five minutes inside the garden, a throng of tourists from a cruise ship suddenly appeared and ruined our visit. Every nook and corner of the garden was full and we couldn't enjoy a quiet moment or even the views of the garden. The garden itself has beautiful rock formations and some exhibits but the flowers were not as colorful as in some other areas in Shanghai. I can imagine that this is a great palce to just enjoy the peace and quiet but it is impossible to do that with hundreds of noisy tourists around.

title: In a compact area it is a great place
content: There are Chinese gardens that are more spectacular. The Humble Aministrator's garden in Souzhou comes to mind. But this garden is so compact and despite heavy tourist traffic remains peaceful and beautiful and serene.

user_loc: 哥伦比亚特区华盛顿特区
title: All the tea in China
content: Yuyuan Gardens looks like the setting for a martial arts period piece set in dynastic China - a warren of large pagoda-style buildings surrounding a few courtyards and the actual Yu Gardens. The stores within the area and along the road that runs through it are fascinating, and you'll find alot of stores that sell Chinese candy, curios and tea. Lots of it. Definitely worth visiting.

title: Worth a visit, but if you have time Suzhou has better examples
content: A good example of a traditional Chinese "rock and water based" garden, not nearly as tranquil or Zen like as the gardens in Japan ( and in Shanghai the pressing throngs mean it's unlikely you'll ever find it tranquil), if you have time to travel further afield then seek out examples out of town, if not then it's worth experiencing the Chinese view of "Landscape Gardening"!

title: The China of my childhood fantasies
content: Crowded and touristy, but this place represents what I thought China would be like. The garden is lovely (although not on par with Hongzhou or Suzhou), the shops are colorful (although absurdly over-priced), the 14 turn bridge is iconic, and the whole place feels a bit like Epcot. Never-the-less, I find myself going back frequently.The lanters, the colors, the smell of incense from the temple, the street food, the crowds...somehow it all works for me

title: Beautiful
content: Beautiful place to visit, Chinese gardens, trees, peaceful place. Worth a visit!

title: 400 year old Gingko tree.
content: Few tourists here. Beautiful gardens and interesting architecture of the the building within the garden. Neat and clean. Worth visiting.

title: A must see for garden junkies!
content: The garden manages to convey serenity despite the crowds. No mean achievement in a city of 22 million people.

title: Pretty tranquil garden in the old city
content: This is a beautifully landscaped city garden with views that delight and surprise as you turn each corner. It is in traditional style with some interesting history and preserved buildings. Don't expect to see mixed floral displays. Instead there are rockeries, ponds, pavilions and interesting sculptures.The five acre garden is believed to be over 400 years old but has had much damage over the years which has since been restored. There are opportunities to view or purchase various crafted items eg Chinese paintings, jade ornaments etc if you wish. It can be quite busy as most tour groups visit here. We walked from the Bund but it can be reached via subway- Yuyuan Garden station, Line 10. It was a pleasant and inexpensive break from city traffic and 'Rolex' watch sellers :-)

user_loc: 加利福尼亚洛思阿图斯
title: Quiet, contemplative oasis in heart of "old" Shanghai
content: The Yu Yuan Garden is a wonderful place to spend a pensive 1-2 hours collecting your thoughts, and imagining simpler life of a Chinese aristocrat 100+ years ago. Get there early in the day, when it's neither hot nor crowded. After your visit, there are 100s of shops in the faux old style architecural buildings just outside it's walls to shop to your heart's content. This is the place to bargain, and bargain hard!

title: Filled with domestic and local tourists...
content: Too crowded, I went in and came out shortly... I preferred the shops that are along the roads (nearby at Shanghai Old Street), rather than those inside the oriental-looking Yuyuan building. I didn't see the tranquil garden part but I guess it's deep inside the oriental building.. but there were too many people and shops were selling almost the same stuff so I didn't venture in deeper. But there are many food outlets, shops selling all kinds of souvenirs, and even a Starbucks here.

title: Yu Gardens
content: A must see. The old part of Shanghai with narrow alleys and which lead to the park. A peacful oasis in the midst of the hustle and bustle.

title: Peaceful gardens
content: The garden is beautifully laid out, well worth a visit.

title: Calming
content: Even with lots of visitors, this refuge in the middle of a city of millions is relaxing and beautiful. Walking from the shoulder to shoulder crowd of shoppers just outside the garden to inside the gate is extreme...and very lovely. Flowers blooming in April... Absolutely would go back!

title: Wonderful oasis.
content: This is a must. It is a beautiful garden in the old town.

title: Just OK
content: Very touristy. Huge crowds and many junky shops. If you go, do pay the fee to get into the gardens, if nothing more than to get away from the crowds a bit. I did have the wonderful steamed buns for lunch and then couldn't wait to get out of the area.

title: It's a pretty getaway, but it looks like all the other gardens
content: This says it all. I've been to so many gardens and they all look the same. Just go to see it for yourself if you've never seen a Chinese garden before. Once you see it, you're pretty much good for the rest of the gardens in China. It's a shame but I'm being honest. Sometimes it's better to go to the gardens with specific attributes (like a garden that specializes in Cherry Blossoms) and go when they're in bloom.

title: Wonderful Spring Break
content: I love the history behind the Garden - No dislikes

title: if your in Shanghai you have to see
content: Its just one of those places that you will go to in shanghai, much the same as most tourist places, full of shops with over priced rubbish but some good cafes not to pricy

title: Beautiful
content: Great place to walk and view and take pictures (but only of the scenary). This is where many parents go and meet eachother to set up their single children and they do not let you take pictures of this.

title: Place of peace in the midst of bustle...
content: Serenity in an ancient Chinese garden and villa complex, off the beaten path...offering peace, beauty, and a harking back to simpler times...

title: Gives you an idea of what your garden could look like
content: i loved walking around and seeing what they did with this garden. I now have a plan for what I am going to do in the future with my back yard.

title: insane but worth a visit
content: The gardens are charming - a maze of rocks and ponds and pavilions - but if you go on a weekend you won't be able to take a picture without someone getting in the way. And the surrounding area is just one huge tourist trap. Go really early in the morning, on a weekday if possible.

title: cosy garden
content: We liked this nice cosy garden with few houses, arts, lot trees. Wish to stay longer or even to live... Better to go in the summer or autumn all flowers would be nicer.

title: A World Heritage Garden
content: As an example of Chinese Culture and garden design its an interesting way to spend two hours. You need a guide or guide book else its just a gathering of buildings and lakes. Outside is where all the action is - in te hmarkets. Check out the old style Chinese peep show. Dont use credit cardsfor urchases here. - some place skim them. The Dumplings are however, to die for.

title: Fun for tourist
content: Very busy place, even during morning time in weekdays. Around the garden there are lots of shops. Don't forget to bargain like crazy. Places inside the shops and those on the street sides often offer the same price. So don't be shy to bargain hard even inside the shops. They'll ask for 85rmb for instance, but it'll end up to only 10rmb.

title: Beautiful garden - a must for anyone visiting Shanghai
content: Go in the morning on a week day when it is much quieter. Allow 1-2 hours to really explore as it has hidden gems if you find them. The surrounding market stalls in the old town are lots of fun too.

title: Very crowded but quiet corners can be found
content: Amidst a crowded shopping area sits the beautiful Yu Yuan Garden...once you have negotiated the busy shopping area and the crowded zig zag bridge you can find some tranquil corners to relax and enjoy these beautiful formal gargens...just explore every nook and cranny and you will have a thoroughly enjoyable and relaxing time here

title: Peaceful place in the city
content: If you want a short break from the city hustle you can take 1-2 hours in these beautiful garden.

title: Gorgeous Chinese Garden, avoid weekends
content: The gardens sit within a busy complex of touristy shops and eateries, there is a small fee to enter but it's a good things as it keeps the hoards of people in the tourist area outside.

title: Big and crowded (not difficult to get around with a kid in a stroller)
content: The garden complex buildings are great to view, if not for the fact that there seem to be a million people around you. Then there's the hundreds of shops and restaurants that also assault your every other (remaining) senses. I suppose, given the lack of historical areas to visit in Shanghai, you should not miss this. And, there's actually some good bargains to be picked up for tea and other souvenirs. Also the famous Nanxing steamed bun restaurant, where the "Outer Sell" (takeaway) line is super long - but where you can go up to the 3rd floor and get a table fairly quickly - it's worth a pit stop for the food. All in all, it's not difficult to navigate with a kid in a stroller, so don't let the crowds put you off.

title: Beautiful garden
content: Great history and a beautiful garden to see in Shanghai.

title: Beautiful, autentic China
content: Great, but dont go there in the weekends, public holidays. Too crowded. Beautiful view

title: Gardens are beautiful, shopping even better
content: Very pretty quaint gardens. The best part to this area is the shopping. I have never seen anything like this in all of China. greqat deals but crowded.

title: Beautifull gardens
content: Huge gardens with koi ponds. Very peacefull, lots of visitors but very relaxing

title: INCREDIBLE
content: This was absolutely the highlight of my trip to Shanghai. It is the most beautiful garden in the heart of the city. It was previously a private garden (which still blows my mind) and was donated to the government. If I had the time, I would have even gone back for a second visit. In my opinion, it should not be missed.

title: lovely Chinese garden
content: Great place to get some nice photos. Nice to see locals chilling out in there also. it covers quite a large area and there are secret walkways to find so take your time. Nice collection of Koi Carp. It wasnt overly busy on the weekday we went

title: A must seen in Shanghai
content: Was there a couple of times, its surely one of the must seen place in Shanghai, a beautifull garden just in the middle of the old town. Bridges, pathways, typical buildings. Expect a lot of people during sunday and saturday, go there early. When you finish the visit you could dive into the old town for some shopping. That's surely an experience.

title: Garden with pounds.
content: Nice to get a fell of the old Shanghai. Around you can find nice little shops.

title: Nice place
content: Yu Yuan Garden is a nice place to be next to the hectic shopping area. We went at a Sunday but is wasn't very crowded. Myabe better to go during weekdays.

title: Worth the visit - wish I had more time
content: Some wonderful shops and restaurants to occupy a good half a day. Certainly worth seeing and a pleasant area. Do keep your wallet close and don't get too annoyed with the many watch salesmen.

title: Heavan in Shanghai
content: If i ever moved from Australia i would like to buy Yu Garden, a home from the Quinn and Ming dynasty with an impossible amount of history to try and cover here - if you travel to Shanghai ensure you come here!

title: Crowded but lovely garden and story of a sons love for his parents
content: Really enjoyed the garden, although very crowded on a Saturday in March. Glad we had a guide who could tell the story of Mr pan and his parents

title: best visited in spring
content: the garden itself is huge.theres also lotsa stuff outside the garden itself.the famous tea house,dim sum restaurant and shopping bazaar are all within a huge area built up like old historical buildings

title: Surprisingly nice gardens
content: After paying the nominal entrance fees (which does keep alot of the locals out), this garden is presented in a well maintained and clean environment.

title: Find Peace among the crowds
content: Incredibly overrun with tourists though it is, the grounds are extensive enough that you can still find peaceful, private courtyards of real beauty.

title: A MUST-See when visiting Shanghai
content: A visit to Shanghai is not complete without a visit to Yu Yuan Garden. Go there early morning, preferably right after the opening, which means it is less crowded. Stroll around and enjoy the scenery. Look back too, as the view does change.

title: Small but okay
content: It was just okay. The only blooming plants were a few potted plants- ginko bilobas. I wouldn't have spent time there had I known before hand what to expect.

title: Amazing ancient garden but beware of the scamers at Yuyuan Garden train station!
content: The Yu Garden is well worth the 30RMB ($5) entrance fee as it’s amazingly beautiful! But it is very crowed and best to go late in the afternoon.

title: Another heritage site !
content: Nice to visit and feel the traditional and imperial times of China. Well maintain, clean and calm.

title: A must see
content: A must see. Very nice gardens with centuries old architecture. Close neighbourhood is full of small shops (e.g. we did buy some tea there) and eateries.

title: Be Early
content: Another great place to visit but I recommend you go early as it's gets very busy. It also backs on to the 'Old Shanghai' so you don't have far to walk if you want to want to walk across the Zig Zag bridge for luck or visit a Tea house. This place closed early too so don't leave it till the last part of the day to do. The 1st time I went I did the Pearl Tower then ventured there.....bad move as it was closed. Most things in Shanghai are open very late, so make this a 1st thing for the day trip!

title: nice
content: Yu Yuan it's really crowded outside, but inside is ok. Don't waste your time outside.

title: Do not miss this pleasant little corner in Shanghai
content: You have to go SOMEWHERE in Shanghai to shop for trinkets, so choose the Yuyuan bazaar. Way in the back is the entrance to this historic site, well worth finding. For about $5 US, you can find a comfortable place to sit and sort through the loot, watch people, and learn what a Chinese garden is. Don't expect big expanses of green, even in 1500 space was valuable, and don't expect quiet anywhere in Shanghai. But who knew koi could top 50 lb! Bring a few crackers. There are shops in many of the historic buildings that have the highest quality art and craft pieces I have seen for sale anywhere in China. If you have $50,000 to spend on an amazing jade dragon or an 8 layer puzzle ball, shop here. If not, enjoy the show.

title: Scenic garden!
content: Visited Shanghai in March, so the garden was still not very colourful. But even though this, it was a great walk through the various sections of the beautiful garden.

title: Lantern festival madness
content: Probably the most touristy part of Shanghai but after many visits we never tire of the area. Visited during the Chinese New Year just before the lantern festival. Beautiful and fun dragon theme but mentally busy thousands of people pushing and shoving their way around the water features. A visit to the huge canteen style restaurants is a must, 100's of dishes individually cooked by dozens of chefs, 1000+ covers but try and get a table at lunchtime - madness.

title: Nice spot, but unnecessary if you've been elsewhere in China
content: It is in and of itself quite a lovely little haven away from the modern city which surrounds it.

title: Terrific experience
content: had a great tour and enjoyed my time here. A little cold when we visited in February, would like to come back when in more vibrant color

title: Hufe crowds
content: The garden itself was not too crowded. Maybe one has to pay to go in so not many tourist did even though it wasn't expensive. Gardens were ok..nothing spectacular. Lotsa shops and eateries outside the gardens

title: A Classic but Compact Chinese Garden
content: While not as large as many Chinese Gardens such as the Humble Administrator's, the Yu Yuan Garden packs a great deal into a beautiful corner of Shanghai. Surrounded by a large shopping area of vendors, shops, street food, and craftsmen, the garden is a tightly wound maze of ancient limestone formations, ponds, fauna, fountains, and exhibition halls and buildings in classic Chinese architecture. A minor complaint is the lack of significant English language to explain the history and identity of the site and sights. Read about the gardens before you visit. Take the time to visit the temple within as well as the shopping mecca that surrounds the entrance and the exit of the gardens. Prepare for crowds and tour groups but with patience you can pace yourself to find the calm corners and quiet paths.

title: Yu Yuan Garden
content: Yu Yuan Gardens were first constructed in 1559 and became a national monument in 1980. The gardens house a number of pavillions, ponds and streams, bridges, sculptures and plantings. The large limestone in the garden is a national treasure. There are no english explaination signs so reading about the attractions or hiring a quide would add to your enjoyment.
